column2: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff announced today that he would hold hearings involving Cabinet members, mayors, sociologists and other experts on slum problems in order to take a fresh look at what he called the crisis in American cities."
GREENSBORO, N.C., Aug. 1 (AP) The Atlantic Coast Conference Executive Committee ruled today that the University of South Carolina had to forfeit all its conference football victories of last season.
Dr. Joseph O. Loretan, deputy superintendent in charge of curriculum and instruction for the New York City public school system, died Sunday in Venice, Italy, while on vacation. He was 63 years old.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy and Reform Democrats appeared squeezed out last night when Manhattan and Bronx regulars got together behind four candidates for Supreme Court justice at the First District judicial nominating convention.
CHICAGO, Aug. 1 Under heavy guard, Richard Speck pleaded not guilty today to eight indictments charging him with the murder of eight student nurses on July l4.
The city's new Fountain Cafe in Central Park was dedicated yesterday to the splash of champagne and a splash of oars that left Mayor Lindsay dripping.

Osborn-Charles Associates, Inc. a New York marketing, packaging, industrial design and consultant concern, announced yesterday the appointment of William Jacoby as vice president and director of special projects.
IN the high decibel hurlyburly of the corridors and offices at City Hall, Frederick O'Reilly Hayes, who was named the city's new Budget Director yesterday, remained unruffled. The frenetic City...

RICHMOND, Aug. 1 Dr. and Mrs. Donald Snead Daniel have announced the engage- ment of their daughter, Miss Josephine Townsend Daniel, to Edgar Robert Kent Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kent of Sherwood Forest, Md.
LONDON, Aug. 1 (UPI) The world heavyweight champion, Cassius Clay, suffered a cut mouth today in five furious rounds of sparring.

Fines totaling $5,191,000 were paid during the city's two-week grace period for persons wanting to pay overdue parking and jaywalking tickets, the Corporation Counsel's office estimated yesterday. Since July 18 more...

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (UPI) The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. accused the Chicago police today of laxity in their efforts to protect civil rights demonstrators from whites who hurled rocks and bottles at them on the weekend.
Omer G. Voss, executive vice president of the International Harvester Company, was elected yesterday to the board of the LaSalle National Bank of Chicago.
WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 1 Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Linhardt have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elinor Joyce Linhardt, to Jack Peter Gelb, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jules B. Gelb of New York.
Bud Powell, the pianist who was an influential figure in modern jazz, died last night at Kings County Hospital. He was 41 years old and lived mostly in Brooklyn during the last year.
Governor Rockefeller signed into law yesterday a program to allow the state to pay finan- cial compensation to the vic- tims of violent crimes.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 1 (AP) Jimmie Hall drove in four runs with two homers as he helped the Minnesota Twins to a 6-2 victory tonight over the Boston Red Sox.
Five candidates for Supreme Court justice in Manhattan and the Bronx were nominated last night by the Conservative party at a judicial convention at 80 Westchester Square, the Bronx.
MOSCOW, Aug. 1 The Soviet Union's newly elected Supreme Soviet (Parliament) will convene in the Kremlin tomorrow for a session of three or four days.
Negotiators for the Pressmen's Union and the World Journal Tribune, Inc., postponed a decision yesterday on Mayor Lindsay's proposal for factfinding continued direct talks in the 99-day-old dispute.

MINEOLA, L.I,, Aug. 1 The creation of an aquarium, a meteorological center, a marine zoo and a floating laboratory in Nassau County was proposed today to provide for the study and enjoyment of marine life.
YONKERS, Aug. 1 Miss Susan Rosenberg and Dr. Abraham Meltzer plan to marry in late autumn.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1 (AP) Jim O'Toole and three relief pitchers held the St. Louis Cardinals to four hits tonight as the Cincinnati Reds scored a 3-2 triumph.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 1 The Chief of Staff of Nigeria's Army announced today that he had taken over the Government after an army mutiny and the kidnapping of the chief of state.
Mayor Lindsay insisted yesterday that "no antipoverty funds have been lost by New York."
VIENTIANE, Laos, July, 23 In the 12 years since Laos received independence from France, the French remaining here have come to occupy a peculiarly nonaligned position in the fitful Laotian civil war.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange took a beating yesterday, with declines outnumbering advances by almost sixto-one.
The Hempstead Bank named yesterday Edwin J. Fehrenbach as a vice president.
The lag in housing starts and the continuing tightness in supplies of some metals brought about a series of price changes yesterday.
Western Europe's affluence, which has brought about heavy buying of fine gems and jewelry in the world's markets, was reflected at the National Jewelry Trade Show here yesterday.
Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman will come to New York this week to help look into the cause of a rise in food prices here.
DETROIT, Aug. 1 (AP) Directors of the American Motors Corporation voted today for the fourth consecutive quarter not to pay a dividend as earnings fell sharply from those of a year ago.
HONG KONG, Aug. 1 Lo Jui-ching, Chief of the Army's General Staff, has been replaced in another major development of the purge sweeping Communist China.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 (AP) Rich Allen whacked an inside-the-park home run leading off the 10th inning and gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 6-5 victory tonight over the Houston Astros.

BERLIN, Aug. 1 (AP) Guenter Gerhard of East Germany and Lydia Jeremina of the Soviet Union won the men's and women's target-jumping titles at the world parachute championships in Leipzig today. the East German press agency A.D.N., reported.
Charles H. Friedrich, director of tax administration for the Radio Corporation of America, died on Sunday night in his home at 119 Hope Road, New Shrewsbury, N.J. He was 49 years old.
Assets of foreign branches of United States banks are on the rise.
The Fire Commissioner issued an order yesterday forbidding any fireman appointed after next Jan. 1 from taking supplementary jobs outside the department.

SANA, Yemen, Aug. 1 (AP) A condemned homosexual was executed before 6,000 people in the main square of Sana today. A religious court sentenced the accused man, Ahmed aOsamy, a 60-year-old municipal employe.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 1 (UPI) Hank Gowdy, the hero of the 1914 Miracle Braves' World Series victory and the first major league baseball player to serve in the armed forces in World War I, died tonight. He was 76 years old.
The program printing machine at the race track broke down long before noon. It was a source of irritation to many patrons. With the machine at a...
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 1 (AP) Gov. John B. Connally Jr. of Texas said tonight he had ordered "a complete and thorough investigation" of the sniper killings in Austin.
WOLFSBERG, Germany Aug. 1 (AP)--The large Volkswagen plant today started its 1967 program with a more powerful version of its familiar beetleshape model.
LONDON, Aug. 1 Despite the sharp braking measures the Government has applied to the British economy to save the pound, the idea of devaluation has not been dispelled.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 1 Delegates to the World Jewish Congress approved by a wide margin today the scheduled appearance before them of Dr. Eugen Gerstenmaier, president of the West German Bundestag, or lower house of Parliament.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 A Senate committee approved today legislation that would authorize President Johnson to order an end to the airline strike for any period up to 180 days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 A labor leader explained Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz's refusal to take a strong position on antistrike legislation today in terms of a man "on the firing line who knows management-labor relations inside out."
Mr. and Mrs. Olav Hammarstrom of New York and Wellfleet, Mass., have announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Sandra Dusenbury, to Robert Clifford Hackett.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 1 A mass departure of teachers from the University of Buenos Aires was being organized today. Many said they planned to leave Argentina.

Mr. and Mrs. E. Vincent Curtayne of Brooklyn and Brightwaters, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caroline Anne Curtayne, to Lieut. Pierluigi Marignani of the Italian Navy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gualtiero Marignani of Rome.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 1 The Black Rock Yacht Club crew of Bridgeport, Conn., captained by Leslie Pfriem, held a 2-point lead over the defending champion, the Larchmont Yacht Club, today after the first two races in the qualifying series of the Long Island Sound girls' championship regatta off the Larchmont Y.C.
NASHVILLE, Aug. 2 (AP) Andrew M. Burton, founder and president emeritus of the Life and Casualty Insurance Company of Tennessee, died at his home here last night. He was 87 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 President Zalman Shazar of Israel met President Johnson at the White House today, and American and Israeli officials said the meeting emphasized the friendly relations between the two countries.
LONDON, Aug. 2 (UPI) The sniper slayings in Austin, Tex., yesterday were front-page news throughout the world today. They prompted more than a little moralizing about the state of American society.

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 2 The 18th annual Darien-New Canaan Autumn Cotillion will be held at the Wee Burn Country Club here Sept. 9. Mrs. Robert Ogden of New Canaan is chairman for the event, which will benefit the Norwalk Hospital and the Stamford and St. Joseph's Hospitals in Stamford.

Charles C. Bassine, chairman, and Murray Sussman, president of Spartans Industries, Inc., have been proposed for comparable posts in the company that will result from Spartans' pending merger with E.J. Korvette, ...

The judicial conventions just held by the major parties here provided graphic examples of how judges should not be selected. This judgment is not altered by the fact that the general level of the candidates nominated seems reasonably good and considerably better than had been expected.

Mayor Lindsay dropped in unexpectedly to buy a CocaCola and a chocolate candy bar at Sol's place on the corner of Utica Avenue and Eastern Parkway in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, last ninht. Sol didn't know who he was.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Aug. 2 Back in the nineteen-thir ties polo was a game for millionaires. Its roster was studded with names like Hitchock, Whitney and Guest and women who made the best-dressed list came to watch Stephen (Laddie) Sanford ride a $22,000 polo pony.
Mayor Lindsay named a committee yesterday to help make Coney Island and Rockaway "the twin amusement capitals of the country."
OMAHA, Aug. 2 (AP) Gov. Frank B. Morrison of Nebraska emerged today from a conference studying riots in Near North Side here and vowed:

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Aug. 2 (UPI) Billy Casper, $16,400 richer for winning the Speedway Festival Sunday, leads the Professional Golfers' Association list of top money winners for the year with $97,915.
The Studebaker Corporation announced yesterday in South Bend, Ind., the appointment of Charles F. Pratt as executive vice president.
A collection of letters describing conditions in the South from 1863 until 1869 will be published Sept. 1 by Vanderbilt University Press entitled "Dear Ones at Home."

F. Carrington Weems, who was assistant to the chief of the export department of J.P. Morgan Co. before he retired in 1935, died yesterday at Beverly (Mass.) Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 825 Fifth...
WOR-FM has a new look to go with its new sound. As part of a promotion campaign for the new popmusic format, which started ...

CLEVELAND, Aug. 2 (AP) Dave Johnson drove in four runs with a homer and a sacrifice fly, and Boog Powell hit a three-run double, powering the Baltimore Orioles to an 8-6 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 2 (AP) All available policemen were called out again tonight when a group of young Negroes threw bottles and rocks at firemen who responded to a fire near the scene of last night's disturbance.
Stock prices see-sawed in indecisive trading yesterday and then closed on a slightly lower note. The decline was the 11th in the last 12 trading days.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 2 Mrs. M. Stuart Roesler of Stanwich eliminated Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of Westchester Country Club, the medalist, 3 and 2, in the first round of the 41st annual women's Westchester-Fairfield ...

SKOVSHOVED, Denmark, Aug. 2 (AP) Williwaw, sailed by G.S. Friedrichs Jr. of New Orleans, won the European championship today in the International Dragon Class. It was the first time that an American boat has won the title.
PORTILLO, Chile, Aug. 2 (AP) A blizzard struck this site of the 1966 Alpine world skiing championships today, leaving an average of a foot of snow on the tracks.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 2--The Pittsburgh Pirates, generally regarded as the most skillful batting team in the National League, used opposite-field extra-base hits tonight to defeat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 6-5, and end a four-game losing streak.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--The estimate of defense spending now being used in the top economic quarters of the Government is that outlays will continue to rise until mid-1967 by about $2-billion every three months, the same rate of increase that has prevailed for the last year.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 2 (UPI) The Indonesian oil and mining department has lifted direct Government control from two American oil companies, the official news agency, Antara, said today.

The marriage of Miss Bonnie Beth Berson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel L. Berson of 912 Fifth Avenue, to Steven Emanuel Stern took place at the St. Regis Hotel last night. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gustav Stern of 115 Central Park West. Rabbis Simon Langer and Ezra Gellman officiated.

VENTURA, Calif., Aug. 2 Miss Elizabeth Ann Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Noble S. Johnson, plans to marry Pierre F. Dominice, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fernand Dominice of Geneva. Announcement has been made by the parents of the future bride.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 2 Mr. and Mrs. Jay C. Rosenfeld have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jayn Rosenfeld, to Jerrold Edward Seigel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Seigel of St. Louis.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) Legislation to tighten Federal supervision over banks and savings and loan institutions was approved today by a Senate banking subcommittee.

LONDON, Aug. 2 (UPI) Bad weather today forced suspension of the air and sea search for the pleasure launch Darlwin and the 31 persons on board. The vessel vanished off the coast of Cornwall during a freak storm Sunday night.

The St. Tropez, a 35-story apartment building on First Avenue that was opened a year ago last February as the first high-rise condominium in Manhattan, has been sold by Countrywide Realty, Inc., to an investing group.

The engagement of Miss Margaret Joan Morrison, the daughter of Dr. Alan Morrison of Oakdale, Calif., and Mrs. Willard Mann of Kensington, Calif., to Capt. Howard Peter Schiele, U.S.A., has been announced by the parents of the prospective bride. Captain Schiele is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Schiele of Yonkers.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 2 Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Howard James Lee of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy French Lee, to Joseph Leeming 3d, son of Mrs. Una M. Leeming of Buffalo and Joseph Leeming of Beas, Punjab, India. An autumn wedding is planned.

TOKYO, Aug. 2 Anne Dinken's Restaurant Kosher has brought bagels and lox to Japan.
Four of television's top producers have been signed by the Columbia Broadcasting System to produce original dramas for the network's "C.B.S. Playhouse" series next season.

In what it called a move "to head off cliff-hanger negotiations," the Long Island Rail Road has offered raises to its 6,350 unionized employes several months in advance of the expiration of their contracts.

WITH the opening today at Altman's of Milo Baughman's six model room settings containing his new collection of upholstered furniture some homemakers may begin to wonder if the designer has gained a monopoly over contemporary furniture sold in department stores.
ALBANY, Aug. 2 (AP)--Governor Rockefeller said today he had vetoed a bill that would have exempted persons more than 100 years old from real-estate taxes on property...
LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Aug. 2 John K.D. Chivers, dean of the Lawrenceville School, died today at Princeton Hospital after an illness of several months. He was 61 years old.

ABOUT 200 years ago it wasn't unusual for some- one to paddle a canoe up the Hudson through Lake Champlain to Canada. And 357 years ago, Samuel de Champlain and a war group of Algonquins canoed down from New France to the big lake that now bears his name.
The Board of Education warned yesterday that 30 school buildings might not be able to open in September because of strikes in the construction industry.
PANTS, tailored or formal, and the women in them, are being greeted with less than enthusiasm by the men who run many of the city's leading hotels and restaurants.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 The nation's nonwhite population, mainly Negro, will rise in the next 20 years from 11.9 per cent of the population now to between 13.3 per cent and 14.1 per cent in 1985, the Census Bureau estimated today.
Rear Adm. Andrew F. Carter, retired, organizer of the Commonwealth Oil Refining Company of Puerto Rico, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Dillon, S.C. He was 83 years old.
DETROIT, Aug. 2 (AP) Denny McLain blanked the Chicago White Sox, 5-0, tonight, on four hits, and gained his first victory after four losses.

The City Council appointed a committee yesterday to study the possibility of reducing the extent of fingerprinting in connection with the issuance of permits and licenses.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 Twelve members of the House of Representatives, including six from New York, have demanded that the Internal Revenue Service rule immediately on the taxexempt status of the Sierra Club, a national conservation ...
TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 2 (AP) Melvin C. Eaton, former president and board chairman of the Norwich Pharmacal Company, Norwich, N.Y., died yesterday in St. Charles Hospital here,...
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 (AP) Cookie Rojas hit a tworun single in the seventh inning to give the Philadelphia Phillies a 4-3 victory over the Houston Astros tonight.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Aug. 2 Thirty-four persons were arrested here tonight in the fourth night of clashes between the police and residents of the Puerto Rican community. At least 10 persons, including four policemen, were injured.
The Northeast drought that began in 1961 is not over. Runoffs into New York City's reservoirs have seriously diminished as the parched ground has absorbed the infrequent rains.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 2 The Argentine military regime ordered extra security preparations today as most of the 75,000 idle students at the closed University of Buenos Aires milled about buildings and classrooms.

MOUNT SINAI, L.I., Aug. 2 Conservationists and boating enthusiasts in this North Shore harbor community are battling over the use of a dredging machine the way residents of landlocked communities sometimes fight ...
CHICAGO, Aug. 2 A force of 140 policemen contained a jeering crowd of more than 1,000 whites today as civil rights workers demonstrated in a white residential area.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 2--John Griffith Peake, who retired nine years ago as chairman of the board and as general manager of Timbrol, Ltd., of Sydney, Australia, manufacturers of basic chemicals, died yesterday at Stamford Hospital.
The spot rate on the British pound rose slightly in fairly active trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday.
The General Fireproofing Company said yesterday it would spend $12.2-million in a three-year expansion program. Most of the money will be spent on new machinery and facilities.
KALAMAZOO, Mich., Aug. 2 (AP) Mark Conti of Detroit, an unseeded player, scored a major upset today in the first round of junior singles in the national junior and boys' tennis championships.
DENVER, Aug. 2 West Coast players dominated the standings in the life master pair championship here this afternoon as the leading New York stars dropped out of contention.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy praised the Manhattan-Bronx Democratic candidates for Supreme Court justice yesterday. But he scored the "factional bargaining" that picked them.
SAN MARINO, Aug. 2 The Most Serene Republic of San Marino, the world's oldest and smallest republican state, lost most of its serenity tonight in a full-fledged government crisis.

For the second time in two months, a film that had earlier been denied the approval of the Production Code Administration, the industry's self-censorship body, has been granted a code certificate after an appeal to the Code Review Board.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 United States aircraft bombed oil installations at Haiphong in North Vietnam today for the third time, the Defense Department announced.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 2 The Larchmont Yacht Club crew, the defending champion and captained by Nancy Stremmel, held a 2-poind lead in the 25th Long Island Sound girls' championship today after winning the first two races in the five-way final round-robin series. The races were sailed in steadily increasing southwest wind.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 Consumer installment credit rose $549-million in June, up from the relatively low May advance of $493-million, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
A driver who collected 156 parking tickets has sent the summonses, a $2,100 check and some strong advice to the Police Department.
NORRISTOWN, Pa., Aug. 2 Ernest O. Jacob, a retired executive of the Young Men's Christian Association, both in the United States and overseas, died yesterday. His age was 80.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Aug. 2 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Allan Sugar of the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Elaine Diane Sugar, to Bernard J. Ridder Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ridder of Pasadena.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 Mr. and Mrs. Francis Trowbridge vom Baur have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nerissa Trowbridge vom Baur, to Andrew Ridgely Walker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Coleman C. Walker of Darien, Conn.
Dr. William A. Roberts of 2441 Webb Avenue, the Bronx, a former president of the medical board of Morrisania Hospital, died yesterday in Union Hospital, the Bronx. His age was 83.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 2 (AP) United States troops and North Vietnamese regulars fought a series of sharp skirmishes in the Central Highlands today for the second day.
WATERFORD, Conn., Aug. 2 (AP) Twenty playwrights tonight attacked representatives of the country's major foundations for their failure to recognize the need for direct help to dramatists.
John B.M. Place, executive vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, was elected yesterday to the board of the Celanese Corporation, a chemicals and fibers producer.
Dr. Charles Townsend Olcott, a pathologist, died Monday of a heart attack in his summer home in Orillia, Ont. He was 76 years old and lived at 181 East 73d Street.

Samuel Sokolski of 300 Riverside Drive, a real-estate broker and builder, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. His age was 77.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday that he was prepared to take legal action against 20 milk wholesalers and distributors for alleged pricefixing in New York City.
The last 25 of the Government's big C-4-class troop ships will be withdrawn from reserve fleet stations and released to private industry under the Maritime Administration's trade-in ...

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 2 (UPI) The Washington Senators sent Don Blasingame, an infielder, to the Kansas City Athletics today in a four-way exchange that moved Diego Segui to Vancouver of the Pacific Coast League.

The city and the Port of New York Authority are on the verge of resolving their six-month-old dispute over the projected World Trade Center. An announcement of the settlement is expected shortly, perhaps today.
AUSTIN, Minn., Aug. 2 (AP) H.H. Corey, chairman of the Hormel Foundation and former president and board chairman of Geo. A. Hormel Co., meat packers, died yesterday in a Rochester, Minn., hospital.

David L. Cole, mediator in the newspaper dispute, urged the pressmen yesterday to accept Mayor Lindsay's proposal for fact-finding with recommendations. The union indicated it would not have an answer until tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 Three more instances where Senator Thomas J. Dodd apparently submitted two bills for the same airline fares came to light today.
MOSCOW, Aug. 2 The Supreme Soviet (parliament) convened in the Kremlin today and promptly re-elected Aleksei N. Kosygin as Premier.
CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) Byron Browne's bases-loaded single with two out in the 12th inning gave the Chicago Cubs a 6-5 victory over the Atlanta Braves today.

The National Association of Manufacturers has asked the Federal Communications Commission not to close the door on a choice of satellite relay systems that might best serve the future communications needs of industry.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) An expansion of Governmentpaid medical and hospital treatment for families of servicemen was approved today by a Senate Armed Services subcommittee.

Senator Jacob K. Javits, who had considered challenging Governor Rockefeller for the Republican nomination for Governor, announced yesterday he would be campaign chairman for Mr. Rockefeller and the rest of the party's statewide ticket.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 2 (AP) Lew Gerrard, the top-ranking New Zealander, became the first seeded casualty today in the men's division of the Middle Atlantic grass court tennis cham- pionship. He lost to Jack Jackson of Knoxville, Tenn., 4-6, 6-2, 6-3. Gerrard was seeded No. 3.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) The State Department said today that Ambassador at Large W. Averell Harriman would go to Cambodia early in September for talks with the chief of state, Prince Norodom Sihanouk.
After an encouraging start, the prices of most issues on the American Stock Exchange weakened and the list declined in quiet trading.
HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 2 (UPI)--Fred Stolle and John Newcombe of Australia advanced in the West German tennis championships today as rain continued to hinder players for the second day.

A peace committee in upstate New York reported last night that it had received a telegram from the Government of North Vietnam saying foreign journalists would be allowed to "eyewitness crimes perpetrated" by United States bombings "when conditions permit."

AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 2 A University of Texas psychiatrist said today that Charles J. Whitman, who killed 14 persons and an unborn baby yesterday, came to him in March for consultation, explaining that he had intense periods of anger.
New-car sales of the Ford Motor Company's Ford division and the Chrysler Corporation in the final third of July slipped below the year-earlier level, the producers reported yesterday.
THE New York Philharmonic and its park audiences are weatherproof almost. At last night's concert in Central Park, a rain squall in the middle of the opening number interrupted the performance ...
For Daniel Smith, things are not looking up.
VERONA, Italy, Aug. 2 The open-air theater of the arena in Verona is not quite 2,000 years old, but as theaters go it must be regarded as fairly well estab- lished.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 Commissioner Philip Elman of the Federal Trade Commission said today "the time has come for a searching re-examination of the Robinson-Patman Act and its administration."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 The House of Representatives tentatively approved tonight the jury and injunctive sections of President Johnson's civil rights bill and planned to take up the controversial housing section tomorrow.
A group of Democrats in the City Council decided in a party caucus last night to recommend increases in the expense allow- ances of Councilmen.
NAKHODKA, U.S.S.R., July 23 This upstart postwar Soviet port carved out of a great natural basin 100 miles southeast of Vladivostok is challenging its century-old rival for Pacific supremacy.

The father of Charles J. Whitman, the Texas sniper, said last night, "I just don't believe my boy could have told a psychiatrist I was brutal and domineering and that was the cause of his trouble."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) Charles J. Whitman, the Texas killer, was court-martialed as a marine for illegally possessing a pistol and ammunition in his barracks and aboard ship, the Pentagon said today.

With one night less for late shoppers, sales of leading department stores in the New York Metropolitan area in July dipped an average of 3 per cent below those of the 1965 month, a survey by The New York Times disclosed yesterday.
The chairman of Haryou announced yesterday that the Harlem antipoverty organization had given a vote of confidence to its executive director, Livingston L. Wingate.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--Senate leaders searched today for a formula by which Congress and the President would share the political responsibility for passing a law to end... the 26-day-old airline strike.

AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 2 (AP) Gov. John B. Connally Jr. arrived in Austin tonight, after cutting short a South American tour, to head the investigation into the slayings yesterday in which a total of 15 persons died.

The skepties who argued long ago that Nigeria was a geographic expression, not a nation, must feel themselves vindicated by the current upheavals there. These have brought that country to the brink of dissolution. On the evidence to date, tribal and regional loyalties are far more potent than any sense of common Nigerian nationality.

Jean-Paul Sartre and Simone de Beauvoir will head an unofficial "international war crimes tribunal" organized by Bertrand Russell to decide whether American conduct of the war in Vietnam constitutes a crime against humanity.

EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 2 (AP) Carol Semple of Sewickley, Pa., a co-medalist, and Jane Huntsberger of Camarillo, Calif., were upset today in the first match play round of the Women's Western junior golf tournament.

The Hat Corporation of America and the Palm Beach Company have agreed to a new licensing arrangement in which the hat concern would manufacture casual headwear for men using the Palm Beach name and fabrics.
AUSTIN Tex., Aug. 2 About an hour before sunset on Sunday, a crew-cut young man named Charles Joseph Whitman sat down at the neat desk in his tan brick cottage to write his last letter.

Despite some flashes of brilliance and much devoted service, American educational television has never lived up to its promise. Its "depressing failure," as described by Ford Foundation president McGeorge Bundy, is in large part the consequence of financial instability hopeless efforts to make a public impact on a shoestring.
Mayor Lindsay will take his first real vacation since becoming Mayor, starting next Sunday.

Governor Rockefeller has wisely vetoed the unsound and unenforceable censorship bill the Legislature passed with the ostensible purpose of curbing pornography. The measure would have made it a misdemeanor for a shopkeeper to permit anyone under sixteen to enter a store where "objectionable literature" was sold unless the youth was accompanied by his parent or guardian.

ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 2 The California Angels became the first team in the American League to reach the million mark in attendance tonight. Then, while the promotional celebration was still going on, the Angels scord two runs in the ninth inning, tying the New York Yankees at 5-5 and sending the game into extra innings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) The House Interior Committee approved today a bill to create a Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore on Michigan's Upper Peninsula on Lake Superior.
Council President Frank D. O'Connor, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for Governor, is scheduled to receive key support from within the Reform Democratic movement.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 2 Allie Sherman has promised Earl Morrall a large share of the quarterbacking duties when the Giants and the Pittsburgh Steelers clash in a National Football League exhibition game at Cornell University this Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 Union spokesmen at the national level took a gloomy view today of their political and public relations posture as a result of the airline contract fiasco. Some expect their position to deteriorate even further.
NEW DELHI, July 2 Pakistan has nearly doubled her military strength in the Pakistaniheld part of Kashmir since the war with India last September, according to official Indian sources here.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 From the outside, there is nothing particularly imposing about the George Town Club the site of the dinner Friday that will follow Luci Johnson's wedding rehearsal.

The current commodity guessing game is by how much Secretary of Agriculture Orville Freeman may increase the 1967 wheat acreage allotment. He has said he will announce a decision soon after the August crop report next Aug. 10.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 2 In one of the most productive days since the annual competition began 16 years ago, four races were completed today in the men's Long Island sailing championship for the Hipkins Trophy. Eight skippers competed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler formally recommended today that Congress give discretionary authority to the banking agencies to regulate interest rates on time deposits rather than fix a statutory ceiling.
The Plaza Theater, once a carriage house belonging to the Vanderbilt family, has been taken over by Rugoff Theatres chain in a sale-andlease arrangement.
CUCHI, South Vietnam, Aug. 2 To most of the 65 American conscientious objectors serving here, all of them unarmed, a question often asked by gunbearing soldiers is unfair.

GREAT NECK, L.I, Aug. 2 Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Ober have announced the engagement of Mrs. Ober's daughter, Miss Ilene M. Psaty, to Alvin S. Mirman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Mirman of Far Rockaway, Queens.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI) Medical experts said today that there was little chance a pecan-sized brain tumor prompted the murder spree of Whitman.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) Luci Baines Johnson enlisted her bridesmaids today to help catch up with wedding mail, amid bridal gown fittings and preparations for a state dinner at the White House.
TOPEKA, Kan. Aug. 2 (AP) Two incumbent Republicans, Senator William H. Avery won renomination tonight in the Kansas primary.
NATHAN HANDWERKER, who ran the nickel hot dog into a $6-million-a-year business, is as much a part of Coney Island as were Dreamland, Luna Park and Steeplechase but he is more durable.
The Inland Steel Company announced yesterday price increases averaging 2.1 per cent on three major steel products.

Arguments in two lawsuits concerning the old-Metropolitan Opera House, originally scheduled to be heard yesterday in the State Supreme Court, have been postponed to tomorrow morning to allow lawyers more time to file the necessary briefs.
ALBANY, Aug. 2 (UPI) A bill standardizing milk butterfat levels has been approved by Governor Rockefeller, it was announced today.

Mt. Sinai Hospital's decision to run a cut-rate garage for employes has provoked charges from a neighborhood garage operator that the hospital has hoodwinked the city and is driving him out of business.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI) A Baptist spokesman said today that passage of a proposed constitutional amendment on school prayers would result in a multitude of similar proposals every time the Supreme Court handed down a controversial decision.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 2 (AP) Gene Heeter, a tight end with the New York Jets for the last three years, retired today.

A November wedding is planned by Miss Leonora Hall and John Taylor Williams. Mr. and Mrs. John Hughes Hall of 142 East 80th Street have announced the engagement of Mr. Hall's daughter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Merton Esshom Williams of Weston, Mass.
Edward C. Schroedel, a retired International Business Machines Corporation executive, died yesterday in the New York Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 2 Washington Square, Larchmont, N.Y.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 2 Nigeria appeared to be moving toward political dissolution today with the Ibos of the Eastern Region openly challenging the new Northern-dominated Government in Lagos.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 2 President Humberto Castelo Branco imposed a one-year wage freeze today in a major move against inflation.
CHICAGO, Aug. 2 The attorney for Richard Speck said today he would ask court permission to have the murder suspect examined by both psychiatrists and psychologists.

GENEVA, Aug. 2 The World Council of Synagogues announced today that it was making a special award to Mrs. Helen Suzman, the only woman member of the South African Parliament, for her opposition to apartheid, or strict racial segregation.
OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 2 (AP) Spring Double, who won the rich Pimlico Futurity last fall on a disqualification, returned to winning form in the six-furlong feature at Monmouth Park today.
The City Council voted yesterday to open its sessions to news coverage by television and radio, ending many years of reluctance.
Canada defeated Mexico in doubles yesterday and took a 2-1 lead for the Stevens Cup at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Aug. 2 Mr. and Mrs. Wesler Thomson Keenan of The Greenbrier have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Oliver Keenan, to Jeffrey Wheeler Alcorn. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert R. Alcorn of Melrose, Mass.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 2 Under Secretary of State George W. Ball today discussed prospects for Vietnam talks with Secretary General Thant, just back from a fiveday Moscow visit.

The start of the country's first nationwide liquid helium distribution system and completion of the world's largest liquid helium production plant to feed the system were announced yesterday by Air Reduction Company and the Kansas Refined Helium Company.
BERLIN, Aug. 2 The East German Communists announced today that they planned to celebrate as a major victory next week the fifth anniversary of the building of the wall that cuts Berlin in two.
OBERLIN, Ohio, Aug. 2 Dr. Carl E. Howe, chairman of the physics department of Oberlin College from 1957 until his retirement last year, died yesterday. He was 68 years old.
A 74-year-old businessman in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn was shot to death early yesterday in a holdup that yielded the killer $7 in cash and $2 in stamps.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 2 President Aden Abdulla Osman of Somalia began an eight-day state visit to Saudi Arabia today in which he is expected to discuss with King Faisal the convening of a conference of Islamic heads of state.
BRUSSELS, Aug. 2 Belgium protested today the "unwonted procedure" by which the Congo Government ordered the Belgian Consul General in Lumumbashi, formerly Elisabethville, to leave the country.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 2--The National Police Chief, Jose de Jesus Morillo Lopez, was dismissed last night.
PARIS, Aug. 2 France today made public a soaring juvenile delinquency rate, one more major sign that hers is an urbanizing and modernizing society.
Paul Badura-Skoda, the Viennese pianist, played at Philharmonic Hall last night in the second concert of the big Mozart Festival being presented there this month.

The task of finding investment funds continued to tax Wall Street yesterday as underwriters prepared to bid today on the $250-million of American Telephone and Telegraph Company debentures.
The London Stock Exchange rallied initially yesterday following publication of reserve figures for July. Dealers marked prices up but found few buyers, causing the market to turn easier.
Air Products and Chemicals, Inc., producer of industrial gases and chemicals, announced here yesterday the election of Dr. T. Keith Glennan as a director.

AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 2 Following is the report of Dr. Maurice, D. Healty, staff psychiatrist of the Unviersity of Texas, prepared after Charles J. Whitman came to him for consultation on March 29, 1966.

Brain specialists yesterday catalogued some of the bizarre effects of brain tumors on behavior, but they were uncertain of the role such effects might have played in Monday's shootings at the University of Texas in Austin.
BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 2 Gov. Robert E. Smylie, a moderate Republican, was rejected today by the voters of his own party, who selected a conservative to run for Governor next November.

Is he as so many people interested in original, funny, creative and brilliant writing agree he is the most original, funny, creative and brilliant writer working in the English language today? Or merely, as these same people hasten to add, the most impertinent and long-winded?
The selloff in the stock market has caused only a slight increase in margin calls, brokers said yesterday.

THE height of the blueberry season is the time to ex periment with new recipes for this berry, which is too often relegated to the pie and fruit salad. Here are recipes for blueberry soup and blueberry pudding.
LONDON, Aug. 2 The British Overseas Airways Corporation will buy six Boeing 747 "jumbo" passenger jets to meet international competition after 1969.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--President Johnson, deploring yesterday's mass killings at the University of Texas, today urged prompt enactment of gun control legislation now stalled in Congress.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI) Hans V. Tofte, a Central Intelligence Agency expert in clandestine operations, has notified the Washington police that jewels, reportedly valued at about $19,000, were missing from his home after two other C.I.A. men visited his residence.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 McGeorge Bundy, president of the Ford Foundation, announced here tonight that the foundation would play "its full part" in the struggle to help the Negroes achieve full equality. He described this struggle as "the most urgent domestic concern of this country."

The Continental Oil Company announced yesterday the award of construction contracts for an $84-million refinery near Immingham, England, about 140 miles north of London.

HONG KONG, Aug. 2 Mao Tse-tung, Chairman of the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist party, has ordered greater integration between the armed forces and the Chinese people, with soldiers undertaking civilian tasks and civilians learning from the army.

DUBLIN, Aug. 2 Peter O'Toole received a rousing welcome last night when the Irishborn actor, known here only as a romantic screen hero, opened in Sean O'Casey's "Juno and the Paycock" at the Gaiety Theater.

LONDON, Aug. 2 The Treasury announced today that Britain's reserves dropped by 25million ($70-million) last month, but hardly anyone in the financial community here thought that figure told even half the story.

The Lincoln Center Repertory Company and the City Center yesterday announced dramatic productions scheduled for the new season.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company raised sales and earnings to new highs for any quarter or half year in the periods ended June 30, Russell DeYoung, chairman and chief executive, reported yesterday.

MADRID, Aug. 2 (Reuters)--A Spanish fisherman who helped find the hydrogen bomb the United States lost in the Mediterranean said today that he was surprised to learn that his lawyers were demanding $5-million in damages from the United States.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 The Public Health Service has opened a major campaign to conquer a form of cancer that is often curable but frequently ignored until it is too late.

LONDON, Aug. 2 Half of the double door was latched top and bottom, leaving only a narrow passageway. The mob outside surged toward the opening that was guarded only by a burly bouncer in a white sweater. One gigantic push shoved one bloke through the doorway, but the guardian of the portals wrapped him in his muscular arms and flung him outside.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 2 (AP) Petty Officer Donald L. Hamilton, the 1965 national pistol champion, took the lead on the basis of unofficial results today after the second day of firing in the 1966 championships here.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 2 Mrs. Charles Shipman Payson, who has enjoyed the experience of having her New York Mets win a doubleheader this season, saw her Greentree Stable win two races in a row at the Saratoga race track today. She watched the triumphs in the company of her brother, John Hay Whitney, who is also a co-owner of the Greentree thoroughbred activities.

YONKERS, Aug. 2 Earl R. Edmonds, a certified public accountant at 62 William Street, New York, died yesterday in St. John's Riverside Hospital here. He wa 61 years old and had lived here.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 A New York Congressman suggested to the Department of Justice today that the concerted action of New York bakeries and milk dealers in raising prices "was not accidental."

The Ford Foundation's proposal for a new structure to finance noncommercial television with earnings from satellite transmission of commercial TV shows opens the vista of an exciting new public-service role for telecommunications.
A four-month old report urging the city to reinstate 17 ferry boat officers was made public yesterday to the apparent annoyance of the Lindsay administration.
