Capt. Frederick W. Mohle, master of the American freighter Smith Voyager, has been found guilty of negligency and misconduct in the foundering of his ship 780 miles east southeast of Bermuda late in 1964. Four lives were lost.
DETROIT, Aug. 2 Former Gov. G. Mennen Williams, a long-time Democratic power in Michigan politics, won his party's nomination for the Senate today.

The San Francisco Giants kept charging last night that Jack Hamilton of the New York Mets was putting spit on the ball. The accusation apparently was not true. Hamilton appeared to be putting nothing on the ball, and as a result the Giants scored an eventful 5-4 victory.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 The Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia threw out today the contempt of Congress convictions of two leaders of Women Strike for Peace and a New York newspaper publisher.
The American Apparel Manufacturers Association announced yesterday the election of W. Frank Evans as president. Mr. Evans is president of Red Kap, Inc, a division of Blue Bell, Inc..
TOKYO, Aug. 2 American military procurement orders in Japan have skyrocketed this year, reflecting United States needs for the war in Vietnam.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 2 (UPI) Two secret witnesses identi- fied as undercover men who risked their lives to appear testified today at the final ses- sion of the county grand jury's investigation of the Hough riots.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 3 William S. Cox, the seasoned skipper who was at the helm of the American Eagle in the 1964 America's Cup trials, won the men's Long Island Sound sailing championship for the fifth time today.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company sold $250million of debentures yesterday at an interest cost of 5.6348 per cent the highest for the company since 1923.

ON July 17, a Sunday, George Milstein Shapiro was sitting in his Park Avenue apartment, talking by telephone to his old friend, Deputy Mayor Robert Price. "The negotiations between the city and the Port Authority on the World Trade Center had been broken...

TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 4 (AP) North Vietnam said today that despite United States bombings it had managed to keep gross industrial output in the first six months of this year at "almost the same level" as a year ago.

AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 3 Gov. John Connally said today that the mass killings in Austin by a University of Texas student Monday were "shocking," but that he did not think any new firearm control laws were needed.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Aug. 3 (AP) President Rene Schick Gutierrez, one of Latin America's most outspoken foes of the Castro regime in Cuba, died today following a heart attack. He was 56 years old.
New York University's Management Institute will offer four professional level, noncredit courses this fall for persons interested in real estate brokerage and investment.
ATLANTA, Aug. 3 A noisy crowd of several dozen Negroes gathered to protest the arrest of a civil rights worker on a traffic charge yesterday afternoon in a Negro section of Atlanta.
OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 3 (UPI)--Powhatan Stable's Tom Rolfe, 3-year-old champion last year, defeated Steel Pike by three-quarters of a length today and won the $27,450 Salvator Mile at Monmouth Park.
The spot rate on the British pound was unchanged in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. After fluctuating narrowly, the pound closed at $2.7899.
TOKYO, Aug. 3 Japan appeared headed today toward an early general election as Premien Eisaku Sato promised intensified efforts to stabilize the economy and improve the welfare of the average citizen.
The National Aeronautics and Space Administration awarded yesterday in Washington, D.C., contracts totaling $252.6-million in support of its Apollo space program.
HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 3 (UPI) Fred Stolle of Australia advanced in the men's singles competition of the German tennis championships today, but his Davis Cup partner, Roy Emerson, withdrew.
CHICAGO, Aug. 3 White hecklers fought unsuccessfully today to break through police cordons and attack civil rights demonstrators in an all-white residential area.

Herbert J. Diener Jr., assistant coordinator of capital appropriations for the Babcock Wilcox Company, manufacturers of equipment for utility companies, was killed Tuesday in an automobile accident in Salem, Ohio.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 3 Mr. and Mrs. Max R. Hall have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Allen Hall, to Victor Arthur Koivumaki 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. V. Arthur Koivumaki of Edina, Minn.
Sales of new cars fell substantially in the final third of last month and for July as a whole, according to reports received yesterday from Detroit.

Arrangements for the funeral are being made by a committee of Harlem citizens led by John H. Young, public relations consultant to the Haryou antipoverty program, and by Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 111.2 on Tuesday from 111.3 on Monday.
Premier Kosygin's "State of the Union" message to the Supreme Soviet yesterday showed unmistakably the dilemma in which he and the other makers of Soviet policy find themselves.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 3--Bob Veale, sidelined by a bad back since July 18, gave the Pittsburgh Pirates an important lift tonight by pitching them to a 3-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
Two 17th-century paintings valued at $300,000 an oil sketch by Rubens and a portrait by Ter Borch have disappeared from the collection of Lawrence A. Fleischman.
CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP)--Swinging Mood, owned by Louis Wolfson of Miami Beach, galloped to an eight-length victory today in the $56,300 Pucker Up Handicap before l8,529 at Arlington Park.
LAFAYETTE, La., Aug. 3 (AP) Boyd Raeburn, leader of one of the country's leading progressive jazz bands in the nineteen-forties, died yesterday at his home. He was 52 years old.
A second banana for the last 16 years, Joe Paterno has found the transition from associate to head football coach at Penn State a rather smooth one, so far.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 3 Outwardly Nigeria was calm today in the wake of last Thursday's coup d'etat by Hausa Northerners in the army, but reports of killings mounted and the nation's fragile unity appeared to be shattered.

LONDON, Aug. 3 Like those other fascinating characters, the Walrus and the Carpenter, Cassius Clay elected today to talk about many things of shoes and ships and sealing wax, of cabbages and kings. Oh, well, maybe he didn't touch all those topics, but he certainly had a lot to say about one of them, his own role as king of the heavyweights.

The Zenith Radio Corporation reported yesterday that it doubled its color-television sales in the first six months of this year. Joseph S. Wright, president, termed it the major factor in raising total volume and profits for the period to new highs.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 3 Chuck McKinley of Port Washington, L.I., winner of the Nassau Bowl in 1964 and runner-up to Roy Emerson of Australia last year, was beaten in the third round of the annual invitation tennis tournament at the Nassau Country Club today.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 3 Israel's Knesset (Parliament) amended the passport law last night to curb abuses made possible by the liberality of the state's Law of the Return.

Miss Lynn Susan Locke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney D. Locke of Woodmere, L.I., was married last evening to Michael Huberman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Huberman of Lawrence, L.I. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the Plaza Hotel.

PARIS, Aug. 3 Boots and more boots marched quiet- ly across the pale gray carpets of the haute couture salons here. During the fall collections that end this week, many couturiers showed the new, very long coat (in cloth or fur) that needs a boot to complete its wintery , Russian look.
The port's ship repair industry hailed yesterday the action of New York State authorities in exempting the industry from the state sales tax.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 3 A California labor spokesman accused the National Association of Manufacturers today of "plotting" with Ronald Reagan "for an extremist takeover in California this year, and an extremist drive for the Presidency two years from now."

WHEN the brilliancy prizes are awarded after the Piatigorsky Cup Tournament in Santa Monica, the judges are not likely to overlook the victory of Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N.Y., over Jan Hein Donner of the Netherlands.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 3 The directorate and editorial staff of the University of Buenos Aires Press resigned this evening after denouncing the military regime of Lieut. Gen. Juan Carlos Ongania.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Aug. 3 Mr. and Mrs. Henry Read de Castro have announced the engagement of their daugh- ter, Miss Odessa Madeline de Castro, to William Powers Bourne, son of Mrs. Harold J. Lamm of Greenwich, Conn., and the late James E. Bourne of Phillipsburg, N.J. An autumn wedding is planned.
HONG KONG, Aug. 3 A social upheaval on a scale similar to the "great leap forward" initiated in 1958 appears to be developing in Communist China.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 Returning to Washington after a long absence is always a depressing reminder of how rapidly the fashion in national passions changes these days.
SAMMY COHEN is the owner of the Santa Anita Race Book in Las Vegas. It's the biggest betting establishment in Nevada. Students of thoroughbreds arrive early to get seats and study the Racing Form.

ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 3 The New York Yankees got a five-run lead tonight and did not blow it, which is news. Instead, they improved it and defeated the California Angels, 9-0, behind the two-hit pitching of Mel Stottlemyre.

Soybeans paced the grain market yesterday to show gains of up to 7 cents a bushel. One impetus for the forward march came from a crop estimate by the National Soybean Crop Improvement Council, a trade group, putting the crop for the year beginning Sept. 1 at 866 million bushels, down from previous predictions of 915 million.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 By a margin of one vote, the House of Representatives ap- proved today a bipartisan amendment that would exempt most individually owned homes from the open housing section of the Administration's civil rights bill.
PARIS, Aug. 3 A French public-opinion poll published today illuminated the religious subcurrents of this country's electorate.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) The Senate Banking Committee approved a bill today designed to make an additional $3-billion available for housing loans through the Federal National Mortgage Administration.
SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 3 A substantial majority of Australians support their Governments policy of providing military assistance to South Vietnam, samplings of public opinion indicate.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 3 The Pathet Lao, the proCommunist forces in Laos, have broadcast over their clandestine jungle-based radio an appeal for freedom and a criticism of United States policy from a person said to be a captured American pilot.
The scoring decision crediting Juan Marichal with the Giants' 5-4 Tuesday night victory over the Mets was based on a directive in The Official Baseball Rules.
OLD SAYBROOK, Conn., Aug. 3 Dr. Hans F. Frese, a professor of languages at Trinity College, Hartford, died today in his home here. His age was 64.
Miss Nancy Thomas Huffman was married yesterday at noon to Peter Bourne Benedict of Hastings, N. Y., son of the late Mrs. Eleanore Benedict and the late John Wendt.
Domestic watch producers, who were showing losses or pale profits a few years ago, are reporting marked gains in earnings, sales and prestige.
LONDON, Aug. 3 An Opposition attempt to force a floor debate on the Labor Government's bill freezing wages and prices was defeated in the House of Commons tonight.
The appointment of Frank C. Hess as vice president and controller of the American Machine and Foundry Company was announced yesterday.
MONTEREY, Calif., Aug. 3 (UPI) Mrs. Eve McClure Ross, artist, actress and former wife of Henry Miller, the author, died here Sunday. She was 44 years old.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 3 A board of inquiry has recommended a trial by courtmartial for a United States Navy captain who called himself "the American Mayor of Saigon."

A major step toward maintaining and enhancing the pre-eminence of the Port of New York among America's seaports has been taken with the agreement establishing a new framework of partnership between the city and the Port Authority.

The 260,000 passengers carried by the Long Island Rail Road each day will have to pay at least 2 cents more for each ride next year, with additional increases of 2 cents for each of the following two years.

WHO on earth would think that cold chicken curry with cold rice would be an ideal dish for a picnic? Nobody but the picnic people who've tried it and that includes assorted French chefs, their relatives and friends.
A board of trustees appointed by Mayor Lindsay to try to save the old Metropolitan Opera House from demolition announced last night that it was giving up the fight.
Markets Commissioner Samuel J. Kearing said yesterday that his department had evidence that a recent increase in the price of milk had been carried out "in a patently collusive manner."
MOSCOW, Aug. 3 Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin disclosed today that the preparation of the Soviet Union's five-year economic development plan had been delayed.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 3 The engagement of Miss Myra Lubitz to John J. Graubard, son of Dr. and Mrs. David J. Graubard of New York, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Irving Lubitz.
The Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation said yesterday it earned $479,000 in the first half after adjustment for a net tax credit of $730,000 and a $294,000 provision for minority interests.
The members of a Brooklyn family who three months ago did not have enough money to bury their slain father, purchased a $29,000 house yesterday.
A special 90-minute edition of the National Broadcasting Company's "Meet the Press" will bring six civil rights leaders together on Sunday, Aug. 21, at 3:30 P.M.

The major commercial banks in Switzerland were reported yesterday to have reached an agreement that should greatly enhance their ability to influence the terms and conditions on which American companies raise money in Europe.

BEDFORD, N.Y., Aug. 3 The Rev. Dr. Arthur Willis Hargate, rector of St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, and Mrs. Hargate have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Ann Hargate, to Hugh Powers Mitchell. He is the son of the Rev. Dr. James A. Mitchell, rector emeritus of St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Englewood, N.J., and Mrs. Mitchell. A September wedding is planned.
The Cone Mills Corporation, a cotton textiles producer, has announced in Greensboro, N.C., the election of Edwin F. Rousch as a vice president.
The Allen Organ Company of Macungie, Pa., said yesterday that it had reached an out-ofcourt settlement with the Rodgers Organ Company in a patent infringement suit filed in June, 1964, by Allen .

Hopes rose yesterday for an early end of the strikes that have slowed or halted $200- million in construction here. The operating engineers reached agreement with the contractors who build, roads, tunnels, highways, subways and structural foundations.
The nation's electric power production rose 12.9 per cent in the week ended July 30 from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.
THE PARTIES The International Association of Machinists and Eastern, National, Northwest, United and Trans World airlines.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 3 PaulHenri Spaak, the former Foreign Minister of Belgium who bowed out of politics last month, has accepted an executive position with the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, it was learned here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 The Senate Interior Committee approved today a bill to establish an Oregon Dunes National Seashore nine years after the recreation area had been proposed by the late Senator Richard Neuberger.

Mayor Lindsay will appoint a full-time official today to coordinate and control the economic forces that have been changing the face of Staten Island since the opening of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge almost 21 months ago.

The Campbell Soup Company announced yesterday in Camden, N.J., the election to the new posts of senior vice president of George W. Crabtree, Oscar H. Curry, John A. McGlinn Jr., and E. Marshall Nucklos Jr.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug 3 The 4,000 spectators at Fairfield University watched in fascination today as Earl Morrall called automatics in a New York Giant workout. A year ago, he didn't even know the original plays, let alone automatics.

Two Reform Democratic delegates to the party's state convention Sept. 7-8 and three Reform alternates announced yesterday that they were supporting City Council President Frank D. O'Connor for the nomination for Governor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 The Senate leadership worked out today compromise legislation under which both Congress and the President would share the responsibility for ending the 27day-old airline strike. But there were signs of growing caution within the chamber about enacting any law.

The 12-story store and office building at 52 Broadway in Manhattan's downtown financial district that had been owned by a limited partnership organized by a subsidiary of the Tenney Corporation has been sold reportedly for about $5million.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 While taking no position on the Vietnam war itself, the 56th annual convention of the National Urban League expressed pride here today in "the part played by Negro Americans in the armed services in Vietnam."
A SPECIAL limited hunting season for antlerless deer will be held in the south branch of the Adirondacks Moose River wilderness area in Hamilton County.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 3 (AP) Max Alvis hit a three-run triple and Fred Whitfield clouted a two-run homer tonight as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Orioles, 9-6, despite five Baltimore home runs.
LONDON, Aug. 3 Little Black Sambo, a favorite character of British children since 1899, has found a little white cousin. Her name is Squibba and like Sambo, she is adept at surviving in the jungle.
"Art: USA," the highly publicized collection of 102 contemporary American paintings owned by S.C. Johnson Son, Inc., will be presented to the Smithsonian Institution.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--The Government did nothing publicly today about the spreading price increase for sheet and strip steel, though action later was not ruled out.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J. Aug. 3 City officials stood tonight on a street corner where clashes have occurred for four nights and told cheering Puerto Ricans that they were scrapping an anti-loitering ordinance that had led to the fighting between Spanish-speaking citizens and the police.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 3 Bay-area dealers of the Honda, the pint-sized Japanese motorcycle that has become noisily familiar on the American scene were charged in a criminal indictment today with a conspiracy to fix prices.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 3 (AP) Republican Senator James B. Pearson won nomination for his first full Senate term and Gov. William H. Avery, also a Republican, easily gained his party's nomination for a second term in the Kansas primary election yesterday.
BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 3 Shock waves from the upset of Gov. Robert E. Smylie by a conservative in yesterday's Republican primary election reverberrated through Western political circles today.
SYRACUSE, Aug. 3--Fifty-nine cars traveled 300 miles without mishap today on the first stage of the MG Car Club's 14th annual 1,000-mile international rally.
Dresser Industries, Inc., a Dallas, producer of drilling and refining equipment, announced yesterday the election of Harold P. Koenig as vice president for planning, a new post.
The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange is pretty stuffy about such things, but the trading floor recently became the setting for a television commercial for a leading brokerage house.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 President Johnson, calling the foreign aid program "a cornerstone of America's international policies" for twenty years, appealed today to critics of the program as well as its champions to "meet on the middle ground of reason and reality."

Representative Adam Clayton Powell urged yesterday that any Negro seeing J. Raymond Jones, New York County Democratic leader, in Harlem "spit on him" for failure to nominate a Negro for Supreme Court justice in Manhattan and the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 Government intervention in labormanagement disputes is as old as the Industrial Revolution. But the nature of its role has changed so much over the years that the subtle and covert influence of the executive may be as significant in major conflicts as the formal procedures...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 Six United States Air Force reconnaissance squadrons will be withdrawn from France by October, the Defense Department announced today. The move will affect about 90 planes and 4,400 Air Force personnel.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Aug. 4 United States B-52 bombers struck for the third time in the demilitarized zone between North and South Vietnam this morning.

OMAHA, Aug. 3 (UPI) A fire set by an arsonist caused an explosion that demolished a cafe and damaged an adjacent service station and three cars near Omaha's racially disturbed near North Side early today, Five persons were injured.

HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 3 (AP) Lenny Bruce, the controversial nightclub comedian whose acts were sprinkled with fourletter words and pungent social satire, died tonight in his home on Hollywood Boulevard. He was 40 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) Senator Javits rebuked Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, today for what he termed the "juvenile" behavior of the Senate's youngest member in criticizing compromise efforts on the airline strike bill.

Thomas W. Gleason, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, said yesterday that he had urged Senator Russell B. Long, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, to support a bill designed to improve the unemployment compensation law.
Evelyn Otero, who is 14 years old, was sitting dejectedly on the stoop yesterday in front of her home at 320 East Fourth Street, on the Lower East Side. For her, it has been a long, dull summer.

Psychiatrists and psychologists agreed yesterday that correct diagnosis of the mental condition of Charles J. Whitman last spring might have prevented him from killing 14 persons in Austin, Tex., Monday.
ALBANY, Aug. 3 Governor Rockefeller has vetoed a bill backed by the Lindsay Administration that would have given New York City half the money to build or expand its jails.

Edmund Melson Ragsdale, a retired Navy career officer and an associate of C. W. Robinson Co., a New York management consultants firm, died of a heart attack on July 21 at Karachi, Pakistan, where he was employed. He was 62 years old and lived at 125 East 57th Street.

Canada won the last two singles matches and defeated Mexico, 4-1, yesterday in the Stevens Cup eliminations at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens, and will meet the United States in the finals starting tomorrow.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 3 (Reuters)--Two platoons of riot police mounted guard today outside the Saigon clinic where Thich Tri Quang, the Buddhist leader, continued his eight-week-old hunger strike in protest against South Vietnam's military rulers.

The City Council's Committee on Arrangements, disbanded as superfluous during the Wagner administration, was reconstituted Tuesday. Immediately afterward, a caucus of the Council's Democratic ma-, jority decided that the committee's chairman needs $1,000 in expenses above the $2,000 a year the caucus decided all Councilmen need above the $3,000 they presently get above their $10,000 annual salaries.

The International Union of Electrical Workers announced yesterday that its executive board had voted to accept $8million from other A.F.L.-C.I.O. unions to bolster its resources in an expected dispute with the General Electric Company and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation for new contracts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) Secretary of State Dean Rusk has informed Congress that the United States observes a no-bombing buffer zone along the border between North Vietnam and Communist China as a precaution against overrunning Chinese territory.
A crowd at an outdoor dance in South Jamaica, Queens, surrounded a policeman last night and forced him to turn over a man he had just arrested.

RUDI GERNREICH'S new sleepwear to stay up in and underwear to match outerwear were shown this week at Bonwit Teller. The lingerie is already on sale at Bonwit's and will be the star of the Gernreich boutique that will open at Stern Brothers next week.
Many professional pulsetakers believe the economy is overheated and have prescribed new taxes or tight money for cooling effect.
WHEN anyone writes a, strikingly good novel, a skeptic on the rare occasion can always put it down with the withering statement that, after all, it's no "War and Peace." Or that book by Melville.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 3 (AP) Pete Rose drove in the lead run with a sacrifice fly in the 16th inning and Dick Simpson followed with a run-scoring single as the Cincinnati Reds beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 3-1, tonight, for their ninth victory in 10 games.
The Treasury Depatrment reported yesterday that public holdings of United States Savings Bonds rose $116-million in July, the fifth consecutive month to show gains over the 1965 level.

Charges of discrimination made by Puerto Rican migrant workers in an upstate village were denied yesterday in a report prepared by the Commission on Human Rights and released without comment by Governor Rockefeller.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 3 (UPI) Nurses at 31 hospitals in the San Francisco Bay area ended a threat of a walkout today by reporting for duty.
The second pilot involved in the two tanker collision that took 33 lives in the Kill Van Kull last June 16 was charged with negligence by the United States Coast Guard yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) A 28-year-old lawyer for the House Education and Labor Committee who was mentioned favorably in a syndicated column critical of its chairman, Adam Clayton Powell, Democrat of Manhattan, has been dismissed.
The plan by the diverse Riklis interests to expand working control of the B.V.D. Company, Inc., moved a step closer to majority control yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. David Schwartz of Jamaica Estates, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diane June Schwartz, to Capt. Lawrence Hanon Climo, Medical Corps, U.S.A., son of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Climo of New Haven.

The surprise defeat of Gov. Robert Smylie in Idaho's Republican primary is largely attributed to voter resentment against a 3 per cent sales tax he had successfully advocated. Like many other governors in both parties in recent years, Mr. Smylie was the victim of his decision to follow a fiscally responsible course.
The American Stock Exchange came to life yesterday and made its best showing in almost two months.
AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 3 One of this city's leading psychiatrists called the problem of dealing legally with patients who make desperate threats "a real gray area in Texas."

GRAND FORKS, N.D., Aug. 3 The engagement of Miss Mary Nell Henley of Washington to John F. Murray has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. David B. Henley, parents of the future bride. Mr. Murray is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert J. Murray of Elmira, N.Y., formerly of the Bronx, New York.
The bribery conviction of certified public accountant here was unanimously reversed yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals. A new trial was ordered.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 3 (AP) Growth in industrial production in the European Economic Community rose 6 per cent in the first six months in 1966, compared with the corresponding period in 1965, the July report of Common Market Economics said today.
Sears, Roebuck Co., the nation's largest general merchandising organization, announced yesterday in Chicago the election of James W. Button as a director.
Riots and other civil disorders have been, occurring with such frequency that an observer might conclude they are part of the American way of life.
TRENTON, Aug. 3 New Jersey's cemetery operators were accused today of attempting to "shock" customers into buying plots and of shortening graves to provide additional plots.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower flew home to Gettysburg, Pa., today after more than a week at Walter Reed Army Hospital for a checkup described as routine.
Mayor Lindsay gave a warm endorsement yesterday to the City Council's plan for $126,000 in increased pay for its members, but there were some discordant notes within the Council itself.
DETROIT, Aug. 3 The younger generation, brimming over with new wave enthusiasm, got a rude lesson in party politics in yesterday's Michigan Democratic primary.

Using a legal form borrowed from his opponent's lawyer, City Councilman Theodore S. Weiss asked yesterday that Sept. 20 be set as the date for a new Democratic primary election in the 19th Congressional District.
TORONTO, Aug. 3 (AP) Railway Express and freight services between Montreal and Toronto were affected today by a strike of 1,000 workers in Toronto and 1,800 in Montreal.

THE HAGUE, Aug. 3 The Netherlands refused today to extend the visas, expiring tonight, of eight Chinese technicians whom the Dutch police want to question in connection with the death of a Chinese technician here last month.

MOSCOW, Aug. 3--Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin declared today that the Soviet Union was determined "to help the North Vietnamese people to drive the American oocupiers from Vietnamese soil as quickly as possible."
Sparked by news of an increase in steel prices, stock prices rallied strongly yesterday in moderately active trading.
Pennant contenders do not falter against second-division clubs. The league-leading San Francisco Giants proved that in Shea Stadium last night when they walloped the New York Mets, 11-1.
The Armco Steel Corporation and the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation joined yesterday in the 2.1 per cent price increase initiated Tuesday by the Inland Steel Company on three major steel products.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 3 (AP) A group of about 100 Negro youths agreed tonight to a 24hour moratorium on threats to burn and loot a North Side shopping district.
New York City, which lost Stanford White's monumental Pennsylvania Station to demolition, is restoring one of the architect's minor masterpieces, a neo-classic peristyle in Brooklyn's Prospect Park.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company asserted yesterday that the Ford Foundation's concern over the future of educational television should receive careful study, but there was no change in the company's basic legal objection to the satellite TV plan proposed on Monday by the philanthropic organization.
LAKE WORTH, Fla., Aug. 3 (UPI) The Roman Catholic Church has absolved Charles J. Whitman from sin because he was "a mental case," the family priest said today.
A dozen welfare clients, backed by the hopes and pennies of hundreds of other relief recipients throughout the city, will leave for Chicago today for the nation's first Welfare Rights Convention.

MONTREAL, Aug. 3 A conference of top legal experts from the United States, led by Southern delegates, voted today not to ask the American Bar Association to endorse a uniform state antidiscrimination law.

TOKYO, Aug. 3 (AP) Lieut. Gen. Renya Mutaguchi, who ordered the first shots of the Chinese-Japanese War fired in 1937 and led Japanese invaders of India in World War II, died of a stroke yesterday at his home. He was 77 years old.

NANTUCKET, Mass., Aug. 3 The racing cruise of the New York Yacht Club was reduced to conversation and other social activity today when the only scheduled event, a predicted-log contest for powerboats, was called off. In the sailing division, the race committee heard many protests over an infraction that occured in Saturday's Una Cup race and disqualified two boats, neither of which figured high in the competition.

Stockholders of the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation were urged to unite in defense of their interests yesterday by Benjamin A. Javits, president of the United Share owners of America, Inc.
It was Viennese night at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday, and six abundantly gifted young singers saw to it that a scintillating time was had by all.

On behalf of all members of the Government formed by he U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet of the Seventh Convocation and on my own behalf allow me to thank you for the trust in us and the high honor accorded us. We realize ours entire responsibility and will exert every effort to be equal to the high demands made by the people of the Government.
The city and the Port of New York Authority agreed yesterday on terms that will permit early construction of the $525million World Trade Center.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 3 Almost everybody in the crowd of 13,505 at Saratoga race track quipped at one time or another today, "I'll take Vanilla," on scanning the entries for the Schuylerville Stakes. When the stakes was over, though, the betting board showed that Vanilla had few takers.

Figures disclosed by Federal antipoverty officials yesterday confirmed that the city's failure to use $10.3million--more than half its allotment for the fiscal year that ended June 30--and showed that only five of the planned 35 projects were able to carry out their full programs.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 3 (AP) Petty Officer 1st Cl. Donald L. Hamilton won his second straight national pistol championship today, according to unofficial results announced at the Camp Perry firing range.
The New York and the American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday the changes carried below in the share holdings of officers, directors and major stockholders.

Negotiators for the Pressmen's Union and the World Journal Tribune, Inc., held an extended bargaining session yesterday in an effort to break the deadlock that has prevented the new company from publishing its papers for 101 days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) Luci Baines Johnson and Patrick J. Nugent parted briefly tonight. She gave a buffet supper for her bridesmaids and he threw a bachelor party with soft drinks for his attendants.
Two of the five airlines grounded by the 27-day-old machinists' strike issued their June-quarter reports yesterday.
I do not believe in violence. Therefore from now on, whenever a black man in Harlem sees Ray Jones in the street, he ought to spit on him.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 3 Sixteen American professors of mathematics are taking a working six-week vacation in Mombasa, Kenya, doing simple school arithmetic.

DENVER, Aug. 3 New York players found the going hard in the semi-final stage of the life master pair championship here this afternoon. None of them were among the leaders of the qualifiers for the final stage.

Thomas J. McGrath, an assistant vice president of the Bankers Trust Company, died yesterday at his home after a long illness. Mr. McGrath was 42 years old and lived at 162-41. Powell's Cove Boulevard, Beach- hurst, Queens.
Cardinal Spellman paid a courtesy call last night on the visiting President of Israel, Dr. Zalman Shazar, at his suite in the Plaza Hotel.

In a surprise move yesterday, the Government withdrew its objections to the public dissemination of an alleged duplicate of the atomic bomb sketch that Julius and Ethel Rosenberg purportedly delivered to the Soviet Union in 1945. At the same time, the Government withdrew its demand for closed hearings concerning the sketch.
BONN, Aug. 3 (Reuters) Chancellor Ludwig Erhard announced plans today for sweeping economic and financial changes to stabilize West Germany's ailing economy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 The other day in, Raleigh, N.C., the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. called for a domestic "Marshall Plan" costing $10 billion in each of the next ten years to eliminate the slum, poverty and educational conditions that he believes are at the root of Negro unrest and rioting.
ROCHESTER, Aug. 3 (UPI) Darkness haited the world skeet shooting championship for 20-gauge shotguns today with a sudden-death battle for victory still undecided.

That was a gentle tap on the wrist the State Department administered to the new Argentine military dictatorship this week. The beating of students and professors including an American at the University of Buenos Aires did not even draw a formal protest. Instead, Washington contented itself with something called "an expression of concern."

City Council President Frank D. O'Connor charged Mayor Lindsay yesterday with either misstating the case or demonstrating an "ignorance of the facts" concerning the loss to New York City of $10-million in antipoverty funds.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Aug. 3 Grand Master Bent Larsen of Denmark moved toward first place in the Piatigorsky Cup Chess Tournament after defeating Lajos Portisch of Hungary in their adjourned ninth-round game at the Miramar Hotel here last night. In the rook ending, Larsen's passed pawn decided after 53 moves.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed with declines yesterday after showing initial improvement.
DUBLIN, Aug. 3 Raymond R. Guest, the United States Ambassador to Ireland, scored an unusual diplomatic victory for the United States today at the Royal Dublin Society's horse show.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 A proposal to postpone indefinitely a meeting of hemisphere foreign ministers originally scheduled for Aug. 29 was approved today by a five-nation working group of the Organization of American States.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP)--The Agriculture Department has scheduled four hearings on the establishment of a cotton research and promotion program to be financed by a $1-a-bale levy on growers.
CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP) Ken Johnson pitched a five-hitter today and Felipe Alou scored on a throwing error and a sacrifice fly as the Atlanta Braves defeated the Chicago Cubs, 2-0.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 The Federal Trade Commission, in a 3-2 split decision, ruled today that Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., made misleading guarantee claims for some of its products.
The new master of the French flagship France, Commandant Elie Desplat, shrugged his shoulders and chuckled gently when asked what he did during World War II.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) Johhny Unitas, making his first start since undergoing knee surgery last season, threw two touchdown passes tonight in leading the Baltimore Colts to a 35-0 rout of the Washington Redskins before a capacity D.C. stadium crowd of 45,805 that included President Johnson and his prospective son-in-law Patrick Nugent.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 3 Mrs. John H. Bartol of Stanwich, who is seeking her eighth Women's WestchesterFairfield Golf Association title, reached the semi-final round of the association's 41st annual championship today.

"The Fantasticks" is the new Off Broadway longevity champion. With its 2,612th performance tonight, the musical by Tom Jones (book and lyrics) and Harvey Schmidt (music) will pass the record of 2,611 performances set by "The Threepenny Opera."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 3 The Security Council refused today to condemn Israel on charges of aggression against Syria.
NEW HAVEN, Aug. 3 New York City is 50 times as large as New Haven, but it received and spent only three times as much money in Federal antipoverty grants last year. Why?
The death of Lord Malcolm Douglas-Hamilton in a plane crash in Cameroun in July,1964, was confirmed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 The Senate Agricultural Committee called upon Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman today to investigate recent increases in prices for milk, bread and other foodstuffs throughout the country.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 3 Thailand urged Malaysia and the Philippines today to join her in working for an Asian-sponsored peace conference on Vietnam.
Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodian Chief of State, has suggested that the key to a settlement, of the war in Vietnam may lie with the Vietcong and not with North Vietnam or with Communist China.
ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 4 The California Angels might not have defeated the New York Yankees, 11-7, today if they had heeded the late W.C. Fields's advice: "If at first you don't succeed, give up."
A flight scheduled to leave Philadelphia tomorrow will mark the start of a new role for the nation's supplemental formerly nonscheduled airlines.

MONTREAL, Aug. 4 Sweeping revisions in laws governing consumer credit in the United States were urged here today at the annual meeting of the National Conference of Commissioners on Uniform State Laws.
MOSCOW, Aug. 4 Foreigners who repeatedly violate the Soviet Union's rigid travel restrictions will be liable to prison terms of up to a year under a new law.
WOODS HOLE, Mass., Aug. 4 There were three new winners today on the New York Yacht Club cruise. Only George R. Hinman's Sagola, which won in the third division, had triumphed previously.

Dr. Charles Bland Jones, a surgeon and former president of the medical board of Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn, died there yesterday. He was 63 years old and resided at 10 Sands Light Road, Sands Point, L.I.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 The House defeated today attempts to weaken further the open housing section of the Administration's civil rights bill.
Stock prices rallied; faltered and then rose again yesterday as the market reacted to developments in the steel price situation. The net effect was a strong advance for the day.

LONDON, Aug. 4 (AP) The Rolls-Royce Corporation is planning a double take-over bid costing at least $168-million that would make it one of the world's largest airplane engine makers, London financial circles reported tonight.

The Very Rev. John Vernon Butler, dean of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine since 1960, has been named 14th rector of Trinity Parish, it was announced yesterday. He will take over the post on Nov. 1.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 The marriage rite and mass that will join Luci Baines Johnson and Patrick John Nugent this Saturday will appear strange to virtually all Americans who are not Roman Catholics.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 4 (AP) A bomb planted in a washroom exploded in the Colombian-American Cultural Center today and killed an instructor from Wisconsin and at least three other persons, the police reported.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 4 India is seeking an expansion of the International Control Commission's role in the demilitarized zone between North and South Vietnam to prevent a further spread of the war into the buffer area.

The State Supreme Court dismissed a second attempt yesterday to punish Representative Adam Clayton Powell for criminal contempt for his failure to pay court costs in connection with a $160,000 judgment he owes.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4 A spokesman for Ronald Reagan has confirmed that the actor met with an official of the National Association of Manufacturers last weekend in what the spokesman described as "a mountain cabin" in the Lake Tahoe area.

PORTILLO, Chile, Aug. 4 (AP) Billy Kidd, the American ski champion from Stowe, Vt., fractured his right leg in a freakish accident today while training on the downhill course for the world Alpine championships.
LONDON, Aug. 4--Spain, which is locked in talks with Britain over the future of Gibraltar, has banned all flights by British military aircraft over Spanish territory.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 A woman member of Congress won a victory today that delighted her male colleagues even though it may be temporary.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 County Jail officials said today a decision on whether to move Richard F. Speck, the 24-year-old vagrant accused of the July 14 murders of eight student nurses, from his jail infirmary bed to a maximum security cell might be made on Monday.

American manufacturing and oil companies, are currently planning to invest a total of $7.1-billion in overseas property and equipment this year, or 19 per cent above 1965, the economics department of McGrawHill, Inc., stated yesterday.

An apartment house on 55th Street between Sutton Place and First Avenue has been sold by the 55 Sutton Company to investing clients of Isaac Taitz of William A. White Sons, the brokers in the transaction.
The Flintkote Company is planning to shift its offices from New York to a $2-million corporate headquarters to be built on a 35-acre site in Harrison, N.Y.

Many of the thousands of registered foreign nurses who come to New York each year are not permitted to work here because they have never studied such subjects as trigonometry or American history in high school.
City Councilman Theodore S. Weiss, Manhattan Democrat, called on Mayor Lindsay yesterday to veto the proposal for $126,000 in increased expense money for Council members.
Mayor Lindsay appointed the city's first director of Staten Island development yesterday and immediately received a stern warning from the borough's president, Robert T. Connor.

OLD TAPPAN, N.J., Aug. 4 Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Chriss have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jacquelyn Clare Chriss, to Lieut. (jg.) Donald Rexford Mason, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth B. Mason of Oradell.

The Democratic state chairman, John J. Burns, rejected yesterday a request by Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. that the party investigate his charge that City Council President Frank D. O'Connor made a deal with two Democratic leaders for their support for the nomination for Governor.

GENEVA, Aug. 4 A United Nations committee temporarily suspended today its attempt to draft the first treaty to govern the exploration of space, with the intention of resuming the effort soon in New York.
ATLANTA, Aug. 4 (AP) A coalition of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee and the separatist Black Muslims would be welcome, a spokesman for the student committee said today.

Heavy military shipments to Vietnam; the end of the coal miners' holiday and the continuing strong pace of the economy pushed freight traffic ahead sharply in the week ended last Saturday, industry figures showed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) Congress was told today that the Soviet Union could achieve supremacy at sea well before the end of this century unless effectively challenged by the non-Communist world.

Eugene M. Becker has served New York City briefly--but with great distinction. A Princeton Ph.D. in cultural history and archeology seems strange background for drawing up a $4.6-billion budget, but Mr. Becker did the job and did it well. He deserves the city's thanks for the part he has played in starting it toward a sound financial basis in his seven months as Budget Director.
Chain store and catalogue sales have never been better in midsummer, judging by reports yesterday of three leading retailers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) The Central Intelligence Agency has suspended Hans V. Tofte from his normal duties while checks are made on whether he committed a security violation.
The three Civil Court judges in Brooklyn nominated by the Democrats for Supreme Court resigned yesterday, effective midnight Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) The House Ways and Means Committee approved today a bill designed to facilitate the use by the Government of foreign currencies it owns abroad.

ATLANTA, Aug. 4 Stokely Carmichael was 11 years old when his family moved from Port of Spain in his native Trinidad to Harlem in 1952. Something of the West Indies can still be seen in him. His fine-cut face is friendly and he carries his tall frame with a slump-shoul-...
Futures trading was dull for most commodities yesterday. Few significant changes were tallied in prices and there was very little news to stimulate activitiy.

CHEDDAR, England, Aug. 4 (UPI) David Lafferty, the world's new caveman champion, was cheered by thousands today as he emerged blinking, sunken-eyed but happy from a record 130 days alone in a dark damp cavern 400 feet underground.
Hazel Bishop says it has banned the bomb the bomb being the aerosol can of hair spray.

The Goodyear International Corporation announced yesterday plans to construct a $14-million tire factory at Philippsburg, German. The new plant is to be built and operated by Deutsche Goodyear G.M.B.H.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 The National Urban League has taken a stand deploring the controversy over the term "black power" because it has diverted attention from the "more meaningful debate around the real problems of poverty and discrimination."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) President Johnson announced today he has chosen Dr. Reynold E. Carlson, associate director of the Ford Foundation's Latin-American program, to be the new Ambassador to Colombia.

Helen Tamiris, the dancer and choreographer whose work ranged from the classical ballet to Broadway musicals, died yesterday of cancer at Jewish Memorial Hospital. She was 64 years old and lived at 36 West 73d Street.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 4 (AP) Dozens of radio stations throughout the United States are banning music by the Beatles because of a statement by one of the rock 'n' roll singers that his group is more popular than Jesus.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that Secretary of State Dean Rusk's plan to appoint a special assistant for refugee matters was inadequate as a permanent solution to the problem of unifying policy in this area.

New York city agreed yesterday to allow a lawyer for the Marine Enginers Beneficial Association to question the Director of Ferries on the union's charges that the Lindsay administration had conspired with another union in a jurisdictional dispute.
An alleged atomic bomb sketch that Julius and Ethel Rosenberg purportedly dilevered to the Soviet Union in 1945 was made public yesterday by a Federal judge.

ATLANTA, Aug. 4 Voter registration in six southern states has increased from 30 per cent of the eligible Negroes to 46 per cent in one year since the passage of the Voting Rights Act of 1965, the Southern Regional Council reported today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Aug. 5 (AP) United States B-52 bombers struck at the demilitarized zone between North and South Vietnam for the second consecutive day today. It was the fourth raid on the zone since Saturday.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 4 In a series of dawn swoops today, the Kenya police arrested five leaders of the country's Opposition party, the Kenya People's Union. They were put in detention without trial under powers recently given to President Jomo Kenyatta by Parliament.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) The Defense Department revised its casualty reporting system for the war in Vietnam today to include servicemen killed in action in Laos.

Ernest Hemingway and F. Scott Fitzgerald will be portrayed in "The Story of Two Afternoons," scheduled to arrive on Broadway late next month. The two-character drama was written by Trevor Reese, who will also produce it. Lester Mack will be seen as Mr. Hemingway and Martin Donegan as Mr. Fitzgerald.

For the second time since 1963, when the I.C.C. approved the merger plan of the Atlantic Coast Line and the Seaboard Air Line railroads, the United State Supreme Court will be asked to review the case.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 4 Lieut. Col. Yakubu Gowon, Nigeria's new military ruler, announced today that he would appoint soon a civilian advisory committee.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that a day-long "symposium on culture" would be held here in November to develop plans for a project to be known as Showcase '67.

WALL TOWNSHIP, N.J., Aug. 4 The nude body of a 19-year-old girl who police said was "brutally beaten to death" was found on a bridle path near Allaire State Park early today. It was the fourth such slaying in this area in less than a year. None of them has been solved.

LONDON, Aug. 4 (UPI) Prime Minister Wilson today announced the appointment of Sir Edmund Compton, the Auditor General, as Britain's first ombudsman a Queen's champion to defend the little man against unjust officialdom.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 4 (AP) President Ongania moved tonight to end the turmoil within the state universities by promising to restore their autonomy. However, he set no timetable.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Following is the text of the statement on steel price increases made today by Gardner Ackley, chairman of the President's council of Economic Advisers:
TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 5 (AP) The political purge sweeping Communist China has reached one of the three surviving founders of China's Communist party, Li Ta, president of Wuhan University.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 4 (AP) Gary Bell pitched a three-hitter and Leon Wagner provided two key singles tonight as the Cleveland Indians beat the Baltimore Orioles, 3-1.
The spot rate on the British pound moved up 5 points to $2.7904 in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. However, sterling for Monday eased back to $2,7893/95.
The steel industry's decision to raise prices on some of its most basic products is likely to provide the coup de grace for the Administration's sagging wage-price guideposts.
ALBANY, Aug. 4 Governor Rockefeller signed today a bill permitting New York City to build hundreds of millions of dollars worth of schools with apartments or offices above them.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) The Senate Rules Committee rebuffed President Johnson today by approving a less sweeping bill than he proposed to tighten controls over campaign contributions and spending.
Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman announced here yesterday that he had asked the Federal Trade Commission to open a nationwide investigation into recent food price increases.
LONDON, Aug. 4 A new plan for remodeling Piccadilly Circus, London's Times Square, was announced today.

OTTAWA, Aug. 4 Canada is urging a full investigation of violations of the demilitarized zone between North and South Vietnam, where United States planes have carried out bombing missions in recent days.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 4 Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Geng have announced the engagement of Mrs. Geng's daughter, Miss Diana Claire Millay of New York and Beverly Hills, Calif., to Geoffrey Montgomery Talbot Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew D.T. Jones of New York.
DUKE ELLINGTON and his orchestra, somewhat hoked up but welcome just the same, were the subjects of the fifth show last night on the WNEW-TV summer series "The Most in Music."

ELMONT, L.I., Aug. 4 An unruly and boisterous gang of about 50 swastika-wearing motorcyclists terrorized motorists and patrons of a tavern here last night before 20 of them were arrested by the police.

The drawing above is a duplication of an alleged sketch of the atomic bomb dropped on Nagasaki that David Greenglass testified he gave to Julius and Ethel Rosenberg in 1945 for transmission to the Soviet Union.
T. Reed Vreeland, an international banker and society leader, died Thursday at New York Hospital of cancer. He was 67 years old.

YONKERS, Aug. 4 Of the $148,082 wagered to win on the Yonkers Futurity Prep trot by 26,704 harness racing enthusiasts at Yonkers Raceway tonight, $83,488 backed Polaris, the favorite in the one-mile test for 3-year-olds. Carlisle, the second choice, attracted $26,201 at the win windows.

FREEPORT, L.I., Aug. 4 The engagement of Miss Laura Ellen Lee to Andrew John Pan has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Young Y. Lee. Mr. Pan is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Pan of the Bronx.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Aug. 4 Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, the recent challenger for the world chess title, held first place in the Piatigorsky Cup Tournament after drawing his 11th-round game with Wolfgang Unzicker of West Germany here last night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) The Post Office Department announced today that 24 more self-service postal stations would be installed in 23 cities within the next seven months.
ALBANY, Aug. 4 New York State will have a Council on Architecture to try to improve the design of its state buildings.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 4 (Reuters) Policemen arrested today 14 Hindu holy men who squatted for the last two weeks outside the home of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. They were protesting the killing of cows in India.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 Mr. and Mrs. Willis H. Satterthwaite have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Ellen W. Satterthwaite, to Peter C. Seibert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kingston S. Seibert of Maplewood, N.J., and Remsemburg, L.I.

The Right Rev. Msgr. Edward J. Begley, pastor of St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Union, N.J., for the last 30 years, died of cancer yesterday morning at St. Michael's Hospital in Newark. He was 79 years old.
The nation's money managers continued to keep the banking system on a tight rein in the week ended Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve System.

PARIS, Aug. 4 A French news agency dispatch from Hanoi said today that Tuesday's bombing of oil installations in the outskirts of the North Vietnamese port of Haiphong appeared to have been the costliest so far in civilian lives.
INWOOD, L.I, Aug. 4--The golfing Stuart brothers moved through two rounds as the metropolitan amateur championship started today.

CORNWALL, Conn., Aug. 4 Frederic Sondern Jr., a roving editor for The Reader's Digest, a war correspondent and a writer on crime and law enforcement, died here last night of cancer. He was 55 years old and lived at Cornwall Bridge.

John D. Pomfret, White House correspondent and labor reporter of The Washington Bureau of The New York Times, was named yesterday assistant to the director of the industrial relations staff of The Times.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. A high State Department official issued today the sharpest criticism of the new Argentine military regime that the United States Government has made.
Thailand's Foreign Minister Thanat Khoman has taken a useful initiative with his proposal for an Asian-sponsored peace conference on Vietnam.

Leaders of the Pressmen's Union here rejected fact-finding yesterday in their dispute with the World Journal Tribune, Inc. Mayor Lindsay, angered by the rejection, accused the union of flouting the pub- lic interest.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 4--Governor Rockefeller received a standing invitation from George D. Widener today to come to Saratoga whenever he wished. And, from the Widener standpoint, for a very good reason.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's $250-million debenture issue, offered Wednesday at a yield of 5.58 per cent, was estimated by underwriters late yesterday to be 65 per cent sold.

The trustees of the nonprofit corporation formed to save the old Metropolitan Opera House have found that it isn't really savable, after all. They gracefully stepped out of the way of the wrecker's ball and of the $484,000-a-year rent that the syndicate building an office tower on the leased site will pay to support the Metropolitan Opera Company in its majestic new hall in Lincoln Center.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 (AP) Home runs by Cookie Rojas and Johnny Briggs powered the Philadelphia Phils to their seventh straight victory tonight as they trounced Houston, 12-2.

**El Matador, 242 East 58th Street, 753-1110. This is a new Spanish-Mexican restaurant with somber lighting, red banquettes, a lot of-air-conditioning and occasional guitar music. The food may not be distinguished for its authentic nature, but it is palatable nonetheless. The menu embraces such dishes as seviche or mari-...
The Commercial Solvents Corporation has reached outside the family for its new president, but only in a manner of speaking.

The myth that the Negro is somehow incapable of liberating himself, is lazy, etc., came out of the American experience. In the books that children read, whites are always "good" (good symbols are white), blacks are "evil" or seen as savages in movies, their language is referred to as a "dialect," and black people in this country are supposedly descended from savages.
Mrs. Isabelle Fradis Goodstein died yesterday in Knickerbocker Hospital at the age of 83. She was the widow of Harris N. Goodstein and lived at 157 East 57th Street.
On the final day of his visit to the United States, Dr. Zalman Shazar, President of Israel, conferred privately with rep resentatives of several Jewish organizations at his suite in the Plaza Hotel.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Aug. 4 (UPI) A retired Army lieutenant colonel pleaded not guilty today to charges that he sold United States military secrets to the Russians for $5,500. He is free on $15,000 bond.
Institutional buyers returned to the London Stock Exchange yesterday to pick up bargains and prices quickly rose.

Net income of the El Paso Natural Gas Company rose to $9,017,511, or 33 cents a share, in the quarter ended June 30 from $8,491,537, or 30 cents a share, in the comparable period last year, the utility reported yesterday.
Gov. Richard J. Hughes of New Jersey gave tentative approval yesterday to the agreement that will permit prompt construction of the $525-million World Trade Center in lower Manhattan.
TEANECK, N.J., Aug. 4 Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Heimoff have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Ann Heimoff, to Daniel Arthur Relles, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Relles of Elberon.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., Aug. 4 George H. Rutherford, Mayor of the Village of Scarsdale, died of a heart attack at his home here yesterday morning. He was 66 years old.
Petitions for a referendum on the new civilian-dominated police review board are expected to be ruled invalid today.
Ron Swoboda, who won it in the ninth inning with a threerun, pinch-hit home run, said: "It was a story-book game. Holy Cow!" And it was just that.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4--The White House branded a steel price increase "irresponsible" and "inflationary" today, but the increase spread across the industry.

Louis W. Menk, who 10 months ago took over the presidency of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad, will become president and chief administrative officer of the Northern Pacific Railroad on Oct. 1. His successor on the Burlington has not been named.

An unusual function has been assigned to public relations in California, which has laid claim to being the nation's most populous state. And the assignment has been given to the world's largest advertising agency the J. Walter Thompson Company.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Aug. 4 Mr. and Mrs. Stephen J. Grob have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Florence Grob, to Mark Allan Levy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Levy of Chestnut Hill, Mass. An October wedding is planned.

The Right Rev. Santos Martin Molina, Bishop of the Spanish Reformed Church, who had been imprisoned at the time of the Spanish Civil War by the government of Generalissimo Francisco Franco, died Tuesday in Madrid. He was 65 years old.
Seventeen trustees were in search of a miracle, or even a millionaire, yesterday to help save the old Metropolitan Opera House. Neither was in sight last night.

The National Education Association expressed enthusiasm yesterday for the Ford Foundation's proposal that a nonprofit organization be established to distribute commercial and noncommercial television programs...
SHELTER ISLAND, L. I., Aug. 4--State Senator Edward J. Speno of Nassau County has been proposed as a Republican candidate to oppose Controller Arthur Levitt, a Democrat, in the November elections.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 4 Dave Zambri, an unheralded driving-range pro, retained his one-stroke lead in the 38th New Jersey State Professional Golfers Association championship today with his second 70 for a 36-hole total of 140. He shot 34, 36.
GENEVA, Aug. 4 Sweden pressed the United States and the Soviet Union today to agree to seek a preliminary accord that would bring underground nuclear testing to a stop by the end of this year.

BERLIN, Aug. 24 (AP) An East German weekly army newspaper identified Capt. Murphy Neal Jones of Baton Rouge, La., today as the first United States airman shot down near the North Vietnamese capital of Hanoi.
A new Democratic primary in the 19th Congressional District was ordered yesterday for Sept. 20 by State Supreme Court Justice George M. Carney.

CHAMONIX, France, Aug. 4 (AP)--An American airman fell to his death on the Matterhorn yesterday, and at least nine climbers from Germany and Japan were reported missing today in a snowstorm on Mont Blanc. Two other climbers died yesterday on Mont Blanc.

The operating companies in the Royal Dutch-Shell Group reported yesterday that net income for the first half of 1966 rose 6.4 per cent to $321,362,000 from $302,078,000 in the first six months of 1965.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 The Senate voted today to send striking airline mechanics back to work for 30 days and to give the President power to keep them there for 150 days more.

PARIS, Aug. 4 He was only 30 years old on the first of August and he is certainly not losing his hair or his waistline. But there are moments now when Yves Saint Laurent, a gifted and much copied designer, strains too hard to convince the world how much he is hand to-hand and eyeto-eye with the very young.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP) A three-member Federal court upheld today an Interstate Commerce Commission order permitting the Missouri Pacific Railroad (Mopac) to take control of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad.
MIAMI, Aug. 4 Mrs. Clarice, Wise Newsum has announced the engagement of her daughter Miss Mary Dianne Newsum, to Dr. Hampson A. Sisler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Sisler of Yonkers.

James J. Torpey, retired head sign electrician of The New York Times and the man who put the news in lights on Times Square for nearly 33 years, died Wednesday evening of leukemia at Queens General Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 15-94 212th Street, Bayside, Queens.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 4 The Philadelphia Orchestra led by Eugene Ormandy settled the big question tonight at the new Saratoga Performing Arts Center: How would the center's $2.6million amphitheater sound with a major symphony orchestra in it?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) A new program designed to provide a continuing check on the kinds and amounts of pesticides retained in the tissues of humans was announced tonight by the United States Public Health Service.

The junior committee of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association of the City of New York will hold its summer cocktail party, "Dans le Bois," Wednesday at the Tavern-on-the-Green in Central Park. The event will take place from 6 to 10 P.M.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 4 Supporting Vernon Law's strong pitching with a 16-hit attack, the Pittsburgh Pirates slipped back into the National League lead tonight by defeating the Los Angeles Dodgers, 8-1.

The size of audiences may or may not be an index of true cultural interest, but those drawn to the current Mozart festival at Philharmonic Hall are impressive. For an isolated program, one might expect a large attendance, but the festival, which opened on Monday, is running nightly for four weeks. On Wednesday, a chamber orchestra program drew 2,500 persons. Last night a quartet program brought in 2,300.

Look magazine is reported to have agreed to pay $650,000 for first serial rights to "The Death of a President," William Manchester's account of the assassination of President Kennedy. The book project was authorized and assisted by the Kennedy family.

An agreement was reached yesterday between negotiators for the major building contractors and 800 striking hoist engineers that is expected to reactivate the city's billion-dollar construction industry beginning Monday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) The House Merchant Marine Committee voted today to make the Maritime Administration, now part of the Commerce Department, an independent agency.
VINHLONG, South Vietnam, Aug. 3 The South Vietnamese Government is quietly doubling the capacity of its only rehabilitation center for delinquent girls, officials disclosed today.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. told a Bronx Reform Democratic Club last night that it would be a waste of money to send delegates to the party's convention in Buffalo next month "if this deal goes through."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) Administration officials asked the Senate Banking Committee today to approve a legislative package they said would restrain the intense competition for savings.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 The Forest Service formally added a 19,000 acre private estate of rolling forest land and lakes in Michigan's upper peninsula to the National Forest System today.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Aug. 4 (UPI)--Former President Harry S. Truman returned to his home today after a five-day hospital stay for treatment of colitis and an annual physical checkup.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP) Ernie Banks hit a homer and Dick Ellsworth ended a fivegame losing streak as the Chicago Cubs defeated the Atlanta Braves, 5-2, today.

CAIRO, Aug. 4--The United States is not expected to sign further aid agreements with the United Arab Republic for the sale of American wheat and other farm surpluses for soft currency, but will insist instead on being repaid in dollars, usually well informed sources disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) The American Jewish Congress opposed Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen's proposed constitutional amendment today under which public schools could provide for and permit voluntary prayer by students.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 4 Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Graeme Clarke Fincke of Pawling, N.Y., and Williamstown have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Magdalene Vanderburgh Fincke, to John Franklin Sears, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Franklin Sears of Williamstown and Hawley, Mass.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug.4 (AP) A Federal appeals court reversed today a decision that had given Eugene T. Connor, former Police Commissioner of Birmingham, Ala., a $40,000 libel judgment against The New York Times.

BONN In his opera "Don Giovanni," Mozart brings to life a massive statue of the Commendatore, who then proceeds to thunder minatory warnings. Beethoven, not Mozart, is Bonn's special composer, and this town is more given to symphonic than to operatic music.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 4 (Reuters) Indonesia's undeclared war against Malaysia, which has helped drain the economy for three years, will end within two weeks, it was officially forecast today.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 4 A year ago, when New York Jets rookies were called on to speak at a luncheon, Al Atkinson got to his feet, swallowed hard and said:

The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun to examine the subject of commission "give-ups" the splitting of commissions between two or more brokers in a move that could affect materially the ways that stock exchanges and mutual funds do business.
An extensive survey of the economics background of teachers of the social sciences in the city's public academic high schools has just been completed.
LONDON, Aug. 4 George Brown, the Labor Government Minister who is slated to become to "czar" of the proposed wage and price freeze, was likened today to Teddy Roosevelt.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 4 The victors, respectively, over Chuck McKinley and Stanley Smith, Peter Van Lingen of South Africa and George (Butch) Seewagen Jr. of Bayside, Queens, were eliminated today in the quarter-finals of the Nassau Bowl invitation grass court tennis tournament.
Albert L. Baldock was appointed yesterday by Richardson-Merrell, Inc., as president and general manager of its subsidiary, the J.T. Baker Chemical Company.

President Arjay Miller of the Ford Motor-Company left Moscow last-night after what the news agency Reuters described as a "secrecy-shrouded" fiveday visit, which included talks with Russian foreign-trade officials.

Seven of New York City's leading producers of highfashion apparel met yesterday with Mayor Lindsay, at his invitation, to discuss ways of improving the prestige and working conditions of the city's garment industry.

Torrance Machinery Engineering, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary in California of P F Industries, Inc., has practically closed a contract for the construction of a $10-million pipe mill in Iran, the parent company reported here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) Mentally ill persons acquitted of Federal crimes on grounds of insanity would be committed for psychiatric treatment under a bill introduced today by Senator Robert F. Kennedy.

AREA A Rough seas put a damper on the fishing for most of the week, but yesterday party boats were taking some fluke, sea bass and cod. The boats going for blues were finding them in the six or seven pound class.
AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 4 A Texas grand jury said tonight, after reading three notes left by Charles J. Whitman, that the sniper "obviously did not intend to be taken alive."

BLACKPOOL, England, Aug. 4 In a somewhat improbable setting, a somewhat improbable challenger for the world heavyweight championship goes through the motions of training for a goal that is virtually unattainable. Brian London, a journeyman fighter of such little distinction that he isn't even ranked among the top 10 by Ring Magazine, will attempt on Saturday to dislodge the crown from its secure perch on Cassius Clay's noggin.

TORONTO, Aug. 4 (Canadian) Press) Realizable value of the assets of the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation, Ltd., was placed at $85,071,751 in the 1965 year-end statements issued yesterday by the Montreal Trust Company, Atlantic's receiver and manager.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 4 The official Cambodian radio, monitored here, said Monday that a nine-member "Americans Want to Know" fact-finding group had ascertained that there was "complete tranquillity" in Cambodia's border areas.

ATHENS, Aug. 4 Expulsion orders have been served on two Turkish citizens living in Greece "in retaliation for the recent ousting of two Greek citizens from Istanbul," a Government spokesman said today.

NEWARK, Aug. 4 Warren W. Wilentz, the United States Senate candidate of New Jersey's Democratic party leaders, established himself today as an enthusiastic supporter of President Johnson's Vietnam policy.
BRUSSELS, Aug, 4 The possibility that one day there will be a more normal relationship between Jews and Germany was broached here tonight in cautious terms by prominent Germans and Jews.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Officials here are gravely concerned that last Friday's army mutiny in Nigeria may result in breaking up black Africa's largest and most prosperous nation.

A GROUP of long-haired musicians called the Eng- lish Setters tuned up their electric guitars, twanged into a solid rock number called "Someday You'll See" and the preview of Macy's International Menswear Collection opened this week to members of the press and other guests. There followed a dazzling display of colors, vivid and violent; bold fabrics; and unaccustomed cuts, and suddenly one 45-year-old man in the audience was turned into a senior citizen.
MONTREAL, Aug. 4 The leaders of the American Bar Association moved today to throw the group's prestige behind a new law to deal with transportation strikes.
