The House of Representatives has turned in a melancholy performance on the open-housing section of the Civil Rights bill.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 The Rev. William F. Graney, assistant editor of The New World, the official weekly newspaper of the Chicago Roman Catholic Archdiocese, said in a signed editorial today that "Catholic Know Nothings" cursed and injured a nun.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 4 Britain asked the Security Council today to call upon the United Arab Republic and Yemen to cease attacks on South Arabian territory that is under British Administration.
PARIS, Aug. 4 Jacques Fouques-Duparc, a career diplomat who served France for 42 years, died today at the age of 69. He had retired in 1963.
A 45 per cent share of the Paris edition of The New York Herald Tribune has been sold to The Washington Post.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4--The Defense Department issued a draft call today for 46,200 men in October--the highest monthly figure since the Korean War.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4--The Defense Department issued a draft call today for 46,200 men in October--the highest monthly figure since the Korean War.

COMMACK, L.I., Aug. 4 A father of 12 was dismissed from his job with the Suffolk County Department of Labor today for allegedly enrolling dozens of ineligible youths in an antipoverty program, including some who were not poor.
The president of Fanny Farmer Candy Shops, Inc., resigned yesterday and was replaced by a representative of the company's controlling stockholder.
Prices advanced for the second consecutive session on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, despite a White House statement decrying the recent rise in steel prices.

The shipping bottleneck in Saigon harbor that had threatened the flow of supplies to troops in Vietnam has been "completely cleared up," Thomas W. Gleason, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, said yesterday.

DENVER, Aug. 4 New York players scored poor- ly this afternoon as the life master pair championship play entered its final stage with 56 pairs competing. The best performances were by Charles Coon, who scored...
CLEVELAND, Aug. 4 (UPI) A former United States amateur champion, Labron Harris Jr., fired a six-under-pan 65 today to take the first-round lead in the $100,000 Cleveland open golf tournament.

Plans of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee to stage a protest march to the White House tomorrow on Luci Baines Johnson's wedding day drew a sharp rebuke from four national Negro leaders yesterday.

OLNEY, Md., Aug. 4 Any dramatization of a great novel is, in effect, two plays one for those who know the book and another for those who don't. (With a lesser novel, the split is not so wide because the book's hold on those who know it is less.) An adapter has to satisfy both audiences at once. I doubt that Hugh Leonard succeeds with either.

MONT GABRIEL, Que., Aug. 4 Roger and Kathryn Bohl of Holmdel, N.J., riding in a new Porsche 912, led the MG Car Club 1,000-mile rally through its second stage today. The 59 teams competing in this 14th annual international event started from the Syracuse Hotel Country House at 8 this morning. The first cars arrived here this afternoon shortly before 5 o'clock. The rally began yesterday at the Stratford (Conn.) Motor Inn.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) The resignation of Franklin R. Saul of Belleville, N.J., as assistant to the Secretary of the Treasury for debt management was announced yesterday
An agreement to merge Southern Nitrogen Company, Inc., into the Kaiser Aluminum Chemical Corporation was announced here yesterday. The transaction would involve $40.8-million.
Trustees of the Sixty Trust, a Textron, Inc., employers' pension fund, have filed a $3.5-million damage suit against United Investors Corporation, a real estate development concern.
Julius Monk, who has produced 15 pint-sized satirical revues during the last 11 years, is abandoning the genre.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Aug. 4 (Reuters)--The Sudan's new Premier, Sadik el-Mahdi, announced today a new Cabinet to replace that of Mohammed Ahmed Mahgoub, who resigned with his Government 10 days ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Compulsory arbitration of disputes in the airline, railroad and maritime industries is recommended by management lawyers on a special committee of the American Bar Association's labor relations law section.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 The Green Bay Packers, considered by many to be the best football team in the world and expected to be even better this year, came down from the woods of Wisconsin today to do battle with the College All-Stars here tomorrow night. The Packers, who somehow lost to the AllStars and mortified their coach, Vincent Lombardi, three years ago, are largely fit and terribly ready.
BONN, Aug. 4 Chancellor Ludwig Erhard interrupted his vacation today and returned to Bonn to deal with the mounting economic and political problems threatening his Government.

PARIS, Aug. 4 Forty miles south of Toulouse, near a highway along which vacationers speed to the Spanish coast, a gray concrete slab stands barely visible above the encroaching corn. In tarnished copper, with some letters worn away, it bears the legend:

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 A position paper, written last winter by dissident members of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee and still considered confidential, shows that the organization's new "black power" philosophy was the product of months of planning.
The Suffolk Board of Supervisors has been ordered to present reapportionment proposals to the county electorate this November within restrictions set down yesterday by a special Federal panel.

About four years ago a group of homeowners in low-lying Rosedale, Queens, appealed to the city for storm sewers. What they are getting, however, are new streets. And they are getting so much of the new streets that they have told the District Attorney that they are being "buried."

WOODMERE, L.I., Aug. 5. The engagement of Miss Lynn Shweitzer to Jeffrey Slutsky has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Shweitzer, parents of the bride-to-be. Mr. Slutsky is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Slutsky of Ellenville, N.Y.

PURDYS, N.Y., Aug. 5. Louis Grossman, a retired manufacturer of women's neckwear and an honorary industry chairman of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of Greater New York, died early this morning at his summer home here. He also maintained a residence at 350 Central Park West, New York City. He was 75 years old.

ATHERTON, Calif., Aug. 5 Mr. and Mrs. William Keene Langhorne have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dana Forsyth Langhorne, to John Stephen Major, son of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Major of Bergenfield, N.J.
Gustave G. Rosenberg, the controversial chairman of the Board of Higher Education, was appointed yesterday by Mayor Lindsay to be chairman of the newly created City University Construction Fund.

STORM JAMESON'S newest novel will remind readers of those drawing room comedies that a great many New Yorkers still yearn after. The furnishings were always expensive, the women elegant, the men imperious; manners were flawless, the conversation crisp and literate. Of course, that was only the veneer.

Stock market activity on the big New York exchanges remains a major influence on the trading pace and price movements of the nation's regional exchanges. But the regional markets are still no mirror image of the big New York boards.
Miss Kathleen Gross, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Gross of Cleveland, was married yesterday to Thomas Lucatorto, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Lucatorto of the Bronx.

Under a program that will start in a few weeks, the city will ease the agony of women addicts undergoing withdrawal pains in police station cells while awaiting arraignment and commitment to a prison ward or a house of detention.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Aug. 5, (AP) Dr. Benjamin H. Pershing, a historian and a theologian affiliated with Wittenberg University here for 40 years, died last night in a hospital at Heflin, Ala., after a stroke. He was 78 years old.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 5 William Steinberg led the Philadelphia Orchestra tonight in its second concert at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5, (UPI) The Senate today approved sections of a bill on nationwide standards of benefits for the jobless, but rebelled at accepting the full proposal of its Finance Committee.

New York is a city of sounds: muted sounds and shrill sounds; shattering sounds and soothing sounds; urgent sounds and aimless sounds. The cliff dwellers of Manhattan who would be racked by the silence of the lonely woods do not hear these sounds because they are constant and eternally urban.
IF the City of New York had scoured the earth for a man to sign its marriage licenses, it would have been hard-pressed to find a more unlikely looking Cupid than Herman Katz.
The early morning quiet along the Hudson River waterfront was shattered yesterday as construction began on the $525-million World Trade Center.

BONN, Aug. 5--Middle-of-the-night police raids and arrests of the kind conducted against the news magazine Der Spiegel and its staff four years ago do not violate West Germany's Constitution, the Federal Constitutional Court ruled today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) The Rev. Robert B. McNeill of Charleston, W. Va., a Presbyterian minister, said today, in urging adoption of a school prayer amendment, that "schools need not only Federal aid but divine aid."
Fifty summonses were handed out on the first night of a crackdown on taxicabs operating illegally in Queens, District Attorney Nat H. Hentel announced yesterday.
BOYKIN, S.C., Aug. 5 Dr. Harry Stoll Mustard, New York's Commissioner of Health from 1947 to 1950, died yesterday at Kershaw County Memorial Hospital in Camden. He was 77 years old.

TOKYO, Aug. 5 The Japanese Government, in an effort to ease a sharp dispute with South Korea, announced today that it was postponing indefinitely the issuance of entry visas to three North Korean technicians.

The wreckage that now marks the spot once occupied by the Administration's anti-inflation guideposts lends urgency to President Johnson's plea to business and labor leaders for "responsible" decisions on prices and wages. But the chances that anyone will pay much heed to the new White House appeal are reduced by the Administration's continued unwillingness to provide any leadership for its own policies.

PORTILLO, Chile, Aug. 5, (AP) Annie Famose, a diminutive star of the French team, captured the women's slalom, opening race of the 1966 World Alpine ski championship today. The four American competitors finished among the top eight.
Hundreds of splash-happy youngsters took 15-minute turns yesterday in what the city hopes will be only the first of many vest-pocket swimming pools in poor neighborhoods.
Mayor Lindsay vetoed a City Council bill yesterday that would have given the Transit Authority $84.3-million to revive the 15-cent transit fare.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 5 Mrs. John H. Bartol of Stanwich won the women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association championship for the eighth time today. In a scheduled 36-hole final at Wykagyl Country Club, she defeated Mrs. William R. Loweth of Wykagyl, 3 and 2, after being 3 down four times during the morning round.

BONN, Aug. 5. A spokesman for Volkswagen said in Wolfsburg today that all Volkswagens produced for export to the United States since Aug. 1 were fitted with dual independent braking systems. This insures that if the main system fails, the car can still be brought to a stop with the emergency brake.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5--The Green Bay Packers routed the College All-Stars, 38-0, tonight before a crowd of 72,000 as Jim Taylor scored two touchdowns. The margin of defeat equaled the record for this game, which was first staged in 1934. In 1949 the Philadelphia Eagles beat the All-Stars, 38-0, too.

BILL BLASS, who designs for many well-dressed mothers and two years ago began dressing their daughters, is now designing for the young sons of the house. His boys' clothes, manufactured by Celeste, will join the girls' dresses in stores this fall.

AS the heavier furniture of the 17th century has become more interesting to collectors, bolder and less delicate wares such as delft are regaining popularity. However, the time is still right for making acquisitions from antiques shops at prices that are not staggering.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Aug. 6--American fighter-bombers attacked oil depots and radar sites in the Haiphong area yesterday and eluded six Soviet-made missiles, the United States command announced today.
DETROIT, Aug. 5, (UPI) Passenger-car production for 1966 is now 600,000 units below last year's pace, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
New York's three professional football teams (up one from last year) make their preseason debuts today on widely scattered fields.

The petitions of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and the Conservative party asking for a referendum on the civilian-dominated police review board were ruled invalid yesterday, setting the stage for a court fight.
HAVANA, Aug. 5 (AP) The evacuation of 880 United States citizens who have been seeking to leave Cuba for two years will begin next Friday, the Swiss Embassy announced today.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 5. Taking his cue from his countryman, Peter Van Lingen, who put out Chuck McKinley on Wednesday, Ray Moore of South Africa defeated Frank Froehling 3d of New York in the Nassau Bowl invitation grass court tournament today.
PITTSBURGH "Call it offseason dullness," said whitehaired James V. Kissane, as the Pittsburgh Stock Exchange meandered its way through another quiet trading session.
LONDON, Aug. 5 Brian London has a lantern jaw that will serve as a beckoning target to Cassius Clay tomorrow when they meet at Earls Court for the heavyweight championship of the world.

PARIS, Aug. 5, (Reuters) The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said in a report issued today that output and trade in its 21 member-countries are expected to show near-record gains this year.
The A.B. Dick Company, a Chicago producer of officeduplicating equipment, announced yesterday the election of Edison Warner Dick and James L. Peirce as directors.

Julius H. Heldman of New York and Robert J. Freedman of Springfield, Mass., won the first two singles matches yesterday to give the defending United States team a 2-0 lead over Canada for the Stevens Cup.
The American Stock Exchange registered its third consecutive advance yesterday in quiet trading.

The memory of street organs grinding out popular Italian operatic tunes made the performance of "Lucia di Lammermoor" at Lewisohn Stadium last night seem perfectly natural. The clearly defined melodies, the oom-pah-pah rhythms and the bang-up climaxes made their effect easily in the open air. Even if the Donizetti work can be a much richer experience in the opera house, the Metropolitan Opera's concert version at the stadium was most enjoyable.
"You can't teach in Harlem from just 9 A.M. to 3 P.M.," a Negro civic leader told 22 new teachers in the city's ghetto schools the other day.
MOSCOW, Aug. 5 The United States Embassy refused today to accept a Soviet protest note alleging "provocation and criminal actions" against Soviet merchant ships delivering cargoes to North Vietnam.
MENLO PARK, Calif., Aug. 5, (AP) Order was restored today to the East Menlo Park area where reinforced policemen, with dogs, put down a riotous disturbance by stonethrowing Negro youths last night.
John F. Burke, a retired newspaper publisher, radio station owner and a drafter of the Prohibition Amendment, died last Wednesday at a nursing home in Altadena, Calif. His age was 93.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5, (AP) Ron Santo's two-run bases filled single with one out in the 10th inning enabled the Chicago Cubs to defeat the San Francisco Giants, 4-3, today.
CHESTER SPRINGS, Pa., Aug. 5, (UPI) Clifton Lisle, who was decorated in both world wars and was also an author and teacher, died at his home yesterday. He was 74 years old.
ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 5, (UPI) Gary Peters pitched a five-hitter and Tom Agee and John Romano hit home runs tonight as the Chicago White Sox downed the California Angels, 3-1.

SUTTON, Mass., Aug. 5, (UPI) A former world tennis queen, Althea Gibson, shot a record-shattering six-under-par 68 today to take a four-stroke lead in the opening round of the $15,000, 54-hole Lady Carling eastern open golf championship at the Pleasant Valley Country Club. The course is 6,280 yards long.

LAKE WORTH, Fla., Aug. 5, (AP) Charles J. Whitman and the first of his 15 victims his mother were buried today in a religious service that included their pastor's prayer for their escape from "the judgement of vengeance."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 As a solution to the armored-car holdup problem, three inventors propose to siphon the day's receipts out of a safe in a store's front window at night.
BEER cans are going to women's heads. So are the ones made for apple juice, tomato sauce and other supermarket staples. An East Side beauty salon cuts the ends off and uses them for hair curlers.

MOUNT SNOW, Vt., Aug. 5--Roger and Kathryn Bohl of Holmdel, N. J., clung to the lead today through the third stage of the MG Car Club's 1,000-mile rally, a journey of close to 300 miles, with a total of 159 penalty points. They are competing in a Porsche 912.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 The House Committee on Un-American Activities will hold at least three days of hearings beginning Aug. 16, on a proposal to make it unlawful for American citizens to send aid to North Vietnam.

The State Health Commissioner yesterday announced the formation of a permanent, interdepartmental committee to advise him on any changes in physicians' fees and fees for services under Medicaid and other state and local health programs.

GENEVA, Aug. 5 Recommendations made more than two years ago by a world conference for speeding the economic advancement of the poorer lands through trade have resulted so far "only in isolated measures taken by individual countries," a United Nations report said today.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the city would have to pay higher salaries to the men managing its complex affairs.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 5. Ernest Cardone, who rides lightly regarded Staunchness in tomorrow's $55,600 Whitney Handicap here, warmed up for that longshot assignment today by winning with four nonfavorites.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 President Johnson, his wife, the bride, the bridegroom, and all the other principals of the wedding of the year were present at a rehearsal today at the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception.
SAIGON, Aug. 4--"Nguyen Cao Ky is a very good pilot," the cynics here used to say, "but Vietnam is not an airplane."
Mr. Antoine Domino Jr., the noted Fats of New Orleans, has in recent years become less noticeable, although richer, being now a fixture in the golden deserts of Las Vegas.

Anthony A. Barnett and W. Fred Goodyear have been named vice presidents of the business and industry division of the Bunker-Ramo Corporation, an electronic data processing equipment manufacturer, which is controlled by the Martin Marietta Corporation.

HIROSHIMA, Japan, Aug. 5--The annual pilgrimage of Japanese leftists to Hiroshima for the anniversary of the atomic bombing that devastated this city on Aug. 6, 1945, appears to have intensified the growing revulsion of Japanese Communists against extremism in Communist China.
The city's billion-dollar construction industry faced new trouble yesterday in its efforts to end a strike of 6,200 plumbers.
WAYNESBORO, Pa., Aug. 5. Dr. Grant Thornton, head of the pulmonary-disease clinic of the Lenox Hill Hospital until 1950, died of pneumonia yesterday. His age was 79.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 President Eisenhower explained in a news conference on July 21, 1954, why the United States would not sign the Geneva agreements. He said that he was glad agreement had been reached to "stop the bloodshed" but that the Geneva accords contained "features which we do not like, but a real deal depends on how they work in practice."

Harry E. Brager, president of Brager Co., Inc., investment and underwriting brokers of 54 Wall Street, died of a heart attack Thursday afternoon in a taxicab at Wall and Water Streets. He was 48 years old and lived at 501 East 87th Street.
GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 5 (UPI) A Greenwich father who puffed anxiously on cigarettes while his wife gave birth to a son in their home has been treated for "smoke inhalation."
BONN, Aug. 5 Soviet charges that West Germany has troops in Vietnam have touched a sensitive spot in this capital.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5, (AP) The Organization of American States postponed indefinitely today a conference of hemisphere foreign ministers that had been scheduled for Buenos Aires before the military seized power in Argentina.

Patients have died in the city's hospitals for lack of adequate nursing. Only 40 per cent of the registered nursing posts are filled in the municipal hospitals; the ratio in the voluntary hospitals is nearly twice as high. Low pay, depressing conditions and lack of professional esteem in the municipal institutions help account for the difference. Nurses have been seen scrubbing floors and fighting off drunks, while surgeons have had to give nursing care.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 5, (AP) A panel of three Federal judges ordered the Missouri General Assembly today to redistrict Congressional districts in accordance with the Supreme Court's one-man, onevote decision.
Question, Mr. Secretary, the Soviet Union has charged that the United States planes have attacked its ships in the Haiphong harbor. Has this occurred? And what is U.S. policy on this question?
The W.E.B. DuBois Clubs denied yesterday charges made before a Cleveland grand jury last week that the organization had fomented the recent riots in that city and Chicago.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 5, (AP) Indonesia's jungled, primitive West Irian has been rocked by riots serious enough to call Foreign Minister Adam Malik to the scene as a mediator, reliable sources reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5, (AP) Joe Torre and Denis Menke drove in five ninth-inning runs with homers tonight as the Atlanta Braves whipped Philadelphia, 9-2, and snapped the Phillies' winning streak at seven games.

GENEVA, Aug. 5, (Reuters) International action against the misuse of hallucination drugs, "pep pills," tranquilizers and other hazardous drugs will be discussed here by a special United Nations committee next week.

For grain traders yesterday, the big news of the day was a crop report issued by Conrad Leslie, crop estimator for Lamson Bros. Co. He regularly publishes his forecast a little ahead of the regular Government crop estimates.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 A joint United States-Puerto Rican commission, after a twoyear study, recommended today that the Puerto Rican people themselves should decide by plebiscite whether to continue in commonwealth status, be independent or apply for state-hood.

BUENOS AIRES. Aug. 5 A plea for more time to transform Argentina's economic and social life and a sharp denunciation of Communism highlighted the first news conference of President Juan Carlos Ongania late last night.
Negotiations in the newspaper dispute between the Pressmen's Union and the World Journal Tribune, Inc., remained at a standstill yesterday.
RAYMOND LOSEY
AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 5. A group of medical specialists should have a report within a month on the mental and physical condition of Charles J. Whitman during the last 48 hours of his life.

BERLIN, Aug. 5 East Germany charged today at the opening of a trial that the United States' Central Intelligence Agency had sought to induce an East German Air Force pilot to fly a Sovietbuilt MIG-21 containing secret equipment to the West.

Hall Park McCullough, a member of an old New England family and a lawyer here for 70 years, died yesterday at his home in North Bennington, Vt. He was 94 years old and lived also at 1035 Fifth Avenue.
The city used Albert and Larry Gallo, leaders of a Cosa Nostra faction in Brooklyn, as peacemakers during the recent outbreaks of racial violence in East New York.
Charles A. Buckley, leader of the regular Democratic organization in the Bronx, said yesterday that Reform Democrats had tried to make a deal with him to divide up four judicial nominations.
THE PARTIES The International Association of Machinists and Eastern, National, Northwest, United and Trans World airlines.

YONKERS, Aug. 5, (UPI) Nelson Guy, a 4-5 favorite driven by Lucien Fontaine, won the $15,000 Fleetwood Handicap tonight, beating Chicago King by three-quarters of a length before 29,611 fans at Yonkers Raceway.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5, (AP) The Federal Trade Commission said today that it was seeking civil penalties of $35,000 against a New York company that it said had violated an order to stop importing and selling highly flammable clothing.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5--The Rev. Laurence E. Henderson, professor of classical studies at Loyola and a former member of the university's board of trustees, died today. He was 59 years old.
LA GRANGE, Ill., Aug. 5. Mrs. Lambert Snyders, secretary of the Illinois Congress of Conservatives, announced today that circulation of petitions to form an independent party had been stopped.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5, (AP) The Federal Power Commission refused today to omit the examiner's decision procedure in a case involving competing proposals to move natural gas from western to eastern Canada by way of the North Central United States.
Theology can be learned in East Harlem tenements as well as in classrooms and libraries, according to a group of students from Union Theological Seminary.
The Federal National Mortgage Association (Fanny May) announced plans yesterday to sell $350-million of 5 7/8 per cent debentures next Wednesday.
CLEVELAND. Aug. 5, (AP) Bob Goalby shot a four-under par 67 today and tied Gay Brewer at 135 for the lead in the $100,000 Cleveland open golf tournament. Brewer posted a 68.

DALLAS, Aug. 5 Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. J. Kenneth Haviland of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Elizabeth Haviland, to Michael Levine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Levine of Lowell, Mass.

Mr. and Mrs. Sam Schoenfeld of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sally Anne Schoenfeld, to Jack Oppenheim, son of Mrs. Jack N. Oppenheim of New York and the late Mr. Oppenheim.
A veil has begun to rise over the begrimed face of the Old Lady of 39th Street.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 5. Salisbury's multiracial Univresity College has announced it will reopen Sept. 5 to "discharge its immediate responsibilities to students in the current year."
Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed with a majority of small gains yesterday after a modest trading session.
Airliner Pilot Dies in Flight

TOKYO, Aug. 5, (AP) The Nationalist Chinese Embassy said today that Douglas Mendel, an associate professor of political science at the University of Wisconsin, had been denied a visa to visit Taiwan because of "anti-Nationalist Chinese activities."

The Continental Casualty Company reported yesterday for the first six months net income from operations of $3,217,593, equal to 41 cents a share. This contrasts with $214,603, or 3 cents a share, for the corresponding half of 1965. At that time the company had the benefit of a tax credit of $2.9-million.
Eddie Neloy won't have anything going today in the $15,000 White Mountain Handicap at Rockingham Park, Salem, N.H., or the $20,000 San Diego at Del Mar in California.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 5, (AP) Gordie Coleman's homer in the sixth inning snapped a tie tonight as the surging Cincinnati Reds defeated the National League-leading Pittsburgh Pirates, 4-3.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz today described the Senate-passed bill to end the airline strike as a "workable amalgamation."

A Suffolk County employe has lost his job on charges that he gave jobs in the Neighborhood Youth Corps to youngsters who were too well off or too well schooled to qualify. The overzealous recruiter, a father of twelve earning $6,700 a year, may have thought he knew better than antipoverty rule makers in Washington what constitutes need.

A Coast Guard hearing on charges of negligence against the second pilot involved in the two-tanker collision that took 33 lives in the Kill Van Kull on June 16, was postponed yesterday until next Wednesday.
Saks Fifth Avenue this week opened a Bye Bye Shop for marked-down fashion merchandise from its regular departments.
VANCOUVER, B.C. Lumber producers in British Columbia are facing an uncertain outlook as a result of several adverse economic developments.

Brian Epstein, manager of the Beatles, flew here late Thursday hoping to quell a storm. The storm blew up from a remark by the quartet's leader, John Lennon, who was quoted as saying that the Beatles were, more popular than Jesus.

HIROSHIMA, Saturday, Aug. 6, (UPI) Thirty thousand citizens of Hiroshima assembled at the city's Peace Memorial Park today on the anniversary of the atomic bombing and pledged anew their hopes for world peace.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 5 The Board of Education today accused an alderman of moving a house onto land that it controls adjacent to the Mount Vernon High School. It ordered him to remove the house within 10 days.

DENVER, Aug. 5 Hermine Baron and Meyer Schleifer of Los Angeles won the life master pair championship here this afternoon with a score of 354 for a total of 783. They thus qualified for the international team trials to be held in November.
The shipping industry's first checks in payment to the port's longshoremen under the annual work guarantee will be mailed during the last week of this month.
The National Tea Company has invited shareholders to tender their common stock to the company for purchase at $16 a share, Norman A. Stepelton, president, announced yesterday.
LONDON, Aug. 5, (Reuters) The state-run British Overseas Airways Corporation is seeking to extend its routes into Communist China. Sir Giles Guthrie, the airline's chairman, said today.

The spot rate on the British pound fell in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The loss was 9 points, which traders considered average for a Friday. It left the rate at $2.7893.
PARIS, Aug. 5, (UPI) About the only people who must be pleased with the continuing airline strike in the United States are officials of the French national tourist office.
The Joint Legislative Committee on Public Health will hold public hearings this fall to investigate the shortage of registered nurses in New York and state procedures for licensing foreign nurses.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. The United States took another step today in its efforts to improve relations with Cambodia by giving public recognition to the achievement of its ruler, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, in keeping his country out of the fighting that has ravaged its neighbors.
The 29-day-old airline strike has delayed the struck carriers' plans for ordering new equipment.
ALBANY, Aug. 5 The state's share of pari-mutuel revenues from the spring meet at Roosevelt Raceway totaled $9,810,318, State Tax Commissioner Joseph H. Murphy reported today.

CHICAGO, Saturday, Aug. 6. The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was struck by a stone yesterday as a crowd of whites raged out of control and battled policemen in a white resi- dential area of Chicago.
The Paramount Pictures Corporation, the first of the film companies slated to be acquired by a big industrial concern, reported a loss of $852,000 in the second quarter ended July 2.

The National Broadcasting Company yesterday became the third network to announce plans for presenting original dramas. The network's decision followed earlier announcements by the American Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 5 The 36 African member states have urged U Thant to stay on as Secretary. General after his term expires in November.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 5, (AP) Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon denounced critics of President Johnson's Vietnam policy today but added that the Administration had failed to make clear its goals.

The Federal Aviation Agency said yesterday that it had decided to lift an air traffic restriction at La Guardia Airport that has prevented jets from landing and taking off over Jackson Heights, Queens.

The reasoning City Clerk Herman Katz used in dismissing the petitions for a referendum on the reconstituted police review board seems persuasive to the layman, but the final word undoubtedly will lie with the courts.

The Federal Trade Commission has approved a consent decree dissolving joint ventures of the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation and the Phillips Petroleum Company, according to a statement both companies released yesterday.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 5, (AP) Frank J. Langr of Northville, founder in 1951 and first president of the New York State Supervisors Association, died Thursday in Albany Medical Center Hospital. He was 59 years old.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 5, (AP) Ken McMullen and Fred Valentine hit consecutive homers in the first inning tonight to pace the Washington Senators to a 4-2 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

CAIRO, Aug. 5 The United States is investigating the seizure of a cargo of American equipment by Egyptian authorities under the Arab boycott of Israel. The cargo was seized as it was passing through the Suez Canal in a Dutch ship.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Aug. 5 Fourteen British employes of the former High Commission, who remained in Dar es Salaam after Tanzania broke diplomatic relations with Britain last December over the Rhodesian issue, left the country last night.
Four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 7.8 per cent in production for the week ended July 30, compared with the level in the corresponding 1965 week.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 5, (Reuters) American bombing of the demilitarized zone dividing the two Vietnams has focused attenton on "the loneliest men in Vietnam" the staff of the International Control Commission.
Seymour Goodman, president and a director of the Lexington Life Insurance Company of New York, died yesterday in his apartment at 143-40 Roosevelt Avenue, Flushing, Queens. He was 56 years old.

The two largest unions representing employes of Long Island Rail Road announced yesterday they would accept an offered wage increase of 3.2 per cent but only as "an interim down payment" on a much larger final settlement.

With the police closing in on his Bronx hideout yesterday, a robbery suspect started a fire to escape in the confusion. But the fire got too hot for him and he ran out, into the arms of detectives, leaving his fully loaded automatic behind.
William J. (Willie the Midge) Smith, a retired boxer, died yesterday in Jewish Memorial Hospital, Broadway at 196th Street, after a long illness. He was 66 years old.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 5 Brazil's major labor group today challenged the Government's one-year freeze on wage increases as unconstitutional and a threat to "social peace."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 President Johnson warned today that the Government might have to cut its spending "in those areas where prices are rising in an inflationary way."

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5. Dock workers of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union have ratified a new five-year contract with the Pacific Maritime Association calling for 90 cents an hour in wage improvements during the life of the agreement. The new contract also embraces an extension of a mechanization and modernization program initiated in the six-year pact signed in 1960.

Net income of the Florida East Coast Railway fell sharply in the first half of 1966, and as a result the carrier cannot pay the September semiannual interest on its second mortgage bonds, the company said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 After three days of debate, the House approved today the compromise open-housing section of President Johnson's civil rights bill of 1966.
HOUSTON, Aug. 5, (AP) Sandy Koufax breezed to his 18th victory tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers exploded for 18 hits and battered the Houston Astros, 12-1, before a crowd of 46,555.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Aug. 5 George W. Leaird and Mrs. Rosalie Powell Leaird have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Anne Leaird, to the Rev. Richard E. Ittner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Ittner of Indianpolis.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 Is it possible to transfer learning by injection?
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Aug. 5 The currency introduced a month ago after Tanzania broke from the East African Currency Union is causing trouble with the Masai.

Weddings are happy events because they express deep, affirmative human sentiments: joy as love is consecrated in marriage; hope as two people begin life's most civilized adventure; and the pride of parents who have successfully raised children to bear the responsibilities of adulthood and marriage. All these sentiments are present today in churches great and small across the nation as couples plight their troth before families and friends.
Pincus E. Rudoy, a writer for The Day-Jewish Journal, died Tuesday at his home in San Jose, Calif., where he had lived since 1952. He was 81 years old.
John B. Aird, a member of the Canadian Senate and also of the Toronto law firm of Edison, Aird and Berlis, has been elected a director of American Metal Climax, Inc.
CAIRO After a long absence, product names such as Christian Dior, Elizabeth Arden, Jantzen of London, Yardley and Balenciaga have reappeared on Egyptian shelves.
Mayor Lindsay pleaded yesterday for Federal control of the sale of firearms.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 5, (AP) Gov. Enrique Dupre Ceniceros of the state of Durango has been impeached by direct request of President Gustavo Diaz Ordaz.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 Secretary of State Dean Rusk suggested today that the United States did not exclude the possibility of sending ground troops into North Vietnam.

AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 5, (AP) "I am prepared to die," said Charles J. Whitman in a note written only hours before he turned the University of Texas campus into a slaughtering ground for 16 persons, including himself.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 5 One thing about the Yankees: all joking aside, they still get stronger as the evening wears on.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Aug. 5. Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, a Grand Master and the recent challenger for the world chess title, retained first place in the Piatigorsky Cup tournament despite the adjournment of his 12th-round game with Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N.Y., last night at the Miramar Hotel.

HILLSIDE, N.J., Aug. 5 John A. Desch of 854 Winchester Avenue, a former mayor here and a senior auditing assistant for the Public Service Electric and Gas Company of Newark, died yesterday of a heart attack at the age of 50.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. The index of primary market prices declined one-fifth of 1 per cent to 106.3 (1957-59 equals 100) during the week ended Aug. 2, the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products and processed foods moved lower in price while industrial commodities averaged unchanged.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 5 Malaysia, Thailand and the Philippines announced today plans to cooperate on 33 proj ects, including a joint shipping line and an economic development fund.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 5 Miss. Betsey Meryl Watten berg's engagement to Arthur Selkowitz of Stamford has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Wattenberg. Her fiance is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harry Selkowitz.

The defeat of Senator Ross Bass for renomination in the Democratic primary in Tennessee is a distinct loss. He was elected in 1964 to fill the unexpired term of the late Estes Kefauver. During the past two years, as well as in his previous decade of service in the House of Representatives, Mr. Bass proved himself conscientious, constructive and progressive minded.
INWOOD, L.I., Aug. 5. An 18-year-old blond, Eugene (Bud) Zachary of Glen Rock, N.J., played spectacular golf today to gain the semi-finals of the metropolitan amateur championship.

An $89-million agreement by which the Occidental Petroleum Corporation would acquire the Permian Corporation, a gatherer and marketer of crude oil in the 15 Mid-Continent states, has been reached, according to a statement made by both companies yesterday. The Mid-Continent states extend from the Rocky Mountain area to the Gulf of Mexico.
The stock market recovery lost steam yesterday. Prices continued to gain but the advance lacked the vigor displayed Wednesday and Thursday.

The 21st anniversary of the atomic bombing of Hiroshima will be marked today all over the nation by demonstrations against bombing and the war in Vietnam, as well as by memorials to the Japanese victims on the bombing.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Aug. 5, (Reuters) President Lorenzo Guerrero, Nicaragua's leader since the death on Wednesday of President Rene Schick Guiterrez, suffered a sunstroke during the burial ceremony of the late President today.
SYRACUSE, Aug. 5 Frank D. O'Connor deplored the fighting within the Democratic party, saying that it had lost the party the last two elections for Governor.

NASHVILLE, Aug. 5-- The Democratic primary yesterday demonstrated that a combination of Negroes and white liberals is still not potent enough to assure the election of liberals in Tennessee, especially when local politics interfere.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5, (AP) The Federal Maritime Commission said today it would investigate a merger proposal by three major steamship lines to determine whether it had jurisdiction.

The New York Mets, who had thrilled a huge crowd with their wonderful victory over the pennant-contending San Francisco Giants on Thursday afternoon, reverted to their customary second-division form last night.
PARAMUS, N.J., Aug. 5 Mrs. Harvey Roscoe of Maplewood won the Myra Scribner net trophy in a Women's New Jersey Seniors Golf Association tournament today with 102-27 75 at the Arcola Country Club.

Members of the Council of Negro Elected Officials, a group of Democratic district leaders and officeholders here, reported yesterday that four Democrats seeking the nomination for Governor have said that a Negro should be included on the statewide this fall.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5, (AP) Turma-Now, owned and bred by Thomas B. Stewart, of Deland, Fla., defeated Diplomat Way in a photo finish to capture the $51,600 Arch Ward Stakes for 2-year-olds today before 13,923 at Arlington Park.

VENICE, Aug. 3 The gondoliers on the Grand Canal, the pigeons in St. Mark's Square, the sun-tanned bodies on the Lido beach Venice in August is gloriously itself. The impossibly chic boutiques that seem even smarter than those in New York, the superb Venetian women walking ...
LONDON, Aug. 5 A House of Commons committee, after another 19-hour overnight session, approved the Labor Government's proposed wage and price freeze bill today.
A 25-year-old bank employe took the lead yesterday in trying to save the Ziegfeld Theater from the wreckers.
A Manhattan businessman won a Federal Court order yesterday directing striking airline mechanics to show cause in court here Tuesday why they should not be enjoined from continuing their strike.
Representative Leonard Farbstein applied yesterday for a court order barring a rerun of the Democratic primary in the 19th Congressional District.

The Rev. Benjamin J. Wasielewski, assistant pastor of Holy Innocents Roman Catholic Church here and former pastor of St. Stanislaus Church, Pine Island, N.Y., died of a heart attack Thursday while visiting friends in Yonkers. He was 53 years old.
An American-flag steamship operator one of the largest in the country is evaluating bids from foreign shipyards to construct cargo vessels for this country's merchant marine.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 5, (AP) Australian and Canadian swimmers broke three world records tonight in the opening events of the British Empire and Commonwealth games.
SAN JUAN, P.R.--Puerto Rico is seeking ways to protect local companies from take-overs by United States companies and other outsiders.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. The Treasury announced the results today of its latest massive refunding operation, and officials called it a success.

MONTREAL, Aug. 5 The Chief Judge of the United States Court of Appeals in New York suggested today that wiretapping by the police might have to be legalized throughout the United States to compensate for the Supreme Court's limitations on the use of confessions.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Aug. 5. Miss Patricia Ann Blatz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo J. Blatz, plans to be married on Aug. 21 to Second Lieut. Matthew John Hoysa Jr., U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hoysa of Springfield, Va. The couple's engagement has been announced by the future bride's parents.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 5 (Reuters) Chiefs of Nigeria's Moslem Northern Region met tonight to discuss the future of this troubled country following last week's army mutiny. They conferred in Kaduna with Lieut, Col. Hassen Katsina, the region's military governor.
EAST BERLIN, Aug. 5, (Reuters) Soviet men and women last night won four gold medals in the world parachute jumping championships in Leipzig.
City Council President Frank D. O'Connor asked the Justice Department yesterday to investigate whether there was "collusion" by the city's milk dealers in the setting of prices.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. (AP) Chief Justice Earl Warren refused today to for- bid the arrest of a group that wants to picket the wedding tomorrow of Luci Johnson and Patrick J. Nugent.
BRUSSELS, Aug. 5 Swastikas and anti-Semitic slogans were painted during the night on the premises of the Palais des Conges, where the World Jewish Congress is meeting.

MONTREAL, Aug. 5, (Canadian Press) Judges at the Fourth Festival of Canadian Films held here this week decided they would be "critical rather than diplomatic" and refused to make awards in more than two of the four categories open to contestants.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 5. Ghulam Faruque, Minister of Commerce, announced today that an agreement was expected to be signed soon with West Germany for construction of a $260-million steel mill here.

MASSAPEQUA PARK, L.I., Aug. 5 Mr. and Mrs. Archie Levitt have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen May Levitt, to Joel Mark Rappaport, son of Mrs. Edward Rappaport of Rockville Centre, and the late Dr. Rappaport.

WOODS HOLE, Mass., Aug. 5 The race for the Astor Cup, one of the most important prizes of the New York Yacht Club cruise, was bogged down in a flat calm today and, after a suitable period, was postponed. The race will be held Sunday off Brenton Reef at Newport, R.I., which makes the old fixture one day longer.

When does a company enter into merger discussions with another company? Until several weeks ago, the Sun Chemical Corporation thought it was having talks with the Harshaw Chemical Company, the company that now plans to merge with the Kewanee Oil Company.

TALL bearded iris, like many other perennials, may be planted at almost any time provided proper care is given. However, the best planting period is during their summer dormancy (shortly after bloom has ended). In southern New York, the preferred time is between July 4 and Labor Day. Most nurseries ship in July and August.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6 (AP) A 55-year-old Philadelphia man, identified as a former mental patient, barricaded himself, in his home last night after shooting at his own and several other children in his neighborhood.

SAIGON, Aug. 6 South Vietnam's Foreign Minister, Dr. Tran Van Do, said today that his country would welcome anything, that the International Control Commission could do to restore peace to the demilitarized zone.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 6 Sudden Sam McDowell, who had not finished a game since, July 1, failed to finish one again today as the New York Yankees defeated the Cleveland Indians, 5-4.
PORTILLO, Chile, Aug. 6 (UPI) Skiers tried out the treacherous men's downhill course today in final preparations for tomorrow's grueling race in the Alpine world ski championships.

In 1952, educational television (ETV) with a nationwide potential was born, when the Federal Communications Commission, after acrimonious battle reserved 242 channels for non-commercial use. But while great hopes were pinned on the commercial medium's baby brother, the infant soon turned out to be an orphan without any regular support and guardian. Last week, McGeorge Bundy, the new president of the Ford Foundation, pronounced the short lifespan of ETV "a depressing failure."

TOKYO, Aug. 6 Japan's largest labor federation, which has long been bitterly hostile to "monoply capital" and "imperialism," ended its five-day annual convention here this week indicating a gradual shift from the left.

The United States is about to take the first small step toward the landing on Mars of a capsule that might indicate whether or not there is life on that planet. During the week beginning Aug. 14, if all goes well, a peculiar rocket-driven craft will be lifted by balloon to the very high atmosphere and fired horizontally to test a proposed parachute design for such a landing.

The human race lives on one planet. All of us breathe the same air, experience the same weather, suffer the same diseases. Drought and pestilence know no national borders. SALT LAKE CITY The Utah route of the Pony Express still cuts across the state to the Nevada border, and most of it retains the 1860-61 look, even though a 70-mile stretch outside this capital city has been paved. The pavement ends at Lookout Pass, and from then on a car can raise as much dust as the horses did in the old days.

SIX scientists of the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station staff will speak Wednesday at the station's annual Science at Work Day. The allday program, which begins at 9:30 A.M. at Lockwood Farm on Evergreen Avenue in Mt. Carmel, is open to all science students and the general public.

WASHINGTON Most visitors who hurry along the treeshaded sidewalks leading to the Capitol are unaware that they are passing through one of the country's better arboretums. In a sense, it was an ordinary week on the economic front. WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) The council of state Chambers of Commerce urged Congress tonight to approve only $2-billion for foreign aid spending during the fiscal year which began July 1.
