Assemblyman Sidney Leibowitz, Democrat of Jackson Heights, Queens, has called on, Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay to join him and various community leaders at a strategy meeting at 10 A.M. Thursday at LaGuardia Airport to discuss the jet noise problem over Jackson Heights.

Frank Milton Smith, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of Capital Cities Broadcasting Corporation, died Saturday of a heart attack in Baltimore. He was 56 years old and lived on Bedford Road in Pleasantville, N.Y.
PINEHURST, N.C., Aug. 7 (AP) Jim Wiechers scored birdies on three holes in a row and went on to defeat Ron Cerrudo, 1 up, to win the Western amateur golf championship today.
CAIRO, Aug. 7 President Gamal Abdel Nasser said last night that the Western type of liberty and democracy would not meet the needs of the United Arab Republic.

Today's money costs, the highest since the nineteen-twenties, are proving a deterrent to expansion and growth in the nation's giant soft-goods industries that will result in a business downturn in the next year or two, according to Charles L. Harding Jr., chairman and president of the Meinhard-Commercial Corporation.
More than 100 employers of longshoremen who work in West Coast ports have entered into a long-term contract with a new wrinkle in labor-management relations.
RAMSGATE, England, Aug. 7(AP) Lady Carson, the widow of Lord Carson, died today at the age of 85.
DETROIT, Aug. 7 The five proud suburbs that make up the exclusive community of Grosse Pointe are among the nation's most affluent and most famous and most segregated.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 7 More than 6,000 South Vietnamese have requested compensation for injuries, property loss and relatives' deaths caused accidentally by allied forces in combat this year, authoritative sources disclosed yesterday.
The current charges about Democratic "deals" for the nomination for Governor are "totally without foundation," Deputy Mayor Robert Price said yesterday.
ALAMEDA, Calif., Aug. 7 (AP) Ed Winrow of the New York Athletic Club bettered the record for the Amateur Athletic Union's national senior one-hour run yesterday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 7 The police fought back thousands of jeering whites today as civil rights marchers demonstrated against alleged housing discrimination in an all-white residential area.

MANILA, Aug. 7(AP) Communist China assailed today plans for an Asian peace conference on Vietnam. A Peking broadcast called the proposal, made by Thailand last week, another move in "the United States peace talks fraud."
Fire heavily damaged a littleknown and unused Central Park landmark yesterday evening an 80-year-old locker building between Heckscher Playground and the 65th Street Transverse Road.
DENVER, Aug. 7 There were no major surprises in the first knockout round of the Spingold master team championship here last night, and the New York players did well.

Thomas E. O'Donnell, a lawyer who specialized in Surrogate Court practice in Brooklyn for 40 years before he retired in 1964, died Saturday in the Bronx Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 50 Carthage Road in Scarsdale, N.Y.
TEL AVIV, Aug. 7 Elhanan Mozdof, known as "Choneh," one of the most colorful characters in American Jewish life, died yesterday in a home for the aged near here. He was 80 years old.

CAIRO, Aug. 7 Five Soviet naval vessels, which arrived yesterday, are returning an Egyptian naval visit to Sevastopol last month. It is the second well publicized Soviet naval visit to the United Arab Republic in recent weeks.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 7 (UPI) Paul Lindblad survived a shaky first inning today and hurled the Kansas City Athletics to a 4-2 triumph over Minnesota in the second game of a double-header after the Twins had won the opener, 2-1.
Two leading pop vocal recording groups, the Mamas and the Papas and Simon and Garfunkel, drew a full house of 14,000 to the Forest Hills Music Festival in Queens Saturday night.
The first meeting of Indonesia's new Cabinet, led by General Suharto, evidently has decided to give priority to peace with Malaysia.

HIROSHIMA, Japan, Aug. 7 The once common custom of obtaining wives by an exchange of photographs across the Pacific is being revived among Japanese living in Hawaii with the aid of the Hiroshima city government.
NASSAU, the Bahamas, Aug. 7 (UPI) Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Nugent flew here, along with seven other newly married couples today, and sped away to a villa on the western beaches of this resort island.
WATERBURY, Conn., Aug. 7 A young father went berserk here today, slashing to death his four children and then taking his own life.
OHRID, Yugoslavia, Aug. 7 Yugoslav Macedonia, which acquired nationhood and its own language during the last 20 years, now has its first beauty queen.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 7 (Reuters) Mrs. Indira Gandhi, Indian Prime Minister, promised today an all-out effort to bring posperity to the country's poverty-stricken millions, and in return asked them to stop rioting over shortages and soaring prices.

General aviation operations at Washington National Airport will be cut back as sharply as those of scheduled airlines under a proposed regulation made public by the Federal Aviation Agency over the weekend.
Its mission a close-up photographic look at the sites where the first Americans might land on the moon, a windmill-shaped satellite starts a 90-hour journey from Cape Kennedy, Fla., tomorrow.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Aug. 7-The Gemini 11 astronauts will attempt a swift first orbit rendezvous with an Agena satellite next month and they will try to tie their spacecraft and the Agena together with a 100-foot line and start them spinning.

LAMBERTVILLE, N.J., Aug. 7 James Wilson Marshall, credited with discovering the gold that led to the California Gold Rush of 1849, is about to receive historical recognition from this small town where he grew up.

EAST GREENWICH, R.I., Aug. 7 Gamecock, sailed by Robert Shiels of Darien, Conn., the president of the North American Multihull Sailing Association, was named today as the United States challenger for the International Catamaran Challenge Trophy. The boat was selected just after she had lost her first race in 11 starts this season.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 7 (Reuters) Maj. Gen. Abdel Aziz al-Oqkeily, former Defense Minister in the Government of Premier Abdel Rahman al-Bazzaz, may become Vice Premier in the Cabinet being formed by Naji Talib, according to observers here.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 7 Manasses Chavez, a remarkably consistent foxchaser owned and ridden by Wendy Wolcott of Weston, Conn., won both the green and junior working hunter championships today at the Vixen horse show.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 7 In the equivalent of a photo finish if there were such a thing in sailing the winner of the Astor Cup, James L. Madden's 57-foot sloop Gesture, beat Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr.'s Cal 40 Illusion, the runner-up, today in the last race of the New York Yacht Club cruise.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 7 Hans Werner Henze's new opera, "The Bassarids," which had its first performance here last night, is the most ambitious and demanding subject this prolific 40-year-old composer has tackled.
Prosperity, as credit men have begun to find, is not without its ironies. Though more Americans are taking in more money than ever before, more of them are going bankrupt than ever before.
FALLS CITY, Neb., Aug, 7 Sheathed in flames, a Braniff jet airliner plunged to earth near this southeast Nebraska town late last night, killing all 42 persons aboard.

Two of Detroit's smaller com mercial banks the City National Bank of Detroit and Public Bank plan to merge, the institutions announced yesterday. The combined bank, which will operate under the City National name, will have assets of about $500-million, and 37 offices in the Detroit area.
LAKEWOOD, N.Y., Aug. 7 (AP) Unofficial results yesterday gave Earl Elms of San Diego the national senior snipe championship at Chautauqua Lake.
SKOVSHOVED, Denmark, Aug. 7 (AP) The American Dragon Class yacht Williwaw, piloted by G.S. Friedrichs Jr. of Seattle, scored a second straight victory today in the world sailing championships.
TOKYO, Aug. 7 (AP) Communist China cautioned Cambodia today against improving relations with the United States, saying Washington "has never shown any respect" for Cambodian neutrality.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz invaded the mahjongg strongholds and cabanas of the Bronx and Westchester County yesterday. Ducking between dripping bathing suits, he talked on a favorite theme, consumer frauds, in what his listeners took to be an early start in his campaign for reelection.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug 7 Miss Margaret-Beth Corey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Corey, was married today to Philip J. Boyce of London, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Boyce of Birmingham, England. The bride's father is "Professor" Irwin Corey, the comedian.

The election of Robert W. Carithers as president of the Leisure World Foundation, a management concern for Rossmoor Leisure World retirement communities, has been announced by William G. Simon, chairman of the foundation's board of trustees.

The 17-year-old son of an official of the Indian Consulate was punched to the ground and kicked early yesterday morning as he stood talking with two Indian friends on an Eimhurst, Queens, street corner.

Among the ensembles giving free concerts in the city's parks during the summer, one of the more industrious is the Municipal Concerts Orchestra, conducted by Julius Grossman. Its appearances are supported by individuals, foundations and business groups and by the Recording Industries Trust Funds through the cooperation of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 7 (AP) R.H. (Dick) Sikes, playing steady golf while the others leaders faltered carved out his fourth straight subpar round today and captured the $100,000 Cleveland open by three strokes with a 72-hole score of 268.

HOUSTON, Aug. 7 (AP) Lou Johnson, Ron Fairly and Jim Lefebvre drove in three runs apiece today as the Los Angeles Dodgers routed the Houston Astros, 14-3, and moved into first place in the National League by one percentage point.
OCEAN BEACH, Aug. 7 A pop artist who says he is the world's greatest painter of fried eggs was one of four persons arrested on narcotics charges yesterday and early this morning on Fire Island.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 7 No buying wave followed last week's announcement of steel price increases, according to steel-mill executives here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI) Vice President Humphrey said today the Johnson Administration was conducting a study of the economy to see whether a fiscal restraint such as a tax increase was needed to fight inflation.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 7 (AP) Two British players, Virginia Wade and Mark Cox, won the singles finals in the Middle Atlantic grass courts tennis championships today, defeating American opponents.
Italian chemical and pharmaceutical manufacturers have joined those in other countries throughout the world to combat a move in India to place restrictions on pharmaceutical patents.

TOKYO, Aug. 7 (UPI) North Vietnam complained to the International Control Commission today that United States and South Vietnamese warships had confiscated North Vietnamese fishing boats. Hanoi demanded that they be released.

LONDON, Aug. 7-A British contractor who specializes in furnishing offices is hoping to make a big sale to the New York Stock Exchange four walls of solid oak paneling that have enclosed all sorts of crucial financial deliberations.

SEATTLE, Aug. 7 (AP) Jim Ranger drove the new Detroit Unlimited hydroplane, My Gypsy, to its first racing triumph today winning his first two heats in the $15,000 Seattle Seafair Trophy race and then coasting to an easy victory by clinching second in the final heat.

The City Council's new committee to investigate rising food prices will use specialists and public hearings "to see if we can't pinpoint just where this spiraling begins and see if we can put an end to it," Councilman Aileen B. Ryan said yesterday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 7 The Soviet Union has agreed to open a $100-million credit to Brazil for the purchase of industrial equipment.
A Manhattan clergyman delivered a "Pow! Thwack! Bam!" yesterday to the assumption that the Batman television series appealed primarily to people's love of adventure and satire.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 7 (AP) Gardner Ackley, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said today management and labor must recognize and adhere to a national wage-price policy to contain a spiraling economy.
DALLAS, Aug. 7 (AP) Following is a list of the 42 killed when Flight 250 of Braniff International Airways crashed last night near Falls City, Neb., as released by the airlines.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 7 Argentine business and agricultural leaders have been busy recently explaining to the diplomatic community here "how our revolution ran off the tracks."

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Aug. 7 It was Sir Walter Scott who described a Scottish deerhound as "the most perfect creature of heaven." Today a deerhound, Ch. Timber of Gayleward, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Gerber of Millbrook, N.Y., was singled out by Mrs. A. Alfred LePine of Canton, Ohio, as the best of 935 dogs at the Hunterdon Hills Kennel Club show at the Flemington Fairgrounds in Flemington, N.J.
CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (UPI) The San Francisco Giants rallied for four runs in the seventh and added two in the eighth today for a 9-6 victory over the Chicago Cubs.
Pan American World Airways has made a strong plea to the Civil Aeronautics Board for a relaxation of its rules governing charter flights by Americanflag carriers.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 Joseph J. Sear, former president and board chairman of the Progressive Life Insurance Company of Red Bank, N.J., died today in the University of Pennsylvania Hospital here. He was 48 years old and lived at 217 Cornwall Avenue, Trenton.
SOON after he took command of the city's summer antipoverty program, Richard Hartline Buford was faced with a poverty crisis in his own office.
IN the age of the sit-in and the swim-in designed to overthrow long-standing barriers of Southern segregation many Harlem residents would like to see a "walk-through."

Two basic mistakes were made by President Johnson last April when, without public announcement, he gave the proposed supersonic airliner virtually the same priority on men and materials as that enjoyed by key war and space programs.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-call in Congress during the week ended yesterday:

Frank Wille, the New York State Superintendent of Banks, announced yesterday that he had appointed an 11-man committee to study the laws and regulations that govern New York's savings banks and savings-and-loan associations.
For an hour last night, citizens picked up the telephone to complain to Mayor Lindsay about everything from soap to traffic lights.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 (AP) Tony Cloninger pitched a five hitter and drove in a run with a double today as the Atlanta Braves defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 3-0.

LONDON, Aug. 7 One day last week Danny Vary, the cheerful little Cockney who trains Brian London, was clutching at straws in a vain effort to counteract his unwelcome fears about the outcome of the forthcoming match against Cassius Clay.

LANGHORNE, Pa., Aug. 7 Roger McCluskey of Tucson, Ariz., driving a rear-mounted Ford Special owned by Lindsey Hopkins of Atlanta, won the 150-mile of Atlanta, won the race on Langhorne's one-mile paved speedway today.

MONTREAL, Aug. 7 (AP) Justice Tom C. Clark of the United States Supreme Court rejected today any suggestion that the high court's decision in the Sheppard case invites trial judges their contempt power to crack down on the press.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 7 A study prepared by the United States Marine Corps holds that North Vietnam can continue indefinitely to absorb casualties in South Vietnam at the present rate.
A series of neighborhood information centers to lead bewildered citizens through the maze of modern-day civilization is envisioned in a report published today by the Ford Foundation.
PORTILLO, Chile, Aug 7 (UPI) Walter Falk, a 19-yearold student at the University of Denver, suffered a brain concussion today in a fall during the downhill race of the Alpine world ski championships.

"Black Comedy," Peter Shaffer's farce, which was successfully produced by the British National Theater, will be presented here in February or March by Alexander H. Cohen. The earlier month would mean that the pre-Broadway tour would be dispensed with. Evening performances will begin at 9.
Margaret Case Harriman, the author and daughter of the late owner of the Hotel Algonquin, died yesterday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Hospital Medical Center. She was about 62 years old.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Aug. 7 (Canadian Press) Allen Fox of Los Angeles defeated Allen Stone of Australia yesterday and won the Canadian lawn tennis men's singles championship. The scores were 6-4, 6-4, 6-3.

BEIRA, Mozambique, Aug. 7 (Reuters) Luis Miguel Dominguin, the Spanish matador, here on safari for big game, has aroused the opposition of his fellow hunters by planning to stage a corrida against a buffalo.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 In the first six months of this year sportsmen and business executives bought more than 8,000 private airplanes, easily a record and nearly half again as many as those purchased last year.

HIROSHIMA, Japan, Aug. 7 Delegates from more than a dozen countries, meeting on the site of the 1945 atomic bomb explosion, condemned United States action in Vietnam today as "posing the danger of nuclear conflagration."

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 7 Miss Elaine Roni Block, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emil H. Block of Maplewood, was married today to Lachman Kishinchand Sippy, son of Mrs. Sati R. Sippy of Bombay, India, and the late Kishinchand Sippy. Rabbi Kenneth H. Rivkin performed the ceremony at the Manor.

The United States completed a sweep of Canada in defense of the Stevens Cup yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens, when George Ball of Roslyn, L.I., and Robert J. Freedman of Springfield, Mass., won the last two singles matches.
REGARDLESS of his final score, Bent Larsen of Denmark was certainly the sensation of the first half of the Piatigorsky Cup Tournament.

Eduardo Z. Romualdez, Secretary of Finance for the Philippines, said here last week that American investments in his country were not "what we would have wished." He expressed hope, however, that a new incentive law before the Philippine Congress would improve the climate.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 7 (AP) Deron Johnson hit two doubles and a single, and drove in four runs today as the Cincinnati Reds defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 9-7, despite a lusty hitting performance by Roberto Clemente.

The Rev. Dr. Donald S. Harrington, state chairman of the Liberal party, yesterday became the first political leader to endorse the Ford Foundation's proposal for establishment of a nonprofit corporation to operate a nationwide satellite television system.
The Pressmen's Union called yesterday for an immediate resumption of bargaining in its dispute with the World Journal Tribune, Inc.
The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen and eight railroads operating in New York State announced an agreement yesterday on how to implement the state's recently amended Full Crew Law.
Twice as many poor people as professional workers are running the city's antipoverty projects, the director of the city's summer antipoverty programs reported yesterday.
VANCOUVER, B.C., July 29 Vancouver, Canada's version of la dolce vita, leaves a visitor with a mixed impression.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 7 Dr. Carlos Lleras Restrepo, an economist, was inaugurated today as Colombia's 11th President and he immediately emphasized his conviction that economic integration must be speeded up in Latin America.
TYONEK, Alaska The newly rich Moquawkie Indians, beset by investment brokers, insurance salesmen, book agents, peddlers and confidence men, have closed their airstrip to all but invited guests.
Three men walking along a path yesterday afternoon near the waterfalls in Bronx Park off 180th Street and Southern Boulevard were ambushed by five armed thugs who robbed and pistol-whipped them.
ADENAU, Germany, Aug. 7 (AP) Jack Brabham of Australia won the German Grand Prix today and virtually clinched his third world driving championship.
SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., Aug. 7 Two persons were killed and two injured in an automobile accident on Main Street in this Rockland County village just before 2 o'clock this morning.
Miss Randy Ellen Lee and Joe-Robert Comfort were married yesterday afternoon at the Union Theological Seminary by the father of the bridegroom, the Rev. Dr. Richard Comfort, a Presbyterian minister.
DEPUE, Ill., Aug. 7 (AP) Bill Siebold of St. Louis captured two titles today as the American Powerboat Association ended its two-day national outboard championship races on Lake Depue.

RICHMOND, Aug. 7 Mr. and Mrs. Clifton Emmett Sutherland have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Carol Sutherland, to Joseph Hayes Keenan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Francis Keenan of Bethlehem, Pa.
CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) A record total of 23,570 traffic deaths were counted in the nation for the first six months of this year, the National Safety Council said today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 Already emotionally spent after two weeks of civil rights debate, the House may have to plunge this week into a bruising fight over the airline strike.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7 (AP) Don Meredith, the Dallar quarterback, hit Pete Gent, is flanker, with two quick firstquarter touchdown passes today to help the Cowboys beat the San Francisco 49ers, 24-13, in a National Football League exhibition game.
Herbert A. Allen Jr., 27 years old, has been elected president of Allen Co., New York investment bankers, it was announced over the weekend.
LONDON, Aug. 8 The unanimous jury verdict a keystone of the English trial system for seven centuries, is to be abolished if the Labor Government has its way.
LONDON. Aug. 8 (Reuters) Bernard Rickatson-Hatt, former editor in chief of Reuters and foreign affairs adviser to the governor of the Bank of England, died here last night. He was 68 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 8 (AP) A printed card spelling out the right to remain silent and to be advised by a lawyer will be handed out to all arrested suspects by the San Francisco police starting next week.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 8 A man of many positions. That was what the coaching staff of the New York Jets was calling Bill Yearby, the club's No.1 draft choice, today after he had taken part in his first workouts since returning from the College All-Star game in Chicago.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana, the Democratic lead er, called today for American support of a Thai proposal for an all-Asian conference to seek peace in Vietnam.
PORTILLO, Chile, Aug. 8 (AP) Austria recovered part of her lost prestige in downhill skiing today when Erika Schinegger won the women's downhill title at the world Alpine ski championships.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UPI) High school graduates from Idaho, Miami and Galveston, Tex., won the three division titles today in the Silver Hill bowling tournament. The teenagers were among 109 from 37 states who entered the tournament.
RIVERHEAD, L.I, Aug. 8 A county legislative system based on weighted votes was proposed today as the reapportionment plan to be offered to Suffolk voters this fall.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 8 Dr. Jose Rafael Molina Urena, secretary general of the Dominican Revolutionary party, was arrested by members of the Dominican Air Force as he entered the town of Barahona Saturday. He was released last night.
BONN, Aug. 8 Chancellor Ludwig Erhard of West Germany will visit India and Pakistan in the first half of November, a Government spokesman announced today.

LONDON, Aug. 8 The Radio Corporation of America, is moving from color into colour. Robert W. Sarnoff, its president, announced here today that it would start manufacturing picture tubes for color-television sets in Britain next year.
DETROIT, Aug. 8 (AP) The final cars of the 1966 model run will roll off an assembly line at Ford's Dearborn, Mich., assembly plant this week as the industry switches over to 1967model production.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UPI) Willie Horton hit a two-out bases-filled single in the 12th inning tonight to drive in two runs and give the Detroit Tigers a 5-3 victory over the Washington Senators.
Several months ago, 17-year old Larry Jackson quit Morris High School in the East Bronx, where 2,913 students have been crammed into a building meant for 2,286.
AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 8 (AP) Charles J. Whitman's father today told one of the policemen who shot and killed his sniper son: "I have respect for you for, doing your job."

NORWICH, N.Y., Aug. 8 C. Nicholas Priaulx, a retired vice president, treasurer and director of the American Broadcasting Company, died today in Shenango Memorial Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 25 Newton Avenue here.

A suspended policeman hobbled into Bronx Supreme Court on crutches yesterday. The man had lost his left leg after he was shot trying to flee from a robbery, said Burton B. Roberts, chief assistant Bronx district attorney.

OTTAWA, Aug. 8 The Canadian Government conveyed to the State Department in Washington today its "concern" over first-hand reports reaching Ottawa that United States planes strafed a Cambodian village last week during a visit by the International Control Commission.

BONN, Aug. 8 Informed sources said today that the West German Government disagreed "completely" with a statement by former Chancellor Konrad Adenauer in which he urged the United States to get out of Vietnam and not to "ignore" Europe. The Government itself declined any formal comment.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Aug. 8 Business was brisker than ever today as Freehold Raceway opened a 60-day harness-racing meeting, even though the track management is engaged in a dispute with the New Jersey Standardbred Breeders and Owners Association. The horsemen are seeking higher purses and improved-backstretch conditions.
The Louisiana Land and Exploration Company reported yesterday second-quarter net income of $9,604,100, or 53 cents a share, compared with $8,356,993, or 47 cents a share, a year earlier.
Weakness developed in the stock market yesterday following last week's rallying attempt.

DETROIT, Aug. 8 An official of the General Motors Corporation said today he was unimpressed with two projected safety features, including one the Ford Motor Company has promised to install on all its cars by 1971.

The Ypsilanti (Mich.) Greek Theater, which is presenting Judith Anderson in "The Oresteia" and Bert Lahr in "The Birds," manages to overcome a financial crisis every week by raising emergency funds to meet the payroll.

Mr. and Mrs. Ignace Golbin of 40 Central Park South have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sylvia Evelyn Golbin, to Edward I. Cohen. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Cohen of Scarsdale, N.Y.

CLIFTON, N.J., Aug. 8 Mike Franko, the 44-year-old Greenacres pro, won a Mustang auto today by scoring a oneunder-par 35, 36 71 at the Upper Montclair Country Club in a special tournament preceding the $100,000 Thunderbird, which starts Thursday.
CAIRO, Aug. 8 President Gamal Abdel Nasser says the western powers are inherently hostile to his pan-Arab nationalism whereas Communist states "always take the side of developing countries."
The $153-million merger of the United Artists Corporation into the Consolidated Foods Corporation was called off yesterday just three weeks after it was first Proposed publicly.

WOODBURY, L.I., Aug. 8 Robert Bernstein of Great Neck, L.I., and Ted Sauer of New Hyde Park, L.I., led the field into the third round of the Metropolitan junior tennis championships at the Woodbury Country Club today by winning two matches apiece.

The Department of Agriculture's announcement yesterday of its long-expected 15 per cent increase in wheat acreage allotments for 1967 came too late in the day to influence futures, which declined without such an impetus.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) Aug.8 Four Israelis who had been in Syrian prisons for up to 12 years were exchanged today for six Syrians. The agreement surprised many Is. raelis.
LONDON, Aug. 8. (AP) Alfred Hitchcock, master of movie suspense, contended today that violence on television is good for the soul.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler urged the Senate Finance Committee today to proceed promptly with a bill to ease the tax burden on foreign investment in the United States.
LONDON, Aug. 8 J.M. Murray, chief ship surveyor at Lloyd's Register of Shipping since 1957 and a noted naval architect, died at his home in Surrey last Friday. He was 65 years old.

Having scored solidly with "The Gospel According to St. Matthew," Pier Paolo Pasolini is now planning three new screen projects, including a drama about St. Paul that will be based on the scriptures but given a contemporary setting. The picture will be made next year here and in Rome.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug 8 Although he broke more slowly than his four rivals in the 5 -furlong event, George D. Widener's Yorkville moved into the lead in good time and won the $34,600 Sanford Stakes by two lengths today at Saratoga. Tamara Geva's Sir Winzalot was the surprise runnerup in the field of five, preceding the Wheatley Stable's Top Bid across the wire by three lengths.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 A movement to organize the nation's poor into a cohesive force against Federal, state and municipal bureaucracies will be started next month, according to Dr. George A. A. Wiley, director of the PovWiley, director of the Poverty Action Center in Washington.
Jonathan Logan, Inc., has arranged to acquire Lana knit Canada, Ltd., in an exchange of stock, Richard J. Schwariz, president of Logan, a diversified apparel producer, announced yesterday.

The first specific step toward ending the reckless sack of New York's "last frontier" has been taken with Mayor Lindsay's creation of an Office of Staten Island Development. In appointing Holt Meyer, an energetic, young Richmond lawyer, to head the new office, the Mayor has made plain his determination to implement the sound recommendations made by the City Planning Commission in its report on Staten Island two months ago.
THE American dancer and, even more, the American ballet master and choreographer have become leading export commodities.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 8 The Argentine Central Bank announced this afternoon that it would revalue the peso in relation to foreign currencies tomorrow. At present, the peso is pegged at 202 pesos to the United States dollar, having been last devalued May 30 from 188.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 8 (UPI) Cassius Clay, the heavyweight boxing champion, will appear before a hearing officer here Aug. 23 to appeal his draft reclassification.
The men who work in New York City subways had two complaints yesterday, both involving money.
The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced yesterday in Washington the selection of three companies to compete competitively to operate certain major parts of the deep space network.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 8 Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Berlin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Sandra Lee Berlin, to Lieut. Henry DeJarnette Light, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Richard Light of McLean, Va. The wedding is planned for Sept. 4.
Consolidation of the Pennzoil Company and the United Gas Corporation moved one step closer yesterday with the proposed sale for $140-million of the distribution properties of United Gas.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 Mr. and Mrs. Donald Howard Richardson have announced the engagement of Mr. Richardson's daughter, Miss. Donna Caroline Richardson, to Christopher Beard, son of Judge Edward Abbot Beard of the District of Columbia Court of General Sessions and Mrs. Beard.
HALIFAX, N.S., Aug. 8 (Canadian Press) "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" starring Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor, has been banned from Nova Scotia theaters by the Provincial board of censors.
The Board of Elections an nounced yesterday that a special summer registration program for new voters would begin tomorrow in 104 public schools and housing projects.

BULAWAYO, Rhodesia, Aug. 8 Sanctions against Rhodesia have failed so far to achieve their avowed purpose of arousing pressure from Rhodesians for abandon ment of their Government's unilaterally declared independence.
The failure of sterling to recover strongly after Britain's drastic new deflationary measures indicates that traders and speculators are still betting against Prime Minister Wilson.

Mr. and Mrs. John T. Cassidy of New York and Rumson, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Claudia Whelan Cassidy, to Frank John Kelly, son of Mrs. Arthur H. Kelly Jr. of New York and the late Mr. Kelly.

Elmer Holmes Bobst, the 81-year-old chairman of the Warner-Lambert pharmaceutical company, told the police yesterday that $100,000 worth of jewelry was missing from the safe in his apartment at 1 Sutton Place.
You may not be able to tell a book by its cover, but Ketchum, MacLeod Grove, Inc., hopes you can tell the agency by its book.

The city rejected yesterday an offer of $1-million by Huntington Hartford to build recreational facilities in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn on condition that it accepted $500,000 more from him to build a cafe in Central Park.

CINCINNATI Aug. 8 (UPI) Willie McCovey's seventh-inning homer, his 23d of the season, gave the San Francisco Giants a 7-5, victory, and a split of a twilight double-header with the Cincinnati Reds tonight.

REDONDO BEACH, Calif., Aug. 8 (UPI) Chet Barker, jazz trumpet player, was recovering at his Southern California home today after a beating by five youths early Saturday morning in the Fillmore district of San Francisco.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 8 Two bloody coups d'etat within less than seven months have left the Nigerian Army all but destroyed as a unifying national force.

Reginald Rose, author of television and motion-picture dramas, will receive the first $25,000 piece of half-million-dollar pie that the Columbia Broadcasting System is offering to writers of original television drama.
John B. Hurt, retired dean of the linguistics staff of the National Security Agency, died Monday morning of a heart attack. He was 62 years old and lived at 330 Third Avenue.

LEEDS, England, Aug. 8 (Reuters) The West Indies, the unofficial world cricket champions, defeated England by an innings and 55 runs in the fourth test at Headingley today to take a 3-0 lead in the five-test series.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8 The East team from the New York area eliminated the West squad, 5-2, today as the United States girls tennis team championship opened at the Germantown Cricket Club.
The garden of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Steinberg at Manhattan Beach in Brooklyn, will be the scene for entertainment refreshments, a flea market and an art exhibit on Aug. 21.
Children who live in the east 90's near Madison and Park Avenues may not completely lose their "castle," the old Squadron A Armory at 94th Street and Park.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 8 (AP) Jim Nash, Kansas City's unbeaten rookie pitcher, checked Minnesota on seven hits tonight for his sixth victory of the season as the Athletics defeated the Minnesota Twins, 6-1.
The Bank of England has moved to restrict borrowings by major American banks in the London money market for use in the United States in order to bolster the sagging pound sterling.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 Donald G. MacDonald, director of the Agency for International Development's mission in Nigeria, was named today to head the mission in Vietnam.

Representative William F. Ryan called yesvterday for the immediate establishment of a joint Congressional committee to study ways of broadening the Selectie Service system into a national service program.

The rapidly expanding Brazilian shipbuilding industry has been awarded contracts worth $27.5-million to construct three ships for the Mexican Government, according to the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 8 (UPI) An American yacht, Chance, won today's sailing of the world 5.5-meter yachting championship and administered the first defeat in five races to Paul Elvstroem of Denmark.
COLUMBIA, Mo., Aug. 8 (UPI) American food stocks are dwindling and the farmer will be called on to expand production in the years ahead, Vice President Humphrey said today.

LONDON, Aug. 8 The British Navy has ordered American steel to go into its nuclear submarines because British steel is incapable of withstanding the great stresses placed on the welded parts of the hulls.
A number of executive appointments were announced yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Marc Bore of Gien, France, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Francoise Bore, to Millard Henry Alexander, son of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Alexander of Brookline, Mass. A December wedding in France is planned.

The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that its affiliate in Britain, Kodak, Ltd., and other major photographic manufacturers and suppliers had reached an agreement with the British Broad of Trade that would reduce the price of film and film processing.
Bud Powell, the bebop pianist, who died in obscure poverty last Monday in Kings County Hospital, was given a Dixieland jazzman's funeral procession last night through the streets of Harlem.

Hayden, Stone, Inc., member of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the appointment of Walter Francis Isaacson as vice president and treasurer. Mr. Isaacson formerly was vice president of Bache Co., also a Big Board member firm.

NASSAU, the Bahamas, Aug. 8 (AP) Sir Sydney Oakes, a sports car enthusiast and the son of the late Sir Harry Oakes, the Canadian gold millionaire, was killed today in an automobile accident. He was 39 years old.

Announcement has been made here of the marriage, July 23 of Miss. Evelyn Ann Pottinger to Elie Georges Saab. The Rev. Roland Abou-Jaoudi performed the Maronite ceremony in the chapel of St. Joseph's College at Cornet Chehwan near Beirut, Lebanon.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 8 Nadine Netter of Scarsdale, the East's third-ranking tennis player, and Giovanni Franzi of Italy won a first-round match in the Eastern clay-court mixeddoubles tennis championships today at the Great Neck Country Club. Seeded fourth, they beat Mr. and Mrs. William Brundage of Pelham, 6-1, 6-2.
JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 8 Senator Edward M. Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. called tonight for billions of dollars in Federal spending for American Negroes.
HOUSTON, Aug. 8 (UPI) A team of surgeons led by Dr. Michael E. DeBakey inserted an artificial heart device in a 37year-old woman today.

The spot rate on the British pound declined slightly in quiet trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. After fluctuating narrowly, the currency closed at $2.7891, down 2 points from Friday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 8 Freezing temperatures, in Brazil's best coffee-growing regions were followed today by reports of frost damage to next year's crop.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 8 Despite opposition from the U.S. Government, The Overseas Weekly, a tabloid newpaper for G.I.'s, may go on sale in South Vietnam within five weeks.

BRANCHVILLE, N.J., Aug. 8 Holly Fuller, a statuesque 17-year-old from Catasauqua, Pa., won the American Horse Shows Association Medal Class, Stock Seat, at the opening session of the Sussex County Horse Show today. Then she promptly began making plans to beat the Westerners at their own game.

MONTREAL, Aug. 8 (AP) Stuart T. Saunders, board chairman of the Pennsylvania Railroad, pledged today that the line would strive for improved passenger service. But he said government assistance was essential.

Milk dealers here said yesterday that they were fearful of meeting with Market Commissioner Samuel J. Kearing Jr., on a possible price cut unless Federal officials sat in on the sessions. They said they believed they might be accused of violating the antitrust laws by conspiring to fix lower prices.

PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 8 (AP) Photographs sent to the United States from its spacecraft Lunar Orbiter, scheduled to be launched tomorrow, will be sharpened by a process that doubled the detail in pictures relayed from the moon by Surveyor 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 New hearings on the planned merger of the Pennsylvania and New York Central Railroads hearings that would postpone the consolidation beyond the present Oct. 1 target date were asked today by the Justice Department.

A top official of the General Electric Company sought yesterday to counter suggestions by some union officials that labor settlements could now be based on productivity measurements within a given industry rather than by national productivity standards.
The National Amateur Athletic Union bobsled committee announced yesterday a 10-man team for the 1967 world bobsled championships at Grenoble, France.
The newly formed Hudson River Valley Commission yesterday elected Frank W. McCabe, chairman of the board of the National Commercial Bank and Trust Company of Albany, as chairman.
Joel Esquith has been named corporate controller of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., effective Oct. 1, Donald B. Smiley, vice chairman and treasurer, said yesterday.
GRENADA, Miss., Aug. 8 (AP) The rally in Grenada was being held outside the restaurant where Federal registrars had come from the Post Office to list more Negroes on the roll books.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 The chief negotiators in the airline strike met together today for the first time in 10 days as Congress stepped up pressure for them to reach a settlement. But the talks recessed tonight and the prospects for an accord remained bleak.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 Treasury bill rates moved in opposite directions at today's auction, with the rate on threemonth bills dipping slightly and that on six-month bills rising, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
A 14-year-old Long Island boy was shot and killed by police bullets early yesterday morning when he allegedly tried to run down two patrolmen in a stolen sports car.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 8 (UPI) About 200 demonstrators were arrested in violencetorn Ahmedabad in northwestern India5s Gujarat state today on the eighth anniversary of "martyrs' day," , according to reports reaching here.
Ballads and madrigals of the age of Shakespeare came to Bryant Park yesterday.
Reports from abroad that bacteria causing one disease can "catch" resistance to antibiotics from other types of bacteria have been confirmed by tests in this country.
The nation's credit unions, well-insulated from the credit squeeze as recently as last May, have suddenly began to experience the effects of tight money.

LANSING, Mich., Aug. 8 (AP) Policemen firing tear gas broke up a mob of 200 Negro youths at a dawntown intersection here tonight and then said this city's second night of racial violence "definitely was contained."
A 75-year-old blind Harlem landlord accidentally shot and killed his common-law wife Sunday night during an argument with one of his tenants, the police reported yesterday.

SEWICKLEY, Pa., Aug. 8 A 17-year-old high school senior, Shelley Hamlin of Fresno, Calif., shot a par 73 today to lead the field in the first round of the 36-hole qualifying test in the 66th annual women's National Amateur golf championship.

The five announced candidates for Governor were urged yesterday to intervene on behalf of the 17 licensed ferryboat officers of the Department of Marine and Aviation who have been unemployed for the last 14 months.

A Senate subcommittee, under the chairmanship of Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, threw its influence yesterday behind maritime groups advocating a new subsidy policy for the United States merchant marine.
The appointment of William T. Buschmann as marketing vice president of the electronic components group of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., was announced yesterday in Seneca Falls, N.Y.

The nation's 506 mutual savings banks gained $175-million in regular deposits last month, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday. This contrasts with a decline of $341-million in April, the month following the preceding interest-crediting period.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Aug. 9--About three companies of Communist troops severely mauled a company-sized unit of the United States First Cavalry Division (Airmobile) in South Vietnam's Central Highlands yesterday, an American military spokesman announced today.

MONTREAL, Aug. 8 The American Bar Association dropped today its traditional detachment from controversial social issues and formed a unit to concern itself with civil rights, civil liberties and racial unrest.
Is the girl in the gray flannel suit just back from Carnaby Street, London? Is the young woman in brass buttons all set for military school? Is the vision do vinyl about to take off for outer space?

Robert J. Murphy Jr. looks like a stunted Jack Nicklaus. However, he has no desire to take a crack at Big Nick's professional marks. At the age of 23, he simply wants to become the best amateur golfer in the world.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 8 The Indian Harbor Yacht Club, crew from Greenwich, Conn., captained by William E. Jessup, led the qualifying series of the Long Island Sound junior championship regatta today as three preliminary races were sailed off Black Rock Yacht Club.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 Two things have combined to render the Government's anti-inflation wage-price guideposts obsolete and ineffective.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 The House voted today to make it a Federal crime for any person using the facilities of interstate commerce to incite or carry out a riot or other violent civil disturbance.
Roger M. Coleman was appointed yesterday as executive director of international sales for the Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation, Louisville. Ky.

On Monday, July 25, executives of the B.V.D. Company, Inc., one of the apparel industry's largest concerns, were informed that an outside concern had acquired almost a one-third interest. The news hit the financial pages the next day. And the business world has been wondering ever since.

UNITED NATIONS, N., Y., Aug. 8 The Security Council adjourned its debate on Britain's complaint against Yemen and the United Arab Republic today to consider a proposal that the Secretary General send a team to South Arabia to investigate the evidence.

The New York Rangers of the National Hockey League announced yesterday that they would open their 1966-67 season on Oct. 19, meeting the Chicago Black Hawks in the first opening-night game between the two old rivals in 21 years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 Among the campaign expenditures of 1964 that Senator Thomas J. Dodd filed with the Secretary of State of Connecticut was the cost of shipping his dog from Washington to Groton, Conn.

FALLS CITY Neb., Aug. 8 (AP) Turbulent weather and the possibility of a fuel leak preceded the crash of an airliner in which 42 persons died Saturday, a Civil Aeronautics Board investigating team indicated today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 Defense Department officials said today that the Department's objections to distribution of The Overseas Weekly through military facilities in Vietnam had been based solely on the question of space and not on editorial content.
NASSAU, the Bahamas, Aug. 8 (UPI) Mr. and Mrs. Patrick. J. Nugent, who are staying at an oceanside villa, succeeded in keeping their honeymoon strictly private today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 In the long run it may turn out that the most important event of 1966 was not the escalation in Vietnam, the Chinese purge or the American rioting, but Russia's flirtation with the automobile industry.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UPI) Spokesmen for Jews and Lutherans joined other religious leaders opposing a constitutional amendment pertaining to prayer in public schools today. In testimony before a Senate judiciary subcommittee, opposition also was voiced by two other groups, Seventh-Day Adventists and Protestants and Other Americans United for Separation of Church and State.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 Unemployment in July was 3.9 per cent of the labor force, essentially unchanged from the level that has prevailed since the beginning of the year, the Labor Department reported today.
Robert Evans, a 36-year-old former actor, radio announcer and business executive, has been elected a vice president of Paramount Pictures, it was learned here yesterday.
NOGALES, Ariz., Aug. 8 (AP) Alfredo Just, a sculptor, died Sunday of cancer at the age of 66.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 8 (UPI) Sun Tumble rallied from sixth place with a quartermile to go today to gain a 1 length victory in the feature race as the season started at the Atlantic City Race Course.

SMITHTOWN, L.I, Aug. 8 (AP) Two Suffolk County detectives, acting on an anonymous tip that a drive-in theater would be robbed near here early today, shot and killed two Smithtown men they found in the act of breaking into the theater's safe.
Most issues on the American Stock Exchange declinecd yesterday in quiet trading after three consecutive sessions of advances.

Queens District Attorney Nat H. Hentel came out for Little League baseball last night, to the dismay of a group of Bayside residents who thought they had gotten the Parks Department to do away with a ballfield outside their front doors.
TRENTON, Aug. 8 Gov. Richard J. Hughes announced his final agreement today to an arrangement permitting the construction of the $525million World Trade Center in lower Manhattan.
Three commanding officers were among 15 members of the Police Department who applied for retirement at full pay yesterday under a new law signed Thursday by Governor Rockefeller.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 Two Cabinet members said today that the Government's longstanding wage-price guideposts policy should be revised but not abandoned in principle.

Konstantin Kobeleff, dancer and teacher, died Sunday at Knickerbocker Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 206 West 92d Street. Mr. Kobeleff was born in Russia in 1885 of a Russian father and Italian mother.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) Representative Robert E. Sweeney, Democrat of Ohio, accused Stokely Carmichael today of undermining the draft law and asked the Justice Department to prosecute him for it.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Aug. 8 Mr. and Mrs. W. Saxton Seward have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Lee Seward, to J. Norman Howard, son of Mrs. Alan Howard of Schenectady, N.Y., and the late Mr. Howard.
GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 8 Andy W. Smith ,Jr., a pioneer motion-picture distributor, died yesterday at Greenwich Hospital. He was 72 years old and had lived at 2 Lauder Lane.
Thousands of older persons have discovered that they are no longer covered by health insurance policies because they failed to enroll in the physician payment plan of Medicare.
VIENNA, Aug. 8, (Reuters) Erik Molnar, a former Hungarian Foreign Minister, died today, Hungarian press agency M.T.I. reported. He was 72 years old.
Magruder Dent, president of Joshua L. Baily Co., cotton textile merchants, died of a heart attack yesterday while lunching at the Union League Club. He was 77 years old.

After more than 16 months of bargaining the Sailors Union of the Pacific and the Pacific Maritime Association have reached agreement on a contract calling for a $78 monthly wage increase over a four-year period.

Pressures for settlement of the 106-day-old newspaper dispute appeared to be mounting yesterday, but there were no meetings between negotiators for the Pressmen's Union and the World Journal Tribune, Inc.
WILMINGTON, N.Y., Aug. 8 This early morning visitor to the East Branch of the Ausable River discovered the other morning that watching the fish and the fishermen can be almost as much fun as fishing.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 8 An investigation into the honesty of bookkeeping and declarations of ownership in Nevada gambling will open tomorrow in Las Vegas. It is fraught with political implications.

One of the fine things about the Mozart Festival at Philharmonic Hall is the exposure it is giving to conductors, most of them young people who are not heard often enough in New York's main auditoriums. A case in point is Jorge Mester, who led the New York Chamber Orchestra last night in the opening concert of the festival's second week.

ATLANTA, Aug. 8 (AP) Denis Menke's run-scoring single capped a four-run rally in the ninth inning that gave the Atlanta Braves a 10-9 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight and knocked the Dodgers out of first place in the National League.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 The Administration told farmers today that they could increase the size of their wheat acreage next year by an additional 15 per cent.
DETROIT, Aug. 8 (UPI) Charlie Dressen, the manager of the Detroit Tigers, remained hospitalized in serious condition today.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 8 The Government charged tonight that Secretary of State Dean Rusk had interfered in Argentine affairs.

Associate Justice John M. Harlan of the United States Supreme Court refused yesterday to delay the discontinuance of passenger service by the Boston Maine Railroad between Springfield, Mass. and White River Junction, Vt.

louis Broido; the city's enterprising Commerce Commissioner, is confident that New York is on the threshold of an industrial building boom. He sees a whole network of industrial parks springing up in Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and even Manhattan.
Trading on the London Stock Exchange was slow and cautious yesterday as dealers were watching uncertainties on Wall Street.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) The Agriculture Department's first forecast of the season today put the cotton crop at 10,820,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight, the smallest output since 1950.
STOKE-ON-TRENT, England, Aug. 8 (Reuters) Busmen threatened to go on strike here today unless they got two full sausages in every sandwich.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 8 (AP) Kipchoge Keino whipped Ron Clarke in the threemile run tonight in the British Empire and Commonwealth Games.
LUONGHOA, South Vietnam, Aug. 7 The Roman Catholic priest of this village, beseiged by the Vietcong, raised his glass of beer today with a little flourish of glee.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 8 Dr. Fernando Lobo, Brazil's Ambassador to the Organization of American States from 1953 until 1961, died yesterday at his home here. He was 69 years old.
Forty-five bus riders saw two patrolmen, with drawn pistols, capture a suspect yesterday in the rear of a bus. The suspect is accused of robbing a taxicab company.
DELPHOS, Kan., Aug.8(AP) Gov. William H. Avery dediGated a monument here today to Grace Bedell Billings who wrote a letter to Abraham Lincoln suggesting he grow a beard.

A State Senator from Harlem asserted yesterday that the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association had pressed for a law in 1958 that would have set up a committee headed by a civilian to review departmental decisions against policemen.

TRENTON, Aug. 8 David Frost, the insurgent candidate in next month's primary contest for the Democratic nomination for Senator, called today for an end to all bombing in Vietnam, an immediate cease-fire and negotiations with the Vietcong.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8 (UPI) Dr. Horace H. Hunsicker, psychiatrist who was kidnapped by Alvin Karpis, the Federal Bureau of Investiga tion's Public Enemy No. 1 in 1935, died at Hahnemann Hospital yesterday. He was 63 years old and lived in Penns Park, Buck County.

Abraham Zagor, a real-estate investor who was long an executive in the woolen business, died yesterday of a cerebral (hemorrhage at his summer home in Silvermine; Conn. He was 71 years old and a resident also of 737 Park Avenue here.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 8 (AP) The Baltimore Colts announced today the trade of an offensive tackle, Lou Kirouac, to the Atlanta Falcons for an undisclosed draft choice.
The appointment of Alan I. Greene as managing partner was announced yesterday by David J. Greene Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange.
Lamb Enterprises, Inc., was incorporated in Delaware yesterday with a capitalization of 10 million shares of $1 par value common stock, it was announced yesterday.

Whites attacking civil rights marches in Chicago have been incensed at the participation in the marches of Roman Catholic priests and nuns. Some of the whites have announced that they were going to withhold church donations.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art is still without a director. Francis Day Rogers, chairman of a museum committee formed last May to find a successor to James J. Rorimer, the, museum's director who died May 11; said yesterday that the job remained Open.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 8 Talks with Jewish leaders from Rumania, Hungary and Cuba indicate that the Jewish communities in the three Communist countries enjoy considerable freedom of cultural expression and religious practice but that their numbers are dwindling and that their Jewish life, while faithful to tradition, lacks vitality.
Strong competition for shortterm funds continued yesterday in the money market, while bond prices failed to show a trend.

GENEVA, Aug. 8 The Investors Overseas Service announced today the appointment of James Roosevelt, United States delegate to the United Nations Economic and Social Council and a former Democratic California Congressman, to the board of directors of the Fund of Funds.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) Adam Yarmolinsky, once Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara's top special assistant, is leaving the Pentagon to become a professor at Harvard Law School.
HONG KONG, Aug. 8 (Reuters) One of Communist China's leading economists has been dismissed under the cultural purge against antiparty dissidents, the Peking radio said today.

The report on the political status of Puerto Rico just released by a joint United States-Puerto Rican commission is strong in its research and tactful in its conclusions. The chief recommendation is that the people of Puerto Rico decide in a plebiscite whether they prefer statehood, independence or continuation of the existing commonwealth.
LIBERTY, N.Y., Aug. 8 Twenty-four persons were arrested today in a series of raids described by the police as the biggest narcotics crackdown in the history of Sullivan County.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 8 Civil rights workers in Grenada, Miss., charged that policemen and state highway patrolmen had used tear gas, gunfire and nightsticks to disperse a "peaceful" Negro street rally tonight.
WHEN he was growing up in Ozone Park, Queens, young Bill Kennedy didn't dream of being a fireman, a priest or President. He knew what he'd be a newspaper pressman like his father.

Mrs. Julia Ransom Miller Doty, a fashion and beauty editor and writer, was found dead yesterday in her home at 220 East 54th Street. She was about 60 years old and was believed to died of a heart attack.

Three days after Mayor Lindsay said he would have to go on increasing salaries if he wanted to get top-flight talent, the City Record disclosed yesterday pay raises for more high-level city officials.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8--Glenn Carney, whose work as a lobbyist and public relations man for the Anaconda Copper Company has made him an astute and experienced analyst of Montana politics, was asked recently what effect the war in Vietnam would have on Democratic Senator Lee Metcalf's re-election chances.
Eugene Rodriguez, a candidate for the State Senate, won a two-week delay yesterday for pleading to charges that he offered to fix a narcotics case. He had sought a six-week delay.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 A bill requiring states to meet certain Federal standards for jobless benefits passed the Senate tonight. The vote was 53 to 31.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 8 Mihajlo Mihajlov, the Yugoslav writer, was arrested today in Zadar on the Adriatic coast.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 8 (UPI) The Florida East Coast Railway appealed to the United States Supreme Court today to block the merger of the Atlantic Coast Line and Seaboard Air Line railroads.

The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation has entered into a conditional contract to purchase a 60-acre tract in Stamford, Conn., on which it plans to erect headquarters for its Chemicals Group, now in Manhattan.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Aug. 8 (AP) Communist terrorists ambushed a 15-man Thai-Malaysian police patrol in southern Thailand late yesterday, killing 10 of the policemen and wounding the five others, police reported today.
Barge traffic for the first six months of 1966 showed an overall increase of 7 per cent over the corresponding figure in 1965, the American Waterways Operators, Inc., reported yesterday.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 8--John Pickens of Tuscaloosa, Ala., who reached the semifinals of the Nassau Bowl tourney last week, was beaten in the first round of the 77th Meadow Club Invitation grass-court tennis tournament today. Pickens, a Rice University senior, lost to unheralded Jose Villarete of the Philippines, a Southern Illinois University student, 9-7, 4-6, 6-4.
Sources close to Senator Robert F. Kennedy expect him to announce this week that he will not endorse a specific candidate for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) The Defense Department says it has begun a new policy under which no more than one immediate member of a family will have to serve in South Vietnam against his wishes.
Work resumed at an uneven pace at construction sites in the city yesterday after a twoweek strike by operating engineers, but another work stoppage was immediately threatened by surveyors.

Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation seized three men in a Maspeth garage yesterday and accused them of a $15,000 hijacking the previous Monday during which the truck's driver was held at gunpoint and driven around the city for 2 hours in another car.
ATLANTA, Aug. 8 (AP) The Atlanta Police Department suspended three officers today pending investigation of a dispute over the arrest of Mrs. Henry Aaron, wife of the Atlanta Braves' home run star.

READERS of this column may recall that a year ago, a distinguished group of New York Met fans made plans to take part in this year's Banner Day. These rabid rooters, watching Met activities from their unique vantage point in heaven, included William Shakespeare, Feodor Dostoevsky, Voltaire, Samuel Taylor Coleridge, Andrew Marvell, Albert Einstein, Rene Descartes and Johann Wolfgang von Goethe.

TOKYO, Aug. 8 (Reuters) Secretary of Defense Robert McNamara was quoted here today as having said that Communist China might within 10 years develop intercontinental ballistic missiles capable of reaching the heart of the Soviet Union or the United States.
CHICAGO, Aug. 8 Civil rights leaders said tonight that they plan two demonstrations this week in white communities that have not experienced such protests before.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 8 (Reuters) Economics Minister Jorge Nestor Salimei said tonight that the peso would be devalued tomorrow to 215 to the United States dollar.

President Johnson was asked yesterday by the National Maritime Union to halt a Navy plan to replace United States citizen seamen with Philippine and Korean nationals. The replacement would occur on six ships of the Military Sea Transportation Service that have been transferred to Far East duty.

UNITED NATIONS N.Y., Aug. 8 Arthur J. Goldberg said today he expected the first treaty on space exploration to be approved at the forthcoming General Assembly. He said the treaty was "very much in the interests of the United States, the Soviet Union and the world community".

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 9-- The Southern California Metropolitan Water District voted today to join partnership with Federal agencies and public utilities in construction of the world's largest water-desalting plant.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 9 --Dr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Michele have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Michele, to Capt. Stacy Carl Bragg, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl C. Bragg of Hampton, N.H.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 9 --Al Sherman, the coach of the New York Giants, juggled his line-ups today.

The one-year prison sentence imposed on Henry F. Chartier, president of Local 32-E, Building Service Employes Union, was suspended yesterday by Federal Judge Edmund L. Palmieri. The union official was also fined $500.

Construction of a $19-million sulphur recovery plant in Dammam, Saudi Arabia, has been agreed on by the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, the Allied Chemical Corporation and Saudi Arabia's General Petroleum and Mineral Organization, Armand Hammer, president of Occidental, announced yesterday.

Roy Innis, chairman of the Harlem chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality (CORE) announced yesterday that a "giant black-power rally" would be held Sunday in the Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 West 138th Street. It will start at 5 P.M.

Dr. and Mrs. Emanuel M. Papper of Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Ellen Papper, to William Lee Lupatkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Lupatkin of Riverdale.
INDIAN LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 9--Every outdoors buff has some spot he promises himself each year he will visit. Sometimes he actually gets there.
PARIS, Aug. 9--A popular French cartoonist portrayed the national reserves this week as a live piggy bank that was complaining it was stuffed with money when it would rather be stuffed with truffles.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP)-- Racial discrimination dooms the Negro physician "to a career of medical mediocrity and his patients to inferior medical care," the new president of the National Medical Association said today.

The Occupational Health division of the United States Public Health Service is investigating a number of instances in which garment-plant employes in the South have suffered physical reaction to the use of chemicals in durablepress apparel.
A MAN OF THE PEOPLE, By Chinua Achebe. 167 pages. John Day. $3.95.
LONDON, Aug. 9--Lord Sherfield, the diplomat and former British Ambassador to the United States who is now a member of the House of Lords, will become chairman of Hill, Samuel Co., Ltd., on Oct. 1.
More than $900-million of bonds, notes and debentures were priced yesterday, and almost all showed interest rates continuing to rise.
ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 9 (AP)--Former President Cemal Gursel has spent more than six months in a deep coma.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 111.2 on Monday from 111.3 on Friday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) --A bill of rights for Federal employes was introduced today by Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, to protect them against what he termed unwarranted invasions of privacy and other "tyrannies" by Government agencies.

DENVER, Aug. 9--The quarter-final matches in the Spingold knockout produced some surprising results here last night. The biggest upset resulted in the elimination of Howard Schenken and Peter Leventritt, both of New York, Lew Mathe, Robert Hamman, Don Krauss and Paul Soloway, all of Los Angeles.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 9--The "minister of justice" in the shadow cabinet of the banned Pan African Congress of South Africa, Zephaniah Mothopeng, today sued the real Minister of Justice, John Balthazar Vorster, for 5,000 rand ($7,000) in damages for alleged maltreatment and electric shock torture suffered in prison.

The American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday that it would represent two activists in the peace movement who have been subpoenaed to testify before the House Committee on Un-American Activities.
Donald R. Young named vice president of marketing at Denver Chemical Manufacturing Company.

Leon A. Mnuchin, a corporation lawyer who was also prominent in fashion and in art circles died yesterday at his summer home in East Hampton, L.I. His residence in New York was at 433 East 51st Street. He was 57 years old.

ACCRA, Ghana, Aug. 9-- Extradition proceedings were begun here today against Dr. Horst Schumann, wanted by the West German Government to stand trial for alleged involvement in the mass murder of more than 30,000 prisoners at the concentration camp at Auschwitz during World War II.
The American Stock Exchange ended on the fence in stepped-up trading yesterday.
Ralph Houk celebrated his 47th birthday at Yankee Stadium last night in a manner that he would like to grow accustomed to--beating the Baltimore Orioles.

HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 9 (UPI)--Margaret Smith of Australia won the women's singles crown in the 60th West German International tennis championships today with a brilliant victory over Maria Bueno of Brazil, 8-6, 6-3. Fred Stone, also of Australia, won the men's title with a 2-6, 7-5, 6-1, 6-2 triumph over Istvan Gulyas of Hungary.
LONDON, Aug. 9 (AP)-- Sir Ranulph Twisleton-Wykeham-Fiennes must stand trial for trying to drive an American movie company from one of England's prettiest villages.

Every American will benefit if the Administration can reconstitute its toppled wage-price guideposts in a way that will make them an effective anti-inflation tool. BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 9-- A new 18-man Iraqi Cabinet under Naji Talib was formed today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9--Dr. John F. Perkins Jr., a professor on physiology at the University of Chicago, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home here. His age was 57.
PARIS, Aug. 9--Ambassador Charles E. Bohlen complained to the French Government today over what he said was the antiAmerican tone of French television and radio programs about Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9--President Johnson said today that the United States was still losing fewer planes than had been expected, despite a recent rise in air losses over North Vietnam.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell was threatened with a year in jail by a State Supreme Court justice yesterday. The judge said that if Mr. Powell did not make a commitment on Friday to appear in court in connection with a $160,000 judgment he would face the year's sentence.

LONDON, Aug. 9--Prof. Sir Dudley Stamp, noted geographer and an authority on land use, died yesterday while attending the regional LatinAmerican conference of the International Geographical Union in Mexico City. He was 68 years old.

The Liberal party's threat to put its own ticket into the gubernatorial race can only be interpreted as a last-ditch attempt to block the nomination of a Democrat for whom it has scant enthusiasm. Since Council President Frank D. O'Connor now seems on the road to bandwagon nomination at the Buffalo Democratic convention next month, he appears the obvious target.
Anne Fogarty, Inc., dress manufacturer, and its president, Leonard Sunshine, were charged in a criminal information filed in Federal Court on Monday with violating the Federal minimum wage laws.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9-- The House Interior Committee reversed itself today and approved a bill to establish the Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore along Lake Michigan.

GRENADA, Miss., Aug. 9 --Civil rights demonstrators were pelted with bricks, bottles and firecrackers tonight while state and local law-enforcement officials stood by, laughing and chuckling.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 9 (AP) --Vada Pinson's single scoring Sammy Ellis, the winning pitcher, broke a 2-2 tie in the seventh inning tonight and sent the Cincinnati Reds to a 3-2 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

TOKYO, Aug. 9 (AP)--Ambassador Edwin O. Reischauer said today that the United States mustt find a better way to handle the Vietnamese problem, based on local nationalism and "very much broader international support than we are able to muster today."
HONG KONG, Aug. 9--Peking indicated today that more persons "in high places" could be expected to be purged.
In the thickening dusk of a warm evening, bells sound from the night pasture as the cows gather last mouthfuls of grass. The music is muted, but the tinkling notes are pleasant to the ear.
Lord Sherfield, who is 62, was called to the bar in 1927 after being graduated from Oxford with high academic distinctions.

Robert Lowell, the poet, is the winner of the Sarah Josepha Hale Award given by the Friends of the Richards Free Library in Newport. The medal and a small honorarium will be presented to Mr. Lowell at ceremonies, at which he will speak, in Newport on Aug. 25.
No definite trend developed in the stock market yesterday. Advances and declines were almost evenly matched and most leading market averages lost ground moderately. Dealings were quiet.

The Adams School, an institution for exceptional children, has bought the four-story parish hall of the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd at 248 East 31st Street, between Second and Third Avenues.
HARPSWELL, Me.--Residents of this piney finger of Maine seacoast have arrayed themselves against highway beautification.

SANTA MONICA, Calif, Aug. 9--Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, the recent challenger for the world chess title, retained his lead in the Piatigorsky Cup Tournament after drawing his 15th-round game with Lajos Portisch of Hungary at the Miramar Hotel here last night. As White in a Ruy Lopez, Spassky brought about middle-game exchanges for complete equilization.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 9 (Reuters)--The Government will reduce public spending after failing to hold inflation below a 15 per cent increase this year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9-- The Architect of the Capitol won his point in the House Interior Committee today.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 9--Jim Johnson, an admirer of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, defeated J. Frank Holt, a racial moderate, today in a runoff primary to select a Democratic nominee for Governor.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 9-- Argentina's military regime has raised the cost of buying a dollar, increased the tax on importers and bowed to union demands for higher wages.
After a luncheon of buffalo steak, Billy Casper discussed yesterday some of his allergies, his relationship with fans and his goals as a professional golfer.

United States Commissioner of Education Harold Howe 2d proposed yesterday that national "standards" be established "to help school people appraise the value of what industry seeks to sell them."

The Lincoln Center Repertory Company is negotiating for the world premiere of "The East Wind," the work of a British dramatist, Leo Lehman. If contracts are signed, the play will open Feb. 9 at the Vivian Beaumont Theater.

GREENBELT, Md., Aug. 9 (AP)--The Goddard Space Flight Center disclosed today a new technique for study of stars by telescope during a rocket flight above the earth's atmosphere.

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 9-- Miss Kristi Townend Heller and William Hill McKenzie 4th, son of Colonel McKenzie 3d, U.S.A., and Mrs. McKenzie of Vienna, Va., will be married on Aug. 26 at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Comforter in Vienna.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 9--The New York Mets have not proved to be much of a stumbling block to the Pittsburgh Pirates this season. In nine previous encounters the hardhitting Pirates had won six. Tonight in Forbes Field Harry Walker's league leaders followed the script by winning, 2-1.
ATHENS, Aug. 9--Achilles Franghistas, the Greek shipowner who recently placed the biggest private order in Soviet ship yards, plans to beat his own record.

LANSING, Mich., Aug. 9 (UPI)--Gov. George Romney assailed advocates of "black power" today and threatened state action against the bands of youths who have taken part in two nights of racial violence.
DETROIT, Aug. 9--Angry crowds of Negroes stoned passing motorists tonight in a milelong area about three miles east of the downtown section.
A serious rift has developed within the 11-man Interstate Commerce Commission over the role of the proposed Cabinetlevel Department of Transportation.

Ambassador James Roosevelt, United States delegate to the United Nations Economic and Social Council, has shown poor taste and judgment in becoming a director of the Fund of Funds. This is a mutual fund in Geneva, Switzerland, that buys shares in American mutual funds and sells shares in itself to foreign nationals abroad. It is controlled by Investors Overseas Services, a company operated by American expatriates in Geneva and incorporated in Panama.

YONKERS, Aug. 9--Don R. Millar, the executive vice president of the United States Trotting Association, the record keeper and controlling body of harness racing, disclosed today that the star pacer, Bret Hanover, had earned $35,000 more than he had received credit for during his racing career.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 9--A United States Air Force major whose peers consides him the outstanding pilot of the war was shot down over North Vietnam yesterday.
VANDERHOOF, B.C. (Canadian Press)--Richmond Pearson Hobson Jr., a rancher and author, died Sunday at his home, the River Ranch. He was 58 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI)--The House Armed Services Committee approved today increased fringe benefits for personnel of the Central Intelligence Agency, including subsidized vacations for them and their families.
BENNINGTON, Vt.--Julie Livaudais, age 12, stretched an outfield hit into a home run as twilight deepened over the Bennington College campus.

LEE, Mass., Aug. 9--That venerable institution of American dance, the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, might perhaps be seen as a distinctive cross between Britain's Glyndebourne and New York's 92d Street "Y," with a notable full-time educational program for some 70 students put in for good measure.
Mrs. Shirley T. Meyer of Spain has announced the engagement of her guadhter, Miss Wendy Ann Meyer, to Richard T. Wheely, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Wheely of Virginia Beach, Va.
The number of jobs in the city increased nearly 40,000 in the first half of the year over the same period of 1965, Louis Broido, Commissioner of Commerce and Development, reported yesterday.

Elmer W. Engstrom, chief executive officer of the Radio Corporation of America and chairman of its executive committee, sold 25,004 of the company's common shares in July to pay a personal debt and to enable him to exercise a fouryear-old R.C.A. stock option.

The spot rate on the British pound rose slightly in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The currency closed at $2.7896, up 4 points from Monday.
