"The Investigation," Peter Weiss's controversial play about the 1964-65 Auschwitz trial in Frankfurt, Germany, will be televised on the National Broadcasting Company network early in 1967, Don Durgin, president of N.B.C.-TV, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9--A House committee searched in vain today for a way to settle the airline strike without enactment of a politically sensitive bill to end the 33-day-old walkout.

The stepped-up war in Vietnam, coupled with a corresponding increase in the number of recruits, has created such a critical shortage of certain apparel and textile items that military officials are taking new steps to stimulate production from the men's wear industry.
PORTILLO, Chile, Aug. 9 (AP)--Jean-Claude Killy of France shook off fatigue and forged into the lead today after the first heat in the giant slalom of the world Alpine ski championships.
Older persons who lost their health insurance coverage when Medicare began won assurance yesterday that their policies would be reinstated.
The Gibraltar Savings and Loan of Phoenix, Ariz., was seized yesterday by state authorities, and all savings accounts at the association were frozen.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 9--India has informed the United States that the supplying of American arms to Pakistan would be regarded as "a very serious threat to the security of India."

The downstairs exhibition hall at the Americana Hotel took on the appearance of a lively television studio yesterday, with batteries of cameras, projectors, tape recorders and other audiovisual aids all focused on a single market--the big and still growing education business.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) --The Senate Commerce Committee approved today two bills designed to put this country in a better position to meet the competition of foreign airlines.
ATLANTA, Aug. 9 (UPI)-- The Atlanta Braves dismissed Bobby Bragan as manager today and named Billy Hitchcock to sucdeed him.
LeRoi Jones, the playwright, waived examination in Criminal Court yesterday to await grand jury action in the assault and robbery case against him.

SOUTH MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 9 --Mr. and Mrs. F.G. Walton Smith have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alexandra Walton Smith, to Daniel W. Hofgren, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilford E. Hofgren of Erie, Pa., formerly of Jamestown, N.Y.
LONDON, Aug. 10 The Government told manufacturers of household detergents today that they were spending too much on advertising and making the consumer pay too high a price.
Ships in the Atlantic have been asked by the Coast Guard to keep a lookout for three small boats heading for England from the United States.
General salary increases of about 15 per cent for top-level city executives were recommended to Mayor Lindsay yesterday in a 31-page report by the Institute of Public Administration.

BERLIN, Aug. 10 A confessed spy who said he tried to get an East German pilot to go to the West with a Soviet-made jet fighter was sentenced to life imprisonment today by the Supreme Court in East Berlin.
Prices moved mostly downward yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. Encouraging reports about possible arbitration of the airline strike did little for most stocks.
Bonds these days are providing some exciting possibilities for profitable personal investment and estate planning. Most of all, there is the obvious advantage of high interest...
LANSING, Mich., Aug. 10 (UPI) A pact between community leaders and residents of a violence-scarred Negro neighborhood gave Michigan's capital city an uneasy peace today.
CANTHO, South Vietnam, Thursday, Aug. 11 United States Air Force jets killed 24 persons, including at least eight civilians and possibly some Vietcong, in an air strike.
Ten former narcotics addicts sat around a table in a downtown office building yesterday morning, but in their imagination they were at another place, one they all knew well.
ZADAR, Yugoslavia, Aug. 10 Associates of Mihajlo Mihajlov called off a three-day meeting scheduled to begin tomorrow to found an opposition magazine.

The 1967 general chairman of the March of Dimes drive in New York City will be Pierce Onthank, who was the general chairman of this year's campaign, it was announced yesterday by Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation-March of Dimes.
LONDON, Aug. 10 (UPI) Shares in the Beatles' music company took a slide on the stock market today, reacting to attacks abroad on John Lennon's remarks about Christianity.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., has amassed the highest sales and earnings for any second quarter and first half in its 39-year history, William S. Paley, chairman and Frank Stanton, president, announced yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 (AP) Premier Ky says he is willing to negotiate an end to the war with North Vietnam "under favorable conditions." The Los Angeles Times reported today.

BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 10 (AP) Five Louisiana parishes were ordered by a Federal court today to add 13,000 persons mostly Negroes to their voting rolls. Federal examiners had registered them under the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

OTTAWA, Aug. 10 (AP) A 150-foot span of a bridge under construction over the Rideau River collapsed in southwest Ottawa today, carrying at least seven workers to their deaths in a mass of half-set cement, timber and railings. Sixty-two others were injured.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 10 (Reuters) Jim Lee of Vancouver, a Canadian comparatively unknown in competition shooting, captured the Commonwealth Games gold medal today in the center-fire pistol match. Lee had never shot competitively until three years ago.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 10 Brazil's progressive Roman, Catholic leaders are coming increasingly into conflict with President Humberto Castelo Branco's regime on social issues and political methods.

Mr. and Mrs. H. Alfred Langben of New York and East Hampton, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Luke Langhen, to Henry Spotswood Fenimore Cooper, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Sage Fenimore Cooper of New York and Cooperstown, N. Y.
Five convicted members of what the Government called the biggest narcotics ring in Harlem received stiff prison sentences and fines totaling $70,000 yesterday from Federal Judge John M. Cannella.
Lynda Bird, President Johnson's elder daughter, took a half hour off from job hunting here yesterday afternoon to have her hair done.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 Is the world in for a resurgence of Squaredom? It is difficult to tell yet, but the sociological tea leaves are filled with strange omens suggesting that the cool, hip, swinging years of the Swinging Sixties are running out of swing.

The Realty Equities Corporation has taken title to two large units of the huge real estate, theater, hotel and broadcasting empire of J. Meyer Schine under a $75-million purchase agreement made last September.

A strike by 400 surveyors that halted construction at half the building projects in the city for two days ended late yesterday. The billion-dollar-a-year industry, almost crippled by strikes for the last 17 days, was expected to return almost to normal today.

The nation's stocks of gasoline declined by 311,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. At the weekend, total gasoline supplies were 180,808,000 barrels, compared with 181,119,000 a week earlier and 187,017,000 a year ago.

LONDON, Aug. 10 A World Bridge Federation Challenge of yesterday's finding by the British Bridge League that two British champions had not cheated in last year's world championship tournament was immediately disputed here today.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 10 Pakistan's Foreign Minister, Syed Sharifuddin Pirzada, accused India today of having expansionist designs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 Clifton C. Carter, the Texan who was one of President Johnson's personal political agents, resigned today as executive director of the Democratic National Committee to return to private business.
"IT'S adorable," a Stern Brothers customer com mented yesterday as she gazed at a navy pin-stripe skimmer dress ($35). "But I wouldn't wear anything as short as that. Not on the street, anyway."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 The miller and the baker told House investigators today that they were not to blame, any more than the farmer, for the rising cost of bread.
A hearing into a charge of negligence against the second of two pilots involved in the two-tanker collision that took 33 lives in New York harbor June 16, was postponed for the second time yesterday.

YONKERS, Aug. 10 George Sholty and Billy Haughton, two reinsmen who never have won a triple crown event, will be driving the favorite and second choice, respectively, in the Yonkers Futurity Trot tomorrow night at Yonkers Raceway.
The Endicott Johnson Corporation, a shoe manufacturer, announced yesterday the election of Charles A. Winding as a director and a member of the executive committee.
The Perkins Will Partnership, architects with offices in White Plains, Chicago and Washington, has elected three new partners.
MONTREAL, Aug. 10 Herbert Brownell Jr. of New York, former Attorney General of the United States, was elected president of the American Adjudicator Society this morning.

City Council President Frank D. O'Connor said yesterday that he had been assured by "high leaders" of the Liberal party that it was "not frozen at all" into a position of refusing to endorse him for Governor.
Grain futures had an active session yesterday, but much of the trading involved balancing commitments pending the Department of Agriculture crop report released after the close of the market.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 10 James Roosevelt, a United States delegate to the United Nations Economic and Social Council, said today "to avoid misunderstanding" he would not serve as a director of the Fund of Funds.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Aug. 10 (UPI) Government officials today displayed in a movie theater a dozen prisoners they said were Vietcong who had infiltrated the Buddhist uprising in Danang earlier this year.

GLEN BURNIE, Md., Aug. 10 Mrs. Ruth McNemar Brown, wife of J. Earle Brown, a retired school official in Federalsburg, died here today at the home of her sister, Mrs. Joseph T. Howard. She was 67 years old.
CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP) The principal of Chicago's largest elementary school, whose administration sparked boycotts by parents twice this year, was transferred today.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 For the last year, California has provided a large-scale test of the antismog equipment that will be required on new cars throughout the country starting with 1968 models.

A Civil Court judge has refused to permit a 23-year-old city employe to add "von" to his name on the legal ground that the Constitution forbids the granting of any title of nobility by the United States.

BRANCHVILLE, N.J., Aug. 10 Mrs. Frank Chapot defeated her husband and two other members of the United States Equestrian Tearn today when she guided Manon to victory in the first open-jumper class at the Sussex County horse show.

UPPER BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug. 10 Mr. and Mrs. G. Chester Doubleday have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Doubleday, to Paul H. Massey of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Massey of River Forest, Ill.

IF plush animals 70 inches high and reptiles up to 6 feet long sound a bit overwhelming for toddlers, the companies that are making the animals are content to have it that way. Such dogs, cats, bears, bulls, snakes and giraffes are intended for teenagers, especially girls.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 Administration sources expressed cautious optimism today as tensions apparently eased in the Congo.
PARIS, Aug. 10 The small, highly personalized meat shop and vegetable store, the backbone of France's tradition of fine food, are threatened by the self-service shop and the supermarket.
Harry Heltzer, whose first job with the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company in 1933 was as a $12-a-week manual laborer, became 3M's new president yesterday. He is 54 years old.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 President Johnson said today that the civil rights bill passed by the House of Representatives last night was "an important new milestone"

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 10?Alan Stone of Australia and Graham Stillwell of England, unheralded 20-year-old tennis players, reached the semi-finals of the 77th Meadow Club grass-court tournament today by upsetting second-seeded Owen Davidson of Australia and third-seeded Gene Scott of St. James, L. I.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 100 The Johnson Administration's diplomatic wager in Vietnam risks undeniable short-term costs for the possibility of appreciable long-term gains.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 At a time when the nation is being asked to set new goals in space, the goals it has already adopted are being challenged more than ever.

You can't tell investment bankers without a scorecard. In an Investment Bankers Association survey of managing underwriters for the first half of the year, Morgan Stanley Co. led the field in terms of managing syndicates offering the largest dollar volume of securities registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A 17-year-old Negro was indicted yesterday on charges of first degree murder in the shooting of 11-year-old Eric Dean, also a Negro, during a racial outbreak in the East New York area of Brooklyn on July 21.

The H. J. Heinz Company has announced the election of Ralph W. Lund as vice president for domestic marketing. Formerly general manager of product marketing, Mr. Lund succeeds Paul D. Townsend, who has resigned.

WITH impeccable technique, the United States chess champion, Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, conquered his perennial rival, Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N. Y., in the 10th round of the Piatigorsky Cup Tournament.
Stock prices moved to new lows on the London Stock Exchange yesterday as the Bank of England acted to further tighten credit restrictions.
MOSCOW, Aug. 10 (AP) The president of Fiat, S.P.A., Vittorio Valletta, arrived today to sign a $320-million detailed contract for the construction of a Fiat-equipped auto factory on the Volga River.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 10 An impressionist view of Rhodesia might see it, physically and psychologically, as the American West with a thin coating of Ye Olde England.
ATLANTA, Aug. 10 (AP) Jim Gilliam's two-base error opened the way for two unearned runs in the fifth inning that sent the Atlanta Braves to a 3-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight.

Mrs. Marian C. Kronenberg of 555 Walton Avenue, Mamaroneck, N. Y., a former instructor in the department of economics at Brooklyn College, and a lec- turer in American philosophy, history and religion in the women's division of Brandeis. University, died at her home. Monday morning of a heart attack. She was 52 years old.
The United States launched an unmanned picture-taking spacecraft yesterday in its first attempt to orbit the moon in search of sites most hospitable for landings by astronauts.
The right of the New York City Housing Authority to set standards for applicants for public housing and to screen out undesirables has been upheld in State Supreme Court.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 10 American strategists are making detailed plans for placing a sizable United States military force into the Mekong River delta, region of South Vietnam.

Scurry-Rainbow Oil, Ltd., reported yesterday that exploratory drilling at its potash deposit 70 miles southeast of Saskatoon, Sask., had proven a reserve of 225 million recoverable tons of high-grade potash and indicated it planned to invest $80-million to bring it into production.
Directors of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) voted yesterday in Cleveland to increase the quarterly dividend for the second consecutive quarter.
A $600,000 program to improve and expand the state's art, science, educational and historical museums has been started by the New York State Council on the Arts.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 10 The Pittsburgh Pirates walloped the New York Mets, 10-4, tonight, but the victory could prove costly to Harry Walker's leagueleading club.

The Wellington Management Company of Philadelphia, manager of Wellington Fund and Windsor Fund, plans to acquire for stock valued at $4-million, Ivest, Inc., of Boston and its investment counseling firm, Thorndike, Doran, Paine Lewis, Inc, of Boston and Atlanta, manager of Ivest Fund.

Carl Ally and William Bernbach will soon be locking creative horns in the great rent-acar battle, with the Ally agency moving into the driver's seat with Hertz and the Doyle Dane Bernbach agency trying a little harder for Avis.
A 26-year-old burglar suspect escaped from Bellevue Hospital early yesterday by jumping from a second-floor window, bouncing off a canopy and then on to the roof of an ambulance.
The nation's electric power production rose 10.8 per cent in the week ended Aug. 6, from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.

Heinz Arntz is a pianist who has not played with the New York Philharmonic, nor have the critics spoken of his Mozart in relation to Artur Schnabel's But Mr. Arntz has one distinction not held by Mr. Schnabel, Vladimir Horowitz, Ignace Paderewski or the other immortals.
Miss Emma Harrison, a former reporter for The New York Times, was named yesterday by Mayor Lindsay as a $75-a-day special consultant to the Welfare Department and the Health Services Administration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI) The Agriculture Department today estimated the 1966 corn crop at 3,981,221,000 bushels, down 240,185,000 bushels from the July forecast and almost 190 million bushels below last year's crop.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 10 Assagai, the excellent young distance campaigner who runs in the silks of the Cragwood Stable, won the $30,350 Bernard Baruch Handicap today, scoring by three lengths over Mrs. John Thouron's Ginger Fizz, with the Greentree Stable's Northern Deamon next in the field of 10.

LIMA, Peru, Aug. 10 The International Petroleum Company, center of a dispute that has affected United States-Peruvian relations, has offered to invest $8-million here to improve its refinery, the country's largest.

INLET, N. Y. Aug. 10 Just to the south of Inlet is a remote 50,000-acre tangle of mountains, forests, streams and ponds called the Moose River Recreation Area. It is managed by the New York State Conservation Department.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Aug. 11 A battalion of United States marines suffered moderate casualties in a battle that raged through the night and into the early hours of today on the coastal plain 340 miles northeast of Saigon, a United States military spokesman said today.
MOSCOW, Aug. 10 Izvestia, the Government newspaper, said tonight that banks and other business concerns in Western Europe were conducting currency-smuggling operations across the Soviet border.
NEW HOPE Pa., Aug. 10 Miss Hope Wells and John Rathbone Reese plan to marry here on Dec. 27.

The new Playwrights Unit, an experimental workshop organized by Richard Barr, Clinton Wilder and Edward Albee, has leased a theater at 15 Vandam Street, between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, in Greenwich Village.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 10 Prominent Negro leaders were dismayed today by the charge that recent riots here were the work of agitators and revolutionaries.

"I THREW away my tie on July 30 and I will never put it back," Ruben Torres said yesterday just before his lingerie designs were presented in the Warner Brothers Company Park Avenue showroom. The gesture was symbolic.

HERO is the eponymous dog figure of the year. The blue merle collie owned by Mr. and Mrs. George Jolley of Priest River, Idaho, has been selected as the winner of the 13th annual Ken-L Ration gold medal, which goes to America's dog hero. The first show dog to ever win the...
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 10 (AP) Dr. John J. Pauson resigned today as acting chairman of the philosophy department at Duquesne University, effective Oct. 5. He will remain on the faculty.

The chance that strikebound airliners might get back aloft on the wings of a voluntary arbitration agreement seems to have been shot down even before the union rank and file is asked to pass on it. Strike leaders, still staggering under the membership's overwhelming rejection of the wage agreement they joined President Johnson in endorsing, obviously have no appetite for going back to the strikers now with the arbitration proposal made by Chairman Staggers of...
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI) The Agriculture Department agreed today to postpone farm elections in Alabama from Aug. 16 until Sept. 15 to give Negroes more time to participate.
SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 10 Australia has decided to tap her large migrant community for conscript soldiers.

ENUGU, Nigeria, Aug. 9 Nigeria's predominantly Ibo Eastern Region is negotiating with the military Government in Lagos, which is dominated by Hausas from the Northern Region, for the separation of all Ibo officers and men from the armed forces, according to Lieut. Col. Odumegwu Ojukwu, the Ibo who is military governor of the East.
BOSTON, Aug. 10 (AP) Lee Stange of the Boston Red Sox, backed by Tony Conigliaro's run-scoring single and George Scott's home run, defeated the Cleveland Indians, 2-0, on nine hits today.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Aug. 10 Mary Ann Eisel of St. Louis, America's fifthranked woman tennis player was upset today in the third round of the Piping Rock Club women's grass-court tournament by 19-year-old Wendy Overton o fOrmond Beach, Fla.

A Federal Court judge ruled yesterday that a three-judge panel should hear arguments on a petition charging that gerrymandering of Brooklyn's Congressional districts had deprived 370,000 Negroes in the BedfordStuyvesant area of their political rights.

SEWICKLEY, Pa., Aug. 10 Shelley Hamlin of Fresno, Calif., who won the 36-hole qualifying round with a record score of 143, led the way today into the second round of the 66th annual women's National Amateur golf championship.

The increase in births in several leading hospitals continued here yesterday, nine months after the 1965 power blackout, as new fathers and mothers joined sociologists and fertility experts in theorizing on the cause of the phenomenon.

HONOLULU, Aug. 10 (UPI) Gen. William C. Westmoreland, commander of United States forces in South Vietnam, said today that he thought he would need more troops. He declined to speculate on the number that would ultimately be required, however.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 10 At the barbecues and rallies when all the candidates for the Democratic nomination for Governor would speak, the crowds would mill around and chat and sip their drinks. Then James Douglas Johnson would start to talk and the crowd ...

Two white men were, shot last night in a clash between six Negroes and a crowd of about 40 white youths in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. The police said Threadward Watson, 21 years old, of 954 East 15th Street, had admitted shooting the two whites with a 22-calibre rifle.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 10 Traffic on the Atlantic City Expressway more than doubled during its second year of operation, Expressway Controller John L. Kelly Jr. announced today.

A suit was filed in State Supreme Court here yesterday by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz charging the Milk Handlers and Processors Association, Inc., and nine persons with having violated the state's antitrust laws by fixing milk prices.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Aug. 10 There was a card game in the room across the hall, but Bill Yearby was not included. The New York Jets' newest football player lay in his bed and looked out the window at the green trees behind the barracks of the Peekskill Military Academy. This athlete is a worrier.
JAMESTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 10 (AP) Bob Battaglia of Buffalo defeated the defending champion, Nick Raasch of Syracuse, by 2 up today in the semifinals of the state junior boys golf championship.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 Retail sales rose by about six-tenths of 1 per cent in July above the June level, which had been revised sharply upward, the Commerce Department reported today.
HISTORY is the art of correcting our ancestors' mistakes. When we welter in contemporary error, why, we just call that ad hoc search for wisdom current events.
The "slumping" Baltimore Orioles snapped out of their slump at Yankee Stadium yesterday, got back to their old tricks and demolished the New York Yankees, 9-4.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Aug. 10 A 44-year-old mother of four children was found shot to death in her car near here early today. She was the fifth woman to be slain in less than a year on the Jersey Shore and there was growing alarm among residents that there would be more killings.
The emblem "R.C.A. Whirlpool" is about to pass into history as a result of an announcement yesterday by the Radio Corporation of America and the Whirlpool Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 About three-quarters of the large foreign companies, whose stock is widely held by residents of the United States, have agreed voluntarily to make their various financial reports available for inspection here.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation scored record sales and earnings for the 28th consecutive quarter in the three months ended June 30, Harold S. Geneen, chairman and president, announced yesterday.
KINGSTON, Pa., Aug. 10 (AP) Felix Serafin, Pennsylvania Open golf champion three times in the nineteen-thirties, died last night in a hospital here.
Nicolai Ghiaurov, the Bulgarian bass, will sing the title role of "Boris Godunov" in a concert version with the New York Philharmonic on Sept. 28 at Philharmonic Hall.

ON a hot day in St. Petersburg, Fla., a year and a half a ago, Bobby Bragan sat in the visitors' dugout at Al Lang Field, surrounded by cheerful reporters, discussing his latest innovation. Bragan had decided that pregame fielding practice was a waste of time, and that henceforth his Milwaukee Braves would use the extra 10 minutes for more batting practice.
The spot rate on the British pound sterling was unchanged in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The closing rate was $2.7895, the same as on Tuesday.

BEDFORD HILLS, N. Y., Aug. 10 Arthur M. Anderson, an advisory officer of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York and a former partner and vice chairman of J. P. Morgan Co., died here last night at his estate, White Gates Farm. He was 85 years old and had a New York home at 834 Fifth Avenue.
Alexander Wolf, a partner in the law firm of Schuman, Wolf, Schuman Davis, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home at 67-40 110 Street, Forest Hills, Queens. He was 80 years old.

The skirl of bagpipes, the imperious growl of a British sergeant and the martial music of a 17th-century regiment will resound in Madison Square Garden next month when the Royal Highland Fusiliers give five performances.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 The $2 bill came to the end of the road today after 190 years.
PRINCETON JUNCTION, N.J., Aug. 10 A specially rebuilt work train crawled along the Pennsylvania Railroad tracks near here today preparing the way for sleek 150mile-an-hour trains of the future.
WASHINGTON, Aug.10 (AP) Don Lock belted a three-run homer with two out in the 12th inning, giving the Washington Senators a 6-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 The Post Office Department is moving air mail by chartered planes, large and small, and using circuitous air routing to offset the impact of the strike on five airlines.
GRENADA, Miss., Aug. 10 Mississippi highway patrolmen cleared white hecklers from the town square at gunpoint tonight to protect civil rights demonstrators from attack.

CLIFTON, N. J., Aug. 10 George Knudson and Gay Brewer shared honors in the proamateur event, a preliminary to the $100,000 Thunderbird tournament opening tomorrow, as the professional golf tour reached here today.
The stock market moved down sluggishly yesterday as Wall Street baked in August apathy. It marked the third successive decline this week in the popular averages.
James Meredith, who is leading a drive to register Negro voters in the city, was authorized to vote yesterday by the Board of Elections.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 The Treasury suspended today, in effect, the tax exemption of state and local bonds that are sold primarily to enable the issuers to invest the proceeds in high-yielding Federal or other issues.
Howard Epstein was named yesterday to the presidency of the Interstate paper Company, a new subsidiary of the Interstate Container Corporation.

Despite the improvement in New York City's finances effected by the Lindsay tax program, the city faces titanic new difficulties next year. The municipal budget is likely to exceed $5 billion, and a gap of at least $400 million looms between projected revenues and expenditures. Gaps of similar magnitude must be expected to recur in future years.
The Port of New York Authority will take legal action against airlines using La Guardia Airport if their jet aircraft land or take off over Jackson Heights.
LONDON, Aug. 10 British banks began a new round of credit restrictions today that may force them to go back on their commitments.
CLIFTON, N. J. Aug. 10 Tommy Jacobs, the chairman of the Players Committee of the Professional Golfers' Association, disclaimed today any alleged "revolt" on the part of the touring pros.
The election of James A. Miller to the newly established post of engineering vice president was announced yesterday in Philadelphia by the Budd Company, a rail transit car manufacturer.

MONTREAL, Aug. 10 The American Bar Association's leaders declined today to criticize a key provision of the civil rights bill, after hearing a rousing defense of the rights proposal by Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach.

LONDON, Aug. 10 Detectives from Scotland Yard have seized as obscene 200 reproductions of 40 drawings by Aubrey Beardsley, the originals of which have been on view at the Victoria and Albert Museum since June 22.

EVEN though he never does get that horse for which he is ready to give his king dom, Richard III is indestructible. This was proved once again Tuesday night with the opening of the third and last of this summer's presentations by Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.

TRENTON, Aug. 10 (AP) Gov. Richard J. Hughes consented today to the construction of a Delaware River Bridge in return for assurances that he would receive the power to veto decisions of the Delaware River Port Authority.

Many defendants now in prison awaiting trial here will be freed because of a court project in which churches, labor unions and neighborhood groups will provide jobs, counseling and even babysitting services.
The city faces a projected deficit of $400-million in the 1967-68 fiscal year, the Temporary Commission on City Finances said yesterday in its final report.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10?A House committee tentatively backed today a bill ordering an end to the airline strike after a flurry of unwarranted optimism that labor and managemeat would arbitrate their differences.

SATTAHIP, Thailand, Aug. 10 Premier Thanom Kittikachorn opened the biggest American-built air base in Thailand today and partly lifted the blackout on Thai-United States cooperation in the war in Vietnam.
MOSCOW, Aug. 10 (Reuters) Communists in northern Laos have set up a network of jungle workshops to manufacture clothes and arms, Pravda reported today.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Aug. 10 Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, the recent challenger for the world chess title, retained first place in the Piatigorsky Cup Tournament after winning his adjourned l3thround game from Bent Larsen of Denmark after 43 moves at the Miramar Hotel last night.
CHICAGO, Aug. 10 Civil rights leaders postponed today their plans to demonstrate in two white neighborhoods where violence has greeted Negroes in the past.

Senator John O. Pastore, chairman of the communications subcommittee of the Senate Commerce Committee, announced yesterday that he would hold hearings on the proposal of the Ford Foundation to create a nonprofit satellite television system.
LONDON, Aug. 10 (AP) Executives of the British Broadcasting Corporation ordered an investigation today into a television program that showed a young couple in bed discussing their sex lives.
How do the blue chips fare in a bear-market? A new computer study shows, not too surprisingly, that it all depends on which stock you are looking at.
The paper products industry, which is in an unparalleled seller's market, is taking action to make sure it can keep its customers satisfied.

Architecture, who cradles a building in her hands, and Painting and Sculpture, with a mallet in her right hand and a palette and small figure in her left, were getting a hot bath in copper nitrate solution here yesterday.
ENVER, Aug. 10 The 72board final of the Spin gold knockout team championship began this afternoon between teams captained by George Rapee of New York and Ira Rubin of Paramus, N. J.
Those oak panels that have adorned the room where the Council of the London Stock Exchange used to meet are not going to be splintered for firewood after all.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has apparently adopted a new and tougher policy in its policing of the public accounting profession, well-informed accounting sources said yesterday.
A proposal to develop a Staten Island park on land already acquired and mapped for Richmond Parkway was announced yesterday by City Parks Commissioner Thomas P. F. Hoving.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 Manuel F. Cohen, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, proposed today that computer simulation be used as a means of determining, in advance, probable impact of changes in securities industry regulation.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Thursday, Aug. 11 (Reuters) Indonesia and Malaysia signed a peace agreement here today, formally ending the undeclared war of the last three and a half years.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark Aug. 10 (AP) Paul Ely ntroem of Denmark, skippering Web III, completed his domination of the 5.5-Meter Class today when he won the seventh and final race in the world yachting championships.
Owners of a 65-foot hydrofoil passenger vessel designed for deep-sea operations are looking for a freighter for transportation to Seattle but have been unable to find one.

"The Colonial Experience," a narrative history by David Hawke, will be released Aug. 25 by Bobbs-Merrill. The author, who is a professor of history at Pace College, traces the development of Colonial America from medieval Europe and the discovery and settlement of the Eastern seaboard to the ratification of the Constitution. Mr. Hawke's previous books include "In The Midst of a Revolution" and "A Transaction of Free Men."
MANILA, Aug. 10 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam said today that he supported the effort of President Ferdinand Marcos of the Philippines to get North Vietnam to the conference table.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 10 Mr. and Mrs. John Francis White have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Cecilia Clopton White, to Thomas Channing Moore. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Channing Moore of Paget, Bermuda, formerly of Bronxville.
Statistics and the views of experts indicate that, despite the recent public and official outcry, the over-all price of food in New York City is not notably exorbitant.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 A strongly backed effort began in Congress today to alter the immigration law to allow Cuban refugees to obtain regular immigrant status and, eventually, citizenship.
The recent rise in municipal bond yields showed signs yesterday of reaching at least some sort of temporary plateau.

When the Malaysian federation was established on Sept 16, 1963, Indonesia, refused to grant it diplomatic recognition. President Sukarno of Indonesia charged that Malaysia, uniting the former British possessions of Malay, the two Borneo territories and, until 1965, Singapore, was a neocolonialist crea- tion designed to perpetuate British influence in the area.
MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 10--Miss Reisa Lou Baylin and Michael Charles Temkin will be married next month.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 In two statements at his news conference yesterday President Johnson removed any hope which may have existed that he will use the power and influence he has freely exerted in other national problem areas to halt the accelerating pace of inflation and restore to normal the flow of interstate commerce. LONDON, Aug. 10 prime Minister Wilson carried out a major reshuffle of his Cabinet tonight as the House of Commons gave final approval to the Labor Government's drastic...
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 10 (AP) A Nevada investigation into alleged underworld takeoffs from legal gambling concentrated today on a Las Vegas Strip hotel-casino in which the F.B.I. once eavesdropped.
DETROIT, Aug. 10 Chuck Dressen, the peppery manager of the pennant-winning Brooklyn Dodgers of 1952 and 1953, died today in Ford Hospital here. He was 67 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 Selective Service officials said today that all male aliens, both on immigrant and nonimmigrant visas, who were born on or after Sept. 15, 1925, and who have reached the age of 18 must register by law with the Selective Service System within six months of their date of entry into the United States.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) The House passed a billion dollar military construction authorization bill today, which its sponsor criticized as "austere and disappointing."
RUTHERFORD, N. J., Aug. 10 Milton B. Ignatius, a retired New York and Rutherford lawyer, died today at Hackensack Hospital. His age was 79.

J. W. Mays, Inc., the Brooklyn-based specialty-store chain, reported yesterday preliminary results for the fiscal year ended July 31, including a rise in sales to above the $100-million mark for the first time.

Miss Nicole Henry of New York and Paris, daughter of Paul-Marc Henry of New York and Mrs. Blanchard Henry of Paris, has become affianced to Pierre Berger of Paris and Lyon, France. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Berger of Lyon.

AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 10 (AP) A laboratory report today said that the blood of Charles J. Whitman, the University of Texas sniper, contained no detectable alcohol, barbiturates or other drugs or stimulants.

LEONIA, N. J., Aug. 10 The engagement of Miss Wendy Ann Gold to Saul Feldstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Feldstein of New York, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Martin Gold.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 10 The Security Council postponed further public debate today on South Arabia to seek a formula in private for United Nations intervention to ease tension in that troubled area.
Efforts to settle the 108-day newspaper tie-up here remained stalled yesterday.

Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., apparently at the instance of the Securities and Exchange Commission, put off for two weeks yesterday a stockholder vote on a grant of options to seven of the company's 10 directors.

PORTILLO, Chile, Aug. 10 (UPI) Guy Perillat, a 26-yearold Frenchman who thought he was jinxed in international competition, streaked down the treacherous Condor's west course today and won the giant slalom in the world ski championships by half a second.
An application for the right to operate a scheduled helicopter service in Washington was filed yesterday by San Francisco and Oakland Helicopter Airlines of Oakland, Calif.

MONTREAL, Aug. 10 (Canadian Press) Bunky Henry of Valdosta, Ga., the defender, and Bobby Cole of South Africa, the British Amateur champion, scored first-round victories today in the Canadian amateur golf championship.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 10 Edmund Greek Davenport, a commercial artist who produced covers for The Saturday Evening Post, Collier's, American Magazine and Women's Home Companion during the late 1920's and early 1930's, died here yesterday. He was 74 years old and lived on Country Club Road West.

The engagement of Miss Dixie Lee Caddell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. LeRoy W. Caddell of Grymes Hill, S. I., and Delray Beach, Fla., to Howard M. Fisher, son of Mrs. Howard V. Fisher and the late Mr. Fisher of Wyomissing, Pa., has been made known by the parents of the bride-to-be.
HONEOYE FALLS, N. Y. Aug. 10 Governor Rockefeller conceded today that the squabbling among the candidates for the Democratic gubernatoria nomination was helping his campaign for re-election.

On the evening before the House of Representatives voted to pass the civil rights bill, several hundred Negroes in Grenada, Miss., gathered to hear a speech by the field director of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. When the police decided that the gathering was impeding the flow of traffic, they attacked the Negroes with repeated volleys of tear gas. Eighteen hours later the gas fumes still hung heavy over the area.
DETROIT, Aug. 10 A Negro pedestrian was wounded by hit-and-run gunmen tonight as scattered vandalism broke out on the city's East Side for the second straight day.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 A $14-billion domestic appropriations bill cleared the Senate tonight after two days of angry and futile efforts at budget slashing.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 10 The nomination of Jim Johnson, a hard-core segregationist, as the Democratic candidate for Governor of Arkansas yesterday was interpreted today by political observers as a clear expression of fear and resentment among white voters. The Johnson victory had many roots. But mainly it was regarded ...
LONDON, Aug. 11 (AP) The statement of account of the Bank of England for the week ended yesterday (in thousands of pounds) follows:
TOKYO, Aug. 11 (AP) Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon said tonight that the Vietnam war might end in two years if it continued on its present scale.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 A New York member of Congress was accused on the Senate floor today of having used "blackmail pure and simple" to exact campaign contributions from civil service typists.
SANTO DOMINGO, Domini- can Republic, Aug. 11 (UPI) One person was killed today as gunfire erupted in various sec- tors of the city. It was not de- termined who was doing the shooting.

PARIS If the French couturiers had their way, bridal gowns and veils would in no way resemble those worn by Mrs. Patrick Nugent and the other young women who think weddings are a time for traditional attire.
OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 11 The 72d annual Monmouth County Horse Show will be held at Wolf Hill Farm, adjacent to the Monmouth Park Race Track here, from Thursday through Aug. 21.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11 Gambling control authorties in Nevada won a Federal court victory today in their fight to be able to exclude hoodlum elements from casinos, even as customers.
TEL AVIV, Aug. 11 (AP) Kentucky's touring basketball team, paced by Pat Riley and Louis Dampier, routed Warsaw, 87-57, tonight and won an international tournament.

TUEXEDO PARK, N. Y.--Like Sleeping Beauty, the house of the Albert Christ-Janers lay hidden for years within an almost impenetrable growth of vines and trees until it was awakened, not with a kiss, but with a cry of delight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) The House passed by a 341-to-1 vote today a bill to add $11.9-billion to the Federal-aid highway program, after barely beating a Republican drive to eliminate $493-million for highway beautification.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 President Johnson has asked W. Averell Harriman, Ambassador at Large, to explore every indication from whatever source and no matter how faint or indistinct that the North Vietnamese Government and its allies are moving toward negotiations.

Governor Rockefeller ordered yesterday an investigation into what he said was the inability of property owners in congested municipal areas to obtain adequate fire insurance. The Governor said the problem was becoming more acute in high-occupancy slum areas, including Harlem, Bedford-Stuyvesant in Brooklyn and some sections of Buffalo.

A large detail of policemen moved into the usually quiet, middle-class and almost totally white section of East Flatbush yesterday following an incident Wednesday night in which a Negro allegedly shot two white men.

Consumers in low-income neighborhoods are paying more for butter, eggs and some other staples as well as for so-called bargain substitutes than the average cost in the city, the Department of Mar- kets declared yesterday.

"There is too much emphasis placed on the mechanics and the physical-material background of theaters in relation to acting. All I want is good actors. Let's do a good job first. If we deserve it, people will help us."
Trustees of the State University yesterday elected Dr. Joseph K. Hill president of the Downstate Medical Cen- ter.

FRANCIS POLLINI is an American now living in England. His first novel, "Night" (1963), was a searing portrait of prison-camp life during the Korean war. Kingsley Amis is an Englishman who won American hearts a dozen years ago with his first novel, the comical "Lucky Jim." Both are talented, intelligent and sensitive writers who have somehow gone very wrong. Their new offerings are, in a word, awful.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11 Three of Communist China's have been invited to two international conferences in the San Francisco area next month.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) The Senate Rules Committee made public today the transcripts of two closed meetings in answer to criticism of its approval of a "modest elections reform" bill without holding hearings on a more stringent Administration measure.

Vice President Humphrey said last night that the adversaries of the United States in Vietnam had not responded to recent peace initiatives by Asians because they still believed the United States would abandon the struggle.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 Senator Frank E. Moss, Democrat of Utah, quoted Under Secretary of State George W. Ball today as having said that the United States would support a General Assembly resolution affirming the United Nations' right to oversee South Africa's administration of South-West Africa.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Osborne Scott Cranston of Perth, Australia, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sonya Frances Cranston of Hong Kong, to Andries Philip LeFevre, also of Hong Kong. He is a son of Mrs. Philip Flagler LeFevre of New Paltz, N.Y., and the late Mr. LeFevre.
UP AT the top of your radio dial is WMCA, whose supercharged disk jockeys have become known as "the good guys."
LONDON, Aug. 11 Prime Minister Wilson's sudden overhaul of his Cabinet produced predictable reactions today from the right to the left.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 11 In a tensely fought test match, Clark Graebner of Beachwood, Ohio, defeated Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., 6-4, 6-4, today and became virtually certain to be named with Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., for the singles in the Davis Cup matches with Mexico starting here Saturday.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 11 Batman has entered the war against the Vietcong.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (UPI) Randy Hundley, a rookie catcher, hit a single, double, triple and home run today and scored the winning run in the 11th inning as the Chicago Cubs beat the Houston Astros, 9-8, in the first game of a double-header.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 The United States is interceding quietly with India and Pakistan in an effort to persuade them to avoid steps that might lead to another armed clash.

Most subway passengers get nothing but a ride for their tokens, but a fortunate few get a ride, a thank you and a cheerful ching-a-ling greeting from a coin collector held in the hand of a smiling conductor.
ELGIN, Ill., Aug. 11 Mrs. Mignon M. Dawes, wife of Gen. Charles C. Dawes, retired executive vice president of the Monon Railroad, died today in the Sherman Hospital. She was 76 years old.

NEW HARTFORD, N.Y. Aug. 11 Mr. and Mrs. Stuart MacMackin of New Hartford and East Chop, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia MacMackin, to Ivo Meisner, son of Mrs. Maimo Meisner of Hamden, Conn.

PORTILLO, Chile, Aug. 11 (UPI) Marielle Goitschel added two more gold medals for France in the Alpine world ski championships today when she won the giant slalom by more than one second and also captured the Alpine combined title.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange declined yesterday as a modest rally at the opening ran into investor disappointment over Britain's trade figures for July.
The Boeing Company's capital expenditures program this year and next will involve outlays of about $500-million. About $121-million of this has already been spent this year.
Miss Susan Fleschner and Edmond Charles Semel will be married Sept. 22 at the Carlyle.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 Controller of the Currency James J. Saxon openly denounced today for the first time a position taken by the American Bankers Association.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11--Because of strong opposition by Southerners and the Republican leadership, Senate consideration of the House-passed civil rights bill is not expected to begin before Sept. 6.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Aug. 11 Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, the recent challenger for the world chess title, retained first place in the Piatigorsky Cup Tournament after drawing his 15th-round game with Miguel Najdorf of Argentina at the Miramar Hotel here last night. Spassky sacrificed the exchange in a 22-move Queen's Gambit Declined to force perpetual check.
The spot rate on the British pound rose in quiet trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The currency closed at $2.7901, up 6 points from Wednesday.
BAGUIO, the Philippines, Aug. 11 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam explained today his stand on proposals for an Asian conference on peace in Vietnam.

MALVERNE, L.I., Aug. 11 The Malverne School Board, acting against a midnight deadline, voted last night to complete integration of the community's elementary schools by ending de facto segregation on the kindergarten level.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 11 (AP) The Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra arrived in Beirut yesterday and ran into a press campaign aimed at barring the orchestra from performing at the Baalbek International Festival.
Traders who are bullish on the outlook for soybean futures liked what they read in the Government's crop report that came out after the close of trading Wednesday.

WESTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 11 Leo Gale of Bellport won the gross prize with a 42, 37-79 in the Long Island Golf Association's senior tournament at the 6,247-yard par-35, 35-70 Westhampton Country Club today Gale also led Class D for golfers 60 to 64 years old.

Douglas Morrison Jefferson, a vice president of the National Bank of Westchester, was arrested yesterday on charges that he embezzled $64,000 of the bank's funds, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said last night. He will be arraigned today.
Two major New York banks are in the process of acquiring important investments in banks in Europe, it was indicated yesterday.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 11--Mrs. Dorothy Groser Smith wife of Walter J. Smith, vice president of the Long Island Real Estate Board, died today in Community Hospital here. She was 58 years old and lived in Lattingtown.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 11 They all live with danger: the rifleman groping through the jungle, the pilot bombing oil storage areas near Hanoi and Haiphong, the civilian aid worker driving along an insecure highway late at night. But not one of them has a more hazardous job than 12 young men who fly from a base somewhere south of the demilitarized zone that divides North from South Vietnam.
ZADAR, Yugoslavia, Aug. 11 The public prosecutor's office indicated today that Mihajlo Mihajlov, the controversial Yugoslav intellectual, would be tried a second time by the Communist Government.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 10. A Brazilian slum, favela in Portuguese, seen at a distance does not look like much of an asset.

LANSING, Mich., Aug. 11 (UPI) Charges of gambling, bribery and extortion involving unnamed public officials and government employes were listed in a petition by the Michigan Attorney General today in asking for a grand jury investigation in Wayne County.
Huntington Hartford has kept the wrecking ball away from the old Metropolitan Opera House for at least five more days.
Nikos Bel-Jon, an artist who made murals in metal, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 55 years old. His home and studio were at 159 East 69th Street.

PAGE, Ariz., Aug. 11 (AP) Six teen-age boys, lost with a party of 26 persons in rugged canyon country since yesterday, stumbled to the nearest trading post late today to report the others were suffering badly from lack of nourishment.

The stock market slipped yesterday for the fourth straight session as it neared the low levels of 1966 on the popular averages. Volume increased slightly to 5.7 million shares from 5.29 million shares the previous day.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) Fine Thanks, a 92-1 shot charged through the stretch today to win the $15,000 Ann Rutledge. Purse for Illinoisfoaled 2-year-old fillies at Arlington Park.
Little League baseball players gave up their Bayside, Queens, ball park yesterday but were promised a new field.

William E. Clark, vice president and general manager of the textile division of the United States Rubber Company until 1963, died Wednesday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 61 years old and lived in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 11 (AP) Al Jackson, the St. Louis pitcher, broke a 1-1 tie with a runscoring triple in the seventh inning tonight and the Cardinals went on to defeat the Philadelphia Phillies, 5-1.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 11 (AP) Saying that National States' Rights party speakers had implanted "the idea of hanging" in a crowd's mind, Circuit Judge William J. O'Donnell extended today for 90 days an injunction banning rallies by the party in Baltimore.

PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 11 The unmanned Lunar Orbiter spacecraft, unable to find its guiding star but undeterred, raced on toward the moon tonight with a new accuracy that swelled hopes for the mission's success.
Reaction here yesterday to London's admonishment of detergent manufacturers over their advertising expenditures was 99 and 44/100ths per cent mild.
JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 11 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s civil rights organization called today for a guaranteed annual income of $4,000 a year for all impoverished American families.

LONDON, Aug. 12 Prof. Felix Andries Vening Meinesz, a Dutch geophysicist who pioneered a method of studying the earth's interior beneath ocean beds and who developed a theory of the origin of mountains, died today at Amersfoot, the Netherlands. He was 79 years old.
The Gillette Company will make its debut soon in luxury fragrance products for men. And Doyle Dane Bernbach, Inc., is preparing the comingout party.
Fifteen thousand Westchester commuters got home late last night, some of them three-anda-quarter hours late, after a third rail was damaged on the New York Central Railroad's Harlem Division.

LANSING, Mich., Aug. 11 (UPI) A second Detroit area race course was named today in a petition filed by State Attorney General Frank J. Kelley charging the drugging of horses and violations of other racing regulations.

The marriage of Mrs. Phyllis Hoffman Taylor of 108 East 82d Street, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Hoffman of Palm Beach, Fla., to Jules M. Baron, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Baron of Cedarhurst, L.I., took place yesterday afternoon.
The New York and the American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday the changes carried below in the share holdings of officers, directors and major stockholders.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 A House committee tentatively backed today all provisions of a Senate-passed bill to end the airline strike for up to 180 days.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (UPI) John Lennon, leader of Britain's Beatles, said tonight that he was sorry he had ever compared the popularity of the Beatles with that of Jesus. But he insisted it was true that the quartet is more popular.

A dismal picture of Jewish life in the Soviet Union a picture of "fear, loneliness, inequality, ignorance and decline" was given yesterday by a group of American Reform rabbis who recently returned from I there.

The Federal Insurance Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries, the Vigilant Insurance Company and the Great Northern Insurance Company, reported yesterday earnings for the first half of 1966 of $4,059,000, or $1.16 a share. Last year the earnings were $3,202,000, or 92 cents a share.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 11 Governor Rockefeller expressed sympathy today with attempts to lower the state minimum voting age from 21 to 18.

The deadlock has been broken in the stalled collective bargaining negotiations between the city and the representatives of its policemen and firemen. But spokesmen for both sides indicated yesterday there had not been any settlement yet.
BOSTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) Tony Conigliaro drove in five runs with a homer, a double and two singles tonight to lead the Boston Red Sox to a 13-3 victory over the Cleveland Indians.
Franklin D. Roosevelt had an enduring and secret romance with a woman who once served as his wife's social secretary, according to a former aide to the President.

Bloomfield College, a 100year-old institution affiliated with the New Jersey Synod of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., has bought the 322-acre Knoll Golf Club in Parsippany-Troy Hills for a new campus.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 The United States today issued the text of a protest to France against a "virulent attack" on American policy in Vietnam by a Gaullist deputy.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) The Senate passed by an 87-to-0 vote today a program of broadened medical benefits for active and retired military personnel and their dependents.

CLIFTON, N.J., Aug. 11 At 11 o'clock this morning, a woman in a billowing pink housedress, coffee cup in one hand, cigarette in the other, languidly drifted out upon the terrace of her apartment. Below her, 100 persons were gathered at the first tee of the Upper Montclair Country Club's golf course, idly watching a professional from Texas tee off in the first round of the $100,000 Thunderbird tournament.
The former supervisor of food at the Federal House of Detention, 427 West Street, will return there next week this time as an inmate.
PARIS, Aug. 11 (AP) Indonesia has informed the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization that she is ready to resume active participation.

UNIONDALE, L.I., Aug. 11 Mr. and Mrs. John W. Weber have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Jean Weber, to Richard Thomas Girards, son of Mr. and Mrs. Valentine Girards of East Meadow.
A Federal survey showing that only 340 Negroes are being trained as registered nurses in New York City is expected to set off major efforts to recruit nursing students from minority groups.

MONTREAL, Aug. 11 (Canadian Press) Bobby Cole, the 18-year-old British Amateur champion from South Africa, advanced to the quarter-finals today of the Canadian amateur golf championship by beating Dick Sucher of Mequon, Wis., 1 up.
The new convertible preferred stock of Kinney National Service, Inc., has been approved for listing by the New York Stock Exchange and trading will begin on Monday, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 President Johnson signed today an executive order aimed at improving coordination of Federal programs in the nation's troubled cities.
The 62d annual convention of the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards will be held Sept. 11 to 14 at the Concord Hotel at Lake Kiamesha, N.Y.
VIENNA, Aug. 11 A report that Archduke Otto of Habsburg, for many years pretender to the Austrian throne, returned from exile today stirred excitement and speculation in Austria.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) President Johnson signed into law today a bill creating the machinery for a new international agreement for handling investment disputes.

SEWICKLEY, Pa., Aug. 11 Mrs. JoAnne Gunderson Carner, a three-time former champion, led the advance today into the semi-finals of the 66th annual women's National Amateur golf championship. Moving up with Mrs. Carner were Mrs. Marlene Stewart Streit, another former champion; Mrs. Barbara White Boddie and Roberta Albers.
Mayor Lindsay has broadened his efforts to help New York's giant garment industry enhance its status, by inviting the participation of a trade group embracing all price lines and styling approaches.
CLIFTON, N.J., Aug. 11 Nine professionals produced golf's biggest scoring jam of the year today by tying for the lead with 69's in the opening round of the $100,000 Thunderbird tournament.

Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., a subsidiary of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, announced yesterday the appointment of George Konkol as operations vice president of its Electronic Tube division.

Lynda Bird, President Johnson's elder daughter, went home to Washington yesterday after a New York visit that she capped by staying out until 4 A.M. and holding hands with George Hamilton, the actor, while he serenaded her.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 11 John F. FitzGerald of 255-03 West End Drive, founder and retired president of Fitz-U, Inc., of Hicksville, distributors of large-scale cleaning equipment, died yesterday in North Shore Hospital, Manhasset. He was 71 years old.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., Aug. 11 The engagement of Miss Louise Ann Irving to Peter Edward Donoghue, son of Mrs. Harold E. Donoghue and the late Borough Councilman Donoghue, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Irving. A wedding in October is planned.
Walston Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the appointment of Michael A. Ward as vice president for research.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 11 (UPI) Senator Edward M. Kennedy appeared last night in a new role as a dramatic narrator at the Tanglewood music festival, reading a touching tribute to an assassinated President.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 11 Thirty-five African states presented a letter to Secretary General Thant today asking for priority for the question of South-West Africa's status on the agenda of the 21st General Assembly, which opens Sept. 20.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 11 (AP) Ellis W. Ryan, the former president of the Cleveland Indians baseball club, died today in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 62 years old.

LONDON, Aug. 11, (UPI) A woman from New Jersey who voted in the British election in March has lost her United States citizenship, but she has 60 days to appeal her case, the American Embassy said today.

Every New York election is important; the one this November is particularly so. Not only will it decide who will sit in Congress and on the judicial bench but also who will run the state's government for the next four years and who will rewrite the state's Constitution. A Governor, a Legislature and a constitutional convention will be determined by the election outcome.
Relief clients who die penniless will no longer have to be buried in Potter's Field.
ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Aug. 11 Edwin J. O'Malley Sr., a construction executive and a sportsman, died today of a heart attack at his home here. He was 62 years old.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 11 (UPI) Jim Alder of Scotland won the Empire and Commonwealth Games marathon today despite taking a wrong turn just before entering the stadium.

WOODBURY, L.I., Aug. 11 Alexander Mayer of Woodmere, L.I., defeated Mike Apfelbaum of Roslyn Heights, L.I., 6-2, 6-1, to win the Metropolitan junior tennis championship today at the Woodbury Country Club.
The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company announced here yesterday the election as vice presidents of Harold S. Brush, Arthur C. Eschenlauer, William E. Pike and Thomas W. Stanley.

SAD to say, but by far the most rewarding concept of Marvin Cordon's "Ballet Concepts," seen last night at Theater Four, 424 West 55th Street, was the only one not by Mr. Gordon himself. Four of the program's five ballets had choreography of sorts by the energetic Mr. Gordon. The fifth was Louis Johnson's "A View From a Ghetto."

GENEVA, Aug. 11--The United States offered today to demonstrate on one of its idle nuclear reactors what it termed an effective and unobtrusive system for checking on the projected prohibition on the production of nuclear materials for weapons.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 The United States declared today that the beating of an American professor by Argentine policemen was a closed incident as far as the Government is concerned.
MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 11 The formation of a seven-member advisory committee for consumer protection was announced today by Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson.

The Pressman's Union and the World Journal Tribune, Inc., are scheduled to resume negotiations next Tuesday in an effort to resolve the 109-day-old dispute that has blocked publication of the new company's proposed morning, afternoon and Sunday newspapers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 Thirty-six per cent of the nation's nonwhite families had incomes last year of $3,000 or less and thus fell below the poverty line, the Census Bureau reported today.

Most major manufacturers of garments made of durablepress fabrics are providing proper working conditions, which prevent workers from suffering physical reaction to chemicals in the fabrics, according to Fred Fortess, manager of the consumer technical services, fabric development and styling, for the Celanese Fibers Marketing Company.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 111.7 on Tuesday from 111.1 on Monday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) The Senate passed today a bill to pump $3-billion more of Government mortgage funds into the sagging home building industry.
An engineering study to determine whether the proposed 1,350-foot World Trade Center would interfere with television program reception will begin soon.
LONDON, Aug. 11 (UPI) The British Broadcasting Corporation said today that it would stand by its screening of a program described as the frankest film on sex to be shown on British television.
WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 11 A $46,000 air-conditioning unit that cooled its owner but steamed his neighbors has been turned off by a Superior Court judge here at least at night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 An increase in the Government's set-aside of copper for defense uses will be announced early next week, it was made known today.
City and state agencies announced yesterday that they had changed the plans for the controversial East River transit tunnel from Queens to East 63d Street to provide four tracks instead of three.
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 11 (Reuters) A Finnish sergeant eclipsed today the world record for rifle shooting with a score of 556 points for 20 shots from three positions at 300 meters.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 Intercity truck tonnage and freight traffic generated by carloadings on U.S. railroads in the week ended Aug. 6, were ahead of the levels in the corresponding week of 1965.

Despite opposition by the Port of New York Authority, jets at La Guardia Airport began taking off in numbers yesterday morning on a previously restricted runway that leads toward Jackson Heights, Queens.

Ernie Terrell, whose indiscretion and stubbornness made Cassius Clay a world traveler, received New York State's seal of approval yesterday. The threeman State Athletic Commission granted licenses to Terrell and George A. Hamid Jr., his new manager.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 11 The Nagaland State Legislative Assembly put the state government out of office today by a vote of 32 to 6 after a brief debate on a motion of no confidence in the Chief Minister Shilu Ao.

Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner's present wife said yesterday that she had been "upset and hurt" ever since last January because of critical remarks about Gracie Mansion made by Mrs. John Lindsay, the wife of the present Mayor.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 11 Mr. and Mrs. David Johnstone of Montclair Country Club won their second consecutive title today in the 35th annual Robbins Memorial husband-and-wife Class A scotch foursomes tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association by scoring 37, 43-80 at Fenway Golf Club.
Most issues on the American Stock Exchange drifted down yesterday in moderate trading.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 Two Republicans complained to the House today that the Office of Economic Opportunity had discriminated in the award of a Job Corps contract in favor of a Democratic party donor.

MONTREAL, Aug. 11 (AP) The American Bar Association closed out its 89th annual convention here today with a report praising President Johnson and the Justice Department on recent judicial appointments.
The Capital Cities Broadcasting Corporation announced here yesterday the election of Thomas S. Murphy as chairman and chief executive officer.
Dr. Alfred Glennon Flagg, an attending surgeon at French Hospital for 20 years, died Wednesday morning at the Wentworth-by-the-Sea Hotel, Portsmouth, N.H., of a heart attack. His age was 68.

Gulf States Land and Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that its subsidiary, Colmar Suriname Oil Company, Ltd. would receive an over-riding royalty of 3 per cent on oil and gas production, if any, attributable to its interest in concessions off the coast of Surinam and French Guiana.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) Employes of United States Government civilian agencies traveling on official business will ride for 10 per cent less than regular fares on 16 Western railroads.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 11 The engagement of Miss Stephanie Hobart to Paul Demun Griffin has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Addison Hobart, parents of the future bride, Mr. Griffin is the son of Mrs. William Griffin of Greenwich and the late Mr. Griffin.

A key campaign aide of Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson in the battle for the Democratic nomination for Governor said yesterday that many county leaders and delegates "previously thought to be" backing Council President Frank D. O'Connor were now "leaning toward" Mr. Nickerson.

Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that a special meeting of its stockholders was set for Oct. 11 in Houston to vote on the proposed merger of the Paramount Pictures Corporation into Gulf and Western. Stockholders of record Sept. 9, will be entitled to vote on this and related amendments to the articles of incorporation, including a proposed increase in the authorized capital stock of Gulf and Western.

The Metropolitan Opera will present 23 operas in its first season at its new home in the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. These include nine new productions previously announced. One of these, Samuel Barber's "Antony and Cleopatra," will open the 30-week season Sept. 16. The closing date will be April 15, 1967.

BONN On May 29, 1951, I lunched with Generals Eisenhower and "Lightning Joe" Collins, then NATO commander and U.S. Army Chief of Staff. Collins explained how, to deter Russia, the American "constabulary" in Germany was being transformed into the equivalent of an armored division, thus boosting U.S. military strength beyond limits technically set by Congress.
Miss Sharon Ashley Wells, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Wells of 903 Park Avenue, will be married on Sept. 10 to Michael K. Mann, son of Mr. and Mrs. J.A. Mann of Chicago.

THE Brooklyn Dodgers of the Continental League, New York's newest pro football team, consists of willing, largely anonymous young players who have no money but big dreams, according to their coach, Andy Robustelli.
BRANCHVILLE, N.J., Aug. 11 Fire One, a mount with a history of bad hooves, won the open jumper bonus point class tonight with Kathy Kusner handling the reins at the Sussex County horse show.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 A group of faculty members at the University of Pennsylvania has called on the school to abolish its Institute for Cooperative Research because of its involvement with projects dealing with chemical and biological warfare.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 Willie Stargell's two-run homer in the ninth inning tonight in Forbes Field was the final note of frustration for the New York Mets.
Vito Pisa, owner of Chez Vito, a restaurant at 36 East 60th Street, died of a heart attack in a Rome clinic yesterday. He was 64 years old.
The investment-banking syndicate that had been offering $250-million of American Telephone and Telegraph Company debentures was terminated yesterday with about $80-million or more unsold.
LONDON, Aug. 11 An increase in British imports last month kept pace with an increase in exports, the Board of Trade reported today. As a result, Britain's trade ledgers stayed in the red for July.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 11--"Logic and economics must prevail in the end. Britain and Rhodesia will settle this thing because it is in their interest to do so, both of them."
CARTHAGE, Miss., Aug. 11 (AP)--A bomb exploded at the home of a Negro civil rights leader last night, inflicting damage but no injuries.
Prostitutes and suspected women naracotics addicts and thieves were rounded up and taken to a single precinct yesterday as a new Police and Correction Department program began.
GREENVILLE, S.C. John T. Fouke, president of the Fouke Fur Company, is head of an unusual business in an improbable place.
ASIAMESE kitten sauntered out among tigers and wildcats at Arnold Constable yesterday and nonchalantly licked a paw. The cat wasn't fooled a bit all those wild beasts were just rabbits in disguise.
John O. Watson, chief editorial writer for the Hearst news papers, died last night of pneu monia in Trafalgar Hospital He was 64 years old.

William T. Garvin, since 1950 an assistant district attorney in the Complaint Bureau of the Queens County District Attorney's office, died yesterday at his home, 164-11 Brinkerhoff Avenue in St. Albans, Queens. He was 64 years old.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 11 (UPI)--John Romano slammed a two-run homer and Don Buford a three-run double in a fifth-inning uprising tonight to lead the Chicago White Sox to a 10-9 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.
A meeting of the Board of Estimate held last May 20 was declared null and void yesterday in State Supreme Court because neither Mayor Lindsay nor City Council President Frank D. O'Connor was present.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 11--A 34-year-old Maryland man was arrested yesterday in a case of alleged industrial espionage involving the theft and attempted sale of documents valued at $3-million.

The superliner United States arrived yesterday at Pier 86, Hudson River, at 46th Sheet, with 1,844 passengers, the largest number carried by the 51,000-ton vessel on an Atlantic crossing in her 14-year career.

DETROIT, Aug. 11 (UPI) Terry Nofsinger, a reserve quarterback, threw two secondhalf touchdown passes to Billy Campbell and a third to Sonny Randle tonight and led the St. Louis Cardinals to their second straight exhibition game vic28-14, over the Detroit Lions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 One of the oddities of a housewife's buying habits is that she does not always choose the less expensive bread from among brands of similar quality, House investigators were told today.

A year-long demonstration project providing the nation's first scheduled air cushion vehicle passenger service has been successfully concluded on the West Coast, according to the Bell Aerosystems Company of Buffalo, which built the craft.
The interracial Freedom National Bank took possession yesterday of five-story brick building in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn for use as the first branch of the Harlem-based bank.

YONKERS, Aug. 11--Polaris, the 7-to-5 favorite, won the $123,015 Yonkers Futurity Trot at rain-dampened Yonkers Raceway so easily tonight that George Sholty, his driver, spent nearly as much time looking backward as he did looking ahead.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 11 (AP) Harbor View Farm's Super Shovel won the Tudor Era Purse at Atlantic City today, covering the 1 1/16 miles on the turf in 1:45 3-5 and finishing 2 lengths ahead of Tully Jr.
WASHTNGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner recommended today that Trans-Carribean Airways be given permanent authority for New York San Juan service.

The Tribunal of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn refused yesterday to intervene in the teachers' strike at St. John's University. The dispute has been marked by student unrest and picketing of the school's Brooklyn and Queens campuses.

Star performers from Maine to Virginia will begin competition today in the American Water Ski Association's Eastern regional tournament in Scotia, N.Y., on the Mohawk River, just across the bridge from Schenectady.
Herman L. Shaw, president and director of the Aquafilter Corporation of Newton, Mass., pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court to stock-fraud charges.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 A number of Republican candidates, seeking a way to exploit the Vietnamese issue in the coming campaign, are planning to emphasize the so-called "credibility gap." They are likely to turn up some votes, too, because most political observers believe that a good part of the public does believe there is a suspicious gap between the Administration's statements and the facts of the war.
James (Sandy) McMenemon, a leader in the Society for the Prevention of Negroes Getting Everything, was arrested last night in Brooklyn and accused in the sale of marijuana.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 The deficit in the United States balance of international payments fell to less than $150million in the second quarter of this year, the White House disclosed today.

Council President Frank O'Connor has boldly but implausibly asserted his belief that he may get the Liberal endorsement if the Democrats nominate him for Governor. In view of the unanimous vote against him by the Liberal party's policy committee and that party's tradition of disciplined action, the O'Connor hopes do not appear to have much foundation.

CANTHO, South Vietnam, Aug. 11 President Johnson ordered a detailed report yesterday on a United States air strike that killed or wounded more than 150 South Vietnamese civilians, an American military adviser said today.

Miss Roslyn Arlene Small, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Small of Atlantic Beach, L.I., was married here last evening to Robert Jay Haber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Haber of Harrison, N.Y. Rabbi Sol Roth performed the ceremony at the Hampshire House.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Aug. 11--Mrs. Billie Jean Moffitt King; the Wimbledon champion from Long Beach, Calif., and three top foreign-seeded players advanced to the semifinals in the Piping Rock Club's invitation grass court women's tennis tournament today.

ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 11 (UPI) Harmon Killebrew's single in the ninth inning today drove in what proved to be the winning run as the Minnesota Twins went on to post a 4-3 victory over the California Angels.

TOKYO, Aug. 11 (AP)--Communist China provoked new speculation today about the health and authority of Mao Tse-tung by deleting from the newspaper Jenmin Jih Pao, of Peking, paragraphs relating to a reappearance of the party chairman in Peking.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11 The Chicago Police Department said tonight that civil rights demonstrators had announced that they would stage a protest march tomorrow in the city neighborhood of Bogan.
The birth rate began returning to normal in several leading hospitals here yesterday following a sharp rise nine months after the 1965 blackout.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 Rural Alabama is likely to witness in the next 30 days a farm election campaign at new levels of intensity.

The waterfront industry has switched sides in the controversial issue of how many longshoremen the port needs, and has asked the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor to open the longshoremen's register to new comers.
GUATEMALA CITY, Aug. 11 The Inter-American Development Bank and the Guatemalan government signed today loan agreements amounting to $9million at a ceremony in the National Palace.
