PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 Northern California won the United States girls' tennis team championship for the third straight year today by defeating Southern California, 4-3, in the final round at the Germantown Cricket Club's grass courts.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 11--United States officials have again revised upward their estimate of Chinese Communist troop strength in North Vietnam. They now place the total at 50,000 uniformed soldiers.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.
HOUSTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) Mrs. Esperanza Del Valle Vasquez today became the first artificial heart pump patient to leave her bed.
The Procter Gamble Company had the highest sales and earnings in its 129-year history for the fiscal year ended June 30.

ENUGU, Nigeria, Aug. 9 A Week ago, shortly after the army mutiny led by Hausa tribesmen from the North that took the lives of scores of officers and enlisted men from the Ibo tribe, the Ibo here in their Eastern Region homeland were talking of secession.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Ont., Motorists from Michigan, crossing the International Bridge into Canada here, enjoy fine industrial views of paper mills, ships laden with wheat and iron ore and the Soo Locks linking Lake Superior and Lake Huron.
DETROIT, Aug. 11 (AP) The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Detroit today announced selection of a successor to the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, controversial radio priest of the nineteen-thirties.
The city's water supply dropped to 81 per cent of reservoir capacity yesterday. On Wednesday it was at 81.3 per cent of capacity.
The city has opened a branch office, supported by private contributions, in the racially troubled East New York section of Brooklyn.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 11 The Connecticut Republican leadership's move to develop a liberal image for the party suffered a setback yesterday with the victory of former State Senator John M. Lupton in a primary election in Fairfield County.

New York got its last look at the Baltimore Orioles last night unless, of course, the Mets get into the World Series. But even if the Mets make it, the public is not likely to see a spectacle like the 11-inning one that unfolded during the evening between the Orioles and Yankees.

MADISON, N.J., Aug. 11 Mrs. Louise Whittlesey Felt, who for 33 years was a missionary in China with her husband, the late Dr. Carl A. Felt, died Tuesday at the Crestwood Nursing Home in Whippany. She was 91 years old.

CENTERPORT, L.I., Aug. 11 Ted Janeway of the Cold Spring Harbor (L.I.) Beach Club and James Blair of the Cedar Paint Yacht Club of Westport, Conn., were the leaders after two races today in the third annual Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound novice sailing championships.

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 11 Mrs. John H. Bartol and Mrs. M. Stuart Roesler, both of Stanwich, scored 40, 40-80 on the 6,003-yard, par-38, 38-76 Wee Burn Country Club course today to tie for the low gross score in the one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association.
The first of some 2,000 high school graduates from disadvantaged areas who normally could not meet the high standards for admission will be accepted this fall by the City University.

GRENADA, Miss., Aug. 11 (AP) The City Council late today banned all gatherings in the town square, where exploding cherry bombs and flying bottles and rocks kept racial tension at a high pitch the last three nights.
The appointment of Mitchell Sviridoff, the director of the New Haven antipoverty program, to direct the city's effort to aid the poor will be announced on Monday, it was learned yesterday.

A $3.5-million treble damage suit charging antitrust violations by 15 American steamship lines has been filed in the United States District Court of Columbia by Sapphire Steamship Lines and its affiliates.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 11 Two Cleveland policemen who infiltrated the Communist party said today that they had no knowledge that riots on the city's racially troubled East Side were inspired by Communists.

A complaint has been filed in New York Federal District Court charging Genesco, Inc., with liability to the public stockholders of S.H. Kress Co. from whom it purchased stock in the variety-store chain in 1963.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 President Johnson received from his Cabinet today an unusually comprehensive report on the state of the economy a report that indicates there are still strong inflationary pressures but that they may be easing in some areas.
Federal Reserve policy held on an "even keel" during the week ended Wednesday, figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York indicated.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 11 American planes raked a United States Coast Guard cutter with machine-gun and rocket fire this morning, killing two coastguardsmen and wounding five other persons aboard the vessel.
Sargent Shriver, the director of the Office of Economic Opportunity, yesterday rejected a request by Representative Adam Clayton Powell that funds to the Jersey City antipoverty program be frozen.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 11 Sabah and Sarawak, the Northern Borneo states whose inclusion in the Federation of Malaysia was contested by President Sukarno of Indonesia, are to be given an opportunity to vote on their status under an agreement between Indonesia and Malaysia signed today.
A fashion item bearing a Paris dateline reports that the new generation has not only discovered Greta Garbo through film revivals but is launching, as the newest of fashions, the "Greta Garbo look."

CEASE FIRE!" Artillery training for sophomore cadets at West Point was interrupted by a range officer's bellow at 1:50 P.M. last Friday after police of the Palisades Interstate Park reported that another long round from a 105-mm. howitzer had escaped the reservation.
Local 237 of the Teamsters Union has won the right to represent cleaners in the City Department of Public Works, according to Barry Feinstein, vice president of the union.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 11 As far as Tommy Walsh is concerned, there could be more National Steeplechase Days on thoroughbred racing programs. The program at the Saratoga track today celebrated National Steeplechase Day. There were two jump races on the program, and Walsh rode the winner of each one.
The leading auto stocks rolled to the bottom of the hill yesterday. General Motors, Ford, and Chrysler all traded at their year's lows as an accumulation of minor problems took their toll.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 11 California's Democratic State Committee fired its first major salvo of the gubernatorial campaign today with a 29-page document that describes Ronald Reagan, the Republican nominee, as an "extremist collaborator and extremists' candidate."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 11 Tony Roche of Australia and Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., advanced to the semifinals of the 77th Meadow Club grass court tennis tournament today. This was a change of pace in the competition that has had at least one upset on each previous program.
STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 11 Harold Premore Moon, an oil broker, died today at his home, 3099 High Ridge Road. He was 56 years old.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 12 (UPI)--Gale Sayers, Rudy Bukich and a great defense sparked the Chicago Bears to a 13-10 victory over the Green Bay Packers tonight in the 17th annual Midwest Shrine football game.
Eleven pacifists have been subpoenaed to testify on Tuesday before the House Committee on Un-American Activities, some of them said here today.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 12 (Reuters)--The police arrested 33 men and women headed by a Spanish-born journalist here tonight and charged them with "conspiracy on a national scale."
Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. and the daughter of a woman reported to have been the "other woman" in President Roosevelt's life issued denials yesterday that their parents had been romantically linked.
The Amax Aluminum Company, a division of American Metal Climax, Inc., appointed Eric Windmiller yesterday as president of the Apex Smelting Company, an operating arm of Amax.

Prime Minister Wilson's Cabinet reshuffle, switching six top posts without dropping a man, is the administrative counterpart of his economic austerity program. Both moves redress an immediate crisis, rather than bring about fundamental change. Both leave major problems unsolved and demonstrate again the political dexterity that temporarily deserted Mr. Wilson in the July sterling crisis.
Glamour stocks pushed the American Stock Exchange to its best showing of the week yesterday in relatively active trading.

SEWICKLEY, Pa., Aug. 12-- Mrs. Don R. Carner of Seekonk, Mass., and Mrs. J. Douglas Streit of Willowdale, Ont., will meet in the 36-hole final of the 68th annual women's National Amateur golf championship tomorrow.

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 12-- Miss Susan Hardy Heath, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Darwin Whitcomb Heath, was married this afternoon to Oliver Shethar Everett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Hurd Everett of Rye, N.Y., and Londonderry, Vt.
BALBOA, C.Z., Aug. 12-- Four crewmen were taken off the Liberian tanker Charles E. Wilson by Canal Zone policemen today at the request of the ship's master.

EDISON, N.J., Aug. 12-- An 18-year-old suspect in the murder of five women at New Jersey shore resorts since last September was arrested today in New Brunswick. He later hanged himself in a jail cell in Edison.
Major religious groups in the United States have lined up in almost solid opposition to the so-called Dirksen Amendment, which would permit voluntary prayers in public schools.
The spot rate on the British pound closed down 7 points, to $2.7894 after quiet trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP)--Senator Wayne Morse said today that the Johnson Administration was trying to prepare public opinion for a massive troop expansion in Southeast Asia.
Governor Rockefeller wired President Johnson yesterday to express concern that a delay in the merger of the Pennsylvania and New York Central Railroads might end New Haven Railroad passenger service.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 12--Graham Stillwell of Britain and Alan Stone of Australia registered upsets today to reach the semi-finals of the 77th Meadow Club grass-court tennis tournament.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Aug. 12 (UPI)--Project Apollo officials today postponed an unmanned launching of a fully equipped Apollo spaceship for three days, to Aug. 25. It was the second delay announced this week.
CLIFTON, N.J., Aug, 12-- For Peter Thomson of Australia, five-time British Open champion, there has been no drought. Indeed, he found more water here than he cared to.

A hot competitive fight between four banks, all battling for the right to establish a branch office on the same street corner in a Suffolk County community, has been resolved by the Controller of the Currency James J. Saxon in favor of the Tinker National Bank of East Setauket, L.I.

Almost as many people showed up on Daffodil Hill in the Botanical Garden in the Bronx to hear the New York Philharmonic last night as there are daffodils on the hill in March, according to a police official.
Four Democratic candidates for the state gubernatorial nominations have accepted invitations from WCBS-TV and WCBS radio to participate in a one-hour live debate on Sept. 4 at 11:30 A.M.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI)--Selective Service officials warned today that United States citizens who go to Canada to evade the draft would be prosecuted, and possibly drafted, when they returned.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12-- Representative John M. Murphy accused Senator Clifford P. Case today of having used "the same kind of tactics he has so vehemently decried as McCarthyism" in criticizing his political fund-raising techniques.

Some residents of Brooklyn's Flatbush section said yesterday they approved calling in Albert Gallo, a racketeer, as a peacemaker in the racially troubled area, but others said the move could be dangerous.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12--Federal officials have told Congress that New York State's program of medical aid for the indigent will cost $1.4-billion a year by the time it is in fullscale operation in 1970.

ATLANTA, Aug. 12--The Episcopal Cathedral of St. Philip was the setting here this evening for the marriage of Miss Josephine Page Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Berrien Moore, to Charles Nathaniel Griffin 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Amos H. Griffin of Upper Montclair, N.J.

LIVERMORE, Calif., Aug. 12 (AP)--Dr. Theodore C. Merkle, an authority on nuclear reactor physics technology and an associate director of the Lawrence Radiation Laboratory here, died of cancer today. He was 47 years old.
LIMA, Peru, Aug. 13--President Fernando Belaunde Terry paced the marble floor of the Pizarro Palace and paused beside a papier-mache model of the huge Olmos irrigation project.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12--A line of more than 700 civil rights marchers paraded almost unscathed through thousands of jeering whites today in a demonstration contesting alleged housing discrimination.
Two Jersey City officials resigned yesterday from the board of Can Do, the local antipoverty program, stating they could no longer give the many hours their board duties required.
MOSCOW, Aug. 12 (UPI)-- The Soviet Union reported today its first casualty of the war in Vietnam. It said a civilian miner was wounded in a United States bombing raid eight months ago.

OXFORD, Miss., Aug. 12 (AP)--The head of the Mississippi Highway Patrol and officials of Grenada, Miss., were ordered today to appear in Federal Court Aug. 24 to show cause why they should not be held in contempt for allegedly failing to provide proper protection for civil rights marchers.

New-car sales by the Chrysler Corporation in the first third of August surged ahead of last year's pace, while those of the Ford Motor Company showed a moderate gain above the 1965 level, according to reports received yesterday from Detroit.
BANCHVILLE, N.J., Aug. 12--Toy Soldier, back from a European trip less than three weeks, today clinched the green jumper championship at the Sussex County horse show.
The three owners of the strike-bound World Journal Tribune, Inc., have decided not to resume publication of The New York Herald Tribune, it was learned authoritatively yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12-- The United States today pressed the search for international supervision that would bar the demilitarized zone in Vietnam to Communist troops and supplics.
A petition by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association for a referendum seeking to abolish the civilian-dominated police review board was upheld yesterday in State Supreme Court.
A Bronx parent's complaint demanding dissolution of the Board of Education because it is appointed, not elected, has been dismissed by State Supreme Court Justice Irving R. Levey.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 12 (AP)--Charles W. Engelhard bid $177,000 for a chestnut filly at the thoroughbred yearling sales last night, a record sale price in the 46-year history of the annual event.

NEWTON CENTRE, Mass., Aug. 12--Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Odell have announced the engagement of their daughter. Miss Patricia Anne Odell, to John H. Hess, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Hess of Brooklyn, New York.

YONKERS, Aug. 12--Bret Hanover, in hand through most of the one-mile distance, surprised none of the 32,053 harness racing fans on hand for the Mayor's Cup pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight by capturing the $35,000 event just about as his driver, Frank Ervin ...
GENEVA, Aug. 12--A special United Nations committee expressed "deep concern" today over the increasing abuse of the drug LSD that gives its takers what they call a "ride."
BIDDING judgment is a difficult art and the most delicate problems arise when all four players are actively bidding. In such circumstances some bids may be open to criticism.

A demanding banner, "Yank 'Em," apparently the Bronx equivalent of "Let's Go Mets," hung limply from the rightfield upper deck at Yankee Stadium last night. But the home team couldn't push, let alone pull.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 12 (AP)--Kipchoge Keino of Kenya, the fourth fastest miler in history, was timed in 3 minutes 57.4 seconds in a qualifying heat today in the British Commonwealth and Empire Games.
MANILA, Aug. 12--Premier Nugyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam today called upon the free Asian countries for a unity of approach as a first step in bringing peace to Asia.
CHINESE gooseberries, also known as kiwi fruit, are in metropolitan markets for the third season in increased quantities.
MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 12-- The State Supreme Court overturned today a decision by Nassau County not to honor the bid of a nonunion company to service traffic lights.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12--Controller of the Currency James J. Saxon announced new procedures today for the examination of banks whose internal and external audit pro cedures are found to be inadequate. In doing so, Mr. Saxon took a passing swipe at his fellow regulators of banks.

ROME, Aug. 12--Pope Paul VI issued today interpretations of Ecumenical Council decrees on bishops, priests, religious orders and missions that were described in progressive circles of the Roman Catholic Church as "positive but not daring."

CLIFTON, N.J., Aug. 12-- Long after the big names of the Thunderbird had holed out and gone home, a locally popular pro caught the affection of the gallery today. He was Milton (Babe) Lichardus of Deal, who scored a 68 for a 36-hole total of 139, good for a second-place tie with Mason Rudolph.

In the case of another air raid on a village--this one well inside South Vietnam--Vietcong broadcasts heard here yesterday insisted that no Vietcong were in the area where American jets killed or wounded more than 100 civilians last week.

Increases in the prices of bread and milk affect everyone, but their pinch is cruelest on the poor. This week a Department of Markets survey confirmed what civil rights and antipoverty agencies have been saying: The poor pay more.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP)--"I am proud to be serving my country by being in Vietnam," a United States serviceman wrote to President Johnson recently.

A patrolman who had been assigned to the motorcycle division less than three months died yesterday afternoon when his motorcycle skidded and crashed into an abutment at the Brooklyn approach to the Verrazano Bridge.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP)--Frank Robinson's tworun homer gave Baltimore a 2-1 victory over Washington in the first game tonight, but the Senators came back to win the second game, 4-1, on homers by Ken Harrelson, Fred Valentine and Jim King.
MONTREAL, Aug. 12 (AP)-- The Canadian National Railways said today that day and night train service between Montreal and New York would be discontinued Sept. 2.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 12 --Voters here rejected plans today for a small municipal airport in this semirural township in Eastern Long Island.

WHEN interest in Americana was at a peak in the nineteen-twenties, there was a tendency to attribute simple blown glass to the ear liest producers. Documents showed that glass was blown at Jamestown, Va., in 1608, and by 1650 there were two factories on Glass Makers Street in New Amsterdam.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 12 (AP) --Manny, Mota's two-run single sparked a three-run rally in the l3th inning tonight that gave the National League-leading Pittsburgh Pirates a 14-11 victory over Cincinnati in a contest highlighted by 11 homers.
KRYSTYNA BUCZKOWSKA, a Pole who moved to Paris six years ago to work as a designer for Such fashion publications as Elle and Jardin des Modes, has...

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 12--A discharged sweeper at a rifle factory here walked into the company's cafeteria at lunchtime today and shot three women in a screaming crowd before he was killed in a gun battle with the police.

PEKING, Aug. 12--A struggle over policy appears to have followed the effort by the Chinese Communist party's Central Committee to moderate China's "cultural revolution" and purge of "antiparty" leaders.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 12 (AP)--President Johnson arrived here today on the way from Washington to his Johnson City ranch for the weekend. He was accompanied by Mrs. Johnson.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 12--The police department here is setting up a secret civilian auxiliary, to the dismay of some residents, who call the move "a Gestapo tactic."

BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 12--Louisiana voters go to the polls tomorrow to nominate party candidates for the United States Senate, eight seats in the House of Representatives, plus numerous candidates for posts as judges, district attorney and school board members.

BERLIN, Aug. 12--The rulers of East Germany today began celebrating the anniversary of the Berlin wall, built five years ago to cut the city in two, by dedicating a memorial to border guards killed trying to prevent escapes to the West.
MOSCOW, Aug. 12 (Reuters)--The works of Rudyard Kipling, the poet and novelist who was the voice of British imperialism at the turn of the century, are growing in popularity in the Soviet Union.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 12 (AP)--Thomas R. Kaiser, 32 years old, was sentenced today to one and a half to seven years in prison for conspiracy and attempted extortion from Irving Holzman, Long Island juke box czar.

Miss Sarah Anne Donovan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Ernest Donovan of 2 Beekman Place, was married yesterday afternoon to Donald Paul Madden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis P. Madden of Winthrop, Mass.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12 (AP)--Dr. Howard E. Wilson, dean of the School of Education at the University of California at Los Angeles, died today after a long illness. He was 64 years old.
An odor that hung low over Brooklyn and Staten Island last night was described by a long time resident of the former as "rancid, rotten, oillike, pungent, gas-like, acidlike, foul and offensive."

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 12--The marriage of Miss Mary Catherine Corwin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald von Glahn Corwin of Interlaken, to Robert Ellerslie Davis Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Davis of Neptune, took place this evening in Trinity Episcopal Church.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12--A trial examiner recommended today that the National Labor Relations Board dismiss a 10year-old charge of anti-unionism against Darlington Manufacturing Company.

Dr. Bruno Z. Kisch, a leading cardiologist and from 1938 to 1962 medical director of Yeshiva University, died Thursday in Bad Nauheim, Germany. He was 76 years old and had lived at 71 Maple Street in Brooklyn.

The Erie-Lackawanna Railroad has filed another petition with the Interstate Commerce Commission asking it again to postpone the effective date of the merger of the New York Central and Pennsylvania Railroads.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 12--Mrs. Sidney Lawrence Markham has announced the engagement of her daughter, Dr. Emily Delphine Markham, to John Joseph Adelmann of Bayside, Queens, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Stephen J. Adelmann of Woodhaven, Queens.

TOKYO, Aug. 12--The North Korean statement endorsed the Soviet position that national Communist parties should evolve their individual policies in accordance with domestic conditions. However, in an apparent criticism of Soviet policy on Vietnam, the editorial added...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12--The North Korean Communist party today proclaimed its independence of both Chinese and Soviet leadership in the Communist world. "Revo lution," the party declared, "can neither be exported nor imported" and outside influence "plays only a secondary role."
Wall Street is no picnic these summer days, what with falling prices, low volume, lack of confidence and staffs sharply reduced by vacations. But the area is a picnic ground, unlikely as it seems.
Unemployment in New York City dipped in the first six months of this year to its lowest level since the comparable period in 1957, Labor Commissioner Henry Shemin reported yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 12--Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge has told the State Department of his "continuing concern and worry" about the conduct of American soldiers in their contacts with the people of Saigon.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12-- The Southern bloc in the Senate decided today not to put up a fight at this time for referral of the civil rights bill to the Judiciary Committee.

HONG KONG; Aug. 12-- Mao Tse-tung, Chairman of China's Communist party, once said that. "political power grows out of the barrel of a gun." Developments in Communist China suggest power may have been gravitating to Lin Piao, the brilliant, enigmatic Defense Minister, who...
Aaron E. Koota, the Brooklyn District Attorney, charged yesterday that "confusion and uncertainty" spread by recent court rulings had "effectively shackled" law enforcement.

FALLS VILLAGE, Conn., Aug. 12--Dr. J. De Lancey Ferguson, professor emeritus of English at Brooklyn and former chairman of its English department, died today of Parkinson's disease at his home on Sugar Hill Road here. His age was 77.
Francis Grover Cleveland, youngest of the four children of Grover Cleveland, who was the 22d and 24th President of the United States, is retiring from the theater at the age of 63.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 12--The Guild Hall's fund for art acquisitions will benefit from a tour of six homes on Wednesday. Mrs. M. Anderson Kennard is chairman for the event.
The Suffolk County delegation to the Democratic state convention endorsed City Council President Frank D. O'Connor last night for the nomination for Governor.

The first tangible measure of how much traffic nonstruck airlines have gained at the expense of their struck competitors was shown yesterday when Pan American World Airways issued its July traffic results.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12-- Barry Goldwater has brought together four conservative political groups into a loose confederation with an eye to the 1968 Presidential election.
The stock market staged a modest rally yesterday after four consecutive days of decline. Volume expanded as prices rose and then slackened in afternoon profit taking.
A small group of mothers, children and college students picketed yesterday in front of St. Patrick's Cathedral to protest the Roman Catholic Church's ban on artificial methods of birth control.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12-- A House committee approved today a bill that would end the airline strike. The vote came as fresh efforts were made to negotiate a settlement.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 12-- Clark Graebner was named today with Dennis Ralston to play the singles for the heavily favored United States Davis Cup team against Mexico. Graebner will face Joaquin Loyo-Mayo tomorrow in the opening match of the series in the final round of the American Zone.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell was held in criminal contempt of court yesterday for his refusal to pay a $162,000 judgment to a Harlem widow he defamed or to submit to a financial examination.
Loans equivalent to nearly $30-million were approved yesterday by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) to push development projects in Singapore, Peru and Honduras.

PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 12 --As the camera-bearing Lunar Orbiter spacecraft streaked tonight toward its rendezvous with the moon, a fresh breeze of confidence swept through the ground control room here.
The Franklin National Bank, the largest on Long Island, announced yesterday a consolidation of its operations in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, and the promotion of three senior executives.

The Rexall Drug and Chemical Company, based in Los Angeles, is planning to diversify further its activities through the proposed acquisition of L.E. Carpenter Co., Wharton, N.J., manufacturer of vinyl wall coverings. The transaction involves an exchange of stock valued at about $6.5-million.
The First National Bank of Boston, by far the largest bank in New England with $2.8-billion in assets, has paved the way for a changing of the guard in its top executive ranks.
ONEIDA, N.Y., Aug. 12-- Frank D. O'Connor said today he would have the votes to win the Democratic nomination for Governor within 24 hours if Senator Robert F. Kennedy declared himself neutral.

Mrs. Hazel Cox Weith is the only woman among about 70 men whose ship models, marine paintings and other nautical handmade objects are being exhibited at the Seamen's Bank for Savings, Fifth Avenue and 45th Street.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12--Richard F. Speck, accused slayer of eight student nurses, today was moved from the County Jail hospital ward to a cell in the jail's security area.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 12--Official Dutch sources reported today "slight indications" that the Netherlands' dispute with Communist China over eight Chinese technicians might be slowly moving towaid a solution.
Four major lumber associations reported a decline of 9 per cent in production for the week ended Aug. 6, compared with the level in the corresponding 1965 week.
When senseless violence is averted or abated, it may seem gratuitous to quibble about the nature of the preventive methods employed.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12-- Eight Atlanta hospitals have been informed that they must eliminate remaining racial discrimination by Sept. 15 to continue receiving Federal funds.

SHAWNEE-ON-DELAWARE, Pa., Aug. 12--Fred Waring, the musical magician who turned a maestro's wand into solid gold, has been doing the same trick for 50 years, and neither he nor his public show any signs of tiring.

The Sun Chemical Corporation has abandoned its efforts to gain control of the Harshaw Chemical Company, by disposing yesterday of some 88,000 shares of Harshaw acquired through a tender offer at $40 a share.

When young Edward Kennedy Ellington was a boy in Washington, where his father worked as a waiter at the White House, he had to go to church twice every Sunday. His mother, a judicious lady, insisted that, since one parent was a Methodist and the other a Baptist, he slight neither church.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 12--There was a historical--although not an ancient--note to the baseball proceedings in new Busch Memorial Stadium tonight.

CLIFTON, N.J., Aug. 12-- Billy Casper arrived at the Upper Montclair Country Club today without breakfast. When he left he led by one stroke in the $100,000 Thunderbird golf tournament after carding a fourunder-par 68 for a 36-hole aggregate of 138.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Aug. 12--Mrs. Billie Jean Moffitt King, the Wimbledon champion from Long Beach, Calif., and Karen Krantzcke, the Australian junior girls champion, advanced to the final of the Piping Rock Club invitation women's grass-court tennis tournament today.

The United States has signed a contract with the West German Government for the procurement of a 20-mm. gun that has been described as substandard by some United States Army officers. Additional orders are expected.

LONDON, Aug. 12 (AP)-- A 23-year-old stenographer with a Communist boy friend worked for 10 days in Prime Minister Wilson's office last November. She was removed when she questioned the text of a letter about Vietnam.

THE New York Giants and Jets, who someday will meet on the playing field, have a confrontation of sorts on television tonight. Both are playing exhibition games in the South and both contests will be shown live by local TV stations during the same time period.
The commander of detectives in the Times Square area said this week that the recent United States Supreme Court ruling on confessions has not weakened law enforcement.
The Port of New York Authority brought suit against American Airlines yesterday to enjoin the airline from taking off or landing with its jets over Jackson Heights, Queens.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP)--Counsel for Jack L. Ruby appealed to the Supreme Court today to overturn his conviction as the slayer of Lee Harvey Oswald, the assassin of President Kennedy.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 12-- The recent mutterings of labor leaders against the military regime of Lieut. Gen. Juan Carlos Ogania have become virtually a roar as the quickening tempo of inflation has slashed consumers' buying power.
For the experts in the State Department and observers at widespread listening posts, the purge-ridden "proletarian cultural revolution" sweeping Communist China presents a dizzying puzzlement.
TOKYO, Aug. 12 (AP)-- North Vietnam announced today that it had captured two United States Air Force pilots who took part in the raid on the Hanoi fuel dump June 29.
PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 12-- Ramon Carrion, editor and publisher of the Spanish-language weekly newspaper El Observador here, died today in Paterson General Hospital. He was 54 years old.
The Boeing Company announced yesterday that six aerospace companies had joined its supersonic transport manufacturing team as major subcontractors.
LONDON, Aug. 12--Comdr. Charles Ralfe Thompson, personal assistant to Winston Churchill during World War II, died at his home here yesterday. He was 71 years old.
That much-vaunted technological revolution in education seems to be running into trouble.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug., 12 --Hilary Smart, the 1948 Star Class Olympic champion who sails out of the Sandy Bay (Mass.) Yacht Club, and Richard Gordon of the Milford (Conn.) Y.C., are tied for first place after the first two races of the Atlantic Coast Star Class championship.

The Lindsay administration has reversed its position and agreed to submit to arbitration the question of whether the duties of policemen and firemen and where they will work are proper subjects of bargaining.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP)-- More than 13,000 fans greeted the Beatles today when the British rock 'n' roll quartet gave the first performance of their American tour. Teen-age girls danced in the balcony of the International Amphitheater while the Beatles played and sang.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass.--Last summer, train passengers disembarking here on Friday nights could enter the 76-year-old granite depot and join the younger set doing the frug or watusi. This summer, they can stop in and browse among gifts imported from Finland, Ireland, Poland, England, Kenya, West Germany, Bolivia, or Mexico, among other places.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 12 --The third annual Corinthians cruise began on Long Island Sound tonight with a 95-nautical-mile overnight race to Block Island. A fleet of 15 started the race. The rest of the 32 entries will join the cruise for the daily squadron runs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12--The Senate Appropriations Committee urged the Administration today to call up a portion of the nation's trained reservists to help meet steadily rising manpower demands sparked by the Vietnam war.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Aug. 13 (UPI)--United States Air Force F-105 Thunderchief jets battled two Communist MIG-17's over North Vietnam near Hanoi yesterday, American military spokesmen reported today. Both of the Soviet-designed planes and one of the United States jets were damaged.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 12 (AP)-- President Joaquin Balaguer said last night he would ask Congress to "procure a real political truce" by restricting. political activity until 1968.

KANE, Pa., Aug. 12 (AP)-- A bank official in this Western Pennsylvania community was arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation today on a charge of falsifying bank records the day before he retired so as to conceal a $239,084 shortage.

ON the morning of March 20, 1911, the corpse of 11-year-old Andrei Yushchin sky was discovered in a cave on the outskirts or Kiev, Russia. He had been stabbed 47 times; most of the blood had drained from his body.
A slight rally by industrial issues failed to win support on the London Stock Exchange yesterday and the market closed the week on a dull note with only scattered gains.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 12--Doctors in an Israeli hospital have found that a transplanted kidney, apparently rejected by the host body, revived with the transplanting of a second kidney.
ANKHE, South Vietnam, Aug. 12--An American soldier who spent nearly five months in Saigon working as a singer and bartender while absent without leave from his unit was convicted today of desertion.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 12-- Twenty-four hours after signing a peace accord with Indonesia, Malaysia today appointed Maj. Gen. Dato Ibrahim Bin Ismail commander in East Malaysia. He replaced Maj. Gen. G.H. Lea of Britain immediately.
LA MESA, Calif., Aug. 12-- Lieut. (jg.) Evva G. Meyer, U.S.N., and Lieut. Alan Henry Donn, U.S.N., will be married next month in London.
VIENNA, Aug. 12--Embarrassed Austrian officials acknowledged today that they had erred in saying that Dr. Otto Habsburg, the former Archduke and claimant to the throne had entered the country.

Once again Congress has stood pat on its right to make an architectural mess of the Capitol if it wants to--as it did a few years ago in defacing the East Front with a $24-million extension and now proposes to do to the West Front at a cost of $34 million.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 12-- Officials of Lake Central Airlines, the Civil Aeronautics Board and the Federal Aviation Agency met here today with five French aviation officals to try to determine what caused engines on three of the airline's French-built Nord turboprop aircraft to fly apart within the last five weeks.

FORT LEE, N.J., Aug. 12-- Mr. and Mrs. Louis M. Tamarin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lois Maxine Tamarin, to Mitchell Steven Camp, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Camp of Englewood Cliffs.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 12 (Reuters)--The regime of President Ongania, today appointed former Judge Luis Botet to head the Administration of the strife-torn University of Buenos Aires as the latest move in a Government crackdown against self-rule by universities.

SAN MARINO, Aug. 6-- From the top of their steep-sloped, craggy Mount Titano, the 17,000 citizens of San Marino, the world's oldest and smallest republic, have the impression of living on an island-- physically and psychologically.
BOSTON, Aug. 12--A minor furor has arisen over an abstract mural by Robert Motherwell in the John F. Kennedy Memorial Federal Building here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12-- The index of primary market prices increased one-tenth of 1 per cent to 106.4 during the week ended Aug. 9, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products and processed foods prices advanced while industrial commodities averaged unchanged.

A Federal prosecutor yesterday urged an early trial for an official of the bricklayer's union and his wife, who are charged with income tax evasion, on the ground that the lives of potential Government witnesses were in danger.
Charges against three men involved in a publicity stunt during which a lion clawed a model's leg at the Automobile Show in April were dismissed yesterday by Criminal Court Judge Thomas G. Weaver.
MONTREAL, Aug. 12 (Canadian Press)--Bill Brew of Hartford, Conn., and Nick Weslock of Burlington, Ont., moved into the final of the Canadian Amateur golf championship today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Aug. 13--A United States spokesman asserted yesterday that hamlets attacked by American aircraft Aug. 2 were in South Vietnam, not in Cambodia, as the Cambodians say.
LONDON, Aug. 12 (UPI)-- The combined tennis teams of Oxford and Cambridge took an 8-4 lead over Harvard and Yale today in the opening matches of their ...

"It was a wild opening," one potato trader commented yesterday. He was talking about the busiest day in the 25-yearold history of potato-futures trading. In the first hour 3,237 contracts changed hands on sharply rising prices. For the full day the total reached a record of 6,514.
SUNDAY brunch is becoming all meals to all people. In Chinatown, in Central Park, in elegant eateries high in the sky and in Lower East Side dairy restaurants, the brunch business is booming.

CLIFTON, N.J., Aug. 12-- A score of 108 was credited to Dave Hill as his tally for the 18th hole in the Thunderbird tourney today. It was a mistake, but the officials maintained the score had to stand as recorded.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 12 (Reuters)--Commonwealth Games swimming events ended tonight with a total of 13 world records established during regular competition and a 14th thrown in for good measure.

Mike McTigue, a smiling, pugnosed fighter who came out of County Clare, Ireland, to win the light-heavyweight championship in the nineteen-twenties, died yesterday in Queens General Hospital after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

WALPOLE, Mass., Aug. 12 (UPI)--Fifteen convicts armed with screwdrivers and homemade knives rioted at Walpole State Prison tonight in an apparent attempt to seize drugs in the prison hospital. Nine were stabled or beaten, two of them seriously.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12 (UPI)--Dancing, music and gaiety filled the streets of Watts today in marked contrast to the rioters, looters and arsonists who roamed its corridors a year ago.

PORTILLO, Chile, Aug. 12 (AP)--Fog and light snow moved in on Portillo this morning leading the officials of the Federation Internationale de Ski to order a day-long break in the world Alpine championships.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 12 (UPI) --State Representative Carl Stokes asked today a Federal grand jury investigation of the city's race riots last month, while the head of a civil rights group labeled an earlier study a "complete whitewash."

Increases in wholesale fresh butter prices ranging from three-quarters of a cent to 1 cent a pound were instituted by the industry yesterday. With top grades of butter quoted at 73 to 73 cents a pound, the commodity reached its highest price level since September, 1952, industry spokesmen said.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12-- Miss Jane Annesley Kean, daughter of Mrs. Charles Duell Kean, was married here this evening to Anthony John DiSalvo-Schmidt, son of Mrs. Maria DiSalvo-Schmidt of Philadelphia and Istanbul, Turkey.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP)--An omnibus housing bill setting up a special Government mortgage insurance program for riot-torn areas was passed by the Senate today and sent to the House.

FAIR HAVEN, N.J., Aug. l2 --Miss Isolde Luise Priebe and Lloyd Feld plan to be married here on Sept. 2. Mr. and Mrs. Frank K. Priebe have announced the engagement of their daughter to the son of Abraham Feld of Highland Park, N.J., and the late Mrs. Feld.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12-- The subcommittee on executive and legislative reorganization of the House Govermnent Operations Committee has summoned Federal agency representatives to testify next week on whether the consumer protection functions of the Government could be strengthened by a Department of Consumers. The hearings will be held Monday and Tuesday.
The bond market ended a dramatic week in undramatic fashion yesterday. Prices were little changed and dealers, blaming mid-August apathy, reported quiet trading.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Aug. 12--Harry E. Rothlisberger of 196 South Springfield Avenue, head of the sales and production department of the Ward Baking Company of Newark, died yesterday at his home. His age was 62.
For the first time, a major segment of the 35-year-old West Side Highway was closed to traffic yesterday for emergency repairs.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12 (AP)--Willie Mays's 27th homer of the season and 532d of his career gave the San Francisco Giants and Gaylord Perry a 1-0 victory tonight over the Houston Astros.

LIMA, Peru, Aug. 12--President Fernando Belaunde Terry will be represented Sunday at a meeting of five South American Presidents in Bogota by Fernando Schwalb Aldana, former Peruvian Premier and now head of the Central Bank.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP)-- Harry Melges of Zenda, Wis., former United States champion and a bronze medal winner in the Olympics, turned back the threat of Dick Pitcher of England today to win the Flying Dutchman national sailing championship.
Traffic on upper Sixth Avenue is still often slowed to a snail's pace. When the cars do move, they bump and bounce over a temporary wooden surface and the noise is still bothersome.
CLIFTON, N.J., Aug. 12-- In some ways it's good to trail Arnold Palmer. And then there are times when it doesn't pay to lead Bill Casper.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12-- A patent granted this week disclosed the rivalry of two electronic giants for the honor of having originated a special kind of laser.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 12-- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has written to President Johnson voicing new concern about intensification of the war in Vietnam.

Senator Mike Mansfield, the Democratic floor leader, has now stated publicly what has long been recognized as a political truism about the civil rights bill: Since the Democrats lose approximately twenty Southerners on a closure vote, they cannot shut off debate on the bill unless they have the cooperation of Senator Everett Dirksen and the Republican minority.

SUTTONS BAY, Mich., Aug. 12 (AP)--A Navy pilot who recently returned from Vietnam where he flew more than 100 missions was killed today when his single-seat plane crashed and burned near his parents' summer home here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12-- Wage settlements negotiated in the first half of this year provided average increases of 3.8 per cent, well above the Government's guidepost figure of 3.2 per cent, the Labor Department reported today.
The nation's money managers breathed a sign of relief in March of 1965 after the United States modified its gold-reserve policy and freed $5-billion of previously committed gold.
PERTH, Australia, Aug. 12 (AP)--The 17-year-old son of an American investment house executive was killed today in a motorcycle accident at Esperance, on the south coast of West Australia.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (UPI) --Racial riot duty and the new "kid glove" technique of handling criminal suspects has been blamed for a growing number of resignations from the Chicago Police Department.

The Publishers Association of New York City, acting on behalf of The New York Times, filed suit in Federal Court here yesterday to collect $25,000 from Printing Pressman's Union No. 2 that had been awarded the newspaper by an arbitrator.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI)--Vice President Humphrey said today that racial demonstrations "have gotten out of hand.' He said a cooling-off period was needed in big-city demonstrations.

Maritime union leaders are urging the Federal authorities to do something about the continuing shortage of trained merchant marine officers that is plaguing the industry and slowing the emergency military sealift in the Pacific.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 12--Max Hirsch, who has been receiving awards at Saratoga race track since the early days of the century, added another stakes victory to his collection today. The 86-year-old trainer sent Mrs. Edward Lasker's Indulto into the $28,350 Jim Dandy and the colt scored a 2 -length triumph in the one mile test.
The birth rate returned to normal in several major hospitals here yesterday, after a sharp rise just nine months after the 1965 blackout.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 12--John Haydock, who retired last year as an editor with Cleworth Publications of Greenwich, died today at the Greenwich Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 22 Plow Lane.
LONDON, Aug. 12--Three plainclothes policemen were shot dead today on a quiet street of a West London working-class neighborhood.

City Hall sources said yesterday that a State Supreme Court decision could be used to question the validity of as many as 5,000 items disposed of by the Board of Estimate since the new Charter took effect Jan. 1, 1963.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Aug. 12--Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, the United States chess champion, moved into a first place tie with Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union last night in the Piatigorsky Cup Tournament at the Miramar Hotel.

ORIENT, L.I., Aug. 2--Harry Shaw Newman, a New York art dealer specializing in American prints and paintings of the 18th and 19th centuries, died today at his summer home on Oyster Lane.

SANTIAGO, Cuba, Aug. 12 (Reuters)--Cuban engineers have produced a hybrid passenger airliner by rebuilding a Russian LI-2 freight plane with an American DC-3's characteristics and naming it the LI-3.
BRUSSELS, Aug. 12 (Reuters)--Union Miniere du Haut Katanga, one of the world's largest copper producers, announced today its second price cut this week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP)--The Federal Trade Commission announced tonight it had ordered the National Dairy Products Corporation to stop what it charged was discrimination in prices and promotional allowances it grants to competing distributors of its Sealtest food products.
The significance of the Metropolitan Opera Auditions was demonstrated anew last night at Lewisohn Stadium, as three past winners headed the cast in a lustrous concert version of 'Madama Butterfly."
FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 12 (AP)--The Army announced today that three soldiers who said they would not fight in Vietnam would be tried by general courtsmartial here.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI)--The Defense Department today identified 10 servicemen who have been killed in action in Vietnam.

COLLECTORS are wonderful people: collectors of anything. It might be matchbox covers that they collect, or first editions, or tarot cards, or paintings, or sheet music, or old automobiles. Whatever it is, their hobby--but one should not call it a hobby; it is a way of life--keeps them ever on the alert and also makes them authorities on a given subject.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 13--Jack Brown's Callooh from the New York Athletic Club was the first day's leader in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's weekend Day Race today on Long Island Sound.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13--The nation's Young Republican organization, under heavy pressure from the party's national leadership, voted reluctantly tonight to purge itself of the Rat Finks, a reputedly anti-Negro, anti-Semitic faction of the New Jersey Young Republican unit.

How to provide a terrace for every one of 104 apartments and still avoid a cluttered-looking facade was one of the tasks facing the architects of Cameo House, a ninestory building now rising in the heart of White Plains.

IN John Knowles's remarkable first novel, "A Separate Peace," the narrator makes a revealing statement about World War II: "Everyone has a moment in history which belongs particularly to him. WEST BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 13--More than 200 craft sailed on Great South Bay today as the Long Island Yacht Club's weekend invitation regatta began, Moderate southerly winds prevailed.

Passengers in the elevators of Sutton East, an apartment house nearing completion at 433 East 56th Street, just off Sutton Place, will be heard as well as seen. The building's security system will include a closed television system, with sound.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13-- Eighty policemen raided four meeting places of civil rights organizations here early today, seized two and half sticks of dynamite and arrested four persons.
COLUMBUS, Aug. 13 (UPI) --The State of Ohio has ordered 1,222 school buses, said to be the largest order ever placed for such buses in the United States.
Lewis S. Rosenstiel, the 73year-old chairman, president and chief executive officer of Schenley Industries, Inc., has relinquished the presidency to John Mackie.

TOKYO, Aug 13 (AP)-- Hsinhua, the official Chinese Communist press agency, said today that an American who attended a rally in Peking Friday had declared that "imperialism was doomed and neither material wealth nor nuclear weapons coulds save it."

CLIFTON, N.J., Aug. 13-- Player members of the Professional Golfers' Association have drawn a petition requesting a separate section in the P.G.A. for the touring pros, Tommy Jacobs, the chairman of the players' committee, said today. Jacobs also said, however, the players were not seeking to "breakaway" from the P.G.A.

THE educational program of the great new Cape Cod National Seashore is now in its first summer of full operation. This Government-protected conservation area confronts the Atlantic Ocean for much of the 25-mile stretch of shore from the Cape's elbow at Nauset to the hook at Provincetown.
Rod Gilbert became the first member of the New York Rangers to agree to terms for the 1966-67 season when he returned his signed contract to Emile Francis, the general manager and coach, yesterday.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., Aug. 13--In the South Presbyterian Church this afternoon, Miss Ruth Bushnell Grell became the bride of Charles Edwin Hamilton 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Jr. of Charleston, W. Va. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. J. Ellis Thomsett Grell.
Homeowners who wish to obtain maximum comfort, efficiency and economy from a central air-conditioning system were advised last week to follow a six-point checklist.

The sumac is unpredictable. You go down a country road, still green and peacefully occupied with late summer, and see a flash of crimson bright as a maple in October. It is startling, that flash of flame that shouldn't be there now. Then you see that it is a lone sumac, often one of an otherwise green clump, already standing like a huge, Sioux warbonnet, every leaf in full color, red as a stormy sunset.
OLYMPIA, Wash.--What may be the last of the Indian wars is being waged with minimal bloodshed along the banks of salmon streams in the Pacific Northwest.

Wilt Chamberlain of the Philadelphia 76ers will play in the eighth annual Maurice Stokes benefit basketball game at Kutsher's Country Club, Monticello, N.Y. on Tuesday night. He will be in the starting line-up for the Western team.

PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 13 --Closing in on its target with almost perfect aim tonight, the unmanned Lunar Orbiter spacecraft appeared ready for its critical maneuver tomorrow morning to become the nation's first vehicle to circle the moon.
MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 13 (AP)--Shooter and Danny Row Gil captured the New York Sire Stakes for 4-year-olds at Monticello Raceway today.

HANOVER, N.H.-- Back in 1782, Capt. Ebenezer Brewster, the first steward of Dartmouth College, decided he was missing a bet in not catering to an increasing family of returning alumni. As a result, he converted his home at the southwest corner of the campus into a tavern.

NEW DELHI. THROUGH the winding alleys of Jullundur poured a bubbling saffron stream. Thousands of marching men wearing saffron caps, youths strutting under saffron banners, scooters and motorcycles decked with-saffron bunting, saffron-clad boys whirling in the traditional Indian stick dance, saffron-draped horses bearing riders in the battle dress of Sivaji, Rani Pratap, the Queen of Jhansi, and other Hindu heroes of glorious yesteryears.

ROSELLE, N.J., Aug. 13-- Catherine E. Nolan of 113 Lo cust Street, a supervisor and director for the New York Telephone Company for more than 40 years, died yesterday at her home. She was 64 years old.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13-- The science of making sea water drinkable made a historic surge forward in California this week.

CAIRO, Aug. 13--The sudden and unexpected return of President Abdullah al-Salal to Yemen after nine months in Egypt is interpreted in diplomatic circles here as an attempt by the United Arab Republic to curb renewed anti-Egyptian sentiment among Yemeni republicans.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 13--Miss Margaret Jane Forelli and J. Arthur Urciuoli were married this evening in the First Congregational Church by the Rev. Morton Libby. A reception was given at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew A. Forelli of Old Greenwich, parents of the bride. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Urciuoli of Syracuse.
Balconies faced with brick for privacy of the tenants using them accent the facade of the first new apartment building to be completed on Second Avenue north of 86th Street in the last 40 years.

PARIS, Aug 13--French authorities are taking dramatic measures to impose discipline on the highways. French motorists, who are among the least disciplined in the world, are reacting with surprising meekness.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 12 --Beekeepers and fish pond owners have joined forces here to prevent the state Board of Health from widespread spraying with a mosquito-killing insecticide.

NEWSPAPER reporters are chronic complainers. They curse their assignments, gripe about their editors, bewail the lack of space allotted their efforts. WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP)-- Because President de Gaulle has ordered United States armed forces out of France, 10,500 Frenchmen stand to collect $2.7-million in severence pay.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 13 --The engagement of Miss Nancy Levitt to Stephen J. Hoffman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold E. Hoffman of Stamford, Conn., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. David M. Levitt, the parents of the prospective bride.

WYNNEWOOD, Pa. Aug. ,13 --Mr. and Mrs. William Carlisle Ferguson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Carlisle Ferguson, to David Terrence Sykes. Mr. Sykes is the son of Mrs. David M. Sykes of Wyncote and the late Mr. Sykes.

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug, 13 --Mrs. Laura Gardin Fraser, a sculptress who was widely known as a designer of historic medals, died of a stroke today at Norwalk Hospital. She was 77 years old and lived at 290 North Avenue, where she maintained a studio.
JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 12-- George Sturm stepped up to the bar in the Hotel Heidelberg at 3:44 P.M. Wednesday and lifted a glass of champagne.

Apathetic activity in the stock market last week was overshadowed by two other facets of business and finance --the exuberant state of the economy and the volatile character of the interest-rate structure.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 13--Win a ball game one day, lose one the next day, that's how it is with the New York Mets.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 13 (UPI) --Vernon Stouffer, a national restaurateur, will purchase the controlling interest in the Cleveland Indians in an apparent effort to keep the ball club here, club officials announced today.

With United States policy in Vietnam high on the unpopularity index of the intellectual community, there was little question about the motivation behind last week's attack by a group of faculty members on the University of Pennsylvania's involvement in classified research for the Defense Department. The protest was directed against $845,000 worth of research on chemical and biological weapons, conducted by the university's Institute for Cooperative Research.
Harness racing's center stage will belong to the distaff side of the juvenile divisions this week at Yonkers Raceway where the 2-year-old fillies take part in two $25,000 features.

SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 13--South Korean experts on North Korean affairs believe that yesterday's declaration by Pyongyang of ideological independence from both Peking and Moscow heralds a new purge in the North Korean Communist party.
Narrow-shaped grooves cut in airplane runways by means of high-speed diamond, cutting wheels are to be tested by the airlines of this country in order to reduce skidding on wet runways.
A tight supply situation may develop in the nation's major farm products with the possible exception of cotton before the 1967 harvest gets under way.

Milton Yale, a social worker widely recognized as an authority on poverty and delinquency, died at Manhattan Veterans Hospital yesterday after a long illness. He was 48 years old and lived at 789 St. Marks Avenue, Brooklyn.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 13 --William E. John Jr., with the International, Foxtrot, and Mathias J. Burggraf, sailing the Class S sloop, Eaglet, were winners on Long Island Sound today during the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club regatta. The regatta drew the largest Yacht Racing Association fleet of the season.

HIGHLANDS, N.J.-- Although it has been largely ignored since the 1930's because of the new highways that take the motorist directly to resorts farther south along the Jersey coast, the Sandy Hook area is beginning to show signs of a revival of tourist interest.

OYSTER BAY, L.L, Aug. 13 --The marriage of Miss Caroline Roosevelt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Alfred Roosevelt of Tres Plumas Ranch, Valentine, Tex., to William Talman Moore Jr., of Centre Island, Oyster Bay, took place here this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church. The bride is a distant cousin of President Theodore Roosevelt.
FALMOUTH, Mass., Aug. 13 (UPI)--Eight pacifists of a group of 20 marching from Boston to Provincetown to protest the war in Vietnam were arrested today 60 miles short of their goal.

Almost always on the annual New York Yacht Club cruises there are one or two yachts whose efforts against the creations of modern naval architecture are a tribute to the lasting genius of Nat Herreshoff. This year such a yacht was Lloyd Bergeson's New York 30, Cockatoo II, designed and built by the Wizard of Bristol 61 years ago.
ONE very tangible development of last year's New York Film Festival is the scheduling of four new features from Czechoslovakia for this year's festival, to be held Sept. 12-22 at Lincoln Center.

MONTREAL, Aug. 13--In one U.S. state, a lawyer who is serving a prison sentence retains his license to practice. He does so by filing successive petitions for release, thereby keeping his conviction theoretically "not final."

BERLIN, Aug. 13 (AP)-- Marcia Smoke of Oklahoma City gave the United States its first victory today in the 12nation West Berlin canoeing regatta, a warm-up for the world championships in East Berlin next weekend.

THE words "dumping," "shaving points" and "rigging" first became prominent on the sports page in 19511952. That was the time when the nation became aware of point-controlled college basketball games, when players cooperated with gamblers to win by fewer points, or to lose by more than expected. The knowledgable cleaned up. Trouble came when both teams tried to lose by a certain spread of points--then the game became pretty sloppy.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 13 (Reuters)--Four hundred soldiers and civilians who allegedly took part in the abortive Buddhist movement to unseat the Saigon Government earlier this year are being detained on an island near Cambodia, a freed prisoner said here today.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 13 (UPI)--Marty Fleckman, the 22-year-old National Collegiate Athletic Association champion from the University of Houston, fired rounds of 66 and 73 today to maintain a one-stroke lead in the eighth annual Porter Cup invitation golf tournament.
Financial records of 89 carriers subject to the Intestate Commerce Commission's jurisdiction showed total freight revenues of $56.6-million for the first quarter of 1966.

FEW men can walk through a hall of mirrors without making some discoveries about themselves. For old men, life can become a hell of mirrors as they notice their prejudices echoed by their friends and their mistakes reflected in their children. In this lean, hard, shaking novel, Paul Olsen has brought together two men and two generations whose bitterness glances off each other until the emptiness becomes blinding --and, eventually, self-destructive.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug 13 --A cragged-faced movie and television performer named Ronald Reagan will be one of the most surprised of California's 19 million residents if he does not become Governor Reagan in January. THE portable or aboveground swimming pool has found wide popuularity with suburban homeowners. It is ideal for the occasional user or the homeowner with limited space and funds. And for those who rent their homes, this type of pool is the only answer to the desire for a private pool.

THERE are probably only three modern American writers who, having given rise to both legends and cults, have become myths: Fitzgerald, Hemingway and James Agee. But if the former two went from blinding success to comparative failure, and their posthumous reputations seem to be in danger of repeating the pattern, Agee was, during his lifetime, a much purer case of failure; and his posthumous reputation, though still not far-flung, spreads steadily, even fanatically.

THERE seems to be a run on Picturesque Philadelphia Parents these days. First we had Dr. Edward S. Gifford's delightful book about his doctor father, called "Father Against the Devil." Now we have Charles W. Thayer's almost-asdelightful book about his mother. "Muzzy" (unfortunate title, but that's what she was called) couldn't have been more different from Dr. Gifford Senior, though they were almost exact contemporaries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13--In the spring of 1864, Gen. Ulysses S. Grant sent the Army of the Potomac into the Wilderness of Virginia. But Grant, unlike so many Union commanders before him, was looking beyond Richmond, the Confederate capital. For the first time in three years of civil war, he had unified the whole of the Union effort on a broad strategic course to end the war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13-- The airline strike is not a national emergency, but merely a national nuisance, and a needless one at that. If the air travelers of America had received ample warning that the strike was coming, no one would be stranded today in Europe or stuck with Miami hotel reservations that he can't use.

In the two months since the United States Supreme Court handed down its new limitation on confessions the gloomy predictions of its critics have been happily unrealized.
