NORTH BATTLEFORD, Sask. A recent tour of Canada's rapeseed industry by oilseed experts from Japan has heightened interest in a new cash crop that, despite recent advances, is stilt a stranger in much of North America.
Alfred Kreymborg, an American poet and poetic dramatist, died last night in a nursing home at Milford, Conn., after an illness of six months. He was 82 years old.

A total of 529,533 square feet of new office space was leased in Manhattan last month. July is traditionally a poor month for the office-leasing business, but the month's total was up sharply from the June level of 383,550 square feet.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 14 (AP) Phil Roof's two-run single capped a three-run rally in the seventh inning that helped the Kansas City Athletics gain a 4-3 victory over the Minnesota Twins and a sweep of their double-header today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 The Treasury Department has decided that legislation is definitely necessary to bring a halt to the use of tax-free municipal bonds to finance construction of private industrial plants.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 14 (AP)--Capt. Lones W. Wigger Jr. of the Army Marksmanship Team from Fort Benning, Ga., shot his way to victory in the aggregate and individual matches of the national small-bore rifle-position championship.

Mr. [Frank S.] Owens, advertising manager of utica Club, said today in a news release that "the B (advertising campaign for Utica Club had created a great deal of favorable comment and has helped built Utica Club's sales to an all-time high."
BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 14--A meeting of South American Presidents opened here today to consider steps to revitalize the Alliance for Progress and promote regional economic integration.
HOWELL, N.J., Aug. 14 (UPI) A second man wanted in the slaying of a red-haired mother of four surrendered to the police early today.
PURCHASE, N.Y., Aug. 14 Bill Whitehead scored three goals today as the New Haven Polo team won the Michelob Cup by defeating Greenwich, 6-3, before 2,500 fans at the Blind Brook Polo Club.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 14 The New York Mets were one out from a sweep of a doubleheader over the St. Louis Cardinals in Busch Stadium today. They never got that final out as the Cards rallied for three runs to win the second game, 4-3, after the Mets had taken the opener, 5-4.
City Council President Frank D. O'Connor expects to fly to Washington today to ask Senator Robert F. Kennedy for a statement about the Democratic nomination for Governor.
Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving said yesterday that he would head a new city agency consolidating recreation, parks and cultural affairs.
Horticultural experts will judge the annual tenant flower garden competition sponsored by the City Housing Authority, Ira S. Robbins, vice chairman, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 Chairman Wright Patman of the House Banking Committee asked today that the Federal Reserve System's powerful Open-Market Committee make available its minutes and other records under a "freedom of information" law just passed by Congress.
The spokesman for the city's patrolmen denounced yesterday as a "civic disgrace" the use of the Gallo brothers in helping to halt racial violence in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Monday, Aug. 15 The Johnson Administration appeared early today to be making some headway toward settling the 38-day-old airline strike before the House considers legislation to end the walkout.
William B. Kegg of 65 East 91st Street, a member of the underwriting division of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, died Saturday in Memorial Hospital. He was 39 years old.

THERE are few recipes in American cooking as per sonal to those who make them as popovers. Each cook is adamant about the method to be used, the heat of the oven, whether a mixture must, be lumpy or smooth and whether the popovers should be pierced a few minutes before they are removed from the oven.

In acting to establish a Human Resources Administration and to put Mitchell Sviridoff in charge of it, Mayor Lindsay has made a decision of enormous potential benefit to New York. For it was Mr. Sviridoff who wrote the book the book in this case being a landmark report entitled "Developing New York City's Human Resources." It recommended precisely the comprehensive reorganization the Mayor is now ordering in the war against poverty.
(UPI)--Police arrested 19 demonstrators today, including the head of a civil rights drive here, when they attempted to enter a white church during the service.
The freight traffic manager of Grace Line's Caribbean service, Norman A. Maxon, has retired after nearly 50 years in shipping.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 Did President de Gaulle ever sincerely desire full cooperation with the United States and the North Atlantic alliance? Or was France's defection from the alliance predestined from the day the general, with his devotion to his country's right to independent action, took power in 1958?

CLIFTON, N.J., Aug. 14 On fairways dominated by the power of Jack Nicklaus and the personal appeal of Arnold Palmer, Mason Rudolph has always been considered a steady, solid, percentage golfer, cautious in technique and phlegmatic in style.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 14 (AP) Norm Nelson of Racine, Wis., the defending United States Auto Club champion, drove a 1966 Plymouth to victory in the 150-mile stock car race at State Fair Park today, setting a track record of 94.214 miles an hour.

WASHINGTON, Aug.14 (AP) A report published today by a Senate subcommittee challenged the suggestion that a coalition including the Vietcong could bring about a satisfactory solution of the Vietnam issue.

TOKYO "Challenge and Response" ... "Don't Be Afraid of Failure Make Full Use of Your Authority" ... 'More Responsibility, More Opportunity." New slogans such as these are being voiced in one of Japan's oldest and largest industrial enterprises since Toshio Doko took on the task of pulling the Tokyo Shibaura Electric Company out ...

ATHENS, Aug. 14 Despite a strike by most of its 139 pilots, Olympic Airways managed to keep the Athens-New York air route open today. But most of the company's 60 other Sunday flights in and out of Athens were halted.
TRENTON, Aug. 14 Democrats who oppose President Johnson's forceful pressing of the war in Vietnam were reported badly split today in the New Jersey primary election campaign.
Commissioner of Customs Lester D. Johnson reported yesterday that the United States Customs Service collected a record total of $2,473,616,824 during the fiscal year that ended June 30.

BUFFALO, Aug. 14 (AP) Trico Products, Inc., reported over the weekend that its net income for the first six months ended June 30 was $2,004,000, off from $2,140,000 for the corresponding period last year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 A new winkle in mutual funds funds whose investment port folios consist mainly or entirely of the shares of other mutual funds is receiving intense attention from the Securities and Exchange Commission.

BOSTON, Aug 14--Miss Dorothy Lucille Elia, daughter of Dr. Andrew D. Elia of Jamaica Plain and the late Dr. Dimetra T. Elia, was married this afternoon to Lloyd Thomas Howells Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Howells of Andover and Columbus, Ohio.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14 (AP) Ron Santo's sacrifice fly and Phil Regan's wild pitch brought in two 10th-inning runs that gave the Chicago Cubs a 12-10 second-game victory and a split of a doubleheader today with the Los Angeles Dodgers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP)--The Agriculture Department predicted tonight that retail food prices would be lower in the coming months.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 Congress is scheduled to focus its attention this week on proposed legislation that could help shape the future of the cities and of the nation's vast transportation network.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 14 Following this afternoon's television extravaganza at the shed of the Berkshire Music Festival, which attracted 8,093, a considerably smaller audience went to the theater-concert hall about 125. The occasion of the evening concert was the inauguration of the week-long Festival of Contemporary American Music, a Tangle-wood ...

WHAT now for Sonny Werblin, the former New York Times copyboy who went on to become the Ed Sullivan, if not quite the Jules Stein, of pro football? Rumors persist that the New York Jets, the team Werblin owns in part and runs in total, can be bought because the planned merger of the football leagues, National and American, has disenchanted Joe Namath's paymaster.
WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 14 Miss Susan Eileen Vucker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M.Vucker, was married today to Jethro Koller Lieberman, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Ben Lieberman of West New York, N.J.
Music lovers in Queens showed their hardiness last night, when about 13,000 of them stayed out in the rain to hear the New York Philharmonic.

Mayor Lindsay's expected appointment of Harold Baer Jr. as executive director of the new civilian-dominated police review board was deplored yesterday by John J. Cassese, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

UNTIL recently, Walter Millis says in his introduction to this intriguing anthology, Americaw military men have been little given to philosophical reflection on their profession, on the nature or war, military policy and the military factor in a free and democratic society.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14 Three men described as officials of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee were sought today on charges stemming from the discovery of dynamite in the local headquarters of the militant civil rights organization.

A COMPETITIVE bidding battle led to defensive problems in the diagramed deal from the Denver tournament earlier this month. East opened the bidding with one heart after two passes, and South bid one spade, or at some tables a pre-emptive two spades.
BAD luck or bad judgment has played a dominant role in many of the games in the Piatigorsky Cup Chess Tournament, which winds up tonight at the Miramar Hotel in Santa Monica, Calif.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 14 (AP) Ramon Emilio Mejia Pichirilo, a leader of the rebel forces in last year's Dominican Republic revolution, died today. He was shot in the back Friday night in downtown Santo Domingo.
RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 14 (UPI) Thousands of Ku Klux Klansmen swarmed into Memorial Auditorium for a rally today and found a band of Negroes in the balcony.
A dispute over a minor automobile incident early yesterday resulted in the shooting to death of one man and the wounding of another on the lower East Side.
LENOX, Mass., Aug. 14 In one of the more convulsive Berkshire Music Festival weekends, it is hard to count the blessings.
BETHLEHEM, Conn., Aug. 14 Ebbtide, an 8-year-old black gelding, made his first start of the year today and won the open working hunter championship at the Bethlehem horse show under a strange rider.
There is an acute shortage of office space in Manhattan's growing crop of skyscrapers.
A Government-sponsored committee of medical experts has concluded that, on the basis of present knowledge, there is no evidence that oral contraceptives are unsafe.

A $100-million sale by California on Wednesday accounts for almost half of the $205,982,054 of tax-exempt bonds up for bidding this week. Last week's revised total was only slightly higher at $222,131,282, according to The Bond Buyer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 The Rock Creek Baptist Church was the scene this afternoon of the marriage of Miss Sandra Mae Cavanaugh, daughter of Mrs. Clyde Howard Cavanaugh and the late Mr. Cavanaugh, to Dr. Marshall Rudd Holley, son of Dr. and Mrs. William A. Holley of Leetes Island, Guilford, Conn.

Columbia University's School of General Studies will begin this fall a one-year pilot program, the Intergroup Relations project, to train selected adults in the techniques of combating racial and religious prejudice in urban communities.
VUNGTAU, South Vietnam, Aug. 14 The commanding general of the 25th Infantry Division remarked today that something, was "very unusual" about his newly arrived brigade.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 14 (AP) Ronald Laird of Pomona, Calif., won the 40-kilometer National Amateur Athletic Union walking championship today by three-quarters of a mile. It was his 29th national championship in 10 years.

LONDON, Aug. 14 The British Government's attempt to freeze prices and incomes is delaying a scheduled rise in home mortgage rates. The delay could mean that there will be less money available for private homebuilding.

There's nothing more personal than the Government's consumer price index, simply because Americans eat, live in apartments or houses, drive cars, buy clothes and watch television. Such matters become price components in the index.

BOSTON, Aug. 14 Senator Jacob K. Javits called on the Administration tonight to take the lead in establishing an "economic opportunity corporation" that would mobilize business and industry as a major weapon in the antipoverty drive.
PAPEETE, Tahiti French authorities here are proceeding on the assumption that the status of the islands of east Polynesia as an overseas territory of France is a permanent arrangement.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 14 The New York Giants did not exactly overwhelm the fledgling Atlanta Falcons in their game at Nashville last night. They won a game in which they were clearly superior, 14-7, and should have scored more points against the National Football League's expansion team.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Aug. 14 Miss Maxine Joan Metzger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Metzger, was married this afternoon in her home to Barry Howard Denker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reuben Denker, of Philadelphia.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll calls in Congress during the week ended yesterday:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 Despite deliberate official vagueness on the subject, the United States prohibits its forces from engaging in ground operations in North Vietnam, according to reliable informants. The prohibition includes the North Vietnamese part of the demilitarized zone.
OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 14 William C. Howard, a pilot and captain with Trans World Airlines, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home, 16 Marshall Street. His age was 49.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 Chicago policemen clashed tonight with a roving band of angry whites who had been throwing rocks and firecrackers and bottles at Negro motorists in the Marquette Park area, the scene of similar violence recently.

Advocates of "black power" appealed yesterday for unity in their ranks at a crowded Harlem rally called to prepare for a nationwide conference on the movement scheduled in Washington over the Labor Day weekend.

ATHENS, Aug. 14 A 22year-old Greek soldier who twice refused to bear arms because of religious convictions was sentenced to death by a court-martial last week, the Athens daily Eleftheros Kosmos reported today.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 14 (AP) Jose Torres, the world light-heavyweight champion, was a 7-2 favorite today to beat Eddie Cotton tomorrow night in their 15-round title bout.

WASHINGTON Aug. 14 (AP) Frank Robinson hit home runs his first two times at bat and Boog Powell and Ed Watt also connected for homers today as the Baltimore Orioles crushed the Washington Senators, 6-0.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UPI) Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman predicted today that the Federal Trade Commission's investigation of soaring food prices would show profiteering by middlemen.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 14 Miss Donna Marie Lerario, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Lerario, was married this afternoon to Stephen Ronald Baar, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Baar of New York.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 14 Steel officials reported steady demand last week. "Our booking rate is about as even as you could get it," one sales manager said. "We're looking for uniform shipments in August, September and October," another said.
To err may be human, but what the Cleveland Indians did in Yankee Stadium yesterday was far-fetched.

The Fifth Avenue Synagogue was the setting last night for the marriage of Miss Willa Marcia Radin to Dr. Hillel I. Swiller. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Jacob Radin of 435 West 57th Street and the late Rabbi Radin. Dr. Swiller's parents are Dr. and Mrs. Samuel L. Swiller of Brooklyn.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 14 (AP)--The United States command reported today the loss of the 14th and 15th American planes in a week over North Vietnam following a day of strikes in the Hanoi-Haiphong area and in the southern panhandle.

WASHINGTON Aug. 14 (UPI) Groups protesting American involvement in the war in Vietnam charged today that the House Committee on Un-American Activities was attempting to kill the peace movement in the United States.

MANHASSET, L.I., Aug. 14 Tony Vincent of New York and William Tully of Pelham, the top two seeded players, reached the quarter-finals of the United States men's 35years-old division of the clay court tennis championships today at the Shelter Rock Tennis Club.

CLIFTON, N.J., Aug. 14 Mason Rudolph earned his richest golf check today by beating Jack Nicklaus in a closing headto-head duel in the $100,000 Thunderbird Golf Classic. With a final round of 69, the 32-yearold professional from Clarksville, Tenn., finished with a 72hole total of 278, one stroke ahead of Big Jack.
The City Commission on Human Rights said yesterday that its drive to increase the employment of Negroes and Puerto Ricans by concerns doing business with the city was showing results.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Aug. 14 (AP) Riot policemen used tear gas today to break up a mob of about 200 Chinese leftist demonstrators protesting rest visits to Malaysia by American forces from Vietnam and stopovers by United States warships.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 14 (UPI) Kathy Whitworth fought off a rash of final-round birdies by unheralded Peggy Wilson and scored her third straight tour victory in the Lady Carling open golf tournament today.

HONG KONG, Monday, Aug. 13 (AP) A Hawaii resident who went on an unauthorized trip to Communist China with two other opponents of nuclear war returned to Hong Kong yesterday and immediately flew to Japan, United States Consulate officials said today.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.L., Aug.' 14 Tony Roche of Australia, the most successful of the touring tennis players this season, added the 77th Meadow Club invitation grass court tournament to his string of achievements today.

THE bloom may be off the rose in swinging British fashion, persistent reports indicate. Recent visitors like Mary Quant, the designer, and Vidal Sassoon, the hairdresser, have voiced their concern about the carnival direction and the exploitation of the youthful revolution they led.
PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 14--Lunar Orbiter 1 moved successfully into an orbit around the moon today. The camera-bearing spacecraft is the nation's first vehicle to circle earth's nearest neighbor.

MILLBRAE, Calif., Aug. 14 (AP) Mrs. Pat Winslow, of San Mateo, Calif., beat Denise, Paschal of San Francisco yesterday in a rerun of the National Amateur Athletic Union women's pentathlon championship.
Escalation clauses, which allow a lender to increase his interest charge when his own cost of money goes up, are rare in home-mortgage lending in the United States, but they are not unknown.
JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Aug. 14 Gen. William C. Westmoreland declared today that, there had been no lessening of North Vietnam's resolve to prosecute the war.

The National Maritime Union has negotiated a new five-year contract covering 200 boatmen working in the inland waterways in the Pittsburgh area for United States Steel, Jones Laughlin and the Wheeling Steel Company.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 14 In Temple Israel here this afternoon, Miss Carol Barbara Feder, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Aaron Feder of Lake Success, became the bride of Samuel Elliott Cohan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Leo Cohan of Takoma Park, Md.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14 (AP)--Leroy Kelly returned a punt 87 yards for a touchdown and Walt Roberts set up another tally with a 42-yard return as the Cleveland Browns gained a 28-17 victory today over the San Francisco 49ers in a National Football League exhibition.

DETROIT, Aug. 14 (AP) New-car sales in the United States advanced slightly in the first 10 days of August despite declines reported over the weekend by the General Motors Corporation and the American Motors Corporation.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 14--Joe Namath, the New York Jets' quarterback, who injured his right knee in an exhibition game last night, will be sidelined two to three weeks. The injury, said. Dr. James A. Nicholas, the Jets' physician, "was the best thing that could have happened to him."

More than half the television viewers in this area believe that educational television should be financially supported by limited commercials, according to a study by Louis Harris and Associates, public-opinion analysts. Educational stations are not now licensed to sell time to advertisers.
Alexander J. Hammerslough, a real estate developer in the nineteen-twenties and later publisher, died Friday night in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 83 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP)--Senate-House conferees agreed today to block any spending this year for the controversial proposal to extend the West Front of the Capitol, but to permit preliminary planning to continue.

YONKERS, Aug. 15--The followers of Stanley Dancer, the skillful harness racing driver from New Egypt, N.J., were rewarded with three straight winners in the third, fourth and fifth races tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 15--Mrs. Harold Fink and Jackie Wolinsky of Hampshire won the 39th annual motherdaughter championship of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Winged Foot Golf Club today.
BOSTON, Aug. 15 (AP)-- Boog Powell's third home run of the game--a two-run blast in the 11th inning--helped the Baltimore Orioles beat the Boston Red Sox, 4-2, tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15-- The United States expressed hope today that W. Averell Harriman, Ambassador at Large, would be able to make a planned visit to Cambodia.

VERONA, Pa., Aug. 15-- Kathleen Ahern of the Dallas Athletic Club led the field by five strokes with a 75 today in the first round of qualifying for the 18th annual United States girls' junior golf championship.

LONDON, Aug. 15--Francis Chichester won't be 65 years old until next month, but there was a party for him at Greenwich today. DETROIT, Aug. 15 (AP)-- The automobile industry completed its 1966 model output last week and reported a total production second only to that of record 1965.
DETROIT, Aug. 15--Tiger Stadium is known in baseball as a "hitters" park. It has a nice green background that is easy on the eyes and nice comfortable dimensions that are easy on the muscles.

F.L. Cappaert, founder and president of the Magnolia Homes Manufacturing Corporation, which was acquired in an $18-million transaction by Guerdon Industries on Aug. 3, was elected yesterday as chairman and chief executive officer of Guerdon.
The Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts and the National Educational Television network have canceled plans to televise a one-hour drama by Jack Richardson.
Ralph S. Saul, a former high official of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has been nominated to become the next president of the American Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15--A Federal judge ordered the House Committee on Un-American Activities today not to hold a scheduled hearing tomorrow on a bill that would make it a crime for American citizens to aid the Vietcong.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 15--United States military officials said today that they had uncovered enemy plans to take over Saigon by force.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 15 (AP)--A Federal judge today changed the school desegregaition plan for Bogalusa, La., to the free-choice system and ordered teachers hired "without regard to race or color."
The Weather Bureau reported yesterday that nearly a halfinch of rain was recorded in Central Park between 6:07 P.M. Sunday and 9:05 A.M. yesterday.

A drug that may cause serious, and sometimes fatal, side effects is being brought into this country from Mexico for the treatment of arthritis, says a news report in the current issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) --If the members of the machinists' union accept the contract settlement drawn up today, the longest, biggest and costliest airlines strike would be ended six weeks after it started.
Unless the 35,000 striking airlines mechanics once again repudiate their union leaders, service will soon return to normal on the planes that carry 60 per cent of the country's air passengers.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 15--Two women who aided Abram Fischer, a Communist lawyer, while he was in hiding from the police last year were sentenced to two years' imprisonment by the Johannesburg Regional Court today.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 15 (AP) --Jan Kiepura, the Polish-born tenor, died of a heart attack today at his home here. He was 62 years old.
Eugene H. Nickerson withdrew last night as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor.
CHICAGO, Aug. 15--Circuit Judge Fred W. (Duke) Slater, one of the first Negroes elected a judge and a member of the Football Hall of Fame, died last night in his home here. He was 67 years old.

PONCE, P.R., Aug. 1--Mayor Eduardo Ruberte held up sketches of graceful colonnaded houses in his office today and proudly explained, how he was trying to preserve examples of them in the center of Puerto Rico's second largest city.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI)--The Air Force disclosed today that it had removed one officer from his post and reprimanded two others after investigating the XB-70 accident of June 8 that took the lives of two test pilots.

IN 1966 the All-American Congress of Conventional Menu Planners gathered about them nuts and bolts and tiny transistors to perfect a machine to provide them once and for all with the ultimate stereotyped menu.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla.,. Aug. 15 (AP)--Lightning knocked out electric power throughout Florida's capital today, and it was more than an hour before some of the 50,000 population got its current back.
Mayor Lindsay moved yesterday to help the "little fellow" who wants to open a barbershop, a grocery, a shoeshine parlor or some other small business.

The American College of Radiology, in an accelerated campaign to allow the nation's 7,000 radiologists to bill patients directly, has closed its placement bureau to hospitals that forbid the practice.
A moderate sell-off in the closing half-hour of trading pushed most issues on the American Stock Exchange yesterday into the minus column.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 15-- The military regime of Lieut. Gen. Juan Carlos Ongania was severely criticized today by Roman Catholic bishops.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 15 (UPI)--Jose Torres of Brooklyn, the world light-heavyweight champion, retained his crown tonight when he gained a unanimous decision over Eddie Cotton of Seattle at the Convention Center.
LIVINGSTONE, Zambia, Aug. 15--The sign at the border said, "You Are Entering Zambia, the Friendly Country."
The nation's credit unions had their best year in l965, the Credit Union National Association disclosed yesterday in Madison, Wis.

The University of North Carolina is planning a dramatic arts building to cost $2.5-million. A bequest of $100,000 toward construction of the multiple-theater structure was left by Mrs. William Meade Prince, an actress, whose husband was an illustrator and author.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15-- A nationwide program to control jet aircraft noise is quietly, under way in the Government.

A Suffolk County District Court judge was directed by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court yesterday to face an inquiry into charges that he had violated judicial ethics by seeking publicity.
Steel production made its sharpest weekly advance last week since May, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
BOSTON, Aug. 15--Senator Edward M. Kennedy outlined today a program "to control the spread of violence in the nation."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15-- Long as a football field, capable of carrying 300 persons from here to there at 1,800 miles per hour, the supersonic jetliner will be among us by 1974. To what use will we put this great machine?

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Aug. 15--Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn and Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union were tied for first place last night as they began the 18th and last round of the Piatigorsky Cup Chess Tournament here.

White prejudice against the Negro has not slackened substantially in the last three years, and the white man, resentful of rioting, now opposes even peaceful Negro demonstrations, a nationwide survey has indicated.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15--An agreement to end the airline strike was reached this morning after an all-night bargaining session between the International Association of Machinists and five major airlines.
GENEVA, Aug. 15--The physical condition of two writers serving long terms in a central Russian hard-labor camp was described today as "very bad."

The Government-sponsored report on oral contraceptives was viewed yesterday in medical circles as a "judicious" report that gives the pills a clean bill of health for the present but cautions that more and better research is needed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP)--The American Telephone and Telegraph Company deferred today a decision on whether to permit news media to share with one another in the concern's communications package deal known as TELPAK.
The nation's struck airlines, which several times in the current stoppage have had their hopes of business as usual dashed, are cautiously making plans to resume service.

BECAUSE of the extraordinary legal circumstances attending the assassina tion of President John F. Kennedy, an extraordinary legal body, the Warren Commission, was created to perform in effect all the functions of establishing legal truth.

PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 15 --Lunar Orbiter 1, looping the moon every three and a half hours, flashed to earth today a television test pattern in the first demonstration that it was able to send high-quality pictures of the lunar landscape.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5-- Treasury bill rates soared to record levels at today's auction, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary announced yesterday that the International Association of Chiefs of Police would study the operations and management of the Police Department here.

Following is the second of a series of five articles by an assistant managing editor of The New York Times, who recently completed an extensive tour of Asia, which concentrated on the countries bordering Communist China.

EIGHT young women gazed into eight mirrors. They chewed constantly. They giggled frequently. But on the whole it was serious business: Before their outlined eyes, their reflections were being, transformed into "natural" shadows of their former selves.
The sandbag, a familiar sight to the combat soldier, is acquiring glamour. Now it's going to be made of woven plastic materials rather than burlap or heavy, coarse cotton.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP)--Senator Everett McKin ley Dirksen of Illinois said today that the problem of racial discrimination in housing requires more study.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 15--Tainted Lady, California-bred owned by Ewing Kauffman, won the Adirondack Stakes at Saratoga today despite a tardy start.

COLUMBUS, Neb., Aug. 15 (UPI)--Carcasses of dead cattle and hogs littered the banks of the receeding Platte and Loup Rivers today, left there by record weekend floods that forced 2,000 persons from their homes.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. I5 (UPI)--A top police official said today that five sticks of dynamite confiscated following a raid on the headquarters of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee were powerful enough to "remove Independence Hall."
The Metropolitan Opera House began its full schedule of rehearsals for the coming season yesterday at its new home in Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.
Walter Germann, an international Swiss banker, was found guilty of contempt in Federal Court yesterday for failing to appear before a grand jury investigating "tax havens" in foreign bank accounts.

The death of The New York Herald Tribune stills a voice that for a century and a quarter exerted a powerful influence in the affairs of nation, state and city. It was a competitor of ours, but a competitor that sought survival on the basis of quality, originality and integrity, rather than sensationalism or doctrinaire partisanship.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., Aug. 15--A group of 25 Rockland County parents is challenging the legality of a school board's plan to begin publicschool classes next month in church and synagogue facilities here.
Deep regret over the end of The New York Herald Tribune was expressed yesterday by leaders in politics, the arts, business and other fields.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 15--Dr. Robert Livingston Schuyler, former Gouverneur Morris Professor of History at Columbia University, died today in a nursing home. His age was 83. Professor Schuyler lived here with his daughter, Mrs. C. Clay Halstead.
Work is under way on an 18story addition to the Decoration and Design Building, an 18-story structure completed two years ago on the northeast corner of 58th Street and Third Avenue.
LONDON, Aug. 15--A 36year-old unemployed man was charged tonight with the murder of three unarmed plainclothes policemen last Friday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 15--Secretary General Thant proposed today a United Nations budget of $128,227,800 for next year--about $6.6-million more than the current budget.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 15--Dr. Robert Livingston Schuyler, former Gouverneur Morris Professor of History at Columbia University, died today in a nursing home. His age was 83. Professor Schuyler lived here with his daughter, Mrs. C. Clay Halstead.
The shrunken staff of The New York Herald Tribune heard of the newspaper's demise yesterday with sadness but no great shock.
Over one of the doorbell buttons in the foyer of an East 18th Street apartment house are the letters M.M.R.P.-O.P.D. The button is pressed dozens of times a day.

BONN, Aug. 15--Helmut Schmidt, vice chairman of the Opposition party, the Social Democrats, proposed today that West Germany recognize Czechoslovakia and Rumania despite the fact that they recognize East Germany.

History's longest permanent, established, floating disarmanent conference is winding up its fifth summer session without action on either of the two treaties needed to halt the spread of nuclear weapons --a comprehensive test ban or a nonproliferation pact.
NORTHPORT, L.I., Aug. 15 --Bill Owens, a Boston lawyer representing the Marblehead, Mass., fleet, won the first race today in the 110 Class national sailing championship on Long Island Sound.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 15--In the view of American military and civilian observers, President Johnson asked the wrong questions when he inquired about the circumstances of the death and injury of more than 100 civilians in an air attack on a Mekong delta hamlet last...
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15-- When words of the tentative settlement of the airlines strike reached the House of Representatives this morning a sigh of relief from its members was almost audible.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 15 (AP)--A Federal appeals court today reversed the convictions of two Negroes who have been in solitary confinement on Death Row for 13 years--a modern record.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 15--Syrian and Israeli planes fought an air duel this morning near the Sea of Galilee. It was their second armed clash in less than a month in that area.
Under a haze that settled over Randalls Island and refused to budge, the Brooklyn Dodgers returned to New York last night.

Mayor Lindsay set up a new agency yesterday to merge and direct all of the city's efforts to aid the poor. He named Mitchell Sviridoff, the head of the New Haven antipoverty program, as its administrator.
Four major corporations announced yesterday the election of new presidents.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange rose yesterday in quiet trading. However, shares closed below their best levels as buying lacked momentum.

ABOARD U.S.S. ST. PAUL, off South Vietnam, Aug. 14-- Through the windows of the captain's air-conditioned sitting room, you can see the coastal plain and the gentle hills farther inland as they slide by. They look verdant and peaceful in the afternoon sun.

The New York Herald Tribune was formally closed yesterday, bringing to an end a long and distinguished journalistic tradition.

MORE than 14,000 spectators attended the ninth annual New Hope, Pa., automobile show, held over the weekend on the New HopeSolebury School Grounds. There were 701 entries for the event, which had 15 judging divisions, an automotive flea market and a safety exhibition ...
An entrance to the Times Square subway station was reopened yesterday with a subterranean fashion show.
Major museums throughout the world are planning to lend hundreds of art objects to museums in emerging countries in Africa and to create a gallery of Western art at the National Museum in New Delhi

A member of a nationwide ring that blackmailed homosexuals received yesterday in Federal Court the maximum prison sentence, five years, and a $10,000 fine.
Brig. Gen. Charles R. (Monk) Meyer, 53 years, old, who would rather fight than retire, has been passed over for promotion by the Army Selection Board and now faces statuatory retirement next July 31.

SAYVILLE, L.I., Aug. 16 Ralph Sperry the defending champion of the Black Rock Yacht Club, held a slender lead today after three races in the area semifinals of the North American junior sailing championship.

YONKERS, Aug. 16 Miss Dee-Ann Ciel Aoth, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Roth of New York and the late Mr. Roth, was married this morning to Ens. D. Michael Kinard, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. Kinard of Homestead, Fla.

A man who had been held by police as a material witness for 12 days was charged yesterday with the two-year-old slaying of a Columbia University nuclear physicist in the Ramble section of Central Park.
SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 16--A sharp new rise in defense spending was announced in Canberra tonight by William McMahon, Australia's Federal Treasurer.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 16 John C. Baldwin of the Plandome C.C., with 70, 71 141, James Rheim of Chula Vista, Calif., with 72, 72 144, and Theodore Weiss of New Orleans with '70, 74 144, earned the three Long Island berths in the United States Amateur today on the 6,463-yard, par-70 Nassau C.C. course.

GASTONIA, N.C., Aug. 16 (UPI) The Gaston County Board of Elections said today it was filing suit against the Federal Government to have the county removed from the registrar provisions of the 1965 Voting Rights Act.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 16 The military regime of Lieut. Gen. Juan Carlos Ongania began a broad retreat today before the angry Argentine academic community.
RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 16 Skippers of the host Monmouth Boat Club won four of the eight class titles today as the eighth annual National Junior Sweepstakes sailing regatta ended on the Navesink River.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy's declaration of neutrality in the race for the Democratic nomination for Governor makes the selection of Council President Frank D. O'Connor virtually certain.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 16 Junior Race Week on Long Island Sound began off the American Yacht Club today with a fleet of 251 sailing in a 10-to-12-knot east-of-south breeze that lightened during the races and then returned.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) Col. Lewis Stone Sorley, the second oldest living graduate of the United States Military Academy, died of a heart attack on Friday night at Walter Reed Army Hospital. He was 99 years old.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 16 The engagement of Miss Elaine Kathryn Ann Kusako to Michael F. Hoben, son of Mr. and Mrs, Francis M. Hoben of Milford, Conn., has been announced by the prospective bride's father, William J. Kusako.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 16 President Sukarno reiterated today his desire to convene a Conference of New Emerging Forces here as part of Indonesia's "struggle against imperialism.'
BOSTON, Aug. 16 Arthur Stanwood Pier, writer, editor and teacher, died Sunday in his home at 186 Marlborough Street. He was 92 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 Senator Robert F. Kennedy announced today that he would not support any specific candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor at the party's state convention next month or attempt to block any candidate.

Now that the Senate has undertaken a study of charges that foreign mills are dumping steel here, a fire of contention appears to have been reduced to a still-hot coal.

A November wedding is planned by Miss Joan Meryle Moss and Jay Jacobson. Mr. and Mrs. Irving Moss of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Jacobson of Merrick, L.I.

Community leaders of the Flatbush section of Brooklyn met last night to discuss ways of heading off further racial strife in their neighborhood, in which a Negro man shot two youths in a crowd of whites last week.

Two Off Broadway shows will be directed by Burt Shevelove, co-author of "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum." He will stage "The Butter and Egg Man" and the marionette revue, "People Is, the Thing That the World Is Fullest Of."
NEW DELHI, Aug. 16 India has protested to communist China against fresh military intrusions in western Ladakh.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 Personal income rose by $2.5 billion in July, slightly less than the average monthly rise in the first half of the year, the Department of Commerce reported today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16-- Judge Howard Francis Corcoran's ruling yesterday enjoining the House Committee on Un-American Activities from holding scheduled hearings took his friends completely by surprise.

MANHASSETT, L.I., Aug. 16 George Ball of Roslyn, L.I., and Dr. Reggie Weir of New York, the fifth-seeded doubles team, won two matches today and advanced to the third round of the National age 35-and-over clay-court tennis championships.
Helena, Mont., Aug. 16 (AP) Richard D. Smiley of Bozeman, a radio station owner and member of the Legislature, led tonight in Montana's only primary contest for a nomination to Congress.
WASHINGTON, Aug.16 (AP) President Johnson nominated four new Federal judges today, bringing the total to nine for two days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 Members of the striking machinists' union appeared to be reacting favorably today to a new airline contract that their president said "completely shatters" the Government's wageprice guideposts "for all unions."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today the firing of a 550-pound instrument package on a 13 -minute flight from its Wallops Island, Va., station to study the earth's horizon.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Aug. 17--United States Navy pilots reported that a surface-to-air missile fired at a flight of A-4 Skyhawks yesterday missed its target, reversed itself and exploded in a populated area east of Haiphong.
The city is building an "instant vest pocket" playground in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 16 Rallying after a slow start, Cestrum of the Bohemia Stable won the feature Saratoga Springs Purse today. With Wally Blum in the saddle, Cestrum scored by a nose over Jacques Wimpfheimer's Petite Rouge in the six-furlong sprint.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16 Former Gov. Goodwin J. Knight, who had maintained a cryptic silence in California's gubernatorial campaign, tacitly aligned himself today with the cause of his fellow Republican, Ronald Reagan.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 16--Prospects for new talks between India and Pakistan to improve relations between them appeared to have dimmed today.
PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 16 City planners were accused today of forgetting people and emphasizing things.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 16 Five South American Presidents called today for the ending of the war in Vietnam, which they said constituted a threat to world peace.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Aug. 16 (AP) The Monmouth County Board of Freeholders posted rewards today totaling $30,000 for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the person or persons responsible for six recent murders in the county. The reward in each case would be $5,000.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) Representative John E. Moss, Democrat of California, urged Congress today to make it a Federal crime to use any kind of eavesdropping device against American citizens.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 Prompted by Republican economy pleas, the House voted 40day to limit funds for the urban mass transit program to the present level of 150-million a year.
Ralph S. Saul, a vice president of Investors Diversified Services, Inc., was elected president of the American Stock Exchange yesterday at a special board of governors meeting.

IF I had my way, the publication of Robert Crichton's brilliant novel, "The Secret of Santa Vittoria," would be celebrated with fanfares of trumpets, with the display of banners and with festivals in the streets. This is an irresistibly engaging, hilariously funny book. It bubbles with gaiety and wit, bursts with laughter and throbs with the sheer joy of life.

VERONA, Pa., Aug. 16 kathleen Ahern of the Dallas Athletic Club tied two records today as she took the medal after 36 holes of qualifying play in the 18th annual United States girls' junior golf championship.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 16 An appeal to Syria and Israel for unconditional observance of a United Nations cease-fire has been made by the head of the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization, whose headquarters is in Jerusalem.
WILLIAMSPORT, Tenn., Aug. 16 Miss Martha Nichols Kinzer of Atlanta and Lieut. Kenneth P. Lord 3d, U.S.A., who attends the Armor School at Fort Knox, Ky., plan to marry here on Sept. 11.

There's something new on the main floor of the New York Telephone Company building at 227 East 30th Street amid the multicolored wires and the soft "click, click, click" of equipment reacting to far-off dial spins. It's a girl.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 The start of Congressional hearings into how some Americans have aided the Vietcong erupted into disorder today, minutes after a head-on clash between the judicial and the legislative branches was averted.

LINCOLN CENTER'S Mozart Festival continued in good form at Philharmonic Hall last night with a recital played by the 23-year-old Israeli pianist, Daniel Barenboim, who is currently making his eighth North American tour.

ATHENS, Aug. 16 Christos Kazanis, the 22-year-old Jehovah's Witness condemned to death for refusing to bear arms, will have a requested review of his case later this month, a Government spokesman said today.
The Republic Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it would build an 84-inch continuous hot strip mill at its Cleveland works at a cost of $125-million.
The nation's Knights of Columbus, 1.2 million strong, were urged last night in Miami Beach to stop thinking of self-defense and to seek out opportunities to defend and help others.

About the only blessing of the airlines strike is that life has been a bit quieter for the people unlucky enough to live within roaring distance of jet airports. Now that the planes are about to fly again, it is time for Congress to do something about taking the decibels out of the aerial parade.
JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), Aug. 16 An Iraqi air force pilot defected today and flew his Soviet-built MIG-21 to Israel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 Robert B. Bowie told a Senate committee today that the United States was justified in supporting and strengthening those groups in Europe that favored the Administration's ideas about European unity.
Miss Marie-Benedicte Blanckaert and Erik Nilsson Dunlaevy plan to be married on Oct. 25 at the Church of Les Invalides in Paris.

Michael Rozental, first vice president of Abbott Adams, Inc., real estate, 292 Madison Avenue, died Monday in Long Beach (L.I) Memorial Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 630 Fort Washington Avenue.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (UPI) A car damaged during a civil rights demonstration is covered by insurance if the owner has a "comprehensive" policy, the Insurance Information Institute said today.
DETROIT, Aug. 16 Ralph Houk sat in the New York Yankees' dugout before tonight's game against the Detroit Tigers and said: "The trouble is, our pitchers aren't getting the key hitters out".

Dr. Henry Horn, a specialist in internal medicine, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. He was 59 years old and lived at 180 East End Avenue.

Lyle M. Farmen has been named treasurer of the R.T. French Company. Mr. Farmen will also continue as controller.

The spot rate on the British pound was steady in quiet trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The currency closed at $2.7892, unchanged from Monday. Volume was small.

National Airlines announced yesterday the start of construction of a $15-million passenger terminal at Kennedy International Airport.

Because of an unusual demand for tickets, the Lake George Opera Festival near Glens Falls, N.Y., will extend its fifth anniversary season an extra week.

The wholesale commodity price index fell to 111.7 on Monday from 111.9 on Friday.
