WASHINGTON, Aug.16 (AP) John W. Macy Jr., chairman of the Civil Service Commission, suggested today that annual pay for members of Congress and key Government officials be pushed toward $50,000. Senators and Representatives now receive $30,000 a year.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 16 Bob Schweickert and Jim Waskiewicz, fourth-round draft choices of the last two years, were among five players cut today by the New York Jets.
BUFFALO, Aug. 16 Governor Rockefeller talked about state aid and Democratic "bossism" today, to the cheers of upstate crowds. He also rode the first elephant of his political career.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 16 (AP) Ken Harrelson's two-run homer with two out in the 13th inning gave the Washington Senators a 6-5 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight.

Supreme Court Justice Arthur G. Klein yesterday gave the Old Met Opera House Corporation until 4 P.M. today to produce the $100,000 offered it by Huntington Hartford, the art patron. If the money is not forthcoming, Justice Klein said he would allow demolition of the opera house to proceed.
The American Civil Liberties Union attacked yesterday the idea of Federal data centers because of what it called their inherent dangers to civil liberties.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 The United States, reversing itself, conceded today that a border village hit by United States air units early this month might have been on Cambodian territory.

VIEWERS of "The Angry Voices of Watts," last night's hour-long "news inquiry" on the National Broadcasting Company network, were afforded not only a rare example of the creative documentary for which television is uniquely suited, but also a searing portrait of Watts one year after.
The stock market dropped to new lows for the year yesterday in active trading, but there was no dramatic news to account for the decline.

Pan American World Airways, Inc., announced yesterday that since July 8, when the airline machinists went on strike, it had paid out $7,341,000 to four of the five struck airlines under a mutual aid pact. A spokesman for Braniff Airways, Inc., said his line had made similar "strike insurance payments of about $750,000."

Swank, Inc., a major producer of men's jewelry, toiletries and accessories, gift items and watches, announced yesterday it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire Prince Gardner Company, Inc., makers of men's and women's leather billfolds and related leather goods. The multimilliondollar cash transaction is subject to approval of Prince Gardner shareholders, according to Marshall Tulin, president of Swank.

Phyllis Diller, Reginald Gardiner, Gypsy Rose Lee and Grady Sutton, stars of "The Pruitts of Southampton," a television comedy series starting next month on the American Broadcastiilg Company network, will be introduced at a ouffet dinner dance on Aug: 27 at Polish Hall in Southampton, L.I. The event has been arranged on behalf of the National Historic Shrines Foundation.
"How to Steal a Million" at Radio City Music Hall.

The Paramount Picture Corporation has elected Bernard Donnenfeld to the newly created post of vice president in charge of studio and production administration, George Weltner, president, announced yesterday.

ALBANY, Aug. 16 (AP) Governor Rockefeller declared farmlands in Ulster and Orange Counties disaster areas today and said he had asked the United States Agriculture Commissioner to release idle land in the counties for grazing.

Negotiators for the Pressman's Union and The World Journal Tribune renewed their talks yesterday in an effort to break the deadlock that has held up publication of the new company's newspapers since April.

MILL NECK, L.I., Aug. 16 The engagement of Mrs. Virginia Winmill Radsch of Briarpatch to Paul Livingston Armstrong of London has been announced by her mother, Mrs. Robert Campbell Winmill of Whiffle Tree Manor in Warrenton, Va.
HONG KONG, Aug. 16 (Reuters) Hsinhua, the Chinese Communist press agency, tonight reported sharp fighting between pro-Communist and Government troops in northern Laos.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 The Senate Banking Committee, by a 10-to-4 vote, approved legislation today to expand the Government's powers to halt unsafe and unsound practices of banks and savings and loan associations.
BREST, France, Aug. 16 (Reuters) Joseph Papp, a Hungarian-born Canadian who says he crossed the Atlantic in a home-made submarine, tonight was sent on his way home to Canada, the police here said.
Bond prices declined sharply yesterday, depressing some corporate issues a full point and pushing some Government bonds down to the lowest levels in 40 years.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. (UPI) The Senate Investigation Subcommittee reactivated its investigation of the TFX aircraft today because of new controversy over its cost and effectiveness.
Dr. Emil Schwarzmann, of 277 Haven Avenue, a surgeon who formerly practiced at 133 East 58th Street, died yesterday at Bellevue Hospital. His age was 81.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 16 (Reuters)--The Indian Government is to give cash incentives to some exporters in an effort to increase the country's exports. This move follows devaluation of the rupee in June.

A HUNTING operation for sportsmen in Utah is under way and will continue until Oct. 28. It is conducted by the Ute Tribal Outdoor Recreational Enterprise over a half-million acres of the reservation along the Green River.

The directors of the Standard Prudential United Corporation stated that an exchange offer to shareholders of Standard Financial Corporation, a factoring concern, was completed yesterday. The action was announced by Theodore H. Silbert president.

Jacques-Yves Cousteau, the French oceanographer, will make underwater expeditions in various parts of the world to film a series of 12 one-hour color programs for the American Broadcasting Company. To finance the expeditions, the television network will provide about $3.5-million, which works out at a production cost for each show of more than $290,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 In one of his rare public witticisms, Secretary of State Rusk addressed himself recently to the idea that other Communist nations might send "volunteers" to the aid of North Vietnam.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 16 Syria said today that she had abandoned diplomacy at the United Nations in favor of direct military response to Israeli "aggression." Dr. Ibrahim Makhous, the Deputy Premier and Foreign Minister, said in a statement reported here that this policy would be pursued whatever the cost.

ROME One might summarize impressions of a recent trip to Bonn as follows: The Adenauer era is over, with interment of his basic policy that if West Germany only stays strong the East will yield, permitting national reunification.
Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary announced yesterday that he will appoint Harold Baer Jr., an assistant United States attorney, as executive director of the civilian-dominated police review board.
VAN NUYS, Calif., Aug. 16 (AP) The parents of two brothers say the young men have been jailed for more than a month by Hungarian authorities for undetermined reasons.

Litton Industries, Inc., the West Coast electronics concern, has continued its unbroken record of peak sales and earnings for the 12th year of its operations, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Charles B. Thornton, chairman.
The Internal Revenue Service has seized the 49-year-old Pasadena, (Calif.) playhouse, valued at $2-million, for tax arrears of $31,000, which includes $3,000 in penalties and interest.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Aug. 16 John Mortimer Rutherfurd, national director of community relations for the International Business Machines Corporation, died of a heart attack Saturday at Edgartown on Martha's Vineyard, Mass. He was 53 years old and lived here on Button Hook Road.

The opening of the House Un-American Activities Committee hearings on left-wing aid to the Vietcong proved as disorderly and unproductive as the work of this committee usually is. There is little reason to suppose that any information developed in these hearings could form the basis of a constitutionally viable piece of legislation.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 16 Jules Dubois, correspondent of The Chicago Tribune for Latin America, died of a heart attack here today while covering an economic conference of the presidents of Chile, Colombia, and Venezuela. He was 56 years old.

The Landmarks Preservation Commission announcedyesterday the designation of 13 landmarks and two historic districts. Among the landmarks is Old St. Patrick's Cathedral, dating from 1809, the first seat of the Roman Catholic See in New York City. It was described by the commission as a "superb example" of Gothic Revival architecture.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) Representative Samuel S. Stratton, said, today that he had asked the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare to delay approval of New York State's controversial medical aid program.

EGGERTSVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 16 Mr. and Mrs. Daniel B. Curtiss of Eggertsville and Wolfeboro, N.H., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Donna Prince Curtiss, to Dr. James R. Pratt. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester J. Pratt of Angola, Ind.
The two leading trade asso- ciations in the footwear manufacturing industry said yester- day they would join forces.

For the first time since General Peron made the mistake of antagonizing the Roman Catholic Church in Argentina, the hierarchy there has openly criticized a government. This is the regime of still another military dictator, Lieut. Gen. Juan Carlos Ongania.

A thick fog was dissipated by a torrential rain at Shea Stadium last night and the Pittsburgh Pirates, showing little muscle, scored a 3-0 victory over the Mets in a game called with two out in the seventh inning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 Paul Rand Dixon, the chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, vehemently opposed today proposals to establish a Cabinet-level department of consumer affairs to represent the public before this agency and elsewhere in the Government.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16 (UPI) Don Sutton held the Cincinnati Red to two hits tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers scored a 2-0 victory.

The United States Maritime Administration and the Federal Maritime Commission have approved Grace Line's acquisition of the Pacific Republics Line, a division of MooreMcCormack Lines, Inc., W.J. McNeil, Grace president, announced yesterday.
YONKERS, Aug. 16 This was to have been a night off his first of the year for John Chapman. He had planned to spend it at home in Westbury (L.I.)
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 In the future the Federal Government will take a chance on hiring "good risk" former criminal offenders.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 16 (AP) The Wimbledon champion, Mrs. Billie Jean Moffitt King of Long Beach, Calif., ran into unexpected opposition, but settled down to defeat Elena Subirats of Mexico City, 7-5, 6-2, today in the first round of the 39th Essex women's invitation tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) Manuel F. Cohen, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, announced today the appointment of David L. Ratner, associate professor of law at Cornell University, as his executive assistant.

Mrs. Hoyte Joyce of 570 Park Avenue and Morton Dean Joyce of New York and Kennebunk, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Handly Joyce, to Dr. Joseph Cornelis Wijman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albertus Geradus Wijman of Utrecht, the Netherlands.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 Mr. and Mrs. Harry Rosen have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mass Tzivia Rosen, to Bruno Bieler, son of Dr. and Mrs. Meyer Bieler of New York.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 16 Bunky Henry of Valdosta, Ga., a place-kicker for the Georgia Tech football team, was the medalist today in the Westchester sectional qualifying for the United States amateur golf championship, which begins Aug. 31 at the Merion Cricket Club Ardmere, Pa.
LUCITE, the glamour plastic of the nineteen-thirties, has made a comeback in furnishings and has been used in a group of serving pieces being introduced by Raymor.
The key interest rate on business borrowing was raised yesterday to 6 per cent, the highest level since the nineteentwenties.
It's getting so a body can't make it even to the breakfast table in the morning without being exposed to advertising even if he doesn't have the radio on.
WINNIPEG, Man., Aug. 16 (Canadian Press) Donald H. Murdoch, a former president of Kiwanis Clubs International, died here yesterday. He was 70 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 Aaron G. Benesch, a newspaperman for more than 50 years in St. Louis and Washington, died today at Providence Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 5480 Wisconsin Avenue, Chevy Chase, Md.
The Chesapeake Ohio and the Baltimore Ohio Railroads announced yesterday the election of Ernest W. Wright as vice president in charge of trailer service for both companies.

Eugene Rodriguez, Democratic nominee for the State Senate from the Bronx Who is under indictment on grand lar ceny and perjury charges moved yesterday to have his case transferred from state to Federal court.
The executive boards of the Lithographers and Photoengravers International Union and the International Stereotypers and Electrotypers Union announced agreement on the terms for a merger yesterday.

Dr. Thomas W. Matthew, executive director of the Interfaith Health Association and of the Interfaith Hospital of Queens in Jamaica, announced yesterday the formation of a new self-help civil rights group to raise money for the construction of hospitals and rehabilitation of slums.

In a sale and lease-back transaction, the San Diego Dynamics Company has bought the 17-story office building at 545 Madison Avenue, on the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and East 55th Street, for $750,000 in cash ovre a first mortgage of $1,650,000.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Aug. 16 A four-way tie for the series lead developed today after Norman Cressy of the Marblehead, Mass., fleet won the second race in the 110-Class national sailing championship on Long Island Sound.
NEWARK, Aug. 16 About 300 heavy-construction equipment operators walked off their jobs in various parts of the state today, shutting down work on about $100-million in construction.

YONKER,S, Aug. 16 Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Basil Kelley of Yonkers and Manchester, Vt., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Maywood Kelley, to Stephen Hughes Zeller. He is the son of Prof. and Mrs. Paul Robert Zeller of Hanover, N.H.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 16 (UPI) White collar workers took over generating plants today to keep electricity flowing to the 711,000 customers of the strike-bound Alabama Power Company.

A statement calling for the abolition of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, signed by about 40 persons, was issued yesterday at a news conference sponsored by Student Americans for Democratic Action at its office at 156 Fifth Avenue. The organization is the student branch of Americans for Democratic Action.

The assets of Webb Knapp, Inc., when the company filed for reorganization under Chapter 10 of the Bankruptcy Act in May, 1965, were $21.5-million and its liabilities were $60-million, according to a trustee's report filed in Federal Court in New York.
Frontier Airlines flew 39,720,000 revenue passenger miles in July, which was a 103 per cent increase over its July traffic last year, the carrier reported yesterday.

ABOARD THE CRUISER ST. PAUL, off South Vietnam, Aug. 15 This 17,350-ton cruiser, the last ship in the Pacific with a full complement of heavy guns, has almost as much firepower as a regiment of Army or Marine artillery.

Judge Floyd Sarisohn of Suffolk County, who is being investigated by the Appellate Division for alleged violation of judicial ethics, charged yesterday that "they are trying and convicting me in the newspapers."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 16 The Security Council turned to Secretary General Thant today to help resolve a dispute involving Britain's charge that her South Arabian protectorate was attacked by planes of the United Arab Republic operating from Yemen.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 Ninth-seeded Marilyn Aschner of Holliswood, Queens, advanced to the fourth round of the 49th annual United States girls grass court tennis championship today by defeating Ginger Pfeiffer of Springfield, Ohio, 6-2, 2-6, 6-4, at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.
A realignment of the top management of Food Fair Stores, Inc., one of the nation's largest supermarket chains, was announced yesterday at the annual meeting in Philadelphia.

New York City is still the business headquarters of the nation, but its economic, growth lags greatly behind the national average and behind that of other large cities, according to a report issued yesterday by the New York Chamber of Commerce.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 (UPI) Jack Ramsay, the head basketball coach at St. Joseph's College for the last 11 years, was named general manager of the Philadelphia 76ers in the National Basket- ball Association today.
The American Stock Exchange suffered its sharpest drop in more than two weeks yesterday.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 16 Greg Stuhler of Mount Tabor, 18-year-old son of a golf pro, led the New Jersey qualifiers for the United States Amateur with 70, 75 145. Chet Sanok, Upper Montclair, with 147, Walter Zembriski of Northwood, 149, and Ronald Goldburg, Twin Brooks, 149, were the other qualifiers over the 6,320yard, par-70 Montclair Golf Club course.

Maine potato futures soared again yesterday on very little additional news. Some traders told of torrential rains in the Red River Valley that might damage potatoes there, but other traders considered the news a little far-fetched in its effect on Eastern supplies.

Although the program for the fourth annual New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center is incomplete, there are indications that there will be no major American film among the 22 entries. The festival will be held at Philharmonic Hall Sept. 12 to 22.
Controller Mario A. Procaccino formally asked the Board of Estimate yesterday to take a step that could result in rolling back the subway fare from 20 cents to its former 15 cents.
CHEYENNE, Wyo., Aug. 16 (AP) Close races for the nominations for Governor and the state's long seat in the House of Representatives marked Wyoming's primary election to night.
Two steamship conferences operating from the United Kingdom and Ireland to the United States and Canada have announced freight rate increases of 8 and 10 per cent to become effective next Jan. 1.
BOSTON, Aug. 16 A government official called on the Administration tonight to intensify its teaching of English throughout the world as "a major goal in the conduct of its foreign policy."

MOSCOW, Aug. 16 (UPI) A Soviet military publication, Krasnaya Zvezda, said today that the Russian-built surfaceto-air missiles fired by North Vietnamese against United States planes were 100 per cent effective.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 Mr. and Mrs. Karl R. Schoettle have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Sally Ann Schoettle, to Leonard Beale Randolph, son of Mr. and Mrs. Evan Randolph.
BOLTS of fabric, rolls of ribbon and boxes of buttons the basic ingredi ents for a new fall wardrobe are arriving daily at specialty stores throughout the city.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Aug. 16 Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union won the Piatigorsky Cup Tournament here last night by winning his final match while Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn was being held to a draw by his last opponent.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UPI The House acted today to postpone until next, year a decision on building a $34-million new West Front on the Capitol.
City Council President Frank D. O'Connor said yesterday he expected a first-ballot victory in the Democratic nominating convention as a result of Senator Robert F. Kennedy's pledge of neutrality.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) The Senate Post Office and Civil Service Committee approved today a bill to liberalize rules on certain mail to and from servicemen overseas and speed outbound transportation.
Negotiations in the strike of 6,200 construction plumbers here were reported at a standstill yesterday. The various groups could not agree on a meeting time.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 Opponents of the House UnAmerican Activities Committee have confronted the Federal courts with a conflict between two fundamental tenets of American constitutional law freedom of speech and the separation of powers.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 Violence erupted briefly again tonight when civil rights demonstrators picketed real estate offices on Chicago's Northwest Side.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 16 Hirsch Jacobs doesn't drink or smoke, but his home in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, contains ash trays and a lavish bar for those who do.

BONN, Aug. 16 East German authorities have sealed off a wide area outside Oranienburg after discovering some 300 unexploded bombs buried deep at the edge of the city. The bombs were left over from a World War II air raid.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 16 (AP)--Home runs by Harmon Killebrew and Andy Kosco marked a four-run fourth inning as the Minnesota Twins beat the California Angels, 8-1, tonight.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 16 Horace Guy Crockett, former managing partner of McKinsey Co., an international management consulting concern at 270 Park Avenue, New York, died today in Mountainside Hospital at the age of 86. He lived at 117 Llewellyn Road.

GREAT NECK, L.I, Aug. 16 Miss Sondra Zena Eskow's engagement to Michael Alan Haberman has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Irving A. Eskow. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice A. Haberman of Hewlett.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 (UPI) Willie Mays tied Jimmy Foxx for second place on the career home run list tonight when he hit his 534th as Gaylord Perry won his 19th game of the season for the San Francisco Giants, a 3-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.
LONDON, Aug. 16 Two men, described as "dangerous and known to be armed," were being sought today by Scoaltnd Yard in connection with the slaying last Friday of three unarmed plainclothes policemen.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) An increase an the minimum wage from $1.25 to $1.60 an hour by 1968 with about 7.2 million more workers covered was approved today by the Senate Labor Committee.

Ollan Cassell, one of the country's top sprinters and quarter-milers for the last decade, retired from competition yesterday to accept the position of director of track and field for the Amateur Athletic Union.
Controversy over the Board of Education's procedure for channeling Federal funds to parochial schools has produced an unedifying exhibition of bureaucratic buck-passing.

Reports circulating on Wall Street yesterday that the General Motors Corporation was trimming its work force across the nation by 10 per cent were denied emphatically yesterday by both union and management officials.
The London Stock Exchange was firm yesterday. Volume remained fairly small, but buyers were encouraged by a general lack of selling and hopes that the recent technical recovery would continue.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 A Defense Department spokesman took strong exception today to suggestions that United States military forces in Vietnam were disobeying military orders.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP)--A determined effort to put Army Reservists and National Guardsmen on active duty in Vietnam got under way in the Senate today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 The Justice Department will undertake an entirely new study of the New York newspaper market in light of this week's decision to end publication of The Herald Tribune, it was learned today.

The city has been conducting a secret investigation for several months into "alleged irregularities" between landlords of rent-controlled buildings and the Rent and Rehabilitation Administration, it was disclosed yesterday.
A dismissed Brooklyn teacher who has long been an outspoken critic of the Board of Education is scheduled to be restored to his job after a two-and-a-half-year fight for reinstatement.

Members of the Subway Supervisors Association voted yesterday to authorize their executive board to call a strike against the New York City Transit Authority, with which the association has been netiating a new contract to replace one that expired June 30.
A Brooklyn civic group demanded yesterday that Mayor Lindsay dismiss two Youth Board officials who had asked the Gallo brothers to help suppress last month's racial disorders in East New York.

BOSTON, Aug. 16 (UPI) Ninth-inning home runs by John (Boog) Powell, his fourth in two games, and Bob Johnson lifted the Baltimore Orioles from a three-run deficit to a 6-4 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight.

PARIS, Aug. 16 Raymond Duncan, who like his sister Isadora was long a symbol of la vie de boheme for Americans, died Sunday evening at the home of friends in Cavalaire, on the French Riviera. He was 91 years old.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UPI) Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, demanded today that the Senate Judiciary Committee vote without delay on gun control legislation.
ALTHOUGH Bryant Park was named for a poet William Cullen Bryant there has been little poetry in its pigeon-scarred soul.
The following dispatch is by David Oancia of The Globe and Mail, Toronto.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 16 The great mines and smelters of the Zambian Copperbelt turn out 60,000 tons of refined copper a month. Until this year all of it reached the outside world by way of the Rhodesian railways.

The National Broadcasting Company, even as the Broadway stage, will present a revival of "Annie Get Your Gun." Ethel Merman will star in a 90-minute television version of the Irving Berlin musical on Sunday, March 26, at 8:30 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 A television controversy of major proportions appeared certain to develop today after the Ford Foundation and the Communications Satellite Corporation differed sharply on the future structure of satellite video.
Reginald W. Pressprich, an investment banker, died Tuesday in Carolton Hospital, Fairfield, Conn., after a long illness He was 64 years old and lived at 1185 Park Avenue.
MANHASSET, L. I., Aug. 17 Tony Vincent led the field into the semi-final round of the United States men's 35-year division clay court tennis championships today at the Shelter Rock Tennis Club.

NEW PROVIDENCE, N. J., Aug. 17 Mr. and Mrs. Lyman Badgley Coddington Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Coddington, to Charles Van Saun Boillod, son of Mrs. Charles Alfred Boillod of Cranford and the late Mr. Boillod.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 17 Mr. and Mrs. George E. Clark of Fairfield and Marion, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margery Jarvis Clark, to Bernhard John Peters, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Peters of Huntington, L. I., and Hollywood, Fla.
The Port of New York Authority brought suit yesterday against a second airline using La Guardia Airport to prevent it from landing or taking off with jets over Jackson Heights, Queens.

LONDON, Aug. 17 In a letter to Bertrand Russell, the philosopher, published today, Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union endorsed the Briton's plan to "try" President Johnson and others at a "war-crimes tribunal" in Paris this fall. Jean-Paul Sartre and Simone de Beauvoir have said they will sit on the panel.

Fourteen Puerto Rican and Negro leaders in the Brownsville-East New York section of Brooklyn, where racial fighting broke out last month, said last night the city would have to act or they could not help keep the peace.
LONDON, Aug. 17 (Reuters) Britain's index of industrial production in June was the lowest this year, and the lowest since June last year.
ATHENS, Aug. 17 The International Transport Workers Federation stepped in today to back the four-day-old Greek pilots' strike and forced Olympic Airways to call off its daily Athens-New York flight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 President Johnson applauded today the accomplishments of the Alliance for Progress and charted a bold agenda for its future, including the economic integration of the 19 countries of Latin America.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission today charged the CurtissWright Corporation of Woodridge, N. J., with monopolizing the sale and distribution of parts for its aircraft engines.
HOUSTON, Aug. 17 (UPI) Pat Jarvis, with help from Clay Carroll, held Houston to four hits tonight in pitching the Atlanta Braves to a 6-1 victory over the Astros and a sweep of the three-game series.
BETONG, Thailand, Aug. 14 Are the Communist terrorists along the Thai-Malaysian border on the verge of a new offensive?

The heads of the major American movie producing and distributing companies, which make up the Motion Picture Association of America, are being asked by Jack J. Valenti, president of the association, to consider a complete revision of the industry's self-censorship policies.
ROCHESTER, Mich., Aug. 17 The Meadow Brook Music Festival has put itself squarely on the cultural map of Michigan and now is bidding for international status.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 Attorney General Nicholas deB Katzenbach warned today that "some unpredictable event" could touch off rioting in 30 to 40 of the nation's cities. But he said that poverty and despair not Communists or black nationalists, were the villains.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 17 The 1966 greeting cards of the United Nations Children's Fund, designed by artists from 11 countries, were placed on sale today.

HONG KONG, Aug. 17 Defense Minister Lin Piao's ranking as top deputy to Mao Tsetung, chairman of the Communist party's Central Committee, was formally acknowledged by the Peking radio today when China's leaders attended a mass rally.
A dangerous drug that is being given as an alleged arthritis cure to American patients by a Mexican physician is marketed in this country by at least two drug companies.

United States department stores set a profit record last year, which topped the preceding year's levels by almost 24 per cent, according to a study released yesterday by the National Retail Merchants Association.
A microfilm system that will provide automated access to land-title records is to be installed this year in Nassau County.

BENNINGTON, Vt., Aug. 17 John Spargo, director and curator of the Bennington Museum until 1954 and a major figure in the Socialist movement early in the century, died today at his home. He was 90 years old.

The election of Norbert C. Hansen, John L. Sowarby and Richard L. Tauber as vice presidents of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York was announced yesterday by Thomas S. Gates, chairman. All were formerly assistant vice presidents.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17--George Meany urged the membership of the striking International Association of Machinists today to ratify the union's new labor contract with five major airlines.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 17 Dennis Ralston, Arthur Ashe and Cliff Richey of the United States Davis Cup team reached the quarter-final round of the Newport Tennis Hall of Fame invitation tournament today at the Casino.
The Federated Metals division of the American Refining and Smelting Company has reduced prices 1 to 2 cents a pound on brass and bronze ingots because of lower scrap costs, it announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) Robert M. Ball, commissioner of Social Security, announced today that teams of experts were visiting hospitals in major cities to observe Medicare in operation and to ease the paper work.
Federal narcotics agents captured five alleged heroin pushers in a brief gunfight last night after three of them robbed an agent who had made a date to buy heroin from them.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 17 The engagement of Miss Gail E. Alexander to Kalman Mark Carmel has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Sidney G. Alexander, parents of the Future bride. Mr. Carmel is the son of Mr. and Mrs. David B. Carmel of Scarsdale.

TORONTO, Aug. 17 (Canadian Press) K. R. Thomson, chairman and president of Thomson Newspapers, Ltd., will be elected soon to the board of the Thomson Organization, Ltd., London-based company that directs the widespread overseas operations of the interests of the Thomson family.

VIENNA, Aug. 17 Nicolai Ghiaurov, Anna Moffo and Nicolai Gedda have signed contracts for an AmericanBulgarian film version of Gounod's opera "Faust." The film is scheduled to be released in New York before Christmas, 1967.
A sales agent who said her income last year was $82,000 was arrested yesterday on charges of having offered a $400 bribe to an Internal Revenue Service agent.

The latest worry to beset the World Trade Center and its sponsor, the Port of New York Authority, is that the center's construction will set "ghosts" walking across television screens in the metropolitan area.

A recovery movement in the final hour of trading partially offset early losses in the stock market yesterday. Leading market averages finished the session with moderate losses, bringing them to new lows for the year.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP) A Negra youth charged with attacking a white soldier aboard a subway train to the accompaniment of cheers from many other passengers was sentenced to 15 months in the Cook County jail today.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 17--Chester Bowles, the United States Ambassador, made a strong sales pitch today to win Indian support for the war effort in Vietnam.

Henry B. Kennedy, who retired in 1964 as vice president of the Frank G. Shattuck Company after 38 years with the concern, died Tuesday in Buck Hill Falls, Pa., after a short illness. He was 68 years old.
Dr. Joseph V. Sullivan, a radiologist for St. John's and Flushing Hospitals, died on Monday in his home at 156-11 Oak Avenue in Flushing, Queens, His age was 60.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 17 An agreement providing for a $70-million commodity loan by the United States to Pakistan was signed today in Rawalpindi.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) J. Clark Salyer, widely credited in conservation circles with developing the national wildlife refuge system, died in his sleep yesterday, his 64th birthday. Death apparently resulted from a heart attack.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 17 A gunman hijacked early today a tractor-trailer loaded with more than 1,500 cases of soap and soap products valued at $11,500. Two companions whisked away the driver, leaving him handcuffed and trussed up in a weedy area.
DUNKIRK, N. Y., Aug. 17 Frank D. O'Connor, jubilantly confident of the Democratic nomination for Governor, virtually ignored his party rivals today and opened his attack on Governor Rockefeller

LEXINGTON, Mass., Aug. 17 Mr. and Mrs. John Fletcher Rich have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Dudley Rich, to Mehmet Rona, son of Mrs. Hikmet Rona of Istanbul, Turkey, and the late Mr. Rona.
A call for a City Council investigation into the adequacy of fire protection here was sounded yesterday by Mrs. Aileen B. Ryan, Bronx Council man-at-Large.

A group of Harlem civic and community leaders asked yesterday that State Controller Arthur Levitt hold public hearings within two weeks on the feasibility of constructing a proposed state office building in Harlem.
LANSING, Mich., Aug. 17 (UPI) Gov. George Romney put on a cowboy hat and strolled down the street with a movie star today, officially beginning his campaign for a third term.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) President Johnson defended the Central Intelligence Agency today as he decorated Adm. William F. Raborn Jr., who recently retired as the agency's director.
VERONA, Pa., Aug. 17 Kathleen Ahern of Dallas and Shelley Hamlin of Fresno, Calif., the favorites, led the way into the second round of United States girls' junior golf championship today.
TOKYO, Aug. 17 With a critical national election approaching, Japan's Government has again deferred a reform of the widely criticized election system.

The demonstrations led by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King in Chicago have dramatically underscored that there is a "white noose" around the center of than Midwest city, just as there is in New York and most other metropolitan areas. The all-white neighborhoods in any city's outlying sections and in the suburbs where Negroes find it impossible to buy or rent property are an affront to basic American principles of equality of opportunity.

Three dissident directors of the Reading Company have reinstated a law suit they suspended 14 months ago that would prevent the Baltimore Ohio Railroad from voting its holding of 38.26 per cent of the voting securities of the Reading.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange declined yesterday under the influence of a number of adverse factors.
Acquisition of a substantial interest in Best Co. may ultimately end a year-long search by S. Klein's Department Stores for a new name.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., Aug. 17 "Eight years ago," said Jack Twyman today, "Maurice Stokes was dead. Now he's going to get better because he has amazing desire. He doesn't feel sorry for himself. He feels that what happened happened. He's going to beat this thing. I really believe that."

ATLANTA, Aug. 17 (AP) Traffic Judge Herschel Cole said today he had disposed of charges against a worker for the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee who was involved in a confrontation between Negroes and whites.

THE English cocker spaniel is an attractive, merry sporting dog. Larger than his American cousin (he stands 15 to 17 inches at the shoulder, compared with 14 -15 ), he also has a longer muzzle, more deeply recessed eyes and a less profuse coat. His gait is powerful and smooth.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 17 Senator Robert F. Kennedy and Secretary General Thant talked privately tonight about the prospects of finding a peaceful settlement of the Vietnamese war.
The Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union agreed yesterday that bus riders could use subway tokens as fares on 74 bus lines where they are not used now.

STRATFORD, Ont., Aug. 17 New full-evening ballets are rare enough anywhere to make their production always something of an event, but the first full-evening Canadian ballet, with Canadian choreography, music, designs and theme, was a particularly interesting possibility. The Royal Winnipeg Ballet's new work, "Rose Latulippe," had its first performance at the Avon Theater here last night, and marked the first venture of the Stratford Festival into ballet.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 17 (AP) Don Mincher's tworun single in the eighth inning sparked a three-run rally that lifted the Minnesota Twins to a 5-3 victory over the California Angels tonight.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 17--The Finance Minister, Dr. Eben Donges, told South Africans today there would be a 5 per cent increase on personal income tax and higher duties on liquor, cigarettes, gasoline, automobiles and other luxury goods, to provide the necessary funds for South Africa to "withstand any military or economic onslaught from any quarter."

Albert and Lawrence Gallo, the brothers linked with organized crime in Brooklyn who were credited with easing racial tensions there last month, have refused to meet today with District Attorney Aaron E. Koota of Brooklyn in response to his request.
The Transit Authority has rescinded a May 1 order that all uniformed members of its police force wear Sam Browne belts.
MINEOLA, L. I., Thursday, Aug. 18 Mr. O'Connor received today the pledged support of 66 of Nassau County's 80 delegates to the convention.
A Federal Court injunction against the sale and distribution of a recently published biography of Howard Hughes, the elusive financier, was lifted yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.

PARIS, Aug. 17 (Reuters) The Tour de France, the world's longest and toughest cycling race, will revert to being an international event with competing national teams in 1967, the organizers announced here today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 15 Shadowy figures raced shouting down Tu Do Street last midnight, but the American military police patrol cruised past them without even a sideward glance.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 17 Bobby Ussery came back to the races with an impact today. Out of action since June 25 because of injury, the popular jockey steered Herbert Allen's Favorable Turn to victory in the $33,150 Saratoga Special.
Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus, who teamed up to win the Canada Cup in golf in 1963 and 1964, were named yesterday to represent the United States in this year's tournament Nov. 10 to 13 at Tokyo.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 17 Prof. Edgar S. Furniss Jr., professor of political science and director of the Mershon Social Science program at Ohio State University since 1963, died here today at Riverside Hospital of complications following an operation. He was 48 years old.
DALLAS, Aug. 17 Air Force planes will begin spraying this city of more than 800,000 at dawn Friday to combat an encephalitis epidemic traced to the Culex mosquito.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 17 Exhibitionist took the lead at the halfway mark with $225,000, but Admiring swept past him in the stretch and topped the auction on a worldrecord bid of $310,000.

The presiding justice of the Appellate Division said yesterday that ethics charges against Judge Floyd Sarisohn of Suffolk County were "not at all related to Judge Sarisohn's socalled bail reform or other reform programs."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 A lawyer for subpoenaed witnesses was forcibly ejected from a Congressional hearing on antiVietnam war activities today in another riotous session of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 17 The United Nations has told Israel and Syria that they must agree on salvage procedures in the Sea of Galilee before United Nations observers will be sent to the scene.

ASPEN, Colo., Aug. 17 Moses Hadas, one of the world's foremost classical scholars and Jay Professor of Greek at Columbia University, died here early today apparently of a heart attack. He was 66 years old.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 A 10hour, top-level meeting of city, real estate and civil rights leaders failed today to reach an agreement that would end marches for open housing that have brought repeated violence to Chicago.
The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York yesterday appointed Allan D. Emil as campaign chairman of its 1966-67 fund appeal. The drive will begin Sept. 21.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 When Joe Pool of Dallas first ran for the Texas Legislature back in 1952, he handed out fans emblazoned, "Keep Cool With Pool." He has been handing them out in every campaign since. "They're popular with the churches, farmers and the Latin Americans ...

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 17 About 2,000 anti-Communist students hurled insults and boos at President Sukarno today as he upheld his belief in a blending of nationalism, religion and Communism as "an absolutely essential element for the reconstruction of the Indonesian nation."
PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 17 Flight controllers here began sending tonight the final commands for Lunar Orbiter 1 to take its first pictures of the moon tomorrow.
OTTAWA, Aug. 17 Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson said today he expected Vietnam would be among the subjects he would discuss with President Johnson on Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UPI) The Senate passed and sent to the White House today legislation to combat the theft of pets and provide humane treatment for animals used in research.

Millions of people living along the main rail routes between Fort Worth, Tex., and New York were cautioned yesterday to look out for a small silvery capsule containing 300 milligrams of radium that could be "highly dangerous" to anyone handling it.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 17 Five years after the United States and 19 Latin-American countries agreed at Punta del Este, Uruguay, to work together for accelerated economic development and social reform in the Alliance for Progress, the prevalent view of responsible Latin-American leaders is that:

Prices for August and September soybeans surged yesterday to new life-of-contract highs. The climb was so vigorous that for a while during the trading session it ran up the 10-cents-a-bushel daily permissible limit.

YONKERS, Aug. 17 Even though Bret Hanover will not be within 200 miles of the track, a win-betting-only race will feature tomorrow night's harness racing card at Yonkers Raceway. It will be the mile-and-aquarter Bye Bye Byrd Free-forAll Pace, a handicap for a purse of $25,000, with post positions assigned by Ted Gibbons, the racing secretary, on the basis of a horse's consistent speed.
LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 16--It is the general belief here that President Kenneth Kaunda will soon take Zambia out of the British Commonwealth.
NORTHPORT, L. I., Aug. 17 Charles Rogers of San Diego took over the undisputed series lead today in the 110 Class national sailing championship by capturing the third race.
Huntington Hartford gave the old Metropolitan Opera House a $100,000 reprieve yesterday, thereby gaining time for the next step in the legal battle to save the 83-year-old building.
Patty Duke, who won an Oscar for her part in "The Miracle Worker," will not appear in "My Sweet Charlie," David Westheimer's dramatization of his novel.
Thirteen Jersey City men and women were arrested last night when they refused to end a sit-in at regional headquarters here of the Federal Office of Economic Opportunity.
LONDON, Aug. 17--Andre Prokovsky, one of the New York City Ballet's principal dancers, returned tonight as guest artist to the company in which he began his career, the Festival Ballet.
The 814 subway cars of the IND line that runs through Queens are suffering from old age, and mounting mechanical breakdowns are causing increasing delays in service.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 17 Dr. Garrett De Nyse Duryea, a physician and staff member of Community Hospital for 40 years, died there last night after an operation for a malignant brain tumor. He would have been 68 years old on Thursday. His home was at 30 Landing Road.
It now seems apparent, even to those who may view the prospect with gloom, that the Liberal party will run its own candidate for Governor this year.
The nation's electric power production rose 8.3 per cent in the week ended Aug. 13, from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.

"CHEESE in Family Meals," United States Depart ment of Agriculture Home and Garden bulletin No. 112, tells how to select cheese that will appeal to individual palates, how to store cheese, serve it and cook it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 A forecast that economic growth would slow next year and that inflationary pressures, while still "troublesome," would decrease, was made today by the Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs, William H. Shaw.

SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio, Aug. 17 Mr. and Mrs. Hyman D. Wilkoff have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Leslie Ann Wilkoff, to Louis Richard Schaul. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Charles Schaul.
BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 17 Mario Savio, main leader of the 1964-65 student revolt on the University of California campus here, today was refused readmission as a student.

PORT CHICAGO, Calif., Aug. 17 (UPI) Marines dragged and shoved demonstrators off a county road in front of the Concord Naval Weapons Station today when they tried to prevent trucks loaded with napalm from entering the base.

Leo M. Patton of 1 Fifth Avenue has announced the engagement of his niece, Miss Jane Patton, to Wilson Jenkins Browning Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Browning of Norfolk, Va. The wedding is planned for the winter.
The New York and the American Stock Exchange reported yesterday changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

BOSTON, Aug. 17 Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America, adopted today a budget of some $10million to maintain and extend its network of social service and medical institutions in Israel and for its activities in this country.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Aug. 18--A United States Marine jet taking off from the Danang air base plunged into a village at the south end of the main runway yesterday, killing 26 Vietnamese civilians and injuring about 15 as it flattened huts.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 17 (UPI) Mooring Stable's Tempt Me Not overtook Am Liberal in the stretch today and won the feature race at the Atlantic City track by threequarters of a length.

KANO, Nigeria, Aug. 17 Anxious over their safety and fearful of the future, the more than 300,000 Ibos who live here in the vast Moslem North have begun a mass exodus to their Eastern Region homeland.
The league-leading Pittsburgh Pirates haven't been losing many baseball games these days especially to the New York Mets.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 17 Patrick A. Bolger, a lawyer specializing in real property valuation, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 119 Pondfield Road West. He maintained an office at 160 Broadway in New York.
"TRIPS for Children," a 62-page illustrated book let listing 156 trips in and around New York, has been published by the Play Schools Association.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Aug. 17 (AP) A 26-year-old, 250pound former labor leader held a 149-vote lead for the Democratic nomination for Wyoming's lone seat in Congress tonight with only three scattered remote precints unreported after yesterday's primary race ...
MONTICELLO, N. Y., Aug. 17 The West coached by Alex Hannum, defeated the East, coached by Red Auerbach, 7572, tonight in the eighth annual Maurice Stokes all-star benefit basketball game.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 The New China News Agency reports that "millions of Chinese people, responding to the call of their great leader, Mao Tsetung, are flocking to the seacoast, rivers and lakes to swim in rough waters."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 The Johnson Administration backed down today on its long-standing proposal to increase the tax on airline passenger tickets from 5 to 6 per cent.
PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 17 A new Pioneer scientific satellite was launched into interplanetary space today to study the supersonic winds and deadly cosmic rays emanating from the sun.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP) Bill Skowron hit a three-run homer in the first game and John Romano and Tommie Agee belted homers in the finale as the Chicago White Sox won a double-header from the Kansas City Athletics, 4-2 and 5-1, tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 The Federal Reserve Board moved today to make money even tighter than it is.
The bond market slumped again yesterday, depressed by the general increase to 6 per cent in the prime interest rate charged by major commercial banks.
A major police campaign to recruit Negroes and Puerto Ricans is under Way at beaches, baseball games, jazz concerts and movie theaters.
RIVERSIDE, Calif., Aug. 17 (AP)--Ken Miles, a sports car driver, was killed instantly today when a new Formula J. Ford he was testing went out of control and crashed at Riverside Raceway.
KINSHASA, the Congo, Aug. 17 (Reuters) The Congolese Government has told Union Miniere du Haut Katanga, the Belgian copper company, to consult it before making any future changes in copper prices.
CHARLES HOWARD was suddenly discharged as a security risk. In a blackhumored fury, he decided to show that the privileged undergrounders who got him sacked were not above suspicion.
Richard C. Jacobs, former president of a mutual fund, was indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of embezzling $69,000 from the fund through "sham" transactions in 1963.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 17 (AP) Two small girls scored upsets today in the Essex invitation women's tennis tournament, toppling the sixthseeded player, Gail Sheriff of Austraila and eight-seeded Tory Fretz of Los Angeles.
Three streets in lower Manhattan on which Dutch and Huguenot settlers once drove their carriages may be eliminated to make way for two office buildings.
MYSTIC, Conn.--Although the Burton Moores of Mystic have a kitchen that measures 3 feet by 4 feet, there is probably no one in Connecticut with a more interesting and varied bill of fare.
The health of this hemisphere is the business of the house in which we are assembled this morning to celebrate the fifth anniversary of the Alliance for Progress.
It is obvious that the American Can Company makes cans. What is considerably less obvious is that the company makes other things as well.

TRENTON, Aug. 17 A spokesman for the cemetery forces in New Jersey accused the state's undertakers today of preying on the sudden grief of survivors and using Madison Avenue gimmicks in trying to sell expensive coffins.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17 The McCone Commission reported today that there had been extensive progress in the Negro district of Watts since the riots of a year ago, but it said that along with other parts of the country, Watts needed a greatly expanded effort to alleviate racial problems.
To introduce its new Private Label collection, Bon wit Teller held a frozen fashion show on Tuesday night and a lot of people were fooled.

A 22-year-old man stood in Bronx Criminal Court yesterday, accused of introducing three boys aged 13, 14, 15 to the use of heroin and a life of crime a burglary ring broken up by Bronx detectives on Monday.
The General Electric Company and the independent United Electrical Workers Union began contract negotiations yesterday.
OLD SAYBROOK, Conn. Aug. 17 (UPI) A 55-foot cabin cruiser and a fishing boat Collided and sank in Long Island Sound today. One of four persons aboard the two boats was injured.
Otis Redding, one of the more volcanic rhythm-and-blues stars, erupted in two concerts last night at the Rheingold Central Park Music Festival.

Knut Hammarskjold, director general of the International Air Transport Association, is seeking to have airlines end a policy of silence they have imposed on the meeting of the agency in Honolulu next month.
PARIS, Aug. 17 (UPI) Andre LeFebre de Laboulaye, former Ambassador to the United States, died here today at the age of 90.

Mrs. Eva Hampton Willis of Columbia, S. C., and Harold B. Willis Jr. of Weston, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Fleming Hampton Willis, to Kirkman Finlay Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Finlay of Columbia.
JAMESBURG, N. J., Aug. 17 Warren W. Wilentz, the Senate candidate of New Jersey's Democratic party leaders, called tonight for direct peace negotiations with the Vietcong.
A libel suit brought by a teacher against the publisher of his brother's first novel was reinstated yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.

ABINGTON, Pa., Aug. 17 Miss Joan Kathryn Diesinger daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Diesinger Jr. of Jenkintown, was married today to Herbert Edward Hendriks Jr. son of Mr. and Mrs. Hendriks of Mount Vernon, Iowa.
Negotiations continued yesterday in the dispute between The World Journal Tribune, Inc., and 10 newspaper unions.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 17 (AP) Leon Wagner hit a three-run homer in the seventh inning tonight to lift the Cleveland Indians to a 5-3 victory over the Washington Senators.
Interest rates rose sharply yesterday throughout the money market in the wake of the increase on Tuesday in the prime, or minimum business lending, rate to 6 per cent, the highest since the 1920's.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 The United Automobile Workers Union has asked the nation's three big auto makers to raise wages of skilled workers 50 cents an hour, even though present labor contracts have another year to run.
BOSTON, Aug. 17 (AP) Luis Aparicio collected five hits and Frank Robinson collected three and batted in two runs today to lead the Baltimore Orioles to an 8-4 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Aug. 17 Mr. and Mrs. William Henry McCarthy Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Elizabeth McCarthy of Cambridge, Mass., to Henry Bell Laidlaw 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. Laidlaw.
The Union Commerce Bank of Cleveland announced yesterday the election of Joseph B. Roberts as senior vice president and Frederick C. Rueckert as a vice president.
The American Stock Exchange took its second consecutive beating yesterday with 448 issues declining. Only 140 issues managed to advance and 244 ended unchanged.

PARIS, Aug. 17 (UPI) A Paris newspaper today attacked William Benton, United States Ambassador to the United Nations Educational, Social and Cultural Organization, for suggesting a campaign to make English an international language.
Indonesia will rejoin the United Nations as soon as the "green light" is given by President Sukarno, Indonesia's Ambassador to Washington, L. N. Palar, said yesterday.

THE Bankers League of New York is not restricted to wizards of finance. Exactly half the 26 teams in the 1965-66 event represented companies in other spheres of activity, and the winner of the six-team round-robin final last month was the squad representing Equitable Life Assurance Society.
Derelicts who can no longer get themselves arrested on the Bowery for such causes as public intoxication or vagrancy will find the police more accommodating at the city's parks and beaches.

Officials of parochial schools in New York threatened the Board of Education yesterday with a demand for a Congressional investigation of the proposed use of Federal funds for disadvantaged children in public and nonpublic schools here.

The Administration's long over-reliance on monetary policy as a brake on the boom has brought the fight against inflation to a critical pass. The rise in the prime bank-lending rate to 6 per cent, the highest level in four decades, is coupled with insistent evidence that even the tightest of tight money will not end the wild scramble for business loans and the instability it brings to the whole economy.
EDWARDS, Miss., Aug. 17 (AP) Mayor C.E. Robbins says he fears half the stores here will be "locked up in two weeks" if a Negro boycott does not end.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17 (AP) Leo Cardenas hit a three-run double in the fourth inning, spoiling ailing Sandy Koufax's bid for his 20th victory and sparking Cincinnati to a 5-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight.
The spot rate on the British pound was lower in dull trading here yesterday. The currency closed at $2,7886, down 6 points from Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) Committee action on a bill to control gun sales was blocked today and Senator Russell B. Long of Louisiana, acting Democratic leader, predicted that no legislation would be passed this year.
The city's Health Services Administrator and the Commissioner of Public Works will leave Saturday on a 10-day tour of eight European cities to study hospital architecture.

BORIS SPASSKY of the Soviet Union, the recent challenger for the world chess title who finished in first place in the Piatigorsky Cup Tournament, found in Berit Larsen of Denmark a dangerous and imaginative foe.
ROME, Aug. 17--Pope Paul VI heralded today the beginning of a "new and great legislative period of the church" in which the work of the Ecumenical Council from 1962 to 1965 would be put into effect.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 The new study by the Department of Justice of the relation of the antitrust laws to the New York City newspaper situation is a perfect example of the gross inequality of these statutes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 Higher interest rates in this country attracted a large volume of foreign investment in the second quarter of this year, thus significantly improving the United States balance of international payments, the Commerce and Treasury Departments reported today.

WASHINGTON Aug. 17 (AP)--Senator James O. Eastland, Democrat of Mississippi, introduced today amendments to the civil rights bill to provide for injunctions against demonstrations that interfere with the use of private and public property.
DETROIT, Aug. 17 The New York Yankees ended three undistinguished days in Detroit tonight by losing their third straight game to the Tigers.
HENRIETTA, N. Y., Aug. 17 Proudly and persistently, Gov ernor Rockefeller told today about his Medicaid program, a touchy topic that he had been warned to avoid among conservative upstaters.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. The Export-Import Bank announced today a new program of discounting export loans held by banks.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 Senator J.W. Fulbright suggested today that newspapers and correspondents who accepted Government transportation to Vietnam might be in a conflict of interest with their readers.

Jervis Langdon, chairman and president of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad, told the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday that for the second half of 1966 the road's earnings from operations would probably be "close to the break-even point."
OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 17 (UPI) A homemade bomb was found today in a filing cabinet at the headquarters building of nearby Offutt Air Force Base command post of the Strategic Air Command.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Tuesday the level it reached on Monday, which was 111.7.
NEWARK, Ohio, Aug. 17 (AP)--The bodies of four executives and the pilot of their chartered plane were found today near Hebron where the twin-engine Cessna 310 crashed on a flight to Chattanooga.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 South Africa complained today that "unwarranted pressure" had been brought by the United States against her policies in South-West Africa.
GLENDALE, Calif., Aug. 17 (AP) Two workers found a radioactive vial on a lot and were hurried to a hospital today, city civil defense reported.
QUEBEC, Aug. 17 (Canadian Press) Activity at the port of Quebec was back to normal today with the return to work of 160 freight-handlers who walked off the job Monday.
HENRY WARD BEECHER, one of the spell binders of the 19th century lecture circuit, once said that if men "wore black feathers and wings, very few of them would be clever enough to be crows."

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that outstanding bankers dollar acceptances fell $51-million in July to a total of $3,369,000,000. The drop followed a gain of $2-million in June, but the total was $32-million above the July, 1965, figure.

Frank H. McConnell, editor of the American Stock Exchange magazine, American Investor, died Tuesday at Beekman-Downtown Hospital after a heart attack. He was 71 years old and lived at 35-10 150th Street, Flushing, Queens.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17 (AP) Willie Mays became the greatest right-handed home-run hitter in baseball history today, belting his 535th homer as the San Francisco Giants downed the St. Louis Cardinals, 4-3, on a pinch-hit single by Jesus Alou in the ninth inning.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 The House passed an automo- bile safety bill today requiring Federal safety standards for 1968 model cars, buses and trucks. The roll-call vote was 371 to 0.
LONDON, Aug. 17 (UPI) United States marksmen were the top scorers today, with 3,070 points, at the end of the third small-arms competition for forces of the Central Treaty Organization.
Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving and Huntington Hartford met yesterday in a radio debate on the question:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration began action today to remove Measurin, a time-release aspirin tablet, from the market.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to empower the President to call up reservists who have completed their required six months of training, but who have not had other active duty. The measure could affect at least 250,000 and possibly 500,000 men.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 17 Miss Kathy Ann Pett's engagement to Robert William Harpster, son of Mr. and Mrs. Doyle E. Harpster of Washington, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Saul Pett.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 17 Miss Lucina Hilton Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Frederick Betts Johnson Jr. of Greenwich and Edgartown, Mass., plans to be married in December to Geoffrey Scott Thompson.

Sales and earnings of the Consolidated Foods Corporation set records for the 11th consecutive year, Nathan Cummings, chairman, and William Howlett, president, reported yesterday in the annual statement covering the year to June 30.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17 (AP) Stephen Smale did not make it to the hearing of the House Committee on Un-American Activities to testify about his campaign against the Vietnam war.

BLUEFIELD, W. Va., Aug. 17 Dr. and Mrs. Wade Hampton St. Clair have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Archer St. Clair of New York, to Thomas Biddle Harvey Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey of Philadelphia.

Operators of two Greenwich Village coffeehouses were given summonses early yesterday for providing musical entertainment without licenses licenses they cannot obtain under existing zoning regulations.

SEA CLIFF, L. I., Aug. 18 Pending the outcome of numerous protests two Cedar Point Yacht Club craft from Westport, Conn., shared the lead after two races in the Atlantic Class national sailing championship today on Long Island Sound. Thirty sloops are competing.
The Department of Traffic ruled yesterday against permitting motorcycles to be parked at an angle to the curb instead of parallel, as presently required.

The contention of many police officials and prosecutors that confessions are the backbone of law enforcement has been challenged by a survey of about 4,000 felony cases made by the district attorney of Los Angeles County. The office is reported to have the largest caseload in the nation.
