MEXICO CITY, Aug. 18 (Reuters) The newly appointed director of Mexico's National University Law School resigned today, a week after he had been pelted with tomatoes by students.

TOKYO, Aug. 18 (UPI) North Vietnam denounced its Asian neighbors today for a proposal for an all-Asia peace conference to end the war in Vietnam. It termed the suggestion by Malaysia, Thailand and the Philippines "shop-worn merchandise" from President Johnson's "clique."

GREAT NECK, L. I., Aug. 18 In Temple Israel here this afternoon, Miss Deborah Nora Zavon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norton E. Zavon, became the bride of Paul M. Ehrlich, son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard I. Ehrlich of Kings Point and East Hampton. Rabbi Mordecai Waxman, assisted by Cantor Benjamin Siegel, performed the ceremony.

MIAMI, Aug. 18 (UPI) A criminal court judge has dismissed charges involving a check that were lodged against Michael Doud Gill, a nephew of Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower, who has been directing the salvage of Spanish treasure from a sunken ship in the Bahamas.

Persons eligible for Medicaid were advised yesterday by the city's chief health officer to consider dropping their private insurance and Medicare medical insurance "in a few months, when we see how Medicaid is getting along."
A Brooklyn grand jury will investigate the use of the Gallo brothers by the city in easing racial tensions in East New York last month, District Attorney Aaron E. Koota announced yesterday.

The Interracial Council for Business Opportunity, a volunteer group of business executives, has called a meeting of Harlem businessmen in an attempt to set up a Junior Achievement operation in Harlem.

LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 18 (AP) Don Schollander, who won four gold medals in the 1964 Olympics, regained his world 400-meter free-style record with a time of 4 minutes 11.6 seconds as two world marks were broken and another equaled tonight in 10 events at the opening session of the 16th National Amateur Athletic Union swimming and diving championships.
The Transit Authority and three unions representing its 3,200 supervisory employes reached tentative agreement last night on a two-year contract calling for a 15 per cent pay increase in three steps.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 A tripartite Presidential committee called today for a more flexible wage-price policy that would be shaped jointly by it and the Administration.

"I think the market is terribly oversold. We're in the process of making a bottom here. I've been a buyer the last two or three days. I'm completely invested. But I was extremely light the middle of last week."
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) A Federal grand jury indicted a former Chicago policeman and two other men today on charges of interstate travel in aid of racketeering.

TORONTO, Aug. 18 The Bell Telephone Company of Canada, expressing concern at foreign take-overs of Canadian telephone companies, announced today a $58-million stock offer for control of major telephone systems in the Maritime Provinces.
LONDON, Aug. 18--Zambia has joined Malaysia in cutting her links with sterling.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP)--A House Agriculture subcommittee dealt a blow today to a proposed supplemental financing plan for rural electric and telephone systems.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) The House passed legislation today designed to promote highway safety by helping states set up programs for vehicle inspection, driving training and accident prevention.
LOOKING like bits of the Parthenon transmuted, occasional tables shaped like columns have been showing up in increasing numbers recently in department stores.

Without getting its pontoons wet, a Coast Guard amphibious plane from Floyd Bennett Field took the sea's temperature yesterday and, in a high-flying census of marine life along the New Jersey coast, counted:

The International Harvester Company announced yesterday it had raised prices an average of 2.7 per cent on heavy-duty trucks to "offset increased labor and material costs." It also reported record sales and earnings for the three-month and nine-month periods ended July 31.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 The Federal Reserve Board intends to let bank credit already the tightest in almost 40 years get far tighter.

The cross-country hunt for a lethal capsule of radium lost in shipment between Fort Worth, Tex., and Woodside, Queens, led Geiger-counter teams yesterday through tunnels and railroad yards, and over bridges and truck routes.
JERSEY CITY, Aug. 18 The police here were investigating today the theft of a tractor-trailer containing 26,000 pounds of frozen shrimp.

LONDON, Aug. 18 (AP) The Methodist Church opened a World Council meeting tonight with a call from its president, Bishop Fred Pierce Corson of Philadelphia, for steady and careful progress toward a universal church.

The Household Finance Corporation reported yesterday a net income in the first half of $23,828,006, equal after preferred dividend requirements to $1.03 a share. In the corresponding period of last year, net income totaled $22,410,374, or 93 cents a share, after giving effect to a two-for-one stock split last April 18.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 111.1 on Wednesday from 111.7 on Tuesday.
VERONA, Pa., Aug. 18 Kathleen Ahern of the Dallas Athletic Club was the only favorite to advance to the semifinal round in the 18th annual. United States girls junior golf championship today.

Although Mayor Lindsay tried to do away with the city's Division of Veterans Affairs, the veterans' lobby prevailed upon the City Council and Board of Estimate to restore its budget, and the Mayor gave in.
ATLANTA, Aug. 18 (AP) Negro pickets shouting "Black power!" tried to storm an Army induction center today and fought a brief battle with the police.

WOODMERE, L. I., Aug. 18 Mr. and Mrs. Charles Ratner have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Rosalie Ratner, to Jerome Saul Leiken. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Leiken of Hewlett Harbor.
Many issues on the American Stock Exchange fell sharply yesterday as the list retreated on a broad front.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 18 Two Long Island teen-age sailors, John Nicholson of Manhasset Bay Yacht Club and Rick Farmer of Knickerbocker Yacht Club, won divisions of the Lightning Class championships of junior race week today as the three-day regatta on Long Island Sound concluded off American Yacht Club.

Louis Abolafia, an artist who proposes himself as a candidate for Governor, thinks that the cause of beauty and culture would be helped if New York had a younger man in the Executive Mansion, specifically himself. But there is a hitch.

ALTAVISTA, Va., Aug. 18 (UPI) Nine persons were killed and 32 injured in the collision early today of a Trailways bus and a tractortrailer. The bus was on its way from Tallahassee, Fla., to New York City.
Money managers at the nation's banks were evidently squeezed tighter in a money vise in the week ended Wednesday.

Mayor Lindsay walked briskly through parts of the Brownsville-East New York section of Brooklyn yesterday and left in his wake many strong and divergent opinions about the value of his trip to this area of racial tension.

LEE, Mass., Aug. 18 Take a smattering of modern dance, a something of classic ballet, add a dash of ethnic dance, and there you have a recipe for the program-building at Ted Shawn's Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival. The balance of the ingredients varies a great deal, but the basic combination remains the same.
PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 18 (UPI) The Pioneer 7 satellite sped along to its orbit of the sun today, exploring the perils of interplanetary travel.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 Patti Hogan of La Jolla, Calif., advanced to the semi-final round of the 49th annual United States girls' grass court tennis championships today by defeating Vicky Rogers of Rye, N. Y., 3-6, 6-1, 6-2, at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

A Federal judge ordered the General Electric Company yesterday to bargain with a negotiating committee of the International Union of Electrical Workers that includes representatives of seven other unions.

Radial-ply tires, long known to be safer and longer wearing, will be introduced as standard equipment on one Ford Motor Company model and will be optional on other lines for 1967, the company said yesterday. Ford had declined to discuss the matter heretofore.
NEWTON, N. J., Aug. 18 (AP) Maj. Obadiah P. Armstrong, retired, a hero of both World Wars, died yesterday in a nursing home. He was 73 years old.
LONDON, Aug. 18 The manhunt for the last of three men wanted in the slaying of three London policemen concentrated today on Epping Forest a few miles northeast of here.

FOR slightly more than four years, from May, 1961, to June, 1965, Stanley Edgar Hyman wrote the best regular book review column in the United States. The column appeared in The New Leader, a biweekly journal of political and cultural opinion which, during this period, achieved an influential position among American magazines ...
PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 18 A United States spacecraft sent to earth today the first pictures of the moon's surface taken from a vehicle in lunar orbit.

The marriage of Miss Joan Ann Kennedy, daughter of Mrs. Francis P. Kennedy of Arlington, N. J., and the late Mr. Kennedy, to George Goldman took place here last evening. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham S. Goldman of New York. Rabbi Judah Kahn performed the ceremony at the Hampshire House.
Mrs. Martha Blau was walking along Seventh Avenue yesterday when who should come by at 38th Street but her old neighbor, Louis J. Lefkowitz.

HONG KONG, Aug. 18 (Reuters) The Vietcong have welcomed Bertrand Russell's proposal to set up an international tribunal to "try" United States leaders for "war crimes" and will supply witnesses and material evidence, the North Vietnamese press agency reported today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 The president of the striking International Association of Machinists predicted today that the union members would approve a new labor contract with five airlines tomorrow.

YONKERS, Aug. 18 Those skeptics who had been hinting that the 10-year-old New Zealand-bred Cardigan Bay was "over the hill" had to change their thinking, following the gelding's hard-earned victory in the $25,000 Bye Bye Byrd freefor-all pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
Following in the shadow of Wall Street, prices on Canadian stock markets took another battering yesterday.
Mrs. Adele Ansbacher Jacobs, the widow of Ralph J. Jacobs, head of a stock brokerage concern on Wall Street, died yesterday at her home, 850 Park Avenue. She was 93 years old.
The Kroll Quartet and Arthur Balsam, pianist, offered an evening of comfortable music-making last night in the Mozart Festival concert at Philharmonic Hall.
Ellis Leach, chairman of the Collins Aikman Company, will retire on Oct. 5, after 45 years in the textile industry. He will continue as a director and will serve in an advisory capacity.

TOKYO, Aug. 18 Ambassador Edwin O. Reischauer told the Japanese today that their highly industrialized and fully democratic country was destined to exert an "infinitely" greater influence on Asia than a "backward" Communist China.
LONDON, Aug. 18 (AP) A guidebook to the lavatories and powder rooms of Paris went on sale today for the equivalent of 50 cents.
The eighth-place New York Mets scored their 53d victory yesterday at Shea Stadium. They beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 9-5, despite four home runs by the losers.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 18 A horse that was as strong a favorite in the feature race as one of his owners used to be when he was the most effective member of the pitching staff of the New York Yankees, contributed a victorious performance today at Saratoga.

BARRE, Vt., Aug. 18 Dr. D. C. Jarvis of this community, author of the best-selling book "Folk Medicine: A Vermont Doctor's Guide to Good Health," died today at a nursing home in South Barre. His age was 85. He had suffered a cerebral hemorrhage earlier this year.
The rift between Frank D. O'Connor and the Liberal party deepened yesterday as Alex Rose, the party's vice chairman, accused the Council President of raising the "ugly issue" of religion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 Intercity truck tonnage and freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States railroads in the week ended Aug. 13 were both ahead of the volume in the corresponding week of 1965.
Long Island Sound can be dammed to create the largest fresh water reservoir in the United States, according to a plan proposed by a Columbia University oceanographer.
MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 18 (AP) Maria Bueno and Virginia Wade were the first to reach the semi-finals in the 40th Essex County Club's women's invitation tennis tournament today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18--An oral hearing for Sept. 19 on the proposed merger of the American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., with the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation was ordered today by the Federal Communications Commission.
The new princess of a predominantly Negro Shrine organization holding its annual convention here this week is a 19-year-old white girl from Bloomfield, N. J.
ALBANY, Aug. 18 (AP) Governor and Mrs. Rockefeller announced today that they expected the birth of a second child early next year.
LONDON, Aug. 18 (Reuters) Capt. Henry Joseph Round, an electronics engineer called the "father of British broadcasting," died yesterday, it was announced here today. He was 85 years old.

HARTFORD, Aug. 18 The purse was high while the scoring was the lowest of the year as the $100,000 Insurance City open golf tournament began today. The event that started 14 years ago as a $15,000 tournament attracted its best field to the Wethersfield Country Club after increasing its prize money by $30,000 since a year ago.
A little tea-leaf reading yesterday turned up the fact that Norman, Craig Kummel, Inc., will soon be named probably today to handle the United States advertising for Salada Foods, Inc.
HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 18 The Fenway Golf Club team of White Plains captured the Hoffhine Memorial Tournament by a stroke at the Westchester Country Club today with a total of 308.
Are soybean prices too high? George M. Strayer, of Hudson, Iowa, who is executive vice president of the American Soybean Association, believes they are.
Tung-Sol Electric, Inc., has reached agreement with the Wagner Electric Corporation on a merger after a long series of discussions.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18--Following is the text of a report on wage-price policy issued today by the President's Advisory Committee on Labor-Management Policy:...
TANGLEWOOD, Mass., Aug. 18 Five consecutive eve nings of contemporary American music came to an end tonight with the Berkshire Music Center Orchestra, conducted by Gunther Schuller,...

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 18 Miss Sally Wolcott Bonney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L.V. Bonney Jr., was married at the home of her parents today to Charles Grosvenor Proctor. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Grosvenor Proctor of Boston.

A seven-story loft and garage building that was once part of the real estate holdings of the former owners of the old Wanamaker department stores here has been sold by David Rapoport to an investing client of Berley Co., broker.

AT A Washington police station on Wednesday, waiting to be booked on a disorderly conduct charge, Arthur Kinoy made the time pass by doing what he likes best giving free advice to people in trouble with the law. And yesterday, when he went on trial, the peppery...

EVEN shrinking violets are causing a mild fashion stampede as they rush for dresses in vividly colored barbaric prints. They are discovering that the outspoken print is a sure way of attracting attention even though the dress it decorates is cut in the simplest kind of nonclinging way.
GENEVA, Aug. 18 The eight nonaligned nations at the disarmament conference called today for immediate steps to halt all tests of nuclear weapons.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 18 The second annual antiques show and sale sponsored by the Preservation Society of Newport County will be held at the Newport Casino Wednesday through Aug. 27. Twenty-two antiques dealers will participate in the show, which is being directed by J. Gresham Wilson of Old Saybrook, Conn.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (UPI) The number of surviving Indian War veterans dropped to four today with the death of a former corporal, who once complained that "it wasn't really much of a war."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 The House Committee on UnAmerican Activities tried without success today to break off its chaotic inquiry into how Americans have aided the Vietcong.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 New concepts that could produce intercontinental, domestic and military versions of a supersonic airliner are being discussed by Presidential advisers.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 18 Frederick W. Payne, who staged industrial exhibitions in the old Madison Square Garden, and was identified later with Grand Central Palace in New York, died yesterday in a nursing home in West Springfield. He was 88 years old and had lived in West Springfield since 1960.
EASTON, Pa., Aug. 18 Mr. and Mrs. Georg Auerbach have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynn Auerbach, to Dr. Steve Kaplan, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Kaplan of Philadelphia.
NORTHPORT, L. I., Aug. 18 Charles Rogers of San Diego, the West Coast champion, clung to his lead in the 110-Class national sailing championship today despite a ninth-place finish in the fourth race.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) Aug. 18 Two Israeli newspapers suggested today that the Government prevent Western governments from inspecting the MIG-21 whose Iraqi pilot recently defected to Israel.
SEATTLE, Aug. 18 After completion of the fourth round of the United States Open Chess Championship at the Seattle Center here last night, seven players of the original 201 entries have scored 4-0.
Arnold Constable, Inc., the 141-year-old specialty-store chain, has begun a "crash program" to build volume and turn deficits into profits by upgrading and modernizing its merchandising.
A 23-year-old man was shot and killed by the police early today after he led them on a wild, eight-mile auto chase in Queens.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange rose 5.5 per cent to a total of 11.4-million shares in the month ended Aug. 15, while customers' net debit balances for the month of July declined by $97-million to a total of $5.7-billion, it was reported yesterday.
SARASOTA, Fla., Aug. 18 (AP)--Attorneys for Dr. Carl Coppolino removed a legal hurdle today to his release on bail.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 18 Retail prices dropped about 3 per cent here last week, economists reported today.
The London Symphony Orchestra and its conductor, Colin Davis, will return to Daytona Beach next summer for another Florida International Music Festival, it was learned here yesterday.

Agents for theater-party benefits, who claim they sell about $7-million worth of tickets to Broadway shows each season--approximately 10 per cent of the annual total Broadway box-office take--are seeking to have their commission from producers raised from 6.8 per cent to 7.5 per cent.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 18 (AP) The Minnesota Twins combined the first triple play in their six-year history today with the four-hit pitching of Jim Grant for a 6-2 victory over the California Angels.
RIO DE JANIERO, Aug. 18--President Humberto Castelo Branco's military Government was attacked by opposition on two sides today as it attempted to placate aroused liberal churchmen on a third front.

RAHWAY, N. J. Aug. 18--William T. Gilgannon, a former Navy pilot and a former pilot captain for Mohawk Airlines, died yesterday at the Rahway Memorial Hospital. He was 46 years old and a resident of Hazlet.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 18--Military information officers here have been ordered to cease reporting to the press the number of surface-to-air antiaircraft missiles spotted over North Vietnam.

OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 18 Wildcat, an aged chestnut mare who once campaigned in the east under the name of Cameo, won the open jumper time class today in the opening session of the four-day Monmouth County horse show.

MOSCOW, Aug. 18--Three years before the United States exploded the world's first atomic bomb, Soviet scientists were engaged in an urgent program to develop such weapons, according to a Russian physicist who had a role in the project.

Like the recent $113-million New York City bond issue, Wednesday's offering of $100million in new California bonds came at rates high enough to make potential customers of many persons who would never have considered tax-exempt bonds in the past.
LONDON, Aug. 18 (Reuters) The Cunard Steamship Company added a feminine member to its board of directors today for the first time in the line's 126 years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) The Johnson Administration's plan to finance $3.23billion worth of Government agency operations without the usual budget appropriations was upheld today by the heavy Democratic majority in the House.

MONTREAL, Aug. 18 (AP) About 2,000 nonoperating railroad employes staged wildcat walkouts today at three Montreal yards and one Ontario depot. Railway officials said no interruption of service was expected. The jobs of nonoperating workers do not involve the running of trains.
A group of some 200 independent milk distributors offered New York City a chance to get into the milk business yesterday because they were "sick and tired and want out."

Americans tend to think of Communist China in of Vietnam and other direct involvements of the United States. But the impact of China's Revolution on other countries around its long periphery is likely to have a more profound effect on world history.
AJACCIO, Corsica, Aug. 18 (UPI) Francois Pietri, a high Government official in France before World War II and the Vichy Ambassador to Spain, died today after an operation. He was 74 years old.

TOURNAMENT bridge can be an expensive recreation when one considers the cost of meals, hotel accommodation and transportation as well as entry fees. It has been estimated that an average master point costs its possessor $100, and this may be true for players who take a long time to achieve life master rank.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 18 A quiet exodus of leading teachers at the University of Buenos Aires has begun.
An explosion and fire aboard a rented 28-foot boat forced nine fishermen into the water at the entrance of Great Kills harbor at Staten Island yesterday. They were rescued by another fishing boat.

Col. Nick Perlmutter, U.S.A., and Mrs. Perlmutter of Fort Totten, Queens, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Perlmutter, to Dr. Denzel F. Hartshorn, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Duane F. Hartshorn of Fort Collins, Colo.

FUN rather than value now seems to be fashion's bat tle cry, and one result is that clothes that used to wear like iron now wear like paper. In fact, disposable printed shifts of a paperlike substance, meant to be thrown out after a few wearings, are now being worn on the streets of New York.
HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 18 (UPI) Seena Owen, who appeared in films starring William S. Hart, Elmo Lincoln and Lionel Barrymore, died Monday in the Hollywood Presbyterian Hospital at the age of 71.
The stock market declined sharply yesterday in continued reaction to the tight-money situation. Losses were widespread, with only a few specialty issues able to resist the downward trend.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 18 An 18-year-old Negro bootblack in the locker room of an allwhite private country club here will enter Harvard University next month with a four-year scholarship won in a national competition and more than $2,000 spending money contributed by golfers whose shoes he shines.

Mrs. Frederic H. Belfield of Abington, Pa., and Hans Joachim Schuchard of Mount Kisco, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Holly Ann Schuchard, to Joseph Michael Lachowicz. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Lachowicz of Glen Spey, N. Y.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 In his weekend swing through such Northern cities as Buffalo, Syracuse and Manchester, N.H., President Johnson will have an excellent opportunity to stir up some public excitement about his demonstration-cities proposal and other elements of his Administration's program for doing something about urban problems and their ugly godchild, racial rioting.
COLUMBIA, S. C., Aug. 18 (AP) Jeff B. Bates, South Carolina state treasurer since 1940, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 69 years old.
TRUONGPHU, South Vietnam, Aug. 17 The South Vietnamese Government is using schoolbags, headache pills and kindness to win the loyalty of this hamlet 50 miles northwest of Saigon.

SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 18 Paul Hasluck, Minister of External Affairs, redefined his Government's attitude toward Communist China today during a general review of foreign affairs in Parliament in Canberra.

A comprehensive listing of the advantages Harlem offers as the site for a new state office building has been sent to Governor Rockefeller by Borough President Constance Baker Motley, who is soon to become a Federal district judge. Similar proposals have been put forward by State Controller Arthur Levitt...

The report from Moscow yesterday that Soviet scientists were trying to develop nuclear weapons three years before the United States exploded the world's first atomic bomb recalls the strange irony involved in this country's accomplishment of the feat.

WASHINGTON Aug. 18 (UPI) Representative J. Edward Roush called today for stiff Federal penalties to be imposed on those who incite riots. The Indiana Democrat introduced a bill in the House providing for fines up to $10,000 and imprisonment up to five years.
August is Japan's annual month of trauma over Hiroshima, the month when she rededicates her spirit to the pacifist gods unloosed by the mushroom cloud.

The appointment of William G. Lord 2d as president of the Galey Lord division of Burlington Industries, Inc., was announced yesterday by Charles F. Myers Jr., president of the parent concern. Mr. Lord had been executive vice president of the division.
MOSCOW, Aug. 18 A clerk at a Gorki Street bookstore, one of Moscow's largest, could find no copies of "War and Peace" on the shelves. There was nothing by Pushkin for sale, no editions of Turgenev.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 An Administration official said today that a well-meaning Congress had occasionally tried to force more money on his department than it could "intelligently handle."

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 18 Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis and Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century blended their shots for a 38, 36 74 today and a two-stroke lead at the midpoint of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association 36-hole best-ball championship at the Essex County Country Club.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 18 Two residents of the Hough area, where rioting and violence occurred in mid-July, began a legal move today to demand the recall from office of Mayor Ralph S. Locher.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 Federal officials and representatives of maritime unions conferred here this afternoon on the difficulty of manning the increasing number of merchant ships involved in the emergency sealift to Vietnam.

VIENNA, Aug. 18 Five Austrians have died in disastrous floods that struck Alpine southern Austria yesterday. Thousands of German tourists were stranded in eastern Tyrol, which was isolated by the waters' rise.
OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 18 Miss Barbara Rossington Whyte and John Justin Moeling Jr. of Boston, son of Mrs. Moeling of Camden, Me., and the late Mr. Moeling, have made plans to marry next spring.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. announced tonight at a civil rights rally that demonstrators would test 100 real estate offices in 10 all-white neighborhoods tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) The House refused today, for the second time this year, to vote further financing for a project to drill deep into the earth's crust in the Pacific near Hawaii.
SINGAPORE, Aug. 18 Malaysia today struck her second economic blow against Britain in three days.

THE Baltimore Colts and the Detroit Lions played a stirring football game last Thanksgiving Day in Detroit, one that ended in a 24-24 tie. Tiger Stadium, a compact, old-fashioned baseball park, was ideal for the television cameras as they framed the action, which seldom ceased.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 18 Gov. George C. Wallace asked the Alabama Legislature tonight to appropriate funds to schools that lose Federal revenues by refusing to comply with the desegregation guidelines of the United States Office of Education.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 President Johnson indicated today that he was considering a "practical system of nonmilitary alternatives to the draft."

Bus service is one of the city's great secrets. The people are not told where the buses run or when. Worldly possessors of route knowledge husband it carefully, as though dealing with intelligence on the last of the great undiscovered French restaurants or marvelous neighborhood dressmakers. Ideograph route maps sprinkled about have helped some riders,...
Mr. and Mrs. Meyer L. Sugarman of Glencoe, Ill., will share their honeymoon hotel tonight at Ellenville, N.Y., with President Johnson and his party of 100 persons.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 (UPI) Willie Davis lofted a tie-breaking solo homer in the third inning and Jim Lefebvre drove in two runs with singles as Don Drysdale pitched the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 3-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 The American Telephone and Telegraph Company asserted today that the Ford Foundation had made a $30-million error in its tentative estimate of the feasibility of a nonprofit television satellite system.
LONDON, Aug. 19 The Government said today it would lend junior medical internes the salary increases that they would have received but for the recent pay freeze.

MIAMI, Aug. 18 Concern about the behavior of 2,100 Cuban scholarship students in Communist-bloc countries was voiced last night at the closing session of a three-day "criticism and self-criticism" meeting in Havana of 500 students on vacation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 A criminal court was told here today that if Arthur Kinoy was convicted of disorderly conduct charges, lawyers for witnesses before the House Committee on Un-American Activities might be inhibited from effective representation of their clients.
A Navy amphibious transport dock ship bumped into the superliner France yesterday while the French Line vessel was taking on passengers at Pier 88 at the Hudson River and 48th Street.

BOSTON, Aug. 18 A Negro mother of five, who directs the volunteer school bus service in her community, challenged a group of church and state leaders today to invest $2-million in Negro talent and manpower to improve racial conditions in Boston.

MANHASSET, L.I., Aug. 18 Bill Tully of Pelham, the winner in 1963, reached the semifinal round of the United States men's 35-year-old clay court tennis championships today at the Shelter Rock Tennis Club.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 18 Anti-Communist students, politicians and newspapers today sharply criticized President Sukarno's speech yesterday on the 21st anniversary of Indonesian independence.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Aug. 18 (AP) A sniper shot a policeman in the arm, two other officers were fired upon, and rocks and bottles were hurled at cars and store windows during a night of violence here and in nearby Pompano Beach.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 The United States will draw $350-million in two foreign currencies from the International Monetary Fund to help protect the United States' gold stock, it was announced today.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 18 In the stable area at the Fasig-Tipton auction headquarters today, trucks carted away mounds of straw bedding from empty stalls.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Nugent returned to the White House tonight from their 10-day honeymoon at Nassau, the Bahamas.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Mark Edward Fox of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Laure Fox, to James Charles Peterson, son of Mrs. Alice Bell of Natick, Mass., and Tore Peterson of Waltham, Mass.
SUFFIELD, Conn., Aug. 18 (AP) Dexter D. Coffin Sr., an industrialist and chairman of the Connecticut Aeronautics Commission, died last night of a heart attack at his home. He was 68 years old.
The water level in the city's reservoirs continued its seasonal decline this week, dipping to 78.8 per cent of capacity by 8 A.M. yesterday.

ROME--Some barely flickering embers in Italy's political fireplace may get a touch of the bellows next month when a book called "Italy Betrayed" is published in New York. It is by Peter Tompkins, a U.S. intelligence agent in Rome prior to its liberation in June 1944.
CORDOBA, Argentina, Aug. 18 (AP) A Cordoba University medical student was wounded today in a scuffle with police. He was identified as Luis A. Cerda, 19 years old.
EDGARTOWN, Mass., Aug. 18 The Corinthians Cruise had a layover day today before racing the final leg, over 24 miles, to Padanaram tomorrow for the final rendezvous at South Dartmouth.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 The construction of new housing units dropped sharply in July to its lowest level in nearly six years, the Census Bureau reported today.
The spot rate on the British pound moved up 6 points to $2.7892 in dull trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) reported yesterday that its net income for the year ended June 30 rose to $143.7-million from $136.9million the year before.

FOX CHAPEL, Pa., Aug. 18 Announcement of the engagement of Miss Sharley Ann Janes, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marc Janes of Fox Chapel, to Graham C. Bryce, has been made by the parents of the prospective bride. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Bryce of Albion, Mich.
More than 600 Head Start teachers, parents and children picketed the city's antipoverty office yesterday to protest a $3.4-million cut in the budget for the pre-school program.

The engagement of Miss Ellen Rose Wolarsky, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Wolarsky of Riverdale, the Bronx, to Jay David Kuris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Kuris, also of Riverdale, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.
All of the 300-room Theres Hotel, Harlem's only major hotel, may be converted into an office building.
Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, announced yesterday increases in seamen's pension benefits from the present $150 a month to $175 effective Sept. 1.

TORONTO, Aug. 18 R.A. Goodfellow, a stock broker associated with C. Powell Morgan and the now insolvent Atlantic Acceptance Corporation, has been expelled from membership on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Mr. Moagan was president of Atlantic.
Many of the best-known columnists of The Herald Tribune will be writing for The World Journal Tribune when it begins publication, Frank Conniff, the editor of the new newspaper, said yesterday.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Aug. 18 Charles V. Flynn, head of Flyndustries, Inc., Manhattan, national sales representatives for plastic container manufacturers, died on Tuesday in Florence, Italy, where he was vacationing with his family. He was 50 years old and lived at 8 Cotswold Way.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Aug. 19 Vietcong guerrillas have burned down 120 homes of war refugees a United States spokesman said yesterday.

LUBUMBASHI, the Congo, Aug. 18 A Belgian travel agent who went out to the airport here yesterday was arrested by Congolese Army troops, beaten about the head and then, after several hours, released. No reason was given for his arrest or release.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 18 Tony Roche of Australia, the champion of France and Italy, and Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., the United States clay court titleholder, won their quarter-final matches in the Newport Tennis Hall of Fame tournament today and will meet in the semi-finals on Saturday.
An end to the 42-day-old airline strike today would be a mixed blessing for the Lear Jet Corporation.
Bond prices moved sharply lower yesterday for the fourth consecutive day this week.

An initial public offering of 375,000 common shares of the Digital Equipment Corporation at $22 a share sold out quickly yesterday and rose to a threepoint premium. The stock was marketed by a syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers. Digital Equipment, based in Maynard, Mass., designs, manufactures and services electronic products and equipment.
The board of directors of Seeman Brothers, Inc., producer of frozen foods, Carlstadt, N. J., announced yesterday a new top-management set-up.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

The dozen protesters against the Vietnam war subpoenaed by the House Committee on UnAmerican Activities for its hearings this week include members or former members of six of the most militant newleft groups.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 The attorney for Richard Speck asked today that the accused slayer of eight student nurses be examined by a panel of six psychiatrists and two psychologists to be agreed upon by both the state and the defense to avoid "a battle between psychiatrists" in the trial.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP)--The Senate approved today President Johnson's request for a record "peacetime" Defense Department budget. It also bid for a larger say in how the military machinery is operated.

More than 270 boys and girls 10 to 15 years old, will participate in the Eastern Sports Festival that will start today at the Wollman Memorial in Prospect Park, Brooklyn and at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island. It will continue through Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 Half a dozen Senators and a top official of the Johnson Administration agreed today that something must be done to help politicians pay the "colossal" cost of their election campaigns. But no two of them agreed on what.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 The Treasury's new offering of $3-billion worth of March and April tax anticipation bills was sold today for the highest yield since tax anticipation bills were first offered in 1951.

EDISON, N. J., Aug. 18 Gregory V. Finnegan of 60 Carmello Drive, an administrative assistant to the Linde division of the Union Carbide Company in Union, died yesterday in Boston after a short illness. He was 43 years old.
Physicians have raised their fees for patients 65 and over by as much as 300 per cent since Medicare began July 1.
Joseph C. Brennan, 55 years old, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, it was announced yesterday.

The election of Peter H.B. Cumming as president and chief executive officer of the Textile Banking Company, Inc., a factoring subsidiary of Commercial Credit Company, was announced yesterday by Berthold Muecke Jr., chairman of the parent company.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 18 President Humberto Castelo Branco celebrated five years of the Alliance for Progress today by signing an agreement for loans totaling $38.4-million.

The remarkable pictures of the moon's surface radioed back by Lunar Orbiter yesterday represent another historic first for the United States space program. Now that this vehicle has shown what can be done, the way is open for it and its successors to provide unprecedentedly detailed photographs of every square inch on both sides of the moon.

The State Supreme Court was asked yesterday to extend its injunction barring the advertising of retail liquor prices to virtually all stores in the city. The injunction now applies to two large liquor stores here.
A seminar to help develop Renaissance men will start here next week.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 18--Freeman White, a rookie end who set seven career records as an all-American at Nebraska, will be in the starting line-up on Sunday at the Yale Bowl where the New York Giants meet the Detroit Lions in an exhibition football game.
ORLANDO, Fla., Aug. 18 (AP) A Federal court ordered a halt today to picketing at Cape Kennedy by sheet metal workers.
Williams Co., real estate brokerage concern, has named Herbert H. Libertson to a vice presidency.
Liberal party members have voted overwhelmingly in a statewide poll to run an independent candidate for Governor.

Patrolman Ramiro Martinez, the 29-year-old Austin, Tex., policeman who shot and killed the mass sniper-killer, Charles Whitman, in the Texas University tower last Aug. 1, was welcomed to the city yesterday by Rafael Martinez, Deputy Public Events Commissioner.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., Aug. 19 Mr. and Mrs. Everett J. Penny have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bonnie Penny, to Hugh Van Seaton, son of Mrs. Walter E. Seaton of Eureka, Mo., and the late Mr. Seaton.

LUBUMBASHI, the Congo, Aug. 19 The disorder and misery for which the Congo is an international byword are evident enough in this sprawling city, the former Elisabethville. It is a Graham Greene setting of dusty streets, intrigue, corruption and sudden brutality.
President Johnson's Advisory Committee on LaborManagement Policy has provided a foggy beacon to guide the nation in the war against inflation.
It was a busy day for picketing at City Hall yesterday.
Following are excerpts from President Johnson's address at Syracuse yesterday afternoon, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. news:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 (UPI) A national official of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee said today he had "some very good evidence that police planted the dynamite" they had found in raids last Saturday at a S.N.C.C. meeting place.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 19 (UPI) An international fugitive was arraigned while in a heavy steel-mesh cell today several hours after his capture at a casino in this gambling resort.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 19 (UPI) At least four persons were reported killed and 15 injured today after a student demonstration against President Sukarno in Bandung erupted into a riot.
Philip Lipstein of 9 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, who owned and developed buildings in many states, died yesterday of a heart ailment in Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 67 years old.
Ballots are to be counted today in a strike vote taken among 22,000 telephone exchange installers employed across the nation by the Western Electric Company.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 19 There is going to be an awful lot of Franz Liszt's music during the final week of the Berkshire Music Festival, and the amenities were launched at this evening's weekend prelude. Jorge Bolet devoted an hour to Liszt piano music, and, if that were not enough, he devoted his program to the kind of repertory not heard for at least a generation.
ROME, Aug. 19 Pope Paul VI today renewed his "most ardent hopes for a rapid overcoming of the sad trials" that beset the people of Vietnam.
The United States, with an annual production of goods and services of about $732-billion, has been described as an "affluent society."

After monitoring 150 miles of New York City streets with hypersensitive Geiger counters, the Health Department abandoned its search yesterday for a lethal capsule of radium that vanished from a box somewhere during shipment from Texas to Queens.
Four major lumber associations reported a decline of 8.7 per cent in production for the week ended Aug. 13, compared with the level in the corresponding 1965 week.
CAIRO, N.Y., Aug. 19 (AP) Darkness forced policemen to halt temporarily their intense search for 7-year-old Debra Smith shortly after 8:30 p.m. today.
MEMPHIS, Aug. 19 (UPI) Firecrackers, fruit and debris were tossed at the Beatles tonight during a concert here.
Translators at the American Bible Society have decided that what's good enough for the Voice of America is good enough for them.

Capitol Records has signed an agreement with the Soviet Union giving the company "exclusive first rights to manufacture, license and distribute in the United States and the western hemisphere all recordings by Russian artists."

The persistent snickersneeing sound of check-processing machines drives many persons from the room. But the rapid hand movements and calm intelligence of the deaf cut through the clatter and chaos to get the job done.

A 24-year-old plumber was arraigned yesterday at the United States Commissioner's office in Brooklyn on the charge that he possessed $12,000 worth of the hallucinagenic drug LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide).
BOGOTA, Columbia, Aug. 19 The decisions reached at the meeting of three South American Presidents here suggest an agenda for the proposed meeting of Latin-American leaders with President Johnson.

WINNSBORO, S.C., Aug. 19--Miss Susan Morris Lyles, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Morris Lyles Jr., was married this evening to William Griswold Randall, son of William Irving Randall, a Massachusetts state senator, and Mrs. Randall of Framingham, Mass.
SEATTLE, Aug. 19 After completion of the fifth round of the United States Open Chess Championships at the Seattle Center here last night, only four players of the original 201 entries had 5-0 scores.
"U.S.S.R. hydrometeorological center begins experimental transmissions most interesting meteorological information received from earth satellite Cosmos 122."
Most commodities took a submarine ride yesterday and cooled off fast. The sinking spell hit a variety of recent recordsetters.

THE neighborhood kids think they're crazing. "Ya sell those pebbles? I can get you a lot for free," offered a T-shirted 10-yearold, who poked his head into Sassafras one hot afternoon recently after being drawn to the jewelry made from stones in the show window.
Thousands of members of the Veterans of Foreign Wars were arriving yesterday for their 67th annual convention that will begin tomorrow at the New York Hilton Hotel.
Mystic Seaport, the marine historical shrine at Mystic, Conn., has announced the appointment of Edmund Elliott Lynch as curator, effective Sept. 1.
WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 19 William Kalker, a builder and an insurance company officer, died yesterday in White Plains Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 152 Hillaire Circle, Scarsdale.

Federal Judge Dudley B. Bonsal cleared yesterday all but two of the 12 Texas Gulf Sulphur Company insiders charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission with capitalizing on advance information of the concern's rich copper strike near Timmins, Ont.
The Provincial Government of Nova Scotia announced yesterday that it would buy Deuterium of Canada, Ltd., and the interest owned by Jerome S. Spevack. The amount of money involved was not disclosed.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19 (UPI) For the fourth consecutive time this season, Larry Jaster, a Cardinal rookie, shut out the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight, hurling St. Louis to a 4-0 victory.
A young mother on the Lower East Side bought a set of children's books from a door-todoor saleswoman who said she represented the Board of Education.

HONG KONG, Aug. 19 (Reuters) The North Vietnamese Government accused the United States today of deliberately continuing to bomb dikes and irrigation works in North Vietnam in an attempt to provoke flood and famine and to hamper production.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 The American Machine and Foundry Company is automating the drive-in restaurant. The order-recording, billing and cooking are all mechanized.

PARIS, Aug. 19 (Reuters) Britain told her allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization today of plans for major savings in the foreign-exchange costs of keeping British forces in West Germany and asked for suggestions on reducing her 59,000-man commitment there.

THE end of August marks the peak of the Thompson seedless grape harvest, which accounts for more than half the grapes grown in California. The size of these bright green, juicy grapes has increased during the last decade because of improved methods of cultivation.
Sales of the May Department Stores Company in the second fiscal quarter ended July 31, rose to $222,718,000 from $211,048,000 in the period last year.
The spot rate on the British pound closed 6 points lower at $2.7884 after quiet trading on foreign exchang markets here yesterday.
SALEM, Ohio, Aug. 19 (UPI) Mrs. Louis H. Brush, widow of a founder of Brush-Moore Newspapers, died last night at her home here. She was 95 years old.
BUFFALO, Aug. 19 (UPI) President Johnson said today he would renew his declaration on drought disaster affecting parts of New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania and Delaware.

ATLANTA, Aug. 19 (AP) An Atlanta judge sentenced 12 antiwar demonstrators to jail today and bound one of them for grand jury action on an insurrection charge stemming from an assault on an Army induction center.
THE HAGUE, Aug. 19 (UPI) The Dutch Government today demanded the immediate release of its Peking charge d'affaires, who has been forced by Communist China to stay in his legation for 28 days.
Three creditors filed a bankruptcy petition yesterday against the Wagner Baking Corporation, maker of low priced fruit pies under the name Mrs. Wagner's Pies.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19--Dr. George Morris Piersol, professor emeritus of physical medicine at the University of Pennsylvania's School of Medicine and an authority on rehabilitation of the disabled, died today in Lankenau Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Wynnewood.
A nice-looking, neatly dressed man in his late forties has been shaking hands with strangers in front of supermarkets and at bus stops from Stuyvesant Town to Tudor City for the last several weeks.
SARASOTA, Fla., Aug. 19 (AP) A second fugitive warrant charging Dr. Carl Coppolino with a New Jersey murder was issued today as the prosecution apparently sought to block his release on bail.
DALLAS, Aug. 18 Three lowflying Air Force planes today sprayed 50,000 acres of residential sections of Dallas with malathion in an effort to halt a spreading epidemic of St. Louis encephalitis.
"Pele, Pele, Pele, Pele, Pele," they screamed, scampering down West 33d Street after a small, dark man in a pink shirt. "Pele, Pele, Pele."

AJACCIO, Corsica, Aug. 19 Francois Pietri, Ambassador to Spain from Vichy France and a Minister in several French Cabinets during the nineteen-thirties, died here yesterday after surgery. He was 84 years old.

SEATTLE, Aug. 19 Miss Nancy Odinov, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Odinov of Brooklyn, New York, was married this afternoon to Richard A. Baiter, son of Mrs. George Baiter of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and the late Mr. Baiter. Judge William Hoar performed the ceremony in the Kings County Court House.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 19 A bizarre business dispute involving the Congo, Belgium and American investors came to light today. It involves Forminiere, a 60-year-old dia mond-mining company which the American investors now seem to control.
A Brooklyn businessman who had angrily informed Mayor Lindsay that he was going to move out of the city because of conditions in East New York, changed his mind yesterday.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 19 Gov. George C. Wallace's proposal to circumvent the desegregation guidelines of the United States Office of Education ran into unexpectedly stiff opposition of Alabama educators today.
Joseph C. Wilson, chairman of the Xerox Corporation, issued a clarifying statement yesterday in an effort to stem the retreat of the company's common stock on the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 Stewart L. Udall, Secretary of the Interior, accused the head of a California lumber company today of pursuing "an outrageous public-be-damned, conservation-be-damned approach" to the proposed Redwood National Park.

Norbert J. Langer Sr., who retired in 1960 as associate editor of American Metal Market, a daily trade paper, died yesterday in Whitestone (Queens) General Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 70 Bank Street, Valley Stream, L.I.
A controversial state law that requires public schools to lend textbooks to parochial school pupils was struck down yesterday in State Supreme Court.
The filter that President Johnson spoke of yesterday for use in the Lake Erie area will work on the principle of the cooking strainer.
TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 20 (AP) North Vietnam said today that a Buddhist monk who acted as vice chairman of the National Liberation Front of South Vietnam was killed in a bombing on Aug. 8.
Interstate cooperation rose to rare heights yesterday when Governor Rockefeller announced that Alaska had given New York a $100,000 Federal grant which the 51st state could not use.
ELLENVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 19 For freshmen Democrats scrambling to keep their seats in Congress, it was a good day to be a friend of Lyndon B. Johnson.
GOTEBORG, Sweden, Aug. 19 (AP) The former world heavyweight champion, Sonny Liston, knocked out Amos Johnson of Medina, Ohio, in the third round of a scheduled 10round bout tonight.

A DECEPTIVE lead by Alvin Roth of New York contributed to the declarer's downfall in the diagramed deal, which was played in the quarter-finals of the Spingold championships this month. He sat in the West seat, and over-called one spade after South had opened the bidding with one club.
WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 19 (UPI) A 66-year-old tuxedoclad pianist sat down at the keyboard today in a West German cafe to begin a 44-day trans-Atlantic piano-playing marathon.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 19 An Argentine scientist who has contributed to the United States space program said today that most of his colleagues were prepared to leave the country with a clear conscience unless the military regime restored freedom to the universities.

ROCHESTER, Mich., Aug. 19 Some of the euphoria returned to the Meadow Brook Music Festival last night when more than 2,100 people came to the second contemporary music program in the eighth and final week of the season.
A SHOP devoted to the designs of John Kloss has been opened on the fourth floor at Henri Bendel as part of its redesigned and redecorated Young Bendel area.

TOKYO, Aug. 19 A leftwing Japanese peace organization, backed by American peace groups, plans to distribute leaflets and other information to American soldiers and tourists here urging them to resist the United States' "war of aggression" in Vietnam.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 19 Governor Rockefeller criticized City Council President Frank D. O'Connor today for raising the issue of his Roman Catholicism and Irish descent to explain his apparent failure to get the Liberal party designation for Governor.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug, 19 (AP) Rico Carty's three-run homer followed by Mack Jones's drive with the bases empty tonight produced a four-run seventh inning for Atlanta to help the Braves beat the San Francisco Giants, 8-5.

The bond market slumped again yesterday, bringing to a close a week of five consecutive daily declines. Over-all, the drop amounted to the steepest downward curve of the... year. Prices yesterday were affected by the report that the Federal Reserve Board intends to let bank credit get far tighter that it already is.

DETROIT, Aug. 19 (AP) Jerry Lumpe cracked three singles and Willie Horton and Don Wert each drove in two runs tonight, leading the Detroit Tigers to a 10-4 triumph over the American Leagueleading Baltimore Orioles.
CHAMONIX, France, Aug. 19 (Reuters) Snowstorms, ice and fog today held up a rescue attempt to bring down two West Germans trapped six days on a mountain ledge in the Alps.
MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 19 (AP) A virus infection felled Mrs. Billie Jean Moffitt King at the Essex County Club women's invitation tennis tournament today and forced her to default.

TOKYO, Aug. 19 (AP)--A list of Communist China's leaders published today suggests that the purge may have hit more members of the ruling Politburo, including Liu Pocheng, possibly the nation's best military tactician. His name was omitted, along with those of five Cabinet members.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 (UPI)--A City Health Department employe was held in "maximum security" today for psychiatric tests following his arrest by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents on charges of threatening the life of President Johnson.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI) The Navy announced to day the award of a $24-million contract to Britain for the construction of three ships.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 The House Committee on UnAmerican Activities ended its raucous inquiry into the New Left today after two witnesses had been dragged from the stand and a dozen other persons had been ejected and arrested for creating disturbances.

OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 19 Quietism, an aged chestnut gelding, broke a first-place tie in the final class of the division today and captured the junior jumper championship at the Monmouth County horse show under 16-year-old Steve Stephens.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 19 Foreign Minister Adam Malik declared today that Indonesia would definitely return to the United Nations, from which President Sukarno withdrew the country early last year.
ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 19 A woman who agreed to complete a book on Spain for a dying author today became the beneficiary of the royalties on his writings and of $15,000 in cash.
PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 19 (AP) A Resolution supporting the Johnson Administration's prosecution of the Vietnam war was adopted by delegates to the National Legislative conference today by voice vote.
The General Baking Company, known on the Eastern seaboard for its Bond bread and other baked goods, is moving into the restaurant field.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) The International Monetary Fund approved today a standby arrangement for Paraguay to draw up to $7.5-million over the next year to meet any difficulties in its international payments.

FITZWILLIAM, N.H., Aug. 19 (UPI) A former mental patient surrendered today after being found beside a rural road with the 13-year-old girl he allegedly abducted yesterday from her home in nearby Winchendon, Mass.
LONDON, Aug. 19 (AP) British television ventured into 21st-century California last night.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 19 (AP) Adolph Nelson, 79 years old, was the handicap winner in the preliminary round of the 67th annual Grand American trap-shooting tournament today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) Airline revenue losses during the strike have been estimated at $8.2-million a day, a total of more than $350-million.
What has unkindly but accurately been called the battle for seventh place wound up unresolved at the Stadium last night as the Yankees and Kansas City Athletics split a doubleheader.

The House Public Works Committee did not give President Johnson a helpful sendoff for his trip to Lake Erie. The announcement of an intriguing new plan for filtering polluted water by means of pulverized coal was a highlight of the President's speech in Buffalo yesterday.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 19 Malaysian and Thai security officials met today to discuss new joint efforts against 500 to 600 Malaysian Communists roaming the jungles of southern Thailand's border region.
MALMO, Sweden, Aug. 19 (Reuters) George Axelsson, a Swedish-born correspondent who covered three European wars for The New York Times, died here today. He was 67 years old.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 19 William S. Cox of Noroton (Conn.) Yacht Club, the men's Long Island Sound sailing champion, built a 7 -point lead in the Area-B semi-finals of the men's North American championship series today.
BONN, Aug. 19 Volkswagen tolr shareholders today that its sales in the first six months of 1966 rose to the equivalent of $1,347,500,000, an increase of 18.3 per cent over the 1965 period.
SYRACUSE, Aug. 19 President Johnson announced here today that he intended to "take the profit out of poverty."

PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 19 With its sharpest camera eye mysteriously dimmed, Lunar Orbiter 1 appeared today to be unable to complete successfully its primary mission of taking detailed pictures of potential astronaut landing spots on the moon.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Aug. 19 (AP) About 600 construction workers stayed off the job at the nation's moonport today after one picket line replaced another.
MOUNTAINSIDE, N.J., Aug. 19 Edward J. Honecker of 152 Mill Lane, a former member of the Borough Council, died yesterday at his home of a heart attack His age was 58.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 19 Buckpasser, Ogden Phipps's 3-year-old colt who is considered the best of his age group, will race in the Travers, the nation's oldest major thoroughbred event tomorrow. Bracketed as an entry with the Wheatley Stable's Stupendous, Buckpasser will be the 1-2 choice. Both Buckpasser and Stupendous are trained by Eddie Neloy; the former will be ridden by Braulio Baeza, and Stupendous by Bob Ussery.

VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 19 Bret Hanover defeated Waygone by 31 lengths in their $20,000 one-mile match race at Vernon Downs tonight. The victory, his 12th in 13 outings this season, added $12,000 to the great 4-year-old pacer's earnings, which rose to $837,352. Bret Hanover's career record is now 57 triumphs in 61 starts.

The 18-hour fourth annual Avant-Garde Festival in New York will be presented on The Mall in Central Park Friday, Sept. 9. From 6 A.M. to midnight there will be musical performances, film projections, painting and sculpture presentations, plays, dances and "hap... penings" that combine several of these elements.
The American Stock Exchange continued to decline yesterday with the glamour issues as the biggest losers. It was the fifth session in a row on the downside.
An investigation into the "complex" affairs of Webb Knapp, Inc., is continuing, but recommendations for any feasible plan of reorganization remain "many months" away.
The state Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Authority has taken the first step toward providing the Long Island Rail Road with commuter cars capable of traveling 100 miles an hour.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 A Criminal Court judge found Arthur Kinoy, a New York lawyer, guilty today of disorderly conduct before the House Committee on Un-American Acitivties.
"Rotate!" boomed the deep voice of the co-pilot C.O. Church as the Convair 880 sped down runway 13 at Kennedy International Airport at 155 miles an hour.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 19 (AP) Thirteen handicap horses, including nine stakes winners this season, were named today for tomorrow's $29,675 Philadelphia Handicap at the Atlantic City Race Course.
ROME, Aug. 19 A one-week delay in the sailing of the liner Cristoforo Colombo, scheduled for Tuesday, was announced today.

AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 19 (AP) Mrs. Luci Johnson Nugent, proclaiming herself "very happy" with marriage, visited her new duplex apartment today, met some old friends and prepared to be a bridal attendant.

LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 19 (UPI) Don Schollander broke his second world swimming record in two days tonight, bettering his 200-meter free-style mark with a time of 1 minute 56.2 seconds in the National Amateur Athletic Union swimming and diving championships.

Special to The New York Times KINGS POINT, L.I., Aug. 19 Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Mintz have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Ellen Mintz, to Alan Richard Batkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley I. Batkin of New Rochelle, N.Y.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 The defending titleholder, Peaches Bartkowicz of Hamtramck, Mich., and Patsy Rippy of Shawnee, Okla., overcame the challenges of California players and reached the final round of the 49th annual United States girls' grass court tennis championships today at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.
A power failure affecting signals and switches disrupted subway service on the Eighth Avenue IND line for 47 minutes last night after the evening rush hour.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 19 (UPI) Representatives of Roman Catholic, Buddhist and other religious groups today accused the Government of Premier Nguyen Cao Ky of being a dictatorship and called on church members to boycott the general elections he has ordered for Sept. 11.
TACOMA, Wash., Aug. 19 (AP) Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara and his party reached the summit of 14,410-foot Mount Ranier today after camping overnight at the 10,000-foot level.
NORTHPORT, L.I., Aug. 19 Charles Rudinsky of South Boston, Mass., a 19-year-old Boston College freshman, won the 110-Class national sailing championship today on Long Island Sound.
FREEHOLD, N.J., Aug 19 In 1960 Henry Zdancewic had a gross income of $35,300 on his dairy farm here. He made a profit of $6,600.
Appointment of Kenneth N. Scott as general manager of the Fisher Body division of the General Motors Corporation, effective Sept. 1, was announced yesterday.

WHEN things go wrong in the East Bronx, Mrs. Florence May Rice is a likely person to be called on for help. Yesterday the heavyset and jovial but deadly serious antipoverty aide got a call from a neighborhood tenant who wanted to know what to do about a snake in ...

In declaring unconstitutional the New York Legislature's provision of state funds for textbooks to be "loaned" to parochial schools, State Supreme Court Justice T. Paul Kane has hit at the dangerous erosion of the separation of church and state in many current school-aid programs.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 19 The New York Jets have three quarterbacks. They arrived here today with two. Tomorrow night in an American Football League preseason game against the Miami Dolphins, they plan to use only one.
ATLANTA, Aug. 19 (AP) Texas has produced 43 of the 52 reported cases of paralytic poliomyelitis in the United States this year, an office of the United States Public Health Service said today.

Market Commissioner Samuel J. Kearing does not want the city to go into the milk business, he said yesterday. Indeed, he said, he would prefer that New York State set up "some kind of price stabilization machinery" to reduce milk prices.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) The House has stuck to its decision to refuse further funds now for a project to drill through the earth's crust.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 19 Art Wall Jr., who has been struggling with his golf game, set a scoring record today. Carding a 7-under-par 64 in the $100,000 Insurance City Open, he brought his two-day aggregate to 129, the lowest total for 36 holes on the pro circuit this year.
The State Court of Claims has ruled that the Thruway Authority does not have to repay the state $24.6-million the unpaid part of an $80-million loan made 15 years ago.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 19 Miss Lynne Randall Bowie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Somervell Bowie, was married here tonight to Thomas Forcey Dillingham, son of Mrs. Paul Williamson of St. Louis and the late Fred Dillingham. The Rev. Don F. Vandegrift performed the ceremony in the chapel at St. James's Episcopal Church.
VERONA, Pa., Aug. 19 Kathleen Ahern of Dallas, and Claudia Mayhew of Carmel, Ind. will meet tomorrow in the 18-hole final of the 18th annual United States girls' junior golf championship.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 19 The engagement of Miss Beth Gruber to Marc S. Goldberg has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. M.A. Gruber, parents of the future bride. Mr. Goldberg is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Goldberg of Jersey City.

A 23-year-old burglar with an arrest record since 1959 was shot and killed early yesterday by police after he reportedly fired two shots at a policeman as he ran from a butcher shop at 84-15 57th Road, Maspeth, Queens, the police reported.

No significant increase in the number of hospital admissions of older patients occurred during the first month of Medicare, according to a nationwide survey of 450 hospitals conducted by the American Hospital Association and released yesterday.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 19 (AP) Newlyweds Meyer L. and Gladys Sugarman sat in the honeymoon suite of a resort hotel here today and spoke about "a very gracious, gentlemanly man." They meant President Johnson, whose overnight stay here tonight threatened for a time to scuttle their honeymoon plans.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 19 An October wedding is planned by Miss Jill Warren Edwards, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Newton Edwards, and Frederick Bittner Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bittner of Poughkeepsie, N.Y. The parents of the future bride have announced the engagement.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 The City of Chicago obtained an injunction today limiting the number and size of civil rights demonstrations.
MADISON, Wis., Aug. 19 A small group of migrant workers completed an 80-mile march today and presented their demands for better pay and living conditions to state officials.

A youth who has been in jail here since June 22 for a robbery he could not have committed because he was in a Hackensack, N.J., prison at the time of the crime had the charge against him dismissed yesterday. However, he was not freed.

A collision of unions in the harbor last year left its toll of men overboard, of whom seventeen licensed municipal ferry officers remain out of work. They were fired for striking in violation of the CondonWadlin Act. They had bolted the National Maritime Union for the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, another A.F.L.-C.I.O. affiliate. The N.M.U. crushed the revolt by providing replacements for the rebels.
The stock market lost ground yesterday for the fifth successive session.
Officials of the five airlines that had been struck said yesterday that flights would be resumed today on a belownormal basis but that fullscale operations would be under way by Monday.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) announced yesterday that its affiliate, the International Development Association, had granted a $150million industrial import credit to India to bolster the country's sagging economy.

Would you believe one million? A tiny cake, a tall candle and a hearty kiss were Anna Moffo's presents to Alfred Lunt yesterday on the occasion of his 74th birthday. "Haphazard," said License Commissioner Joel J. Tyler speaking of the growth of the city's sidewalk cafes since new regulations governing them were released in May, 1965.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 President Johnson's $1.2-billion plan for erasing city slums passed the Senate today after a sharp debate. The vote was 53 to 22.

Jacob Buchholtz, who retired in 1961 as chief of the bureau of administration of the city controller's office, died yesterday at the New York Infirmary. He was 76 years old and lived at 235 East 22d Street.

Forty Federal, state and city legislators from the metropolitan area urged Mayor Lindsay yesterday to rehire 17 municipal ferry officers and lift penalties against 122 others. They were involved in a strike against the Staten Island Ferry service in May, 1965.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19--The index of primary market prices increased one-tenth of 1 per cent to 106.5 (1957-59 equals 100) during the week ended Aug. 16, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Prices of farm products declined while processed foods advanced. Industrial commodities averaged unchanged.
When a New York Stock Exchange official stepped to the rostrum and rang the closing gong yesterday afternoon at 3:30 P.M., Wall Streeters were not sorry the week was all over.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 19 Two British officials arrived today for a new round of talks with officials of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's Government on the crisis caused by its declaration of independence last November. They were noncommittal about the progress made to date.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 19--Australian soldiers killed more Vietcong in four hours yesterday than they had previously since they began fighting in Vietnam in June, 1965.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19 One of the most attractive matches to be seen here in recent years in the National Lawn Tennis Hall of Fame invitation tournament was set up today when Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., and Arthur Ashe of Richmond, the two ranking players of the country, qualified to meet in tomorrow's semi-finals at the Casino.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 A mighty home run by Richie Allen that came with two out in the 10th inning and sailed high over the left-field roof of Connie Mack Stadium gave the Phillies a 5-4 triumph over the New York Mets tonight.

GIMBELS put a wholly unauthorized copy of Luci Johnson Nugent's wedding dress into one of its 32d Street windows yesterday and it made as much impact as a box of rice tossed at a departing bride and bridegroom.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 The longest and costliest airline strike in the country's history ended tonight in its 43d day as members of the machinists' union approved a new contract with five major airlines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI) The Senate approved and sent to the White House today a $214-million legislative appropriation bill that prevents any construction on the proposed extension of the West Front of the Capitol until next year.

Two groups protested, yesterday the manner in which a New York lawyer, Prof. Arthur Kinoy of the Rutgers University law faculty, was ejected Wednesday from a hearing of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

The 3 there completed Wall's 69 after Ellis had finished minutes earlier with a 68 over the 6,568-yard course.
Queens residents, routed by terrified screams early yesterday morning, acted to save a young woman who had been attacked by a man with an ax on a dark Elmhurst street.
Thirty years of scheming and arguing ended successfully yesterday for Robert Moses as he bent over a shovel to break ground at the World's Fair site for the city's only cageless zoo.

Schmidt of the Eastern Cruiser Association, in his Queen Bee with an error of 1.33 per cent. This is the second American Power Boat Association-sanctioned contest won this year by Commodore Schmidt.

The pitcher, a 5-year-old girl with pigtails, tosses a crushed beer can at a small boy in a red jersey. He swings at it hard with the cardboard core from an oilcloth roll.

One of the most remarkable features of the earth's surface is an almost continuous valley that snakes across it for some 40,000 miles. Its existence has become known only in recent years because most of it lies under water. It cleaves the mid-ocean ridges that bisect the great oceans, in particular the Atlantic, and is visible only in the few places where it appears above water.

LONDON. THE other day, there was yet another successful get-away in broad daylight by several prisoners from Wormwood Scrubs, a gloomy old-fashioned jail in the middle of London. An official of the association stated: "If the public demands a more liberal regime for prisoners, it must expect that it is easier for them to escape."
