What more fitting memorial for Frederick Law Olmsted could there be than the Olmsted Trailway, a footpath that would wind through the linear park now proposed for the Staten Island greenbelt? One of the designers of Central Park and an American pioneer in landscape architecture, Mr. Olmsted made his home on a farm on Staten Island.

The American Research and Development Corporation, a Boston-based venture capital investment company, has acquired a 52.5 per cent interest in the Miller Fink Publishing Corporation of Stamford, Conn., it was announced over the weekend. Terms were not disclosed.

EVREUX AIR FORCE BASE, France, Aug. 19 In a softly menacing drawl, the colonel said into the telephone that Somebody had been giving his officers ultimatums. Somebody will please knock if off, he said.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Aug. 21 (AP) Mr. Emmaunel's mother, Mrs. Thomas H. Emmanuel, said: "We did not give up hope. We knew we'd find him alive and we're very sorry about the other one, Grimaldi."
BUFFALO, Aug. 21 (UPI) The New York Pioneer Club won the National Amateur Athletic Union one-mile relay run today in the 32d annual Buffalo Firefighters Games.

The Cuban revolution is full of paradoxes and one of them is the continued willingness of Premier Castro to let Cubans leave the island as fast as the United States can take them. However, a puzzle within the paradox is the declaration by Foreign Minister Raul Roa yesterday that no Americans living in Cuba will be given exit transportation until all Cubans desiring to leave have gone.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz said today that the recent increase in steel prices and bank interest rates had done more damage to the nation's economy than the new contract ratified by striking airline machinists.

JAKARTA, Indonesia Under the crystal chandeliers of the great hall of the Negara Palace, President Sukarno stood in his stockinged feet on a Persian carpet and exhorted the assembled Indonesian officials to obey "all my teachings."
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21 (AP) Sandy Koufax pitched a six-hitter and struck out 10 batters today to gain his 20th victory as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the St. Louis Cards, 4-1.

PEKING, Aug. 21 (Reuters) Crowds of teen-agers virtually took control of Peking's shopping streets today, ordering shopkeepers, restaurant managers and even hairdressers to rid themselves of Western ways.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 21 Miss Judith Mindel, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Mindel of Newton, Mass., was married this afternoon to Richard Efman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Efman of the Bronx.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 Drenched by rain, 500 civil rights workers led by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. marched five miles through an all-white neighborhood here this evening in another demonstration for open housing. They were met as in previous marches in other all-white Chicago neigborhoods, by jeers, curses and insults.
TRENTON, Aug. 21 (UPI) Ray Hendrick of Richmond won the fourth annual Trenton 200 modified stock car race today for the second successive year.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 21 Miss Deborah Ann Gould, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl A. Gould, was married this afternoon to Robert David Stillman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Stillman of New Paltz, N.Y.

Miss. Hilda Wiedenfeld has resigned as managing director of the Textile Distributors Association, Inc., a trade group made up of textile converters and wholesalers. She had served in an executive capacity in the association and its predecessor organization, the Textile Distributors Institute, Inc., since the formation of the institute in 1938.
EDWARD ALBEE rises from the black brown tufted leather sofa, and, with an oblique glance swept by the long lashes that shadow his eyes, holds out his hand.

SEATTLE, Aug. 21--Grand Master Robert Byrne of Indianapolis and Dr. Anthony Saidy of San Francisco moved into a first-place tie in the United States Open Chess Championship after completion of the seventh-round games at the Seattle Center here last night. Each has scored 6 points.
The appointment of John R. Kane and L. Felix BledSoe to new executive positions with the Newport News (Va.) Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company has been announced by D.A. Holden, chairman of the board.

CAIRO, Aug. 21 The Supreme State Security Court today sentenced seven leaders of the illegal Moslem Brotherhood to death by hanging after finding them guilty of conspiring last summer to assassinate President Gamal Abdel Nasser and overthrow the Government.

MANHASSET, L.I., Aug 21 21 Tony Vincent of New York, seeded first, defeated Fred Kovaleski, also New York, 6-2, 6-3, in the final of the United States clay-court tennis championship for men 35 years and over today.
When Federal Judge Dudley B. Bonsal cleared last Friday all but two of the 12 Texas Gulf Sulphur Company insiders charged with turning advance information on a
The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor and leaders of the longshore industry have agreed that the port needs more dock workers.

PALISADES PARK, N.J. Aug. 21 John J. Dickerson, former Republican State Chairman, and for many years Republican leader of populous Bergen County, died in his sleep last night at his home, apparently of a heart attack. He was 66 years old and lived at 54 East Oakdene Avenue.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 21 (AP) Floyd Robinson and Smoky Burgess sparked a three-run rally in the seventh inning that gave the Chicago White Sox a 3-2 victory over the Cleveland Indians today.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 21 More than a million terrified people in the earthquake disaster zone in eastern Turkey are living in the open. They refuse to take shelter in houses still standing for fear of new shocks.
The New York Yankees said good-by yesterday to the Kansas City Athletics and to Whitey Ford, and for vastly differing reasons were sorry to see both depart.
VIENNA, Aug. 21 Viennese reacted strongly today to the bombing that destroyed the Italian airline office near the State Opera yesterday and damaged neighboring buildings.

SOMERSET, N.J., Aug. 21 Michael J. O'Donnell, retired teacher and dean of the lay faculty at St. Francis Xavier Military High School in New York, died Thursday in St. Peter's Hospital, New Brunswick. He was 77 years old and lived at 10 Summerall Road here.

A 14-story distribution and office center to be built over the Pennsylvania Railroad tracks in midtown Manhattan will be financed under a $26.3million agreement with the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company.
A pilot project in plastic surgery has shown that disfigured ex-convicts are less likely to lapse into crime again if their sears and deformities are removed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) Fulton Lewis Jr., the commentator who broadcast his conservative views for nearly 30 years over the Mutual Broadcasting System network, died at Doctors Hospital here today. He was 63 years old.

ELKINS PARK, Pa., Aug. 21 Miss Eileen Louise Sichel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Loeb Sichel of Cheltenham, was married this afternoon to Paul Alan Bloustein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Bloustein of Riverdale, the Bronx, New York.

ATHENS, Aug. 21 The supreme military tribunal in Greece has set Aug. 30 for the retrial of Pvt. Christos Kazanis, the 22-year-old Jehovah's Witness sentenced to death two weeks ago for having refused to bear arms.
A Greek Orthodox congregation changed boroughs yesterday and celebrated the occasion in a bank's parking lot with a high mass, a barbecued lamb picnic and traditional Greek dancing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 Following are excerpts from a report on antibiotics prepared for the Food and Drug Administration by the committee on the veterinary medical and the nonmedical uses of antibiotics:

The B.V.D. Company, Inc., the diversified apparel producer, is consolidating 20 wholly owned companies into six new merchandise divisions in a plan to strengthen and streamline its expanding operations, Sol Kittay, president, announced over the weekend.

TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 22--Scientific data of vital concern to the growth and development of the Pacific area will be presented, studied and discussed in the next three weeks at the largest science congress ever held in Asia.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 21 In the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Chapel today, Mrs. Charlotte Fox, a teaching fellow and doctoral candidate at the Harvard Graduate School of Education, was married to Peter Temin, an assistant professor at the Alfred P. Sloan School of Management at M.I.T.

A 23-block East Side subway spur was proposed yesterday to serve the growing financial community of Lower Manhattan and to help prepare for the development of residential neighborhoods at the tip of the island.
MOSCOW, Aug. 21 (Reuters) Pravda, the Soviet Communist party newspaper, accused China today of launching into what it called crude slanders against the Soviet Union and its party.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 21 It is complete ly fascinating. There are firemen everywhere, 134 companies from all over Connecticut come to New London for a convention. Fire engines are tearing through the town as if all hell had broken loose and Connecticut was doing its best to put it out.
The Government has been advised in a report being released today to tighten its requirements on the use of antibiotics in food-producing animals and as food preservatives.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 21- Steel producers and steel users were waiting last week for signs of a new market trend.

SAIGON, South Vietnam Aug. 21 United States B-52 bombers from Guam struck today at the suspected headquarters of a Vietcong division near the Cambodian border and at North Vietnamese troops two miles south of the demilitarized zone between North and South Vietnam.

HAVANA, Aug. 21--Foreign Minister Raul Roa said today that, while the Cuban Government would not hold up the departure of 880 United States families now in Cuba, they would have to wait until all those "who have a right to leave" do so under the refugee agreement between Cuba and the United States.

Fieldcrest Mills, Inc., has appointed Frank W. Green as president of its Fieldcrest division to succeed G. William Moore, who earlier this year had been elected executive vice president of the parent corporation, it was announced over the weekend.

WATERBURY, Conn., Aug. 22 Mr. and Mrs. J. Douglas Lunan of Middlebury have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alexandria Dodds Lunan, to Martin S. Rosen, son of Mrs. Caleb Rosen of Brooklyn, New York, and the late Mr. Rosen. A September wedding is planned.
LONDON, Aug. 22 (Reuters) Britain published today a report that it said provided convincing evidence that North Vietnamese troops had been operating in Laos.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 22 Open Fire broke the Saratoga track record for 1 1/8 miles while winning the $28,400 Diana Handicap by 10 lengths today for the Brandywine Stable. The 5-year-old daughter of Cochise amazed the crowd of 14,136 with her great speed. She was timed in 1:48 4-5 on a sloppy track.
The General Motors Corporation received yesterday contracts totaling $36.5-million for production of munitions and for conversion of aircraft.

It was possible yesterday, for those with Christmas shopping in mind, to buy a $1,500 35pound suit of armor, suitable for detergent-delivery use, or a $60 wooden clothes valet, a swim cap at perhaps $5 or $6 in mod and op-art style with chin strap and visor, or a gold or silver lame dress of paper for not much more.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 22 Directors of the 13,000-member California Nurses Association have turned their backs on an antistrike policy adopted in 1950 by the American Nurses Association.

GENEVA, Aug. 22--An exhibition of United Nations stamps has rolled out of the Palais des Nations, the world organization's second home here, in a gleaming aluminum trailer that will travel about 7,000 miles through Eastern and Western Europe before it returns in November.
William Tell may have won a point with his bow and arrow but he has lost a round with the Selective Service System.

AMONG spaghetti eaters, there are front winders, side loaders, shovel ers, twirlers and slurpers, as demonstrated by 30 Cub Scouts from Pack 246, Mineola, L.I., at a recent luncheon. The scouts have also developed a vacuum action, a cut and push form and an intriguing gravity flow from fork and finger.

The block workers in the South Bronx Community Progress Center often spend their time sitting in the office at 368 East 149th Street rather than working among the poor. The reason? The center has not received its money for carfare yet.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 Organized labor's high command strongly supported today a fouryear-old program for assisting trade unions in Latin America.

VAN NUYS, Calif., Aug. 22 (UPI) Peter Fonda, 26 years old, an actor, and three other men were ordered held for trial today on charges of possession of marijuana. Mr. Fonda is the son of Henry Fonda, the actor.
DETROIT, Aug. 22 The automobile industry rejected today a demand by the United Automobile Workers that contracts be reopened to give special pay rises to workmen with skilled trades.
Stock prices continued in full retreat yesterday, pushing leading market indicators to new lows for the year.
TORONTO, Aug. 22 Canadian railway unions representing 115,000 workers today set noon Friday for the start of a national railway strike if significant wage increases are not won.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UPI) The Senate, spurted by the sinking of the cruise ship Yarmouth Castle, voted today to bar from United States ports all passenger vessels deemed unsafe by the Coast Guard.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 22 The Babylon Tuna Fishing Club's 10th annual marlin and tuna fishing tournament was won for the first time yesterday by the host club as 615 tuna and three marlin were boated ...

FURNITURE pieces designed to display objects are available in stores today in increasing num ber and variety. Probably not since the Victorian Age has there been such interest in showing off one's possessions.

United Air Lines, Inc., reported yesterday it had sustained losses last month of $7,736,000 "because of the strike" by the machinists union. In the same month last year, the company had a net profit of $6,731,000.
Bache Co. will acquire the main office and 12 branch offices of Richard J. Buck Co., another member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, effective Sept. 1.

TRENTON, Aug. 22 (AP) Three million New Jerseyans are eligible to vote in the Sept. 13 Congressional primary elections, a slight tail-off from last year, the Secretary of State's Office reported today.

DISCARDING in defense in a manner that will not help the declarer can be a delicate operation. If dummy has a four-card suit including at least one high honor, a defender will strive to preserve a four-card holding in the same suit. But if he has five cards in dummy's four-card suit one discard would seem to be entirely safe.
Somewhere in New York, there is a group of subwayriding music-lovers with weak memories and thieving tendencies. About 25 per cent of 3,300 ads for a music festival have disappeared.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 22 Vietcong gunfire brought down two allied planes this afternoon in the Mekong delta, 120 miles southwest of Saigon, a United States military spokesman said. Both pilots were rescued.

LONDON, Aug. 22 (Reuters) A subsidiary of Britain's second biggest industrial complex announced today that one of every nine of its staff was being dismissed because of the Government's deflationary policy.
ST. CATHARINES, Ont., Aug. 22 (Canadian Press) The St. Lawrence Seaway Authority soon will use closedcircuit television to speed traffic through the Welland Canal.
Mrs. Hal Davis took her year-old pup to the Parks Department's new Dog Obedience Training Class in Central Park yesterday. It seemed to be a good idea. He's much bigger than she is.
Northwest Airlines' services on the Seattle-to-Honolulu and Seattle-to-Anchorage runs will not resume until Thursday.

CAIRO, Aug. 22 Forty-nine more members of the illegal Moslem Brotherhood were convicted and sentenced to prison today by the Supreme State Security Court for trying to revive their organization and to force charges in the United Arab Republic's Constitution.

Mrs. Mary Hemingway, widow of Ernest Hemingway, said yesterday that she had accepted long ago that her husband committed suicide, but that she had never been quoted in print to this effect "because no one happened to ask me."

A group of Harlem youngsters danced to the music of an African-Cuban combo in an old loft yesterday, and occasionally one of them would strike an actor's pose and casually toss out a profane line obviously learned in the streets.

Henry M. Curran, a New York State Senator who is chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee to Revise the Banking Laws, has announced the appointment of 10 members to the Advisory Council of his committee.

With traditional hoopla, officials of Trans Caribbean Airways yesterday broke ground for the National Airlines terminal at Kennedy International Airport. Among the absent were representatives of National Airlines.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 The State Department has asked the Havana Government not to impede the return to this country of 700 to 800 United States citizens still in Cuba.
ADEN, Aug. 22 (AP) The Federation of South Arabia today closed its border with Yemen, banned trade and said it would deport 105 Yemenis tomorrow.
PEKING, Aug. 22 Young people in Peking's streets publicly cut off their long hair and slashed their narrow trousers tonight.

Mr. and Mrs. Christian Cardin of New York and Paris have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Cardin, to Francois Grandchamp des Raux, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard des Raux of Paris. The wedding is planned for Oct. 8 in Fleurines, near Paris.
The credit markets were in a bearish frame of mind 3-yesterday.
GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 22 (AP) Two young men publicly disagreed with their father today by picketing the roofing company he owned and for which they worked.

The Brown and Sharpe Manufacturing Company, a machinetool producer, filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday covering the proposed sale of $7,088,700 of convertible subordinated debentures, due Oct. 1, 1986.

The Middle South Utilities, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains of 5.4 per cent in total operating revenues and 3.8 per cent in net income for the 12 months ended July 31. Shares earnings declined by 0.9 per cent because of a 4.3 per cent increase in shares outstanding during the past year.

The United Service Organization, a voluntary civilian group that serves the spiritual, welfare and educational needs of the Armed Forces, will be honored on U.S.O. Day, Sept. 3, at the 1966 United States National Tennis Championships at the Forest Hills (Queens) Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 Arthur J. Goldberg pledged today that the United States "will never agree" to the expulsion of Nationalist China from the United Nations as the price of Communist China's admission.

Stock prices declined sharply in active trading yesterday, carrying leading market indicators to new lows for the year. The Dow-Jones industrial average fell 12.59 points, to 792.03, its lowest closing level since Feb. 10, 1964.
A delegation of Quakers, mailed yesterday token parcels of medical supplies to Canada for transshipment to the North Vietnam and Vietcong Red Cross.

There is a touch of irony in the timing of its trend-spotting, but the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association sees a trend toward print in advertising, and toward newspapers in particular.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Aug. 22 Seymour S. Epstein, a partner in the law firm of Sulzberger Sulzberger, 295 Madison Avenue, New York, died today in his home at 119 Carthage Road. He would have been 47 years old on Sept. 7.
A jury of 11 men and one woman was chosen yesterday for the trial of an official of the bricklayer's union and his wife on charges of income-tax evasion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 Ever since W. Averell Harriman was first called to public service by Harry Hopkins in 1934, to become New York State Administrator of the N.R.A., he has never refused a summons in the name of the public interest. Therefore, it is natural that, when disaster befell the United States in on a of the many areas of his proficiency, his name would lead all the rest in the search for reparation.

Investor purchases of mutual fund shares fell last month to $362,883,000 from $380,459,000 in June, according to figures compiled by the Investment Company Institute. In July, 1965, purchases amounted to $331,971,000.
WALLKILL, N. Y., Aug. 22--Miss Elaine Lascow and Henry Wagner of New York plan to marry Sunday in New York.

The New York Civil Liberties Union in a statement to a Republican platform committee yesterday, renewed charges that parochial and nonsectarian private schools were being used "as a last haven of segregation."

The cause of humane treatment of animals has achieved a merited victory in Congress. Both houses last week approved a bill that for the first time establishes strict regulations over the interstate traffic in animals used for medical research.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 22 (UPI) The federal police fired tear-gas bombs in a crowded street tonight to break up a demonstration by 300 students protesting Government intervention at the University of Buenos Aires.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) The Senate approved today a bill to give Federal regulatory agencies new powers to control unsound practices of banks and savings and loan...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) Senator John Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, said today he had asked that further funds be withheld from the Child Development Group of Mississippi pending an investigation into the group's affairs.
The Liberal party formally declared its intention last night to run an independent candidate for Governor.

JAKARTA, Indonesia The military police ripped open a bamboo cupboard in the corner of a shabby Javanese bungalow and confronted the crouching fugitive, who arose, faced the guns, and said: "I am Aidit."

Walter Germann, wealthy international Swiss banker, failed once again to appear before a Federal grand jury yesterday. As a result, the Government moved to collect a $25,000 fine plus $1,000 for every day he does not go before the panel.

TRUJILLO, By Robert D. Cressweller, 468 pages, Macmillan, $8.95. IF as Emerson remarked, an institution is the lengthened shadow of one man, then the Dominican Republic during Trujillo's reign must have been in perpetual night. One reads Robert D. Cressweller's engrossing account of Trujillo's 31-year dictatorship with morbid and eventually sickening fascination. It is a history of a nation, ...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UPI) Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, charged today that the company once headed by Matthew H. McCloskey, long a contributor to the Democratic party, was allowed to underbid a competitor for a $12.6-million Government contract after the deadline had passed.

CLARKSBURG, W. Va., Aug. 22 (UPI) Sam Snead of White Sulphur Springs won his 10th West Virginia Professional Golfers Association championship today. He shot a final 61 for a Clarksburg Country Club course record.
The election of Michel E. Puyans as executive vice president was announced here yesterday by the Great Lakes Carbon Corporation.

The engagement of Miss Alida Livingston Fish and Keith Henry Chiappa has been announced here. Miss Fish is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Stuyvesant Fish of Cluster Village in Warwick, Bermuda, and a granddaughter of Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish of New York and Mount Kisco, N.Y., and the late Mr. Fish. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Chiappa of Parquito at Spanish Point in Pembroke, Bermuda.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 22 Shouting "Books, si! Boots, no!" mobs of angry students taunted heavily armed police units today as the University of Buenos Aires reopened part of its buildings scattered about this capital.

The August soybean contract, last of the old crop months, expired with a flurry yesterday. It was up the limit of 10 cents bushel during the day and at the close, indicative of the strength that carried it a while ago to a lifetime high of $3.98 a bushel. The close was $3.86 .

OCEANSIDE, L.I., Aug. 22 Dr. Howard T. Herber, Superintendent of the Malverne School District, died yesterday in the South Nassau Community Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 69 Lexington Avenue, Malverne.

The Amagansett (L.I.) Historical Society and the Miss Amelia, Museum there will receive proceeds from a tour of six homes in or near Amagansett tomorrow. These homes are noted for their architecture and decoration.
Narcotics anents seized a jar that they said contained 40,000 closes of LSD yesterday from a man who pulled a gun on an undercover agent.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 22 (AP) President Tito charged today that enemies from abroad were stimulating foes of socialism in Yugoslavia "to undermine the successful development of our country."

The engagement of Miss Miriam Carmel DeCock, daughter of Mrs. Romain DeCock of Gysegem, Belgium, and the late Dr. DeCock, to Guy Camu has been announced here. Mr. Camu is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Willy Camu of Hekelgem, Brabant, Belgium.

LONDON, Aug. 22 (AP) More elaborate meals and faster planes are cutting the time that airliner staffs have to devote to passengers, stewards and flight hostesses for the British Overseas Airways Corporation complained today.
The New York Philharmonic played to total audiences estimated at 396,000 during its 12 free concerts in city parks this summer. Last summer the estimated total was 462,500 persons.

SWEET peppers are frequently referred to as bell peppers because of the shape of the leading variety. The green mature peppers are crunchy and tangy; when red-ripe, they are sweeter. Once purchased, the peppers should be stored in the vegetable crisper or in plastic bags.

Ira M. Younker, a department store executive and philanthropist who introduced many reforms into family welfare work, died here last Wednesday after a brief illness. He was 82 years old and lived at 480 Park Avenue.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Aug. 22 A leading critic of the Administration and a State Department spokesman, discussing the Vietnam war at the 19th congress of the National Student Association today, agreed that a new trend toward moderation was apparent among students.

The Federal Maritime Commission announced yesterday that four steamship conferences had decided to reduce ocean freight rates for the State Department and other Government agencies to the same level the Defense Department has been paying.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 22 (UPI) Lou Johnson's single in the bottom of the 12th inning gave the Los Angeles Dodgers a 4-3 victory over the Atlanta Braves tonight.

SAIGON, Tuesday, Aug. 23 (AP) A United States-chartered merchant ship hit a mine in the Saigon River today and was reported sinking. At least six crewmen were reported killed and four more are missing.
PARIS, Aug. 22 A long and difficult flight from Peking to Hanoi was described in vivid terms tonight by a French correspondent, Jean Raffaelli.
The National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that it would televise a musical show that stations owned by the Columbia Broadcasting System had declined to present.

Ten steamship lines and a conference have petitioned the United States Court of Appeals in Washington to reject a recent Federal Maritime Commission decision that approved competitive bidding for military cargoes.
LONDON, Aug. 22 The Labor Government's controversial wage freeze is threatening to undercut the very thing Britain wants most an increase in national productivity.

SARASOTA, Fla., Aug. 22 Rear Adm. William Augustus Evans, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Evans of Bird Key have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diane Margaret Evans, to John Amos Marks, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Shapard Marks of Birmingham, Ala.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 22 (Reuters) British and Rhodesian officials met for more than three hours today in the third round of exploratory talks aimed at settling differences arising from Rhodesia's declaration of independence.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 The interest rate on three-month Treasury bills declined a little at today's auction from last week's record, but the rate on six-month bills rose to another new high, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
A 72-year-old sailor who became ill while trying to cross the Atlantic alone in an 11-foot boat has been taken aboard the Coast Guard cutter Ingham.
NOROTON, Conn., Aug. 22 The Noroton Yacht Club, captained by Philip Franklin, led the way today through the qualifying series of the Long Island Sound Midget sailing championship.
Trinity Church and buildings occupied by three of its chapels in Manhattan have been designated as landmarks, the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission announced yesterday.
BONN, Aug. 22 The commanding general of the West German air force was temporarily relieved of his command today as a result of his demand last week for the reorganization of the Defense Ministry.

An assortment of piquant novelties, a 20th-century classic and a work by Beethoven were played by Musica da Camera in Washington Square Park in the second of the three free concerts the chamber wind ensemble is giving there this month.

The Food and Drug Administration will propose today that the raw flesh of poultry and fish must not show the residue of two antibiotics used to preserve them. The action is intended to eliminate a possible public health hazard.
LONDON, Aug. 22 (UPI)--Three shipbuilding concerns in Clyde said today that they had agreed to merge.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP)--Senator J.W. Fulbright said today that he still opposed United States policy in Vietnam even though he believed Moscow, Peking and Hanoi would "be grievously deceiving themselves if they underestimated the militant spirit" in the United States.

Richard L. Weiss has been appointed vice president of Levitt Sons, home builders of Lake Success, L.I. He formerly was vice president in charge of the real estate division of the Sunset International Petroleum Corporation of Beverly Hills, Calif. Another Levitt appointment is that of Miss Bernice J. Banks to the new position of manager of interior design.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 22 (AP) Mrs. Peninah S. McLaurin, a retired teacher who was the first Negro to apply for admission to the University of Oklahoma, died Saturday in a hospital here. She was 74 years old.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 22 A proposal to enlarge the Suffolk Board of Supervisors and establish weighted voting will be presented to county voters in a November referendum.

LONDON, Aug. 22 (Reuters) The nation's greatest manhunt moved into its 10th day today with the 400th reported "sighting" of Harry Roberts, who is wanted for questioning in the murder of three London policemen.

Five Manhattan State Senators protested yesterday what they called the Consolidated Edison Company's "gigantic" advertising and promotion campaigns in connection with its request for higher electricity charges.

WHILE the greatest New York Met team in history stormed into Chicago yesterday, the Yankees were redeploying troops like mad. They placed Whitey Ford on the disabled list, then placed him aboard an airliner for St. Luke's Hospital in Houston.
SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 22 A new possible challenger for the America's Cup in September 1967, took to the water for the first time today.

The political crisis in West Germany over crashes of Starfighter planes revolves chiefly around domestic issues. But the row that had led to suspension of the German air force chief brings into question again the wisdom of the continued Pentagon pressure on Bonn to buy more American weapons than either the German Government or its military leaders want.

Fares between New York and the Virgin Islands will be cut this winter by Pan American Airways if the Civil Aeronautics Board approves, the airline announced yesterday. The company also said the number of flights would be increased.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 22 Colombia altered her complex foreign-exchange-rate structure today in a moderate devaluation of the peso.
"My pipes aren't the best in the world," said Robert Presiton.
MONTEREY, Calif., Aug. 22 (AP) Maj. Gen. Richard C. Moore, retired, former Army deputy chief of staff, died yesterday on the golf course of the Monterey Peninsula Country Club. He was 85 years old.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) Thousands of nursing homes throughout the country will be invited this week to participate in the Medicare program to provide extended-care services.

BONN, Aug. 22 A merger between the Bayerische Motoren Werke, A.G. (B. M. W.) and Hans Glas, G.m.b.H., apparently will be the next step in the increasing concentration of West Germany's automobile industry.
TOKYO, Aug. 22 (AP) North Vietnam said today that transport and communications systems throughout the country had been improved and expanded despite United States air strikes.
DETROIT, Aug. 22 (AP) The automobile industry picked up speed today in its drive to build a full schedule of 1967model cars before model introduction time next month.

TOKYO, Aug. 22 (UPI) North Vietnam officially denounced all United States ef forts to find a peaceful solution for the Vietnam war today and rejected the proposal of its Asia neighbors to hold a peace conference.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that the American Electric Power Company and the Michigan Gas Utilities Company might have broken the law in connection with the purchase of stock in another utility the Michigan Gas and Electric Company.
The Board of Elections closed 33 of its 114 special voter registration locations yesterday, after two weeks in which some places enrolled as few as three new voters.

Auto men are almost congenitally bullish, but Matthew S. McLaughlin, assistant general manager of the Ford Motor Company's Ford Division, dropped a pinch of caution yesterday into the outlook for next year.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange retreated along a broad front yesterday.
Met with U.N. Ambassador Goldberg; conferred with John Macy, chairman of the Civil Service Commission.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 22--General Suharto, chairman of the Cabinet Presidium, has blamed Communist infiltration for Friday's riots in Bandung, the West Java capital.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 22 The Asian Development Bank, devoted to helping Asian lands accelerate economic growth, came into legal existence today.

MILLBURN, N.J., Aug. 22 Edward F. Lonergan, Democratic Essex County committee chairman of this township for 48 years, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital, Summit. He lived at 330 Millburn Avenue here. Reticent about his age, at the time of his retirement in 1965 he admitted to being "over 75."
The spot rate on the British pound was mostly steady in quiet trading on foreignexchange markets here yesterday. The currency closed at $2.7883, down one point from its closing level on Friday.

DENVER, Aug. 22 (AP) Sinclair Oil Corporation has filed a $1.2-million suit against the Oil Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union. The company charges the union has attempted to "frustrate the normal ratification process" of a proposed contract agreed to on Aug. 4.
Secretary Rusk warned in a speech here yesterday that a premature American pull-out from South Vietnam would "Surely" lead to World War III.
A 150-minute documentary film called "Rush to Judgment," dealing with the assassination of President Kennedy and the findings of the Warren Commission, is in the final stages of preparation here.
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 22 (UPI) Four teams from the United States and four foreign entries will compete in the 20th annual Little League World Series starting tomorrow.

HOUSTON, Aug. 22 (AP) Curt Flood drove in two runs and Steve Carlton pitched a seven-hitter tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Houston Astros, 3-0. Carlton allowed only one Astro to reach third as he gained his first major league shutout.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 The confusion that attended the New York Mets' delayed flight yesterday from Philadelphia was still in evidence today at Wrigley Field. The New Yorkers opened a four-game series in desultory fashion, losing to the Cubs of Leo Durocher, 8-4, on a sunny, windy afternoon before a crowd of 4,105 paying fans.

Dr. and Mrs. Maury D. Sanger of Atlantic Beach, L.I., and Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Sanger, to Dr. Murray Zung, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Zung of Brooklyn. A December wedding is planned.

WEST CHESTER, Pa., Aug. 22 (AP) A 16-year-old high school sophomore trying out for his school's football team drowned Sunday night in what police called a hazing incident. The victim, Lamont R. Jenkins, died in the swimming pool at Camp Arrowhead in Willistown Township.
David M. Goodstein of 130 East 75th Street, a retired manufacturer of women's sports dresses, died Sunday of a heart attack here. He was 72 years old.
Both sides reported progress yesterday in contract negotiations between the Western Electric Company and the Communications Workers of America.
Two leading jazz piano stylists, Thelonious Monk and Bill Evans, appeared in two concerts last night at the Rheingold Central Park Music Festival.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22--Consumer prices continued their steady rise in July, the Labor Department reported today.

Fifteen professors ousted from St. John's University appealed yesterday a decision by the Tribunal of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn 10 days ago not to intervene in the teachers' strike at the university.
CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 22 (UPI) Marine Cpl. Douglas M. DeHaas of Camp Pendleton, Calif., was named the winner today of the Leech Cup competition at the national highpower rifle matches here.
Steel production eased threetenths of one per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
Two savings banks in the New York area announced yesterday changes in trustees and operating executives.

VALDESE, N.C. Aug. 22 (AP) Burke County's Sheriff, famed for his raids on moonshiners, died last night of a gunshot wound in the neck. Five hours later his accused slayer was flushed from a neighbor's house.

YONKERS, Aug. 22 Royally bred Pay Dirt, a chestnut colt by Florican out of Impish, who was by The Intruder, captured the $25,000 Scotland Trot for 2-year-old colts and geldings at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 22 The South Vietnam Government plans to use computers and aerial surveying to spur its lagging land-reform program, authoritative sources disclosed today.

The special stockholder meetings scheduled for Thursday of Spartans Industries, Inc., and E.J. Korvette, Inc., to vote on a merger proposed by both managements have been postponed for a month, the companies announced yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 22--Secretary of State Dean Rusk told U Thant today that the United States wanted to de-escalate the Vietnam war but that there had been a lack of interest on the part of Hanoi and its allies.

GUATEMALA, Aug. 22 A brawl in a cabaret early yesterday in which a student and two army lieutenants were killed raised political tempers in Guatemala today, pointing up the sharp division between military and civilian elements.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 22 (UPI)--The old ballyhoo of politics erupted here today with a bang--also with a bong, a croon, a blare of loudspeakers and a swish of slogan-lettering paintbrushes.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 22 (UPI) Hal Lanier drove in two runs in a perfect day at bat and Lindy McDaniel pitched four scoreless innings in relief today to pace the San Francisco Giants to a 5-2 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 22 Host-club contestants won two of the top three prizes in today's Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association's Westchester district pro-amateur tournament at the Winged Foot Golf Club.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 22 The Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra left Israel today, a popular and critical success despite a slow start and some formidable obstacles. This was the fourth stop on a 10week tour sponsored by the United States Government.
"The next rally when it starts will be a good one. There's so much bearishness around Wall Street, the market probably won't go much lower."
GARY, Ind., Aug. 22 (AP)--Acquisition of The Gary Post-Tribune by Northwest Publications, Inc., was announced today by H. B. Snyder, president of the newspaper.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 22 John S. Adams, who retired in July, 1964, as president and publisher of The Atlantic City Press, died of a cerebral hemorrhage this morning at his home. He was 59 years old and lived at 19 North Mansfield Avenue, Margate.

Deere Co., the farm equipment producer, reported yesterday record sales and earnings in the three-month and ninemonth periods ended July 31. William A. Hewitt, chairman, attributed the showing to a rise in North American sales.
MERIDEN, Conn., Aug. 22--A 39-year-old Hartford man remained in critical condition today after having spent six days trapped beside a dead man in the wreckage of an airplane.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Jennifer Bronwen Nielsen to Peter Charles Kahn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor F. Kahn of New York. The future bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arild Nielsen of Brisbane, Australia, where a Dec. 17 wedding is planned at the Chapel of Emmanuel College.

The Board of Education is considering a recommendation to establish an organization that would give free performances of plays in high schools and dramatize aspects of various study programs in classrooms.

SEATTLE, Aug. 22 The pace-setters, Grand Master Robert Byrne of Indianapolis and Dr. Anthony Saidy of San Francisco, met in the eighth round of the United States Open Championship at the Seattle Center here last night. Cautious tactics by both players in a 20move King's Indian Defense led to a balanced position and a draw.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 22 (UPI) The Government warned today of the danger that cholera might sweep the earthquake disaster area of eastern Turkey.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) The Senate passed today a bill authorizing an international agreement to construct a drainage system in Mexico. The system is designed to clear salt water from the lower Rio Grande.
MONTREAL, Aug. 22--Eight canoes of the type used by Canada's earliest explorers set out today on a Centennial and Expo '67 World Exhibition mission to New York.
IN A GLASS DARKLY, by Janet Caird (Mill: Morrow, $3.95), Novel of suspense.
BOSTON, Aug. 22 A class of 42 executives of franchising companies became students at the Harvard Business School today at the opening of a fiveday seminar.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 President Johnson announced today that he would renominate Gerald A. Brown to the National Labor Relations Board despite the strong opposition of the United States Chamber of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 Mayor Lindsay said today that it would take $50-billion more in Federal funds in the next decade to transform New York City into "a thoroughly livable and exciting place in which to live."

KINSHASA, the Congo, Aug. 22 Cyrille Adoula, the Congolese Ambassador to Belgium, has been appointed Ambassador to the United States and is expected to leave for Washington early next month, the Congolese news agency reported today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 Federal aid to education is a great thing according to Representative Roman C. Pucinski, but rules, regulations and guidelines are reducing teachers' effectiveness.

The usually lighthearted Beatles press conference took on a serious tone yesterday as the mop-haired singers fielded questions on the war in Vietnam, bigotry in the United States and the comments by one member of their quartet on Christianity.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 The outcome of the nation's biggest airline strike appears to have damaged both President Johnson's value as an enforcer of Government economic stabilization policies and the policies themselves.
In Bangkok, the Chineseborn intelligence officer said, most Chinese businessmen display a photograph of Gen. Chiang Kai-shek in their office.
JUNEAU, Alaska, Aug. 22 (UPI) An Alaska Coastal Airlines pilot, Paul Morf, was flying eight passengers over Eagle Glacier yesterday as part of a scenic trip from Skagway to Juneau.
ASHEVILLE, N.C., Aug. 22 (AP) Holt F. Callaway, a retired vice president of the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company, died yesterday in a hospital here. He was 76 years old.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 Many "flying saucers" may be balls of ionized air originating along high-tension electric power lines, an authoritative aeronautical journal suggested today.
Spring Mills, Inc., announced here yesterday the appointment of James P. Kelley as executive vice president in charge of sales. He succeeds Burnet valentine, who will retire Aug. 31.

ROME, Aug. 22 (UPI) Pope Paul VI today named two Haitian-born priests to fill key posts in Haiti following an agreement last week that "normalized" relations between the Vatican and the regime of Dr. Francois Duvalier.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UPI) Secretary of State Dean Rusk has "no intention of resigning" despite his comments about his financial problems, a State Department spokesman said tonight.

BONN, Aug. 22 Friends of Lieut. Gen. Werner Panitzki say he fits the pattern of a modern West German general hard working, intelligent, considerate to his subordinates and steering clear of party politics but taking care to stay on good terms with ...

Four major department stores will have their own buildings in a shopping center planned by the Leonard L. Farber Company of New York on a 60-acre site at Pompano Beach, Fla., about eight miles north of Fort Lauderdale.

Aid in many forms and from many countries is being rushed to earthquake-stricken Eastern Turkey, where over two thousand people have died and a million others are seeking safety by abandoning their homes, living in the open while the tremors persist.

Two of the nation's major department store chains Federated Department Stores, Inc., and Associated Dry Goods Corporation registered record sales and earnings in the three-month and six-month periods ended July 30, their reports disclosed yesterday.
When the Nimbus 3 weather satellite is launched next year, its primary function will be to provide day and night pictures of the clouds that swirl about the earth.

Because of the length of the airline strike, many people have forgotten how to fly. The following guide, compiled with the help of some of the country's most dynamic airplane passengers, is intended as a refresher for all who are caber to get back into the sky but are hesitating for fear of committing a faux pas.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Aug. 22 Thomas F. Gagan, dean of the Rockland County Bar, died here today after a heart attack at the home of a daughter, Mrs. M. Ambrose McCabe, with whom he made his home. He was 86 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) The Senate, after hearing charges of windfall profits, returned to its Public Works Committee today a bill to extend a program of lease con struction of post office buildings.
Owens-Illinois, Inc., the Toledo, Ohio, glass producer, realigned yesterday the senior executives of its $15-million Bahama Island sugar operation.

"Hope Is My House," by Devorah Wigoder, will be issued by Prentice-Hall on Sept. 22. This is the autobiography of a woman born Jane Frances MacDwyer and raised in the Roman Catholic faith who became Jewish and took the name Devorah Emmet Jaffe. She subsequently married Geoffrey Wigoder, a Jewish scholar from Dublin whom she met while studying at the Jewish Theological Seminary in New York. They live with their two sons in Israel.

LONDON, Aug. 22 (Reuters) English cricketers beat the West Indies by an innings and 34 runs in the fifth test match at The Oval today to salvage a consolation victory from a series that the world champion West Indies won by a 3-1 margin.

Policemen from Manhattan were sent to the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn early today to help break up crowds of disorderly persons roaming. A police spokesman said the trouble was not a result of racial disorder and was "fairly common on a hot night like this."
MONTREAL, (Canadian Press), Aug. 22 Canadian National Railways and Canadian Pacific Railway announced today embargoes on freight and express shipments of a variety of goods.

CAIRO, Aug. 22 In an unexpected reversal of policy, the United Arab Republic has decided to permit two destroyers from the United States Sixth Fleet to pay an official visit to Port Said early in September.
Arnold Hoffmann, an artist best-known for his anti-Nazi paintings, died Sunday night in Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. He was 80 years old and lived at 144 East 58th Street.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 The General Services Administration said today it was standard practice to try to negotiate lower prices after contractors have submitted proposals for a construction contract.

Governor Rockefeller is logging pre-convention mileage on the issue of Democratic "bossism," an allusion to the charge that Frank D. O'Connor, that party's front-runner for the gubernatorial nomination, is the beneficiary of an unsavory deal.

For the sixth consecutive session prices on Canadian markets declined yesterday. Brokers attributed the development to tight money, the international situation and, especially, the weakness on Wall Street.

A DOZEN Seventh Avenue manufacturers are seek ing Government assistance in cracking foreign markets. Calling themselves the American Exporters of Fashion, they are asking the United States Department of Commerce for designation as an industry-organized trade mission.
Margaret Smith of Australia will not defend her title in the United States championships starting Sept. 1 at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.
A strike by construction plumbers here entered its fifth week yesterday, and a building industry spokesmen said that the walkout had halted $250-million in construction.
PITTSBURGH, Aug.22 (AP) Bill Mazeroski's triple sparked a four-run rally in the fifth inning and gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 6-5 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) A bill that was originally drafted to prevent picketing of the church marriage of Luci Johnson and Patrick J. Nugent was passed today by the House, 249 to 44, and sent to the Senate.

The stock market keeps sliding downhill in the face of a still lusty economy and inflationary symptoms that normally would be expected to make stocks an attractive hedge against depreciation of the dollar. Wall Street is never the most trustworthy barometer of the actual or prospective state of business, but some of the factors operating to pull down stock prices are plain enough.
David Eisenhower, 18-yearold grandson of former President Dwight D. Eisenhower, has broken a family tradition by deciding not to go to West Point.
ISLIP. L.I., Aug. 22 Mr. and Mrs. Roy E. Pardee have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Maureen Partiee, to Richard G. Saunders, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Saunders of Sag Harbor.
VILLAGE VANGUARD, 178 Seventh Avenue South. Ornette Coleman, saxophonist.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) New guidelines for the advertising and labeling of automobile tires, designed as a stop-gap measure until Congress fixes minimum safety standards, will go into effect next Feb. 19, the Federal Trade Commission said today.
Representatives of the World Journal Tribune, Inc., met separately yesterday with four unions in an effort to end the 121-day shutdown of the new publishing company.

While the New York Stock Exchange rocked under another selloff yesterday, Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey lunched quietly near the exchange board room with top Wall Street figures and talked of Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 During the next two months, Senator Robert F. Kennedy is planning one of the most ambitious national campaign schedules ever undertaken by a freshman Senator. The New York Democrat's office has received nearly 100 invitations. They have come from candidates for Governor, Senator and Representative, from ... Democratic state and county chairmen and from many lesser politicians and officeseekers.

CAMP PERRY Ohio, Aug. 22 The rattle and snap of high-powered muskets mark the final week of the month-long national shooting matches. There is probably no other sporting event in the United States with more competitors. When the final shot is fired on Saturday, 5,441 small-bore rifle, pistol and high-power rifle shooters will have competed for a large array of prizes and trophies.
Three men accused of having assaulted a Green Beret lieutenant and his father early yesterday appeared in Criminal Court later in the day, obviously the losers in the fight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 The House Committee on UnAmerican Activities got no support today from the Johnson Administration for its controversial bill to set criminal penalties for obstruction of the Vietnam war effort.
AMBAH, India, Aug. 21 As dusk fell last night along the muddy banks of the Kunwari River, a dozen bandits crept into the little fishing village of Bholaramkapura.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Aug. 22 (UPI) A third Roman Catholic priest who broke his vow of celibacy to marry has joined in a movement here to get the church to lift the vow.

Two scientists intimately involved in making the atomic bomb swore yesterday that the key scientific evidence used to convict Julius and Ethel Rosenberg and Morton Sobell of espionage in 1951 was worthless.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 22 The Indian Harbor Yacht Club's junior novice open regatta began today with two races in each of two Blue Jay Class divisions. They were sailed inside Captain's Harbor in light southwesterly breezes. There were 35 crews representing 11 member clubs of the Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound.

Among the Americans hardest hit by the recent upsurge of consumer prices are the millions of workers at the bottom of the wage ladder, many of whom already earn so little that they must rely on public relief to supplement their weekly pay envelopes. These workers will be the chief beneficiaries if the Senate acts swiftly to approve the liberalized minimumwage bill unanimously voted last week by its Labor Committee.

A half moon came through the haze last night. Rafita Martinez, strumming a guitar and singing softly and richly, moved with heavyset grace across the stage. The beneficent presence of Puerto Rico settled on the Delacorate Theater.

At a series of noisy rallies on the steamy sidewalks of Queens and Brooklyn, Governor Rockefeller challenged Democrats yesterday to investigate their intramural charges of "deals" for the nomination for Governor.
LOUISVILLE, Aug. 22 (UPI) Cassius Clay, the heavyweight boxing champion, will try a new type of attack to stay out of the Army he will seek deferment as a Black Muslim minister.
PLAINVIEW, Tex., Aug. 22 (AP) An explosion ripped a church here tonight, injuring 40 to 50 persons and trapping 12 under the building's falling roof.
MADISON, N.J., Aug. 22 A Federal air-pollution expert said here today that an expanding economy would bring increased air and water pollution.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 The sheriff of Cook County urged the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. today to call off a march for open housing in suburban Cicero, scheduled for next Sunday.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22 Three of six defendants arrested in police raids on meeting places of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee here Aug. 13 were held in $50,000 bail each for court today on charges involving possession of dynamite. The other three persons were freed.

ALBANY, Aug. 22 Senate Majority Leader Earl W. Brydges will be named to deliver the keynote address, and Assembly Minority Leader Perry B. Duryea to be permanent chairman, at the Republican state nominating convention next month.
SAYVILLE, L.I., Aug. 22 The week-long Thistle class national sailing championship began today amid confusion caused by a wind that refused to settle.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 22 (AP) Jorge Velasquez rode Mrs. Ben Cohen's Bacasiwo to a one-length victory over Mighty Happy today at Atlantic City.

The scientific units of the city's Police Department will be overhauled as the result of a doctoral thesis by an inspector who studied on weekends, wrote on vacations and slept only five hours a night for four years.
The leaders of a proposed major-league United States professional soccer league said here today they would definitely open competition in April, 1967.

ATLANTA, Aug. 22 (AP) Dr. King said here tonight that he did not plan to cancel the Cicero march and that he felt civil rights leaders had met the request of Chicago officials by giving a week's notice of intentions to go into the area.
MARIA STADER, the Swiss soprano, was soloist at the Mozart Festival Concert given by the New York Chamber Orchestra at Philharmonic Hall last night, and she brought down the house.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 Victor Hugo Proetz, curator of the Alice Pike Barney Memorial Collection of the Smithsonian Institution, and special consultant to the editor of Museum News, publication of the American Association of Museums, died Saturday at George Washington University Hospital. He was 69 years old. Mr. Proetz was an architect and interior designer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UPI) Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, announced today that the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations would open hearings Wednesday on Governmentinsured multifamily housing projects built as part of the urban renewal program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) Frank Kowalski, a former Democratic Representative who has become a critic of President Johnson's policy in Vietnam, said today he felt "a little sad" about not being renominated to the Subversive Activities Control Board.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) Democratic leader Mike Mansfield of Montana reminded his Senate colleagues today that, unless they start legislating, the current Congressional session, like time, "will be endless."

Charles H. Weissner Sr., a retired vice president of ReynoldFitzgerald, Inc., newspaper advertising representatives here, died Sunday at his home, 214 Babbit Road in Bedford Hills, N.Y. He was 70 years old.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 President Johnson directed John W. Gardner, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, today to begin a "major study" of rising medical costs.
HOUSTON, Aug. 23 J.H. Creekmore, president of the Houston Endowment, was listed yesterday as publisher of The Houston Chronicle.
BELLMAWR, N.J., Aug. 23 (UPI) Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested another suspect today in a drive on an alleged nationwide ring that extorted money from homosexuals.

LONDON, Aug. 23 (AP) A solution to the problem of marriages between Roman Catholics and Protestants is needed if there is to be church unity, Dr. Harold Roberts, a former president of the World Methodist Conference, said today.
