Some men grow under stress, others stiffen into rigidity. The speeches here this week by Secretaries Rusk and McNamara, both subjected to the tremendous strains of the war in Vietnam, illustrate the two phenomena. The Secretary of Defense sounded the statesman, while the Secretary of State expounded the increasingly rigid outlook that has come to characterize his views.
The Women's Auxiliary Board of the New York Philharmonic is sponsoring the gala opening of the orchestra's forthcoming season, to take place on Sept. 28 at Philharmonic Hall.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Aug. 23 (AP) George Haggarty of Grosse Pointe, Mich., won his first-round match today in the world senior golf championship at the Broadmoor.

NASHVILLE, Aug. 23 (AP) Metropolitan detectives today investigated the disappearance of 1964 and 1965 financial records of Local 327 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. The police listed the case as a theft.
The American Stock Exchange made another comeback try yesterday, but ended again in the loss column for the seventh straight session.
The International Finance Corporation announced yesterday it would join with European and Senegalese investors to finance a West African fertilizer plant at a cost of $12.4-million.
The spot rate on the British pound continued mostly steady in moderate trading on foreignexchange markets here yesterday. The currency closed at $2.7882, down 1 point from Monday.

Acquisition by the General Mills Corporation, Minneapolis, of the Tom Huston Peanut Company, Columbus, Ga., is expected to be completed on Saturday, the final day of the Tom Huston company's current fiscal year, it was said yesterday by E.W. Rawlings, president of General Mills.

SOME players habitually overbid because they have optimistic temperaments, while others underbid for the converse reason. Such players will be losers in the long run, but occasional overbidding or underbidding may be a paying proposition if it is based on an estimate of the ability of the four players at the table.

LAKE RONKONKOMA, L.I., Aug. 23--An Air Force captain, his wife, and their four young children were killed this afternoon when their rented plane crashed here on an unfinished section of the Long Island Expressway.
WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 23 Harry R. Sherwood of 5 Maple Lane, one of the oldest practicing lawyers in the state, died today in Westport Manor, a convalescent home and hospital. He was 93 years old.

The Singer Company announced yesterday it had enlisted the aid of Enoch Light, the orchestra leader, to direct its entry into the production of phonograph records. The company, known mainly as a maker of sewing machines and household products, including phonographs, said Mr. Light would be president and chief executive officer of a new company in which both parties would hold a half interest.

TORONTO, Aug. 23--When Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson shuffled his Cabinet last year, quite a few heads shook in disbelief at his selection of a lawyer and former business executive as his Labor Minister.
United States businessmen were advised yesterday to change their thinking about the nature of export trade to the Far East in general and Japan in particular.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 The three commercial television networks voiced a host of reservations today about the Ford Foundation's proposal for a nonprofit satellite television system to help finance educational video.
HURRICANE ISLAND, Me. Sam Robinson, a strapping teen-ager from Newark, looked down into the 48degree ocean water into which he was supposed to jump.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 23 (AP) One body was recovered and four others were presumed buried in rubble of a wire manufacturing company executive office building ripped by an explosion today. The blast injured 19 other persons and destroyed a $1.38-million computer.
Stock prices swung erratical- ly and declined slightly at the close yesterday in the heaviest trading in three months.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 Republicans were moving quickly today toward a new Vietnam policy that emphasizes peace negotiations in an all-Asian conference instead of a hard line of stepped-up military activity.

Actors Equity Association was rewarded last night with a certificate of appreciation from Mayor Lindsay for the union's "outstanding contribution and exceptional services to the New York City antipoverty program" by allowing its members to perform without salaries this summer at various centers affiliated with Operation Head Start.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 23 (AP) Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach has asserted executive privilege in ordering the Federal Bureau of Investigation not to produce conversations among Las Vegas gamblers.
AUGUSTA, Me., Aug. 23 (AP) Two of Maine's big buck deer are going to live in Texas as a result of President Johnson's visit to Maine last weekend.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 The Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations threw its strength and prestige today behind two merged California farm labor groups engaged in a bitter representation election battle with the Teamsters Union.
Miss Maureen Lois Moffatt and Thomas Engelhard Myers Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Myers of Charleston, S.C., plan to be married in November.

PLAINVIEW, Tex., Aug. 23 (AP) Investigators today blamed a natural gas leak for a thundering explosion that sent the roof crashing down last night on 200 worshipers in the Negro Church of God in Christ. A woman was killed and 53 other persons were injured by the falling debris.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 Senator J.W. Fulbright said today that he believed that the "real purpose" of the United States in Asia was to stay there indefinitely to counterbalance Communist China.

SAYVILLE, L.I., Aug. 23 Tom Wilson of New York sailed Waterloo to victory in the third race of the Thistle Class national championship today after fiinshing fourth this morning and took the lead in the series being sailed in Great South Bay off here.

MORE than 150 entries have been received by the Northern New Jersey Region of the Sports Car Club of America for the eight 30mile area championship races it will conduct at the Lime Rock, Conn., course on Saturday. One of the star drivers entered is Sam Posey of

TORONTO, Aug. 23 Canada's Labor Minister, John R. Nicholson, indicated today that a national railroad strike set for noon Friday approved inevitable despite what he called an excellent response from both sides to his offer of personal mediation.

Readers of The Times obituary page may have noticed that the In Memoriam column on Monday carried seven tributes to one Richard Plantagenet, "piteously slain and murdered" on Boswell Field in 1485 and since then "slandered by the Tudors" presumably through their insidious public-relations man, William Shakespeare.
IT'S been a fantastic sum mer," said 23-year-old Ann Gilford.

CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 23 (Reuters) Arthur Calwell, leader of the Opposition Labor party, charged tonight that the dispatch of troops to Vietnam was "the worst mistake Aus- tralia has ever made in foreign affairs."

BLANTYRE, Malawi, Aug. 23 Dr. H. Kamuzu Banda, President of Malawi, told Parliament today that work on developing Lilongwe as Malawi's new capital would start immediately. "I've decided to take the plunge," he said.

W.R. Grace Co. and the Miller Brewing Company, two old-line companies founded in the eighteen-fifties, may join forces through an option Grace is said to hold to buy a 53 per cent interest in the privately owned Milwaukee beer concern.

Dean Chance defeated the New York Yankees last night for the first time in 12 months, pitched his first shutout of 1966 and provided a rousing flashback to the days when he was billed as the brightest young pitcher in baseball.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 23 An Army marksman took the top place in the Wimbledon Cup shootoffs today in the national matches. Sgt. 1st Cl. Cecil L. Stevens of the Army Marksmanship Training Unit at Fort Benning, Ga., hit the V ring firing in the "any rifle" category to eliminate his two rivals for the Victorian era trophy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) The Interstate Commerce Commission refused to combine today the nearly completed merger case of the Chicago North Western and Chicago Great Western railroads, with a new battle for control of the Chicago Rock Island Pacific railroad and the North West ern.

Exceptionally hot weather caused an abnormal rise in auto thefts last month, Michael J. Murphy, president of the National Automobile Theft Bureau, said yesterday. He said 46,926 cars were stolen throughout the country.

Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary yesterday swore in Harold Baer Jr., a former assistant United States attorney, as executive director of the civilian-dominated Police Review Board in a brief ceremony at Police Headquarters. Mr. Baer said that he would start on his new job at 9:30 A.M. today, faced with a caseload of 100 complaints against policemen. The complaints range from accusations of brutality to insults and slurs against civilians.
CHICAGO, Aug. 23 The New York Mets got back on the right track today on a sunny, cool afternoon in Wrigley Field by beating the Chicago Cubs, 4-1.

The promoters of the United States Soccer Cup of Champions said yesterday that they had doubled the number of special policemen for the tournament's second game tonight at Randalls Island betwen A.E.K. of Greece and Santos of Brazil.
Mayor Lindsay told Brooklyn businessmen yesterday that the city was seeking Federal aid to begin planning for redevelopment of almost half the borough.
John Clark Knox, a judge for 46 years on the busiest Federal bench in the nation, died yesterday at his home, 160 Central Park South, after a long illness. He was 84 years old.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday proclaimed Sept. 2 through 18 as "Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit Days."
SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 23 (UPI) Faith, the sixth tropical storm of the season, whipped up to hurricane strength late today and raced westward with winds of up to 85 miles an hour.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 23 A State Supreme Court justice held today that residents of Sleepy Hollow had raised legitimate questions about moving State Route 117 away from Governor Rockefeller's home and ordered the case to trial next month.

CHAMONIX, France, Aug. 23 (Reuters) Gary Hemming, 33-year-old American mountaineer, was cheered as a hero by a crowd here today as he arrived in a helicopter with two German climbers whom he saved after they had been trapped for five days on an Alpine ledge.
MEAUX, France, Aug. 23 (UPI) Two priests received prison sentences today for having robbed 79 churches in the Paris area during the past four years.
A 97-mile railroad that will play a key role in the giant Pennsylvania-New York Central merger is up for sale.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 "Any Negro youngster who doesn't believe now that the way to get something is through violence obviously is not intelligent," Bayard Rustin, dynamic civil rights leader who advocates nonviolence, asserted today.

The head of a $10-million-ayear gambling syndicate based in Westchester and his chief lieutenant were sentenced to prison yesterday in Federal Court. Both had pleaded guilty to violating Federal gambling laws.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 23 There is growing concern here about a bill before the Dominican Congress that would curb political activity until three months before the next electoral campaign. It is feared the bill, if enacted, might alienate political parties from the Government of Dr. Joaquin Balaguer.

LAWRENCE, L.I., Aug. 23 Miss Judith Fern Rosenberg's engagement to Marshall Feuer has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Rosenberg. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Menkes Feuer of New York and Long Beach.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 23 (AP) Bill White drove in four runs with a pair of bases-loaded singles to lead the Philadelphia Phillies past the Pittsburgh Pirates, 5-4, tonight behind the seven-hit pitching of Chris Short.
HOUSTON, Aug. 23 (AP) Bob Gibson pitched a three-hitter and Dal Maxvill drove in two runs and scored the third as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Houston Astros, 3-0, tonight.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 23--Governor Rockefeller carried his re-election campaign from the sidewalks of New York to the farmland and resorts of the North Country today.
Moshe Koussevitzky, one of the leading cantors of his time, died yesterday at his home, 135 Hicks Lane, Kings Point, L.I. He was 67 years old.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 23 Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Adler have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Adler, to Victor Bers, son of Prof. and Mrs. Lipman Bers of New York.
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 23 (UPI) Sacramento, Calif., and Houston scored openinground victories today and moved into the semi-finals of the 20th annual Little League World Series.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI) Key lawmakers praised Secretary McNamara's plan to lower military induction standards, but some questioned whether Mr. McNamara was aiming more at rehabilitation of the unfit than providing needed military manpower.

The J.C. Penney Company, one of the nation's largest general merchandising organizations, registered records in sales and earnings in the 13 and 26 weeks ended July 30, its report disclosed yesterday. Sears, Roebuck Co. is the largest in the field.

The Board of Education said yesterday that it would be "virtually impossible" to start a pre-kindergarten program for 7,000 children here next month, as planned, because a strike of construction plumbers meant that many schools would not be usable.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 23 Vietcong terrorism has been at a relatively low level since the beginning of August. An American tabulation shows fewer incidents each week than in July.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission said today it had ordered Knoll Associates, Inc., of New York City to stop discriminatory pricing of its modern furniture.
City Council President Frank D. O'Connor said yesterday that he had gained enough pledged delegate strength to win the Democratic nomination for Governor on the first ballot.
At noon yesterday, with stock prices wobbling lower, a man riffled the ticker tape in the Yale Club at 50 Vanderbilt Avenue and asked his companion: "Where is that rally?"
LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 24 (Reuters) Television chiefs issued a warning to millions of youngsters today after an inquest on a boy who died while imitating his masked and cloaked hero. "Batman."
The profit taking in potato futures that depressed prices in recent sessions abated yesterday. Renewed interest among speculators pushed prices upward.

SEATTLE, Aug. 23 Grand Master Robert Byrne of Indianapolis assumed the undisputed lead in the United States Open Chess Championship by defeating the Rev. William Lombardy of Yonkers, N.Y., in their ninth-round game at the Seattle Center here last night.

TRENTON, Aug. 23 James Farmer proposed a state antipoverty program here today that would, he said, ultimately eliminate the functional illiteracy of one million New Jerseyans. The state's population is more than seven million.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 23 They snarled and they grunted through this morning's mist, 108 of them hurling themselves over the damp grass as assistant coaches bellowed, "Faster, faster, gotta hurt, gotta hurt."

BALTIMORE, Aug. 23 (AP) Sam McDowell, apparently recovered from a long siege of arm trouble, pitched a six-hitter and Rocky Colavito collected his 28th home run as the Cleveland Indians beat the leagueleading Baltimore Orioles tonight, 2-1.
Nationwide contract negotiations opened here yesterday between the General Electric Company and the International Union of Electrical Workers with an exchange of angry statements.

TEANECK, N.J., Aug. 23--Supported by outraged citizenry, the police of this community pressed an intensive search today for vandals who had painted swastikas on the windows and walls of one of the township's five Jewish houses of worship.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) President Johnson announced today that he intended to nominate Miles S. McKee, 55 years old, of Grosse Pointe, Mich., to the advisory board of the St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation.
A 17-year-old white youth was cut on the face last night as whites exchanged insults with Negroes in the border area between the Bedford-Stuyvesant and Williamsburgh sections of Brooklyn.

Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara disclosed yesterday that 40,000 draft rejects and substandard volunteers, most of them with "poverty-encrusted" backgrounds, would be "sal- vaged" for military duty in the next 10 months.
Mayor Lindsay estimated yesterday that the city would receive $840.2-million in Federal aid in the 1966-67 fiscal year.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23 (AP) Willie Davis's two-run single with two out in the ninth inning capped a three-run rally tonight and gave the Los Angeles Dodgers an 8-7 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 The Export-Import Bank reports that there has been no request from Prodexports, the Rumanian trade company, to guarantee a loan to finance the construction and equipment of a pork processing plant in Rumania.
The Transit Authority has lost a substantial number of riders since raising its fare but has gained a substantial amount of revenue, the Authority chairman, Joseph E. O'Grady, said yesterday.
Mrs. Stephen Wahl of 1185 Park Avenue has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Stephanie Ruth Wahl, to Ronald J. Lavit, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Lavit of Woodmere, L.I.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 23 The 10th annual Beach Point Yacht Club overnight race for the junior distance sailing championship of Long Island Sound began in a light drizzle today, with a fleet of 23 auxiliary cruising yachts heading eastward from off Scotch Caps in a 10-knot westerly that lightened shortly after the guns were fired.

Paperboard production rose 6.6 per cent with 414,800 tons in the week ended Aug. 20, from the 414,8000 tons in the corresponding 1965 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 23 In St. John's Episcopal Church this evening, Miss Jane Casad Hockett, daughter of Dr. Robert Casad Hockett and the late Mrs. Hockett, became the bride of Pvt. William Fredrick Carey 3d, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carey.
LOUISVILLE, Aug. 23 (AP) Cassius Clay, the heavyweight champion, a copy of the Koran under one arm, appeared at a special hearing today to ask for a draft deferment on religious grounds.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 23 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky has indicated he favors an exchange of North Vietnamese prisoners for downed American fliers, a New York Rabbi said tonight.
TOKYO, Aug. 23 Last spring, even with Japan in the grip of a recession, there were two jobs for each high school graduate in Tokyo.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) Willie Kirkland's pinchhit home run in the eight inning gave the Washington Senators a 4-3 victory over Minnesota tonight and a split of their double-header.
"Minor" progress was reported as contract talks continued here yesterday between the Western Electric Company and the Communications Workers of America.
The Federal Maritime Commission began an official investigation yesterday into ocean freight rates that American steamship companies have been charging various departments of the Government.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 23 India has moved a full division of troops to the Pakistani border opposite the city of Sialkot, Pakistani sources said today.
MOSCOW, Aug. 23 (AP)--Six Russian Baptists have been sentenced to prison terms for "antisocial activities," including the poisoning of children's minds, a Soviet newspaper said today.

The Central and South West Corporation reported yesterday operating revenues of $245,073,752 for the 12 months ended July 31. This compared with $228,634,797 a year ago. Net income rose to $46,177,322, equal to $2.17 a share, from $42,206,706, or $1.98 a share on fewer shares, in the 1965 period.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23 (AP)--The San Francisco Warriors acquired today Walter Dukes, a 7-foot former National Basketball Association star.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Aug. 23 Arthur Murray of Cedarhurst, the 1966 Eastern regional champion, took the lead today in the sixth annual Cougar Catamaran national championship after two races in East Rockaway Inlet. The races were conducted by the Cedarhurst, Yacht Club in a light southerly breeze over a five-mile Gold Cup triangular-windward-leeward course.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 23 A proposal to create a state department of service to answer inquiries from the public was made today at a meeting of the Republican Advisory Platform Committee.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI) A National Labor Relations Board examiner ruled today that entertainers were illegally required to join the American Guild of Variety Actors as a condition of employment.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI) The United States Chamber of Commerce joined today a parade of individual food producers in opposing "far packaging and labeling" legislation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) The House Interior Committee approved today a controversial bill calling for Federal-state action to protect and develop the scenic, recreational and other resources of the Hudson River.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 Reports from South Vietnam now indicate somewhat fewer combat incidents involving large North Vietnamese units and somewhat more guerrilla and terrorist attacks than might have been expected.
Reform of the antipoverty program's complicated financial procedures will "definitely" be a first priority of the new Human Resources Administration, the agency's acting director said yesterday.
GENEVA, Aug. 23 (Reuters) The United States denied today that it was blocking work on a treaty to stop the spread of nuclear weapons, as Communist nations have charged.

The battle to save the rare and beautiful dunes of the Great Lakes has not yet been won. After first suffering an upset defeat, conservationists in the House Interior Committee under the leadership of Representative John Saylor, Pennsylvania Republican, rallied their forces and retrieved the bill to establish the Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore in Michigan. Final action by the House at this session seems likely but is not certain.
HAMPTON, Va., Aug. 23 (UPI) Lunar Orbiter was ordered today to snap a moon'seye view of the earth, 240,000 miles away.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 23 Edmund B. Rose Jr., president of the Rutkin Electric Supply Company here, died yesterday at his home in nearby Ocean Township after a long illness. He was 64 years old.

Despite earlier indications to the contrary, at least two American features will be shown at the fourth annual New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center from Sept. 12 to 22. Both are well over 30 years old.

ADEN, Aug. 23 The South Arabian Federal Council was today told that giving up the habit of chewing kat was a small price to pay to fight Yemen-inspired terrorism in the South Arabian Federation. Yesterday the border was closed and trade with Yemen was forbidden because of hostile Yemeni propaganda and terrorism.
MADISON, Wis., Aug. 23 (AP) A West German automobile manufacturer is being sued in a Madison Circuit Court for negligence in designing and constructing a car without certain safety features.

SHINNECOCK, L.I., Aug. 23 Billy Pagels of Sayville, L.I., who won the Blue Jay Class national championship last week, added another laurel today, taking the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's juniors single-handed championship.

Irving Wormser, former president of Continental Distributing, Inc., and Carl Peppercorn, former executive vice president of Cinema V, have formed a new corporation to produce and distribute films for theaters and television.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 Negro and white demonstrators for open housing were jeered and pelted with rocks, bottles and firecrackers tonight as they marched through the all-white Chicago suburb of South Deering.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 23 (UPI) Gov. George C. Wallace's legislative program to fight Federal school desegregation guidelines was given overwhelming preliminary approval in the General Assembly today.
Directors of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company voted here yesterday to raise the quarterly dividend by five cents a share, to 42 cents.

More than 45,000 teen-age girls and a few anguished parents as well rent the sultry Flushing Meadow air with shrieks and moans last night as the Beatles returned to Shea Stadium for their annual concert.

BONN, Aug. 23 GEn. Heinz Trettner, highest-ranking officer in the West German armed forces, has resigned because of a dispute with Kai-Uwe von Hassel, the Minister of Defense, it was disclosed tonight.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23--Francis X. Bushman, the romantic hero of the silent screen, died today after an accident in the kitchen of his home in suburban Pacific Palisades. An ambulance crew, summoned by his wife, Iva, pronounced him dead. He was 83 years old.
A general increase in the interest rate charged automobile dealers on loans to finance their inventories appeared to be in the offing yesterday.

BEL AIR, Calif., Aug. 23 Mr. and Mrs. Peter Colefax have announced the engagement of Mrs. Colefax's daughter, Miss Penny Cook, to William J. Gemar, son of the late Dr. William J. Gemar and the late Mrs. Alvin H. Engle of Omaha.

SARASOTA, Fla., Aug. 23 (AP) Circuit Court Judge John Justice issued a writ of habeas corpus today that could mean freedom for Dr. Carl Coppolino, 34 years old, a former New Jersey anesthesiologist charged with two murders.
Former heavyweight champion Floyd Patterson and his wife of 10 years, have been divorced, Mr. Patterson's attorney, Julius November, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 The Senators Kennedy succeeded today in adding about $570-million to President Johnson's antipoverty budget.
It was a busy day at Kennedy International Airport 1,319 flights going in and out, many on the instruments that are the pilots' eyes in murky weather.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 23 (UPI) Two teen-agers captured top honors today in the class championships of the 67th Grand American Trapshoot.

YONKERS, Aug. 23--Dr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Schwartz have announced the engagement of Dr. Schwartz's sister, Miss Jeanne Patricia Schwartz, to Dr. Myron J. Zitt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Zitt of West Hempstead, L.I.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) A Federal Trade Commission examiner recommended today the dismissal of a complaint charging R.H. Macy Co. of New York City with misbranding wool products.

Seamen of the National Maritime Union who failed to be voted into national office in the labor organization's election last spring will carry a fight for union reform to its national convention in October.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 A subcommittee of the House Committee on Un-American Activities approved today a bill setting criminal penalties for giving aid to the Vietcong and North Vietnam and for obstructing the movement of United States troops and military supplies.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 Senate-House conferees agreed today on a compromise bill to pump $4.76-billion more of Government mortgage purchase funds into the sagging homebuilding industry.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 110.5 on Monday from 110.6 on Friday.

Plans for Cinema Center, the $50-million project of office buildings, theaters and movie studios designed to go up on the site of the present Madison Square Garden, are being revised to give substantially more space to film-production facilities.

DALLAS, Aug. 23 (UPI) Six aircraft covered about 75,000 acres with insecticide today in the air war against the encephalities-carrying Culex mosquito, but city health officials said that the disease had claimed its sixth fatality.

Institutional investors do not like to show their trading hands, particularly when they have laid out a large-scale buying program in a stock. They tend to nibble at the market through, a painstaking series of relatively small individual transactions until they have reached their objective.
Just 37 days before the Japanese bombed Pearl Harbor and plunged the United States into World War II. Freedom House was established in New York.
Richard Dowling, author of the novel "All the Beautiful People," died on Thursday in St. Barnabas Hospital. He was 37 years old and lived at 60 Gramercy Park.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) President Johnson announced today he would nominate Leo S. Packer to be Assistant Postmaster General for the bureau of research, development and engineering.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 23 (AP) Meadowbrook Farms' Buz On relished the rain and took the feature race by a head from the fast-closing Big Rock Candy at the Atlantic City race track today. He paid $32.20 for $2 to win.
West Point-Pepperell, Inc., the textile producer, announced yesterday the formation of three new divisions, effective Aug. 29.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff declared today that, despite its glitter and claims to greatness, "right now the City of Los Angeles, doesn't stand for a damn thing."

ATHENS, Aug. 23 Greece is resisting a Soviet proposal for an international trading contract that would carry a hedge against a possible devaluation of the United States dollar. The contract involves a major commercial deal.
DETROIT, Aug. 23 (UPI) Michigan's Attorney General Frank Kelley, said today that he had been threatened with bodily harm and political ruin since he began an investigation of organized crime.
PAGO PAGO, American Samoa This smallest of United States territories seven South Sea islands with a total area of 76 square miles and a population of 26,000 has ceased to be one of the most backward.
GENEVA, Aug. 23 (AP) Membership in Lutheran churches throughout the world has reached 74.5 million, an increase of 2 per cent over 1963, the Lutheran World Federation said today.
In the heaviest trading since May, stock prices swung erratically yesterday and closed with a slight loss on average.
STOCKHOLM, Aug. 23 Rodney Sline, a professor of education at Louisiana State University, has been ordered to change the subject of lectures he has been giving at Swedish teachers training institutes.

LONDON, Aug. 23 The Thomson Organization, Ltd., publishers of The Sunday Times of London and other newspapers and magazines throughout the world, has formed a new paperback book company, Noonday Books, Ltd.
BRASILIA, Brazil, Aug. 23 A public, unofficial debate over South Africa's policy of strict racial separation, started today with delegates from 27 countries attending.

CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 23 (AP) The New Hampshire Racing Commission disclosed today it had revoked the licenses of five persons at the Hinsdale Raceway. The commission said the revocations were made under a rule forbidding possession of drugs, hypodermic syringes or needles.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI) The United States Commissioner of Education said today that the best solution to the problem of racially distorted schoolbooks was to expose them to public view.
COTTAGE GROVE, Ore., Aug. 23 (UPI) Hundreds of fire fighters took advantage of calm weather today and "contained" Oregon's worst forest fire since the end of World War II.
PEKING, Aug. 23 Thousands of teen-agers enforcing China's tough new drive for a stricter Communist way of life closed and defaced Christian churches today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 23--Petite Rouge demonstrated her liking for the Saratoga track by scurrying to an expected victory in the feature six-furlong race today. Backed confidently by the 12,191 customers, she paid $3.80 for $2 to win.

This may come as no surprise to public relations practitioners they've been saying how important they are to management for years but there is now some documentation that public relations is achieving top-level management status in the nation's leading industrial corporations.
DELL CITY, Tex., Aug. 23 (AP) Army helicopters ferried water, food and vaccine into flood-Stricken Dell City tonight after deluges of rain struck far western Texas and eastern New Mexico.

A 28-story office building is planned by St. Andrews Associates, an investment group headed by Peter J. Sharp, a real estate man, on the southeast corner of the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) and 56th Street.

WHAT a pleasure it is to come across a really good first novel, particularly when it is by a very young author. This is the more remarkable because he is still, presumably, very close to the subject of his
Mrs. Aline Meyer Liebman, an artist, widow of Charles J. Liebman, an industrialist active in aiding refugees, died Sunday in her home at 415 East 52d Street. She was 87 years old.
Six months ago William Barnett came to New York from California and looked for an apartment. When he could not find one, he thought he was being discriminated against because he was a Negro.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) The Senate passed a $110million authorization today to operate the Peace Corps for this year, after Senator J.W. Fulbright praised the agency for tightening its budget so that "the money voted by Congress goes further each year."
Following are excerpts from a speech by Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara yesterday to the Veterans of Foreign Wars convention in New York:
The city will ask the Federal Government for $1.5-million to test ways of reducing smoke from incinerators.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 The head of the Census Bureau expressed doubt today that the agency would require citizens to specify their religion in the 1970 census.

Mayor Lindsay, who has already bestowed many titles as the city's chief executive, was awarded a new job title yesterday: "Sanitationman (Honorary), First Class (Detached to sweeping duties at City Hall").

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) The Commerce Department said today it approved applications for export of $41.6million in United States goods to the Soviet Union and its Eastern European satellites during the April-June quarter of this year.
ATHENS, Aug. 23 An Athens court-martial today ordered six years imprisonment for Pvt. Argyrios Papageorgiou, who twice refused to bear arms, pleading religious objections.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 The Justice Department said today that it had found "no improprieties" in the awarding of a $12.6-million Federal contract to McCloskey Co., a Philadelphia construction concern with strong Democratic ties.

SURF CITY, N.J., Aug. 23 (AP) A teen-age surfer, who had just come out of the water, was struck on the chest by a lightning bolt and killed today. A companion and two girls were injured, apparently by the same bolt.

With bands and bagpipes blaring till after midnight, the Veterans of Foreign Wars marched down Fifth Avenue last night to the complaints of sleepless residents who seemed almost ready to march on the V.F.W.

ROME The U.N.'s Food and Agriculture Organization has had massive headquarters here for 15 years and although many Romans aren't quite sure what it is, they all delightedly refer to it by its initials, F.A.O., which they pronounce like part of a Welsh nursery rhyme or the name of a Chinese warlord.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 23 Indonesia and the Philippines hinted today that Indonesia might eventually join an organization of Southeast Asian nations.
Sales of the nation's leading chain stores and mail-order houses increased moderately in July above the level in the corresponding 1965 month, a survey made by The New York Times disclosed yesterday.

PARIS, Wednesday, Aug. 24 (Reuters) Foreign Minister Tran Van Do of South Vietnam said in an interview published here today that his Government would ask the United States to evacuate its troops once North Vietnam had withdrawn its men.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Ollie Brown, playing center field for the resting Willie Mays, powered San Francisco into first place in the National League tonight with a three-run homer that gave the Giants and Juan Marichal a 7-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds. The triumph was Marichals' 18th of the season. chals' 18th of the season.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 23 South Vietnamese naval officials ordered the main shipping channel to Saigon closed today to all but emergency traffic as salvage crews worked to remove a sunken United States freighter.

The bond market retreated yesterday as an $80-million issue of Southern California Edison bonds reached the market at the highest yield for a double-A rated bond since the mid-nineteen-twenties and found few takers.

Dr. Armand Hammer, presi dent of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, stuck to his guns yesterday amid "raids" on his statement last Friday concerning the company's Walker River Indian Reservation iron ore discovery.

Mayor Lindsay had a few concrete proposals, most of them sound, to put before a Senate subcommittee investigating the "crisis in cities" in Washington this week. He brought less than a total blueprint for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, but he did suggest legislation that would enable it to do its job better.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 23 Seismic shocks continued for the fourth day to rock the earthquake zone in eastern Turkey and spread terror among the population of the stricken area.
SANTO DOMINGO, Aug. 23--The brother of the widow of the dictator Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina has been acquitted of charges of illicitly enriching himself during the Trujillo rule.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 23 (AP) The 50-state Equipment Safety Commission's executive board told tire manufacturers today that it was upgrading performance specifications.

The World Journal Tribune, Inc., and the mailers union discussed contract adjustments yesterday for four hours, but no final agreement was reached. The talks were recessed, subject to recall by mediators.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange continued to lose ground over a wide range yesterday.

The American Electric Power Company, which has been seeking to acquire the common stock of the Michigan Gas and Electric Company since May 17, said yesterday it "welcomed the opportunity" to present its case to the Securitics and Exchange Commission. This was in answer to the announcement on Monday of a Sept. 8 hearing before the S.E.C.
HOMER, La., Aug. 23 (UPI) A group of civil rights marchers were arrested today in this North Louisiana town for parading without a permit.

The process of converting the Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn into a light-industrial complex got under way yesterday with the granting of $58,750 in Federal funds to pay the salaries of a small staff of planners.

LONDON Jimmy Brown, the actor, stood beyond camera range and watched the scene being shot, studying techniques with the same intensity he once applied to football. As the action developed, the scene appeared to assume a certain symbolism, an impression that was heightened later by a significant remark from the retired fullback wonder of the Cleveland Browns.

BUDAPEST, Aug. 23 (AP) Two American brothers, who allegedly daubed an anti-American poster to make United States bombers in Vietnam look like Soviet planes, will go on trial next week, Hungarian sources said today.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Aug. 23 State Senator and Mrs. William Thomas Hiering have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marea Christine Hiering, to Ens. David John Beatty, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. George Beatty of Shoreham, L.I.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 23 The new army commander of Brazil's Northeast called today for peace with liberal Roman Catholic Bishops in the area.

NOROTON, Conn., Aug. 23 The Larchmont (N.Y.) Yacht Club, captained by Douglas Campbell, won the second and third races off the Noroton Y.C. today to take a 2-point lead in the annual Long Island Sound midget sailing championship.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 Julius T. Bloch, a Philadelphia artist who specialized in portraits of workingmen, died yesterday at the age of 78.
About 70 antipoverty workers from Jersey City staged a sit-in at the northeastern office of the Federal Office of Economic Opportunity here yesterday.
FREEHOLD, N.J., Aug. 23 (AP) A Federal lien for $6,742,552.75 for income taxes for 1955-56 has been filed against Francis Peter Crosby, former husband of Denise Darcel, the actress.
The Bank of New York announced yesterday the election as vice presidents of John W. Arthur Jr., William M. Lees, Jesse C. Morris Jr. and Frank U. Naughton 3d.
HARTFORD, Aug. 23 A third party in Connecticut, known as the Independent party, was formed here today.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 23 Ted Janeway of the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club and Miss D.J. Hyde of the Centerport Yacht Club were the series winners today as the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's novice open regatta ended with racing over a five-mile course, twice over a windward-leeward pattern, inside Captain's Harbor.
ROME, Aug. 23 Treasury officials are confident that Italy's coin crisis will be resolved next month when several million 500lire (80-cent) banknotes go into circulation.
Following is the third of a series of four dispatches on Indonesia by The New York Times's chief correspondent in Southeast Asia, who recently traveled through the country.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 23 The military regime today dissolved the powerful Argentine University Federation and several student organizations in the wake of street demonstrations last night.

The Torah Yeshiva of Brooklyn will benefit from a champagne reception and buffet to be held on Sept. 6 from 4:30 to 7 P.M. in the lobby of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company branch at Madison Avenue at 47th Street. The event will also open an exhibition of paintings and sculptures arranged with the help of the John J. Myers Gallery.
DETROIT, Aug. 23 (AP) A sacrifice fly by Wayne Causey, a pinch-hitter, in the 12th inning scored Jerry Adair to give the Chicago White Sox a 2-1 victory over the Detroit Tigers tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, threatened today to ask the Senate Finance Committee to step in if the Banking Committee does not act on legislation to curb interest rates.
Arthur E. Palmer, the Mayor's Transportation Administrator, promised yesterday to consider within 60 days a proposal to build a subway spur along Water Street in Lower Manhattan.
BONN, Aug. 23 Esso, A.G., interrupted a temporary armistice in West Germany's "gasoline war" today by announcing that it would reduce gas prices on a selective basis next week.

A national competition for student-made films will be sponsored by Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, the Motion Picture Association of America and the United States National Student Association.

The Liberal party has now made formal its refusal to back either Frank D. O'Connor or Nelson A. Rockefeller for Governor this year. It intends to have a candidate of its own on the November ballot, but the unresolved question is who.
The long and distinguished playing career, of Roosevelt Brown, the offensive tackle for the New York Giants, ended yesterday with the expected official announcement of his retirement.
The Police Department's Tactical Patrol Force, the mobile unit of young patrolmen trained in judo and crowd control, will be expanded into one of the most powerful units within the department.
Patrick Joseph Roe McEntegart, a lawyer and the brother of Archbishop Bryan J. McEntegart of Brooklyn, died Tuesday at St. Vincent's Hospital after a brief illness. He was 69 years old.
ALBANY, Aug. 24 Republican sources said today a "consensus" was developing to nominate State Tax Commissioner Joseph H. Murphy as Governor Rockefeller's running mate for Controller this fall.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 Senator Kennedy's office issued the following reply by the Senator today to Mayor Yorty's attack:
Directors of Becton, Dickinson Co., proposed yesterday a 100 per cent stock distribution, to be followed by an increase in the company's quarterly dividend.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 24 Gen. William C. Westmoreland asserted today that the question of civilian casualties inflicted by allied forces in South Vietnam was a "great problem" that must be solved.
MOSCOW, Aug. 24 (Reuters) All Moscow shops except food stores will close Sundays starting Sept. 4, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 Unfortunately, Dean Rusk's statement that he is slowly going broke on his $35,000 salary as Secretary of State will probably not receive much sympathy from the average family man who is living on $7,000.

JAKARTA, Indonesia Indonesia is suffering from a monumental hangover after a 20year ideological binge that estranged the Southeast Asian nation from the world community and sapped the economic life of its 107,000,000 people.
BALTIAMORE, Aug. 24 (UPI) The Cleveland Indians collected 15 hits tonight and routed the Baltimore Orioles, 10-4, despite two home runs by Frank Robinson.

Two questions had to occur to any alert baseball fan watching the California Angels defeat the New York Yankees, 2-1, at Yankee Stadium last night in a game in which all the runs were scored on ninth-inning homers.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, Aug. 24 (UPI) The United States, competing in its first PanAmerican Maccabiah games, swept the boards in swimming today as Paul Katz and Mark Spitz each won two gold medals.
A young man who regularly fell out of taxicabs, as often as four times in one week, was indicted yesterday by a Bronx grand jury on charges of making fraudulent accident claims that totaled $1,375.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24--Ignoring the opposition of the Administration, the House Committee on Un-American Activities approved today a bill making it a crime to give aid to the enemy in Vietnam or to obstruct the movement of United States troops and supplies.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 President Johnson left unanswered today the question of whether he favored the renomination of Vice President Humphrey in 1968.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 24 A smashing upset occurred in the $78,400 Spinaway at Saratoga today when C.V. Whitney's Silver True beat the Wheatley Stable's Great Era by 1 lengths. Sent off at 3-to-10, one of the lowest prices of the meeting, Great Era was unable to offer anything to hold off the closing speed of the Whitney representative in the six-furlong test.

Johnny Persol, a 26-year-old light-heavyweight contender, will step up in class tonight at Madison Square Garden in the scheduled 10-round main event against James J. Woody, an undefeated heavyweight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 The Federal budget that records all Government receipts and spending showed a surplus at an annual rate of $3.9-billion in the second quarter of this year it was disclosed today.

MIAMI, Aug. 24 The Castro Government celebrated yesterday the sixth anniversary of the Federation of Cuban Women, one of its "organizations of the masses," with a call for greater participation by woman in production.
After seven days of dropping prices, the stock market finally made an upward turn yesterday, What did it mean? A new bull market? A mere pause in the bear market? What lies ahead?
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 24 The shipping channel to Saigon was reopened this morning after a United States freighter disabled by a Vietcong mine had been grounded near the shore.
Stock prices rallied strongly yesterday in the first upward move in eight sessions.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Aug. 24 A second welfare recipient was sentenced to 30 days in jail today for refusing to take a job during a drive on welfare violations in Niagara County. He was released on $250 bail pending an appeal.
CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 24 (UPI) Army Spec. 4th Cl. Phillip L. Matte of Ft. Benning, Ga., won the oldest trophy in the national matches, the National Rifle Association said today.
Prices plunged yesterday on the London Stock Exchange to their lowest level in more than three years.

Home rule the extent to which a community may run its own affairs without close state supervision was on the minds of the mayors who gathered yesterday around a hollow square of green-draped tables in the Americana Hotel.
WOMEN who have considered going out in their nightgowns may be tempted to do so when they see the sleepwear designed by Chuck Howard for Tempo.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 24 (Reuters) The police have arrested more than 2,000 people here on the eve of a one-day general strike called by leftwing Opposition parties in protest against rising prices and food shortages.
The sun finally broke through the clouds over Wall Street yesterday. Stock prices rallied strongly in the first upward move in eight sessions.
TEL AVIV, Aug. 24 Workers digging in the ruins of a second-century villa in the Negev this week recovered a hoard of more than 10,000 Roman coins 8,000 of silver and 2,000 of lower value.

The Veterans of Foreign Wars almost started a local war with their night parade down Fifth Avenue on Tuesday; now they are busy demanding that all the angry people they kept awake with their trumpets, drums and rifle volleys be investigated as Communists.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Thursday, Aug 25 (UPI)--Several thousand anti-Communist, anti-Sukarno students converged on the Indonesian Parliament today and many broke through military and police cordons and stormed the building itself.

A fund of $750,000 is being raised by the North Shore Community Arts Foundation of Beverly, Mass., to erect a yearround professional theater with a seating capacity of 1,000. Beverly, 20 miles from Boston, has a population of 36,000.

TRENTON Aug. 24 Gov. Richard J. Hughes announced today that Raymond F. Male, New Jersey's Commissioner of Labor and Industry, would leave for South Vietnam this weekend to advise Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge on civilian manpower problems.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 24 (UPI)--West New York, N. J., beat Kankakee, Ill., 3-1, and Osaka, Japan, defeated Rhein-Main, United States Air Force Base, Germany, 6-2, today to advance to the semifinals or the 20th annual Little League World Series.
TEANECK, N. J., Aug. 24 Miss Viola Anna Sadlier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. Sadlier, plans to be married in May to Ronald Mason Huse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Grosvenor C. Huse.
Miss Rosalind Fisher and Eugene J. Glaser will be married next month.
Malcolm Frager was soloist with the New York Chamber Orchestra at Philharmonic Hall last night in a Mozart Festival concert conducted by Donald Johanos.

The United Artists Corporation achieved record earnings in the second quarter and first half of this year, despite lower worldwide gross income, according to the report issued yesterday by Robert S. Benjamin, chairman, and Arthur B. Krim, president of the film company.

Five prisoners from the Queens House of Detention for Men were unexpectedly delayed for half an hour yesterday in their trip to Manhattan Criminal Court when an elevated subway wire fell on their prison van.
Howard J. Samuels, the upState Industrialist who is seeking the Democratic nomination, said yesterday he would not take second place on an O'Connor ticket.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24 A funny thing happened to the New York Mets today on the way to clinching their first season series in Wrigley Field against the Chicago Cubs.
New car sales by the nation's largest automobile manufacturer, the General Motors Corporation, fell 8.2 per cent from the 1965 level in the mid-August period.
The State Commissioner of Housing charged yesterday that the City Housing Authority was discriminating against lowincome families seeking apartments in its projects.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 24 The first season of concerts at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center here is ending this week with two operas in concert form. Last night there was Richard Strauss's "Der Rosenkavalier" and tonight there will be Johann Strauss's "Die Fledermaus."

The term folk-rock has been loosely bandied about for a year or more. The phrase has often been considered inexact. But it seems exactly the term to describe a quartet called the Lovin' Spoonful, which gave twin concerts last night at the Rheingold Central Park Music Festival.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 24 The New York Giants took a remedial step on behalf of their defense today by obtaining Jim Garcia, a big, young player, from the Cleveland Browns. The cost was a future draft choice of unannounced designation but believed to be a high one because low choices will no longer have much value in the coming common draft of the two football leagues, National and American.

Pan American World Airways, Inc., reported yesterday that on the basis of preliminary and unaudited figures its July net income was $15,206,000, or 97 cents a share, compared with $12,040,000, or 84 cents a share, in the same month last year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 The Justice Department "intends to proceed" with its case against the purchase of some assets of the Tidewater Oil Company by Phillips Petroleum, a department spokesman said today.

In Chicago, target of a sustained civil rights drive aimed mainly at cracking the housing barrier, continual marches have long since passed the point of diminishing returns. The community is being polarized into hate-filled camps, and the danger of large-scale disorder grows.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 24 (AP)--United States marines clashed heavily with enemy forces today in South Vietnam's northern sectors, where the foe had generally avoided combat since more than 800 North Vietnamese regulars were cut down in fighting last month.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 The Senate prodded the Johnson Administration today to propose legislation for dealing with such labor disputes as the recent airline strike.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 (AP) Jim Gilliam reached base on an error in the 11th inning, stole second and scored on Maury Wills's single tonight, giving Los Angeles a 2-1 victory over the Atlanta Braves. The triumph stretched the Dodgers' winning string to four.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board urged airlines today to cut fares on North Atlantic, northern and central Pacific and United States-Mexico routes.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP)--President Johnson sent greetings today for a Happy New Year to "my fellow Americans of the Jewish faith" in advance of celebration of Rosh ha-Shanah.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 24 (AP) Donald Trask of San Francisco, piloting Swingin' Star, took a one-point lead over Bill Parks, an Olympic bronze medalist, from Chicago, in the North American Star Class sailing championships today at the Cleveland Yachting Club.
HUNTSVILLE, Ark., Aug. 24 John Samuel Faubus, the father of Arkansas Gov. Orval E. Faubus, died here today of Hodgkin's Disease. He was 78 years old. The Governor was at his bedside.
PARIS, Aug. 24 President de Gaulle will leave Paris tomorrow for a 27,000-mile world tour, and a chance to talk on the war in Vietnam from a dramatic platform in neighboring Cambodia.

Philadelphia's five legitimate theaters are following the trend of charging higher prices to meet costs. One of the largest increases will apply to "Breakfast at Tiffany's," the new Abe Burrows-Bob Merrill musical. The top price at night will be $9.

While Americans have been absorbed with Vietnam, a political upheaval of far greater importance has been under way in Southeast Asia's richest, most populous and potentially most powerful country. The army take-over in Indonesia, after an abortive leftwing coup, has halted a twenty-year trend toward Communist ascendancy that was accompanied by adventurism abroad and economic decline at home.
WILLIAMSBURG, Ky., Aug. 24 Miss Carroll Jean Gatliff and Jan P. Lindholm 3d plan to marry in New York in December.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 24 (Reuters) Tens of thousands of refugees from Burma are pouring into northern Thailand, Gen. Prapas Charusathien, Interior Minister, said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) Ken McMullen's single in the 11th inning scored Fred Valentine from third base tonight and capped a two-run rally that gave the Washington Senators a 6-5 victory over the Minnesota Twins.
William Willis, an aged wanderer on trackless oceans, was back yesterday from his latest agonizing adventure in solitude, looking like a man who had spent a few days in Miami.

SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 24 Gen. Dwight E. Beach, the incoming commander of the United States Army in the Pacific area, said today that he saw no possibility of a Communist attack in Korea under present conditions.

A quiet drive is under way to provide jobs in the United States for hundreds of College professors and graduate Students seeking to leave Argentina in protest against the military regime of Lieut. Gen. Juan Carlos Ongania.
DETROIT, Aug. 24 The Automobile Manufacturers Association has announced formation of a committee to help formulate industry proposals for the pending Federal traffic safety bill.
WANTAGH, L. I., Aug. 24 The latest grade-crossing elimination project on the Long Island Rail Road started this morning with shouts and ceremony.

OCEANSIDE, L. I., Aug. 24 Matthew J. Heslin, space salesman in the national advertising department of The New York Times, died early today at the South Nassau Communities Hospital here after an illness of three weeks. He was 63 years old and lived at 721 Colonial Street, Uniondale.
LONDON, Aug. 24 (UPI) Progress was reported today on the introduction of an Africanproposed system of "selectivity" into the International Coffee Agreement.
The following quotations are selling prices in United States dolars and cents for banknotes at New York. These rates do not apply to regular exchange business transacted by banks.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24--"We can afford whatever must be done" to erase slums and restore city life, President Johnson said today.
ALBANY, Aug. 24 A joint legislative committee today scheduled public hearings on hospital costs for Oct. 17 and 18 in New York City and offered its help to a Federal study of rising medical costs.
Charles Pratt Rather, chairman of the Southern Natural Gas Company, was elected yesterday to the board of the Air Reduction Company.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 The executive council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations reported today that the average membership of the merged group for the 12-month period from July, 1965, through June, 1966, was 13,385,000. This was an increase of 921,000 over the low point of three years ago.

BETHPAGE, L. I., Aug. 24 Vice Adm. Edward W. Clexton, U.S.N., retired, a consultant of Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation here, died last Thursday at the United States Air Force Hospital, Wiesbaden, Germany, of acute leukemia, according to word received here today.
Two brothers were suspended without pay from their jobs as housing inspectors in the Bronx yesterday, after they had refused to waive immunity and testify before a grand jury.
SOME women of affluence refuse to jump when fashion shouts "go." They exercise restraint about hemlines, show their waistlines if the want to and choose clothes that speak softly.
The president of a Long Island frozen food company was arrested by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday in connection with the theft of 10,000 pounds of frozen shrimp.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined by 1,569,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, total supplies were 178,695,000 barrels, down from 180,264,000 a week earlier and 184,908,000 a year ago.
SAN JOSE, Calif. Raul Rojas, 130 pounds, San Pedro, Calif., outpointed Pete Gonzales, 130, San Jose, 10 rounds.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 24 (AP)--United States Attorney Merle M. McCurdy said today the city's recent Hough area racial violence had not been instigated by Communists and other agitators.
Federal Judge Edward C. McLean declined yesterday to issue a preliminary injunction that would prohibit Genesco, Inc., from exercising its 95 per cent control of S. H. Kress Co.
A Federal Maritime Commission investigation into truck loading and unloading rates in the Port of New York ran into a legal road block yesterday.

BOSTON, Aug. 24 (AP)--Ed Charles and Jim Gosger smacked two-run homers and Mike Hershberger drove in three runs with a pair of singles tonight, leading the Kansas City Athletics to an 8-3 victory over the Boston Red Sox and a sweep of their double-header.
CARLSBAD, N.M., Aug. 24 (UPI) The wild Pecos River calmed down today, and residents of the flooded areas of Southeast New Mexico and West Texas "mopped up" with a wary eye on the weather forecast.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 Golf's biggest money tournament is being bypassed by an overwhelming majority of top United States professionals, a survey showed today.

The $700-million Peace River power project, the key issue in the expropriation of the British Columbia Electric Company five years ago, is taking giant strides toward completion under public ownership.
