The young scientist found a job in Princeton, N. J., and took his pregnant wife house-hunting. After they found a split-level house they liked, the husband went to see about a mortgage. To his dismay, he found that local banks would not give him one on terms he considered acceptable.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 The Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation has begun paying off in record time the depositors of the defaulted Gibraltar Savings and Loan Association of Phoenix, Ariz.
The nation's Apollo moonship is to undergo its second and possibly final unmanned test today in a 93-minute flight three-quarters of the way around the world.

MADELLIN, Colombia, Aug. 24 Striking students today occupied the buildings of the University of Medellin in protest against a Government decree requiring a minimum classroom attendance to get a degree.
Harry Gilmore, the former secretary of the Western Electric Company, died Sunday at his home, 225 Oenokes Ridge, Neva Canaan, Conn. He was 88 years old.
They came 38 men and women from more than 20 states to New York University yesterday morning to learn more about their trade: arts administration, one of the newest specialties in a specialized age.
HOWELL TOWNSHIP, N.J., Aug. 24 (AP) One man was killed and nine persons injured tonight when a truck and a bus collided on Route 33, two miles west of the Wall Township line.

Mayor Lindsay, in a playful mood, wrote a summons yesterday day and served it on a reporter who dropped a cigarette butt on the ground in front of City Hall. But what started out as a joke soon raised an awkward problem or legality.

TIJUANA, Mexico, Aug. 24 (Reuters) Three Americans were held here today on charges that they had staged a wild-sheep chase from a pian. They were identified as Charles Louis Wilson, Henry Penn Wenger and Rodney Stoddart. The police said the men used a light plane to hunt sheep in Lower California, where the sheep are protected by law.
MANHASSET HILLS, L. I., Aug. 24 Miss Donna Beth Meyer and Jeffrey M. Goodman plan to marry on Sept. 4.
The nation's electric power production rose 7.5 per cent in the week ended Aug. 20, from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.
Senators Robert F. Kennedy and Jacob K. Javits will conduct a joint campaign this fall in support of a civilian-dominated police review board if there is a referendum.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Aug. 24 Samuel Bolhack of 118-30 83d Avenue, Kew Gardens, Queens, founder of the Manhattan typesetting company that bears his name, died at his summer home here yesterday after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) A bill designed to improve the organization of the Small Business Administration and strengthen the agency's regulatory powers over the Small Business Investment Company program was endorsed today by Administrator Bernard L. Boutin.
ALEXANDER, N. Y., Aug. 24 Governor Rockefeller charged today that "big city bosses" had taken over the Democratic campaign to unseat him in November.
Aaron A. Koota, Kings County District Attorney, has distributed questionnaires to his 89 assistant district attorneys to learn the extent and source of their incomes outside his office.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) President Johnson signed today a measure aimed at preventing the use of stolen pets in medical research.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 College teachers only think they are professionals, according to Dr. Israel Kugler, president of the United Federation of College Teachers. Dr. Kugler proposed doing something about it.
GARDINER, Ore., Aug. 24 (AP) A woman's refusal to give up tight pants kept more than 300 men out of work again today.

MIAMI, Aug. 24 (UPI) Two Kurd tribesmen from the mountain country of Iraq were free on $10,000 bond each today after they allegedly tried to ship 500 rifles and 2,500 pistols home to fight the Iraqi army.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 24 William Killea of Knollwood won the 42d Westchester County Golf Association junior championship, defeating William Harmon of Winged Foot, 5 and 4, today at the Knollwood Country Club.

TOKYO, Aug. 24 (AP) A Japanese correspondent reported today that the Red Guards of Peking had issued an ultimatum demanding that the eight minor parties allied with the Communists dissolve themselves within 72 hours from Tuesday midnight.

Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, said yesterday that congestion and delay at major airports showed his agency was right seven years ago in predicting the need for a fourth major airport here.
HARTFORD, Aug. 24 (AP) John T. Emmanuel, trapped six days in the wreckage of a small plane, died today in Hartford Hospital.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 Debate on a proposed department of transportation began in the House of Representatives today amid strong pressure to exempt the Maritime Administration from the plan.

United Air Lines has suspended the showing of movies aboard passenger planes ip the continental United States. The showings stopped when flights resumed Saturday after settlement of the 43-day machinists' strike.
Central Harlem's antipoverty agencies will hold open house from 10 A.M. Monday, HaryouAct; the leading antipoverty agency in the area, announced yesterday.
The United States Plywood Corporation set records in sales and earnings in its first fiscal quarter ended July 30, Gene C. Brewer, president, reported yesterday.

Max Goldman, who in 1915 negotiated the first collectivebargaining contract in the millinery industry, died Tuesday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 1311 Brightmater Avenue, Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 24 Pierre Havre, a 36year-old American Airlines pilot who lives in Plandome, L. I., and Beverly Hills, Calif., depending upon which side of the country he is at any given time, was one of the winners today at the start of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's 34th annual race week.

FORT-LAMY, Chad, Aug. 24 (Reuters) The Government has closed its border with the Sudan and ordered its frontier forces to open fire on any aircraft with Sudanese markings flying over Chad military installations.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) President Johnson today designated Monday, Oct. 3, as Child Health Day.

A Canadian railway strike affecting the whole country now seems inevitable starting at noon tomorrow. The results are going to be highly disturbing for the Canadian economy, however the issue is handled.

ORILLIA, Ont., Aug 24 (Canadian Press)--The handwritten manuscript of "Sunshine Sketches of a Little Town," by the Canadian humorist Stephen Leacock, has been purchased by the Stephen Leacock Memorial Home.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 (AP) Vada Pinson hit a grandalam home run to back the steady pitching of Joe Nuxhall today as the Cincinnati Reds beat Gaylord Perry and San Francisco, 9-4, snapping the Giants' four-game winning streak.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 24 Safety inspectors at entrances to the Thomas E. Dewey Thruway last week turned back 111 out of 2,404 cars, trucks and buses because they had serious defects in tires, tail lights, headlights, stop lights and directional signals.
The National Park Service which observes its fiftieth anniversary today has occasion for soulsearching as well as celebration.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) President Johnson announced today 10 members of a group to study Federal programs for training career Government officers and improving their performance.
Northeast Utilities and its subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for 12 months ended July 31.
Queens District Attorney Nat Hentel opened his campaign for re-election yesterday, describing himself as "the nonpartisan candidate."
Robin took one look at the nearly 7,000 howling children pouring across Central Park and onto the Mall. "Holy Turnout!" he blurted. Batman kept his cool.

MOSCOW, Aug. 24 A quarter of a century after German troops murdered tens of thousands of Jews at Babi Yar, a ravine in Kiev, a harsh and detailed description of the massacre has been published for Soviet readers.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 24 U Thant will inform the United Nations' 117 members by letter on Sept. 1 whether he will accept another term as Secretary General.
LONDON, Aug. 24 (AP) Prime Minister Wilson agreed today to risk his prestige in a fight to bring organized labor behind the Government's austerity program.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24 Organ- ized labor's top leaders said today that substantial increases in wages were necessary to put pay scales in balance with prices and profits.
CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Aug. 24 (AP) For the second time in eight days Pope Paul VI criticized today those within the Roman Catholic Church who oppose changes made by the Vatican Ecumenical Council.
The Chock Full o' Nuts Corporation is seeking to buy independently owned lunch counters and coffee shops in downtown areas to remodel and operate them on a franchise basis.

McGraw-Hill and the Jewish Theological seminary of America are working together on a series of books intended to make the Old Testament intelligible to children, young people and adults without training in biblical studies. The first volume of the series, "Understanding Genesis," by Prof. Nahum M. Sarna of Brandeis University, will be published next month. Other books in the series wlll come out one a year.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and major stockholders of listed companies.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 24 (AP) Dr. Carlos Martinez, American Cancer Society Professor at the University of Minnesota, known for his work in transplanting organs, died at a hospital here today of a heart attack. He was 52 years old.
A new house means new habits and new problems, Metropolitan Opera officials are discovering, now that they are getting poised for opening night on Sept. 16.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 Mayor Samuel W. Yorty complained today about his treatment in Washington yesterday by a Senate subcommittee investigating urban problems.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP) C.V. Whitney's Fish House, a long shot, caught the leaders at the 16th pole and went on to win the $26,250 Lassie Trial stakes by two lengths today at Arlington Park.

BONN, Aug. 24 Dr. Hans Zehrer, editor in chief of Die Welt, one of West Germany's leading newspapers, since 1953, died in Berlin last night. He was 67 years old, and was to retire on Sept. 1 because of ill health.
MOSCOW, Aug. 24 The Soviet Union launced another space research station today with the indicated intention of putting the craft, called Luna 11, into orbit around the moon.

Mrs. Margaret S. Robinson of Westport, Conn., and Peter C. Robinson of Bridgeport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sylvia Helme Robinson, to Michael Corrigan, son of the Right Rev. Daniel Corrigan, former Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Colorado, and Mrs. Corrigan of New York.

A Civil Aeronautics Board official said here yesterday it would take two or three days to determine the probable cause of the crash of a rented plane Tuesday at Lake Ronkonkoma, L. I., in which six persons were killed.
Dealers throughout the band market did little business yesterday as they watched in vain or Tuesday's $80-million Southern California Edison issue to gather steam.
BONN, Aug. 24 When KaiUwe von Hassel took over the West German Defense Ministry from the stormy and controversial Franz Josef Strauss at the end of 1962, there were audible sighs of relief in Bonn.
A new product is being introduced that's bound to appeal to almost any redblooded American dog.

Miss Kay Ellen Brooks of 160 East 84th Street, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Blumberg of 125 East 87th Street, was married yesterday evening to Edwin Joel Blick of New York. He is the son at Mr. and Mrs. Louis D. Blick of Elizabeth N.J.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Aug. 24 A spokesman for the Food and Drug Administration today found himself in the unusual position of tentatively agreeing with the poet Allen Ginsberg, a persistent advocate of legalizing LSD and marijuana.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 24 (UPI) The Alabama House passed and sent to the Senate today Gov. George C. Wallace's bill defying Federal school desegregation guidelines.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 Troops of the Illinois National Guard will be on hand to assist the police in preventing clashes over the weekend when the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. expands his drive against housing bias in Northern cities into the explosive, all-white Chicago suburb of Cicero.

Mr. and Mrs. Jack D. Newton are offering an extraordinary reward of $1,000 for the return of an ordinary small black poodle because, Mrs. Newton said yesterday, it was so much a member of the family that "it's ruined my life losing him."

DETROIT, Aug. 24 (API) Bill Freehan hit his first home run in more than a month tonight, capping a four-run rally in the second inning that carried the Detroit Tigers to a 6-2 victory over the Chicago While Sox.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 24 Mrs. Florence Jaffe Falk, a former New York City teacher, died Monday in Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx. Her age was 39.
FREEHOLD, N.J., Aug. 24 (AP) A husky mill hand was charged today with the slaying of Donna DeRier, a 19-year-old college girl, three weeks ago.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Aug. 24 (Reuters) West German motor vehicle production in July fell sharply to 152,842 units from 279,843 units in June, mainly because of the vacation period, the Motor Manufacturers Federation said here today. Output in the first seven months, however, was up by 4.3 per cent to 1,786,104 from 1,711,709 units in the corresponding period of last year.

A tea will be given on Sept. 8 at Stoneleigh, the home of Mrs. Horace J. McAfee in Irvington-on-Hudson, N. Y., for the young women who will be presented at the annual Mistletoe Debutante Ball, Dec. 21, at the Pierre Hotel.
The stockholders of Leslie Fay, Inc., received an unexpected dividend yesterday.
The American Stock Exchange made its best showing in three weeks yesterday as the list rebounded with strong gains after seven sessions of declining prices.

William J. Kennedy, president of Printing Pressmen's Union No. 2, reported "a bit of progress" yesterday after a fivehour meeting with representatives of The World Journal Tribune, the city's new merged newspaper.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) Negotiators of the Senate and the House of Representatives agreed today on legislation to give President Johnson unrequested authority to call up thousands of reservists and National Guards men for duty in Vietnam.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 (AP) A petition for a preliminary in junction to void the purchase of $385-million in Tidewater Oil Company assets by the Phillips Petroleum Company was denied today in Federal Court.
THE Emperor Franz Joseph grumbled at sacrificing medieval walls to Vienna's urban renewal. He wanted big, strong new ones built if the town must grow.

SEATTLE, Aug. 24 Robert Byrne of Indianapolis, as Black in a 30-move Dutch Defense, was held to a draw by Pal Benko, grand master of New York, in the 10th round of the United States Open Chess Championship here last night.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 24 Syria told the Security Council today by letter that she would pursue a policy of legitimate self-defense in case of future Israeli aggressive acts.

OTTAWA, Aug. 24 (Canadian Press) John R. Nicholson, Canada's Labor Minister, began to seek concessions from both sides today in a last-ditch bid to settle the deadlocked railwaywage dispute before a Friday strike deadline. There was no hint of a break.
A suit to void a resolution by the Board of Estimate doubling the sewer and water taxes imposed on city property owners was filed in State Supreme Court yesterday.
ALBANY, Aug. 24 (AP) Mrs. Grace Rayan of Red Hook posted a 79 today to win the New York State senior women's golf championship over the 5,544-yard par 73 Wolfert's Roost Country Club course.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 24 Dennis Ralston and Clark Graebner, the United States Davis Cup combination, lost the opening set to Jim Osborne of Honolulu and Jerry Cromwell of Long Beach, Calif., and were five times within a stroke of yielding the fourth set before gaining the victory in the national doubles tennis championships today at the Longwood Cricket Club. The scores were 7-9, 6-4, 6-0, 13-11.

DETROIT, Aug. 24 (AP) Carrying signs saying "No Dice," "Like Hell" and "A Dollar Now," some 200 members of the United Automobile Workers protested today the refusal of big three auto makers to reopen labor contracts.
The National Union Electric Corporation announced yesterday the election of Harry C. Mills as a director. Mr. Mills retired in 1961 as a vice president and director of the J. C. Penney Company.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 24 Michael S. Dent, 20 yeas old, and Harvey Franklin, 22, both of 112 Hillside Avenue, Newark, were indicted today on a charge of murder in the fatal beating of Benjamin Caruso, 65, in his apartment in Plainfield on Aug. 7.

MALIBU, Calif., Aug. 24 (UPI) Jeremy Slate, star of television's "The Aquanauts" and husband of Tammy Grimes, the actress, was taken to the psychiatric ward of Los Angeles County General Hospital Monday, sheriff's deputies disclosed today.
MASTER JOHN CURDO of Chelmsford, Mass., scor ing 5 - , won the recent Central New England Open Chess Championship at the Wachusett Club of Fitchburg, Mass.

LONDON For 40 years, Jack Solomons dreamed the dream that fills the fancy of every fight promoter. Some day, he would stage a bout for the heavyweight championship of the world. Not long ago he achieved his ambition in a left-handed sort of way. He produced the Cassius Clay-Brian London epic, which ended in total disaster.

IT had to happen and it did happen yesterday at 33 neighborhood movie houses. "Batman," the pride and joy of American Broadcasting Company television and the twice-weekly ritual of millions of viewers, swooped down as a feature film. And don't worry, folks. That miserable little pipsqueak, Robin, flapped in with him.

President Johnson has ordered an inquiry to find out why medical costs are going up twice as fast as all other items in this inflationary year. The recent inauguration of Medicare and Medicaid makes this a particularly relevant question.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 24--President Carlos Lleras Restrepo of Colombia said today that Latin America, needed not only its own common market but also a special trading relationship with the United States.

Fulton Freeman, United States Ambassador to Mexico, and Mrs. Freeman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Freeman, to Victor Pasquale Manuelli, son of Mrs. Pasquale Charles Manuelli of South Pasadena, Calif., and the late Mr. Manuelli.
MEMPHIS, Aug. 24 (UPI) John McCormick and Bob Scarpitto paced the Denver Broncos to a 28-16 victory over the Miami Dolphins tonight in an American Football League exhibition game.
The Gallant Ship Award, a bronze plaque given to ships with outstanding records of performance at sea, will be put on display this morning in the lobby of the First National City Bank, 2 Broadway.

Two Brooklyn policemen were suspended early yesterday after one had been arrested in connection with an abortion and the other had refused to answer questions at a City Department of Investigation inquiry into a reported insurance fraud.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 24 (AP) Vern Law pitched six innings of shutout relief and Bill Mazeroski and Bob Bailey each drove in two runs as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 6-4, tonight to regain the National League lead.
The 14-story Southern Hotel in downtown Baltimore will be sold at a court-ordered public auction at the hotel on Sept. 13.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Aug. 24 (AP) Dr. Vicente Mejia Colindres, President of Honduras from 1929 to 1933, died today. He was 88 years old and had spent his last years writing books and newspaper articles.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24, (AP) The Navy disclosed today that it had sent radio messages by satellite from a ship stationed off Vietnam to the Pacific Fleet headquarters in Honolulu.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 Defense Department manpower experts estimated today that possibly 30 per cent of the 40,000 draft rejects and substandard volunteers to be "salvaged" for military service over the next 10 months would he Negroes.
The International Silver Company announced yesterday in Meriden, Conn., the election of Donald E. Noble as a director.

A number of merger negotiations have come unstuck lately some for technical reasons, some because the selloff in the stock market has drawn the value out of exchange ratios that until fairly recently looked like a good deal to all hands.
ONE might suppose that all the players who take part in the National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League are experts, but this is far frown true.
Grain carryings on the Great Lakes hit a new monthly high of 2.8 million tons during July, to help establish a new seasonal record of 11.1 million tons.
Walton Butterfield, an actor during the nineteen-twenties, and later an advertising executive here and in Boston, died on Monday at his home, 34 Gramercy Park East. He was 68 years old.

ALTHOUGH the Welsh springer spaniel has been known in has native Wales for hundreds of years, he is a comparative unknown in the United States. Last year, of the 112 breeds registered in the American Kennel Club stud book, the red-and-white Welshman ranked No. 103.
Lufthansa is flying through a storm of protest generated by its new ad campaign.

Lawrence and Albert Gallo obtained a brief delay in State Supreme Court yesterday blocking their appearance before a grand jury. The jury is investigating their "peacemaking" in the recent disturbances in the East New York section of Brooklyn.
MIAMI, Aug. 24 (AP) A hurricane, threatening the eastern Caribbean islands, pounded tonight on a westerly course that postponed an effort to tame its winds.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 24 (UPI) Curtis Cokes of Dallas knocked down Manuel Gonzalez in the 12th round tonight, then went on to gain a unanimous decision in their fight for the world's welterweight championship. The title was vacated when Emile Griffith won the middleweight crown.

The Raytheon Company of Lexington, Mass., is further diversifying its activities through the proposed acquisition of the Seismograph Service Corporation, an international geophysical research company based in Tulsa, Okla.

George Meany, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said yesterday that a letter to clerical and other employes of Pan American World Airways who are voting in a union representational elec tion was signed fraudulently with his name.
PEKING, Aug. 24 The high command of the Chinese Army has started a propaganda campaign glorifying Korean war veterans and stressing the superiority of man over weapons of mass destruction.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 24 (AP) An organization of Quakers received State Department permission today, it said, to send medical supplies to North and South Vietnam through the International Red Cross in Geneva.
The press secretary tells me that some of you wanted to meet with me today. I am available for any questions you may want to ask.

The Fifth Avenue residents who complained to City Hall about the late late parade of the Veterans of Foreign Wars on Tuesday night should be reprimanded by Mayor Lindsay and investigated for possible unAmerican activities, speakers at the V.F.W. convention said yesterday.
WILBERFORCE, Ohio, Aug. 24 Robert Burgette Johnson, chairman of the social studies department of Wilberforce University, died yesterday at his home here. He was 44 years old.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 24 (AP) Civil rights lawyers filed a $20-million damage suit against Mississippi law enforcement officers today in connection with the death of a 24year-old Crystal Springs Negro.
BONN, Aug. 24 A third high-ranking West German Army officer, Maj. Gen. Gunther Pape, resigned today, adding to the storm beating around KaiUwe von Hassel, the Minister of Defense.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 24 Government opinion is split on where the 8,000 to 10,000 homeless victims of last Friday's violent earthquake in eastern Turkey should be rehoused.

ANCHORAGE, Aug. 24 In a record primary election vote, spurred by the bitterest gubernatorial campaign in Alaska's short years of statehood, Democratic Gov. William A. Egan today won the right to seek what amounts to a third term in office.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 Imports rose again in July to a new high while exports fell slightly, the Department of Commerce reported today.

John E. Bradley, a partner in the antique importing firm of Flint and Bradley, Inc., died yesterday at his country home in Pipersville, Pa., after a, long illness. He was 70 years old and lived at 206 East 52d Street in Manhattan.
BRUSSELS, Aug. 24 Hopes for repairing Belgium's relations with the Congo sagged today as officials studied the latest moves of President Joseph D. Mobutu.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 24 (AP)--Premier Nguyen Cao Ky today gave the Vietnamese people his "word of honor as a soldier" that the coming national elections world be honest and representative.

ELMONT, L. I., Aug. 29 The meat department of Great Eastern Mills, a discount house on Hempstead Turnpike, was robbed of $15,000 to $20,000 this morning by three armed men dressed in butchers' jackets and a woman who carried a sawed-off shotgun in her oversized purse.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) Clarence G. Marshall, Washington editor of Newport (Va.) Daily Press, Inc., died tonight in a local hospital after suffering a heart attack.

Pincus J. Barash, head of P. J. Barash, Inc., 225 West 34th Street, manufacturer of women's dresses for the mail order trade, died Tuesday in the Jewish Memorial Hospital, of which he was a trustee and former president. He was 81 years old and lived at 23 West 73d Street.

Jersey City's troubled antipoverty program was told yesterday by Federal officials that it must end practices of nepotism and proceed with plans for an election for a new board of directors on Sept. 21.

LONDON, Aug. 24 The failure of the economic sanctions applied so far to topple the Government of Rhodesia and the possibility of further action were examined here today by members of the Commonwealth Sanctions Committee.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 24 (UPI) Gov. Grant Sawyer, critical of the Federal Government's refusal to cooperate in the Nevada "skimming" inquiry, charged today that Washington had begun an "undeclared war" against Nevada's gambling industry.

What Brazilians call their Carioca style of soccer passing, twisting, turning and jumping produced plenty of thrills but little scoring against an outstanding goalie last night as Santos turned back A.E.K. of Greece, 1-0.
The nomination of Mrs. Constance Baker Motley; Borough President of Manhattan, as a Federal judge was approved 12 to 2 yesterday by the Senate Judiciary Committee.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 President Johnson denied today that contributions to the elite President's Club influence awards of Government contracts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 President Johnson warmly endorsed today a proposed all. Asian conference to settle the Vietnam war. But he also stressed the United States' willingness to attend a reconvened Geneva conference.
The Board of Estimate overrode Mayor Lindsay yesterday and voted informally to make one last try at restoring the city's 15-cent rapid transit fare.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24--President Johnson warned to-day that the Government might have to "take other measures" to control inflation unless business and labor exercised self-restraint on prices and wages.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 Frank D. O'Connor, seeking political exposure for his expected race with Governor Rockefeller of New York in the fall, made the rounds of the White House and the Vice President's office and spoke at a National Press Club luncheon today.

A new play by William Hanley, originally intended for production on Broadway next winter, has been diverted to the National Broadcasting Company television network for $112,500. This is the highest amount an author has ever received from television for a single work.
A surprise rally for copper futures and a continuation of higher prices for soybeans were the highlights of an otherwise dull day in commodity trading yesterday.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 24--After a lapse of 42 years, the Palma Trophy next year with 20 United States riflemen competing against a Canadian team, and possibly others, in Canada as part of that country's centennial celebration.

The Detroit Edison Company looks for 1966 earnings about 7 per cent higher than the $57.5million, or $2 a share, reported in 1965, Walker L. Cisler, chairman, told a luncheon of the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday. This would compare with the annual earningsrate growth of 8.3 per cent over the past five years.
Owens-Illinois, Inc., announced yesterday that it would raise prices on 60 per cent of its glass containers an average of 3 per cent effective Oct. 1.
The Canadian dollar rose in foreign exchange trading here yesterday, despite a national railroad strike threatened for noon tomorrow. The currency closed at 93.09, up from 93,016 on Tuesday.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Aug. 24 John D. Friebely, personnel director and a member of the board of the Ortho Pharmaceutical Corporation, died Monday night of a heart attack at Muhlenberg Hospital here. He was 51 years old and lived at 832 Hillside Avenue.

E.F. Hutton Co., Inc., stock brokerage concern, has leased 6,300 square feet of office space on the 12th floor at 1350 Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue), southeast corner of West 55th Street, for a branch office. Steven R. Levy, David S. Raspler and George L. Studley of Julien J. Studley, Inc., were brokers in arranging the 10-year lease, which has an aggregate value of almost $500,000.
Civil rights leaders denounced yesterday Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara's proposal for "salvaging" draft rejects on the grounds that it would place undue hardships on Negroes.

The directors of Texas Instruments, Inc., have approved a rights offering to stockholders of record Sept. 16 in the ratio of one new share for each 17 held, it was announced yesterday by Patrick E. Haggerty, president.

Stocks fell sharply, with investment-grade and glamour issues showing the biggest losses in slower trading, volume, 6.76 million shares. Corporate bonds declined in less active trading; transactions, $12.41 million.

The election of Oscar A. Lundin as president was announced here yesterday by the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, one of the nation's largest sales finance companies, Mr. Lundin, 56 years old, formerly was treasurer of the General Motors Corporation. His successor in that post has not been selected.

AREA A--Warmer water in the last week failed to brighten what one operator calls a "very dismal situation" in southern part of area. Crabbing has been excellent in Barnegat Bay, but fishing is spotty: a few blues in surf near Barnegat Light, small porgies and snappers...

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 25 (UPI) West New York, N.J., earned the right to meet Houston in the championship game of the Little League World Series when it combined Ike Alonso's two-hit pitching and two two-run innings for a 4-0 victory today over Osaka, Japan. Houston beat Sacramento, Calif., 4-0, earlier on a one-hitter by Mark Harding.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
The nation's most powerful rocket and its newest spacecraft flew an apparently successful test three-fourths of the way around the world yesterday.
HAWORTH, N.J., Aug., 25 Nancy Porter of the Rivertor Country Club won the Maureen Orcutt Junior Trophy at the White Beeches Golf and Country Club today. Fourteen play ers competed.

The New York Yankees, who used to be compared to a huge, profitable, industrial complex, are setting more lows than a stock market these days. By losing to the California Angels, 5-1, at Yankee Stadium yesterday, they touched a couple of new nadirs.

The D.W.G. Cigar Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to make a tender offer for all of the outstanding common shares of Wilson Brothers, Inc., a leading men's shirt manufacturer, in exchange for a new D.W.G. securities issue.

A Westchester gambler, arrested yesterday as he left his $60,000 Mount Vernon home, later asked for a court-appointed lawyer because he was "too poor" to hire counsel. He was charged with failing to purchase a $50 Federal gambling tax stamp.
A 56-year-old descendant of a distinguished New York family gave free shoes and clothes to scores of his poor Puerto Rican friends yesterday.

Ten pickets who charged discrimination in the hiring of Negro welders demonstrated for two hours yesterday in front of the Pan American World Airways passenger terminal at Kennedy International Airport.

A second operation on Whitey Ford's left shoulder, performed yesterday in Houston, is expected to cure permanently the circulatory problem that has plagued the 37-year-old New York Yankee pitcher for two years. A six-inch vein from his leg was transplanted into his shoulder.
UTRECHT, the Netherlands, Aug. 25 (Reuters) Frank Wiegand, a 23-year-old East German swimmer, lowered the men's 400-meters free-style world record tonight by fivetenths of a second in 4:11.1.
ALBANY, Aug. 25. The state's Medicaid program, which ignited a major controversy when it was enacted nearly four months ago, has drawn fewer than 200,000 applications for medical assistance so far.

The Kayser-Roth Corporation the nation's largest apparel manufacturer, exceeded $300-million in sales for the first time in the fiscal year ended June 30 and realized a 21 per cent increase in earnings on a sales gain of 27 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI) Representative Edward Hutchinson, Republican of Michigan, proposed 12-year terms today for the Chief Justice of the United States and the Associate Justices of the Supreme Court. They now serve for life or until they retire.

OAKLAND, Md., Aug. 25 (AP) Lidge Schowgurow, whose murder conviction led to Maryland's historic court decision on belief in God, pleaded guilty to second-degree murder today and was sentenced to 18 years in the Maryland penitentiary.
WAUWATOSA, Wis., Aug. 25 (UPI) Nearly 100 civil rights demonstrators, chanting "black power," picketed a judge's home for the seventh consecutive evening in an all white neighborhood.

From her wheel chair, Mrs. Lili DePillis, 60 years old, reaches for a telephone several times a day to call E.F. Hutton Co. or Harris, Upham Co. Though she owns some stocks, her main interest is commodity futures.

HINGHAM, Mass., Aug. 25 Morton Bromfield of the Boston Harbor Yacht Club became the first skipper to capture the International 210 Class crown four times when his Challenge placed fourth in the fifth and final race of the 19th annual championship on Hingham Bay today.
The School of the Arts of the St. James Community Center in Harlem will benefit from "An Evening With Peter Nero" on Sept. 26 at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin J. Buttenwieser.
The stock market sprang back into a downward track yesterday.

An amalgamation of militant, youth-oriented Negro groups is threatening to boycott at least two Harlem schools to get African and American Negro history into the curriculum and Negroes into supervisory posts in Harlem schools.

Cocktail pianos are generally more seen than heard, the idea being that people should be able to drink, eat, talk, schmoozle. But when Cy Walter plays at the Drake Room the hands clasp under the tables as middle-aged lovers become kids again to "Begin the Beguine" or "Body and Soul."
Miss Ilene S. Cottler and Arthur S. Schantz were married last night by Rabbi Harry Halpern at the Unity Club in Brooklyn.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 25 Nobody was more delighted with the way the second regatta of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's Race Week ended today than an all-girl crew headed by Mary Lou Grinnell of Larchmont in the Shields Class.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) President Johnson will speak in three Western states tomorrow.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 25 (AP) Robert Bolivar DePugh, leader of the Minutemen, a militant anti-Communist organization, charged tonight that Federal agents had used Gestapo tactics, including a drugged witness, obtaining a conspiracy indictment against him and four other followers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 The Senate Antitrust subcommittee will hold hearings next week in an attempt to explore what can and should be done to strengthen the application of antitrust laws and concepts to overseas operations of American business.

Supreme Court Justice Edward G. Baker ruled in Brooklyn yesterday that Representative Edna F. Kelly, the regular Democratic organization candidate in the borough's 12th Congressional District, was "rightfully nominated" in the primary last June 28.
MOSCOW, Aug. 25 (AP) Production of a modified version of the Italian Fiat automobile will begin in 1969 and reach a rate of 600,000 a year by 1972, a Soviet trade official said today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 By a 378-to-3 roll-call vote the House defeated today a Senate proposal to give President Johnson special power to use National Guard troops and the Reserves in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON. Aug. 25--Democratic party leaders across the country do not generally accept the theory that Senator Robert F. Kennedy would be more acceptable to party members than President Johnson as their 1968 Presidential nominee.

Airport congestion in the metropolitan area would be relieved to some degree by a fourth major airport, but the proposal "is not the all-in-one answer that the Port Authority makes it out to be," an airline industry official said yesterday.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 25 Under the forbidding burden of 166 pounds, Mako contributed a compelling performance in the $21,950 Saratoga Steeplechase Handicap today. The 6-year-old gelding, owned by Mrs. Ogden Phipps and ridden by Tommy Walsh, won the 2 -mile event by eight lengths in the creditable time of 4:37 3-5. The triumph was the fourth straight for Mako.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 President Johnson appointed an inter-departmental committee today to study the recommendations of the White House Conference on Civil Rights of June 1 and 2.
LONDON, Aug. 25 The latest effort to resolve the Rhodesian crisis has ended in failure.
WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 25 (AP) Davis J. Walsh former sports editor of the International News Service which was merged with United Press, died Tuesday. He was 74 years old.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Aug. 25--Arthur Murray, sailing a superbly consistent series of six races, became the new national champion of the Cougar Catamaran Class, clinching the title with a second and third today in light southerly airs off Atlantic Beach, L.I.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 25 Vice President Humphrey denounced some critics of the Vietnam War today as advocates of a "new isolationism" that would stress domestic affairs to the detriment of foreign policy.

The executive board of the Communications Workers of America rejected yesterday a new wage offer from the Western Electric Company for 22,000 telephone installers across the country. It also authorized the union president to call the installers out on strike at any time.
ATHENS, Aug. 25 Two British yachts allegedly used to fish antiquities from Greek waters have been seized by the Greek coast guard in the Gulf of Corinth.

Marching behind a rhythmic, blue-uniformed drum and bugle corps, James Meredith led a parade of 300 youngsters through the Lower East Side yesterday afternoon to encourage more voter registration in the area.

ATLANTA, Aug. 25 It was a tiny kind of miracle that was achieved in Georgia last night when Atlanta's Municipal Theater presented the first major American production of Tchaikovsky's "The Sleeping Beauty." The company had as its nucleus the Atlanta Civic Ballet, but the cast was drawn from regional companies from all over the Southeast.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 A key Congressional leader questioned today the need for a national debate on the next major goal in space beyond the moon.

About 90 more employes within the jurisdiction of the Newspaper Guild of New York on the three newspapers merged into The World Journal Tribune have applied for voluntary termination of their employment, Thomas J. Murphy, executive vice president of the Guild, said yesterday
TOKYO, Aug. 25 A Japanese Government spokesman said today that "it is not the intention of the Japanese Government to consider nuclear armament."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 The nation's railroads and rail unions agreed today to seek legislation that would increase pensions for retired railroad workers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 Secretary of State Dean Rusk told Congress today that the United States might have to use its armed forces in "collective defense against armed aggression" even in the absence of clear-cut American defense treaty ties with the nation attacked.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 25--The Sara toga Performing Arts Center ended its first season on a buoyant note last night with a concert performance of Johann Strauss's "Die Fledermaus" in English. About 7,300 persons filled the fanshaped amphitheater's orchestra and balcony and dotted the hillside into which the huge structure is set.

YONKERS, Aug. 25 Noble Victory, they 4-year-old free-forall trotter who seems to have made a habit of breaking track records wherever he goes postward, added the Yonkers Raceway mark for 1 miles tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) President Johnson, who will be 58 years old Saturday, said today that he already had a birthday present the education, health, housing and poverty programs.

BOSTON, Aug. 25 Directors of Marrud, Inc., filed bankruptcy proceedings today in Federal District Court here seeking protection while trying to reach an agreement with creditors. New Sun Ray Drug, Inc., a subsidiary, filed a similar petition.

BERLIN, Aug. 25 (Reuters)--Wolfgang Langhoff, a leading figure in East Germany's cultural life and vice president of the Academy of Arts, died Tuesday after a long illness, A.D.N., the East German press agency, reported today. He was 65 years old.

ONE of the great individual projects of the 19th century is the series of paintings 435 in all done by John James Audubon between, roughly, 1820 and 1837 for the multi-volume, "Birds of America," the final installment of which was engraved in England and distributed to subscribers in 1838.
