PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 25 --The name of the game is professional football. The name of the game is also passing.

Sharon McClain,8-years old, sat next to her 7-year-old sister, Roslyn, yesterday on a bench in a leafy corner of Kingston Park in the BedfordStuyvesant area of Brooklyn. Around her neck Sharon wore the keys to the family apartment on Hancock Street. The two little girls and 50 other youngsters, faces alight with anticipation, were crowded on two benches, waiting for the sound of music.

THE Rebekah Harkness Foundation Dance Festival announced yesterday that it would return Tuesday for its fifth and most ambitious season a nine-day run this time in Central Park's Delacorte Theater. A major part of the credit for bringing the program produced by the New York Shakespeare Festival ...

Mayor Lindsay attempted yesterday to smooth the ruffled feelings of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, whose midnight parade down Fifth Avenue on Tuesday night was received sourly by residents who said they needed sleep.

It now seems fairly certain that Uruguay is going to change her form of government from the Swisstype collegiate system back to the one-man presidential system. The Congress in Montevideo, at a joint session this week, agreed by a comfortable majority on a proposition to be submitted to the electorate Nov. 27.

The Portuguese Government has suspended the right of Iberia Airlines, the national airline of Spain, to make its direct, twice-a-week flights from New York to Lisbon, an Iberia official said here yesterday.
DETROIT, Aug. 25 (AP) Auto production this week was nearly double that of a week ago, according to estimates made today by Automotive News, a trade publication.

TOKYO, Aug. 25 The 22,400 people in the town of Matsushiro, who have been living under the threat of a major earthquake for more than a year, have been warned that the period of greatest danger is at hand.
HONG KONG, Aug. 25 (Reuters) North Vietnam denounced Britain tonight for circulating a report that North Vietnamese troops were fighting in Laos early last year.

Twenty-six-year-old Bernard Stroble Jr. was arraigned in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday on 60 counts charging murder, assault, kidnapping, arson and robbery. His only response was to ask the court's permission "to marry a young girl with whom I am living and she is pregnant."

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 25 Chasing two escaped prisoners through the scrubby woods near the Fort Dix stockade, a soldier newly assigned to stockade duty accidentally shot and killed a fellow guard today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 Two modifications in the administration of the immigration law that will ease the flow of immigrants to the United States will be made soon.

The Board of Estimate, in an 18-to-4 vote, decided yesterday to let the Appellate Division rule on the legality of an $84.3million subsidy for the Transit Authority. The avowed objective of the move was to role back the 20-cent subway fare to 15 cents.
Increased and extra dividends were voted yesterday by directors of a dozen or more companies including the Union Pacific Railroad, the Bendix Corporation, the Anaconda Company and Genesco, Inc.

President Johnson's renewed appeal for labor-management self-restraint to curb inflation got a swift reply from the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Executive Council: Blame industry. The federation insists that substantial wage increases are needed to put employe earnings in balance with the high prices and higher profits. Its statement translates into a declaration that, so far ...
Cornell MacNeil, a leading Metropolitan Opera baritone, said yesterday that the opera company had become "a monster, a vast competition with immense tension that serves no purpose."
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 25 John M. Budinger, a director and former senior vice president of the Bankers Trust Company, died here today at his home, 10 Sussex Avenue. He was 65 years old.

Rumblings of renewed labor troubles arising from the settlement terms in last year's 77-day seamen's strike were reported here yesterday, following unsuccessful talks in the last two days between shipping lines and a union of ship's officers.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 25 Nikolai T. Fedorenko, the Soviet representative at the United Nations, gave a festive outdoor luncheon today for fellow diplomats at the Soviet delegation' estate at Glen Cove, L.I.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 With France abstaining, nine of the 10 leading industrial and financial powers disclosed to day their agreement in principle that the world will need in the future some kind of international money to supplement gold and dollars in the nations' official reserves.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP)--The House Rules Committee rejected today a bill to permit a study of whether the United States should adopt the metric system of measurement.
The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee threatened yesterday to seek a tighter draft law if Cassius Clay, the heavyweight boxing champion, got a deferment as a Moslem minister.
Conditions have changed at 56th Street and Sixth Avenue in the 100 years since it was a dusty shanty town but thanks to a 10-cent lithograph they have not been forgotten.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 25 The Thai Foreign Minister, Thanat Khoman, warned today that rejection of his call for an Asian peace conference on Vietnam would "be likely to have the effect of supporting the Communist position," which favors escalation of fighting rather than a peaceful settlement.

A 13.4 per cent increase in St. Lawrence Seaway cargo volume during the first half of the 1966 navigation season over the same period last year has been reported by Joseph H. McCann, administrator of the St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation.
The Union Carbide Corporation annuonced yesterday that it would build a new marine bulk-cargo terminal in the Boston area able to handle shipments of more than 100 million pounds of chemicals a year.
CHICAGO, Aug. 25 Harold Howe 2d, United States Commissioner of Education, called today for continued teacher militancy and he urged a greater voice for teachers in making policy for education.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 Senate-House conferees reached final agreement today on an auto safety bill.

BONN, Aug. 25 Leaders of West Germany's Public Service, Transport and Traffic workers Union greeted today's decision by Chancellor Ludwig Erhard to accept the resignation of three rebelling generals as a victory for German democracy as well as for organized labor.
DJIBOUTI, French Somaliland, Aug. 25--Nationalists and French policemen clashed violently tonight shortly after President de Gaulle arrived for an official visit to France's last territory in Africa.

DIFFICULT bidding problems are often presented by hands with some length in the suit bid by an opponent but all the strength in the other suits. With the North hand shown in the diagram, for example, most experts would pass an opening bid of one diamond by West. In that case East would raise to two diamonds and South would make a take-out double.
SAN DIEGO, Aug. 25 The San Diego Chargers of the American Football League were sold today for $10-million to a group of businessmen, including Pierre Salinger, a former White House press secretary.
A white youth shot a 17-yearold Negro last night on the grounds of a city housing project, the police said.
CHICAGO, Aug. 25 Wrigley Field has become a den of horrors for the New York Mets.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 24 The South Vietnamese Government, with the encouragement and assistance of the United States, is planning a major overhaul of its rickety taxation system.
LONDON, Aug. 25 Five masked men fired at least 12 shots from their car at two unarmed policemen in a pursuing car today in a chase through the dockland streets of southeast London.
Mayor Lindsay, who campaigned on a program to bring government closer to the people, appeared yesterday to feel there are times when the people get too close to the government.
There will be a new shoot'em-up on TV in a couple of weeks, with a demonstration of sharpshooting that might well prompt Matt Dillon to turn in his badge.

Gimbels has started a Theater Club. It will be headed by Robert M. Zarem, former assistant to the vice president of Macy's Theater Club, which has been active for four years. A somewhat similar service has been organized by the Theater Guild, it was announced yesterday by Joel Wyman, the guild's subscription manager.

The Cunard Line, in contrast to the majority of the port's steamship and terminal operators performing truck loading and unloading services at piers, yesterday complied with a Federal Maritime Commission subpoena calling for the production of confidential business records.

LONDON, Aug. 25--A cost-of-living bonus scheduled to be paid next Thursday to printers in the newspaper industry seems likely to be the first major test of the workability of the Labor Government's voluntary wage freeze.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 25 Manuel Santana of Spain, the Wimbledon and the United States tennis champion, was beaten today in one of the longest matches on record in the national doubles tournament at the Longwood Cricket Club.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Aug. 25 In the Scarsdale Congregational Church tonight, Miss Pamela Diane Farnham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Railton Farnham, was married to Steven John Wohl, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Wohl of Brooklyn. The Rev. Frederic B. James, assisted by the Rev. Walter S. Ryan, performed the ceremony.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 South Africa's Ambassador today charged Senator Robert F. Kennedy of New York with distortion and misstatements in a recent magazine article about his country.
BOSTON, Aug. 25 (AP) Hank Fischer, making his first start since being acquired from Atlanta, defeated Kansas City, 4-1, as Boston completed a sweep of its double-header against the Athletics today.

The Sperry Rand Corporation's Remington office machines division and the Saxon Paper Corporation said yesterday that they had signed an agreement for Sperry to distribute a new electrostatic office copying machine being developed by Saxon's Copystatics division.

SEATTLE, Aug. 25 Grand Master Robert Byrne of Indianapolis recovered the undisputed lead in the 11th round of United States Open Chess Championship by defeating E. Macskasy of Vancouver, B.C., in a 35more Caro-Kann Defense here last night. Macskasy refused the offer of a draw during play and was subsequently outplayed.
JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 25 (AP) Charles Evers, the civil rights leader, asserted today that all-white Mississippi draft boards were punishing Negro rights workers with induction.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Aug. 25 (AP) Two 16-year-old stars, Mark Spitz and Paul Katz, and a drafted basketball player and diver led the American swimming team to six victories in seven events today in the Pan American Maccabiah Games.

The judicial questions recently raised over Federal school aid to church-related schools give special pertinence to Senate efforts to open the way for effective clarification of the issue by the courts, and ultimately by the Supreme Court. Senate bill 2097, which would permit judicial review of Federal programs in aid of education and such allied areas as anti-poverty projects, has been passed and is currently before the House Judiciary Committee.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 25 (UPI) Paul Blair's single with the bases filled in the 11th inning gave the Baltimore Orioles a 4-3 victory tonight over the Cleveland Indians.

ATHENS August's dog days drive statesmen to the beaches, news to the boondocks and columnists to the anniversary compilations where one comes across the startling information that Saturday marks the birthday of Lyndon B. Johnson and Confucius. Mr. Johnson was born in 1908, Confucius in 550 B.C.

CUMONG PASS, South Vietnam, Aug. 23 Almost every day about 200 women from a Vietcong-controlled area make their way along twisting Highway 1 to this mountain pass and, quite unafraid, pass through a military checkpoint manned by South Korean troops.

OTTAWA, Aug. 25 (Canadian Press) The Canadian Government rejected today a bid by Trans-Canada Pipe Lines, Ltd., to build an East-West naturalgas pipeline, with a section passing through the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 Intercity truck tonnage and freight traffic generated by carloadings on U.S. railroads in the week ended Aug. 20 were both ahead of the volume in the corresponding week of last year.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Wednesday the level it reached on Tuesday, which was 109.6.

A five-alarm fire swept through five buildings in the Williamsburgh section of Brooklyn last night. It broke out shortly after midnight in a three-story frame building at 68 Siegel Street and raged out of control for more than an hour. There were no injuries.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25--The Senate gave President Johnson and organized labor an uncomfortably narrow victory today by defeating a move to delay an increase in the minimum wage to $1.60 an hour.
TORONTO, Aug. 25 Canadians prepared today to cope with the effects of a national railroad strike, which appears set to begin at noon tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff rejected today a charge by Mayor Samuel W. Yorty of Los Angeles that a Senate inquiry into the problems of big cities was politically designed.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 25 A proposed $8-million county office building became involved in political controversy today when County Executive H. Lee Dennison vetoed the Suffolk Board of Supervisors' choice of an architect.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange opened firm yesterday but slipped in later trading.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 25 Friends of Arturo U. Illia, the deposed Argentine President, have begun a quiet campaign to raise funds to save him from destitution.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 25--Syria announced triumphantly today that her armed forces had recovered a wrecked MIG-17 fighter from the Sea of Galilee.

GENEVA, Aug. 25 (AP) The 17-nation disarmament conference recessed today after seven months of stalemate on all major issues. But East and West appeared optimistic that a breakthrough was in the wind.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 25 (UPI) Run-scoring doubles in the fourth inning by Dick Groat and Jackie Brandt and Jim Bunning's eight-hit pitching paced the Philadelphia Phillies to a 4-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) Senate investigators heard today the unhappy ending of the tale of two young men who failed to make a go of a $21-million, Governmentinsured apartment project in Los Angeles.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 Tom Weiskopf left a note for Arnold Palmer, borrowed a putter and then scored a 66 today in the $110,000 Philadelphia Golf Classic. The six-underpar first round at the Whitemarsh Valley Golf Club gave the 23-year-old Ohioan the lead by two strokes.
THE National Broadcasting Company discovered or ganized crime in the United States for 3 hours last night, but unfortunately neglected to arrange bail for the viewer.
Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. abandoned his campaign for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination yesterday with a slap at the Democrats and a comehither glance toward the Liberals.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 25 (UPI) Noting and then ignoring the presence of "outsiders" at the bargaining table, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation began new wage contract talks today with the International Union of Electrical Workers.

THE planes that flew in the first of the Paris fashions this week also brought in the acces sories with which each couturier stamps his look. Givenchy made no bones about what belongs to him his name is emblazoned, three inches high, on a purple scarf bought by Ohrbach's.

The American Electric Power Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday record profits of $84,175,000, or $1.87 a share, for the 12 months ended July 31, from the $78,075,000, or $1.73 a share, cleared a year earlier.
Local anglers don't need to go to Nova Scotia or New England to catch tuna or, at least, to try to catch tuna.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 25--If George Morris, the highest scoring United States rider in the 1960 Olympic Games, had the time he'd be riding Big Line this year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP)--American air strikes have had what United States officials described today as very substantial and very serious effects on North Vietnam's oil supplies.
Consumption of newsprint in this country set a record for July and for the first seven months of 1966, the American Newspaper Publishers Association said yesterday.

Fred S. Dubin Associates, consulting engineers, have announced that Selwyn Bloome and Norman D. Kurtz have been admitted as partners. Mr. Bloome and Mr. Kurtz will continue to direct the mechanical and electrical engineering operations of the Dubin firm's New York office.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Aug. 26 A United States Air Force plane today strafed and dropped napalm on a battalion of the United States Army's First Infantry Division on an already-bloody battleground north of Saigon. Twenty or more Americans were reported killed or wounded.
An official of the National Urban League denounced yesterday a reportedly growing practice in American industry of recruiting skilled European labor, United Press International reported.
PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 25 The Mayor of this city ordered a criminal nuisance complaint yesterday against the mayor of a posh little nearby town for operating slum buildings here.

KINGSTON, R.I., Aug. 26 (AP) A nurse at the University of Rhode Island says that "a White House man" asked her and another nurse to camouflage a protest by a professor who walked out of ceremonies for President Johnson on the campus last Saturday.

DUBLIN This isn't where it started exactly, but it's where the sweep- stakes idea gained its first semblance of respectability. So enormously successful have the now famed Irish Sweepstakes been over the better part of four decades that they finally have followed generations of Irish emigrants across the Atlantic to America.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) The Federal National Mortgage Association reported tonight a record number of mortgages purchased under its secondary-market operations during the year that ended June 30.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.

Last Monday, a day before Deputy Mayor Robert Price ended his six-day European vacation and returned to New York, the following classified advertisement appeared in the Paris edition of The Herald Tribune:...

LONDON, Aug. 25 Gen. Tadeusz Bor-Komorowski, cen tral figure in one of the most desperate, and tragi episodes of World War II, the ill-fated Polish uprising in Warsaw against the Nazis in August of ...
The spot price of the British pound rose modestly in foreign exchange dealings here yesterday, but the discount on the pound for delivery in three months widened further.
The Raytheon Company of Lexington, Mass., producer of electronic components, announced yesterday the election of John D. Clare and Dr. Edward L. Katzenbach Jr. as vice presidents.
MIAMI, Aug. 25 (AP) Victor Galli of Orlando, Fla., won the senior men's slalom in the national water ski championships today. He had 41 buoys.
VANCOUVER, B.C., Aug. 25 (UPI) Sue Jones, 18 years old, of the Santa Clara Swim Club broke the world record in the women's 110-yard breast-stroke today, with a time of 1:18.3.

The Patriarch Aleksei, head of the Russian Orthodox Church in the Soviet Union, has written to his bishops warning against clerics who "stir up suspicion and distrust in church authority and the fatherland." The letter was circulated throughout, the Soviet Union in June.

ANCHORAGE, Aug. 25--Mr. and Mrs. Max B. Kirkpatrick have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Irene Kirkpatrick, to Paul Gerry Maurer. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul B. Maurer of Hollywood.

SAYVILLE, L. I., Aug. 25--The battle for the Thistle Class national championship narrowed down to two skippers today as Walter Stubner of East Hartford, Conn., and Tom Wilson of New York City moved far ahead of the rest of the field. The series will conclude in Great South Bay tomorrow.
President Johnson's proposal for a new Cabinetlevel Department of Transportation, already seriously weakened in committee, has come under heavy attack in the House of Representatives.
PARIS, Aug. 25 Every day it becomes more apparent that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization will not be able to finish packing before April 1, the moving day suggested by its French landlord.

WASHTNGTON, Aug. 25 Washington, and presumably the remaining half of the country, suddenly is buzzing with talk that maybe Senator Robert F. Kennedy of New York, not Lyndon B. Johnson, will be the Democratic candidate for President in 1968; or maybe Senator Kennedy will replace Vice President Hubert Humphrey on the Johnson ticket.
James L. Marcus, Mayor Lindsay's assistant in charge of water affairs, said last night that he hoped that the city would begin a program of universal water metering by the first of the year.

Johnny Persol, a ranked lightheavyweight, stepped briskly into the heavyweight division last night with a unanimous decision over James J. Woody, who never got the chance to use his 13-pound weight advantage.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 25 Members of Indonesia's Parliament demanded today that President Sukarno leave the country or take a long rest.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 25 The United States carried out yesterday the heaviest concentration of air raids in the war against North Vietnam.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Friday, Aug. 26 (UPI)--A hurricane aimed 100-mile-an-hour winds at the resort islands of the Caribbean early today. The Weather Bureau warned more than three million residents that danger "is definite and great."

Only a minuscule part of a tin can is tin, but, even so, everyone appears to be trying to get rid of it entirely. The reason is that tin is expensive and its supply is constantly threatened by instability in the Far East the major source. Besides, tin is not required to make cans anymore.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP)--The House passed by voice vote today a $1-billion compromise military construction authorization bill.
A young man broke into an apartment in the Briarwood section of Queens early yesterday morning and abducted a 23-year-old housewife.
The bond market took a new setback yesterday as bellwether issues in all three sectors lost ground.

The chief investigator for the House Education and Labor Committee asked the State Supreme Court yesterday to prevent an examination of his financial dealings with Representative Adam Clayton Powell, the committee chairman.
The chairman of ACF Industries, Inc., announced yesterday in Houston that the company achieved record sales and earnings in its first fiscal quarter.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) The Senate passed a compromise bill today making available $300-million in mass transit subsidies to cities.
President Johnson has written Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Hoffman of Rumson, N.J., expressing thanks for the service of their five sons in the Marine Corps.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI) Cambodia's chief of state, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, has sent word to the United States officially postponing a trip to his country planned by Ambassador at Large, W. Averell Harriman, the State Department said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI) On Maui in the Hawaiian Islands there aren't any soldiers. But Senator Daniel K. Inouye said he was "shocked, incredulous and ashamed" that some were not found for the funeral of a corporal who died of Vietnam wounds.
YOUNG men heading back to college next month will not necessarily fill their trunks with flowered shirts, cowboy boots, ties as wide as ascots and hip-riding pants anchored with a three-inch belt.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Walter O. Leiser of Sao Paulo, Brazil, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Lou Leiser, to Brooks de Wetter Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. St. Clair Moen Smith of Keene, N.H.

Northwest Airlines, Inc., which was grounded by the machinists' strike from July 8 to last Friday, announced yesterday that its net income in the first half this year rose to $28.1-million, or $3.07 a share, from $18.6-million, or $2.04 a share, in the first six months of 1965.

The Mutual Broadcasting System announced yesterday that Fulton Lewis 3d had been named to succeed his late father, Fulton Lewis Jr., as a radio commentator and news analyst. The elder Mr. Lewis, who broadcast on the Mutual network for 27 years, died on Sunday.
EAST NORWICH, L.I., Aug. 25 Miss Helaine Press, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jules H. Press of Great Neck, was married today to Andrew Ross, son of Mr. and Mrs. S.S. Ross of Flushing, Queens.
HOLLYWOOD, Aug.25 (AP) Senator George Murphy, Republican of California, was reported "feeling terrific" today after surgery to remove a tumorlike growth on his vocal cords.
NANCI WHITE, 16 years old, of Walnut Creek, Calif., would like her bedroom to have a Polynesian theme, with bamboo-trimmed furnishings and "bright, vivid colors" green, orange, pink, red and gold.

OMAHA, Aug. 25 Miss Lisbeth Cherniack and Jules Norman Stiffel, both of Chicago, plan to marry in the autumn at the home here of Miss Cherniack's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jay Cherniack. Mr. and Mrs. Theophile Alphonse Stiffel of Chicago are the future bridegroom's parents.
ANCHORAGE, Aug. 25 (UPI) Late returns today from Tuesday's Alaska primary election showed Representative Ralph J. Rivers had won the Democratic nomination in his bid for reelection.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) The intention of consumers to buy new automobiles and major household durable goods has changed little overall in the last three months, the Census Bureau said today.

Lynda Bird Johnson, the President's elder daughter, yesterday discussed a career in the publishing business with Anthony Mazzola, the editor of Town and Country magazine, in his office at 527 Madison Avenue at 54th Street. Miss Johnson returned to the White House yesterday afternoon.

While a holdup man was pressing a loaded pistol to the back of his head, Patrolman Robert Geraghty spun around and shot the thug dead early yesterday in a tavern at 198 Rogers Avenue near Union Street in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn.
Leo Israel Meltzer, a teacher and principal in city schools since 1928, died yesterday at his home. He was 58 years old and lived at 1 74th Street, Brooklyn.
Wheat futures weakened slightly yesterday following news that the Senate's agricultural committee had approved a bill cutting funds from the Government's Food for Peace Program.
FREEHOLD, N.J., Aug. 25 (UPI) William George Doss a mill worker charged with the first-degree murder of Donna de Rler, a college co-ed, stood accused today of another crime the rape of a waitress.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 The Treasury sold an issue of oneyear bills at auction today that produced an effective interest yield to buyers of 6.20 per cent.

WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Aug. 25 Governor Rockefeller said today's withdrawal of another potential opponent provided fresh evidence that "the big city bosses" had taken over the Democratic campaign to unseat him.
DUBROVNIK, Yugoslavia, Aug. 25 (UPI) The Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra left today for Lucerne, Switzerland, after providing a rousing climax to the 17th Dubrovnik Summer Festival.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 Civil rights leaders said today there was a possibility that a negotiated peace with real estate interests might cancel plans for "the biggest ever" street demonstration against Northern housing discrimination, scheduled for suburban Cicero on Sunday.
DUBROVNIK, Yugoslavia, Aug. 25 (UPI) The Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra left today for Lucerne, Switzerland, after providing a rousing climax to the 17th Dubrovnik Summer Festival.
The controversial plan of New York University to build a $20million library south of Washington Square Park was approved yesterday by a 12-to-10 vote in the Board of Estimate.
WASHINGTON, AUG. 25 Two Federal employes who distributed literature of a supposedly political nature have been ordered suspended for 30 days without pay.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 25 Israel today began the salvage of a patrol boat stranded on rocks in the Sea of Galilee near the Syrian border as United Nations observers stood by.
Marsteller, Inc., has moved into the West Coast market with a bang, through the merger and acquisition route.

BONN, Aug. 25 Backing his Defense Minister to the hilt, Chancellor Ludwig Erhard today accepted the resignation of three insubordinate generals and appointed two new members of the West German High Command.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 Representative Wright Patman of Texas charged today that the Treasury Department was giving President Johnson "weak, namby-pamby" advice on what to do about high interest rates.

The American Stock Exchange was unable to open trading in Westec Corporation common yesterday because of a heavy imbalance of sell orders. Both the Securities and Exchange Commission and the exchange itself are checking into the source of the selling, which coincided with the disclosure that Westec's board had met to "evaluate" the recent purchase of about 160,000 shares in the company by Ernest M. Hall Jr., president.
For more than 20 years James Rubertone, a 61-year-old executive, had worked in close and friendly association with his boss, Lawrence Burman.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) The Justice Department opposed today legislation that would require community antenna television systems to comply fully with requirements of copyright laws.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 25 The Football Giants will have all their pass receivers available for duty for the first time when they face the Philadelphia Eagles at Princeton's Palmer Stadium Saturday in a National Football League preseason game.

Commercial bank reserve positions, which basically control the amount of money in the economy, remained under heavy pressure during the week ended Wednesday, according to figures reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve System.

Klein, who was born in New York City and played at end for Evander Childs High School and New York University, said his new venture was a private one and not connected with National General Corporation. National General owns 250 movie theaters across the United States.
BOMBAY, India, Aug. 25 (Reuters) Seventeen policemen were among 36 people injured today in clashes with leftist strikers demonstrating against rising prices and food shortages.
MADRID, Friday, Aug. 26 The first photograph of the earth taken from the vicinity of the moon by a United States spacecraft was received at a tracking station near here last night.
New York University yesterday agreed to consider a hall of fame for newspapermen in the expansion of its Washington Square campus.
DETROIT, Aug. 25 (AP) Denny McLain held the Chicago White Sox to two hits tonight in leading the Detroit Tigers to an 8-0 victory.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 25 Representative James D. Martin, Alabama's No. 1 Republican, will open his campaign for the Governorship tomorrow, confident that a lingering Barry Goldwater following in the state will enable him to defeat the Democratic candidate, Mrs. George C. Wallace Jr., wife of the Governor.

PEKING, Aug. 25 (Reuters) Peking's youthful Red Guard demonstrators today took over a Roman Catholic convent run by four elderly nuns and plastered it with posters denouncing religion and "foreign devils."
MADRID, Friday, Aug. 26 The first photograph of the earth taken from the vicinity of the moon by a United States spacecraft was received at a tracking station near here last night.
New York University yesterday agreed to consider a hall of fame for newspapermen in the expansion of its Washington Square campus.

Miss Ronnie M. Abrams, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Elias N. Abrams of Brooklyn, was married last evening to Dr. Richard J. Gordon, son of Mrs. Martin Feingold of North Bergen, N.J., and Louis Gordon of Union City, N.J. Rabbi Abraham B. Hecht performed the ceremony at Temple Shaare Zion in Brooklyn.
The election of William M. Kirkpatrick as a vice president was announced here yesterday by the Anaconda Company, a major copper producer.

Prices dropped sharply on the American Stock Exchange yesterday in moderate trading. The market rose at the opening, but profit taking soon pared the gains. By 1 P.M. the list was mixed and thereafter most issues moved lower, with the glamour issues the biggest losers.
MONTEVIDEO Uruguay, Aug. 25 (AP) Uruguay, plagued by economic troubles, has taken the first step to restore the presidential system it abandoned 15 years ago in favor of a nine-man ruling council.

JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), Aug. 26 Israeli authorities announced tonight that they would place on view tomorrow major parts of the Syrian MIG-17 that Syria announced she had retrieved from the Sea of Galilee in a commando action.
Mayor Lindsay declared yesterday that he saw no possibility of the transit rare being rolled back to 15 cents.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 Dave Marr said he got rhythm in his golf swing today. Using a new cadence, Marr scored a six-under-par 66 to share the 36-hole lead in the $110,000 Philadelphia Golf Classic with Don January and Billy Martindale at 138.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) House leaders today scheduled President Johnson's antipovery hill for floor motion starting Sept. 12. There was no assurance yet they could pass it.

TORONTO, Aug. 26 About 115,000 workers struck seven Canadian railroads today after negotiators failed to settle a wage dispute. The national strike left most of the country without train or telegraph service.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 Miss Sarah Karwoski, daughter of Mrs. Jens T. Wacher of Carmel, Calif., was married this afternoon to Hendrik D. Gideonse, son of Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, and Mrs. Gideonse of New York and Yorktown Heights, N. Y.
SALEM, N.H., Aug. 28 (AP) Buffle, the winner of the Sub urban Handicap at Aqueduct last month, has joined the ranks of contenders in the $250,000 added New Hampshire Sweepstakes Classic Sept.3.
KINSHASA, The Congo, Aug. 26 Talks between The Congo, Burundi and Rwanda began here yesterday to review a wide range of problems of common interest to the three former Belgian colonies.

David H. Joseph, city editor of The New York Times for 21 years and an assistant managing editor for four years until his retirement in 1952, died last night at his home, 801 West End Avenue; after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

The New York Giants, healthy for a change, and the New York Jets reasonably but not completely healthy, play professional football exhibition games today within driving range of the city. For those who want to watch the pros in person without leaving the city, the Brooklyn Dodgers will play at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.
Market analysts pointed to Motorola yesterday to show what seemingly bad news can do to a stock in a nervous market.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 Mayor Ralph S. Locher of Cleveland "wholeheartedly" agreed today with grand jury findings that recent riots in his city had been fomented by trained agitators, assisted by Communists.

SEATTLE, Aug. 26 Grand Master Robert Byrne of Indianapolis maintained first place in the United States Open Chess Championship when he defeated Richard Verber of Chicago on the black side of a 27-move Sicilian Defense in the 12th and penultimate round at the Seattle Center last night. Byrne gained the minute bishop-pair edge and outmaneuvered his opponent.

A distinguished 46-year chapter in local shipping history will start to close this afternoon with the final sailing of the Furness Line cruise ship Ocean Monarch. The chapter will close late in November when the line's other passenger ship, the Queen of Bermuda, quits the port.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) Senate action on a proposed constitutional amendment to permit voluntary, prayers in public schools was put off indefinitely today.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 26 The Jewish War Veterans of the United States of America today endorsed the Administration's policy in Vietnam after a heated debate.

CHICAGO,Aug. 26 (AP)--The American Medical Association said today that its trustees had advised local units not to act in support of radiologists or other hospital-based specialists in disputes with hospitals over billing practices.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Aug. 26 William Haywood Kinsey, 24 years old, a Peace Corps volunteer from Washington, N. C., went on trial for murder in the High Court at Mwanza today. He is charged with killing his wife, Peverley, a volunteer from Riverside, Conn., on March 27.
Eastern Air Lines and Trans World Airlines reported yesterday substantial losses for July as a result of the 43-day airline strike.
LONDON, Aug. 26 Isaac Keesing, founder of Keesing's Contemporary Archives, a diary of world events, died on Aug. 18 in Amsterdam, the Netherlands. He was 80 years old.

HOUSTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) Failure to gain permission to build a $314-million gas pipeline to California today was expected to cause a number of Texas gas suppliers to cancel their contracts with California utilities.

The Federal Maritime Commission's investigation into the legality and reasonableness of a 17 per cent increase in truck loading and unloading, charges by members of the New York Terminal Conference brought out testimony, yesterday that the increase might drive business away from the port.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 28 (AP) Mickey Wright equaled a Professional Golfers' Association ladies' record with a 30 on the front nine today in the first round of the $25,000 Glass City Golf Classic and then came in with a 39 for a 69 and the firstround lead.

The superliner United States left here for Southampton and Le Havre at 1:40 A.M. today after being delayed for more than 13 hours by a strike of nine deck officers against the United States Line in a money dispute.
In a move unusual in Hollywood, a producer has completely re-edited a $3.5-million film that had been shown in preview, and is holding up general release for almost a year.

NASHVILLE, Aug. 26 Miss Frances Blythe Barbour, laughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Crawford Barbour, will be married tomorrow night to Thomas Lumbard. He is the son of Chief Judge J. Edward Lumbard of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit and Mrs. Lumbard of New York and Fairfield, Conn.

DJIBOUTI, French Somaliland, Aug. 26 Angry crowds demanding independence from France fought policemen and troops in bloody riots in the Place la Garde today, forcing the cancellation of plans for a speech there by President de Gaulle.
CHICAGO,Aug. 26 (AP) Donald S. Boynton, a retired Industrialist who with his wife created the Norwegian Chapel in Door County, Wis., died yesterday, He was 79 years old.
SQUIRREL ISLAND, Me., Aug. 26 Dr.Thomas A. McGraw, a New York City surgeon, drowned while swimming to his boat yesterday near his summer home here. He was 42 years old and lived at 9 East 92d Street.
LONDON, Aug. 26 (AP) The World Methodist Council issued a strong appeal today for liberal policies on civil rights, Rhodesia, Communist China and the war in Vietnam.

RUMSON, N. J., Aug. 26 "It all began when George enlisted;" Mrs. Henry J. Hoffman said yesterday. "He was 19. All the rest of the boys went too. Hank used to tease me and says he'd join the Air Force but I told him if he did, I'd break his arm.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) Dr. Herbert L. Ley Jr., 42 years old, of the Harvard School of Public Health, today was named director of the Food and Drug Administration's Bureau of Medicine.

In a staid looking building in St. Mary's Park in the Bronx, a hundred-foot dragon arched lazily down a hall. In an adjoining room a boy beat bongo drums. And in still another room a five-foot canary argued with a bearded German sculptor.

Miss Gail Robison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. MacDonald Robison of Mount Holly, Vt., was married in Brussels yesterday to Donald Gibbs Brodie, son of Bruce Brodie of Plandome, L. I., and the late Mrs. Brodie.

Alex Rose, vice chairman of the Liberal party, discussed the gubernatorial race last night with Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., who withdrew from the contest for the Democratic nomination on Thursday with harsh words for Democratic "bosses."

The commander of the Philadelphia Police Department's civil disobedience unit, which polices civil rights and other demonstrations, will become a personal assistant to Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary here on Sept. 12.
Nicholas Veronis, a retired restaurateur, died yesterday at his home in Easton, Pa. He was 77 years old.
ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 26 A municipal employe disclosed in Magistrate's Court here last night that he had operated the city dog catcher's truck for three years without a driver's license.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 26 A tenacious and dangerous colonial problem, half forgotten by the outside world, hangs heavy over the three-day visit of president de Gaulle to Emperor Haile Selassie and the ancient empire of Ethiopia.
TOKYO, Aug. 26 Communist China's rampaging young Red Guards have destroyed Greek, Roman and Chinese art pieces, including statues of the Venus de Milo and Apollo, the Peking radio said today.
Hunt Foods and Industries, Inc., of Fullerton, Calif., announced yesterday that it had achieved record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended June 30.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 The American Federation of Teachers ended a five-day convention here today at the Edgewater Beach Hotel with a strong assertion of teachers' rights, including the right of civil disobedience.

MOSCOW, Aug. 26--A University of California mathematics professor was taken for a fast and unscheduled automobile ride through the streets of Moscow, questioned and then released today after he had criticized both the Soviet Union and the United States at an informal news conference.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 26 A triple entry representing the Wheatley Stable will be the overwhelming favorite tomorrow probably as low as 1 to 5 in the $75,000 added Hopeful Stakes, the feature event on the final day's program at the Saratoga race track:
A 21-per-cent gain in the sales volume of the men's apparel industry by 1970 was predicted yesterday by the president of the Menswear Retailers of America.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange continued to take a beating yesterday as the market slumped for the ninth time in the last 10 sessions.
ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Aug. 26 (AP) Employes of the Swift Co. packing plant here have voted to take a pay cut of about 40 cents an hour to save their jobs for at least a year.
The Grand Union Company, a supermarket chain, announced yestesdey in East Paterson, N.J., the appointment of Alan C. Goulding as vice president and general manager of its Sunrise division.
Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon, who recently toured the South Vietnam battlefront, said yesterday that the Johnson Administration had unnecessarily resigned itself to a long war there.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 26 U Thant was urged today by 177 United States Representatives to accept another five-year term as Secretary General of the United Nations. The request was made in a telegram signed by both Democratic and Republican legislators.

BOSTON, Aug. 26 (AP) Peter J. Carroll, an Associated Press photographer for more than a quarter-century and a World War II correspondent, died today in the Massachusetts General Hospital. He was 55 years old.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 26 The commander of the United States First Infantry Division took pains today to absolve the Seventh Air Force of any blame in the acci
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 The first lunar orbiter has revealed a "hospitable," slightly pear-shaped moon in two weeks of circling flight, scientists said today.
PLAINFIELD, Vt., Aug. 26 (AP) Bayard Rustin, the civil rights leader, says the Congress of Racial Equality is dead and the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee is dying.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) Congress completed action today on legislation to continue Federal aid for urban transit systems at a cost of $300-million over the next two years.
"Fairly deceptive" counterfeit $10 bills have been turning up in the New York area, the Secret Service reported yesterday.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 26--Midget, a 7-year-old gray mare owned and ridden by Nancy Baroody of Lakeville, Conn., swept to her fourth championship in the last eight days today when she won the small pony hunter title at the C.W. Post horse show.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 President Johnson told a leading Democratic critic of high interest rates today that the Government's authority to set interest levels must be kept flexible.

The Veterans of Foreign Wars yesterday gave a gold medal, special citation, three loud cheers, a standing ovation, an Indoor parade and a rendition of "For He's a Jolly Good Fellow" to Representative Joe R. Pool, acting chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 28 The State Department is preparing a report for President Johnson recommending that he authorize renewal of large-scale American aid to Indonesia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 The index of primary market prices increased one-tenth of 1 per cent to 106.7 during the week ended Aug. 23, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products and processed foods moved higher in price while industrial commodities averaged unchanged.
ABOUT 20 years ago, Mrs. Lee Rosenthal, then an embroidery designer, made an organdy pinafore for a small niece. Her husband, Leon, a cartoonist, painted some kittens on it.
MOSCOW, Aug. 26 Soviet and North Vietnamese leaders apparently met for a secret policy conference last week at a Black Sea resort, according to information received by Western diplomats.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 26 (AP) Wyndham Mortimer, a founder of the United Automobile Workers of America and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, died on Tuesday in Hawthorne. He was 82 years old.

Out at the eastern end of Long Island, as too many now know, lies a lovely land of potato fields and winter hweat, of old New England houses and tree-shaded streets,all within minutes; of the noblest beaches anywhere in the world. Embraced by sea and sound, that end of Suffolk County has for a long time been a blissful world apart for those lucky enough to summer, winter, or weekend there.

The Nature Conservancy, a national, private, nonprofit conservation organization, has announced the appointment of Charles H. W. Foster as its new president.
The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court ruled 3-2 yesterday for a referendum on the Nov.8 ballot to decide whether the city's civiliandominated police review board should be abolished.

YONKERS, Aug. 26 A small portion, of Arthur Nardin's considerable financial empire, a 5-year-old trotter named Speedy Count, races tomorrow night at Yonkers Raceway in as $8,000 mile test that should add $4,000 to Nardin's bankroll.

SABBATHDAY LAKE, Me. From time to time, Sister Mildred Barker interrupts the serenity of her ordered days to attend an auction at which Shaker furniture is advertised for sale. For the last two years, none of it has proved to be the real thing.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 26 (UPI) Art Baker, the whitehaired actor and former master of ceremonies of television's "You Asked for It," collapsed and died today in a bank on Wilshire Boulevard. He was 68 years old.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) The Senate Public Works Committee was urged today to conduct an early hearing on a bill to improve maritime safety in Newark Bay.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 23 (UPI) Gary Cuozzo passed for two second-half touchdowns tonight as the Baltimore Colts rallied for a 24-17 victory over, the Cleveland Browns in the second game of a National Football League exhibition double-header before 83,418 fans.
The Internal Revenue Service has filed a lien against the Congress of Racial Equality for $22,500 in taxes allegedly collected from CORE employes but not transmitted to the revenue agency.
MADRID, Aug. 26 An airlines war is developing between Spain and Portugal over Portuguese demands for a bigjet route into Madrid.

DETROIT, Aug. 26 Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, took exception today to a statement of policy on Vietnam approved on Wednesday in Chicago by the executive council of the merged labor federation.
LONDON, Aug. 26 Tailor and Cutter had some cutting observations to make today on the royal family's taste in clothes.
PLAQUEMINE, La., Aug. 26 (AP) A Negro candidate for the Iberville Parish School Board has pulled out of the runoff primary, assuring the nomination and election of another Negro.

ROSELLE, N.J., Aug. 26 Mrs. Ruth T.Evans, wife of Maurice H. Evans, a former member of the City Council here, died today at the Elizabeth General Hospital. She was 69 years old and lived at 517 North Wood Avenue.

In these skittish market days, commodity traders usually take their weekends seriously, so much so that they tend to even out their commodity positions in case some important announcement comes on Saturday or Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 The Senate passed tonight the high-priority Administration bill to raise the minimum wage to $1.60 an hour and to broaden coverage. The vote was 57 to 17.

PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 26 The manuscript of a Rudyard Kipling novel has been presented to the Princeton University Library, and it sheds some light on a literary mystery of more than 75 years' standing. The manuscript of "The Light That Failed" in Kipling's own hand was given by Nelson Doubleday of Princeton's class of '55, grandson of the publisher who founded Doubleday Co.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) Officials of the Selective Service System announced today that two more opportunities would be given on Nov. 18 and 19 for registrants to take the Selective Service college qualification test.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 26 (AP)--An official of the Internal Revenue Service and another from the Justice Department have been subpoenaed to testify in state hearings into alleged underworld casino rakeoffs, the state said today.
Are the Kennedys trying to delay, censor or squelch the serialization of William Manchester's account of the assassination of the President?
DETROIT, Aug. 26 (AP) Bret Hanover, harness racing's top money-winning pacer, was sold to Castleton Farms of Lexington, Ky., today and will be retired to stud after this season.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 26 (UPI) The bettors at Randall Park race track received a refund of $23,548 today when a mechanical failure in the starting gate caused the stewards to declare the second race no contest.
W. R. Grace Co. reported yesterday plans to acquire the Sea Pak Corporation of St. Simon's Island, Ga., through an exchange of shares valued at about $10.5-million.

The steady sandpapering of stock prices-the market has gone up only one day in the last two weeks finally is getting under the skin of brokerage-house salesmen. At noon yesterday, a customer telephoned his broker and said, "Where are you?" "I'm hiding behind my desk," came the reply in a faltering Harvard accent.
LONDON, Aug. 26 (AP)--It may seem unbelievable, but the British are losing their taste for fish 'n' chips.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 26 Arthur Ashe of Richmond and Martin Riessen of Evanston, ILL, defeated the Wimbledon finalists from Australia, Owen Davidson and William Bowrey, today and qualified to meet Roy Emerson and Fred Stolle of Australia, the defending titleholders, in the semi-finals of the United States doubles tennis championships.

Mickey Mantle, with one swing as a pinch-hitter, produced two nearly obsolete commodities at Yankee Stadium last night a soul-satisfying thrill for Yankee fans among the 14,385 customers on hand and elsewhere, and a ninthinning victory for his team.
Mayor Lindsay defended yesterday the Youth Board's use of the Gallo brothers, Brooklyn gangland figures, in easing racial tensions and said he would "certainly" call on them again if the need arose.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 26 (Reuters) Metalworkers throughout Argentina struck today in the worst labor conflict since Lieut. Gen. Juan Carlos Ongania's regime installed itself two months ago.

Huntington Hartford, the philanthropist, yesterday presented "on loan" to Frank's Restaurant, 315 East 125th Street, in Harlem, two paintings by his former wife Marjorie Steele, as a "key to the door of culture" for the community.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Aug. 26 (UPI) America's mightiest military rocket, carrying eight communications satellites for flashing messages to United States troops in Vietnam, exploded in a flash of orange and pink fire 80 seconds after a perfect launching today.

A criminal record dating from 1931 and evidence of mental depression were turned they dug into the background of James Rubertone to learn why he killed two persons and then himself in a Broadway office.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 The Interstate Commerce Commission denied today a request made by the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad for a lengthy postponement of the planned merger of the Pennsylvania and New York Central Railroads.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- The 68th American Exhibi- tion at the Art Institute of Chicago, the latest in this venerable museum's series of exhibitions surveying the contemporary art scene in the United States, is one of the most sensational shows ever mounted here. Twenty artists are represented in an exhibition entirely devoted to "en-...

An agreement between The World Journal Tribune and the pressmen's union was reached yesterday. It raised hopes of ending the 124-day shutdown of the new newspaper, formed by the merger of three New York dailies.

AN unwise use of the Stayman convention helped the defenders in the diagramed deal, which was played in the Denver Nationals. Many players who use this popular device tend to use it automatically whenever they hold a good hand, neglecting other possibilities that may be more effective.
NEW HAVEN, Aug. 26--A young man with a carbine stormed into an apartment here early this morning and shot seven persons, killing five of them.

ALBANY, Aug. 26 Alexander Aldrich, a cousin of Governor Rockefeller and unsuccessful candidate for a Republican Congressional nomination, has been appointed as a $25,000-a-year special assistant to the Governor, it was announced today.
LUSAKA, Zambia Within the next few weeks final approval is expected to be given for a 1,000-mile oil pipeline to supply this landlocked country in the heart of Africa.
IBADAN, Nigeria, Aug. 10 (Delay) The other day, caddles at the Ibadan Golf Club stumbled across two bullet-ridden bodies lying in the rough.
BERLIN, Aug. 26 (UPI) A 4-year-old Canadian girl kidnapped early Monday was found today in a garden hut. Her abductor was still being hunted.
Edward I. Koch, the Greenwich Village Democratic leader, and New York University continued their battle yesterday over the university's plan to build a library south of Washington Square Park.

In the nearly three years that I have been your President, I have spoken on numerous occasions about the foreign policy of the United States. I naturally hope that my fellow citizens have read and remembered all these speeches. However, as a onetime school teacher, I am aware that one cannot count on universal enthusiasm for even the greatest literature. So I am not optimistic.

TOKYO, Aug. 26 (UPI) A Japan Air Lines Convair 880 jet airliner exploded in flames today while taking off on a training flight from Tokyo's Haneda International Airport. The five persons aboard, all Japanese, were killed.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Aug. 26 (AP) Two Dallas, youths, Mike Estep and Sherwood Stewart, upset the two topseeded players today in the National Junior Davis Cup tennis competition at the Poughkeepsie Tennis Club.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, Aug. 26 (AP)--A taller American basketball team overwhelmed Argentina, 94-59, today in the Pan-American Maccabiah Games.
LONDON, Aug. 26 (AP) Lady Ursula James, sister of the Earl of Shrewsbury, was killed today in a light plane crash off the English Channel island of Alderney. She was 57 years old.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 26 (AP) Roberto Clemente got four consecutive hits tonight, sparking a 17-hit attack that carried the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 7-4 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

SION, Switzerland, Aug. 26 (UPI)--Hermann Geiger, the Swiss "glacier pilot," who braved death time and again to rescue lost or injured Alpinists, was fatally injured today when a glider crashed into his plane 60 feet above the runway of the Sion Civil Airport. He was 51 year old.

BUFFALO, Aug. 26 (UPI) Willie Sutton, bank robber and prison escape artist, was reported in satisfactory condition today in Buffalo General Hospital after removal of a section of the main artery of the abdomen.
PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 26--Mrs. Lillian Eddy Rice retired residential lighting spe- cialist for General Electric in New York City, died here yesterday at the age of 64 after a long illness.

Hayden, Stone, Inc., reported yesterday an "unexplainable disappearance" of 5,000 shares of International Business Machines. The stock, at yesterday's closing price, was valued at more than $1.5million.

LONDON, Aug. 26--Rolls-Royce, Ltd., announced tonight the terms for a double takeover which, at a cost of about 62-million ($173.6-million), will make it one of the two biggest airplane engine manufacturers in the world.
Buell Hoilister, partner in and a founder of Pyne, Kendall Hollister, stockbrokers at 37 Wall Street, died yesterday in his home at 125 West 63d street. His age was 82.

NEWARK, Aug. 26--Miss Althea Josephine Hawkins was married today to Apollo K. Kironde, Uganda's permanent representative to the United Nations and president this month of the Security Council. Miss Hawkins is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry H. Hawkins of Brooklyn and Port of Spain, Trinidad. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Asanasio Kironde of Entebbe, Uganda, and the late Mr. Kironde.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 26 Dr. Ralph R. Wilkinson, who delivered about 3,000 babies during his career as an obstetrician here, died Tuesday at the age of 90.
MIAMI, Aug. 26 (AP) A hurricane made another northward shift today and brushed almost harmlessly past the Leeward Islands on a track that will keep it clear of Puerto Rico.

The "little summit" meeting in Bogota, Colombia, last week has assumed added significance with publication of the full test of the "Declaration of Bogota." The conference provided a spark of light in the gloom-caused by Argentina's military coup d'etat, which made it necessary to defer the Council of Foreign Ministers scheduled for next Monday.

Mayor Lindsay has a low threshbld of tolerance for other people's verbiage. He made this quite plain during the Board of Estimate's four-hour public hearing on New York University's prospective new library in Greenwich Village.
Miss Gloria M. Kaufman of New York was married yesterday afternoon to sol Charles Klein, president of the Paul Art Press. Rabbi Julius Mark performed the ceremony in his study at Temple Emanu-El.

Singing bravely as they marched up the ramps at Grand Central Terminal, the little people carried guitars, tennis rackets, fishing rods, stuffed animals, live frogs, clothes and an assortment of thing's They had made.

Two 23-Year-old men were indicted here yesterday on firstdegree murder charges in the killing of Assistant Prof. Charles J. Gallagher, a Columbia University nuclear physicist whose body was found in Central Park on April 25, 1964.

ATLANTA, Aug. 26 -- Joe Torre, Atlanta's slugging catcher, brought an abrupt end to the Braves' five-game losing streak tonight in Atlanta Stadi- um. Torre hit a pair of homers to lead his teammates to a 6-3 victory over the New York Mets.
Prices of Government and corporate bonds fell sharply yesterday while municipal issues closed steady.

LAKESIDE, Mich., Aug. 26 Miss Marjorie Ellen Greenleaf, daughter of Charles Willard Greenleaf of Elkhart, Ind., and the late Mrs. Greenleaf, was married here this evening to Paul Richard Valliere, son of Mrs. Ruth B. Valliere of Boston and Bernard F. Valliere of Blandford, Mass.
CHICAGO, Aug. 26 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. announced today a halt in street demonstrations against housing bias in the Chicago area.

RICHMOND, Aug. 26 Miss Emory Dabney Williams, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Carrington Williams Jr., was married this evening to Timothy Columbus McCoy, son of Mrs. Hulburt Christopher McCoy of Gordonsville and the late Dr. McCoy.

ATLANTIC, CITY, Aug. 26 (AP) Ralph Galle's Rivoli, second choice in the feature race at Atlantic City, rallied, in the last quarter-mile today to defeat Tosinisbad by a length and a quarter with Lost Lad, another outsider, third, another length and a quarter back.
CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP) Tom Rolfe is a strong favorite to win the $100,000 added Washington Park Handicap tomorrow at Arlington Park.
RHINEBECK, N.Y., Aug. 26 Governor Rockefeller spent another hot day today as the star attraction on the upstate county fair circuit.

PRYOR, Okla., Aug. 26 President Johnson issued today an unusually strong and eloquent appeal to the Soviet Union to "abandon the dogmas and vocabularies of the cold war" and join the United States in "rational acts of common endeavor" despite the war in Vietnam.

The official disclosure that there have been no fewer than twelve occasions in South Vietnam since July 1 in which allied air and artillery strikes have hit civilians and friendly troops confirms reports that such incidents have been more numerous than hith erto acknowledged.

HOMER, La., Aug. 26, (UPI) Twenty-five Negroes got out of jail today and trudged off on their voter registration march, two days after Louisiana's registration books were closed.
Sterling declined yesterday on foreign exchange markets here. It fell 9 points to $2.7884 from $2.7893 on Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) Vice President Humphrey said today that a crisis of confidence threatened the progress of the civil rights movement.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 26 The New England junior Wightman team defeated the Eastern Lawn Tennis Associatian team, 6 to 3 at the Field Club of Greenwich today in their annual interassociation junior Wightman Cup match.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 26 Two Noroton (Conn) Yacht Club skippers, Manton Scott and Bruce Mosbacher, were winners in the annual Pequot Yacht Club Blue Jay regatta that ended today with one race on Long Island Sound. The final race was sailed in an 8 to 10knot southerly breeze.

TOKYO, Aug. 25 The Japanese Government, pressing a new campaign to gain greater administrative rights in the strategic island base of Okinawa, has begun to backtrack on some of its stronger statements of the last few days.
UTRECHT, the Netherlands, Aug. 26 (AP) The East German men's relay team broke the European record for the 400meter free-style today in 3:36.8 at the European swimming championships.

The Metropolitan Opera has sent out a call to arms. Soldiers are needed to fill the ranks of the armies of Caesar and Antony for the battle scene in the production of Samuel Barber's new opera, "Antony and Cleopatra," which opens the new house at Lincoln Center Sept. 16.
ROME, Aug. 26--Pope Paul VI has urged the Government of South Vietnam to seek contacts with "the legitimate representatives" of North Vietnam, L'Astrolabio, a left wing publication, said today.
DETROIT, Aug. 26 (UPI)--The nation's three largest car makers have planned a higher production pace, at least through October, than last year, Ward's automotive reports said today.

LONDON, Aug. 26 (AP) A 19-year-old student from Los Angeles who boarded a transAtlantic jet airliner without a ticket was allowed to fly to Copenhagen tonight after his mother guaranteed his fare, airline officials said.

BONN, Aug. 26 Despite the Government's contention that the defense crisis is over, the Social Democratic party today renewed its demand for the resignation of Kai-Uwe von Hassel, the Defense Minister.

The Chase Brass Copper Company, a subsidiary of the Kennecott Copper Corporation, said yesterday it would reduce its prices to wholesalers on copper water tube and threadless copper pipe by 14 cents a pound, effective Monday.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 26 (AP) Dr. Curtis H. Dickins, former Chief of Navy Chaplains, died yesterday at the age of 101 in La Jolla, Calif.

MERIDEN, Conn., Aug. 26 Edward E. Elsenheimer, secretary of the Meriden Record Company, publisher of The Meriden Morning Record and The Meriden Journal, died today at his home here. He was 73 years old.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Aug. 26 (AP) A United States Circuit Court judge refused today to stay a Federal court order that the General Electric Company must deal with a negotiating team that includes representatives of seven unions.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 26 Mrs. Albert B. Sabin, the wife of the discoverer of the oral antipolio vaccine was found dead in the bedroom of their home here by a daughter this afternoon. She was 56 years old.
Renewed selling pressure threw the stock market into a new tailspin yesterday. Prices fell sharply on a broad front, carrying leading market indicators to new lows for the year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) The Agriculture Department announced this week that it would make export subsidy payments in cash only on United States products sold abroad.
DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 26--Miss Susan Mercer Field, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Albert Field, was married this evening to John Townsend Sammis, sonof Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Rutledge-Sammis.

The men who helped build the new Metropolitan Opera House at Lincoln Center over the past seven years have been invited to a special dress rehearsal of Samuel Barber's "Antony and Cleopatra," on Sept. 10. The opera will open the new house Sept. 16.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 26 (UPI) Russ Snyder's single with the bases filled in the 12th inning tonight gave the Baltimore Orioles a 3-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox after the Orioles had dramatically tied the score in the ninth on pinch homers by Vic Roznovsky and Boog Powell.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) The Pentagon said today its policy was to provide relatives of servicemen missing or captured in Vietnam with "immediate, sympathetic and personal notifications." It said it supplied continuing help through the personal services of a casualty assistance or survivor officer."

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 26 Rhodesia's Minister of Justice, Law and Order, Desmond LardnerBurke, told Parliament today that proposed constitutional amendments to allow the Government to detain subversives were designed to restore normality and end "a constant state of emergency.'
Reactive Metals, Inc., announced yesterday it would spend $70-million in the next four years to expand titanium production capacity.

Dozens of registered nurses at the Bellevue Hospital Center threatened yesterday to resign because they had not received the salary increases promised by the city last May after threatened mass resignations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) The United States military and command structure in Europe will move its headquarters from outside Paris to Stuttgart, West Germany, early next year, the Defense Department announced today.
There was a time when the Harvard Club meant strictly the company of good fellows and absolutely no women allowed. But, as George Bernard Shaw observed, "Women upset everything."

SAYVILLE, L. I, Aug. 26 Walter Stubner of East Hartford, Conn., won the Thistle Class national sailing chainpionship today despite a l0thplace finish in the final event of the six-race series held at Great South Bay off here. It was the worst finish of the series for Stubner's Endeavor. Stubner's score for the week showed four firsts, a fifth and a tenth. Tom Wilson of New

ALBANY, Aug. 26 The Board of Regents said today that a proposed state lottery to raise money for education presented "serious moral considerations" and "might well be injurious to the advancement of education."
TUCKAHOE, L.I., Aug. 26 A bearded Suffolk County policeman arrested three young men here last night on charges of selling marijuana among the young summer set in the Hamptons.

Reginald Barrett, director of the programs in diplomacy for the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, 345 East 46th Street, died on Thursday in Johannesburg, South Africa. He was 54 years old and lived at 71 Popham Road in Scarsdale, N. Y.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 26 The South Vietnamese election campaign opened tonight on a note of disappointment and tragedy.

STRATFORD, Ont., Aug. 24 What's a brand new play, about the last of the Czars, no less, doing in a repertory theater where the emphasis has been on Shakespeare and a few other classics like Chekhov, Moliere and Wycherley?

WAUWATOSA, Wis., Aug. 26 (UPI) Gov. Warren P. Knowles put four National Guard units at the disposal today of Wauwatosa officials, who fear possible white violence because of civil rights demonstrations in this affluent Milwaukee suburb.

WASHINGTON, Aug.26 (AP)--The Securities and Exchange Commission today barred three New York City security representatives from further association with any broker-dealer for what the commission said were violations of the antifraud provisions of the Federal securities laws.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 The North Vietnamese Government's hostility toward peace talks, it was suggested today, may be based on the fear that the Vietcong would collapse once negotiations began and that Hanoi's influence and position would be damaged by any retreat from the present hard line.

Edward S. McCann, founder and former president of E.S. McCann Son, a construction concern with headquarters at 630 Fifth-Avenue died yesterday morning in Plainview, L. I. He was 75 years old and lived in Miami Shores, Fla.
PARIS, Aug. 26 Many American tourists here seem more discouraged and offended by French money than by the foreign policy of President de Gaulle.
A Queens woman was accused of shooting her estranged husband in the stomach and attempting to strangle her 2-yearold niece while the three were driving across the Triborough Bridge early yesterday.

YONKERS, Aug. 26 -- Twenty-six harness-track drivers, three track officials and 27 gamblers were subpoenaed tonight to appear at a grand jury investigation into possible conspiracy affecting racing at Yonkers, Roosevelt and Monticello raceways.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, in two separate decisions, held today that neither variable-annuity life insurance companies nor face amount certificate investment companies could issue stock options to their employes.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 26 A Lincoln, Neb., shotshell-reloading equipment salesman turned in a perfect score of 100 targets today to top nearly 3,500 trapshooters in the Grand American Handicap of the Amateur Trapshooting Association of America.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 26 A new production of "Fireworks," a favorite modern operetta of the German-speaking world, was given here last night. The composer, Paul Burkhard, conducted and also provided most of the piano accompaniment.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I, Aug. 26-- Too many boats in too many classes finished too close together today in the third regatta of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's annual Race Week and the result was a chaotic situation that required extraordinary efforts by the race committee to establish who finished where.
Prices retreated along a broad front yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
SEATTLE, Aug. 26 (AP) Amid rumors and the usual mob of screaming teen-agers the Beatles picked up $73,717,81 as their cut of the gate here last night.

There was no trading in the Westec Corporation for the second successive day yesterday and the American Stock Exchange said the issue would not be permitted to open until the company gave out more detail on the activity of its president in the stock.

The "stacking up" of planes at busy airports some times causes such long delays that the jet passenger finds himself is the air longer than he did a quartercentury ago traveling by DC-3. Such tie-ups are among the tribulations caused by the tempestuous growth of air travel. Passenger traffic has almost tripled since 1955 and promises to double again by 1970.
A MEMBER of Veterans of Foregin Wars Post 9211 in Reno got up to nominate Leslie M. Fry as the Nevada Department commander a few years ago. The speech was long and flowery.

JOHANNESBURGH,--South Africa, Aug. 26--The Minister of Justice, Balthazar Vorster, said today that terrorists against South Africa were being trained by the United Arab Republic, the Soviet Union, Algeria, North Korea, the Congo Republic (Brazzaville), Communist China and Tanzania. He warned that the terrorists were being sent "to certain death."

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 26 (UPI) United States District Judge Herbert W.Christenberry today ordered public schools desegregated this school year in Plaquemines Parish (county), stronghold of Leander H. Perez Sr., the militant segregationist.
GLOUCESTER, Mass., Aug. 26 A growing number of devotees of Americana are coming here every summer to visit Beauport and to reconsider the phenomenon of the American tradition in the decorative arts.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 26-Jean H. Mcfarland,librarian of Vassar college since 1957-, died Wednesday of her home, 44 Fox Terrace. Her age was 59.

HAMILTON; N.Y., Aug. 26 Miss Judith Appley, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Asa Appley of Saddleback Farm and Deerfield Beach, Flag., was married today to Karl Otto Gratter. He is the son of John Leonard Grutter of Syracuse and Mrs. Clark V. Collins of Alexandria Bay.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 (AP) Jack McKinney was named head basketball coach at St. Joseph's College today. He succeeds Jack Ramsay, who resigned from his post with the nationally-ranked Hawks to become general manager of the Philadelphia. 76ers of the National Basketball Association.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP)--The Senate passed a bill by voice vote today to permit Federal officials to force a recalcitrant witness to testify in racketeering cases by granting him immunity from prosecution.
Contemporary art should be as much a part of the church's preaching as Sunday morning sermons, according to an official of the United Church of Christ.

DAILOC, South Vietnam, Aug. 26 (AP) First Lieut. Gerard Nugent, whose brother Patrick is President Johnson's son-in-law, is no celebrity to his fellow marines, but they say he did an outstanding job as a commander in recent fighting.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa. Aug. 26 (UPI) Kankakee, Ill., defeated Monterrey, Mexico, 2-1, today for fifth-place honors in the 20th annual Little League World Series. The winning run was scored on a throwing error in the sixth and final inning.

The president of the Communications Workers of America sent a telegram last night to the president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company asking that they meet in an effort to avert a strike by 22,000 telephone installers around the country.

Lunar Orbiter's two pictures of the earth taken from near the moon, 240,000 miles away, showed photographically for the first time the earth in one of its moon-like phases at present a crescent-shaped "lastquarter" earth.

Residents in a section of the South Brooklyn waterfront--a proposed urban renewal area-- have expressed fear that many low-income families who live in the area will be forced out by high-income housing and industrialization.

ALTEA, Spain--This village of whitewashed houses and blueenamel domed churches clings to a steep hillside overlooking a quiet, Mediterranean fishing harbor. But in summer, the lazy pueblo of 5,000 inhabitants becomes bloated with 15,000 tourists and the Arab-tinged sounds of Valenciano, the local dialect, are replaced by less musical tones of German, Dutch and English.
MOSCOW, Aug. 27--The Soviet wheat harvest is almost in and the crop looks good enough to give a much needed impetus to the leadership's ambitious agricultural policies.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 27-- President Johnson has been drawing a flurry of informal encomiums from sanitation engineers as a salesman for the sewage-treatment industry. Some, however, have been wondering this week if he was not overenthusiastic in intimating that a shortcut had been found toward cleaning up the nation's biggest single pollution problem, Lake Erie.
LAPLACE, La., Aug. 27 (AP) --Two cars collided on narrow U.S. 51 about 15 miles northeast of here early today, killing seven men--six of them Marines.
A new milling process has been devised that its sponsors say produces a whiter rice, a protein-rich rice bran and an inexpensive rice oil.

BETHEL, Conn., Aug. 27-- "The greatest moving sporting dog in the east" was the way Judge Elsworth S. Howell described the English setter, Ch. Valley Run Dinah Mite, his choice as best in today's Newtown Kennel Club show.
The West Side in the next few years will replace the East Side as the center of officebuilding construction in Manhattan, according to a study just completed by a New York realty company.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested two men yesterday less than 24 hours after they allegedly had held up a savings and loan association in the Bronx.

THERE are two excursions in this new novel by Francis Pol lini, whose "Glover" and "Night" created great expectations. The first is a European bedroom odyssey made by an ex-ballet star, Janet Hunter, who seeks through various sexual encounters to recapture the spiritual harmony she has lost along with her desire to dance. The second is the reader's journey into the consciousness of the disturbed girl. That journey's end alone explains her strange behavior.

FOR 50 centuries or more the majestic Nile has sustained Egypt, throbbing like lifeblood through the land of the Pharoahs before spending itself in one final muddy thrust into the shining blue Mediterranean. ROLLINSVILLE, Colo.-- The Moffat Road of Colorado (elevation 11,660 feet) was once a high adventure in railroading. Today, it is a high adventure in motoring. It is "The Complete Photographer" (Englewood Cliffs, N. J.: Prentice-Hall. 344 pages. $8.95), which he calls a "synthesis" of the preceding books, reorganized and updated.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) --Senator Wayne Morse, Democrat of Oregon, announced today he would not campaign for Democratic nominees in Oregon because of "sincere and honest differences of opinion" with some of them on foreign policy.

External Affairs Spokesman, Canberra: We favor all genuine third party attempts to get any movement toward an honorable peace. We are not optimistic that proposal for Asian peace conference will get any response but all avenues worth exploring some day may attain breakthrough.

A NEW idol is a-borning in the Soviet Union. The Russians call it elektronno-vychislitel' naya mashina or, for short, E.V.M., meaning "electronic calculating machine." When you see it you recognise it as the computer.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 27--Four miles a day of walking through the United Nations' corridors as a guide is a far cry from Devinder Faridkot's life in India. There, she is waited on by a staff of 20 because she is Princess Devinder, niece of the Rajah of Faridkot, a former princely state.

The Senate subcommittee investigating the crisis of the cities has elicited valuable testimony on the scope and character of the programs needed to reverse the present tidal drift toward urban decay and disorganization.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 26-- Two newspapers reported today that the town clerk of San Lorenzo, Luis Pitman, had been forced to resign because he was a Jew.

DALLAS, Aug. 27 (AP)-- The number of suspected encephalitis cases climbed by two to 104 today, the Dallas Health Department reported. The death toll remained at seven. Confirmed Dallas cases stood at 77.
