TOKYO, Aug. 27 (AP)--The International Siwmming Federation recognized today 10 men's and 13 women's world records set in 1966, including four by United States swimmers.

WESTMINSTER'S Collectors Series is growing into a project of genuine sta ture as more and more of the company's fine back list from the nineteen-fifties is restored to the catalogue.

The pro football war may be over in the front offices of the teams but it is far from over on television. The battle of ratings, pitting the National Football League and the National Broadcasting Company, will be fought on a larger scale than ever this season.
The first completed apartments in the twin 28-story Horizon House towers being built on the Palisades at Fort Lee, N.J., have been opened for public inspection.

Back-to-school selling is already showing up in store figures. With children back from camps and summer vacations, the department store and children's wear shops are doing a big business. Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were up 16 per cent over a year earlier. Total retail sales climbed 12 per cent.

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 27-- Miss Joan Wilson Edmonds, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Kirkpatrick Edmonds, was married today to Peter George MacDonald, son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. MacDonald. They Rev. Thomas C. Witter performed the ceremony in the Noroton Presbyterian Church.

THESE three books, all written by "believers," are dedicated to the proposition that, as the title of one suggests, flying saucers are "serious business." There is no doubt that the reports of "flying saucers" or "UFO's" (unidentified flying objects) constitute one of the most perplexing phenomena of our time. There are now on record detailed descrip tions of various craft that have been seen, not only in distant flight, but close to the ground.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 2-- President Carlos Lleras Res trpo's bid for emergency powers to get the new Colombian administration moving has hit a political roadblock.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Aug. 27 --If the New York Jets hope to win the American Football League's Eastern Division title and then the championship playoff, the team they must beat is the champion Buffalo Bills. If they play against the Bills the way they did in an exhibition game tonight, they may never lose again. The fired-up Jets routed the Bills, 34-17.
Eddie (Cannonball) Martin, a former bantamweight boxing championship, died yesterday at his home of a heart ailment. He was 63 and lived at 11 70th Street, Brooklyn.

An off-duty Housing Authority patrolman was arrested and charged with felonious assault yesterday after he shot a man outside a Bronx bar.

KINSHASA, the Congo, Aug. 27--An international tin conference organized by the Ministry of Land, Energy and Mines will open in Kinshasa, formerly called Leopoldville, Sept. 7. BOMBAY, India, Aug. 27 (Reuters)--Eighteen members of the Maharashtra state legislature resigned from the ruling Congress party today to protest the state government's handling of two big political demonstrations.

PARIS--Americans headed abroad know in advance that the European does not eat the same kind of breakfast they are used to at home. After a swing around the Continent, they also know that breakfast is different in each country. Often there are differences from region to region, or even from city to city.

Sweeping changes are being plotted by the New York Yankees for 1967, as the team enters the final month of its worst season in half a century. WASHINGTON, Aug. 27--Is it possible to have too many laws? The ancient Spartans thought so, and operated for 700 years on the principle that no written law was valid. AMONG eminent Victorians, John Bright, Quaker radical and embattled man of peace, occupies a unique place. The 19th century in England was as age of reform, and there was no lack of dedicated reformers. But it would be hard to find anyone who more steadfastly applied rigorous moral principles to politics and who more consistently questioned some of the dominant values of a society still aristocratic in its upper and deferential in its middle ranks.

The appointment of Rabbi Bernard Mandelbaum as president of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America was announced yesterday by Dr. Louis Finkelstein, chancellor of the seminary. The post had been vacant since 1952, when Dr. Finkelstein, fourth president of the 80-year-old institution of Conservative Judaism, was named chancellor.

Big pond, small lake, the naming doesn't matter. It is water, fresh water cupped in a hollow among the green hills, cool haven from summer's heat and hurry, a priceless heritage. PARIS. MARGUERITE DURAS, the celebrated French novelist of the Parisian avant-garde, is spending these summer days from nine to six--in a projection room on the ChampsElysees, editing a film, "La Musica," which she has just co-directed. Madame Duras is the first taken woman novelist to have taken to movie direction.
CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (UPI)-- Bold Bidder, a 4-year-old owned by John R. Gaines, closed fast in the stretch today to handily defeat the favored Tom Rolfe and win the $109,200 Washington Park Handicap.

A truck transportation company moved half of its New Jersey operations to Brooklyn yesterday in a "show arrival" designed to publicize the arrival of a new business. But things didn't quite work out as planned.

WATERVILLE, Ireland--The entire preposterous sequence of events started with a casual conversation at the Winged Foot Golf Club back home and reached its improbable climax here on the edge of a mountain stream that races down to the sea from the glorious green hills of Kerry. Maybe the leprechauns had a hand in it. There's no other explanation of an adventure that defies logic and common sense.

The American Tobacco Company announced yesterday the election of two vice presidents, Eugene F. Mooney and Julien B. McCarthy.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 30 Mr. and Mrs. Andrew A. Amatruda have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Elizabeth Amatruda, to Dr. James Foreman Flint, son of Dr. and Mrs. Orin Q. Flint of Delhi, N.Y.
BONN, Aug. 30 Defense Minister Kai-Uwe von Hassel left today for an inspection of Wilhelmshaven, West Germany's biggest naval base, on the North Sea.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Aug. 30 Bob Benning of Plainfield posted a two-under-par 36, 32 68 and won the top pro prize in the third annual New Jersey interclub golf championship today at the Spring Brook Country Club.

POINT ALBINO, Ont., Aug. 30 (Canadian Press) Tom Allan of Buffalo, the defending champion, was one of 30 Americans to qualify for the North American Lightning Class sailing championship in the four days of competition that began today.
WASHINGTON, Aug, 30 Is Harlem a sink of iniquity? Or is it an exciting, creative, inventive place in which to live?

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 30 The Soviet Union has mildly reproached Secretary General Thant for having sent a special representative to check on the Thailand-Cambodia border without the prior approval of the Security Council.
BELVEDERE, Calif., Aug. 30 (AP) West Coast teams finished the first day of the women's North American sailing championship yesterday in a one-two position on San Francisco Bay.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 Secretary of State Dean Rusk and members of a Senate armed services subcommittee argued today over how wide a commitment the United States needed throughout the world to keep the peace.
ONE of the paradoxes of today's stock market is that prices have fallen while earnings estimates for this year have been jacked up repeatedly.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) A bill that would increase rates and package sizes for parcel post was sent to President Johnson today by the House of Representatives.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 Two lawyers received Presidential appointments announced by the White House this evening.

The amazing Mets scored their fastest knockout in history last night over Sandy Koufax, chasing the great lefthander inside of three innings and overpowering the Los Angeles Dodgers, 10-4.
The stock market was a seesaw affair yesterday. Prices rose, fell, then rose again. At the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange, prices were generally up.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 30 (AP) Dr. S. Marx White, president of the board of regents of the American College of Physicians in 1931-32 and professor emeritus of the University of Minnesota Medical School, died Sunday. He was 93 years old.

The Overmyer Company, parent organization of operating companies in the warehousing, leasing, finance and communications fields--including a new television network--has leased 30,000 square feet of office space at 205 East 42d Street and the adjacent office tower at 201 East 42d Street.

Nancy Richey of San Angelo, Tex., who shares the No. 1 women's ranking in the United States with Mrs. Billie Jean King, will open the national tennis championships tomorrow against Valerie Ziegenfuss of San Diego, Calif.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 Prices received by farmers rose in August to the highest level since the Korean war, the Agriculture Department reported today.

NORTH HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 30 Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Allen have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Julia Darmour Allen, to Carlton H. Thiele of Bridgehampton, L.I., son of Mrs. Charles A. Thiele and the late Mr. Thiele.
A Negro who is a former member of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association was appointed assistant director of the civilian complaint police review board yesterday.
Five men convicted of conspiring to smuggle into the United States the largest amount of heroin ever seized by the Federal Narcotics Bureau received long prison sentences yesterday in Federal Court.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP)--Senate-House conferees reached agreement today on a $322-million highway safety bill to encourage states and cities to develop strong accident-prevention programs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. Charles L. Watkins, the Senate's first official parliamentarian, who guided that body's proceedings though a maze of rules and precedents, died yesterday at the Bethesda-Silver Spring Nursing Home in Maryland. He was 87 years old.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 30 The Brazilian Congress will be called into a special session to vote on the draft of a new Constitution to be drawn up by the Government.

Deputy Mayor Robert Price and Edward N. Costikyan, former New York County Democratic leader, will serve as political analysts for the statewide educational television network coverage of the Republican and Democratic State Conventions next week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP)--Moderate Republicans conceded bleakly tonight that, the way things are going, Barry Goldwater might be right in predicting that the party's 1968 convention will be under conservative control.

William Hallam Tuck, a former director general of the International Refugee Organization and an assistant to former President Herbert Hoover in relief and other activities, died Monday of a heart ailment in his summer home in Rougemont, Switzerland. He was 76 years old and lived in Upper Marlboro, Md.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 30 Israeli leaders dedicated their new Knesset building today before 5,000 guests, including speakers and parliamentary delegates from 41 nations.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 (AP) The Beatles closed another successful tour of the United States last night with a performance in Candlestick Park before about 25,000 hysterical fans.
The Cleveland Museum of Art will open on Sept. 10 an exhibition that represents the most important single collection of art works acquired by an American museum through purchase.

IT is hardly ever right to double a game contract that the opponents clearly expect to make. Inexperienced players sometimes double a game their opponents have reached voluntarily, and generally regret their action afterward. The possible profit is relatively small, and the loss may be big, especially if the opposition redoubles or if the double helps the declarer to make his contract.

ATHENS, Aug. 30 Olympic Airways, the Greek airline owned by Aristotle Onassis, will resume its daily flight to New York tomorrow. Pilots called off tonight their 15-day strike for a 50-per-cent pay raise. The strike grounded most of the company's domestic and foreign flights.

The Kimberly-Clark Corporation announced yesterday in Neenah, Wis., the election of four new directors and a successor to a retiring director. This raises the board total to 17 from 13. The producer of book and fine papers also announced record profits in its first fiscal quarter.

HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., Aug. 30 Mr. and Mrs. Lester J. Kelly have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Colleen Mary Kelly, to Lieut. (jg.) Robert Wesley Thornburgh Jr., U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thornburgh of Cincinnati.
The bond market produced some grounds for encouragement yesterday, but over-all the performance was mixed.

VENICE, Italy, Aug. 30 Spain is represented this year at the Venice Cinema Festival by a brooding, moody and sluggish motion picture, "La Busca" ("The Search"), a slice of Madrid tenement life about 1900.
The city began yesterday to buy 900 voting machines at $1,725 each to provide faster voting next November in the city's more populous election districts.
The appointment of Howard Cohen as vice president for corporate affairs was announced here yesterday by Revlon, Inc., the cosmetics producer.

PULASKI, Va., Aug. 30 Mr. and Mrs. Curtis Cleveland Jordan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Harris Jordan, to William Gaines Ellyson, son of Mrs. William Ellyson Jr. of Richmond and the late Mr. Ellyson.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30--President Johnson said today that he must assume that the Chinese Communists mean every militant word they utter until there is proof that they cannot or will not encourage a whole series of wars.
The 113-old-building of the Astor Library at 425 Lafayette Street, which has been taken over by the New York Shakespeare Festival, will have two small playhouses.
MIAMI, Aug. 30 Premier Fidel Castro conceded today that his Government was under stong internal and external economic and political pressure, but he vowed to continue "on our own way to Communism."
TOKYO, Aug. 30 (UPI) North Vietnam announced today that it had signed an agreement with Communist China to receive "nonrefundable" economic and technical aid presumably guns and rice.

EDWARD AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Aug. 30 (AP) Air Force Ma. William Knight reached a speed of five times that of sound today in an X-15 test of a coating designed to prevent air-friction heat from damaging the surface or structure of the rocket plane.
The United States rowing squad left last night from John F. Kennedy International Airport for the world rowing championships in Bled, Yugoslavia.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 The House passed tonight a stripped-down version of an Administration bill to create a Department of Transportation. The vote was 336 to 42.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 30 (UPI) The Communists have put prices on the heads of key United States and South Vietnamese civilian and military officials and have sent out squads to kill them, official sources said today.
Washington, Aug. 30 (UPI) A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner recommended today that Lake Central and Ozark airlines be authorized to provide new service between Louisville and Indianapolis.

Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner kept a ray of hope alive yesterday among those who would like to see him run for Governor with a statement that he was "not a candidate at this time."

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 30--James J. (Don) McNamara Jr. of the Boston Yacht Club won one race, finished second in another and then, when everybody was ashore, had to win a battle over the protest table today before keeping his position as leader in the men's North American sailing championship and the Mallory Cup.

Africans are most critical of the American presence in Vietnam and the treatment of Negroes in the United States, 10 American and Canadian college students said yesterday on their return from a two-month work-aid program in Africa.

Stockholders of Rust Craft Greeting Cards, Inc., refused yesterday to go along with a previously announced plan for a merger of the company into the Boise Cascade Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP)--The Defense Department gave assurances today that it would not "cut muscle" under a plan disclosed over the weekend to reduce civilian construction personnel in South Vietnam.

The Robertshaw Controls Company announced yesterday that it would raise prices 6 per cent on its installed temperature-control systems for commercial buildings as of Sept. 1. The change appeared to be in line with an earlier move by Honeywell, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 Arthur Sylvester, Assistant Secretary of Defense for Public Affairs, is expected to be questioned closely on Defense Department news policies regarding Vietnam when he appears tomorrow before the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations.

LONDON, Aug. 30 (UPI) The prosecution, opening its case against 17 persons accused of being part of an organized international crime syndicate, charged today that its leaders had extorted money and information by torture.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) Representative Adam Clayton Powell, Democrat of Manhattan, who has urged that Sargent Shriver resign as head of the Office of Economic Opportunity, got some similar advice from a colleague today.
LONDON, Aug. 30 Britain has not closed the door on a resumption of talks with Rhodesia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) An emergency board named by President Johnson to study issues underlying a threatened strike next month against American Airlines declined today to recommend settlement terms but urged against "an exaggerated settlement."
WAUKEGAN, Ill., Aug. 30 Mayor Robert V. Sabonjian took the first step today to carry out his threat to remove racial demonstrators from public payrolls and out of public housing.
Stock prices churned erratically in heavy trading yesterday and closed at the top of a strong upward swing.

Terminal operations in New York and other Atlantic Seaboard ports were likened to those of a public utility yesterday by an import spokesman, who said rates for such terminal services should be subject to review and determination by a Federal agency.

BUDAPEST, Aug. 30 (Reuters) East Germany, entered in the competition for the first time as a separate entity, won two of the three gold medals at stake when the European track and field championships began tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) Both the number of babies born in this country and the birth rate continued to decline during June, the United States Public Health Service reported today.
The spot rate on the British pound was mostly steady in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The final quotation was $2.7883, up 1 point from Monday.
Joseph F. McMahon, a retired food industry executive, died yesterday in his home at 2330 Gunther Avenue, the Bronx. He was 72 years old.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 The Chrysler Corporation introduced the first of the United States automobile industry's 1967 models today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 Inspectors of the United States Office of Education believe that Howard University's liberal arts college should raise its admission standards.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Aug. 30 (AP) Jack Disney of Pomona, Calif., and Preston Handy of New York won their preliminary heats today and qualified for the quarter-finals of the amateur sprint in the world bicycle racing championships. Both were clocked in 12.1 seconds for the 20 meters.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 30 (UPI) Gov. William W. Scranton has disclosed plans for Pennsylvania to participate in a high-speed railway pilot project that eventually could put the state at the crossroads of a 160-mile-an-hour rail transport system between Boston, Washington and the Midwestern states.

The Avco Corporation announced yesterday the promotion of E.D. Kenna to corporate vice president in charge of marketing and planning. He had served previously as vice president in charge of the Avco missiles, space and electronics group.
Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary is looking for a portrait of former Police Commissioner Theodore Roosevelt. He wants to hang it over the fireplace in his office at Police Headquarters.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 Senate and House negotiators hammered out today a compromise foreign-aid bill that gives the Administration $3.5billion, a little more money than it asked for.

THE United States road racing championship is going down to the last of the season's eight races for a decision. The championship will be determined next Sunday in a 500-mile contest over the picturesque four-mile Road America circuit in the hills of Elkhart Lake, Wis.
ATHENS, Aug. 30 The sentence of a Jehovah's Witness who was condemned to death three weeks ago for refusing to serve in the army was commuted today to four and a half years in prison.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 (AP) Fist fights and rock throwing broke out between Negro and white youths at an athletic meet today and 20 suffered minor injuries before the police quelled the disturbance.

CORNWALL-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 30 Eimer A. Wiener, a former concert manager and press agent, died of cancer yesterday in Cornwall Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 8 Horatio Street, New York City. He had a summer home here.

A Chinese Communist diplomat who sought asylum in the United States Embassy in Damascus last month said here yesterday that the leadership in Peking was "still very cautious" about any confrontation with the United States over Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI) The outgoing national commander of the American Legion, L. Eldon James of Hampton, Va., told delegates to the 48th annual convention that "America is doing what it must and what is necessary in South Vietnam necessary to the defense of freedom."
KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 30 On one of Karachi's busiest boulevards, motorists are confronted by a huge green sign that reads "interest-free bank interest you discard, ideology you preserve."

Mr. and Mrs. Elwyn Greeley Preston Jr. of 47 East 88th Street and Holderness, N.H., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Greeley Preston, to Henry Crosky Mustin 3d. He is the son of Mrs. B. Hubbard Mustin of San Diego, Calif., and Henry Ashmead Mustin of Washington.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI) House Republicans turned up today what they said was a fourth case in which heavy contributors to the President's Club had won special treatment from the Johnson Administration.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 30 Associate Justice Arthur D. Brennan of the State Supreme Court's Appellate Division and Mrs. Brennan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Smith Brennan, to William Stanley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter A. Stanley of Ossining.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 30 (AP)--Public schools here will start integrating their teaching staffs when classes open tomorrow, superintendent Carl J. Dolce announced today.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Aug. 30 Mr. and Mrs. Richard Nelson Parks have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Paula Hughes Parks, to Eric Gordon Dalrymple Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Dalrymple of Springfield.

American Airlines is going to the grass roots of America with 128 of its first-class Astrojet seats. And in the next two years the airline hopes to fill those seats with a couple of million of the 100 million persons who have never flown.
SAIGON, South Vietnam Aug. 30 (AP) Aerial flares lighted the sky above a skirmish only three miles south of Saigon tonight.

Efforts to resolve new obstacles to the publication of The World Journal Tribune appeared to be at a standstill yesterday, with no indication of when the new company would be able to put out its first edition.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 30 (AP) The Pittsburgh Pirates scored five runs in the fourth inning, two on Willie Stargell's bases-loaded single, and downed the Houston Astros, 8-2, tonight. The Pirates victory snapped the Astros' winning streak at six games.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 30 (AP) "Oil companies are not agencies of imperialist powers, but neither are they angels," Interior Minister Gonzalo Barrios said today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI) The United States Public Health Service set down desegregation guidelines today for all nursing homes participating in Medicare.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) The Senate passed and sent to the House by voice vote today a $19.7-billion highway bill authorizing grants to the states over the next five years.

Mrs. Rae Goldberg Sorin, vice chairman of the executive committee of the Democratic party in Kings County, died yesterday at Adelphi Hospital in Brooklyn. She was 84 years old and lived at 387 Bradford Street in that borough. Her husband, Herbert Sorin, died in 1930.
WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 30 The City of New Rochelle has won the right to tax a county owned restaurant, the Glen Island Casino, in Long Island Sound.
Johnny (Blue Moon) Odom held the New York Yankees to one hit, a first-inning double by Roger Maris, as he pitched the Kansas City Athletics to a 4-1 victory today.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 30 (AP) Buckpasser, thoroughbred racing's youngest millionaire, was withdrawn today from Saturday's $250,000 added New Hampshire Sweepstakes at Rockingham Park after his second unsatisfactory workout in three days.

There are dozens of football players out of work today, victims of the roster reductions in the National and American Leagues. Yesterday, the N.F.L. teams cut down to 43 players each, the maximum allowed this week, and most of the A.F.L. clubs to 40, the maximum permissible this season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI) Lunar Orbiter 1 apparently completed its photographic survey of possible astronaut landing sites on the moon without getting a picture of its teammate, Surveyor 1, space agency officials said today.
Unmarried applicants for aid to dependent children in Monmouth County, New Jersey, may place themselves in jeopardy of prosecution on charges of fornication or adultery.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 30 The Government ordered the closing today of the University of Antioquia in Medellin for the rest of this semester because of a student strike that has lasted a month. Under an earlier decree, none of the 7,000 students will be eligible to take this semester's final examinations.
GREENVALE, L.I., Aug. 30--The Long Island Festival, which just completed the first financially successful season in its four-year history, will be back next year.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Aug. 30 The Beckett Aviation Corporation announced today that the Federal Aviation Agency has certified the company to operate at Category II minimums cutting the standard instrument minimums for ceiling and visibility by 50 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today the nominations or the following four Ambassadors:
BUDAPEST, Aug. 30 Michael and John Savko of Van Nuys, Calif., were sentenced today to three months in prison by a Hungarian court that convicted them on a charge of sedition.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP) Robert Held of the Monmouth, N.J., Yacht Club maintained his lead today in the National junior sailing championships on Lake Michigan.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Aug. 30 The engagement of Miss Frances Elizabeth Sherer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clark Grosjean Sherer, to Peter Devigne Caldwell has been announced by the parents of the prospective bride. Mr. Caldwell is the son of the late Mrs. Blanche Devigne Caldwell of New York and the late Nelson Forsyth Caldwell of Cincinnati.
OTTAWA, Aug. 30 The House of Commons was caught in a cross-fire of angry partisan debate tonight as it ended the second day of consideration of a Government bill to end the nationwide railway strike.

Withholding of taxes for New York City starts tomorrow on paychecks received by more than three million residents and commuters. The city hopes the new levies will yield $160-million toward the current $4.6billion budget.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 30 The Alabama Senate today scheduled a vote tomorrow morning on Gov. George C. Wallace's plan to prohibit Alabama public schools from desegregating voluntarily under agreements with the Federal Government. The bill would provide a method for the Governor to take control of most of the state's public schools.

"A large percentage" of the 4,000 Puerto Ricans who voted for the first time in the Bronx in 1965 filed improper affidavits and should not have been allowed to vote, a spokesman for a Bronx grand jury said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 The tables have turned for Arthur Sylvester. When he was chief of the Washington bureau of The Newark Evening News he was known as an aggressive reporter who took no guff from Government officials.

DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 30 About 25,000 people will pay from $3 to $7.75 for the privilege of watching a dozen 3-year-old trotters go postward tomorrow in the 41st annual Hambletonian Stake, harness racing's prime showcase. It will be the 10th straight time this blue-ribbon event will be held at the Du Quoin state fair grounds, where it was shifted from Goshen, N.Y. in 1957.
Governor and Mrs. Rockefeller headed the guest list last night at the Suffolk County Republican Ball in the Plaza Hotel here.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 30--President de Gaulle warned today that the war in Vietnam, pressing on Cambodia's frontier, could lead the world to its worst disaster.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 109.2 on Monday from 109.3 on Friday.

ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 30 (AP) Carl Yastrzemski hit a homer with a man on to highlight a fine-run rally in the sixth inning tonight and lift the Boston Red Sox to a 7-6 victory over the California Angels.

Miss Rosmari Ann Malloy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Wilkinson Malloy, was married on Sunday to John Philip Case, son of Everett Case, president of the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation and Mrs. Case of Van Hornesville, N.Y., and New York.
CODY, Wyo., Aug. 30 Martin W. Littleton, District Attorney of Nassau County, N.Y., in the nineteen-thirties and later a prominent criminal defense lawyer, died here yesterday. He was 68 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI)--An Inland Steel lawyer, J. Edward Day, denied today reports that the company planned to donate its property at the south end of Lake Michigan as site for a second state medical school and for inclusion in the proposed Indiana dunes national lakeshore.
A spate of bargain hunting brought a last minute recovery on the London Stock Exchange yesterday. The market was also buoyed by reports of a rally in stocks on Wall Street.

The engagement of Miss Jean Bennett Strakosch to H. Wells Walker 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walker Jr. of Hartford, has been made known by the prospective bride's father, Charles Edgar Strakosch of 26 East 63d Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 The Johnson Administration, jarred by what has been happening in the stock and bond markets and by the steep climb in interest rates, is taking another look at the possibility of some kind of tax increase at the current session of Congress to ease the pressure on the economy.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 30 Townsend Clarke, the Army's 1966 football captain and linebacker, said. "For the past few seasons we have had a name coach [Paul Dietzel]. We had to rally round the name. Now we have a man to work for who gives us work and dirt and we all like the change."
LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, Aug. 30 (AP) An engine-room explosion killed two crewmen on the British submarine Rorqual early today off Portuguese Mozambique, Portuguese authorities reported.

Competition, which can add zest to life, can also add a little complexity to commodity trading. The members of the Chicago Board of Trade have just voted, 416 to 267, in favor of establishing a live beef cattle futures contract. This will compete with the two live cattle futures contracts now traded by its neighbor, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 30 (AP) Jim Northrup, Al Kaline and Norm Cash hit homers in support of Earl Wilson's seventh straight victory and his 16th of the year as the Detroit Tigers defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 5-4, tonight. It was the fourth loss in a row for the American League leaders.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 The United Mine Workers announced today that it had signed an improved agreement covering union members in the northeast Pennsylvania hard coal counties.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 (AP) Five persons, were killed today when a police helicopter and a radio station's freeway observation helicopter collided near Dodger Stadium and crashed in flames, the police reported.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Aug. 30 (AP)--Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower spent about a half-hour today discussing domestic and foreign issues with seven visiting Republican candidatas.

MIAMI, Aug. 30 (AP)--A hurricane twisted toward the United States mainland today, carrying top winds of 120 miles an hour. The new course, in the general direction of the Carolinas, postponed and probably canceled an attempt to quell the storm by seeding it with silver iodide crystals.
Mrs. Charles D. Reader of 4 East 95th Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Josephine Anne Reader, to Alan Kotliar, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Kotliar of New York.

Claude D. Watts, a former president of the New York Mercantile Exchange, died yesterday of a heart attack in Narragansett, R.I., while on vacation. He was 65 years old and lived in Mountain Lakes, N.J.
Michael Drinkhouse, a Manhattan restaurateur, who has been hoping for years to have a "name" thoroughbred run in his colors, must have felt yesterday that he finally had one.
Montgomery Ward Co. reported yesterday in Chicago a decline in profits for the six months ended Aug. 3, despite an increase in sales.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 30 The engagement of Miss Carole Irene Faller to Jacques Andre Mercier of Paris has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Richards Faller.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has upheld the first complaint ever filed by a union under the equal employment provisions of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 30 The General Confederation of Labor has demanded that the Argentine military regime free all political prisoners. Union leaders said last night that this would include jailed university students as well as 2,500 workers accused of industrial sabotage by the previous Government.

Mayor Lindsay announced plans yesterday for a new airport for small private planes and light cargo aircraft in a section of Staten Island now used for garbage disposal.

FIRE ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 30 The Federal Government announced today emergency measures to head off speculation by private builders and to control troublesome automobile traffic on the Fire Island National Seashore.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP) Max Alvis's two-run homer in the second inning, the first Cleveland home run in Chicago this season, launched the Indians to a 6-2 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight.
If Mrs. Motley leaves office before Sept. 20, the Public Officers Law provides that the Mayor convene the eight Manhattan City Councilmen, who will choose an interim successor.
In a stuffy, slightly worn suite on the fourth floor of the Hotel Commodore, Howard J. Samuels issued a "position paper" yesterday on crime prevention in New York State.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 Members of the House Administration Committee are looking into a complaint by the estranged wife of Representative Adam Clayton Powell that she has not been receiving the payroll checks made out to her, although the checks have been cashed regularly.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 30 (AP) Two home runs by Pete Rose and one by Deron Johnson, his third in the last two games, helped the Cincinnati Reds beat the St. Louis Cards, 6 4, tonight as the Reds stretched their winning streak to seven games.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 30 (AP) Three members of a Long Island family were killed today in a head-on collision of two cars at the intersection of Montauk Highway and a road leading to the East Hampton Airport.
The United States Plywood Corporation and Champion Papers, Inc., jointly announced yesterday that they were considering plans to merge.
TOKYO, Aug. 30 China called today for anti-American uprisings throughout the world "so United States imperialism can be nibbled up bit by bit" while United States troops are occupied in Vietnam.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 (AP) The San Francisco Giants broke open a close game in the eighth inning, scoring four runs on homers by Tito Fuentes and Jim Hart and defeating the Philadelphia Phillies, 7-1, tonight.

Of course the very idea of ballet dancers, those ethereal creatures, threatening anything so crude as strike action may seem incongruous. Yet those ethereal creatures have to eat. They find themselves in a new ensemble role called "Labor," pitted against the direction of their own companies, called, unfamiliarly, "Management."

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 30 Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Totten Sutton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Anne Sutton, to David Duncan Robinson. He is the son of Mrs. Ann Robinson of Stoke-on-Trent, England, and the late Thomas Robinson.

ARDMORE, Pa., Aug. 30 The 66th United States Amateur golf championship, which starts here tomorrow, is viewed as a stepping stone for Bobby Cole of South Africa and collegiate golfers. The field of 150 that will tee off for the first of four 18-hole stroke-play rounds has a formidable roster of youthful experts, including 18year-old Cole, the British Amateur champion.
Construction has begun on the first phase of a three-year program to make commuting on the Long Island Rail Road quicker and more comfortable.
WHAT do construction workers find when they open their lunch bags?
Northwest Airlines, Inc., was the only one of the five airlines affected by the recent machinist's union strike to operate profitably in the month of July.
The Rev. Dr. Elmer T. Clark, retired secretary of the World Methodist Council and a Methodist historian, died Monday in Birmingham, Ala., after a long illness. He was 79 years old.
Walter Kerr has been appointed drama critic of The New York Times.

In the light of the shambles the settlement of the recent airlines strike made of national wage policy, a Presidential emergency board has understandably shrunk from any attempt to set forth the specific terms it believes ought to prevail in the current contract dispute covering mechanics on American Airlines.

DANCE came once more to Central Park when the New York Shakespeare Festival presented the opening of the fifth Rebekah Harkness Foundation Dance Festival last night at the Delacorte Theater. If that sounds like a lot of festivals this would be appropriate for the atmosphere was festive, too.

President Johnson put his finger on the principal explosive force in today's world when he told the American Legion that, by 1970, more than half the world's people would live in the southern half of the globe, yet they would command only a sixth of the world's goods and services.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 Martin W. Clement, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad from 1935, and chairman from 1949, until his retirement in December, 1951, died early today after several recent illnesses that had confined him to his home in suburban Rosemont. He was 84 years old.

Top-level executive changes were announced yesterday by the directors of the Westec Corporation, the Houston-based mining and real estate company whose shares were suspended from trading on the American Stock Exchange for 10 days by the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday.

ASK a gunner which is the most difficult of game birds and from his answers you'll get a pretty good idea of his home area. The grouse or woodcock will probably be named first by New Englanders, a man from the Plains States will likely nominate the pheasant, and a Southerner is certain to pick the dove and quail.
BENTON HARBOR, Mich., Aug. 30 (AP) Two white youths shot and wounded a Negro tonight in the wake of a protest march that turned into a rock-throwing demonstration, the police said.
Three district attorneys promised yesterday to cooperate with the Brooklyn grand jury investigation into charges that harness races had been fixed by drivers and gamblers.
Mayor Lindsey disclosed yesterday that he established his first Little City Hall last Aug. 10 in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

C. Shelby Carter, executive director of the Mayor's Commission for Physical Fitness, resigned his unsalaried post yesterday, charging Mayor Lindsay with an "apparent lack of appreciation" for what the commission could do.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 Chauncey Steele of Cambridge, Mass., scored victories over two New Yorkers today in reaching the semi-finals of the Middle States senior grass-court tennis championship at the Germantown Cricket Club.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 30 (AP) The United States Steel Corporation expects to spend this year a little less than $500million on capital improvements, compared with $600million that originally had been planned, Roger M. Blough, board chairman, said today.
General de Gaulle wasted no time after his arrival in Cambodia in reasserting that his chief interest is the achievement of peace in Vietnam and Southeast Asia.

BIRKDALE, England, Aug. 30 (UPI) Tony Jacklin, an unheralded British golfer, raised hopes for a local victory in the $200,200 Carling world golf championship today when he shot a 10-under-par 63 practice round.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) Representative Glenn R. Davis complained today that a United States information Agency film, "John F. Kennedy, Years of Lightning, Day of Drums," was to be used for political purposes.
ALBANY, Aug. 30 Former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey has turned down a bid to become one of the Republican candidates for the 15 at-large delegate positions at the State Constitutional Convention.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) Mrs. Constance Baker Motley of New York City was confirmed by the Senate today as a United States district judge for Southern New York. As far as can be determined, she is the first Negro woman named to the Federal bench.
STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 30 Miss Isabelle H. Siegel and Roger Noel Greene plan to marry in November.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 More than 400 San Francisco nurses voted tonight to accept a new city wage offer and return to jobs they had abandoned for a day by reporting in "sick."

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the city "has gone about as deeply into the well as it can on local taxation" and that he hoped it would not be necessary to impose new taxes in the foreseeable future.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 30 President Kenneth D. Kaunda said that he would not attend the Commonwealth Prime Ministers' conference in London next week. He said at a news conference that Foreign Minister Simon M. Kapwepwe would head the Zambian delegation instead.
A $500,000 order for new furniture and equipment for Bellevue Psychiatric Hospital was prepared yesterday by the Hospitals Department and the Health Services Administration.
The two-year separation period for couples acting under the state's new divorce law begins tomorrow.
ALBANY, Aug. 30 Former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey has turned down a bid to become one of the Republican candidates for the 15 at-large delegate positions at the State Constitutional Convention.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) Mrs. Constance Baker Motley of New York City was confirmed by the Senate today as a United States district judge for Southern New York. As far as can be determined, she is the first Negro woman named to the Federal bench.
STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 30 Miss Isabelle H. Siegel and Roger Noel Greene plan to marry in November.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 More than 400 San Francisco nurses voted tonight to accept a new city wage offer and return to jobs they had abandoned for a day by reporting in "sick."

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the city "has gone about as deeply into the well as it can on local taxation" and that he hoped it would not be necessary to impose new taxes in the foreseeable future.
The Columbia Pictures Corporation announced after a directors meeting yesterday the election of Ben Regan to the board.
MONTREAL, Aug. 30 A scale model of the New York State pavilion at the Expo 67 world exhibition here was put on exhibit today.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Aug. 30 Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Flanagan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Ann Flanagan, to Dr. M. Peter Heilbrun. He is the son of Dr. Norman Heilbrun and the late Mrs. Heilbrun of Buffalo.
The Allied Chemical Corporation announced yesterday the election of three executive officers.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 31 United States Navy pilots destroyed a North Vietnamese patrol boat and damaged another early today in the Gulf of Tonkin, a United States military spokesman said.
RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 31 The State Tax Study Commis sion recommended today that North Carolina impose a tax of two cents a package on cigarettes.

The engagement of Miss Elaine Leshnower to Michael R. Roberts has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Leshnower of Flushing, Queens, parents of the prospective bride. Mr. Roberts is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Roberts of Bayside, Queens.
One of the men who was closest to former Mayor Robert F. Wagner in his capacity as the Mayor's chief labor mediator, Morris Tarshis, has won recognition from Mayor Lindsay.

FARMINGTON, Conn., Aug. 31 In the First Church of Christ (Congregational) today, Miss Jean Graham Gear, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick T. Gear, was married to Samuel Hazard Gillespie 3d, son of Mrs. Ruth Reed Gillespie and S. Hazard Gillespie of New York.

NAPEAGUE, L.I., "I just love picnics," Mrs. Wil liam Lewis, barefoot, said in a soft Southern drawl as she glanced about the dunes to select a proper site. "This is the loveliest spot of all and, let's see, the wind's from the southwest. How about here?"

THOSE who get up early enough in the morning can spot a figure in gray sweat togs jogging around the Central Park reservoir, but it's not Clark Kent; it's Arnold Guy Fraiman, the square-jawed city Commissioner of Investigation who charged yesterday that there
In an otherwise peaceful day for commodities, the cocoa market managed to cause a little excitement yesterday. Heavy ume caused a rush of orders at the day's end and the final quotations were late.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The Administration's rejection of the proposal by the Senate Democratic Policy Committee of a reduction of the United States armed forces in Europe is only the latest instance of its settled policy of negativism
The Union Camp Corporation, a paper bag producer, announced here yesterday the election as a director of R. Manning Brown Jr., executive vice president of the New York Life Insurance Company.
ANGRA DO HEROISMO, Azores, Aug. 31 (UPI) The Dutch liner Prins der Nederland hit a rock south of Flores Island today and was in danger of sinking, the ANI news agency reported.

Alumni officials of the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L.I., reported yesterday that 186 of the last graduating class of 196 were known to be serving at sea on ships of the merchant marine.

LOTUS LAND; on the fifth floor of B. Altman Co., today begins its fourth season of offering Far Eastern shop signs, sukiyaki tables, ceramic stools and other examples of the exotic. The shop will stay open through Christmas.

SOUTHPORT, England, Aug. 31 (AP) Kel Nagle, a slopeshouldered Australian, shot four birdies and an eagle on the back nine for a 68 and took a twostroke lead today in the $200,000 Carling golf tournament, the world's richest. First prize is worth $35,000.

OTTAWA, Aug. 31--The Government tonight paved the way for parliamentary approval of back-to-work legislation by proposing additional wage increases for 120,000 railway workers. Final action is expected Thursday.

MIAMI, Aug. 31 (AP) After making passes at every land mass from the Leeward Islands to Florida, Hurricane Faith turned tonight to a northeast path that could lead it far from the United States mainland.

BEFORE the start of the 18th and final round of the recent Piatigorsky Cup Chess Tournament in Santa Monica, Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, the United States champion, and Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union were tied at 10 -6 , almost mathematically beyond reach of the field.

Following several weeks of advancing prices for the raw sugar they use, leading refiners raised prices yesterday by 10 cents per 100 pounds. The increase is effective at the close of business on Sept. 9.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) After a heated discussion about including alcoholic beverages and tobacco, the Senate approved by a 74-to-2 vote today a two-year extension of the Food for Peace Program and a new $5-billion authorizetion to pay for it.

LEBANON, N.J., Aug. 31 Harry L. Husson, who retired in 1955 as assistant engineer of manufacture of the Western Electric Company, died yesterday at Trenton State Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived on Deer Hill Road here.

Tot Seymour, a writer of lyrics for popular songs since the early nineteen-twenties,died yesterday at her home, 215 West 75th Street. She was in her 70's and the widow of Harold Seymour, a business executive who died in 1959.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Aug. 31 (UPI) Kentucky threw its support today behind a move by Delaware to revise the system of casting Electoral College votes in Presidenial elections.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 30 If Johnny doesn't like his "new math" course when school opens next month, he may in some cases be showing sound instinct rather than obstinate resistance to progress.

SUNNYVALE, Calif., Aug. 31 (UPI) Photographic proof that two clouds of cosmic rubble are orbiting the earth in the same path as the moon was announced today by J. Wesley Simpson, an engineer with the Lockheed Missiles and Space Company.
Davis Shuman, the trombonist, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital of a brain tumor. He has been ill for six months. He was 54 years old and lived at 741 Bradford Street, Brooklyn.

Medicare, which is for persons over 65 years of age, will provide an unexpected benefit for some persons under 65 a reduction of 5 to 30 per cent in the premiums they pay for health and hospital insurance.
MOSCOW, Aug. 31 (AP) The Soviet Lung 11 satellite contains "an entire orchestra of rocket engines," Pravda said today.
The superliner United States has completed her second fastest eastbound crossing of the Atlantic since she entered service 14 years ago and won the blue ribbon speed record on her maiden voyage.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 31 (AP) Gene Alley's two-out, basesloaded single drove in two runs and sparked a four-run uprising in the fifth inning tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4-3. The Dodger loss was their third straight.

New England's three largest utilities have decided to look into the possibilities of forming a giant power system serving most of the heavily populated regions of the six states. The new super-utility, as yet without a name, would rank in the top three in size of all utility networks in the country.

In the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon, Miss Martha Eleanor Bianco, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Anthony A. Bianco of New York, was married to Gerard Daniel Robilotti, son of Mrs. Joseph G. Robilotti of Flushing, Queens, and the late Dr. Robilotti.
The index of the Warren Report, officially known as "Report of the President's Commission on the Assassination of President John F. Kennedy," contains 60 references to the Soviet Union.

TEANECK, N.J., Aug. 31 Mrs. Pauline Birnbaum Levine, a former secretary and treasurer of the national board of the National Council of Jewish Women, died last night at her home here. She was 73 years old and the widow of Herman B. Levine, controller for J.C. Penney Co.

The growth of the "black power" concept may be attributed to the political ineffectiveness of the labor-liberal-Negro coalition, Bayard Rustin, the civil rights leader, argues in the September issue of Commentary magazine.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 31 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled today that schools in Wilcox, County, Ala., must be desegregated when clasases begin Sept. 12.

Robert V. Roosa, former Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, warned the Federal Reserve Board yesterday against using methods of "crude brutality" in its fight against inflation.

The $24.5-million Costa Line passenger vessel Eugenio C., the largest postwar liner to be built for a private Italian steamship line, sailed yesterday from Genoa on her maiden voyage to South America. Larger Italian-flag vessels have been constructed for governmentowned lines.
Mrs. Ruth McGowan of Brooklyn has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Grace Ruth McGowan, to Peter Linnekin French, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. French of Plainfield, N.J.
The nation's electric power production rose 7.3 per cent in the week ended Aug. 27, from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.
A growing number of persons and business concerns were reported yesterday unable to move into new apartments and office buildings because of a strike of 6,200 construction plumbers here.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) Robert Held of the Monmouth, N.J., Yacht Club clinched the title in the national junior sailing championships on Lake Michigan today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP)--A bill to tighten Government regulation of small business investment companies was approved today by a Senate banking subcommittee.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 31 (AP) Twenty-five Africans, turned away from a cafe in Stuttgart, Ark., yesterday, received an apology today from Gov. Orval E. Faubus.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 31 James Fleming, retired assistant controller of the United States Steel Corporation, died on Monday at Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 40 Woodland Road.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 (AP) Federal District Court Judge Thomas J. Clary heard legal arguments today on a motion for dismissal of a Justice Department suit opposing a merger of two Philadelphia banks.
Officials of The World Journal Tribune suddenly called a meeting last, night for 11 A.M. today with the leaders of the 10 newspaper unions.

Bill Mahoney, who comes from a family of seven and is the father of seven children, has written "My Wife and I," a musical extolling long-run matrimony. The show will be presented Oct. 10 at Theater Four, 424 West 55th Street, by Mr. Mahoney and Tom Ross Prather, who will also direct.
Blue-chip issues led the stock market upward yesterday as prices rallied for the second day in a row.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 31 A controversial bill before Congress, designed to curb political activity until three months before the next election campaign, has been placed under study by a 10-member, bipartisan congressienal committee.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (UPI) Pete Ward hit his first home run of the season and Gary Peters lowered his league-leading earned-run average to 1.88 tonight as the Chicago White Sox took a double-header from the Detroit Tigers, 7-6, and 3-1.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 31 (UPI) A Minneapolis concern said today that it had developed a salt for use on roads and streets in the winter that won't rust cars.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP)--The House Rules Committee approved a bill today aimed at the activities of some antiwar groups that have tried to block United States troop trains and ship blood and medical supplies to the Vietcong.

It is to early to assess the ultimate value of all the grants that have been made by the National Arts Endowment, but it is not a bit too soon to commend its chairman, Roger L. Stevens, and his advisers, the members of the National Arts Council, for their energy and breadth of vision. The endow

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) With plaudits for its past successes and best wishes for the future, the House passed and sent to the White House today legislation to keep the Peace Corps in business in 1967.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 31 (AP) Art Shamsky hit a pinch three-run homer in the eighth inning tonight and lifted the Cincinnati Reds to their eighth straight victory, a 7-5 decision over the Chicago Cubs.

Mayor Lindsay, pleased with the performance of the city's first Urban Corps this summer, announced yesterday that the program not only would be resumed and expanded next summer but would be continued through the coming academic year.

Banks and other savings institutions are ardently wooing savers in the current "money-scarce" market. But the institution offering the highest interest (or dividend) rate is not necessarily the one that pays the most on savings.
Bobby Richardson, the New York Yankees' second baseman, confirmed reports last night that he was retiring from baseball after this season.
LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 1 A Britannia airliner carrying 110 vacationing Britons and a crew of seven crashed as it approached Ljubljana Airport in northern Yugoslavia last night.

The Liberal party's nine-man screening committee was reported yesterday to be so divided on a candidate for Governor that it will make no recommendation to the party's 26-member policy committee tonight. The discussions were likely to extend into next week.
WASHINGTON Aug. 31 (AP) The Senate confirmed by voice vote today the nomination of Miles S. McKee of Grosse Point, Mich., as a member of the St. Lawrence Seaway Advisory Board.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Manufacturers' total inventories rose by $981-million in July, well above the average monthly gain of $656-million in the first half of the year, the Commerce Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) Congress passed and sent to President Johnson today legislation requiring Federal safety standards for new autos starting with 1968 models and for used cars within two years.
ARDMORE, Pa., Aug. 31--The caddie fee for a round in the United States Amateur Golf Championship remained at $10 today after an attempt to subsidize the cost was prohibited.
The taxicab industry called yesterday for a 5-cent-a-mile increase in rates.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 31--(AP)--Frank Robinson's two-run homer off Luis Tiant in the eighth inning gave the Baltimore Orioles a 5-1 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight. The Orioles four-game losing streak was thus snapped.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 31 Five Negroes registered today at a formerly all-white school at Woodlawn, south of New Orleans, signaling the first public school desegregation in Plaquemines Parish, the domain of Leander H. Perez Sr.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 31 (Reuters) Students clashed with policemen at the University of Rosario today. Thousands of undergraduates throughout the country continued strikes in protest against the new military regime's decision ending their traditional self-government.

BUDAPEST, Aug. 31 (Reuters) Poland brought off a spectacular double in the 100 meters events at the European track and field championships today, Wieslaw Maniak winning the men's race and Ewa Klobukowska the women's.
ALBANY, Aug. 31 (AP) The name of L. Judson Morhouse was stricken from the state's roll of lawyers today. Mr. Morhouse, the former Republican state chairman, has been convicted of bribery.
The Board of Education approved yesterday a $65-million program for aiding disadvantaged children in public and parochial schools, but a dispute over disposition of the funds continues.

LINWOOD, N.J., Aug. 31 (AP) Col. Edmund O. Howell, U.S.A., retired, who helped promote the political career of Woodrow Wilson and who served as a deputy commander of the military government of Italy late in World War II, died here yesterday, in a nursing home. He was 80 years old and lived at Swainton in Cape May County.

Twelve of the Fire Department's 13 electrical inspectors have been suspended for allegedly taking "payoffs" from companies that installed fire alarm and sprinkler systems in hospitals, nursing homes, factories and schools.

The spot rate on the British pound rose 11 points to $2.7894 in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The improvement seemed to have been largely the result of normal midweek considerations.
ARDMORE, Pa., Aug., 31 Even though he swung once at a ball and missed, Roger McManus, of Hartville, Ohio, led the opening round of the United States Amateur golf championship today with a 69.

ROWAYTON, Conn., Aug. 31 Mr. and Mrs. J. Douglas Smith have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Margaret Hoyt Smith, to Louis Peter Pataki Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Pataki of Peekskill, N.Y.

BONN, Aug. 31 Dr. Gerhard Starke, one of West Germany's leading radio commentators and executives, will return to the newspaper world tomorrow when he takes over as editor in chief of Die Welt, one of the Federal Republic's three newspapers with national circulation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP)--President Johnson approved today the retirement requests of two Federal judges.

TO the reviewer who has seen ice shows come and go through the years with the inevitability of the seasons, a strange thing happened last night as "Holiday on Ice of 1967" was making its 1966 debut at Madison Square Garden.

Mr. and Mrs. George W. Smith of Thetford Mines, Que., and Montreal have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Isabella Smith, to the Rev. Stephen David Matthews of St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Glen Ellyn, Ill.
Housewives can expect to pay half a cent a quart more for milk here as a result of an increase in the price, starting today, that distributors must pay to farmers.

MONROE, N.Y., Aug. 31 Mrs. Lili E. Peller, psychoanalyst, educator and lecturer, and the wife of Dr. Sigismund Peller, a consulting surgeon, died of a heart attack at her summer home here yesterday. She was 68 years old, and maintained her home and office at 164 East 81st Street in New York City.
ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug, 31 Dean Chance, gradually moving back toward the pitching excellence that made him rich and famous in 1964, defeated the New York Yankees for the California Angels tonight, 5-2.
In approving the bill to establish a new Department of Transportation, the House of Representatives has further enfeebled a weak measure.

An hourlong news report on whether something is really wrong with the American economy will be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System on Friday, Sept. 9, at 10 P.M. Areas to be covered will include the downturn in the stock market, the slowdown in building, and the higher prices of consumer products and services.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 31 (AP) The 1966-67 season of the Kansas City Philharmonic appeared in jeopardy today with neither the orchestra's sponsoring association nor its musicians budging in their deadlock over a new contract.
BONN, Aug. 31 A young Yugoslav shot and killed a Yugoslav consular official in Munich last night. The official, Sava Milovanovic, was shot eight times at close range.
The appointment of William G. Peoples as senior vice president in the executive department of the Southern Pacific Company was announced yesterday.
A decline of 1,242,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.
Two telephone holding companies engaged yesterday in an unusual transaction--they swapped operating companies.

The exigencies of mountainous demands for municipal services, complicated by years of borrow-now, pay-later financing, culminate today in the first bite out of local pay checks by the new city income tax. The initial bite will be especially sharp because sixmonths' taxes will be withheld during these last four months of 1966.

ATHENS, Aug. 31 Foreign intelligence sources here dis counted today a report that 30,000 expatriate Greek Communists had massed in southern Bulgaria with plans to force their repatriation by crossing the border.
URBANA, Ill., Aug. 31 (AP) The National Student Association called today for abolition of the present Selective Service System and opposed "in general any system of forced service to the Government."

MOSCOW, Aug. 31 The Soviet Communist party, in its strongest attack on the Chinese party leaders since the days of former Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev, accused the Peking regime today of undercutting the war effort in Vietnam against the United States.

County health departments have begun to charge fees for the first time for home care of the sick, traditionally given free by public health nurses.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) Congressional action was completed today on a bill designed to raise health and safety standards in mines other than coal mines.
The Mighty Mets came within an ace of defeating Juan Marichal before 50,502 persons last night in another Shea Stadium spectacular, 24 hours after they had dispatched the great Sandy Koufax.
Mayor Lindsay called on the Public Service Commission yesterday to hold public hearings on the Consolidated Edison Company's proposed increases in its charges for electricity and steam.
Stephen E. Smith, Senator Robert F. Kennedy's brother-inlaw and campaign manager, is expected to accept a high position in Frank D. O'Connor's campaign for Governor if he wins the nomination.
SAIGON, Sept. 1 (AP) A Vietnamese woman selling bread on a busy Saigon street was killed today when an American soldier took a shot at a taxi driver.

CHATTANOOGA, Aug. 31 (UPI) Walter Christopher Johnson Sr., retired secretarygeneral of the Southern Newspaper Publishers Association and the former general manager of The Chattanooga News, died today. He was 88 years old.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 31 The Alabama Senate approved tonight Gov. George C. Wallace's plan to prohibit the state's public schools from desegregating voluntarily under agreements with the Fedeal Government.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31--Nurses at three city hospitals here were back at work today after a one-day "sick leave" walkout, the nation's first mass "strike" of hospital nurses.
The P. Lorillard Company is moving swiftly to capitalize on the recent study that found its new True cigarettes the most effective of nine filter brands tested for screening out tars and nicotine.

BROKERS weren't willing to talk about the situation when the market was sliding, but yesterday with a strong recovery under way some admitted that margin calls were becoming worrisome after Monday's retreat.

HONG KONG, Thursday, Sept. 1 Defense Minister Lin Piao warned youthful Red Guards at a huge rally yesterday that they must carry out their campaign against "bourgeois" influences "by reasoning and not by coercion or force."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) Provisions for special treatment of 52 urban renewal programs in 50 cities were knocked out of a pending housing bill today by the House Banking Committee.

The fight for control of the Michigan Gas and Electric Company ended in an amicable settlement yesterday. But questions raised by the Securities and Exchange Commission about the legality of the fracas remained as alive as ever.

Manuel Santana of Spain, the Wimbledon and United States champion, will begin the defense of his American title today in the 85th tournament of the United States Lawn Tennis Association at Forest Hills, Queens.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) A Negro editor chargd today that most history textbooks ignored the contributions of his race to American society.

With Senate passage of the revised Food for Peace bill, both houses of Congress now have approved a radically new concept for American aid in feeding a hungry world.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 31 (Reuters) The Nigerian military Government today Published a decree formally restor ing the country's federal system, of government.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) Controller of the Currency James J. Saxon, long at odds with the Justice Department over bank-merger policy, now has, differed with the Federal Reserve Board over still another phase of bank regulation.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Aug. 31 Roy Franklin Penman, who retired in 1962 as a consulting general engineer of Ebasco Services, Inc., died of a heart attack today in his home at the Garth Wood Apartments here His age was 69.

Frank S. Grey, a detective in the New York City Police Department for more than 30 years until his retirement 13 years ago, died Tuesday night at Kings Highway Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 75 years old and lived at 2110 Newkirk Avenue, Brooklyn.
The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), with 142 ships flying the flags of 16 nations, is the largest operator of tankers in the world, according to a study published yesterday by the Sun Oil Company.
A flood of calls yesterday inundated the city Finance Department and its special telephone number for inquiries566-8844 on the eve of today's start for withholding city taxes from pay checks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) The White House' said today President Johnson, who has been making weekend speaking tours recently, hoped to visit West Virginia and Pennsylvania on Saturday. Bill D. Moyers, Presidential press secretary,
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 31 Civil rights demonstrators surprised city officials twice today.
ONE of the most vexatious of things that can happen to a pair of defenders at the bridge table is to have the declarer make the winning play for the wrong reason.
OSSINING, N.Y., Aug. 31 The election of the fifth superior general of the Catholic Foreign Mission Society, popularly known as Maryknoll, was announced today.

John C. Paige Co., insurance broker, announced here yesterday the election of Thomas A. Sperry Jr. as president. He joined the company in 1951 and has served most recently as vice president and a director. As president, Mr. Sperry succeeds Waldo M. Hatch, who becomes chairman and chief executive officer.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Senate and House conferees agreed today on the major features of a minimum wage bill that Administration sources described as, "highly satisfactory."

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 31 Mrs. Harriette Draper Mark, a former consultant for the State Education Department on school lunch programs, died today at United Hospital here. She was 66 years old and lived at 66 Milton Road in Rye. She was the widow of Richard E. Mark, a New York
WHO runs the television set, the husband or the wife? A possible answer may come on Sept. 10, when most households will have to decide whether they prefer Miss America or Paul Hornung.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 31 John A.S. Dunn, for nearly 50 years the secretary and treasurer of the New York Coffee and Sugar Clearing Association, died yesterday in Hempstead General Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived here with his daughter, Mrs. Edward L. Kane.

Two mental health officials called yesterday for the overhaul of psychiatric services in the city's hospitals, suggested far-reaching programs, and warned that the promised infusion of more money was not enough.
The London Stock Exchange turned firmer yesterday following Tuesday's recovery on Wall Street. However, trading was light.

VERSHIRE, Vt., Aug. 30 The dwellings are tiny and squalid. The roofs are made of corrugated metal that intensifies the heat of the midday sun The floors are dirt and sawdust. Wads of burlap plug cracks in the walls.

MOSCOW, Aug. 31 The Soviet Government has ordered the United States Embassy to halt the distribution of a Russian- language edition of the Warren Commission Report, saying it slandered the Soviet people.

Wieland Wagner will not come to New York to stage the Metropolitan Opera's new production of his grandfather's opera, "Lohengrin," as previously announced. The 49-year-old director of the Bayreuth Festival was to have made his United States debut Dec. 8, but illness has forced him to cancel his trip.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Richard M. Nixon told the 48th annual American Legion Convention today that "those who predict the Vietnam war will end in a year or two are smoking opium or taking LSD."

Miss Elaine E. Graifer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Graifer of Saddle Brook, N.J., was married yesterday evening to Louis O. Schwartz, son of Mrs. Samuel Schwartz of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Schwartz.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 31 John Cartwright, Navy's quarterback, became a celebrity of sorts after the listless ArmyNavy football game last fall when he complained that he had not been permitted to call the plays during the 7-7 affair in Philadelphia. After all, is even a Navy quarterback permitted to complain about his coach, or any superior?

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Aug. 31 The annual fair of St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church, to be held on Sept. 10, will have the atmosphere of a gypsy camp, complete with a fortune teller, an herb shop, bright decorations, violin music the day long and a gypsy cast at the entrance to the church grounds.

Serious attention has been drawn in the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist party to the communique, published in the Chinese press, of the 11th plenary meeting of the Central Committee of the Communist party of China, whose work was under the leadership of Comrade Mao Tse-tung.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 South Vietnam's National Liberation Front expressed a defiant and extremely tough line toward negotiations of any kind in a statement prepared for an American television showing tonight.
Poverty and politics were commingled yesterday as a Little City Hall formally opened after a three-week trial run in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 31 Kerry Way, a filly handicapped this season by an infected ankle, an impacted tooth and a swollen knee, beat 11 other 3-year-old trotters in straight heats in the 41st annual Hambletonian Stake at the Du Quoin State Fair Grounds today.
Gimbel Brothers, Inc., the department store chain, announced yesterday that it increased its sales and earnings in the second fiscal quarter and first six months ended July 31.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Aug, 31 (AP) The National (Association for the Advancement of Colored People proposed today that Florida adopt its own civil rights law and threatened to campaign against legislative candidates who would not support it.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 31 President de Gaulle discussed prospects of peace in Vietnam today with Nguyen Thuong, chief of North Vietnam's diplomatic mission in Cambodia.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The nation's gold loss was $116million in July, the largest so far this year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Four harness racing officials testified yesterday before a Brooklyn grand jury investigating a possible scandal involving drugged horses and fixed races at the Roosevelt, Yonkers and Monticello tracks. They were the first witnesses to be called.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 31 William S. Cox of the Norton Yacht Club beat the only opponent who really mattered, John J. (Don) McNamara. Jr. of the Boston Yacht Club, twice today. What he did made him the leader for the men's North American sailing championship, for which the Mallory Cup is the symbol.

William F. Buckley Jr., editor of the conservative fortnightly magazine National Review, said yesterday that a foundation of which he is an official is in the process of authorizing a $2,000 grant to study the adequacy of the Warren Commission's report on the assassination of President Kennedy.

The labor dispute between New York dancers and their management tiptoed uneasily to the brink yesterday. The argument, which is about money, or how much money, has been intensifying, but apparently not clarifying ever since Monday.

THE tallest dog in the world is the Irish wolfhound. Three feet tall, he averages 160 pounds. There are only 1,000 in the world, with half that number in America. The leading kennel in the metropolitan area is owned by Mr. and Mrs. Gordon F. Graham of St. James,
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Walter W. Heller predicted today a continued, exuberant boom in the economy too much boom in his view for the rest of 1966 and the first half of 1967.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31 The Chrysler Corporation unveiled today its 1967 Dodge automobiles, promising a range of 53 models in dealer showrooms in September.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 (AP) Rich Allen smashed a two-run, first-inning homer and followed with a single and two doubles to help the Philadelphia Phillies rout the Houston Astros, 10-5, tonight.
LONDON, Aug. 31 "Beatrix," given its world premiere by London's Festival Ballet at the Royal Festival Hall tonight, is the second evening-long new production by this company in

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 A Swedish scholar who spent all of May in Communist China reported today that "incredible" steps had been taken by Mao Tse-tung's Government in excavating and preserving Chinese antiquities.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 People fond of staring at the West Wall and mumbling "Whither America?" were given food for brooding by The Wall Street Journal the other day. In a story headlined "Whiz Kids:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) The House passed a bill today authorizing $19.7-billion in Federal highway grants to the states over the next five years.
BELVEDERE, Calif., Aug. 31 (AP) Martha McDougle of Rochester, and her crew of two, finished seventh among eight boats today in the final race of the North American women's sailing championship.
BONN, Aug. 31 The East German Government has protested to China against alleged maltreatment of its diplomats and their families in Peking.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 31 John David Allen, a partner in the Allen Shipping Company, a steamship freight brokerage concern in New York, died today at Norwalk Hospital. He was 44 years old and lived at 100 Maywood Road.
UPSTATE duck hunters will have a straight 55-day season this year under regulations selected by the Conservation Department. It will run from Oct. 15 to Dec. 8.

In isolation, the Kremlin's ban on distribution of Russian translations of the Warren Commission report on President Kennedy's assassination would be a regrettable, but relatively minor, matter. After all, when Soviet citizens are denied full access to the documents of their own history, it is too much to expect that they will get unlimited access to documents of American history.

The Metropolitan Rigid Paper Box Association, Inc., announced yesterday that it had reached a new labor agreement with the Paper Box Makers Union, Local 299. The agreement provides $10 in weekly wage increases over a three-year period.

The fact that Summer Scandal was racing against a mare that had been purchased recently for $117,000 didn't scare the keen students away from the formful contestant in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday.

IF a somewhat visionary look has begun to creep into the eyes of Roy Emerson of Australia, it's because he is looking beyond the United States lawn tennis championships that will begin today at Forest Hills. He is seeing escape from the merrygo-round he has been riding with considerable distinction and skill for many years.
KINSHASA, the Congo, Aug. 31--Pie Massambuko, Foreign Minister of Burundi, announced here yesterday that the kingdom would resume diplomatic relations with Communist China.

IT was young choreographers' night at the Dela corte Theater in Central Park last night, where the Harkness Foundation Dance Festival presented works by Gus Solomons Jr. and Judith Willis. Both works were of marked originality, skirting, albeit narrowly, the charge of too much overt cuteness.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 108.7 on Tuesday from 109.1 on Monday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 The Humble Oil and Refining Company officially called off its Monterey Bay fight with conservation groups today and announced the imminent construction of a $100-million refinery on San Francisco Bay.

In a recent poll of American Protestant clerygymen, 72.9 per scent of those responding opposed Communist China's admittance to the United Nations and 93.7 per cent opposed the expulsion of Nationalist China from the world body to accom
