SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 The A.F.L.-C.I.O. claimed victory today over the Teamsters Union in one of the most significant collective bargaining elections in California's agricultural history.

LONDON, Aug. 31 President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia decided to stay away from the Commonwealth Prime Ministers' conference in London next week even though Britain had doubled her offer of economic aid from 7-million ($19.6-million) to 14-million ($39.2-million). President Kaunda wanted 70-million ($196million).

A Federal Maritime Commission investigation into the reasonableness of higher charges for pier truck loading and unloading was told yesterday that such costs were driving some exporters from the port of New York.
Bond underwriters and dealers were heartened yesterday by sharp gains in all three markets Government, corporate and by the reception accorded to the week's largest new offering.

WITH Jim Brown in retirement, the big back in pro football this season may be a somewhat forgotten competitor named Jimmy Taylor who toils for Green Bay. Taylor, 30 years old and about to embark on his ninth National League season, is bursting with health and
BENTON HARBOR, Mich., Aug. 31 (AP) A Negro youth died from a gunshot wound and Michigan National Guard troops were mobilized today as Benton Harbor braced for renewed racial violence.

The Westec Corporation be cause of the uncertainties gen erated by the still largely un explained activities in the com pany's stock has decided, at least for the moment, not to go through with the 10 or so acquisitions it has pending. The Houston concern, which is in mining, real estate and aerospace, among other businesses, has grown largely by acquisition.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The United States Information Agency film, "John F. Kennedy Years of Lightning, Day of Drums," will not be shown in Milwaukee to raise campaign funds for a Democratic candidate for Congress.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 President Johnson has made an almost final decision to include a temporary repeal of the special tax credit on business investment if he seeks any hind of tax increase this year.

VENICE, Italy, Aug. 31 Diplomatic tension flared up at the Venice Cinema Festival today when the French delegates refused to attend this evening's performance of the Italian film "The Battle of Algeria."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) Gen. Bernard A. Schriever, commander of the Air Force Systems Command and a key figure in the emergence of America's missile might, retired today after 33 years in the Air Force.
PHILADELPHIA. Aug. 31 Walter Biddle Saul, a lawyer and former president of the Philadelphia Board of Education, died last night. He was 85 years old.

The boardroom watchers looked moderately cheerful yesterday despite the recent severe declines in the stock market. Their attitude could hardly be pinned to the tale of yesterday's rally because many thought the bear market would continue. It was a matter of amiable stoicism.
The directors of the Times Mirror Company approved in Los Angeles yesterday a 2-for-1 stock split of the common shares, to be followed by an increased quarterly dividend on the new stock.

ATHENS, Aug. 31 The North Atlantic Treaty Organization today began air-lifting a fivenation mobile force and seven million pounds of material to northern Greece in a display of allied solidarity and strength in an exercise that envisions Greece as facing invasion threats from the north.
THE macabre tales Gerhard Zwerenz tells in "Remembrance Day" are as murkily wild as underground movies, gas stylish ly brutal as the theater of the absurd.
SWEDEN, Me., Aug. 31 (AP) The state police say they have found and impounded almost all of more than 30 stolen bushels of apples coated with a poisonous spray.
A 72-year-old man accused of hundreds of housing violations in five Harlem tenements was sent to jail for 10 days yesterday.

Negotiations for the sale of the 18-story Holiday Inn at 57th Street and Ninth Avenue are now under way. The prospective purchaser is a union group that would like to turn the motel into a housing project for retired workers.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 31 The United States has suspended its program of assistance to the University of Hue, which was a major command post for the Buddhist-led dissidence that swept Central Vietnam earlier this year.

WASHINGTON; Aug. 31 The powerful Senate Democratic Policy Committee proposed today that the United States substantially reduce its forces in Europe. The White House replied promptly that it did not favor such a move.

Teddy Roy, a pianist with jazz groups and dance bands since the late nineteen-twenties, died of cancer yesterday in the Veterans Administration Hospital at First Avenue and 24th Street. He was 61 years old.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 31 More than 2,000 persons were arrested as political agitators in Panjim, the capital of Goa, today as they demonstrated against the local Government headed by Dayanand Bandodkar.

Miss Jean Alice Augustine, daughter of Mrs. John Augustine of Elmhurst, Queens, and the late Mr. Augustine, was married yesterday to Dr. Bernard J. Ficarra of Mill Neck, L.I., son of Mr. and Mrs. O. Ficarra of New York.

UPPER BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 31 Mr, and Mrs. Jerald H. Melum have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sheila Merrill Melum, to David Earle Whitney of Springfield, Vt., son of Mr. and Mrs. Earle E. Whitney.
ATLANTA, Aug. 31 A privately financed program intended to stimulate the organization of poor people in rural areas of the South was announced today by the Citizens Crusade Against Poverty.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 31 The Mekong River continued today to encroach into this city of 88,000 people despite efforts by laborers and troops to build a sandbag-and-earth dam.
SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 31 (AP) An early morning accident near here today killed two New York City youths and critically injured a third.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) The Small Business Administration announced today it would raise its ceilings on direct loans to $100,000 and on participation loans to $50,000, effective tomorrow.
PNOMPENH, Thursday, Sept. 1 President de Gaulle said today that the United States must agree to withdraw its forces from Vietnam before a negotiated settlement of the war is possible.
The American Stock Exchange turned in its best performance yesterday in more than three months as most of the list made strong gains in active trading.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Representative Adam Clayton Powell accused the Johnson Administration today of flouting the law by failing to coordinate antipoverty programs.

BEST CO., which has long paid special attention to little girls, has renewed its concern for their older sisters. In recognition,of the snappy, young career girl who has emerged from yesterday's nursery set, the store has redone its seventh floor in a light, airy manner and renamed it "Cosmo 7."

Harold Wilson faces a critical public test of his economic austerity program when he addresses Britain's Trades Union Congress at Blackpool next week. Some commentators believe this could be the Wilson administration's "most fateful day."

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 31 Wilfred Burchett, a leftist Australian journalist who returned Monday from Vietcong areas in Vietnam, says that insurgent leaders expect that the war will go on for years. Mr. Burchett interviewed Nguyen Huu Tho, chairman of the National Liberation Front.

WASHINGTON, August 31 The Russian-language edition of the Warren Report is identical to the full-length, 816-page, version printed by the Government Printing Office, according to a spokesman for the United States Information Agency.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 31 United States servicemen and Government employes in cities of South Vietnam will be confined to their quarters for 34 hours during the weekend in which the South Vietnamese vote to elect a constitution-drafting assembly.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 The first and secondseeded players, Bob Sherman of Tem ple City, Calif., and Bob Galloway of La Jolla, Calif., reached the final round of the Middle States senior grass court tennis championship today at the Germantown Cricket Club.
NAZARETH, Israel, Aug. 25 A group of American teenagers presented an Israeli community with an unusual gift this summer, a children's park and playground.

PARIS, Aug. 31 (Reuters) The United States Government has forbidden the sale of three French civilian jet planes with American engines to the South African Government, usually reliable sources said here today.
The admission of a number of new partners was announced here yesterday by White, Weld Co., and Dreyfus Co., member firms of the New York Stock Exchange.
"Holy Jupiter," cried 4-year-old Billy (Robin) Walters, his Batman shirt heaving, as he espied the foot-and-a-half long monitor lizard clinging from the sixth floor of the building in which he lives.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Senator J.W. Fulbright, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, announced today that he would hold hearings on Thailand. He said he feared the Administration might be heading into a war there.

PARIS, Aug. 31 (Reuters) The United States Government has forbidden the sale of three French civilian jet planes with American engines to the South African Government, usually reliable sources said here today.
The admission of a number of new partners was announced here yesterday by White, Weld Co., and Dreyfus Co., member firms of the New York Stock Exchange.
"Holy Jupiter," cried 4-year-old Billy (Robin) Walters, his Batman shirt heaving, as he espied the foot-and-a-half long monitor lizard clinging from the sixth floor of the building in which he lives.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Senator J.W. Fulbright, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, announced today that he would hold hearings on Thailand. He said he feared the Administration might be heading into a war there.

MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 31 Half the population of Alabama is waiting to learn whether Joe Namath, one of this state's folk heroes, will play for the New York Jets tomorrow night in their exhibition football game against the Boston Patriots. He probably won't.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The man who represents most of Harlem in Congress defended it today as "a sort of Mecca, a symbol to the black people all over the country."
Upper Madison Avenue was stretching and yawning this week. Next week it will wake up from its usual summer sleep.

The Marschalk Company, Inc., has come up with what must surely be the biggest thing in house-organ publications. It's somewhat smaller than a desk top, but twice the size of the "In" tray (and "Out" tray, too, for that matter).
Bottles and rocks were thrown last night on firemen and two police patrol cars in Brooklyn's Wililamsburg section after two men were arrested for interferring with firefighters.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 1 The Vietcong today continued their wave of terror, apparently aimed at discouraging participation in the Sept. 11 elections for a constituent assembly.
Queens District Attorney Nat H. Hentel led a 10-man squad of detectives and Hack Bureau inspectors last night in a crackdown on gypsy cab operators at Kennedy International Airport.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 1--The Government has come to terms with the fierce hill tribesmen who staged a brief but bloody rebellion against its authority last December, Vietnamese officials said today.
The cumulative impact of months of mounting monetary restraint may finally be starting to slow the expansion of business borrowing.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 1 Officials of the N.A.A.C.P. announced today that demonstrations against public officials belonging to segregated private clubs would be expanded to cities in seven Midwestern states.
MADISON, Wis., Aug. 31 Early experience with a Federal experiment in legal aid Shows that poor people want divorces far more than protection from loansharks and landlords.

Mrs. Mary Ryan King, who retired in 1962 as principal of Public School 401 after 50 years of service with the Board of Education, died on Aug. 22 at the home of her sister, Mrs. Marguerite Cavallo, in Catania, Sicily. She was 74 years old and had lived at West Shore Road, Roslyn, L.I.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) A bill aimed at simplifying the method by which states tax small businesses in interstate commerce was approved today by the House Judiciary Committee.

DETROIT, Sept. 1 Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, has suggested that the car manufacturers may use new safety features to justify an "unwarranted" price increase this fall
CLEVELAND, Sept. 1 (AP) Duke Sims's two-run homer and a home run by Max Alvis aided Sonny Siebert's five-hit pitching tonight as the Cleveland Indians beat the Baltimore Orioles, 4-1.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 1 A troupe from the University of Southern California has stolen the limelight from most of the official attractions at this year's Edinburgh Festival.
MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 1 The New York Jets, scoring three touchdowns on Mike Taliaferro's passes and two on fumble recoveries, routed the Boston Patriots tonight, 41-3.

DETROIT, Sept. 1, (AP) Lou Michaels kicked a pair of field goals in the second quarter and Johnny Unitas tossed a two-yard scoring pass to John Mackey in the third to lead the Baltimore Colts to a 20-0 victory over the Detroit Lions tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept.1 (AP) Stronger Federal supervision and controls over the Small Business Investment Corporations was recommended to the Senate today by its Banking Committee.

The American Jewish Committee yesterday accused 50 of the largest commercial banks in the United States, including nine in New York City, of virtually excluding Jews from executive positions because of prejudice.
ATHENS, Sept. 1 An earthquake struck southern Greece today, injuring at least 19 persons and seriously damaging hundreds of houses.
"Hello, Ma...yeah, yeah, it's me...sure I'm still here... this is something new though."
FIRE ISLAND, L.I., Sept. 1 Residents concerned over exceptionally high tides today at this barrier beach urged emergency action to safeguard waterfront properties here and on the mainland.
The development of a diabetic strain of mice, reported in the journal Science, may open exciting new avenues of research in diabetes.
Ignazio Currenti, confined in a hospital for the criminal insane for 26 years, walked free yesterday and began a search for his wife and son.

PASSAIC TOWNSHIP, N.J., Sept. 1 (AP) The owner of the cannon in the cornfield was told to cease fire today when the township sheriff served him with an injunction barring further use of the booming scarecrow.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Sept. 1--William S. Cox of Darien, Conn., a member of the Noroton Yacht Club, sailed a final race that was free of trouble except at the beginning today to become a North American champion for the second time in 36 years.

The Liberal party's policy committee instructed the screening committee last night to confer with Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. as a possible candidate for governor, and to report back next Tuesday night.

"We see plenty of short selling. I can't emphasize that too strongly. We might see a little hesitation in the stock market here. After that it could work higher. We see a great deal of short selling in Xerox. SCM looks higher and we would buy it on dips below 60. It looks as if a bottom has been made in Jersey."
GUATEMALA CITY, Sept. 1 The rebel guerrilla organization released last night two former officials who were kidnapped four months ago.

VENICE, Italy, Sept. 1 "Chappaqua," the last of the three new American films that have come to the Venice Film Festival, was shown tonight and turned out to be a harrowing record of the experiences and hallucinations of a narcotics-addicted poet from upstate New York who enters a Paris clinic in search of a cure.

WASHINGTON, Sept, 1 (AP) President Johnson ordered introduction today of emergency legislation to block a California timberman from cutting his own trees because they are inside the boundaries of a proposed Redwood National Park.
A Republican candidate for Congress who had decided to refuse the Conservative party's endorsement was told yesterday by the Appellate Division that he must accept the endorsement.
The House Ways and Means Committee is considering a drastic revision of the law under which the state Medicaid program was set up. The revision would reduce greatly the scope of the program.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 1 U Thant refused today to offer himself for a second term as Secretary General of the United Nations.
The Ford Motor Company reported yesterday that its daily selling rate for passenger cars in the last 10 clays of August rose by 14 per cent over a year ago to 6,874 cars a day from 6,019 last year.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 1 Representatives of veterans' organizations last night began a campaign to preserve the birthplace here of George M. Cohan, composer of "Over There."
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and major stockholders of listed companies.

Jack Molinas, a former basketball star serving a prison sentence on bribery charges in the fixing of college basketball games, has been quietly transferred from Attica State Prison to the Tombs for special questioning by authorities in Brooklyn.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 1 Strawberry Ridge, driven by Dick Welch, scored a tremendous upset in the New York Sire Stakes, a $48,828 3-year-old pace, at the state fair grounds today. This was the richest purse ever offered for New York State-bred harness horses.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1--The Senate began to divide sharply today over the proposal made yesterday by the Senate Democratic Policy Committee for a "substantial reduction" of United States forces in Europe.

SALEM, N.H., Sept 1 At 11:30 A.M. today, a member of the New Hampshire Sweepstakes Commission glanced at the name on a piece of paper that had just been plucked from a small plexi-glass drum at Rockingham Park.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 a Senate judiciary subcommittee approved today a broad civil rights bill that included a partial ban against discrimination in the sale or rental of housing. The bill is similar in most respects to a measure passed by the House on Aug. 9.

MILLBURN, N.J., Sept. 1--Miss Iris Eve Chuven, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Merrill Chuven of Linden, was married tonight at the Chanticler to Alan David Freeman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius E. Freeman of Bayside, Queens, N.Y.
ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 1 Fritz Peterson, with assistance from Dooley Womack, registered the 11th victory of his rookie season with the New York Yankees tonight by beating the California Angeles, 5-2.
The North German Lloyd liner Berlin, the doyenne of the North Atlantic and widely remembered as a World War II mercy ship, arrived here yesterday morning on her final westbound Atlantic crossing.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 1 (AP) Ron Fairly's two-run single in the 10th inning capped a threerun Los Angeles rally tonight as the Dodgers beat Pittsburgh, 4-3.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 Bob Sherman of Temple City, Calif., won the Middle States senior grass-court tennis championship for the second successive year by scoring a straightset victory in today's final at the Germantown Cricket Club.
The newly formed Oakland (Calif.) National Repertory Theater will swing into action Sept. 12 with Mildred Dunnock and John Saxon in "The Glass Menagerie."

Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes signed a contract yesterday that he said would bring a step closer the day when motorists would be able to cross mid-Manhattan in 10 minutes instead of 30 minutes.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 1 The Rhodesian security police took a university lecturer into custody today under the country's emergency regulations and held him for questioning.

LAKESIDE, Conn., Sept. 1 Sixy-five Columbia football players reported today to Coach Aldo T. (Buff) Donelli for the start of two weeks of preseason workouts at Camp Columbia. With six more players due to arrive later this week, the Lions' squad will be the largest in six seasons.
Amos Ben-Gurion bears a famous name, an engaging smile and a strong desire to sell more Israeli-made products in the United States.
Miss Carol Goodz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Goodz of Ste. Sophie, Que., was married yesterday morning to Lewis R. Kaster, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin C. Kaster of 30 East 65th Street.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 1 Benjamin Shanefield, a lawyer for 45 years, died last night at Shea Stadium, New York, of a heart attack while attending a baseball game between the New York Mets and the San Francisco Giants. He was 70 years old and lived at 110 Rynda Road here.

A group of South Bronx storekeepers appealed to Governor Rockefeller yesterday for state policemen or national guardsmen to protect them from a wave of robberies, burglaries and crimes of violence. They threatened to form "vigilante squads with rifles and shotguns" if the Governor failed to act immediately.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) Tighter restrictions on travel by United States citizens to Communist countries were voted today by the House Judiciary Committee.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 1 (AP) Don Kesisnger had four hits and Billy Williams drove in four runs to give the Chicago Cubs an 11-3 victory over Cincinnati tonight. The Cub victory ended the Reds' winning streak at eight games.

HONG KONG, Friday, Sept. 2 Peking's leaders greeted North Vietnam's national day today with a message of support that maintained the cautious approach of the Communist Chinese hierarchy to the question of intervention in the Vietnam war.

New York City's special 12day voter registration program, aimed primarily at enlisting new voters in minority areas, will end tomorrow, with the final tallies falling far short of similar efforts during the last two years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) Dr. Robert Henry Randall, who was a leader in the fields of cartography, surveying and geography, died of a heart attack yesterday while visiting at Lake Arrowhead, Calif., members of his family announced today. He was 75 years old.

BUDAPEST, Sept. 1 (Reuters) Bodo Tuemmler of West Germany powered his way to a surprise victory in the 1,500meter run today at the European track and field champion ships. The victory was the first for his country.
Mayor Lindsay greeted Jane Morgan, the singer, and Lionel Hampton, the vibraharpist, at City Hall yesterday during a ceremony he called a "sort of opening of the entertainment season in New York."
Some Manhattan deliveries by the United Parcel Service were halted for the second day yesterday by what the company called an illegal work stoppage by 250 drivers.
JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 1 The Justice Department charged the Marion County Hospital at Columbia, Miss., today with violation of the 1964 Civil Rights Act in the first suit to desegregate a hospital.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 (AP) Rich Allen's triple against the right-field wall and a single by Bill White scored two runs in the sixth inning tonight as the Philadelphia Phillies beat the Houston Astros, 3-1.

Word that President Johnson is close to asking Congress for a temporary suspension of the 7 per cent tax credit on business investment drew some adverse reaction from the business community yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 Secretary of State Dean Rusk recently spoke to the Veterans of Foreign Wars. On the same day he conferred with U Thant, the Secretary General of the United Nations. Senator J.W. Fulbright of Arkansas, a dedicated Rusk-watcher, then rose in the Senate to discuss. The New York Times's account of Mr. Rusk's statements.

Royall Smith of 44 Christie Hill Road in Darien, Conn., vice president and associate creative director of Lennen Newell, Inc., the advertising agency, died Wednesday in the Memorial Hospital. He was 49 years old.
Wall Street sources consider it likely that the Securities and Exchange Commission will extend its 10-day trading ban on the Westec Corporation beyond the initial deadline of Sept. 7.

MALVERNE, L.I., Sept. 1 (AP) The Malverne Board of Education has turned down an offer of $51,200 from the State Department of Education to aid the school district in implementing an order to end racial imbalance.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 This city has embarked with spirit on a campaign to decorate its cultural scene with the American Consevatory Theater to replace the defunct Actor's Workshop.
The shipping industry has won an increase in fees for operating vessels for Government account after months of complaining that it was being underpaid.

Stanley Kauffmann, who has been drama critic of The New York Times, has been named associate literary editor of The New Republic. He will also review plays on the Channel 13 program. "The Wednesday Review" and serve as host on the station's show "The Art of Film."
The Xerox Corporation announced yesterday in Rochester the election of Albert H. Swett as vice president and associate general counsel.

A treasury of raw material of history will be made available to the public with the issuing this week of "The New York Times Index: A Book of Record 1863-1874." The Times and R.R. Bowker Company have combined on publication.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson will take President and Mrs. Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines to the opera in New York Sept. 16, the White House said today.
FREEHOLD, N.J., Sept. 1 (UPI) Frank Tagariello drove to consecutive wire-to-wire victories to highlight today's harness racing program at Freehold Raceway.
Complaints about youthful crowds that have been swarming around a First Avenue corner brought the owners of a sidewalk cafe called T.G.I. Friday's to a Licenses Department hearing yesterday.
OTTAWA, Sept. 1 Parliament adopted tonight a bill ordering an end to the seven-dayold general railway strike.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 1 Louis E.G. Langheinz, a pharmacist with the Elizabeth General Hospital who drew a series of cartoons on the life of Booker T. Washington in 1960, died of a heart attack yesterday at the Community Hospital in Toms River. He was 63 years old and lived at 433 Marshall Street.
Marshall Field Co., the Chicago department store organization, announced yesterday an increase in sales and earnings in the three and six months ended July 31.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) President Johnson signed today a bill to allow veterans of the Vietnam war to become members of the American Legion.
The meteorologist in charge of the Weather Bureau here closed the books yesterday on the summer with this finding: It was the hottest on record.

With all my heart, I thank His Royal Highness Prince Norodom Sihanouk for extending to us such a magnificent welcome in his noble capital. At the same time, I thank the Khmer people for according me this extraordinary testimony of their generous confidence, and also of the close friendship that unites our two countries.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 Directors of the Curtis Publishing Company acted today to continue interest payments on an outstanding debt and elected three new vice presidents.

George F. Everson, secretary and a director of Charles Scribner's Sons, and manager of the publisher's production department, died Wednesday of a heart attack at his home, 133 Woodlawn Avenue, Upper Montclair, N.J. He was 57 years old.
DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 1 The fatal shooting of a Negro man touched off rioting in a Negro area of Dayton today, but the authorities pronounced the situation under control tonight.
CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (AP) Tenth-inning homers tonight by Norm Cash and Willie Horton gave Detroit a 7-5 victory over Chicago.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 1 United States military policemen arrested an American soldier in connection with the fatal shooting of a 33-year-old South Vietnamese woman on a crowded street in downtown Saigon this morning. No specific charges were made immediately.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1--The Federal Reserve System moved today to reinforce the anti-inflation effects of its "tight money" policy by cautioning banks to slow the expansion of their loans to business.

TORONTO, Sept. 1 The Quebec government is expected to announce soon it is ready to proceed with the long-delayed Churchill Falls hydroelectric development in the Labrador wilderness, about 740 miles northeast of Montreal.

It is the view of the Federal Reserve System that orderly bank credit expansion is appropriate in today's economy. However, that expansion should be moderate enough to help insure that spending and particularly that financed by bank credit does not exceed the bounds that can be accommodated by the nation's growing physical resources. An excessive expansion of bank credits would aggravate inflationary pressures that are already visible.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 1--"Fiddler on the Roof," performed in Hebrew, ended a record-breaking run here last night.

Fleet owners have broken the news, at a hearing of Mayor Lindsay's Taxi Study Panel, that they want a nickel-a-mile fare increase. They cite unionization, inflation and the high cost of medallions the license required to operate a cab as justification for a higher fare.

Manuel Santana of Spain, Arthur Ashe of Richmond, Tony Roche of Australia and Cliff Drysdale of South Africa paraded across the stadium and grandstand turf at Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday, but the player who put on the show of the opening day of the United States Tennis Championship was the one who won the title there 12 years ago.
PARIS, Sept. 1 Observers here were not sure what President de Gaulle had in mind in speaking of an "international arrangement" for Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) The House Banking Committee approved today a somewhat trimmed version of President Johnson's Demonstration Cities Program, essentially in the form that the Senate had passed it.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (UPI) Robert Held, 17 years old, representing the Monmouth Boat Club of Red Bank, N.J., received the Sears Cup today in the North American junior sailing championship at Belmont Harbor.
The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday the election of two new directors and the resignation of four board members because of age.
Tommy Burns, who did not win the $11,325 Harbor Hill steeplechase handicap at Aqueduct yesterday, turned to the jockey who did and exclaimed, "Your horse jumped like a mountain goat, didn't he?"
SARASOTA, Fla., Sept. 1 (AP) The defense in the Carl Coppolino murder case challenged the prosecution today to state how the 34-year-old doctor is alleged to have murdered his wife.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 1 President de Gaulle said today that if the United States decided to withdraw its forces from Vietnam in favor of an "international arrangement" for peace and progress, it "will not, in the final analysis, involve anything that could injure its pride, interfere with its ideals and jeopardize its interests."
Directors of the United States Plywood Corporation and Champion Papers, Inc., agreed yesterday on a new plan to merge the two forest products producers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 Miss Margaret McNamara, daughter of Robert S. McNamara, the Secretary of Defense, and Mrs. McNamara, was married to Barry Edward Carter at the Washington National Cathedral this afternoon.
CHESTER, Pa., Sept. 1 (AP) A new interstate highway and the bridge meant to carry it miss each other by 11 feet.

IT was a rehearsal hall called Bohemia on 73d Street between First and Second Avenues. But yesterday no one was rehearsing. The dancers of American Ballet Theater were sitting in serried rows of unfamiliar chairs, and discussing strike action.

The appointment of James P. Twomey as deputy director of the local development services division of Urban America, Inc., has been announced by William L. Slayton, executive vice president of the organization.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 1 The strains of "Praise, my soul, the King of Heaven," sung by a girls' choir, resounded through St. Andrew's Dune Church here today as Miss Serena Mary Churchill Russell walked down the blue-carpeted aisle for her marriage to R. Stephen Salant Jr., a commodity broker.

The New York Mets continued to throw monkey wrenches around the upper echelons of the National League yesterday, as Dennis Ribant outpitched Gaylord Perry of the San Francisco Giants, 2-1, before 37,516 persons.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) The House approved today, 217 to 127, a $3.5-billion compromise foreign aid authorization bill that keeps United States assistance on a year-toyear basis.
WHILE all eyes were on the losers in last month's down market, a small select group of stocks on the New York Stock Exchange-mostly electronics companies bucked the trend.

The decision of U Thant not to present himself for another term as Secretary General of the United Nations comes as a deep disappointment, even though it had been long predicted. For all his own disclaimer of any concept of indispensability, Mr. Thant was and still is the best man for the post anywhere on the horizon. Every effort must be made to induce him to change his mind.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 1 Louis J. Richards, director of the Health Department here from 1898 to 1947, died yesterday at his home in Norwich, Conn. His age was 91.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 1 (AP) Senator Clifford P. Case, was rebuffed by New Jersey Teamsters today. The Republican Senator asked for their election support, but they endorsed his Democratic opponent instead.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 1 Yugoslavia's worst air disaster took the lives of 95 Britons early today when a plane chartered by vacationists crashed while approaching the Ljubljana Airport, in the northern part of the country.

Members of the organization are aware that my term as Secretary General of the United Nations expires on Nov. 3, 1966. During recent months I have had exchanges of view with many of them, including in some instances heads of state and government. I believe that it would be proper for me and helpful to the governments of member states to make my own decision known at the present time.

In an unusual three-way operation, the Christophers, a Roman Catholic movement dedicated to the development of individual responsibility in society and government, has acquired new and better headquarters two doors from the building it has occupied.
CARSON CITY, Nev., Sept. 1 The Nevada Gaming Commission charged today that the state had been under siege by Federal investigators seeking evidence of tax cheating by licensed gamblers.
Sterling fell 18 points yesterday on foreign-exchange markets here.

President Johnson's persuasive power may have lost some of its early magic on Capitol Hill, but it operated with beneficial effect in the quick decision of Senate-House conferees to speed up the timetable for a higher Federal minimum wage.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 1--A young Asian student recently approached U Thant and asked why he did not insist that the war in Vietnam be taken up in the Security Council.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 Rail freight ton-mileage generated by carloadings and intercity truck tonnage for the week ended Aug. 27 were both ahead of the volume in the corresponding week of 1965.

Vice President Humphrey will help the New York State Democrats get their campaign for Governor off to an impressive start by making a major address after the nomination next week at the party's convention in Buffalo.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 1 John J. Fitzgibbons, board chairman and former president of the Famous Players Canadian Corporation, Ltd., of Toronto, owner and operator of theater chains, television stations and community antenna systems, died in a nursing home here yesterday. He was 76 years old and lived at 27 Olmstead Road, Scarsdale.

The rivalry of the television networks to outdo one another in prestige drama continues to grow. Under development for the National Broadcasting Company is a drama festival next spring that would offer five one-hour original plays on successive evenings.

A copper price rise appears imminent. The mood of the industry, after much soul searching, is wary. But trade sources indicate copper producers believe that demand and cost pressures now outweigh pressures from Washington to maintain an artificial price.

The reported intention of the Johnson Administration to urge temporary repeal of the 7 per cent tax credit for capital investment represents a desirable inflation check, already too long delayed. The move will bring into play an effective but relatively moderate fiscal weapon for curbing upward price pressures without further overdependence on high interest rates and other tight-money policies, now being made tighter still by the Federal Reserve System.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 1 Nguyen Thien Nhon is a forthright young man of 31 whose round face wears a permanent look of amusement.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange seesawed through the session yesterday but closed with more gains than losses.
SOUTHPORT, England, Sept. 1 (AP) Bert Yancey, a 28year-old pro from Radnor, Pa. birdied the last four holes today in the $200,000 Carling open tournament, the richest golf event in the world.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 1 The Government has decided to allow 1,200 Belgian teachers now vacationing at home to return to their posts in the Congo as part of an aid program that "must remain outside political controversy."
BALTIMORE, Sept. 1 (AP) The Baltimore Bullets of the National Basketball Association traded Bailey Howell today to the Boston Celtics for Mel Counts, a center, in a straight player deal.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 1 (AP) Landings this week have poured 3,000 more Americans into the Vietnam war, which is expected to engage 400,000 by the end of the year. The United States command disclosed today that the total of land, sea and air forces has risen to 303,400.

Bond prices continued yesterday the rally that began late Tuesday, Government and corporate issues rose sharply in early trading, faltered toward midday and closed higher for the day but below their best levels. WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 The National League of Insured Savings Associations, in a reversal of position, announced today it would support proposed legislation to fix a 4 per cent interest ceiling on bank certificates of deposit of $100,000 or less.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1 (AP) Mayor A.J. Cervantes said today that he was certain many St. Louis firemen would not join a threatened strike tomorrow. The Mayor noted that a vote to strike for more money represented about 20 per cent of the 1.150 firemen in Local 73 of the International Association of Fire Fighters.
SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Sept. 1 (AP) Carol Mann from Towson, Md., shot a four-under-par 68 today to take the lead after the first round of the first Women's World Series of Golf.
Two more newspaper unions have reached full agreement with The World Journal Tribune, bringing the prospect of an end to the 130-day dispute closer.
The Rank Organization, Ltd., the large British film producer and distributor, announced yesterday in London that it set records in sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended June 25.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 Within two weeks after Lieut. Col. John Edward Davis of the Army returned to his home town of McClusky, N.D., in October, 1945, he did what every other veteran did in that ranching town of 900 persons he joined James Roberts Post ...

Two narcotics agents arrested a member of a heroin peddling ring who gave them $20,221 as down payment on an alleged $100,000 bribe to permit a heroin "factory" to operate, the police charged yesterday.

Sell orders deluged the New York Cocoa Exchange for the second day in a row, sending prices for some contracts down the 1 cent-a-pound daily limit. Volume rose to a record 5,874 contracts, outpacing the 4,704 contracts changing hands Wednesday, the former peak day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 The Johnson Administration and the New York Police Department came under vigorous attack today as a Senate subcommittee ended its first round of explosive hearings into urban problems.
American Airlines, Inc., which was not struck during the recent machinists strike that started on July 8 and ended Aug. 19, reported yesterday a sharp rise in profits and revenues for July.
The Phelps Dodge Corporation said yesterday that it would spend $100-million to develop its copper ore body at Tyrone, N.M.
Manuel Diaz Jr., a civilian member of the Police Review Board and director of the city- ...
The Vendo Company, a manufacturer of automatic vending equipment, announced yesterday in Kansas City, Mo., the election of George S. Arneson as president and chief administrative officer.
New York State school districts were told yesterday that they could still receive funds under the new State Textbook Loan Law, despite the fact that the law has been declared unconstitutional.

Reductions in the wholesale prices of ground regular coffees were announced yesterday by two large processors as a consequence of lower prices for green coffee. Wholesale prices of instant coffees were not affected.
To save the redwood forests of Northern California from wanton destruction, President Johnson and Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall have appealed to Congress for emergency legislation.

HEIDI MURRAY, an 18-year-old actress, describes her philosophy of clothes crisply and concisely: "Get 'em and forget 'em." Her mother, Mrs. Jeanne Murray Vanderbilt, has been listed as one of the world's best-dressed women.
Consumers in the New York area hardly missed a beat in stepping up their purchases in July, a month that saw an 8 per cent drop in the value of stocks on Wall Street.

Myron J. Schloss, a retired furniture manufacturer, died Tuesday in the Harlem Hospital, where he was admitted after his car had struck an abutment of the Willis Avenue Bridge in the Bronx. He was 72 years old and lived at 1230 Park Avenue.

State Supreme Court rulings declaring Representatives Edna F. Kelly and Abraham J. Multer the winners of Democratic nominations for Congress in the primary election last June 28 were upheld last night by the Appellate Division.
The Royal Typewriter Company, Inc., is introducing a new office-electric machine with a campaign that goes right after its principal competition "most people know the other company by its initials."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) The Senate voted today to ban sales of dangerous toys.
The election of Donald C. McVay Jr. to the new post of senior vice president for corporate development was announced yesterday in Pittsburgh by the H.J. Heinz Company.
While Cassius Clay was pummeling Henry Cooper and Brian London during his last two heavyweight title defenses, Joe Louis was tramping about a golf course.

A CERTAIN wry skepticism has always made me dubious of that tag, the best things in life are free. Yet, at the moment, the free, and eagerly accepted Harkness Dance Festival at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park is offering New Yorkers some sumptuous dancing.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 108.5 on Wednesday from 109 on Tuesday.
BONN, Sept. 1 Lieut. Gen. Werner Panitzki told the Defense Committee of the Bundestag today that the Defense Ministry had watered down his report on the crashes of the air force's Starfighter planes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) Senate-House conferees reached agreement today on compromise legislation that would raise the Federal minimum wage to $1.60 an hour in 1968 and expand coverage to about eight million additional workers including for the first time farm hands.

A number of Off Broadway offerings were announced yesterday, Stella Holt will produce Owen Rachleff's "Javelin" and Rene Marques's "The Ox Cart," the former next month at a theater to be announced and the latter in November at the Greenwich Mews Theater under the auspices of George Edgar.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 Vice President Humphrey and Senator Robert F. Kennedy of New York are not running for anything not this year, at least but they seem to be trying to outdo each other in helping their Democratic friends.

DEER PARK, L.I., Sept 1 An agreement to purchase three Suffolk weekly newspapers has been made by Cowles Communications, Inc., which intends to publish a new daily newspaper. The Suffolk Sun, here this fall.
A former marine was killed in an exchange of gunfire with the police early yesterday in a Lower East Side apartment. One policeman was shot in the head and wounded.

The Metropolitan Opera will dedicate Welhelm Lehmbruck's 1911 sculpture "Die Kniende" ("The Kneeling Woman") at a ceremony at the new house next Tuesday. The work, which commemorates the gift, announced in 1961, of $2.5 million to the Wet by the German government, will stand at the head of the grand staircase leading to the Grand Tier promenade. The new house will open Sept. 16 with Samuel Barber's Antony and Cleopatra."
Nine out of ten of the city's 11,772 licensed taxicabs fail to meet Hack Bureau specifications for passenger comfort and safety, the Police Department acknowledged yesterday.
JACKSON, Mich., Friday. Sept. 2 (AP) Gangs of whites and Negroes spread violence across parts of this city last night and early today, injuring at least four persons.

Intermediate School 201 is a sleek, recently completed $5million structure that stands on concrete stilts amid the squalor of East Harlem. A sign proclaims it to be "New York's First Windowless, Air-Conditioned School."
Mrs. Marta Safar Gurtoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emerich Safar of Elmhurst, Queens, was married last night to Dr. Frederick Paul Siegal, son of Dr. and Mrs. Sheppard Siegal, of 65 East 96th Street.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 1 Gov. Karl F. Rolvaag of Minnesota is the healthiestlooking political corpse in the Middle West.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) President Johnson will fly to Michigan and Ohio Monday for four Labor Day speeches.
The marriage of Miss Katherine Graubard to Dr. William Howard Calvin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred H. Calvin of Kansas City, Mo., took place here yesterday.

A Coast Guard plane and a Navy transport stood by a disabled Italian tanker last night as 35-foot waves and 55-knot winds churned up by the tail of Hurricane Faith pounded at the vessel and poured the heavy seas into her engine room.

The Jazz in the Garden series at the Museum of Modern Art wound up its summer season last night one week later than had originally been planned. Because the concert by Roland Kirk's group was rained out several weeks ago, the Booker Ervin Quartet was booked last night to complete the 10-concert schedule.

Basic changes in the operation of the United States Merchant Marine Academy have been recommended in the 19th annual report of the Congressional Board of Visitors to the Kings Point, L.I., ship-officer training school.
ARDMORE, Pa., Sept. 1 Deane Beman scored a 67 today, the low round of the United States Amateur golf championship, and led with a 36-hole total of 138.
MOSCOW, Sept. 1 The Soviet leadership rejected today President Johnson's appeal for new East-West "acts of common endeavor" despite the war in Vietnam.

HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, N.J., Sept. 1 Edmund E. Field of 333 Springfield Avenue, a lawyer associated for the last 60 years with S.M. and D.E. Meeker, a law firm at 1 Hanson Place, Brooklyn, died yesterday at Hackensack Hospital. He was 83 years old.

THE education of Don Davis and Francis Peay, the huge rookie tackles of the New York Giants, will really begin to- morrow night in the unscholarly setting of the Green Bay stadium. They have taken preliminary courses and learned valuable lessons. But knowledge of the finer points of football play is about to be crammed down their throats and rolled over their prostrate bodies by some of the most expert teachers in the land.
Foremost Daries, Inc., which already owns about 40 per cent of the 4.25 million outstanding shares of McKesson Robbins, Inc., is making a tender offer for 550,000 more shares.
Stock prices continued to rise yesterday, although the advance lacked the vigor of the preceding two sessions.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 1 About 100,000 people demonstrated in front of Parliament today in a Communist-sponsored march to demand the resignation of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.

BELVEDERE, Calif., Sept. 1 (AP) Jerie Clark of Seattle won the most important race of her career yesterday as she skippered her team to the North American women's sailing championship. Her crew comprised Renate McVittie and Mary Anne Easter.

The American Export Isbrandtsen Lines passenger vessel Atlantic, inbound from the Mediterranean, rendezvoused early yesterday morning with the outbound Israeli liner Shalom to take aboard a seriously injured member or the Shalom's crew.

YONKERS, Sept. 1 Stanley Dancer, the New Egypt, N.J., squire, topped his "greatest day" in a harness racing driving career that he began 21 years ago with a victory tonight behind Cardigan Bay in a $25,000 free-for-all handicap pace at Yonkers Raceway.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara was accused on the House floor today of overruling the Army Vice Chief of Staff in ordering the purchase of "substandard" 20-mm. guns from the West German Government.
DU QUOIN, Ill., Sept. 1 (AP) Stanley Daneer drove 4-yearold Noble Victory to a world trotting record in the first mile heat of the $20,000 Hambletonian Maturity at the Du Quoin State Fair today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 Dr. Howard A. Rusk of New York received tonight a gold medal in recognition of his contributions to rehabilitation medicine.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 1 Salah el-Bitar, co-founder of the Baath (Arab Renaissance) party, who was ousted as Premier of Syria in a left-wing military coup last February, has escaped from prison and found asylum in Lebanon.
An Episcopal priest will perform this month at the hungry i nightclub in San Francisco.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 1 A high Republican leader suggested today that his party consider a bipartisan endorsement of State Controller Arthur Levitt, the only elected Democrat in the state administration.

SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 1 Miss Constance Moench, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Moench of Summit, was married this morning to Dr. Alvin M. Goodman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Goodman of Atlantic City.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) The House passed by a voice vote today a $545.5-million child nutrition bill that would provide breakfasts for needy schoolchildren.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 1 A Rockville Centre art dealer, his two partners, a lawyer and a Nassau County bank were involved today in a court case that centered on a painting that the dealer had asserted was the work of Michelangelo.
THE HAGUE, Sept. 1 The annual budget debate in Parliament this fall is expected to produce a controversy over the cost of the Monarchy.
Recently concluded acoustic tests at the new Metropolitan Opera House in Lincoln Center confirm what has been open gossip that the new auditorium will be a complete success.

HEADINGLEY, Man. (Canadian Press) Sept. 1 Ten prisoners broke out of the Headingley provincial jail tonight after seizing guards at knifepoint and opening the prison's gun locker. Armed with rifles and pistols, they fled in three automobiles.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Sept. 1 Upon quitting the Buffalo Bills, the champions of the American Football League, last winter, Lou Saban, their coach, said, "There can be little left to conquer in professional football." With that Saban moved to the University of Maryland, where he has everything to conquer as head coach of an underdog for 1966.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 1 Local pride appears to be dominating economic reason as Nigeria nears a showdown on whether to split into ethnic pieces or remain united in federation.
The Conservative party announced yesterday that a third aspirant was under consideration for its gubernatorial nomination.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange advanced yesterday for the third consecutive session although some late profit taking erased some gains.

FIERY RUN, Va., Sept. 1 One of the oddities of the Johnson Administration is that it looks so different from far away. Distance may not lend enchantment, but it lends detachment. From afar, the President's yearnings and purposes come across much clearer than his politics and his tactics, which dominate the capital in Washington.

BOLZANO, Italy, Sept. 1 Leaders of the ethnic German majority of Bolzano Province, northernmost in Italy, gave carefully conditioned acceptance tonight to an Italian-Austrian proposal for local autonomy. The plan is designed to put an end to a dozen years of political agitation and terrorism.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1 President Gustavo Diaz Ordaz suggested today that the United States was not completely meeting the social and economic aspirations of Latin America.
A group of frightened and angry Bronx storekeepers who had threatened to form an armed vigilante squad to guard their shops was promised around-the-clock city police protection yesterday.

Representatives of private employment agencies here have accepted an invitation, to meet Tuesday with the regional direcfor of the Federal antipoverty program, Robert J. Mangum. The subject will be the thousands of jobs that the agencies say are available.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell presses his drive to oust Sargent Shriver as director of the Office of Economic Opportunity in sublime disregard of the fact that it is Mr. Powell, not Mr. Shriver, who has delayed the whole poverty program, diminished the voice of the poor within it and cut the flow of money and jobs into Harlem and all the Harlems U.S.A.
BONN, Sept. 2 There may be two Fords in West Germany's future.
The majority of issues on the American Stock Exchange retreated yesterday following three successive sessions of ad- vances.

KENILWORTH, N.J., Sept. 2 Lloyde Monroe, the pro at the Essex Fells Country Club, teamed with Santo Renda, an amateur, today to win the Francis X. Coakley Memorial Trophy in the 22d annual tournament at the Galloping Hill golf course.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) Baltimore's reliever, Stu Miller, hit two men with pitches in the 11th inning, forced in the winning run, and Chicago beat the league-leading Orioles, 9-8, tonight.

The Sunday ban on automobiles in Central Park to reserve its roadway for bicycles has proved so popular that yesterday Mayor Lindsay extended it to Forest Park in Queens and Silver Lake Park on Staten Island.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) Roger LeClerc booted five field goals in as many tries tonight as the Chicago Bears rallied to defeat the St. Louis Cardinals 22-20, in the exhibition finale for each National Football League club.

YONKERS, Sept. 2 Speedy Rodney, a 5-year-old stallion, smashed his own world record for a mile race on a half-mile track at Yonkers Raceway tonight when he won the $20,000 Danbury trot in 1:58 3/5 before 24,173.
A race that has established itself as one of the most important tests for fillies on the fall calendar, the Gazelle Handicap, will be the feature attraction on the program at Aqueduct today.

LONDON, Sept. 2 In London, as in New York, much of the most interesting theater happens away from the smart uptown houses. At the Hampstead Theater Club, a 130-seat box constantly threatened by financial failure, a new play by John Bowen, "After the Rain," collected some of the most enthusiastic notices of the season.

DETROIT, Sept. 2 (UPI) Car production this week was double that of a week ago as the big four car makers cranked up their assembly lines for the full output of 1967 models, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
ALBANY, Sept. 2 The Republican state chairman sought tonight to squelch any move to get his party to endorse State Controller Arthur Levitt, a Democrat, for re-election.
HARRISON, N.Y., Sept. 2 Mrs. Herman D. Baskind has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Louise Baskind, to David B. Lippner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jordan Lippner of Scarsdale.
VERNON, N.Y., Sept. 2 (AP) Bret Hanover smashed the world one-mile racing record with a clocking of 1:54 in a time trial at vernon Downs tonight.

The National Association of Manufacturers told President Johnson yesterday that withdrawal of the 7 per cent tax credit for business investment "would result in confusion and chaos in planning capital expenditures and orderly expansion."
Is Senator Robert F. Kennedy a good father to his nine children?

BUDAPEST, Sept. 2 (UPI)--An offer of reasonable compensation from the Soviet Union and Poland to the Amateur Athletic Union will save them having to explain to the International Amateur Athletic Federation why they walked out on sanctioned international matches against the United States this summer.
PARIS, Sept. 2 The visit of President de Gaulle to Cambodia is viewed here now as an attempt by him, albeit one conceived in considerable pessimism, to play a role as a future mediator in Indochina.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 2 A new union in the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations was officially declared the winner today of a hotly contested election among grape pickers.
LEWISBURG, Pa., Sept. 2 Carroll, Huntress had such a successful season in his first year as head football coach at Bucknell last fall that he and the Bisons may have nowhere to go but down in 1966.
SALEM, N.H., Sept. 2 At the annual Suffolk Downs business meeting this summer, an indignant stockholder charged that New England horse racing had gone to the dogs.
PROSPECTS Good but may be not good enough to repeat as M.A.C. champion.
LONDON, Sept. 2 The survival of the frog in Britain, an Oxford professor warns, is being threatened by the "depredations of biologists" intent on finding specimens to dissect in their laboratories.
Areas in Harlem equal to 31 city blocks consist of unused land, either as vacant lots or as properties with empty, rotting buildings, a survey by the Manhattan Borough President's office has shown.
SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Sept. 2 (AP) Mickey Wright shot a five-under-par 67 today and won the first Ladies World Series of Golf by four strokes.
OTTAWA, Sept. 2 Trains in Canada began running today fo the first time in a week after Parliament ordered 120,000 railwaymen to end their strike.
FORT LEE, N.J., Sept. 2 (UPI) A Brooklyn woman was killed and three other persons were injured early today when two cars collided head-on on the George Washington Bridge.

The United States chapter of the Czechoslovak Society of Arts and Sciences opened a three-day convention yesterday with meetings at Columbia University and a concert at Carnegie Hall. Works by two Czechoslovak composers were played last night; three by the late Bohuslav Martinu and three by 75-year-old Karel Jirak.

NOUMEA, New Caledonia, Saturday, Sept. 3 President de Gallue arrived in Noumea this morning as he continued his world tour. He will spend two weeks in New Caledonia, New Hebrides and French Polynesia before returning to Paris by way of Guadeloupe in the West Indies.

ALBANY, Sept. 2 The Court of Appeals declined today to review a lower court decision which ordered a new Democratic primary election between Rep. Leonard Farbstein and City Councilman Theodore S. Weiss in Manhattan's 19th Congressional District.

ARDMORE, Pa., Sept. 2 Downing Gray of Pensacola, Fla., the son of a former Navy football captain, plunged through the United States Amateur golf championship field today on a 68 and tied Deane Beman for the lead at 214.

You have heard the lamentations, and they are well-founded. We live in an age of speed, noise, tension and shocking violence. But all is not lost. The National Arts Endowment has made a grant of $400,000 for the cultivation of chamber music and its acolytes.
Stock prices closed slightly lower on average yesterday after weathering a midsession sinking spell that sent quotations on leading issues tumbling downward.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 2 Gov. George C. Wallace signed today a bill that declares "null and void" the desegregation guidelines of the United States Office of Education and prohibits Alabama schools from signing any statements of compliance with the guidelines.
A strong rise in gold-mining shares highlighted brisk trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.
Mrs. Alfred R. Gross of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Sharon Lynne Gross, to Mark Sabin, son of Mrs. Benjamin Sabin of Miami Beach and the late Mr. Sabin.
DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 2 The sudden flash of racial violence that erupted yesterday in the west side Negro section has been snuffed out by the police and National Guardsmen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2--Joblessness among Negroes and the unskilled has risen this summer, the Labor Department reported today. This occurred even though over-all unemployment continued at the relatively low level of 3.9 per cent of the labor force.

TOKYO, Sept. 2 Japan's three leading newspapers today condemned the new Socialist party platform calling for abrogation of the security treaty with the United States. Their position is thought to indicate a strong swing to the right in Japanese political sentiment.

NEWTOWN, Conn., Sept. 2 Arthur L. Treble, former president of Frederick Warne Co., Inc., 101 Fifth Avenue, New York, book publishers, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home, 8 Knollwood Drive. He was 76 years old.
The proposed five-cent-a-mile taxi fare increase must stand "the same scrutiny" as a rise in utility rates, Mayor Lindsay warned yesterday.
LONDON, Sept. 2, The British Government is adamant in its determination to save atleast 34-million, or nearly $100million, on the annual foreign exchange cost of its army in West Germany.

An 18-year-old Egyptian youth, the finest tennis player to come out of his country, challenged Roy Emerson of Australia in a fashion amounting to lese majeste against the erstwhile Wimbledon and American titleholder in the United States championships at Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday.

The gap between advocates and critics of the past decade's revolution in American mathematical education seems to have narrowed considerably. At a Rutgers University symposium this week, several key leaders of that revolution warned against excesses too much abstraction, needless jargon and the like.

Mayor Lindsay's Cabinet met 86 floors above the mistcovered city yesterday morning, then watched while the Mayor pressed a switch that transferred radio station WNYC-FM's transmission to an antenna atop the Empire State Building.

ITALIAN Renaissance furniture, once a necessity as a status symbol for latter-day Medici such as J.P. Morgan, Henry Frick and their imitators, are now being sought by collectors who have intellectual interests.
LONDON, Sept. 2 With a guile that has become customary, the Treasury announced today that Britain's gold and foreign currency reserves dropped by 19-million ($53.2-million) in August.

The fall edition of the Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit opened yesterday in Greenwich Village. The show customarily has something for everyone, and this year it even had something for the "fuzz."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 2 A collection of jazz recordings and writings considered to be the most extensive of its kind has been acquired by Rutgers University. The collection, comprising the archives of the Institute of Jazz Studies, will be used by the university for a wide-ranging program of jazz research, study and performance.
The American Enka Corporation announced yesterday increases of 3 to 5 cents a pound on all of its textile rayon filament yarns, effective Oct. 1.
ON weekends and evenings, New York's financial district is quiet and empty. Even during normal working hours, activity on the streets is relatively limited.

Despite the anti-American tone of General de Gaulle's remarks in Cambodia, the Johnson Administration can best advance the cause of peace in Vietnam by accenting the positive in its response to the concrete proposals he and Prince Sihanouk have made in their joint communique.
MONTREAT, N.C., Sept. 2 (AP) Anne Morrow Graham, the daughter of Dr. Billy Graham, the evangelist, and Mrs. Graham was married to Dr. Daniel Milton Lotz of Chapel Hill tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 The State Department announced today the expulsion of a Soviet diplomat charged with trying to buy secret information on the United States space program, missiles and aircraft.
Municipal, corporate and United States Government bonds finished the week with sharp advances yesterday in a continuation of the almost uninterrupted rally that started Tuesday afternoon.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 2 The leaders of the Soviet and United States delegations had an hour-long private talk today on the situation resulting from U Thant's refusal to seek another term as Secretary General.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 2 It was all smiles at the Union Building in Pretoria today as Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd and Basutoland's Premier, Chief Leabua Jonathan, met. It was the first time that a South African Prime Minister had met in South Africa with the leader of a black African state.
ATLANTA, Sept. 2 (AP) Atlanta, firemen walked off their jobs tonight for the second time in three months in a dispute with the city over wages and hours.
TORONTO, Sept. 2 Color television programs were broadcast over Canadian stations for the first time last night.

WASHINGTON, Sept.2 (AP) The Internal Revenue Service said today that tax refunds for wives of servicemen in Vietnam would not be delayed because the husband had failed to sign a joint income tax return.
The National Maritime Union turned down yesterday a Government offer of funds to finance emergency expansion of the union's training program for seamen.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Sept. 2 Miss Lisa Kirkland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Wilkinson Kirkland, was married today to James Michael Kerrigan. He is the son of Mrs. Ambrose Lawrence Kerrigan of Fitchburg and the late Mr. Kerrigan.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 2 (AP) Mickey Stanley scored the tie-breaking run on a force play in the 10th inning and Don Wert followed with a run-scoring single tonight to give the Detroit Tigers a 7-5 victory over Cleveland and a sweep of their double-header.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 2 The last of the season's distance ventures into blue water for Long Island Sound skippers began tonight with the start of the Stamford Yacht Club Vineyard race off The Cows bell buoy outside Stamford harbor.

A committee of Negro Demo- cratic leaders has gone on record in favor of the nomination of a Negro for Lieutenant Governor and against the idea of choosing a Negro candidate for the lesser post of Attorney General.

COPENHAGEN, Sept. 2--Princess Margrethe, 26-year-old heiress to the Danish throne, is to become engaged to a French diplomat, Henri Marie Jean Andre Count de Laborde de Monpezat, third secretary of the French Embassy in London, it was reported here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) A former Assistant United States Attorney General denied charges today by the Nevada Gaming Commission that the Justice Department wanted to make a massive raid on the state's gambling casinos in 1961.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 3 (AP) Roberto Clemente slammed a three-run homer for his 2,000th major league hit tonight, leading the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 7-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs.
POINT A. LA HACHE, La., Sept. 2 (AP) A leader of the Plaquemines Parish school boycott said today a private school for whites would be set up in Leander H. Perez's former home.
TORONTO, Sept. 2 A record Canadian wheat crop this year of nearly 800 million bushels was forecast today by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 2 (AP) A civil rights group carried its protest concerning club membership policies to a Congressman's home tonight after having agreed to suspend picketing in Milwaukee suburbs for the Labor Day weekend because of insufficient police.

Three Harlem groups claimed victories yesterday in their fight with the Board of Education to have African and American Negro history taught in Public School 175 and to gain a stronger voice in the school's affairs.

The Federal Reserve System may have to slow sharply the rate at which it provides new credit to the economy in order to prevent interest rates from going through the roof, Homer Jones, vice president and chief economist of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, said yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 2 American pilots carried out concentrated attacks near Hanoi yesterday, bombing targets north of the capital of North Vietnam. Two fuel dumps and several bridges were among them.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 2 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi announced today that the Government was lifting a ban on the production of gold ornaments of more than 14 carats to provide relief to India's two million goldsmiths.

Burnside R. Value, a former Army engineer who had served as deputy administrator of the National Recovery Administration in the early days of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's Administration, died Thursday in Colebrook, N.H., where he had lived for the last four years. He was 77 years old.
HONG KONG, Sept. 2 The United States has made a strong bid to expand its share of Hong Kong's market for imported foods with the opening this week of an exhibition of American products.
WHEN the idea of beef, lamb or fish cooked on the outdoor grill begins to pall, it is time to think of pork, which provides a variety of cuts for both spit and grill cookery.

ATLANTA, Sept. 2 (AP) Ed Mathews hit two home runs in the first game and Denis Menke singled in the winning run in the nightcap as Atlanta won a double-header for the first time this season, beating the Houston Astros, 6-5 and 2-1.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, who is the chief Senate sponsor of automobile safety legislation, said today that he saw no need for Congressional hearings now on passenger car prices.
Intrauterine contraceptive devices can be used successfully by nearly three out of four women who try them, according to a report by a World Health Organization medical committee.

SOUTHPORT, England, Sept. 2 (AP) Kel Nagle, an Australian golfer, held a one-stroke lead after three rounds of the Carling golf tournament today, with Billy Casper, the United States Open champion, breathing down his neck after shooting a four-under-par 69.

New expansion probrams were announced yesterday by a number of companies in a variety of industries. The Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company said it would build a $37 million mercury-cell, chlorine caustic powder plant at its Lake Charles, La., chemical operations.
ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 2 (AP) Joe Adcock hit a tworun pinch homer in the eighth inning to give the California Angels a 6-5 victory over the Washington Senators tonight.
ATHENS, Sept. 2 Leaders of the Greek Orthodox Church today termed "oppressive" the draft of a Government bill that would press drastic reforms in church administration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 Dr. Arnold Shamaskin, a specialist in tuberculosis and other chest ailments, died yesterday of a stroke at the Sleepy Hollow Manor Nursing Home in Annandale, Va. He was 83 years old and lived in North Springfield, Va.
The West Side Federal Savings and Loan Association, New York, announced yesterday the election of Cecil N. Rudnick as a director.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) Representative Charles E. Chamberlain, Republican of Michigan, said today the Post Office Department had agreed to stop leasing foreign-made vehicles.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 2 William J. Cassano, an architectural designer with of fices here, died last night at his home in nearby Ocean Township. He was 54 years old.

BONN. Sept. 2 The very acclaim that greeted the appointment of Lieut. Gen. Johannes Steinhoff today as the Inspector General of the West German Air Force has put the battle-scarred World War II ace on the spot.

TORONTO, Ont. Sept. 2 (AP) A United States Navy jet of the Blue Angels acrobatic team, performing before thousands of spectators at the Canadian National Exhibition, crashed and burned today on the shore of Lake Ontario.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2 Federal District Judge Joseph S. Lord 3d ruled today that Pennsylvania law prohibits Girard College from excluding Negroes.

MINEOLA, L.L., Sept. 2 (UPI) Two Syosset restaurateurs were arrested today on charges of first degree manslaughter in the killing of Ralph Bozzone, whose body was found late yesterday in Jennings Lake, Cold Spring Harbor.
Officials of The World Journal Tribune continued their efforts yesterday to reach agreements with additional newspaper unions.
Four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 6.2 per cent in production for the week ended Aug. 27, compared with the level in the corrsponding 1965 week.

Milt Jackson, the vibraphonist of the Modern Jazz Quartet, appeared last night at Town Hall backed by a 15-piece orchestra instead of his usual colleagues. The concert was a benefit for the Grace Congregational Church's communityservice program.

WINNIPEG, Man., Sept. 2 (AP) Canadian and United States police early today recaptured five of 10 heavily armed fugitives from a Manitoba, jail and a sixth turned himself in. Ronald Fast, 17 years old, a guard's son kidnapped as a hostage, was freed.
MARLBOROUGH, Conn., Sept. 2 (AP) A young woman clad in a nightgown was abducted from her home early today and escaped from the kidnapper by jumping from his car, the State Police said.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 2 South Vietnam's chief of state, Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu, said today he would not be a candidate for President in an election expected to be held next year.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 2 (AP) The Brookfield Farm's Imasmartee goes after his third consecutive stakes victory in to- morrow's $35,150 Kelly-Olympic Handicap at the Atlantic City Race Course.
MIAMI, Sept. 2 (AP)--Claims for damages resulting from the sinking of the cruise ship Yarmouth Castle amount to more than $59-million.

POINT ABINO, Ont., Sept. 2 (AP) Harry Sindle, a boat builder from Virginia, piloted Vim VI through six-foot-high whitecaps on Lake Erie today to win the fourth race in the North American Lightning Class sailing championship. The final race will be sailed tomorrow.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 2 Rhodesia's Minister of Law and Order, Desmond LardnerBurke, and the officer commanding the Rhodesian Air Force, Air Vice Marshal Hawkins, broadcast warnings today to potential terrorists.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 2 Mr. and Mrs. A.R. Goebel have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jerilyn Diane Goebel to Dane Chapman Scott, son of Dr. and Mrs. Roderic M. Scott also of Stamford. A wedding early in January is planned.
DAWSON CITY, Yukon Restoration of Arizona Charlie's palace grand saloon and opera house has helped lift local spirits cast down by the vanishing gold industry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 The Senate ethics committee has issued more than 80 subpoenas and interviewed about 50 persons thus far in its widened investigation into the financial activities of Senator Thomas J. Dodd.

CRESCENT CITY, Calif., Sept. 2 (AP) A flood of telegrams from Del Norte County citizens protesting President Johnson's proposed legislation against the Rellim-Miller Redwood Company went today to the White House and members of Congress.
About 2,500 tennis hungry youngsters turned out yesterday for a free clinic at the West Side Club in Forest Hills, Queens, forcing the sponsors to put out the S.R.O. sign in the grandstand.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) President Johnson named today an advisory commission to study ways of improving the nation's libraries.

The strike that never was will never be. After days of teetering on this brink or that, American Ballet Theater has solved its labor difficulties. The dancers, represented by their union, the American Guild of Musical Artists, have agreed on a contract with their management. The muse of the dance, at least for the moment, smiles benignly and equally upon all.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 2(UPI) Wayne Embry, the team captain and center of eight seasons with the Cincinnati Royals of the National Basketball Association announced his retirement from professional basketball today.
Charges that New York City's police "walk away from trouble" were termed "unfair" yesterday by Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary. But other policemen said they were true.
After the vacation has run its all too brief course and before falling back into step with life's routine there's a time to count all the pleasures and satisfactions of the recent past.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 Outstanding consumer installment credit rose by more than half a billion dollars in July, a larger rise than June's but a smaller one than the monthly average for the first part of the year.
JAKARTA, Indonsia, Sept. 2 Foreign Minister Adam Malik's long-planned visit to the Soviet Union was canceled today.

Robert F. Six, president of Continental Airlines, said yesterday he had filed a report with the Securities and Exchange Commission showing his sales of 20,542 shares of Continental's capital stock during August. He said he continued to own 17,000 shares.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 2 The Mapai and Ahdut Avodah parties, the main ones in the coalition governing Israel, adopted a new economic plan last night that fell far short of Premier Levi Eshkol's proposal for a three-year freeze of incomes, prices and taxes.
Mayor Lindsay made an appeal to the public yesterday to help in the campaign against school vandalism.

New York State Medicaid deserves a chance, as Governor Rockefeller, Mayor Lindsay and City Council President Frank O'Connor all agreed yesterday. Government medical aid for the medically indigent families that are self-supporting while in good health but unable to afford illness is a sound idea. So is the attempt to keep such aid from degenerating into "poorhouse" medicine.
KANSAS CITE, Sept. 2 (AP) Lew Krausse allowed Boston six hits tonight as the Kansas City Athletics defeated the Red Sox, 5-1, and moved out of last place in the American League.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 The Treasury bill rate, for both three-month and six-month bills, rose to record levels again at today's auction, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

Heublein, Inc., a producer of food and mixed cocktails, has announced in Hartford the election of Arthur A. Milligan as a director and Kurt E. Volckmar as vice president of the international division.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 The Johnson Administration showed considerable annoyance today over what it took to be an unfair appeal by President de Gaulle for United States concessions on Vietnam.

Partly because of the British seamen strike that paralyzed British shipping for weeks earlier in the summer, the Italian Line was the top carrier of passengers from the United States to Europe in the first seven months of the year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) State Department officials said today that a prominent Burmese Socialist, U Aung Than, had been asked to leave the United States on the ground that his visa had been issued by mistake after his passport had been declared invalid by the Burmese Government.

Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters threatened yesterday to strike the city's 22 municipal hospitals in its effort to oust another union as bargaining agent for 20,000 nonmedical employes.

RUMSON, N.J., Sept. 2 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David Townley Brewster of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Strong Brewster, to Robert Fairchild Porter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon D. Porter of Kensington, Conn.

GASTONIA, N.C., Sept. 2 (UPI)--The driver of a truck that killed Representative T. Ashton Thompson of Ville Platte, La., near Gastonia, N.C., was cleared today of manslaughter and reckless driving charges.
