SAN MARINO, Calif., Sept. 2 Miss Ann Brooks Mattoon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Amasa Mattoon Jr. of Flintridge and Houston, was married this evening to George Torrey Wofford 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wofford Jr. of San Marino.

The Board of Education, concerned that a six-week strike by plumbers in the construction industry will prevent a dozen schools from opening in September, 1967, is canceling its contracts with strikebound plumbing contractors.

MIAMI, Sept. 2 (UPI) The Oakland Raiders turned two pass interceptions into 10 points tonight to defeat a surprising tough band of Miami Dolphins, 23-14, in the opening game of the American Football League's regular season.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 Three surgeons and a chemist have invented a method for extending the shelf-life of collected blood, which is now limited to about 21 days. For shipment to Vietnam, a much longer pe riod would be desirable.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP)--The United States Savings and Loan League, in a reversal of position, supported today a bill that would fix a 4.5 per cent ceiling on the interest banks can pay on certificates of deposit of $100,000 or less.

THE biggest corduroy season in fashion history is under way. A variety of new pattern designs and an increased choice of texture have stimulated interest in the ribbed fabric that was once considered merely functional.

The pace of new car sales picked up in the final 10 days of August and, as a result, industry sales for the entire month just missed surpassing last year's record level, according to reports received yesterday from Detroit.
TOKYO, Sept. 2 (UPI) Gen. Yasuji Okamura, who served as commander of the Japanese expeditionary forces during World War II in China, died today of stomach cancer. He was 82 years old.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 2 (AP) At a time when many shipyards are becalmed, Avondale Shipyards, Inc., is busier than a sailor in a storm.
Dr. William Bakrow has been named president of the Motorola Executive Institute.
Reports on the alleged fixing of harness races at the three major raceways circulated behind prison walls, it was learned yesterday from sources close to the investigation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 The index of primary market prices declined one-tenth of 1 per cent to 106.6 during the week ended Aug. 30, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products and processed foods moved lower in price while industrial commodities averaged unchanged.
Has success spoiled "big labor" in the field of civil rights? Yes, to a certain extent it has according to the National Catholic Welfare Conference.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 2 In the name of unity, King Faisal of Saudi Arabia and President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic are defining and emphasizing differences between conservatives and leftists in the Middle East these days.
ATHENS, Sept. 2 Premier Ion Gheorghe Maurer of Rumania ended his official visit to Greece today by completing seven agreements on trade, communications and cultural relations.

CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 2 (AP) Supreme Court Justice Byron (Whizzer) White will present a bust of Walt Kiesling, the late Pittsburgh Steelers coach, to John McNally at the National Professional Football Hall of Fame enshrinement ceremonies here Sept. 17.
BOULDER, Colo., Sept 2 (AP) A coed at the University of Colorado filed suit in district court today in an effort to get a better grade in English.

Rumors of plots in the Dominican Republic are coming thick and fast these days. There is no evidence to bear out the reports, but unhappily the Dominican Republic has had such a long history of internal trouble except during the odious Trujillo era when a coup d'etat would have been a blessing that nobody can rest easy today.
MILFORD, Conn., Sept. 2 (AP) Two men hijacked a truck reportedly containing $150,000 in razors and razorblades today and kidnapped the driver, the police reported.
ALBANY, Sept. 2 The Court of Appeals ruled tonight in favor of a referendum to deter- mine whether New York City's civilian-controlled police review board should be abolished.

DALLAS, Sept. 2 (AP) Bob Hayes outraced the Minnesota secondary twice on long touchdown passes tonight as the undefeated Dallas Cowboys beat the Vikings, 28-24, in an exhibition game between National Football League teams.
With a thudding fast ball and curves that snapped through the warm, moist air, Jim Bunning extended his perfect record at Shea Stadium last night by turning back the New York Mets, 6-0.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) The tape recorder for the Nimbus 2 weather satellite has frozen and is no longer recording pictures for delayed transmission to earth.

The official visit that the President of the French Republic paid to Cambodia from Aug. 31 to Sept. 2, 1966 is a fresh testimony to the confident relations and to the close friendship that unite the French people and the Khmer people. Prince Norodom Sihanouk and General de Gaulle wished to conclude their discussions with the following declaration, which shows the community of their views on both the situation in Southeast Asia and French-Cambodian relations.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UPI) The Civil Aeronautics Board today held pilot error responsible for the crash of an Allegheny Airlines plane near Williamsport, Pa., more than a year ago.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 2--President de Gaulle called on world powers today to join in a pledge of nonintervention in the internal affairs of Vietnam.

EVEN before word got around that corporations might lose the 7 per cent investment tax credit, economists and Wall Street analysts were doubtful that corporate profits would continue to make impressive gains in 1967. These doubts have been a contributing factor in this year's erratic stock market.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 2 (UPI) A gunman kidnaped a police sergeant, a college student and a motorist today after staging a $300 holdup at the collections office of a Government operated housing project here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) The coordinator of an inquiry ordered by President Johnson into the rising costs of medical services said today he did not plan "a witch hunt for skulduggery."

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 2 Pakistan has charged India with deploying and reinforcing troops "in a threatening posture" along the Jammu-Sialkot border and in the Chamba area of Indian-occupied Kashmir.

"May at 80." "Pay 90 three Dec." Two dozen of the busiest men in Wall Street have been shouting cryptic remarks like those above at the New York Cocoa Exchange in trading that has had its moments of frenzy recently.
The City of New York and representatives of local film producers and film unions are planning a joint campaign to attract more moviemakers to the city.

Mrs. Anne East Harbison of 11 Riverside Drive has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Hope Anne Harbison, to Lieut. Richard E. Pullen, U.S.A.F. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Pullen of Amityville, L.I. A November wedding is planned.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 2 (AP) The A.C. Nielsen Company, the Chicago television rating agency, dropped its $1.5-million damage suit late today against Rex Sparger, former Congressional investigator, and a former Oklahoma legislator.

PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 2 With approximately $30,500 raised or pledged toward a $150,000 goal, the deficit-ridden Pasadena Playhouse is hopefully making plans for the opening of its golden anniversary season on Sept. 27.

Some familiar faces around the folk-music scene appeared last night at the Rheingold Central Park Music Festival. An audience of a few hundred less than capacity, which is news at this summer series in the Wollman Memorial Rink, received approvingly the New Lost City Ramblers, the Rev. Gary Davis, Bruce Murdoch and Sonny Terry and Brownie McGhee.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Sept. 2 (Reuters) Irina Kirichenko of the Soviet Union tonight won the women's world cycling sprint championship for the second time.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. and the Liberal party moved a little closer together yesterday when he accepted an invitation to confer with party leaders Tuesday and the leaders said he was the only possible gubernatorial candidate they would interview.

The Latin sounds were so compelling that the theatrical personalities Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne paused last night in their stroll in Carl Schurz Park, East End Avenue and 86th Street, to watch the Latin Dance Festival.

CHEVY CHASE, Md., Sept. 2 Mr. and Mrs. William G. Finn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carole Bernice Finn, to David A Fisher Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. D. Allen Fisher of Schenectady, N.Y. The wedding is planned for November.

VENICE, Italy, Sept. 2 The Venice Film Festival encountered yet another embarrassment today when the Swedish entry, "Natt Lek" ("Night Games"), which was not permitted a public shoving by Italian censors, received a special showing before the jury and invited journalists.

Automatic landing systems for jet aircraft have become so refined in the last 18 months they they will soon relieve pilots of the task of guiding planes along runways once they touch down at an airport, according to James E. Bevins, general manager of The Bendix Corporation's Eclipse-Pioneer Division.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2 Gov. Otto Kerner ordered tonight the mobilization of 2,000 Illinois National Guard troops to maintain order Sunday during a civil rights march into suburban Cicero.
Tense faces, querulous voices, blaring horns and baggageburdened travelers heralded yesterday's beginning of the Labor Day weekend, in which Americans by the millions switched locales until Tuesday.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 2 (UPI) Wes Parker and Ron Fairly socked home runs to lead the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 6-1 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight.

ALBANY, Sept. 2 (AP) The Malverne, L.I., school board was told by the State Education Commissioner today that "there is no excuse why, after all these many months" it should fail to integrate its schools within the next five days.

Albert Rabinowitz, a 52year-old stamp dealer of 145 Nassau Street, has been arrested on a charge of possession of six stolen United States stamps valued at $5,000, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported yesterday.

NARRAGANSETT, R.I., Sept. 2 Former United States Attorney General J. Howard McGrath, the soft-spoken, hardworking politician whose 22 years in public life started as City Solicitor of Central Falls and ended in fireworks, died at Sunnybrook Farm, his summer place, this morning. He was 62 years old.

DARMSTADT, Germany, Sept. 2 (AP) Kasimir Edschmid, one of the leaders of the expressionist literary movement, died of a heart attack Wednesday while vacationing in Vulpera, Switzerland. He was 75 years old.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Sept. 2 Mr. and Mrs. James L. Ginsberg have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ronna Jane Ginsberg to Edward Joseph Goldstein. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Goldstein of Somerville, N.J.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2 Gov. Otto Kerner ordered tonight the mobilization of 2,000 Illinois National Guard troops to maintain order Sunday during a civil rights march into suburban Cicero.

IS anything more intimidating than to be told "come with children?" You might not have any odd children to spare. You might not like children. All the children you know might be either taking a trip or watching "Son of Batman" (you mean they haven't; they will).
BUDAPEST, Sept. 2 (Reuters) France, Italy, the Soviet Union, Poland and East Germany each won a title today in the European track and field championships here.

The behavior of invertebrates, the backboneless creatures that make up about 95 per cent of animal life, is illustrated in a new exhibit which will open this morning at the American Museum of Natural History.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 108.6 on Thursday from 108.5 on Wednesday.
MOSCOW, Sept. 2 (UPI) Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov, former Defense Minister, today began publication of his wartime memoirs, which give full credit to Stalin as commander in chief of the Red Army.
PHILADELPHLA, Sept. 2 Fayette R. Plumb of Haverford, former board chairman of a hand tool manufacturing company bearing his name, died on Monday at the age of 89.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 The Defense Department denied today that "substandard" 20millimeter guns were being purchased from the West German Government.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Sept. 2 (UPI) The National Aeronautics and Space Administration reported today that a combination of inadequate test procedures and an ill-fitting part caused the explosion of a Saturn 5 moon rocket second stage May 28 in Mississippi.

Miss Isolde Luise Priebe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank K. Priebe of Fair Haven, N.J., became the bride yesterday afternoon of Lloyd David Feld, son of Mr. Abraham Feld of Highland Park, N.J., and the late Mrs. Feld.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 2 The Twins' pitcher, Jim (Mudcat) Grant, admitted he "had nothing" tonight, but with the help of 13 Minnesota hits and a line-drive-catching outfield it was enough to carry him to an 8-5 victory over the New York Yankees at Metropolitan Stadium.

BONN, Sept. 2 Lieut. Gen. Johannes Steinhoff agreed today to take over the job of Inspector General of West Germany's Air Force. The position had been empty since last week, when Chancellor Ludwig Erhard accepted the resignation of the Luftwaffe's commander, Lieut. Gen. Werner Panitzki.
MOSCOW, Sept. 2 (Reuters) The Soviet Union's supersonic airliner may be delayed beyond 1970, Yevgeny Ioginov, the Soviet Civil Aviation Minister, indicated today.

HOLLYWOOD. TRY telling a waterfall to slow down. Try telling Marlo Thomas. Looking like some wood sprite in pale green, she perches on the edge of a cloud-soft, buttercup-yellow velvet sofa, digs her bare toe into the deep red carpet, widens her almond-shaped brown eyes and the words come cascading out. The New York Giants will be playing the coming National Football League season without two of their regulars, Tucker Frederickson and Bill Swain. Both athletes were injured in Milwaukee on Saturday night as the Giants lost to the Green Bay Packers, 37-10, and both underwent surgery last night at St. Vincent's Hospital for repair of damaged knees.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 4 (AP) Hop Riopel, Holy Cross College sports star and administrator, died at St. Vincent's Hospital today, less than a week after he had suffered a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 4 (UPI) The National League-leading Pittsburgh Pirates overcame a 5-0 deficit today by scoring four runs in the third inning and three in the fourth en route to an 8-5 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 4 American servicemen and employes of the Defense Department in Vietnam have been confined to military installations until after the Sept. 11 election of a constituent assembly to draft a constitution, a United States military spokesman said tonight.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 4 Steve Worcester, who held a 3 -point lead after three races yesterday, won the two races today to capture the New England Moth Class sailing championship off the Rocky Point Club on Long Island Sound.
TOKYO, Sept. 4 Lin Piao, China's second-ranking leader, has taken over as commander in chief of the Red Guards, a youth movement formed to speed a cultural revolution.

Communist China's power to influence events in other nations is rapidly becoming a major theme of international discussion. President Johnson the other day referred to the threat of a series of Chineseinspired "wars of liberation" as a major justification for the American effort in Vietnam.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 4 The marriage of Miss Ellen N. Slippen, daughter of Mrs. Irving Slippen of Hempstead and the late Mr. Slippen, to Kenneth Howard Christie of Beacon, N.Y., took place this afternoon in the Huntington Town House. Mr. Christie is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Christie of Brooklyn.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Sept. 4 Russell Plitt, in the Thistle Class, and Ed Perry, in the Lightning Class, completed three-race sweeps today as the Northport Yacht Club's annual Labor Day weekend regatta for Tri-Club Yacht Racing Association boats ended.
BONN, Sept. 4 (UPI) Willy Brandt, Social Democratic party leader, called today for the resignation of Defense Minister Kai-Uwe von Hassel.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UPI) The Commissioner of Education, Harold Howe 2d, predicted today that school integration would double this year.
MINEOLA, Sept. 4 School districts in Nassau County are preparing for another year of record enrollments and operating budgets and higher supporting taxes.
More than 60,000 racegoers are expected to watch a field headed by Tom Rolfe and Bold Bidder run today in the 54th edition of the $100,000 Aqueduct Stakes.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the U.S. has elected Frank H. Briggs as vice president in charge of buildings and administrative services. He succeeds John H. Muller, a senior vice president who is retiring after 30 years with the company.
Miss Loveleen Bhatia, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Baldev Bhatia of New Delhi, was married here yesterday to Eric Posmentier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Posmentier of New York.

FREE, easy and amiable are the proper adjectives for the columns Brooks Atkinson wrote for The Times as Critic- at-Large between 1960 and his retirement from the paper a year ago. Nearly a hundred are collected here, and they cover all manner of subjects in fact, anything that caught Mr. Atkinson's appreciative eye or...

HARTFORD, Sept. 4 Miss Karen Colleen Paullin was married this afternoon to Second Lieut. Philip Sinclair Will, U.S.A.F., in a Quaker Meeting for Worship on the lawn of Hartford College for Women. The overseers were Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Wolf and Mr. and Mrs. George Ritter.

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 4 About 300 Mexican-American farm workers shouting "huelga," the Spanish word for labor strike, trudged into Austin late this afternoon ending a 400-mile march from the Rio Grande Valley to the Texas capital. The march was held to dramatize a demand for a minimum wage of $1.25 an hour.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 4 According to the Morris County Superintendent of Schools, Leslie V. Rear, a shortage of classrooms is causing the most concern for the 39 municipal school districts and three regional high school districts.
SAIGON, Sept. 4 American soldiers killed 59 of the enemy in two actions yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 Miss Janet Falik and Dr. Bernard Ralph Aserkoff were married today at the BellevueStratford Hotel. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Max E. Falik of Melrose Park, Pa., and Mr. and Mrs. Louis Aserkoff of Silver Spring, Md. Rabbi Aaron Landes and Rabbi Mortimer J. Cohen officiated.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 4 Despite a steady decline in population in Hudson County since the end of World War II part of the great exodus to the suburbs school enrollments have been increasing steadily. This is because the child population has been rising among the residents who remain, particularly among Negroes, Puerto Ricans and Cuban refugees.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 4 (AP) Willie Horton's lead-off homer against Sam McDowell in the 12th inning gave the Detroit Tigers a 4-3 victory over the Cleveland Indians today and ran their winning streak to five games.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 4--The United States Agency for International Development mission in Vietnam is conducting a study that may lead to a system of priorities among the 277 distinct activities involving American aid here.
LONDON, Sept.4 A long-lost painting by the 17th-century Flemish artist Peter Paul Rubens has been found in a consignment of 40 pictures sent to Christie's, the London auction house.

Warren Hollister McCredy, a lawyer associated with Boyd, Holbrook Alford, 420 Lexington Avenue, died of a heart attack yesterday in Sherburne, N.Y., at the home of a brother, Robert. He was 43 years old and lived at 201 East 79th Street.

Maritime unions are getting an increasing number of complaints from seamen about the emergency sealift vessels on which they are serving in the Southeast Asia operation, and the most frequent protests involve failure to get personal mail.

MENASHA, Wis., Sept. 4 (UPI) Lynda Bird Johnson, elder daughter of President Johnson, went for a choppy three-hour cruise on Lake Winnebago today with Michael Phenner, a social aide at the White House.

FORT LEE, N.J., Sept. 4--A policeman was killed in a barrage of bullets early today as he tried to capture two men who had just held up the Riviera Motel here on Route 4 near the George Washington Bridge.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Sept. 4 Miss Michelle Fay Rappaport and Leonard Irwin Goldstein were married this afternoon in the Congregation Sons of Israel by Rabbi Paul Siegal. Miss Rappaport is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney P. Rappaport.
The City Markets Commissioner said yesterday that he would seek legislation to regulate milk prices in the state in an attempt to reduce prices.

ARDMORE, Pa., Sept. 4 Although the Merion Golf Club's famed "quarry hole" cost him a 7, Gary Cowan of Kitchener, Ont., defeated Deane Beman of Bethesda, Md., by one stroke today for the United States amateur golf title.
The 12 spectators at Orchard Beach Lagoon yesterday saw only the exciting finish of the most unusual race staged during the 75th annual Middle States rowing regatta.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 4 Passaic County is emerging in the 1966-67 school year as a county of contrasts, with burgeoning enrollments in fastgrowing communities like Wayne and tapering demands in more stable communities like Clifton.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Sept. 3 Some angry farmers here in Cumberland County are keeping Federal Vista volunteers off their land and out of their migrant labor camps, accusing them of "stirring up" Negroes and helping labor unions organize the farm workers.

GALWAY, Ireland, Sept. 4 (Reuters) Capt. John Ridgway, 27, and Sgt. Charles Blyth, 26, who spent three months rowing the Atlantic, were given a heroes' welcome when they arrived here tonight from Kilronan, in the Aran Islands.
Rain forced the cancellation of play yesterday in the United States grass-court championships at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.
MEADVILLE, Pa., Sept. 4 The University of Pittsburgh's varsity football program fails to qualify for Federal assistance under the antipoverty program or as a disaster area.

The second annual International Inventors and New Products Exhibition, which will open at the New York Coliseum next Friday, promises everything from "ablution boots," in which the wearer can treat his feet while walking, to a new system of transportation combining the family car and overhead rails.

The two teams that have monopolized the world club soccer championship for the last four years, Inter Milan of Italy and Santos of Brazil, meet today at 3 P.M. at Yankee Stadium. A crowd of 40,000 is expected.

WASHINGTON, Sept.4 (UPI) A. Philip Randolph, president of the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, said today that the problem of the American Negro had reached "crisis proportions" that black power cannot solve.
SEOUL, Korea South Korea, with a large reservoir of lowcost labor, is attracting American manufacturers to set up plants or enter joint ventures with Korean businessmen.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 4 Miss Susan Elaine Mitchell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Mitchell, was married this afternoon to Lewis J. Greenstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Greenstein of New York, formerly of New Rochelle.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept, 4 (AP) Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the Cambodian chief of state, said today that he was prepared to normalize relations with the United States if Washington recognized Cambodia's present frontiers.

GARY, Ind., Sept. 4 (AP) Officers of one of the largest locals in the United Steelworkers of America have been suspended, and an international union representative, Fred A. Gardner, of Harvey, Ill., has been sent in to take over.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 4 (AP) The Fraternal Order of Eagles, under indirect attack by a civil rights group for more than two weeks, was picketed here today by 200 persons, most of them white.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 3 (AP) Ore receipts at iron and steel plants in the United States and Canada totaled 15,969,820 gross tons in July, compared with 17,313,019 tons in the 1965 month, the American Iron Ore Association reported today.
NEWARK, Del., Sept. 4 The big football news on the University of Delaware campus is that Dave Nelson is sitting on the sidelines while a new head coach hopes to follow in some giant-sized footsteps.
SAN DIEGO, Sept. 4 (UPI) The San Diego Chargers parlayed the arm of John Hadl and a stout defense into a 27-7 victory over the Buffalo Bills today in an American Football League opener.
James Farmer, the former national director of the Congress of Racial Equality, ruled himself out yesterday as a candidate for Lieutenant Governor on the Liberal Party ticket.

FREDERICK, Md., Sept. 4 (AP) Lieut. Col. Oliver Patrick Arquilla, 39 years old, of Dayton, Ohio, was killed today while conducting a routine maintenance test flight of his race plane after the semi-finals of the Washington National Air Races being held at the Frederick Airport.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 Robert V. Roosa, former Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, has privately urged the Government to curb drastically in the next few months its sales of securities of Federal agencies, including the so-called "asset sales."

PAUL TRENT and Carol Krupp, a young New York partnership that has had several successes in the last year, won the two-session open pair championship Saturday at the Greater New York Bridge Association's Knickerbocker championship.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 4 President Tito demanded a "top-to-bottom" reorganization of his ruling Communist party in a speech made public today.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept 4 (AP) Pakistan has warned the Indian Government against moves to erode the special status of Kashmir as a disputed territory, the Government announced today.
MIAMI, Sept. 4 The recently reorganized Cuban Confederation of Labor has stepped up a drive to introduce a competitive system in which groups of farm, workers vie with one another in productivity.

"WHAT have we got left in New York ?" Nelson Still, of George M. Still, Inc. ("Oysters-Clams Wholesale"), surveyed the bustle and clutter of trucks at the Fulton Fish Market in the narrow, crowded area below his second-floor office at 228 Front Street.
WHEELING, W. Va., Sept. 4 (AP) Paul Duda ran 31 yards for a touchdown in an overtime period tonight to give the Norfolk Neptunes a 16-10 Continental Football League victory over the Wheeling Ironmen.
DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 4 (AP) About 600 National Guard troops will stay on duty here until at least 6 P.M. Tuesday, well beyond a visit tomorrow by President Johnson.
WARSAW, Sept. 4 (AP) The newspaper Kurier Polski conducted a poll among its readers to pick the 10 most worthy Poles in the country's history.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 4 "We are caught up pretty well with building programs, and now we are concentrating more on staff and instruction," said Dr. Bernard L. Bryan, School Superintendent of Westchester's southern supervisory district.
ATLANTA, Sept. 4 (AP) The majority of Atlanta's striking firemen continued to risk their jobs today by not reporting to work, in defiance of a court order and union leaders.
Many words of praise or disparagement might be spoken of Buffy Sainte-Marie, the folksinger and songwriter who appeared Saturday night at Music Festival. "Dull" is not one of them.
YONKERS, Sept. 4 A 20year-old Army deserter, Robert Fitzpatrick of Yonkers, is being sought as a "prime suspect" in the killing of his older brother, John, according to the Yonkers police.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Sept. 4 The Cabinet approved an agreement today under which the Columbia Broadcasting System will act as adviser in establishing a general television service for Israel.
The Transit Authority announced a record high operating budget yesterday that could force a new fare increase next year.
Bobbie Brooks, Inc., a Cleveland apparel manufacturer, announced yesterday the election of Jack Ranen and Phillip L. Groedel as vice presidents.
The University of Pennsylvania, which came under faculty criticism last winter because of its involvement in research dealing with chemical and biological warfare, announced...

The galloping growth of downtown Manhattan much of it already evident and much, much more in the construction or blueprint stage is matched by the growing inadequacy of the subway service in that area.

HACKENSACK, N.J. Sept. 4 New ideas, new teaching techniques and new problems with mini-skirts and Beatle haircuts mark the educational scene here as the county's 163,000 public school students prepare to return to the classroom.

NEWARK, Sept. 4 A continuing concern for developing the capabilities and broadening the educational horizons of handicapped, deprived or maladjusted children is a key element of planning among Essex County's public schools, which open Wednesday and Thursday.
The United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce announced over the weekend that it would assume the responsibility of issuing carnets to American commercial travelers in Europe.
SEPARATES, a style of dressing that was born at the turn of the century and flourished during the Depression, has been given a new lease on life by Seventh Avenue manufacturers.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 3 Emperor Haile Selassie is moving this ancient empire into the modern age but at a pace he hopes will be gradual enough to accommodate those who have the furthest to go.

MOSCOW, Sept. 4 Why has the Kremlin decided to answer back against China's attacks, forgoing the policy of turning the other cheek that dominated the thinking of the Soviet leadership during its first 22 months after the fall from power of Nikita S. Khrushchev? That such a decision to shift tactics...

DANANG, Soutr Vietnam, Sept. 4 (AP) For five days, nearly 1,000 United States marines who were scheduled to go to Okinawa, either enroute to the United States or for rest and recreation, have been packing into the marine transient camp here waiting for planes. And for five days all flights to Okinawa have been canceled because Typhoon Aliee and a sister tropical storm have been crashinf against the island.
EL PASO, Sept. 4 (AP) A 26-year-old El Paso man, Leopoldo Morales Jr., was charged with murder today in connection with the early morning deaths of four El Paso residents.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 4 The Common Market's Executive Commission, following up or recent court victories in the untitrust field, has just issued new draft regulations that will pertain to thousands of companies.

BOSTON, Sept. 4 Miss Carol Ann Rogers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Freeman P. Rogers of Plainville, was married here this afternoon to Jules J. Siegel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Siegel of Hewlett, L.I. The ceremony was performed in the chapel of Temple Israel by Rabbi Harvey J. Fields.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 4 Miss Rochelle Jolie Tinkleman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Abraham H. Tinkleman, was married this afternoon to Dr. Irving S. Kolin. He is the son of Mrs. Leo Kolin of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Kolin.
PEKING, Sept. 4 (Reuters) The Red Guards have closed the capital's cemetery for foreigners and renamed it "anti-imperialist anti-revisionist orchard."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. John Wesley Dennis of Warrenton, Va., an illustrator of children's books on horses, died Saturday at a hospital at Falmouth, Mass., where he had a summer home. He had been ill about six months. He was 63 years old.

District Attorney Aaron E. Koota of Brooklyn said yesterday that there had been a 40 per cent increase in the last two months in the number of suspects who refused to make statements to Brooklyn authorities in criminal cases.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 4 (UPI) The Kansas City Athletics combined an 11-hit attack with a triple play and three double plays to beat the Boston Red Sox, 7-2, after the Red Sox had taken the opener of a doubleheader, 3-0.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) Two liberal Republican Senators put public pressure on the Senate minority leader, Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois, today to drop his opposition to the open-housing section of the civil rights bill of 1966.
LADENTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 4 Ch. Barberry Knowe Bingo, a 4-year-old male Scottish terrier, was selected as best in show today at the Rockland County Kennel Club show, which drew 850 dogs.
CICERO, Ill., Sept. 4--A two-hour march for open housing in this all-white suburb of Chicago ended today in violence. At least 12 persons were hurt during the march,...
Rain threw a wet blanket yesterday on the last holiday weekend of the summer, but mostly sunny with a high in the eighties was predicted for today, Labor Day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) Attorney General Edward W. Brooke of Massachusetts said today that Republicans had lost elections "because we have been rejecting Democratic solutions without giving alternative Solutions."
SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 4 MiSS Toni Lisa Hahn, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Walter Hahn, was married today to Steven Roger Schlesinger, son of Prof. and Mrs. Rudolf B. Schlesinger of Ithaca, N.Y.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 4 H.S. Hall's Magic Dragon sailed off with honors in the Seawanhaka Corinthian. Yacht Club's annual 43-nautical-mile overnight race to Stratford Shoals and return today.
ARDMORE, Pa., Sept. 4 "What's going to be, is going to be," Gary Richard Cowan said today, "and 7's on a golf course don't necessarily mean you will lose."

NEW CITY, N.Y., Sept. 4--Space is the annual problem in the Rockland County school system, where enrollments have increased 9 per cent in the last year, school budgets more than 19 per cent and the population nearly 19 per cent since 1963.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 4 Paul and William Corey's Stark Ravin led a fleet of eight Ravens across the finish line today as 89 boats sailed in the second of three Labor Day weekend Cow Bay regattas, conducted by the Port Washington Yacht Club.

AFTER Birdie Tebbetts had turned in his portfolio as Cleveland manager a fortnight ago, he bundled his family into the car and headed for his home in Florida. The car broke down five times. When they finally straggled to their destination, they discovered that the home airconditioning system was out of whack. That's the kind of year it has been for the usually effervescent Mr. Tebbetts.

The National Council on the Arts has made an allocation of $10,000 to be given to the dramatist whose play is chosen for production by the American Playwrights Theater, an association of university, college and community playhouses.

A crude bomb exploded early yesterday morning at Communist party headquarters on West 26th Street. It wrecked a basement room, damaged the offices of the party newspaper, The Worker, ripped out the fronts of other buildings and shattered some of the 110-year-old stained glass windows of a cathedral across the street.

ATLANTA, Sept. 4 (AP) Don Schwall and Jay Ritchie combined to pitch a six-hitter today as the Atlanta Braves beat the Houston Astros, 2-0, for their fifth straight victory. The Astros' losing streak was extended to eight games.

TRENTON, Sept. 4 New Jersey school systems, historically dependent on sky-high local property taxes and the vagaries of school budget referendums, begin a new school year buoyed by the proceeds of the state's now sales tax.
A Trotskyite group endorsed a Brooklyn Communist for Congress yesterday despite its ideological, differences with the Communist party but each side remained wary about the other.

About 4 per cent of all the jobs in the country are vacant. This is the chief finding in the nation's first comprehensive survey of employers by the Manpower Research Council in cooperation with the American Society for Personnel Adminstration.
MADISON, Frid., Sept. 4 (AP) Tahoe Miss won the championship heat by more than one-half mile today and took the Governor's Cup race for unlimited hydroplanes for the third straight year.
BUDAPEST, Sept. 4 (AP) Michel Jazy of France outlasted Harald Norpoth of West Germany in the stretch today and won the European 5,000-meter run.

LONDON, Sept. 4 Prime Minister Wilson will fly to Blackpool tomorrow to confront a rebellious meting of about 1,000 representatives of Britain's 8,750,000 organized workers with the hard facts that brought about the country's wage freeze.
CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (UPI)--Two young men fired shotguns at a crowd on a corner tonight. The rain of pellets wounded eight young persons.

LONDON, Sept. 4 (UPI) Alan Hardaker, the secretary of the English Football League, turned down today a $30,800-a-year job offer to become secretary-manager of the proposed professional American National Soccer League.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 4 Jim Kaat reached a milestone with his 22d pitching triumph for the Minnesota Twins today, and the New York Yankees approached one by losing to him, 9-2.

VENICE, Italy, Sept. 4 "Au Hasard Balthazar," a film by Robert Bresson that was seen out of competition in Cannes and had a disappointing run in Paris, is now seeking honors at the festival here as an official French entry.

LOCH SHELDRAKE, N.Y., Sept. 2 A singular hush, betrayed only by the occasional romping of crickets or the stomping of a stray hen on the greensward, fell this Labor Day weekend on the rococo precincts of the New Roxy Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Sept. 5 (Reuters) South Vietnam's Foreign Minister, Dr. Iran Van Do, said today that he believed President de Gaulle's view of the Vietnam situation was blinded by antiAmericanism.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 4 That 150,000 people will pay their way into Dodger Stadium to watch the Los Angeles Dodgers play the San Francisco Giants tomorrow afternoon, Tuesday evening and Wednesday evening explains much about basic policy differences among major league baseball owners.
A picture showing a Negro officer and a white enlisted man talking on a ship was flashed on a screen, and white Californian college students were asked to provide captions.

Pat Boone will resume his television career as the star of a daytime musical variety show over the National Broadcasting Company network. It will be presented from 11 to 11:30 A.M., Mondays through Fridays, beginning Oct. 17. "The Pat Boone Show" will replace "Chain Letter," a game show with Jan Murray as host.
The Japanese Communist party has criticized both the Soviet Union and China for failing to provide more direct military and diplomatic aid to North Vietnam and the Vietcong rebels in South Vietnam.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4. (AP) The Right Rev. James A. Pike gave his last sermon today as rector of Grace Cathedral.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 4 T. Vincent Learson's Thunderbird of the American Yacht Club, a Class B sloop of the Cal 40 type of fiber-glass yacht, finished well up with the fastest of the larger Class A yachts as the 32d annual Vineyard Race of the Stamford Yacht Club ended today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 4 William E. John Jr. sailed Foxtrot to his third International Class victory of the season on Long Island Sound today during the Larchmont Yacht Club regatta, the 31st on the Yacht Racing Association championship schedule.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP) Charlie Lau's tie-breaking pinch triple in the eighth inning and five successive hits by Luis Aparicio led the Baltimore Orioles to an 8-5 triumph over the Chicago White Sox today.

BRANCHVILLE, N.J., Sept. 4 Brian Joyce of Dalton, Pa., won the Maclay Trophy and the American Horse Shows Association Medal Class, Hunter Seat, then finished as runnerup for the Hunter Seat Chamionship today in the Top O' Jersey Horse Show.
A world Protestant leader called on ecumenical and anti-ecumenical Christians yesterday to bury their theological hatchets and get on with uniting Christendom.

Organized labor arrives at Labor Day with the Johnson Administration's wage-price guideposts chopped into matchsticks but with no certainty that unions can push up workers' purchasing power faster than the rise in living costs. Labor's other big worry is that strikes in major industries and in essential municipal services will stir fresh clamor for anti-strike legislation of the type it successfully blocked in Congress during the airlines tie-up.

Temple Beth Elohim in Brooklyn was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Miss Christina Mae Bagley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Bagley of Fairbanks, Alaska, to Dr. James Richard Lehrich, son of Mrs. M. Zachary Lehrich of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Lehrich. Rabbi Eugene Sack performed the ceremony.

Two long-term leases for space in the Manhattan Industrial Center on the lower West Side, involving aggregate rentals of $1.1-million, have been concluded by the Franchard Corporation, owner of the center.

GARY, Ind., Sept. 4 (UPI)--Three jail-breakers from Canada, captured in a gun battle with Gary policemen last night, were transferred today to the Lake County jail in nearby Crown Point, Ind. The fourth fugitive remained in a Gary hospital with gunshot wounds.

2 GIRLS, 9 AND 7, RAPED AND KILLED A partly paralyzed 9-year-old girl was raped and thrown out of a window to her death and a 7-year-old girl was raped and slain in separate attacks reported by the police yesterday.
ROME, Sept. 4 Pope Paul VI expressed apprehension today over the decline "in the world of great, good ideas" such as peace, effective disarmament and moral health.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 The House Ways and Means Committee has tentatively agreed on the basic features of a bill to restrict Federal outlays for medical care of needy persons, members reported today.
PARIS, Sept. 4 France added to the common monetary reserves of the Western world last month, but the switch appears to have been temporary.
MIAMI, Sept. 4 (AP) The tropical storm called Greta, the seventh of the season, developed in the warm Atlantic today.
NOUMEA, New Caledonia, Sept. 4 (AP) President de Gaulle told cheering New Caledonians today that France was moving to the forefront of the world with the task of bringing balance to a divided globe.

The Federal Maritime Commission has obtained an order in the United States District Court here directing Zim Israel Navigation Company, Ltd., to show cause why it should not comply wtih a subpoena issued by the regulatory agency.

OTTAWA, Sept.(AP) Resistance by defiant railroad workers to a Parliamentary order to end their strike dwindled today, and Canada's two major lines expressed optimism that service would be near normal tomorrow.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 4 School expansion and integration will continue to pose major problems here during 1966-67.
WASHINGTON, Sept, 4 An Administration official said today that it was up to the North Vietnamese to make the first move in any general troop withdrawal from South Vietnam.

LAKE MOHAWK, N.J., Sept. 4 Herbert V. Hardman, founder in 1925 the H.V. Hardman Company in Belleville, manufacturers of rubber and synthetic resin adhesives, died today in his home on West Shore Trail. He was 85 years old and also had a home at Fort Lauderdale, Fla.
PAPEETE, Tahiti, Sept. 4 (AP) France hopes to detonate a thermonuclear device over the South Pacific this month, according to the director of her nuclear test program.

The City Human Rights Commission has decided to have a series of community meetings during the next two months to help the public "understand the background" of the civilian-controlled Police Review Board.

The Court of Appeals decision in favor of a referendum on the police review board injects an emotional and divisive issue into the coming political campaign. We had previously expressed our hope that the courts would decide that the appointment of the board was within the Mayor's administrative discretion and did not involve a change in the City Charter.

CAPETOWN, Sept, 4 (Reuters) A man who served in the South African Army as a white, played cricket for an all-white team and stayed at a whitesonly hotel appealed today against being classified as colored a person of mixed blood.

Appropriations for naval shipbuilding and conversion under the 1967 fiscal year program will probably total $1,756,700,000, the Shipbuilders Council of America reported yesterday in its weekly bulletin.

THE man who led 250 civil rights marchers through the embattled all-white Chicago suburb of Cicero yesterday is one of the new breed of leaders in the Negro movement militant, suspicious of structured organizations as opposed to popular movements, more interested in individual...
ALBANY, Sept. 4 One-third of the 53,400 hospital beds for long-term care in the state are in unsafe facilities, Dr. Hollis S. Ingraham, the State Health Commissioner, said today.
INDIANAPOLIS Sept. (AP) A New Jersey drag racer was killed today when his car crashed into a guardrail at the national championships at Raceway Park.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 4 Jonathan Ford's Encore II in the Lightning Class and Anthony G. Pavlis and H. Franklin Bloomer Jr.'s Flying Scot, Glaros, were the winners on Long Island Sound today in the 31st championship regatta of the East-of-Rye Yacht Racing Association season.
Cooperation between customs authorities here and the Commerce and Industry Association of New York has resulted in a change in handling procedures for certain imports.
STAMFORD, Conn., Sept 4 Technological innovation and increased state and Federal aid are the story in Fairfield County this year, as the suburban public schools struggle to maintain their excellence.
DENVER, Aug. 31 Colorado Republicans, sorely mauled two years ago, are hopeful of regaining two House seats while holding on to a Senate seat and the governorship this year.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 4 Among the education problems that confront Monmouth County is the continued debate over the building of a new middle school in Asbury Park, which would eliminate the aging Bond Street School in the downtown business area.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 31 A quiet revolution is taking place in the Caribbean. It shares none of the political upheaval of Cuba or the violence of the Dominican Republic. Yet the changes taking place in ways of living and thinking are profound.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 4 (AP) Juan Marichal gained his 21st victory and Willie McCovey drove in three runs with a homer and a double today as the San Francisco Giants beat the St. Louis Cards, 9-2. The victory ended a three-game losing streak for the Giants.

Miss Vivian Marie Bogen, daughter of Mrs. Jules I. Bogen of 29 Washington Square West and Croton, N.Y., and of the late Dr. Bogen, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Neil Gordon. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold W. Gordon of Woodbridge, Conn.
Suburban school systems will reopen this week and next with a new emphasis on the individual student how he learns and what he learns.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Sept. 5 (AP) In the heaviest fighting of the last 10 days, South Vietnamese troops clashed yesterday with 500 to 600 Vietcong in the Mekong delta and killed 276 of them while capturing 11 others, a Government spokesman reported.
PARIS, Sept. 4 (Reuters) Five men accused of kidnapping Mehdi Ben Barka, the Moroccan opposition leader, are to go on trial here tomorrow.

The wedding of Miss Linda Barth and Neil Janovic took place yesterday in the garden of the Hampshire House, with Rabbi Judah Cahn officiating. Miss Barth is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Barth of Oklahoma City. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Joseph Janovic of New York and the Late Mr. Janovic.

NOROTON, Conn., Sept. 5--Miss Katherine Douglas McMillan, daughter of Donald Cameron McMillan and the late Mrs. McMillan, was married today to Duncan Gregory Burke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gregory Thomas Burke. The Rev. Michael F. Blanchard performed the ceremony at St. John's Roman Catholic Church.
Eliahu Ben-Horin, a writer on Middle Eastern affairs and a Zionist leader, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital at the age of 64. He lived at 639 West End Avenue.

AN INTIMATE film study of the totally demoralizing effect of narcotics addiction on a young married couple was presented last night on WPIX under the title "Storm Signal." The James Lipscomb production took first prize in the documentary category at the 1966 Venice Film Festival.
The anesthetic halothane, once linked to liver damage, has been found to be as safe and perhaps safer than other general anesthetics.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 5 (AP) Sonny Siebert pitched a sixhitter as the Cleveland Indians snapped a five-game losing streak today by beating the Boston Red Sox, 3-1, in the second game of a double-header. The Red Sox won the opener, 5-1.
MIAMI, Sept. 5 (UPI) The tropical storm called Greta weakened in intensity today, foiling for the second time this season the plans of weather scientists who want to tame a fullblown twister.
DETROIT, Sept. 5 (AP) Auto assembly lines will move into high gear tomorrow as the time draws near for the introduction of 1967 models to the public.
SEASIDE, Ore., Sept. 5 (AP) This coastal resort town, scene of youth rioting on Labor Day weekends of recent years, was generally calm today as the police held a tight rein.

Miss Cecilia Meyers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Meyers of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Leonard Sacharow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Sacharow of Dublin. The ceremony at the Jewish Center, 131 West 86th Street, was performed by Rabbi Samuel Walkin, uncle of the bridegroom.

BUDAPEST, Sept. 5 (Reuters) Track and field competitors in future Olympic Games and European championships will be subject to spot checks for drugging, the Congress of the International Amateur Athletic Federation decided today. Athletes will be chosen at random, as in this year's World Cup soccer competition in England.

DARLINGTON, S.C., Sept. 5 (AP) Darel Dieringer, who has been racing for 20 years, won the 17th Southern 500-mile stock car race today after Richard Petty, who had been in the lead, brushed a guard rail with only eight laps to go.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 5 (AP) The Atlanta Braves rode out a four-run ninth inning rally by the Pittsburgh Pirates today and won the second game of a double-header, 7-5, for a split with the league leaders.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 5 Howling crowds of teen-agers and college students battled policemen on this resort's Boardwalk and side streets for two hours early this morning.
WICHITA, Kan., Sept. 5 (AP)--A Russian-born man has been admitted to citizenship without swearing to bear arms for the United States if called upon, a Federal District judge said today.

THE Rebekah Harkness Dance Festival entered its final few days at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park last night. It runs through tomorrow. The engagement, produced by William Ritman and Bernard Gersten for the New York Shakespeare Festival, has seen some vividly varied dancing.

YONKERS, Sept. 5 Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas M. Washienko of 55 Nimitz Road celebrated their 70th wedding anniversary today with a family gathering and congratulatory messages from President Johnson and Governor Rockefeller.
ANOTHER Broadway season is op'nin' on Sept. 22 when Edward Albee's "A Delicate Balance" arrives at the Martin Beck.
BRUSSELS, Sept. 5 Belgium announced today the end of a general freeze of wholesale prices. The freeze began May 9 for "a minimum" of three months.

Mr. Henry was first president of the Community Service Society of New York. He was active in its formation in 1939 through a merger of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, which he had headed since 1934, and the Charity Organization Society.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 5 (AP) The police charged a 27-yearold man tonight with helping his 15-year-old girl friend escape from the Camden County Juvenile Shelter at the point of a shotgun. The escape took place at 4 a.m. today.

MADRID, Sept. 5--Any individual who has been intoxicated four times in a calendar year "has an alcohol problem," a leading United States specialist on alcoholism told the fourth World Psychiatry Congress in a paper here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 Head teeming with questions, Q. popped into Harry's Bar Grill, spotted A. in the back booth and sat down without invitation. "I have a question," said Q. "So do I," said A. "To wit, why is it that you always get to ask the questions while the dirty work of answering them is always dumped on me?"

SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio, Sept. 5 Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Hale Ham have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lola Josephine Ham, to James MacDonald Minifie Jr. of Cambridge, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Minifie of Washington. A November wedding in Boston is planned.

Representative Herbert Tenzer, New York Democrat, disclosed last night that he had urged President Johnson to call a peace conference on Vietnam and invite the North Vietnamese and the Vietcong to take part.

KINGS POINT, L.I., Sept. 5 Miss Carol A. Diedricks, daughter of Comdr. Louis F. Diedricks of the Merchant Marine Academy and Mrs. Diedricks, was married at noon today to Ens. William M. Shubert Jr., U.S.N., son of Dr. and Mrs. Shubert of Bangor, Me.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 5 Richard C. Kettles Jr., a paper company executive and former breeder of champion dogs, died yesterday at the home of friends in Mill Neck. He was 75 years old and lived on I.U. Willets Road here.
Hebrew day schools in the metropolitan area will open tomorrow with an expected enrollment of 47,100 students, 2,300 more than last year.
PARIS, Sept. 5 In a sweltering Paris courtroom, a strange trial began today, filled with overtones of the dim, dark, conspiratorial side of life.
ROME, Sept. 5 (Reuters) Emilio Cecchi, Italian essayist and literary historian, one of the main Italian interpreters of American literature, died here today of a heart attack. He was 82 years old.

Peking's intensive campaign to eradicate bourgeois vestiges has taken some curious turns. Consider, for instance, the pedicab a sort of tricycle pedaled by a driver with a seat behind him for the passenger.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 5 Shedding an injured starting pitcher again the way a superior fullback sheds tacklers en route to a touchdown, the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the San Francisco Giants this evening, 4-1, and improved their position in the National League race.
BUENOS AIRES, Tuesday, Sept. 6 (UPI) Mrs. Silvia Martorell de Illia, wife of former Argentine President Arturo U. Illia, died at a hospital here early Tuesday. She was 48 year's old.

The newly named City Center Joffrey Ballet makes its bow tonight as the New York City Center's resident ballet company. The opening program of a three week season that runs through Sept. 25 is Gerald Arpino's "Viva Vivaldi!" "Sea Shadow" and "Olympics," and Anna Sokolow's "Opus 65."

PARIS, Sept. 5 (UPI) Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today that United States forces would be built up to whatever strength was necessary to meet the Communist threat to Vietnam, even at the risk of war with Communist China.

KINSHASA, the Congo, Sept. 5 (Reuters) Gen. Joseph D. Mobutu, President of the Congi, told Congolese deputies and senators today he was restoring some of their powers suspended since he took over the Government of the Congo in November.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Sept. 5 Mrs. Charlotte Boettger Ryan has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Charlotte Boettger Ryan, to William Gary Waterstradt, son of Mrs. William Waterstradt of Ogden, Utah, and the late Mr. Waterstradt.
WALTON HEATH, England, Sept. 5 (UPI) Clive Clark, a 21-year-old Englishman who turned pro eight months ago, shot a 64 today and took the first-round lead in the News of the World tournament.
HOPEWELL, Va., Sept. 5 (AP) Senator Harry F. Byrd Jr. charged today that Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach had, in effect, condoned the recent racial rioting in Cleveland.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 5 Baltimore's pitchers still couldn't finish a game, Luis Aparicio had a 17-game hitting streak snapped and Boog Powell sat in the dugout with a fractured finger.

The Equitable Trust Company of Baltimore is subsidizing the drama for the first time with seven free outdoor performances of Moliere's farce, "The Miser," beginning tonight. A professional company will perform in four neighborhoods at a cost estimated at $20,000.

BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 5 Prime Minister Wilson warned the Trades Union Congress today that if organized labor did not make the Government's wage freeze work, Britain might face up to 2 million unemployed in a world of economic chaos like that of the nineteen-thirties.
PUERTO ASSIS, Colombia--A new threshold for penetration of the Amazon basin is being opened here by American oil developers who fly drilling rigs over the jungle in helicopters.

NORTHFIELD, Ill., Sept. 5 Mrs. Roy W. Booth has an nounced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Donna Claire Booth, to Jeswald W. Salacuse, son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Salacuse of Niagara Falls, N.Y. A fall wedding is planned.
HICKSVILLE, L.I., Sept. 5 An anonymous phone call to the police today led to the discovery of a home-made bomb attached to an automobile owned by a Nassau County District Court judge.
New York State Superintendent of Banks Frank Wille has sharply criticized some recent bank advertising as "deceptive and misleading."

Perhaps in these days of "creative" advertising, it is no longer news when a company says in its ads that its products are not the best in the world. But the new campaign for Renault automobiles is going one step further by candidly stating that the French concern's past models were not exactly "parfait."

COLORADO SPRINGS, Sept. 5 (AP) Harry Bridges, president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, charged today that a fellow labor leader, James R. Hoffa, was being railroaded to jail.
George W. Lacks, a retired girdle manufacturer, died in Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals yesterday. He was 60 years old and had homes at Premium Point in New Rochelle N.Y., and at Palm Beach, Fla.
SCARBOROUGH, England, Sept. 5 (Reuters) Runs were scored fast today in the second day of the three-day match between the West Indies and T.N. Pearce's eleven at the Scarborough Cricket Festival.

SHINNECOCK HILLS, L.I., Sept. 5 At the Shinnecock reservation today, it was a time for tourists to buy trinkets imported from the West and to visit the Indians on the rare occasion when they wear feathers and deerskin and use names like Red Fox and War Hawk.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Sept. 6 (AP) Douglas Ramsey, a 28-year-old American aid official who was kidnapped by the Vietcong in an ambush Jan. 17, is still alive, according to reports reaching the Catholic refugee village of Bacha, which he assisted.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 5 University College in Salisbury, a multiracial institution, began a new term today.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 5 Prof. and Mrs. Bernard F. Huppe of Binghamton and Castine, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne McMaster Huppe, to Gup B. Gorelik, son of Mr. and Mrs. Josef Gorelik of New York, of New Milford, Conn., and of Gnayaquil, Ecuador.

Chinese Nationalist faculty members in Taiwan and Chinese organizations in this country sponsored a full-page advertisement in today's New York Times asking Americans not to help Communist China "widen its participation in international affairs."
The appointment of Charles G. Bolte as vice president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace was announced yesterday.

L. Vincent Foscato, retired president of V. Foscato, Inc., manufacturers and installers of mosaic and terrazzo, died yesterday at the Manhasset (L.I.) Medical Center. He was 79 years old and lived at 42-23 208th Street, Bayside, Queens.

William Henry Sullivan, a Brooklyn-born Irish-American who was manager of Mama Leone's Restaurant on West 48th Street for 19 years until Gene Leone sold it in 1959, died yesterday in Valley Hospital at Ridgewood, N.J. He lived at the Whitby Hotel on West 45th Street.
DETROIT, Sept. 5 The first campaign confrontation between possible political rivals of 1968 was longer than President Johnson had planned but shorter than Gov. George Romney had hoped.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 5 Three weeks before the opening of Rutgers University's football season, many polls already have written off the Scarlet as a loser.
EMPLOYES at the Hebrew National Kosher Food plant in Maspeth, Queens, worked yesterday to fill an order for half a ton of pastrami--destined for Hong Kong.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 5--Several ominous cracks appeared lately in the walls of Pepe's Bar, which boasts "the most flat-chested waitress in the French Quarter."

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 5 (AP) Smoky Burgess, a pinch-hitter, and Tommy Agee stroked run-producing singles in a four-run seventh-inning today that gave the Chicago White Sox a 7-4 triumph over the Minnesota, Twins.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation has furnished "a few names they dug out" to city detectives investigating the bombing of the Communist party's building on 26th Street early Sunday, a detective said yesterday. He said he did not know whether the names were those of persons who had made threats against the party.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) The voting records of many Congressmen, including the Kennedy brothers and freshmen Democratic House members, have become more conservative this year, Americans for Constitutional Action said tonight.

MR. AND MRS. WILLIAM PASSELL of Hartsdale, N.Y., won the Master Pair championship Sunday in the Greater New York Bridge Association's Knickerbocker tournament. The winners of the Novice game were Mr. and Mrs. J.P. Benkard of New York.

PARIS, Sept. 5 (Reuters) Three French concerns said today they would take part in the study and manufacture of satellites for the world telecommunications network scheduled to go into operation in 1968.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 5 (AP)--The Syrian Government and the internationally owned Iraq Petroleum Company have announced plans to start negotiations here Saturday on Syria's demand for doubled transit royalties.

EAST NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 5 Mr. and Mrs. John Hanford Woodward of East Norwalk and Hamburg Cove have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Bishop Woodward, to Midshipman Wesley Robert Brandt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick E. Brandt of Honolulu.
YELLOWKNIFE, Northwest Territories Thanks to a a frontier breed of editors, the newspapers in the Canadian Northwest enjoy a freedom of the press unlike that of more staid parts of the world.
The new-issue calendar is light this week, with only one large corporate debt offering scheduled for bidding along with a couple of municipal issues.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 5 (AP)--Gov. George C. Wallace put the national Democratic and Republican parties on notice today that they could look for him to campaign for President again in 1968 "unless they can give us someone we can vote for."
THE mysterious Orient most of it price-tagged and ready to be delivered or carried away takes over the world's largest store tomorrow.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 5 Mr. and Mrs. Richard William Howell have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Howell, to Peter Murray Kendrick. He is the son of Mrs. Wallace D. Kendrick of Boothbay Harbor, Me., and the late Mr. Kendrick.

GRADY, Ark., Sept. 5 (AP) The state police used tear gas and fired shots into the air to break up a disturbance among striking convicts at the Cummins Prison Farm today, an aide to Gov. Orval E. Faubus said.

WINNETKA, Ill., Sept. 5 Miss Lucinda Kingery, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Charles Kingery, plans to be married in late December to Benjamin Franklin Lenhardt Jr., son of Colonel Lenhardt, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Lenhardt of Greenville, S.C. The engagement has been announced by the future bride's parents.
CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP) Touloure won the $56,900 Benjamin F. Lindheimer Handicap today over 1 miles on the grass at Arlington Park.
The London Stock market was firm yesterday in quiet dealings. Because of the light activity on the market some advances were out of proportion to the actual business done.
The pilot of a four-passenger light plane was killed yesterday when it stalled on take-off and crashed at Flushing Airport.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 5 (Ap) South Vietnamese Buddhists asked President Johnson today to pray for Thich Tri Quang, the militant monk who has been fasting for 90 days in protest against the Saigon government and United States policy in Vietnam.

The deputy manpower administrator in the United States Labor Department was appointed yesterday to be the city's Commissioner of Manpower and Career Development. In naming the official, Samuel Ganz, Mayor Lindsay praised him as "probably the single most qualified person in the nation to administer this program."

An experimental version of a Neighborhood City Hall in five rooms of the Brownsville District Health Center in Brooklyn will give sponsors and critics of the controversial program a better idea of its worth. Mayor Lindsay campaigned for his office arguing that government be brought closer to the people.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 5 Bishop John J. Wright of the Pittsburgh Roman Catholic Diocese called today upon organized labor in Pennsylvania to join with organized religion in a united "conscience crusade" for Social justice and civil rights for Negroes.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 5 (AP) A Negro woman said today in Municipal Court that she did not want the Congress of Racial Equality to demonstrate in behalf of her 18-year-old son, who has been accused of assaulting a white policeman.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 The Senate will begin at noon tomorrow what could be a long and bitter fight over the Administration's civil rights bill.
TOKYO, Sept. 5 (Reuters) The world's biggest ship, the 209,000 ton tanker Idemitsu Maru, was launched in a construction dock 35 miles south of Tokyo today, seven months after work started.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Sept. 5 Miss Jeanne Medalie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Hamilton Medalie, was married this afternoon to Richard J. Temkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Temkin of Boston, at the Medalie home by Rabbi Lawrence W. Schwartz.

YONKERS, Sept. 5 As the distance of a harness race lengthens, the importance of a horse's post position, while still of some significance, lessens. That's why the drawing of No. 7 slot this morning for Noble Victory in Thursday night's $100,000 Hilltop Trot at Yonkers Raceway brought no tears to Stanley Dancer's eyes.
HAYNEVILLE, Ala., Sept. 5 (AP) Schools opened in Lowndes County today with white pupils observing a total boycott of Hayneville High School.
PURCHASE, N.Y., Sept. 5 Herb Pennell scored four goals today to lead Blind Brook to a 6-4 victory over New Haven at Blind Brook Polo Club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) Senator Thruston B. Morton assailed the Senate Democratic leadership today for "embarrassing" President Johnson by proposing a reduction in the United States troop commitment to Europe.
DALLAS, Sept. 5 (AP) Frank W. Wozencraft, the youngest mayor in Dallas's history, and a former Washington lawyer, died Saturday in Baylor University Hospital. He was 74 years old.

The box office of the New York State Theater opens today for the sale of tickets to all performances of the New York City Opera's seven-week fall season.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 5 There is mounting suspense here oven whether Nigeria will remain one powerful nation or splinter into four tribally based autonomous provinces.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Sept. 5 Alex Bell, starting his seventh season as Villanova's head football coach, was in a jolly mood today. He offered to trade some halfbacks and wondered whether the "q" in quarterback really stood for "question mark."
ADEN, Sept. 5 (Reuters) The Aden radio said tonight that Maj. Gen. Hassan alAmri, Premier of Yemen, had been put under house arrest in Sana.

An agreement to transfer the management of nine Liberianflag vessels owned by the Anglo Norse Shipping Company of Great Britain to Dutch management has been reached between Anglo Norse and the Naess Shipping Company.

Five major sports events thoroughbred racing, harness racing, soccer, tennis and baseball attracted 162,505 spectators in New York yesterday. The biggest crowd was the 64,738 at Aqueduct in Queens that saw Tom Rolfe win the $114,300 Aqueduct Handicap.

SUBURBAN bird watchers who happen to see a yel low bluejay these days have not found a new species. The bird wasn't hatched yellow, and it wasn't hatched very bright in the thinking department either.

Richard Rodgers will write the music and lyrics for a 90minute television musical based on "Androcles and the Lion," the George Bernard Shaw play about Christian martyrs who are thrown to the Roman lions. NOUMEA, New Caledonia, Sept. 5 President de Gaulle occupied himself today, the third day of his visit to this French South Seas territory, with the problems, the leaders and the people of Noumea.

DETROIT, Sept. 5 (UPI) Homers by Norm Cash, Al Kaline and Mickey Stanley led the Detroit Tigers to a 7-4 victory over Washington in the second game of a double-header tonight. Frank Howard was the batting star as the Senators won the opener, 6-4.
KIEL, Germany, Sept. 5 (AP)--A Danish-Swedish combination of Paul Elvstroem and John Albrechtson scored an upset victory today in the opening race of the world Star class championships.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 Only a few states are taking full advantage of funds allocated to them under the 1965 Federal Aid to Education Act. Eleven states have used less than 80 per cent of their allotted sum.
