Although tripped, mauled and kneed, Pele led Santos of Brazil to a 4-1 rout of Inter of Milan yesterday before the largest turnout for a soccer match in the United States in 40 years.
The owner of an East Side restaurant was kidnapped and robbed of $4,000 early yesterday by two bandits who intercepted him at his home after he had closed his establishment, according to the police.
An enjoyable concert version of Rossini's "The Italian Girl in Algiers" was presented on the Mall in Central Park last night for the fourth and final Naumburg concert of the 1966 summer season.

The increasing involvement of United States companies in export and overseas operations has led to an upgrading of the international executive and is pushing him rapidly into the upper echelons of many businesses, according to a twoyear study of the National Industrial Conference Board.
The city is trying to head off emergencies in its governmental departments by continuously reviewing their operations rather than waiting for crises to arise.

LONDON, Sept. 5 There are 225,000 white people in Rhode sia, about the population of Staten Island. For 10 month this group has stood off the British Governments's effort to get it to submit, and there is no sign of surrender. That is the humiliating fact facing Britain in the 16th conference of Com ...

Negotiators for the Newspaper Guild, the only one of the 10 newspaper unions that has not reached a contract settlement with The World Journal Tribune, will meet today with officials of the new corporation in an effort to achieve agreement.
SOUTHINGTON, Conn., Sept. 5 Like a cannonball, a rounded, 10-pound rock plummeted from an overpass and crashed through the windshield of a car early today, killing the driver.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UPI) George Meany, A.F.L. C.I.O. president, said today that concern over the United States economy was the result of a "profit inflation" and was not caused by wage increases won by organized labor.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 5--Next to the Cal 40 Thunderbird, the sloop with which T. Vincent Learson of the American Yacht Club gained the main honors, Mrs. Elizabeth M. White's 73-foot yawl Bolero was the chief recipient of silverware in the Stamford Yacht Club's Vineyard race that was wrapped up today.

A wide-ranging telephone canvass seeking to block the prospective Democratic nomination of Council President Frank D. O'Connor for Governor was attempted over the last few days, but it appeared last night to have faded.
A Brooklyn real estate broker surrendered to the police yesterday on a charge of shooting a fellow-member of Alcoholics Anonymous outside an A.A. meeting hall.

METUCHEN, N.J., Sept. 5 Ch. Fezziwig Raggedy Andy, the sensational Old English sheepdog owned by Serana and Hendrik Van Rensselaer of Basking Ridge, N.J., took his 15th best in show award and 67th working group tonight at the New Brunswick Kennel Club's third dog show and obedience trial in Roosevelt Park.

BONN, Sept. 5 A small but dedicated group of West Germans is trying to convince Federal and state authorities to reinstitute the distinctive German script, known as Fraktur, for official use in schools.
Seventeen new schools and three school additions have been cleared for occupancy for the opening of school next Monday, the Board of Education announced yesterday.

NO professional wrestler who has the slightest respect for his intelligence will ever watch a wrestling match. He knows that it's a barney with the outcome pre-arranged and he wouldn't be found dead as a spectator. But on one wintry night in 1933 a troupe of matmen dreadfully short-changed the customers at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn. In their haste they saw to it that every bout ended in nothing flat.
MOSCOW, Sept. 5 Reuters) The Soviet Government newspaper, Izvestia, accused an Israeli diplomat today of spreading "dirty Zionist propaganda."
More people were killed on the nation's highways this weekend than on any other Larbor Day weekend.
The New York Mets labored mightily on Labor Day yesterday and produced two results characteristic of their past labors: an attendance record and a double defeat.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) Msgr. Frederick G. Hochwalt, for years a spokesman on education policies for Roman Catholic bishops in the United States, died today aboard a ship on the way to Italy. He was 57 years old.
Controller Mario A. Procaccino renewed yesterday his request that $84.3-million in the city's budget originally earmarked for the Transit Authority be given to that agency.

Two things were evident from the outset of Britain's effort to end the illegal seizure of independence by leaders of Rhodesia's white minority. First, imposition of sanctions was simply the least uninviting among the policy choices available. Second, if sanctions could bring Ian Smith's regime to heel at all, this could be achieved only over a very long period.
MOSCOW, Sept. 5 (AP)--The Soviet Union said today that United States involvement in Vietnam was a major cause of U Thant's decision not to seek another term as United Nations Secretary General.
Francis I. duPont Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced over the weekend the admission of Alfred R. duPont Jr. as a partner.
ATLANTA, Sept. 5 (AP) Some 267 of Atlanta's 500 striking firemen have been suspended from their jobs, Fire Chief C.H. Hildebrand announced today.

The board of directors of Joshua L. Baily Co., Inc., has elected Alonzo F. Bonsal president. Mr. Bonsal, who joined the textile selling agency more than 50 years ago, had been executive vice president, a position that will be filled by his son, Richard I. Bonsal.

DOES the olive in a martini break the Lenten fast, or is it considered part of the drink? Such is the kind of not so-classic question raised by John Bellairs in this collection of ecclesiastical satire whose publication date must surely rate as a "Feast of the First Class with Octave" on the liturgical calendar.
A 29-year-old woman was stabbed several times early yesterday while waiting for a taxi at Park Avenue South and 17th Street.
United Air Lines, the nation's largest air carrier, announced yesterday that it had placed options to buy six British-andFrench-built Concordes and six American-built supersonic airliners.
Willis Reed and Emmette Bryant, plus 10 rookies, not including Cazzie Russell, will check in today to begin preparations for the New York Knickerbockers' 2lst National Basketball Association season.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 6-- Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Goertzel have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Marie Goertzel, to Peter Sandman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard E. Sandman.

ENDICOTT, N.Y.--In 1946 Wes Harvey and Alex Alexander, two ex-G.I.'s, borrowed $10,000 from a local bank and opened a mens' wear store here in their home town. Last year, their sales totaled about $300,000.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6--Civil rights leaders, municipal officials and real estate men failed to agree today on the composition of a "watchdog" committee to oversee the enforcement of Chicago's new open-occupancy housing accord.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 6 (UPI)--The California Angels scored four runs in the first inning tonight, then relied or the strong relief pitching of Clyde Wright and Bob Lee for a 4-3 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6--A Hudson River conservation bill --termed "absolutely worthless" by one Congressman--was approved today by the House of Representatives. The Senate will begin hearings tomorrow on companion legislation.
Wes Westrum was given a pat on the back and a cash bonus yesterday for his "outstanding job" in managing the New York Mets in 1966 and a $45,000 contract to repeat the performance in 1967.
DALLAS, Sept. 6 (UPI)-- The president of America's largest Negro religious denomination said today that recent civil rights activity had set the cause of equality back 50 years.
CAIRO, Sept. 8 (AP)--The state Supreme Security Court announced today sentences ranging from life imprisonment to a year in jail for 116 members of the banned Muslim Brotherhood organization.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) --The House passed a bill today that would channel the future income-tax returns into seven regional automatic data-processing centers--instead of 58 Internal Revenue Service offices.
Ernest Gallashaw, the youth indicted for the murder of an 11-year-old boy on a night of racial rioting in East New York, won the right to freedom in $15,000 bail yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court.
MOSCOW, Sept. 6 (UPI)-- The Soviet Union announced today that it had completed a series of booster rocket tests down a range in the Pacific Ocean six weeks ahead of schedule.
The new Metropolitan Opera House, which has been unveiling its beauties piecemeal, yesterday put on view a Wilhelm Lehmbruck sculpture.

Another traffic jam was in the making yesterday. Consolidated Edison announced it had started excavation for a 30-inch steam transmission line to run between 57th Street and Ninth Avenue and 56th Street and Seventh Avenue. The project, to serve the growing business demands of the area, is scheduled for completion by the end of the year.
The Securities and Exchange Commission apparently is investigating the possibility of market manipulation in the stock of the Westec Corporation.
The spot rate on the British pound declined 4 points, to $2.7871, in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday.
TOKYO, Sept. 6 (AP)--The population growth in Communist China is definitely out of hand and must be arrested, a prominent population expert said today.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 6--Ray Sadecki, the left-hander for whom the San Francisco Giants gave Orlando Cepeda to the St. Louis Cardinals early this season, produced his first outstanding performance as a Giant tonight, defeating the Los Angeles Dodgers, 6-0.
A moderate selloff in the last half-hour of trading depressed most issues on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as volume slumped to its lowest level in more than a year.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 108.9 on Friday from 108.6 on Thursday.
NEW CITY, N.Y., Sept. 6-- Rockland County will vote on a county charter and a reapportionment proposition in the November general election under resolutions passed today by the county board.
TRENTON, Sept. 6 (AP)-- Democrats may have made a mistake in ejecting two "peace candidates" from a recent party rally, Gov. Richard J. Hughes said today.
The election of James L. Bauchat as a director of the American Tobacco Company was announced yesterday by Robert B. Walker, president and chairman.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 6 (AP)--The blue and white United Nations flag will not be flown at half-staff for Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd, a United Nations spokesman said today.
PERSIAN ROOM, Plaza Hotel, Fifth Avenue and 59th Street. Jane Morgan, singer.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I. Sept. 6--The engagement of Miss. Lee Ann Bernstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Bernstein, to Stuart B. Bauer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Bauer of Brooklyn, has been made known by the parents of the prospective bride.

Office building construction in Boston, which had lagged far behind that of other major cities in the postwar years, has been accelerated to produce 3.5 million square feet of new space since 1963 with 4.5 million square feet scheduled for completion in the next five years.

Dr. Hendrik Frensch Verwoerd, who was assassinated yesterday, was the prime champion of apartheid, literally apartness, the South African system of strict segregation condemned by most of the governments of the world but hailed by racists.
A combination of dry air southwest breezes and a burst of ragweed pollinization drove the pollen count to a record high for the date yesterday, according to Long Island Jewish Hospital.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I. Sept. 6--Westchester's team of golf professionals gained a fivestroke lead today as the intersectional matches with Long Island and New Jersey began at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club.
Mrs. Samuel E. Kramer of 420 East 64th Street has made known the engagement of her daughter, Miss. Jean Alice Kramer, to Martin Marshall Ossad, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alex Ossad of Metuchen, N.J.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 6 --President Humberto Castelo Branco has relieved an army general of his command and halted a conflict between reformist Roman Catholic bishops and anti-Communist military officers.
NAHA, Okinawa, Sept. 6-- Typhoon Cora left 2,363 people homeless today on the island of Miyako after battering the southern Ryukyu Islands for 30 hours with 200-mile-an-hour winds.
The first new waterfront workers in the current reopening of the Waterfront Commission's longshore register should be showing up on the docks in about two weeks, the bistate agency said yesterday.
Mayor Lindsay signed a million dollar contract with the Legal Aid Society yesterday to provide lawyers for every needy defendant in the city.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 6 (AP)--Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested an Army deserter today, who was wanted in Yonkers on a charge of murder.

Mrs. Moses took her husband's defeat at the hands of Gov. Herbert H. Lehman in stride. She said later that the campaign had been fun and she consoled herself with the thought that "no one ever lost so gracefully."
KINSHASA, the Congo, Sept. 6 (Reuters)--A Belgian priest and two Congolese assistants have been kidnapped by rebels in the northeastern Congo, the Catholic Press Agency reported here today.
A strike by United Parcel Service men in Manhattan spread yesterday to a point where all deliveries in the city and in Nassau, Suffolk and Putnam Counties will be stopped today.
MINOA, N.Y., Sept. 6 (AP) --A 17-year-old youth, who had been arrested on a traffic charge during a routine holiday check, was charged with firstdegree murder today in the shooting of his parents.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6-- An attempt to work out a compromise version of legislation aimed at stopping the "rate war" between banks and savings and loans will be made in the House later this week.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6--The House leadership, in step with the maneuvers of Representative Adam Clayton Powell, put off action today on the $1.75billion antipoverty authorization bill until Sept. 26.

UNITY HOUSE, Pa., Sept. 6 --The International Ladies Garment Workers Union voted today to provide $25-million in mortgage money for workers' housing in Puerto Rico that the Rockefeller-backed International Basic Economy Corporation will build.
The head of a chemical company was arrested yesterday on a charge of perpetrating a fraud on the Navy that delayed a number of ships bound for Vietnam.
The first substantially new Renault in three years was introduced yesterday by Renault, Inc., United States affiliate of the parent French manufacturer.
Prices retreated over a broad front on the London Stock Exchange yesterday under the impact of economic uncertainties and the assassination of Premier Hendrik F. Verwoerd of South Africa.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 6-- Leaders of the Baath party in neighboring Syria announced today that they had destroyed a conspiracy aimed at overthrowing their six-month-old Government.

THE new Repco 8-cylinder, 3-liter engine that has brought Jack Brabham of Australia to a clinching of his third world driver championship will be seen in action in the United States Grand Prix for Formula One cars at Watkins Glen, N.Y., on Sunday, Oct. 2.
The architectural firm of Morris Ketchum Jr. Associates has named William J. DeVito an associate.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 6 (UPI) --A national civil rights leader told a state inquiry into this area's tense racial situation today that the term "black power" was nothing to become alarmed about.

The World Journal Tribune reached a contract settlement last night with the Newspaper Guild of New York, the last of 10 unions with which it needed agreements to begin publication of an afternoon and a Sunday paper.
TUCSON, Ariz., Sept, 6-- Margaret Sanger, the birth control pioneer, died this afternoon of arteriosclerosis in the Valley House Convalescent Center. She would have been 83 years old on Sept. 14.

THE new network television season crept in quietly last night, and the still of the evening could be heard from coast to coast. In its anxiety to be first on the boards the American Broadcasting Company offered four premieres-- three situation comedies and a preview of a children's cartoon series. The early bird is not always to be envied.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6--The State Department, responding to Congressional criticism, announced today the appointment of former Ambassador James W. Wine as special assistant to the Secretary of State for refugee and migration affairs.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 6--The Rhodesian Parliament adjourned two hours early as a mark of respect to Dr. Verwoerd.
SAIGON, Wednesday, Sept. 7 (Reuters)--Vietcong terrorists carried out two grenade attacks last night in an intensification of their campagin to sabotage the election, the police reported today.
ATLANTA, Sept, 6--Rioting Negroes fought the police with bricks and bottles today and toppled the city's Mayor from the roof of a car when he attempted to calm them.
J. Stewart Baker, former president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died Monday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital after a short illness. He was 73 years old.
RIDGEFIELD, Conn.--A blue flag impressively em bossed with gold braid rippled triumphantly in the breeze, announcing that "Cornelius Ryan is home."
The appointments of Thomas J. Carter and David A. Crowell as vice presidents were announced here yesterday by the Chase Manhattan Bank, National Association.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 6 (AP) --Joe Torre's three-run homer in the eighth inning lifted the Atlanta Braves to a 4-1 victory over the National Leagueleading Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.

In a new Broadway trend, young general managers are pooling their forces to become producers and at the same time continuing their duties with shows by other managements. The latest such producing team to emerge is Joseph Harris and Ira Bernstein.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 6-- Black Africans seemed confused tonight by the assassination of Prime Minister Hendrick F. Verwoerd of South Africa. It was as if they were not sorry it happened but were worried lest events rush in on them and make a bad situation worse.
SEBRING, Fla., Sept. 6 (AP) --The Automobile Racing Club of Florida announced today it would move its annual 12-hour International Grand Prix of Endurance sports-car race from Sebring to Palm Beach.

YONKERS, Sept. 6--The feature event at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night will be a Class A-3 one-mile pace for a gross purse of $4,500, half of which will go to the owner of the winner. A team of California researchers presented strong evidence here yesterday for the controversial view that personality characteristics are at least as important as biological ones in predisposing a man to heart disease.

The Gulf Sulphur Corporation and Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that they had agreed to call off their previously announced merger plan.
RENO, Sept. 6--Gov. Grant Sawyer was the victor tonight in Nevada's primary election. The Democrat was seeking a third four-year term.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) --The House voted today, 259 to 0, to create a 12-member national commission to recommend revisions in criminal laws to close gaps that permit accused persons to escape punishment.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 6 (AP)--An Iowa State University history professor won the Democratic nomination for Senator today, but a fellow faculty member in economics was having tough going for the Republican nomination for Governor.

The Allied Chemical Corporation, which last December officially opened the refurbished Times Tower as its headquarters showcase in Times Square, has obtained permission from the Post Office Department to change the address of the building.

Al Kelly, double-talking comedian, died early this morning after suffering a heart attack at the Friars Club. He was pronounced dead on arrival at Roosevelt Hospital.

Former Welfare Commissioner James R. Dumpson, who once attended Fordham University's School of Social Service as a part-time student, has been named head of the school.

A SENSE of history being made is, at the fleeting time, perhaps nothing more than a spark in the air--an electric awareness that something is happening. This spark was present last night at the New York City Center where the newly named City Center Joffrey Ballet (the former Robert Joffrey Ballet) opened its inaugural season as the City Center's resident ballet company.
BONN, Sept. 6--Chancellor Ludwig Erhard of West Germany said today that Defense Minister Kai-Uwe von Hassel would remain in office.
The Giants and Jets, New York's two major pro football teams, made personnel changes yesterday as they continued preparations for their opening league games this weekend.
RUMSON, N.J., Sept. 6-- Seven young women were presented tonight at the annual Rumson Debutante Ball in the Sea Bright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club. About 390 persons attended.

The extreme turbulence experienced in the nation's financial markets is giving the jitters to business forecasters as well as to investors. While many forecasters still predict that business activity will continue forging ahead under relatively clear skies, a sizable minority now feels that the economy itself will encounter much rougher weather.
The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday record sales and earnings for the three and nine months ended July 31.
Mrs. Constance Baker Motley will take the oath of office Friday as a United States District Court Judge, becoming the first Negro woman to occupy the Federal bench.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 6--The Philippine delegation said today that it had a plan for bringing Indonesia back into the United Nations.
A former assistant commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration has been named by the Foundation for Cooperative Housing as executive vice president of its subsidiary FCH Company.

CHOPPED nectarines contribute moistness and a fruity flavor to a mellow meat loaf. The baked loaf can be garnished with more nectarine slices, which have been dipped in lemon juice to prevent discoloration. Here is a recipe.

LONDON, Sept. 6--In the six years that separated his encounters with David Pratt and Dimitri Stifianos, Hendrik F. Verwoerd became more than an exponent of the system of racial separation and police power known as apartheid. He became its prophet.

MOSCOW, Sept. 6 (Reuters) --A Soviet correspondent in Peking reported today that girl Red Guards there complained of disorderly conduct by the thousands of Chinese Communist youths flooding in from the country.

THE Open Team Championship, which ended the Knickerbocker championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association Monday, resulted in a victory for Dr. Norman Buch, Dr. Morris Halper, Paul Baer, Allen Spielholz and Sheldon Marks, all of New York.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP)-- Observance of the three-day Labor Day weekend cost the nation a record toll of 636 lives in traffic accidents.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6--The development of an American supersonic airliner entered a critical phase today as the aircraft industry submitted its final designs to the Government.

THE timing of the move gave it the extra impact it needed. The New York Mets had just lost four in a row and they had just been mathematically eliminated from the pennant race. So the Met front office yesterday signed Wes Westrum for another year as manager, a contract renewal he definitely had earned and richly deserved.

Msgr. Francis J. Oechsler, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Andrew Avellino in Flushing, Queens, and former chancellor of the Diocese of Brooklyn, died of a heart attack yesterday in Miami. The 78-year-old prelate was on a brief vacation when he was stricken.
BUFFALO, Sept. 6--New York State's Democrats will open their two-day convention here tomorrow with almost all indicators pointing to a firstballot nomination of Frank D. O'Connor for Governor.
ATLANTA, Sept. 6 (AP)-- City officials said today they planned to hire more than 400 men to replace Atlanta's striking firemen.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP)--A new battle flared today between organized labor and the National Right to Work Committee, which demanded a Federal investigation of union political activities.

MIAMI, Sept. 6 (AP)--A tropical disturbance--which at one time had the potential to become a hurricane-all but died out tonight.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 6 (AP) --Max Alvis and Chico Salmon drove in two runs apiece and Gary Bell pitched a three-hitter tonight to lead the Cleveland Indians to a 6-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

TWO-THIRDS of the way through the evening of early one-act plays by Thornton. Wilder that opened at the Cherry Lane last night, one is still waiting to be moved, to be tickled, to be reached as one has been reached by Wilder in the past. And it happens. "The Happy Journey to Trenton and Camden" is worth the wait.

The president of the Board of Education and the Superintendent of Schools went to East Harlem yesterday in a personal effort to get local parents to drop plans for a boycott of the new Intermediate School 201.

An 18th-century ballroom-- the perfect room for ladies and gentlemen, silks, satins and brocades--has been recreated in the new wing of Gracie Mansion, the 168-year-old official residence of the Mayor of New York.

Eastern Air Lines, Inc., estimates that its net loss in August was "roughly comparable" with July's $4.9-million deficit, Todd G. Cole, senior vice president for finance and administration, said yesterday.

FARGO, N.D., Sept. 6 (AP) --A Bismarck investments man, Thomas S. JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Sept. 6 (AP)--Dr. Abraham Rubashoff, a brother of President Zalman Shazar, died today after a heart attack. He was 74 years old.

Back in 1939 two young nuclear physicists, Leo Szilard and V.S. Weisskopf, created a sensation among their university colleagues by suggesting the imposition of voluntary secrecy on the then new findings about nuclear fission. Accustomed to publishing everything freely, many of those approached were shocked by the idea and some refused. Szilard and Weisskopf, of course, had already foreseen the possibility of the atomic bomb.

For the second time in six weeks a capsule of radium has been lost in cross-country railway shipment. New York City, Chicago and Seattle were described as the most likely centers of radioactive contamination if the capsule is ruptured.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 8 Cornelius Shields Jr. sailed one trouble-free race and another in which he had to overcome difficulties brought about by a poor opening leg today to restore the Manhasset Bay Challenge Cup to the Larchmont Yacht Club.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8 (UPI) Gordon P. Getty, 32year-old son of J. Paul Getty, oil magnate and one of the world's richest men, filed a "friendly" suit today against his father and three brothers, seeking $7-million of an estate worth nearly $300-million.

MAE SALONG, Thailand, Sept. 4 Four hundred of Gen. Tuan Shi Wen's Chinese Nationalist exile troops left their austere bamboo and thatch barracks today, lined up for inspection and then began to file past their headquarters staff on their way to Burma.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 8 South Vietnam's ruling military junta has concluded that the Vietcong cannot "seriously" disrupt Sunday's national elections, according to an authoritative report.
GENEVA, Sept. 8 (Reuters) Twenty-six sick Vietnamese children, most of them suffering from polio or heart disease, arrived by air tnday from Saigon for treatment in Swiss and Italian hospitals.

Transeastern Associates, Inc., which operates a 515,000-ton, fleet of bulk carriers, was absorbed yesterday by Seatrain Lines, Inc., its former subsidiary, which has a fleet only 15 per cent as large.

Mayor Lindsay has taken the only possible course in firmly backing up Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery's new policy of shifting firemen and firefighting equipment to the areas where they are most needed, despite shrieks of outrage from the firemen's unions. This is a command decision; the city cannot bargain about the flexibility of the Fire Department.

IF the world and all its homes suddenly went mod ern, it would be like an atomic explosion, said Joe Cesare Colombo, the Milanese architect and furniture designer who would Iilce to be the man to push the button.

Pan American-Grace Airways will begin the only DC-8F jet freighter service between North and South America on Sunday when it places a new Douglas Jet Trader on the route, the company announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 President Johnson said today that he was encouraged by Communist China's apparent shift toward the view that it did not face a military confrontation with the United States.
Financial records "affecting races and other matters" at the Roosevelt, Yonkers and Monticello harness tracks have been subpoenaed, District Attorney Aaron E. Koota of Brooklyn said yesterday.

The Federal Trade Commission was reported yesterday to have reached agreement with Spartans Industries, Inc., and E.J. Korvette, Inc., under which both discount chains would divest themselves of a "significent" number of 'their stores in the same trading areas so that their proposed merger may be permitted to take place.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 "There is latitude enough in the Constitution to embrace within its four corners these advances," said Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen as he explained his decision to support the landmark Civil Rights Act of 1964.

Traders in wheat futures had the Soviet wheat crop very much in mind yesterday. From Moscow came a report by Tass, the official press agency, that the current year's grain harvest was not only bountiful but might exceed the 130 million-ton average of the last five years.
LONDON, Sept. 8 Development costs for the BritishFrench supersonic airliner Concorde will amount to 500-million ($1.4-billion) before it is ready for service, probably in 1973.
WALLOPS ISLAND, Va., Sept. 8 (UPI) An attempt to light up the sky tonight with a multicolored chemical cloud was delayed by a natural cloud formation.
Tight money is a key factor in the "sweeping shakeout" now in process in car rental and leasing, industry leaders asserted yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 If a man can be known by the cliches he inspires, then Burma's ruler, General Ne Win, is authoritarian and puritanioal and a zealous Socialist.
The city's water supply dropped by 1.6 billion gallons in the 24 hours ended at 8 A.M. yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 8 (AP) Warren W. Wilentz, the choice of Democratic leaders for the United State Senate, won a pre-election victory today. A judge upheld his use of the designation "Regular Democratic Organization" in next week's primacy contest.

Johnson Johnson is sponsoring a sweepstakes contest in which 10 grand prizes of family vacations in Europe will be awarded. A coming ad campaign will show photographs of 10 families enjoying a portion of that vacation in the Roman Coliseum.

TRENTON, Sept. 8 New Jersey antipoverty officials made public today a housing and welfare program for migrant Negro farm workers that would get them out of squalid camps and into new, cooperative community centers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 President Johnson greeted Burma's chief of state, General Ne Win, today with words of praise for his country's jealously guarded neutrality.

PARIS, Sept. 8 A French policeman accused of having helped to kidnap the Moroccan Opposition leader Mehdi Ben Barka testified today that he had participated in the kidnapping because he believed that a top aide of President de Gaulle was in on the plot.
Joseph Vincent Terenzio, a 48-year-old lawyer and hospital administrator, was sworn in yesterday as the first Hospitals Commissioner in the city's history who was not a physician.
SAO PAULO. Brazil, Dept. 8 A university strike was called today in Sao Paulo State after the political police thwarted an assembly of the state's student leaders by arresting 178 participants.
MADRID, Sept. 8 A secret group of Roman Catholic priests and laymen who call themselves Action Moses and seek to force an open split it the Spanish church is causing concern to the hierarchy here.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Sept. 8 The International Union of Electrical Workers rallied its organizational strength and financial support for a mayor collective bargaining battle with the Westinghouse Corporation and the General Electric Comnany.
The nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday declined by 1.3 million barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
A decision on the future of satellite television has been delayed until some time next year, at the earliest.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 8-Milika Sundic, the Belgrade radio correspondent in Moscow, reported Monday night that Premier Pham Van Dong of North Vietnam had asked the Soviet leadership during a recent visit to Moscow to help seek a peaceful solution to the Vietnam conflict.

Marc Chagall, a small pixie inhabiting a forest of microphones, spotlights, movie cameras, still cameras, reporters, technicians, gate-crashers and Rudolf Bing (who was everywhere at once), had a wonderful time about noon yes
The spot rate on the British pound was again firmer in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here.
Dr. Abbott Kaplan, a leading educator in the performing arts, was named yesterday as president of the new Westchester college of the State University of New York.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) The United States contributed $l.5-million yesterday to a new Inter-American Development Bank fund to spur Latin America's economic integration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 The Senate finally mustered enough members today to begin debate on the civil rights bill of 1966. A Southern filibuster, postponed twice by parliamentary procedures, then began in earnest.

I have conferred with the leadership during the last few days, and as recently as the hour. I am sending to the Congress this afternoon a message on fiscal policy. That message is or will be available to you.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 8 Listening to Ben Schwartzwalder cry poverty over the lack of defensive tackles and a good defensive right end at Syracuse University makes one think of J.P. Morgan complaining about a lack of funds.

YONKERS, Sept. 8 As Stanley Dancer eased Noble Victory toward the paddock, following their easiest of victories in the $100,000 Hilltop Trot, the unmistakable sounds of raucous boos were heard at Yonkers Raceway tonight. Why?

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 It was a warm, relaxed evening at the White House last night. The host arid hostess were in high spirits, delighted to be honoring five Americans who had distinguished themselves at the 1966 Tchaikovsky International Competition in Moscow. The guests

The New York Central Railroad plans to enter the highway-trailer manufacturing field through the acquisition of the Strick Corporation. Central's directors approved yes- terday an agreement in principle to acquire all the capital stock and warrants of Strick for a maximum price of $31-million.

The Consolidation Coal Com pany said yesterday its first and principal liquidating dividend would be $48.30 a share in cash plus the distribution of shares held by Consolidation in seven other companies.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 Charles L. Ornstein, one of the leading figures in the amateur sports movement in the United States for more than 40 years, died of pneumonia this morning at Doctors Hospital here. He had been admitted to the hospital on Tuesday after receiving injuries in an automobile accident last Sunday. Mr. Ornstein was 72 years old.

OTTAWA, Sept. 8 Medical supplies partly financed by United States residents will be shipped tomorrow by a Canadian Quaker group to the North Vietnamese Government, the South Vietnamese Government and to the National Liberation Front, the political parent group of the Vietcong.
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 8 Francis W. Bronson, editor of the Yale Alumni Magazine from 1937 until his retirement in June, died today at the YaleNew Haven Hospital. He was 65 years old.

POMONA, Calif., Sept. 8 (AP) Gill Robb Wilson, a pioneer aviator, an organizer of the Civil Air Patrol and a writer on aviation, died of a bone disease today at a hospital here. He would have been 73 years old on Sept. 18.
CAIRO, Sept. 8 (Reuters) The Supreme State Security Court today sentenced the general secretary of the outlawed Egyptian Communist party, Mustafa Agha. to life imprisonment at hard labor.

DETROIT, Sept. 8 (AP) Auto production this week reached its highest point thus far in the 1967 model run as an estimated 112,247 cars were built. This compared with last week's 86,661 and the 54,021 built in the comparable week a year ago.
CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP) The American Federation of Teachers announced today the establishment of a civil rights department headed by a 45year-old Negro teacher.
The top weight of 164 pounds gave little trouble to Mrs. Ogden Phipps's The Sport in the $16,700 Broad Hollow Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. The 8year-old son of Ambiorix car
The 299-seat Forum Theater in the basement of the Vivian Beaumont Theater will be utilized by the Lincoln Center Repertory Company for the first time starting in November.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 8 Four young women were honored this evening at a dance held in a pink marquee at Highlawn, home of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Adams here.
BOSTON, Sept. 8 (AP) A Boston lawyer disclosed today he headed a group that had bought President Kennedy's birthplace in Brookline.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 8 The third annual Debutante Ball of the Junior League of Greenwich was held in a pink and white striped marquee at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Bennett Fisher here tonight. The Fishers' twin daughters, the Misses Constance Allen Fisher and Susan Bliss Fisher, were among the 13 daughters of league members presented.
The battle between Staten Island and the bulldozer grew more determined Yesterday.
About 500 members of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters voted unanimously last night to authorize their executive board to call a strike at the 21 municipal hospitals here.
LONDON, Sept. 8--The Atlanta professional team announced here today that it had signed a British soccer star to manage the club it plans to enter in the new National Soccer League.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 8 (AP) Samuel H. Sheppard returned today to the courtroom where he was tried 12 years ago and shouted "not guilty" to a new charge in the old crime murder of his first wife, Marilyn.
The acquisition of the operating control of Best Co. by the McCrory Corporation and S. Klcin's Department Stores interests is expected in a matter of days.
ATLANTA, Sept. 8 Stokely Carmichael, chairman of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, was arrested and jailed here tonight in connection with the Negro riot Tuesday afternoon.
Stock prices closed with a slight decline on average yesterday after an afternoon raily wiped out most of an array of sharp losses registered earlier in the day.

AREA A The big boats are reporting good catches of hefty-sized codfish up to 50 pounds. The surf and jetties in Long Branch-Brielle area are hiding spots for stripers. "They're not being slaughtered," reports one boatman, "but they're big." Stripers range from five to 10 pounds.

The Friedberg Management will go out of business at the End of the 1966-67 season after 54 years of concert management. The announcement was made by Cesar Saecheringer, president of the organization since 1953.
CAPETOWN, Sept. 8 Dimitrio Tsafendas, the assassin of Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd, appeared briefly before a magistrate in a private office of the Caledon Square police station here today.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 8To the legends of Willie hays, a,dd the game he played at Dodgers' Stadium, Chavez Ravine, the night of V'ednesday. Sent. 7. 1966.

BLED, Yugoslavia, Sept. 8 (AP) Don Spero, former Diamond Sculls champion from New York, defeated Vyacheslav Ivanov of the Soviet Union, the three-time Olympic champion, today and reached the finals of the world rowing championships.

The two major party conventions have produced platforms which, like their choice of gubernatorial candidates, are hardly surprising. The most interesting deviation from the expected lies in the "peace plank" of the Democrats, who reflected the general public concern over the Vietnam war by offering a set of carefully worded recommendations to bring about an end to hostilities, concluding with a reaffirmation of "the free right of dissent."

Manuel Santana just barely escaped the cataclysm yesterday that had engulfed five of the top eight players earlier in the United States Amateur Championships at Forest Hills, Queens, in a hair-raising, threehour match that created a bedlam of excitement in Forest Hills Stadium.

TARZAN, an early swinger, returned to the entertainment scene last night without Jane but with a polished vocabulary, matching sidenurns and a recognition that civilization can hold some advantages over the jungle. The urbanization of the Edgar Rice Burroughs hero appears ominously total.

The inauguration of a new freighter service between Australia and the West Indies and United States Atlantic ports was announced yesterday by Chester, Blackburn Roder Inc., general agents for Reefer Express Line.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 8 Hundreds of university students fought with the police tonight in Cordoba, Argentina's third largest city, for the second consecutive day.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 Following is the text of President Johnson's message to Congress on the economy:

Julian T. Bishop, a retired New York stockbroker who said in 1936 that he would leave the country if President Franklin D. Roosevelt was re-elected, died Tuesday at his home in Southern fines, N.C. He was 76 years
The city's Commission on Human Rights has found an American Legion Post in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn guilty of discrimination and has ordered it to pay $100 in damages.

Mr. and Mrs. George Lair of Baie D'Urbe, Quebec, formerly of South Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Anne Lair, to John Arthur Golden of Phoenix, Ariz., son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Golden of Long Branch. N.J.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Sept. 8 Gemini 11 is ready to go into space tomorrow morning for a fast chase after a target satellite, a linkup during the first orbit and a climb to record altitudes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 "When I consider the prpblems this bill is trying to cope with," the chief tenant at the White House said today, "I am thankful that I work at home."
The American Stock Exchange declined for the fourth consecutive session yesterday in moderate trading.

Directors of Chris-Craft Industries, Inc., Oakland, Calif., and the Grow Chemical Corporation, New York, have reached agreement in principle for Chris-Craft to acquire Grow Chemical's business and substantially all of its assets.

TAYNINH, South Vietnam, Sept. 8 (AP) South Vietnam's Premier, Nguyen Cao Ky, said today he had accepted an invitation to speak at the convention of the Associated Press Managing Editors in San Diego, Calif., in November.
Senator Gale W. McGee, Democrat of Wyoming, said last night that the United States must win time in Southeast Asia so that "the winds of change may bring moderation to China."

MIAMI, Sept. 8 The New York Jets, with the best team in their young history, open their American Football League season tomorrow night. Mike Taliaferro will be at quarterback and Joe Namath probably will be a spectator.
Last night's free outdoor concert on the steps of City Hall was a well-meaning affair that misfired, largely because of adverse effects of poor sound epuipment and local noise.

Angry Negro parents marched out of a meeting with Board of Education officials yesterday and vowed to prevent the scheduled opening on Monday of a new East Harlem public school, Intermediate School 201. They also declared that they would later try to force the closing of every, "black school" in Harlem.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8 A new time-sharing computer system designed to spare secretaries much routine work in editing and typing documents was introduced and put to commercial use here today.

Mrs. Fred Smolen of Forest Hills, Queens, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Florence Jane Smolen, to Pvt, Robert Arnold Handler, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Handler of New York The couple plan a fall wedding.

The Allstate Insurance Companies and the Allstate Life Insurance Companies set new growth records in the first half of this year, Judson B. Branch chairman, and Arch R. Boe president, reported yesterday. The companies are subsidiaries of Sears, Roebuck Co.
A court order requiring the General Electric Company to negotiate a nationwide contract with a committee consisting of representatives of eight unions was thrown out yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept, 8 A leading civil rights advocate who has played a key role in the legal defense of Negroes in the South opposed today the spreading doctrine of civil disobedience among demonstrators against racial injustices.

The marriage of Mrs. Eileen Johnston de Coppet, widow of Andre de Coppet of New York and daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Johnston of Islip, L.L., to Karl Viktor Prince zu Wied of Munich, Germany, took place here yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church.

The Bendix Corporation of Detroit, producer of aviation, missile and aerospace products, announced yesterday the appointment of Dr. Winston E. Kock to the new post of vice president and chief scientist.

The Erie-Lackawanna Railroad brought suit in Federal District Court here yesterday seeking to prevent the Pennsylvania and the New York Central Railroads from effecting their merger. The target date for beginning operation of the Penn-Central has been Oct. 1.
A strike of United Parcel Service men entered its ninth day yesterday as opposing sides did not meet to negotiate a settlement of the dispute.

The New York Returnee Association of the American Field Service will give a dinner dance on Monday night aboard the Holland-America, liner Seven Seas, which will arrive in this country for the last time on Sept. 10. Afterward she will serve as a floating dormitory for the University of Rotterdam.

Business borrowings at New York banks declined $5-million in the week ended Wednesday from the level of the preceding week, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York

Manual portable typewriters have gone automatic. The SCM Corporation, one of the largest manufacturers of portables, introduced yesterday a new model with a space bar said to be fully automatic without using electricity.
CLEVELAND. Sept. 8 (AP) --The Cleveland Browns announced the signing today of Nick Pietrosante, who was put on waivers by the Detroit Lions.
DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 8 - Miss June Hermes and Jonathan Farmer Murphy have made plans to be married Oct. 22 in the Congregational Church in New Canaan.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 8 Governor Rockefeller and his campaign strategists offered somewhat different forecasts today of the type of campaign that he will wage against Frank D. O'Connor, the Democratic challenger.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 The American Trucking As sociation, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage for the week ended Sept. 3 was 5.4 per cent ahead of the corresponding week of last year.
Police diverted traffic around a Bronx intersection for four hours yesterday as a group of men and women blocked the roadway demanding installation of a traffic light.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 The Philadelphia Orchestra Association today offered its 105 musicians a $1,690 salary increase spread over five years, but a spokesman for local 77, of the American Federation of Musicians, termed the offer "woefully inadequate."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 The faculty of the University of Pennsylvania will receive a near-veto over future university contracts with the Government or private industry that limit the right to publish the results of research.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Sept. 8 Cassius Clay did a lazy lap around the Frankfurt horse track at dawn this morning and pronounced himself ready to pocket a few more dol lars in his blitz of foreign boxing rings this year.

Joseph F. Cullman 3d, president of Philip Morris, Inc., said yesterday the recent report by the Roswell Park Memorial institute on the influence of filters on the tar and nicotine content in cigarettes was "incomplete."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI) President Johnson appointed today John P. Roche, former national chairman of the Americans for Democratic Action, as a special consultant.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 8 (UPI) The Cleveland Plain Dealer, a morning paper, printed the Sheppard story today on page seven with the headline, "Sheppaid Case Just Routine, Says Judge."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) The Department of Agriculture raised slightly today its estimate of this year's Government-curtailed cotton crop to 10.992,000 bales.

JOHN PAUL MATHIEU, a smallish man with bright blue eyes, drove a red, twodecKer London bus from Gimbels to the Plaza Hotel Wednesday morning. It was Mr. Mathieu's first tangle with New York traffic, but with typical British stiff-upper-lipness, he said he wasn't at all nervous about it.
Jolm Stahr of Larchmont, who umpired the SantanaBowrey match received the Terry McGovern annual award for outstanding service in 1966.
Guido Errante, professor emeritus of Romance languages at City College, died of cancer Tuesday at his summer home in Milan, Italy. He was 73 years old and lived here at 1199 Park Avenue.
Gustave G. Rosenberg, the controversial chairman of the Board of Higher Education, has informed Mayor Lindsay of his intention to resign from the board by Sept. 26, it was learned yesterday.
PROVIDENCE, Sept. 6 The primary concern of football coaches opposing Brown University the last three seasons was, hopefully, to devise a defense that would halt Bob Hall's aerial circus.

CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., Sept. 8-The Reader's Digest Association invited 750 employes at its headquarters here today to designate charitable organizations to receive $500,000 in gifts from the magazine concern.

TUCSON, Ariz., Sept. 8 (AP) Mrs. Margaret Sanger was "a good, fighting saint" who experienced martyrdom, an Episcopal priest said at a memorial service here today for the birth control leader who died Tuesday at the age of 72.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 A 10 per cent sampling of the scores on the Selective Service's college qualification test showed today that 84 per cent of the undergraduates who took the test might be eligible for deferment. They did so by scoring 70 or better.

WASHINGTON, Sept, 8 President Johnson re-emphasized today that the question of withdrawing some United States troops from Europe would be "more wisely handled" by discussions within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization rather than in a Senate resolution, sust as has been offered by the majority leader, Mike Mansfield and a group of Senate Democrats.

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 8 A "highly malignant" brain tumor could have contributed to the murder rampage of Charles J. Whitman last Aug. 1, a panel of 32 physicians and psychologists said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 8 The United States, Britain and France are agreed that every effort must be made to induce U Thant to remain as Secretary General of the United Nations, diplomatic sources said today.

An artificially induced riot involving a few hundred susceptible Negroes shattered the calm of an Atlanta afternoon, and it may have shattered much more. There is no way of gauging fully its effect on a Southern community that had been deservedly considered a model in race relations.
CHICAGO Sept. 8 (UPI) Under Secretary of Labor John F. Henning told a national conference of union meat cutters today that "there is no place for compulsory arbitration in a free society."

The first two floors of the Excelsior, a 47-story apartment house now under construction at 303 East 57th Street at Second Avenue, have been leased 'for offices of the Norman 11'I. Morris Corporation in one of the largest commercial space transactions in a residential building in recent 5 ears.
SYDNEY, Australia., Sept. ! Dame Pattie, one of Australia's two America's Cup con tenders, was a sorry sight when she was christened today by Sir Robert Menzies at the Royal Sydney Yacht Squadron.
RECIFE, Brazil,. Sept. 8 (AP) Irvan Wolff, a 74-year-old sugar-refining expert from New York, was stabbed to death yesterday at a sugar mill south of here, it was reported today.
Michael L. Haider, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), was elected last night to a two-year term as chairman of the Radio Free Euroue Fund.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 8 A pair of talented horsewomen from the United States Equestrian team monopolized the dumping events at today's opening of the North Shore Horse Show.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Sept. 9--Dr. Ernest B. Forbes, director of the Institute of Animal Nutrition at Pennsylvania State University for 24 years until his retirement in 1946, died at his home here on Thursday. He was 89 years old.

MAE SALONG, Thailand, Sept. 5--A file of Chinese teenagers of both sexes, clad in slacks and shirts, slowly wound its way up the steep, muddy slope leading to this mountaintop stronghold of Gen. Tuan Shi Wen.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia Sept. 9--Authorities in Zadar released Mihajlo Mihajlov from jail today following confinement of a month and a day.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 9 --The latest crisis in troubled Syria appeared to be over tonight. A curfew, which had kept the city quiet throughout last night and all day, was lifted at 5 P.M.

WHAT ever became of sassafras tea? For that matter, where are arnica, camomile, mus- tard plasters, asafetida and sulphur and molasses? They have all vanished from the family medicine chest, along with most of the other tonics, restoratives, specifics and panaceas that were popular early is this century. Among the few home remedies of that era that have survived, only one is still prominent: aspirin. It is a drug that people today take for granted.

Miss Frances Saffell Parker of New York and Lexington, Ky., was married yesterday to Fred J. Antkies of New York by Judge Jack De Forest of the Connecticut Superior Court in his chambers in Stamford.

The court suit that the ErieLackawanna and Delaware Hudson railroads brought last week to upset the Oct. 1 merger of the Pennsylvania and New York Central railroads was expanded by four more railroads yesterday.
GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Sept. 12 (Reuters) All shipping in this capital of former British Guiana came to a standstill today when dockers stopped work after demanding the removal of a security guard.

LONDON, Sept. 12 Jan van der Joel, an assistant administrative attache in the consular office of South Africa House, was stabbed today by a man who jumped over a counter on the ground-floor of the embassy building, then escaped, into the crowds in Trafalgar Spuare.

The World Journal Tribune, Inc., published Vol. 1, No. 1 of its new daily newspaper yesterday. Despite a one-hour delay in getting the first papers off the presses, about 930,000 copies were printed and bundles of the paper sold out almost as fast as they were delivered at many points in the city.
Prices were advanced yesterday on a variety of products. Among them were guitars, thermoplastic pipe used for home construction and folding and rigid cartons.

George H. Schroder, a civic leader and president of the Mutual Drug Sundry Co., Inc., in the Bronx, drug-sundry distributors, died Sunday in St. Barnabas Hospital, the Bronx. He was 73 years old and lived at 4745 Grosvernor Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx.

The president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union threw a chill on the Liberal party campaign of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. for Governor yesterday with the comment, "I don't expect we'll spend any great amount of money for the governorship."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 Labor Secretary W. Willard Wirtz endorsed today a basic change in the Administration's anti-inflationary wage-price guideposts. The change would recognize a rise in the cost of living as a valid basis for onion wage increases.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 12 Mr. and Mrs. Paul Allen Norton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Ruth Norton, to Robert Lewis Padgette, son of Mr. and Mrs. Curtis Davenport Padgette of Atlanta. The wedding is planned for next summer.

GRENADA, Miss., Sept. 12 Four hundred white citizens of Grenada jammed the City Hall auditorium tonight to demand withdrawal of Mississippi state highway patrolmen who entered this Delta town in force today after a white mob had beaten up several Negro schoolchildren and three white newsmen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 "We don't need Senator Dirksen nearly as much as we need Hubert Humphrey," a supporter of the Administration's civil rights bill said today as the measure seemed headed for defeat.
LONDON, Sept. 12 In an effort to stem corruption, Britain is going to try to take the big profits out of gambling clubs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) The American Civil Liberties Union asked the Supreme Court today to set aside the jury tampering conviction of James R. Hoffa, teamsters' union president. The. A.C.L.U. said that Hoffa's constitutional rights had been violated by the Government in its efforts to convict him.

YONKERS, Sept. 12 Yonkers Raceway's practice of eliminating place and show betting from events in which one or more standout standardbreds are entered will be continued Thursday night with the $100,000 Lawrence B. Sheppard Pace for 2-year-olds.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 Following is the statement by President Johnson on vetoing a bill to increase life insurance coverage for Federal employes and members of Congress:

MONTREAL, Sept. 12 (AP) Canadian National, and Canadian Pacific railways announced tonight they planned to raise freight rates 10 per cent on traffic moving under the categories of competitive rates and agreed charges.
BONN, Sept. 13 (Reuters) Chancellor Ludwig Erhard was given a strong mandate by his party tonight to push his economic program into law.
Stock prices rallied strongly yesterday in the sharpest and broadest one-day advance in 14 months.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday proclaimed next Monday as San Gennaro Day in New York City in honor of the festival currently being observed in Little Italy for the patron saint of Naples.

TWO HUNDRED women, most of them beyond the age of active scouting, gathered at the Plaza Hotel yesterday for a good deed that combined fashion, food and that indefinable sense of wellbeing that comes from a worthy cause.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) Congressional sanction of the projected merger of the National and American Football Leagues was proposed today by Representative William C. Cramer, Republican of Florida.
A six-team amateur junior hockey league was formed in the metropolitan area yesterday by the New York Rangers with the hope that it will expand to a major four-city circuit next year.

A moratorium in its dispute with the A.B.C. Freight Forwarding Corporation over the use of street storage space near 27th Street and the Hudson River had been arranged by the Department of Marine and Aviation.
COACH ALLIE SHERMAN of the New York Giants went to the movies yesterday. What he saw didn't especially enchant him.
The New York Knickerbockers came to terms yesterday with their all-American Dream, Cazzie Russell, ending months of apprehension for their longsuffering fans.

DURHAM, N.H., Sept. 12 (UPI) J. Orlean Christian, who plans to retire as director of athletics, at the University of Connecticut, was named today to the newly created post of commissioner of the Yankee Conference.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 Mrs. Lyndon Johnson will go to the gala opening of the San Francisco Opera on Sept. 20, four days after attending the opening of the new Metropolitan Opera House at Lincoln Center in New York.
Negotiations to head off a musicians' strike that would prevent the scheduled opening of the new Metropolitan Opera House Friday night resumed yesterday.

Harlem's recently formed Black Panther party, an antiintegration group of articulate young militants, staged its first direct-action demonstration yesterday picketing a local school. Twelve of its members were promptly arrested. The charges included disorderly conduct.
An automated chemical laboratory designed to speed diagnosis of disease, tested in hospitals in Virginia and California, was put on display here yesterday.
A donnybrook is brewing in the colorful world of commercial art that could affect the future of that form of expression.

"Winds of Change," the first volume of Harold Macmillan's autobiography and history of his times, will come from Harper Row on Sept. 28. The book covers the period from Queen Victoria's Diamond Jubilee in 1897 to the outbreak of World War II. The former Prime Minister writes: "For most of ...
Russ Togs, Inc., apparel ansportswear manufacturer, announced here yesterday that it set records in sales and earnings in fiscal 1966 for the sixth consecutive year.
LONDON, Sept. 12 The already severe restrictions on press reporting of criminal cases in Britain will be further tightened by virtually ruling out reports of preliminary hearings.

Lee M. Limbert a limited partner in the New York investment banking firm of Dean Witter Co., died Sunday of a heart attack in Memorial Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived on Bayville Road in Locust Valley, L.I.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 12 The engagement of Miss Harriet Gillett Van Kennen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Fisher Van Kennen of Winnetka, Ill., to Charles Gogolak was announced tonight at a party at the home here of Mr. and Mrs. William Rockefeller. Mrs. Rockefeller is an aunt of the future bride.

I SPENT part of my August vacation on a Navy carrier in the Pacific," Keith Funston remarked last week to a luncheon guest. "Golly, I wanted to find out what those fellows were doing and you know what? They kept asking me for tips on the stock market.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (UPI) Dr. Hermann J. Muller of Indiana, University, winner of the Nobel Prize for his work in genetics, has urged that sperm banks from outstanding men, for use in artificial insemination, be begun immediately.

CAPETOWN, Sept. 12--Political observers considered it virtually a certainty today that Balthazar J. Vorster, Minister of Justice, Police and Prisons, would be elected Prime Minister of South Africa tomorrow to succeed Hendrik Verwoerd, who was assassinated last Tuesday.
In a new series of Longchamps ads, mixing metaphores is as simple as serving a chop-suey pizza.

Herbert Brownell Jr., Herman Badillo and Morris B. Abram will serve as co-chairmen of the citywide committee that will fight the efforts of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association to kill the civilian-dominated police review board.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) President Johnson announced today that he planned to reappoint Howard G. Gamser to another three-year term on the National Mediation Board.
Six men were sentenced to prison yesterday for their roles in the Mays Department Store swindle of 1964. All had pleaded guilty earlier this year.

UPTON, L. I., Sept. 12--The Atomic Energy Commission today announced it has signed the construction contract for the $12-million Tandem Van de Graaf accelerator at Brookhaven National Laboratory here.

Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange since 1951, announced yesterday that he would step down when his contract expired on Sept. 10, 1967. The an nouncement by the 55-yearold executive confirmed recurring rumors that he would relinquish the $125,000-a-year Big Board post.

A sweeping revision in the concept of the surviving corporation to result from the merger of Spartans Industries, Inc., and E.J. Korvette, Inc., has been agreed to by the two companies and the Federal Trade Commission.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 President Johnson welcomed as a "good sign" this evening the large turnout of voters in South Vietnam's election of a constituent assembly.
FRENCHMAN FLAT, Nev., Sept. 12 (UPI) Radiation was leaked into the atmosphere to day when the United States exploded an underground nuclear device with a maximum force of 20 kilotons.

AWESOME numbers of catch phrases have found thier way into the storehouse of football memorabilia during the last century, starting with the imperishable, "I'd die for dear old Rutgers." Among the many deathless lines that have endured over the years is the classic remark uttered by Andy Kerr of Colgate in 1932.
VILLAGE VANGUARD, 178 Seventh Avenue South. Thelonious Monk, pianist Jackie McLean, saxophonist.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 12 The Westchester County Board of Supervisors tonight refused to consider and probably killed a reapportionment plan submitted by its legislative commitee.
The Montreal Trust Company, receiver and manager of the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation, approved yesterday an offer for part of the receivables of the defunct Canadian finance company.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI) The State Department began today a campaign to discourage efforts to block trade by American concerns with the Soviet Union and Communist Eastern Europe.
After three years of demolition and reconstruction, the new Pennsylvania Station is beginning to emerge from behind builders' temporary walls.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Sept. 12 Dr. John Henry Martin resigned tonight as superintendent of schools in this city long torn by tensions arising from racial imbalance in its public school system.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 12 (AP) Lieut Col. Yakubu Gowon, head of Nigeria's military regime, today gave Nigerians a choice of four forms of government.

DETROIT, Sept. 12 Port authorities throughout the Great Lakes area have neglected the need for preserving the area's basic traffic and the United States fleet in favor of stimulating overseas traffic, Vice Adm. James A. Hirshfield of the Coast Guard, president of the Lake Carriers Association, charged today.

LONDON, Sept. 12 (AP) Eric Taylor, general manager and secretary of Sheffield Wednesday a leading British soccer team has been offered the position of executive secretary of the newly formed National Professional Soccer League of America.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 12--The large turnout of registered voters in South Vietnam's national election yesterday will force North Vietnam "to have second thoughts" about the war and "to adopt a wiser attitude," the South Vietnamese chief of state said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 Yields of new issues of both three-month and six-month Treasury, bills rose by more than of one per cent this week, to push Government borrowing costs to a record for the second successive week.

Pierre Salinger, former Presidential press secretary now on the promotion trail for his new book, "With Kennedy," stole a moment yesterday to murmur to his French-born wife, "If I ever go back into politics, dear, you are getting a look at what a campaign trip is like." The couple were on the sixth day of an 18-day scramble through 15, cities.

A backlog of unsolved problems remains, but the anger seems for the moment to have drained out of the system. SINGAPORE, Sept.13 (Reuters) Former Foreign Minister Subandrio of Indonesia will stand trial on Oct. 1, the Jakarta, radio reported today.
STAMFORD, N.Y., Sept. 12 Dr. Blanche M. Kelly, professor emeritus of English at the College of Mount St. Vincent in the Bronx, died in a hospital here today. She was 85 years old.
William Zeckendorf Sr. will be the guest speaker at the monthly luncheon meeting of the Young Men's Real Estate Association of New York today at noon in the 60 East Club, 60 East 42d Street.

MOSCOW, Sept. 12 (Reuters) The Red Guards have demanded that all "landlords, rich peasants and harmful and counterrevolutionary elements" leave Peking by Thursday to take up permanent residence in the country, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported today.
Dr. Emil J. Gumbel, adjunct professor of industrial engineering at Columbia University, died Saturday at Caledonian Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 75 years old and lived at 441 Ocean Avenue in Brooklyn.
Frank D. O'Connor predicted yesterday that his Liberal opponent, Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., would conduct a "filthy campaign" for Governor during the next eight week.

The world of electronics came up yesterday with a variety of items that are designed to speed up product ticketing and inventory controls, make life easier for busy executives and extend the reliability of computer tapes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI) Eleven states vote tomorrow biggest primary days of the year in elections testing the appeal of the Kennedy name, Republican chances for gubernatorial gains and shadowy "white backlash" senti ment.

Tight money, the object of much attention in Washington and throughout the business community in recent weeks, has not been as much or a deflating influence as economic observers had expected, according to a nationwide survey just made by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

A spokesman for Raytheon said last night that Mr. Koch was a contract employe of the Institute of Modern Languages, Inc., of Washington. He said this concern was a subcontractor in Raytheon's program of installing "Hawk" missiles in Saudi Arabia and training local personnel in handling them. He said that Mr. Koch had been engaged to teach English to Saudi Arabians in that program.

Soybean traders were caught with their estimates too low and their hopes too high after the close on Friday. Many of them apparently did not expect the Department of Agriculture crop estimate to be as high as 925,685,000 bushels.
The D.W.G. Cigar Corporation announced yesterday a modification of its earlier offer to stockholders to buy the outstanding shares of Wilson Brothers, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)--A group of engineers and scientists with long experience in aeronautics has recommemded testing a new concept in vertical take-off aircraft that uses "umbilical" lines to provide a supply of compressed air from the ground.

TRENTON, Sept. 12 New Jersey voters will nominate a Democratic candidate for United States Senator and both parties will choose candidates for the House in the state's 15 reapportioned Congressional districts in the primary elections tomorrow.

Harold Jones, solo flutist with the Symphony of the New World, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. He played sonatas by Marcello, Bach and Reinecke, Busser's Prelude and Scherzo, Taffanel's transcription of Chopin's Nocturne, Op. 15, No. 2, and Lennox Berkeley's Sonatina. He was accompanied by Alan Booth, pianist, in all the works except Bach's, which was for flute alone.

Even more than the survival of Nigeria as a nation is at stake in discussions now under way among leaders of the country's four regions. The decision taken at Lagos will affect in a major way the hopes for stability and orderly development over much of the rest of the new Africa.
Robert Hays Rosenberg, an architect known for his design of modern residences, died yesterday of a heart ailment in Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 28 East 13th Street.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 The Senate agreed today to vote late Wednesday afternoon on whether to end a filibuster against the Administration's civil rights bill.
PAPEETE, Tahiti, Sept. 12 President de Gaulle left French Polynesia this morning for Paris by way of the French island of Guadeloupe in the Caribbean.

CARMARTHEN, Wales, Sept. 12 (UPI) Brian Curvis of Wales scored an eighth-round technical knockout over Des Rea tonight and immediately agreed to meet Curtis Cokes in Dallas Nov. 7 for the World Boxing Association version of the welterweight title.
Production of steel by the nation's mills continued to rise last week. However, for the year to date it was still 3.3 per cent below the corresponding 1965 figure.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI) Marcel Rocca, head of the Institute of Modern Languages, said Mr. Koch had been hired as a $7,000-a-year employe for a trial period. He was supposed to go to Jidda, Saudi Arabia, to observe teacher training methods and eventually teach classes in English.

Shhh. Don't tell Gimbels, but a television drama is about to be filmed in Macy's. Production starts today on "Evening Primrose," a fantasy about a group of people who live secretly in a department store and come out at night.
The Morton Salt Company announced yesterday in Chicago the appointment of H. R. Stratford as president.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 Ralph Ginzburg, New York publisher under conviction for mailing obscene literature, made a part payment of $13,790 today toward $42,000 in fines imposed on him and his three publishing concerns.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 12 Vice President Humphrey reminded the nation's mining men today that their industries were forward multipliers capable of affecting growth and price structures "in a whole chain of manufacturing and consumer activities."
SMALL-GAME hunters in New York State killed more than 3.5 million game birds and mammals last year, according to a survey taken by the Conservation Department.
Commemorating the 75th anniversary of the founding in New York City of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, a new United States postage stamp went on sale here yesterday.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Sept. 12 The Gemini 11 astronauts rocketed into space today and caught and linked up with their target satellite on their first orbit. It was the first time a manned spacecraft had achieved rendezvous and docking in its first orbit.
LONDON, Sept. 11 Sibylla's, the newest of London's swinging, really super (pronounced soo-pah) discotheques, may soon have a New York branch.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 12 (AP) After decades in storage, some rare paintings of the Old West as it was almost 100 years ago have been placed on display here.
ROME, Sept. 12 (AP) Premier Aldo Moro called on West Germany and Austria today to help stamp out terrorist violence in Italy's troubled Alto Adige (South Tyrol).
Eisenhower College of Seneca Falls, N.Y., has elected John S.D. Eisenhower, son of former President Dwight D. Eisenhower, a trustee, it was announced here yesterday.

The boards of the Paramount Pictures Corporation and Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., held separate meetings last night, apparently to work out the final exchange ratio on the proposed merger between the two companies.
The executive committee of the New York County Democratic party designated Assemblyman Percy E. Sutton last night as its candidate for Borough President of Manhattan in the Nov. 8 election.

GRENADA, Miss., Sept. 12 A throng of angry whites wielding ax handles, pipes and chains surrounded two public schools that were integrated today and attacked Negroes who attempted to leave when classes were over.

It his always great news for jazz lovers when they learn that Mel Torme is back in town. He is among the few popular singers whose musicianship is superb, and whose instinct for what is good in popular music is on the button, not off by a half-beat or a half-note.

THE Open Team event that closed the Asbury Park Regional Championships Sunday night was won by Lester Sokolower of Baldwin, L.I., Martin Ginsberg of Atlantic Beach, L.I., Harry Stappenbeck of Uniondale, L. I., and Richard Budd of North Caldwell, N.J.
Trans World Airlines has readopted its old policy of charging passengers for inflight alcoholic drinks, excluding first-class passengers.
Knightly Manner, the good grass and distance campaigner owned by Mrs. Henry Obre, won the 1 5/8-mile Brighton Beach Handicap on the turf at Aqueduct yesterday for the second year in a row.
The spot rate on the British pound eased slightly in moderately active trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday.
