SREMSKA MITROVICA, Yu goslavia, Sept. 11 Something strange is going on in this city of 22,000 on the Sava River but it is difficult for a casual Sunday visitor to determine just what.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 12 A dispute that threatened earlier this summer to split the Greek Orthodox patriarchate of Antioch has been settled by compromise.
ROME, Sept. 12 (Reuters) The Vatican reassured the Roman Catholic Church's bishops today that they would not automatically be required to give up their dioceses on reaching the age of 75.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12-- The Los Angeles Dodgers won their fifth straight game tonight, and gained half a game in the National League pennant race with 18 to go, by defeating the New York Mets, 3-2.
The General Electric Company announced yesterday the appointment of Cecil S. Semple as marketing consultant for merchandising at its headquarters here.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 12 (AP) General of the Army Omar N. Bradley today married Mrs. Esther Dora Buhler, a Los Angeles screenwriter, at the San Diego County Courthouse. Superior Court Judge William Mahedy performed the ceremony.
The District Attorneys of two counties are investigating reports that a well-known harness driver was beaten by gamblers for refusing to fix a race at Roosevelt Raceway.
HOUSTON, Sept. 12 A Defense Department experiment carried out today by the Gemini 11 astronauts may lead to a method of inspecting unidentified satellites in orbit around the earth.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) Top-seeded Judy Tegart of Australia and Francoise Durr of France easily won their opening match in the Kenwood invitation women's doubles tournament today.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 12 F. Gardner Cox Jr. of Vil lanova, Pa., representing the Mantoloking (N.J.) Yacht Club, lost and then regained the lead today to win the first of five races for the national championship in the international 5.5-Meter Class.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 12 President Ferdinand Marcos of the Philippines will lead a movement to draft U Thant for a second term as Secretary General when the General Assembly of the United Nations opens.

Steve Lindell, one of Army's two sophomore quarterbacks, has earned the starting assignment for the Black Knights' opener against Kansas State at West Point Saturday. The other, Jim O'Toole, will undoubtedly see action against the Big Eight team that lost all of its 10 games last season.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. The Mayor of New York, who by tradition accuses the state of shortchanging his city, today accused the Federal Government of being a shortchanger, too.
JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 12 (AP) Gov. Paul B. Johnson Jr. vowed tonight that the law would be enforced and that "those who raise the sword of violence will be met by the sword of law enforcement."
The office space market in Manhattan is in "a very healthy condition" according to a survey by the Real Estate Board of New York.
RENO, Sept. 12 (UPI) A strong earthquake centered in the Sierra Nevada sent a rolling shock today over a wide area of Northern California and Nevada.
WHILE Paris couturiers seem to be encouraging women to tighten their belts and lengthen their skirts, American designers are concerned with what they consider more pressing fashion matters.
MOSCOW, Sept. 12 Powerful support has been voiced in the Communist party in favor of freely fluctuating prices in the year-old effort for economic and industrial reform.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Sept. 12 (Canadian Press) Auckland International Airport is leaving nothing to chance in reducing the hazard of sea birds to aircraft.
Four Greenwich Village residents have sued the city in an effort to halt New York University's plan to construct a 15-story library building on Washington Square South at West Broadway.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 Robert H. Shelton Jr. Imperial Wizard of the United Klans of America, faced a jury today that included three Negroes as he went on trial on a contempt of Congress charge.

Britain should come "very close" to equalizing her ratio of exports and imports with the United States within the next five years, Sir. Patrick Dean, British Ambassador to the United States, predicted here yesterday.
DETROIT, Sept. 12 Chevrolet displayed its new Camaro today with the hope that the sporty little car will compete successfully with the Ford Motor Company's popular Mustang.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 The Soviet Union is believed to have finally begun developing a rocket of 7.5-to-10-million pounds of thrust, enough to send men to the moon or past Mars, official sources said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept.12 (AP) President Johnson signed today the $1,005,842,000 military construction authorization bill but objected strongly to a provision for notifying Congress before a military base could be closed.

UPTON, Hass., Sept. 12 (AP) Bill Summers, an American League umpire from 1933 through 1959, died here today. He was 70 years old and lived here.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 12 Bishop Eugene Maxwell Frank and Mrs. Frank have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Frank, to Michael Pomerantz of Indianapolis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mihiel C. Pomerantz of New York.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 12 (UPI) Bob Rodgers slid home with a run on a disputed play in the eighth inning tonight to give the California Angels a 6-5 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

THE fourth annual New York Film Festival went into, orbit last night with a showing of Milos Forman's Czechoslovak film "Loves of a Blonde," to a capacity audience in Philharmonic Hall and a gala reception afterward in the grand promenade of the New York State Theater.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept 12 (AP) A Wayne Township policewoman who refused to take judo lessons with men in order to qualify for the force may still have to wrestle for her job. But she has received assurances her partners will be female.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 Ralph Forbes, a lieutenant in the American Nazi party, was fined $300, and his leader, George Lincoln Rockwell, won a postponement of a court hearing today on charges stemming from a march they staged Saturday in a South Side Negro district.

BOGALUSA, La., Sept. 12 (AP) Militant whites and Negroes brandished guns and glared at each other here today after a white man pointed a shotgun at a Negro man outside a desegregated junior high school.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 108.4 on Fri day from 108.3 on Thursday.
TRENTON, Sept. 12 Gov. Richard J. Hughes today nominated 20 judges to the State Superior Court and 22 judges to other courts in the state.
The first day of rehearsal for "Under the Weather," the collective title for Saul Bellow's tree one-acters, got off to a good start yesterday morning at the Cort Theater.
The fourth annual New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts opened last night before a capacity audience at Philharmonic Hall.
RONKONKOMA, L.I., Sept.12 An attempt to halve the loneliness of the long-distance commuter was begun here today on a stretch of the Long Island Rail Road.

PAWLING, N.Y., Sept. 12 R. William Hamlet, a retired assistant treasurer of the Mobil Oil Corporation, died today in New Milford (Conn.) Hospital. Mr. Hamlet, who was 77 years old, suffered a stroke Friday while playing golf at the Quaker Hill Country Club here. He had a home here and at 200 East 66th Street, New York.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 12 When Mel Massucco began his first year as Holy Cross football coach last season, his expectations were high. On the fifth day of practice Jack Lentz, the star quarterback, suffered a severe knee injury. That ruined the season before it began.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI) The House voted today to make the United States an active participant in two agreements intended to stimulate the flow of books, objects of art and other educational, scientific and cultural materials between countries.
Two major appointments were announced yesterday by the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 12--Arthur J. Goldberg, the United States representative to the United Nations, called today for the world's first space treaty as a matter of urgency.
The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor announced yesterday that it would activate its 16th employment center for longshore workers tomorrow morning at the Military Ocean Terminal, Bayonne, N.J.

TOKYO, Sept 12 Chinese Communist army units were called out to control a crowd of 100,000 people protesting the activities of the youthful Red Guards in Kweilin, the Newspaper Asahi reported today in a dispatch from its correspondent in Peking.
DETROIT, Sept. 12 (AP) The automobile industry, spurred by the public attention its new 1967-model cars are getting at preview time, is stepping up its output.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., the Liberal party's candidate for Governor, has an obvious personal motive in proposing a conference of all nominees for the purpose of limiting campaign expenditures. Since he does not have Governor Rockefeller's fortune and, unlike Mr. O'Connor, the Democratic choice, does not represent one of the major established parties, he would clearly have most to gain from a spending limit.

MWANZA, Tanzania, Sept.12 (Reuters) A two-man jury today found a Peace Corps teacher, William Haywood Kinsey, not guilty of having killed his wife. But under Tanzanian law a judge must make the final decision.
A Westec Corporation stockholder has brought suit in Federal Court here charging the company with overstating its profits so as to "bolster artificially" the price of the stock.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 12 The United States sent a record number of fighterbombers over North Vietnam yesterday, continuing its gradual increase of pressure.
LONDON, Sept. 12 (Reuters) The British Broadcasting Corporation took aim at American Westerns today and old cowboy movies and TV serials bit the dust.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 12 --Governor Rockefeller toured Suffolk County today searching for hands to shake and ran into occasional hostile questions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) Despite President Johnson's opposition, Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana said today he intended to press his attempt to put the Senate on record for substantial reductions of United States forces in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 Prof. Eric Goldman's resignation as Presidential envoy to the intellectual community forebodes an ugly era in the already unhappy relationship between Lyndon Johnson and the thinking men of America.

GRENADA, Miss. Sept. 12 (UPI) Negroes called off a protest march tonight when the state police asked them to disperse because of the ugly mood in the town. The police, the Negroes said, promised full protection for children tomorrow.

OSSINING, N.Y., Sept. 12 The home-club team of the professional, Gerry Schultheis, and Michael LaRosa won the Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association Westchester proamateur tournament by two strokes today by carding a net best-ball score of 29, 33 62 at the Pines Ridge Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 Two Jewish leaders denied today that President Johnson had in any way related United States support for Israel to the degree of support he found among American Jews for his policies in Vietnam.
VIENNA, Sept. 12 Pleasure seekers flocked to the Prater, Vienna's permanent fun fair, last week as the celebration of its 200th anniversary reached its peak.

MOSCOW, Sept. 12 The Soviet Union announced today that a United States citizen,' described as a former Roman Catholic priest, had requested political asylum in Moscow to take "an active part in the struggle against the injustice and cruelty of the Vietnamese war."

New York Medical College, officials said yesterday that they would close the operating rooms of the 1,000-bed Metropolitan Hospital, except for emergencies, on Oct. 1 unless the city provides $1.5-million for additional staff and equipment.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) A conference on water pollution problems of the Great Lakes and the surrounding states will be held in Chicago this Thursday and Friday, the Interior Department announced yesterday.
James A. Farley, the former United States Postmaster General, was elected president of the Little League Foundation yesterday. He succeeds Harry E. Humphreys Jr.
LONDON, Sept. 12 Prime Minister Wilson offered new proposals on Rhodesia today to the meeting of Commonwealth Prime Ministers in an attempt to avoid a walkout by African members.
The natural sequel to the successful election in South Vietnam on Sunday is to try to calculate what effect it may have on the efforts to bring about negotiations and an ultimate truce or peace.

MADRID, Sept. 13 (AP) Three Spanish intellectuals prominent for their anti-Government stand started a 30-day jail term today after having refused to pay court-levied fines for their part in an illegal assembly of students.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 12 (AP) A realtor was sentenced today to a year in jail and was fined $500 for conspiracy in the sale of a former Post Office garage to the city at a $143,000 profit after a realty firm held title for two minutes.
Canadian Breweries, Ltd., confirmed yesterday persistent reports that a recent attempt had been made to buy control, but added that the bid had been refused.
The Port of New York last month set two records. It broke the monthly collection record for import duties and it received more international passengers by ship and air than in any previous month.
Mayor Lindsay appointed four antipoverty officials yesterday.

Lawyers for Morton Sobell filed an affidavit from a handwriting expert yesterday that they said shows forgery in a piece of evidence used to convict Sobell and Julius and Ethel Rosenberg in 1951. They had been charged with conspiracy to commit espionage.
Miss Jennifer Erica Carolyn Gooch and William Randolph Hearst 2d were married yesterday in Our Lady's Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral by Msgr. Patrick V. Ahern.
The new school term got off to a generally smooth start throughout the city yesterday despite racial demonstrations outside five schools.
The American Stock Exchange made its broadest gains in more than three months yesterday as most stocks advanced in moderate trading.
ATHENS, Sept. 12 Former Premier George Papandreou, Greece's opposition leader, denied tonight any desire to end the monarchy in Greece.

GENESEO, N.Y., Sept. 12 Miss Sheila Elizabeth Welch, a member of the faculty of the Pittsford (N.Y.) Central School District, will be married next summer to John Winthrop Chanler, who is related to many families prominent in New York society.
The Johnson Administration has finally wriggled off the hook of its design that has put painful pressure on the nation's money markets and harmed its own economic objectives.
RESIDENT JOHNSON'S proposal to suspend the tax credit for investment for 16 months has caused many an executive to reach for the aspirin bottle in the last few days.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., Sept. 12 (AP) Nine oil companies that had been indicted on charges of price fixing in the sale of liquid asphalt to the state of Kansas offered today to withdraw pleas cf not guilty and to enter pleas of no contest.

A Coast Guard board of investigation began taking testimony yesterday from crewmen to ascertain the details of how the West German Liner Hanseatic caught fire here last Wednesday and the efficiency of fire-fighting measures.
Two executive appointments have been announced by James Conforti Jr., president of Conforti Eisele, Inc., building contractors.

San Francisco, and Chicago are working on an agreement to share the American Conservatory Theater. It had been announced Wednesday that the nonprofit repertory group was planning to set up shop in the former city
What triggers a cocoon to develop into a moth or butterfly? What spurs the fantastic development of an egg immediately after it is fertilized?
THIS satire is not just another saga of gaga. It clears the air for the contemporary underground novel, where humbug loses many wars with cant.
BONN Sept. 12 The vendetta between Yugoslav exile, terrorist and Government groups being waged in West Germany is becoming bloodier.
Stock prices rallied strongly yesterday in the sharpest and broadest one-day advance in 14 months.
Short-term interest rates moved up sharply yesterday, reflecting current tight money market conditions and the prospect of increased Treasury bill sales.

ACCRA, Ghana, Sept. 12 (UPI) The military regime announced today that it was dismissing Ghana's magistrates and judges, who were accused of being political appointees of the ousted President, Kwame Nkrumah.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Sept. 12 The two-lane road that winds out of Jerusalem is dotted Wednesday afternoons with the cars of government and parliamentary officials heading for Tel Aviv.
Small investment demand and a shortage of stock sent prices moderately upward yesterday o on the London Ssock Exchange.

LONDON, Sept. 12 A wide range of Sir Winston Churchill's personal papers and documents, some never before reproduced, will be published in facsimile portfolios with the biography of the late British statesman by his son, Randolph Churchill.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--President Johnson vetoed tonight fringe benefits worth $90million in life insurance coverage for Federal employes and members of Congress. He cited the bill as an example of the kind of spending he wants to stop in the fight on inflation.

There was more than a dazzling display of technical virtuosity in yesterday's historic sharpshooting feat by the Gemini 11 crew. Primarily it was a demonstration of the practicality of a maneuver that may well be crucial if the first Americans landed on the moon are to return safely to earth.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 12 Mr. and Mrs. Glenn McHugh have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen McHugh, to Gastone Mannozzi of Rome. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nello Mannozzi of Rome, where a Sept. 23 wedding is planned at the Greek Orthodox Church of Badia di San Nilo.
The teamster local that is being sued because of a 12-day wildcat strike of truckmen against United Parcel Service ordered its striking members yesterday to return to work tomorrow morning.

ATLANTA, Sept. 12 Nonviolent followers of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. struggled today for a foothold of influence in an Atlanta neighborhood that had been shaken by rioting the two previous nights.
DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 12 (UPI) Teacher strikes affecting 12,500 students at a twoyear college here and 5,000 schoolchildren in Traverse City, Mich., were settled today, six days after they began.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 Two 'Cabinet officers assured Congress today that the proposed suspension of tax incentives for the expansion of business investment in equipment and buildings was a temporary expedient to restrain inflationary pressures.

Three apprentices of the Sandy Hook Pilots Association have received commendations from The Council of American Master Mariners for helping in the rescue of the 39-man crew of the British tanker, the Chelwood Beacon, last Jan. 23.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 12 1 Ann Rockefeller Pierson, Governor Rockefeller's oldest daughter, and her husband, the Rev. Robert L. Pierson, appeared separately with their lawyers today in State Supreme Court here.

Eight additional charges of negligence were placed yesterday by the Coast Guard against Capt. Donald Baker, docking pilot of one of two tankers involved in the crash on June 16 off Staten Island that claimed 33 lives.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI)--President Johnson's popularity has slipped to the lowest level since he entered the White House, according to a nationwide public opinion survey released today.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 12 Finance Minister Pinhas Sapir made public today the three-year economic plan, adopted by the Cabinet yesterday, designed to put a brake on Israel's rapid economic growth.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)--Mrs. Mary Reed of Gaithersburg, Md., and Mrs. Donna Fales of New York upset the second-seeded South African team of Maryna Godwin and Esme Emanuel, 8-6, 6-8, 6-3, in the semi-finals of the Kenwood invitation women's tennis double tournament today.
A $25.2-million project to create more containership space at its marine terminal in Elizabeth, N.J., was announced yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.
OTTAWA, Sept. 13--British Columbia's Social Credit party, led by Premier W.A.C. Bennett, won its fifth consecutive general election yesterday.

This year will probably be a record one for the leasing of new office space in Manhattan, in the opinion of George L. Studley, vice president and director of Julien J. Studley, office leasing concern.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 13--The United States offered a compromise today to get Soviet approval for a treaty on space exploration. It dropped its demand that all space stations and vehicles on the moon or other celestial bodies must be "open at all times" for inspection visits.
THERE are few things of value given away these days, but a New York State small-game hunting license can be acquired if you meet the test.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 13 (AP) --Judge Florence E. Allen, the first woman to serve on the Common Pleas Court here, the Ohio Supreme Court and the Sixth United States Circuit Court of Appeals in Cincinnati, died last night at her home in Waite Hill. Judge Allen, who had been in ill health since she broke her hip last year, was 82 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- The United States Federal Reserve Board, the Bank of England and the central banks of nine other countries announced today a major expansion of the credits they are willing to grant each other to head off currency crises.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- Legislation giving the Government temporary power to regulate the interest rates paid to savers by savings and loan associations and banks was approved unanimously today by the Senate Banking Committee.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- The House Commerce Committee abruptly shelved a so-called "truth in packaging" bill today. The vote was 12 to 7.
LONDON, Sept. 13--A large majority of Commonwealth members rejected today as inadequate Prime Minister Wilson's latest plan to end the rebellion in Rhodesia.

LORD luv a duck if McGregor-Doniger's "Brolly Male" hasn't gone and got himself a "Brolly Dolly." It all came about as a result of the concern's success with its "Brolly Male" line, a swinging sportswear group designed for the adventurous man from, roughly, 18 to 25.
A gala cocktail party benefiting the Hospitality Committee for United Nations Delegations will be held on Tuesday at Bloomingdale's, Lexington Avenue and 59th Street.
Directors of the Heli-Coil Corporation authorized yesterday in Danbury, Conn., a 100 per cent stock dividend, to be preceded by an increase in the quarterly dividend.

Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Joseph McCarthy of 399 East 72d Street have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Claire Anne McCarthy, to Craig Peterson. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Peterson of Evanston, Ill.

HAYNEVILLE, Ala., Sept. 13 (AP)--A Lowndes County grand jury composed of 11 Negroes and seven white men refused today to return a new indictment against a man accused of shooting a civil rights worker.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 13--Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. McManus have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann McManus, to Anton B. Deiters, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Dieters of Wassenaar, the Netherlands.
Maj. Gen. Leon B. Kromer, U.S.A., retired, former Chief of Cavalry, died Sept. 6 in a nursing home in Germantown, Md. His age was 90.
Stock prices continued to advance yesterday, but the gains were well below those scored in Monday's sweeping rally.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- The United States and the Phil ippines will sign an agreement on Friday to reduce to 25 years the remaining period of the United States right to its Philippine bases.

Theodore Kheel and A. Philip Randolph will be part of a fiveman team that will head a committee organized to fight the efforts of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association to block the civilian-controlled review board.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (UPI)-- The Atlanta Braves smashed 14 hits, including four homers, one triple and four doubles, today and routed the Chicago Cubs, 10-2, for their 12th victory in the last 13 games.
The Lindsay administration has under consideration a drastic new program to force more commuters to use public transportation instead of their own cars.
HOUSTON, Sept. 13--Willie Stargell hit a three-run homer and Gene Alley got four hits tonight to lead the second-place Pittsburgh Pirates to a 9-3 victory over the Houston Astros.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 13-- Bruce Rose of Sydney, Australia, won the first race today in the International Dragon Class Association series off Newport for the trophy of the EnglishSpeaking Union.

GROTON, Conn., Sept. 13 (UPI)--Frank C. Carpinella, a New Haven Republican town Committee member and real estate broker, was arrested early today and charged with shooting a man to death on a lonely road in Ledyard.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- The Budget Bureau has ordered a sharp cutback in paid overtime for Federal employes as part of the Administration's program to curb inflationary spending.
GRENADA, Miss., Sept. 13-- After another warning of violence in connection with school integration, the Mississippi State Highway Patrol restored order here this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- The Justice Department brought suit today to require officials in Grenada, Miss., to protect Negro children from whites who are opposing school integration there.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 13--The Special Committee of 33 will tell the General Assembly that the task of finding an agreed-upon formula for the authorization and financing of future peace-keeping operations was too much for it.

The Federal Reserve Board, now dominated by "new" economists, deserves recognition for helping to convince the Johnson Administration to employ fiscal policy in counter ing inflation. Many factors-- economic and political--contributed to the President's decision to suspend incentives for stimulating business spending.

The Lindsay administration formally asked the state yesterday to substitute the proposed Cross-Brooklyn Expressway for the $240-million Bushwick Expressway in the New York area's Interstate Highway System.
HERMIONE GINGOLD knelt in the blue and white bedroom of her East Side penthouse and fished out a hat from under the bed.
Sales of new cars, which had risen strongly near the end of August, fell back again in the first 10 days of September, the four domestic manufacturers reported yesterday.
IN the second race of the Canadian-American Chal lenge Cup series, to be run at Bridgehampton, L.I., on Sunday, the favorite will be John Surtees of England in a LolaChevrolet.

MUCH the nicest thing to happen on television last night was Patricia Harty, a young lady of such totally becoming naturalness and winning appeal that she made a viewer more aware of what was right than wrong with the National Broadcasting Company's new comedy series, "Occasional Wife."

Federal Judge Richard H. Levet ruled yesterday that a three-judge court would be convened next week to consider whether a temporary restraining order should be issued against the merger of the Pennsylvania and New York Central railroads.
Bond prices tended to stabilize yesterday, closing little changed for the day after a series of gains that stretched back to Aug. 30.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13-- An Appellate Court was asked here today to modify Ralph Ginzburg's five-year prison sentence on the ground that it had been imposed "arbitrarily" by a lower court.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 (AP)--Bernard Friedman, a mathematics professor at the University of California, since 1955 and an authority on mathematics applications in physics and engineering, died today at Children's Hospital. Professor Friedman, who was 51 years old, had been ill with cancer for several months.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 (UPI)--Herman Franks, the manager of the San Francisco Giants, received a new contract today that included a pay raise.

Peter J. Brennan, president of the Building and Construction Trades Council of Greater New York, accused Mayor Lindsay today of having wrongly implied that the union leader had avoided a hearing on discrimination in hiring practices.
In a dull trading day for most other commodities, soybean futures dropped the 10cents-a-bushel limit once again in early trading yesterday.
Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., said yesterday that it had bought an additional 108,427 shares of Paramount Pictures Corporation common stock.

TOKYO, Sept. 13--A former Japanese Foreign Minister now in Peking has stated that problems of "adjustment" seem to have arisen between the Chinese Communist party and the youthful Red Guard movement, but that the entire country is being "solidified" under Chairman Mao Tse-tung.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- President Johnson let it be known today that the Administration's pleasure with a decline in farm prices last spring has given way, in this political autumn, to even greater plea sure with their recent rapid rise.

Plans to divide the assets of the California Texas Oil Corporation in Europe between the two parent companies-- Texaco, Inc., and the Standard Oil Company of California-- have reached an advanced stage of negotiations.
TOKYO, Sept. 13 (Reuters) --Delegates from development banks in 15 Asian countries met here today to begin three days of meetings to discuss the financing of economic development in the region.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 13 --There may be a few football coaches around who believe that "it matters not whether you win or lose." But Fred Dunlap, in his second year as head coach at Lehigh, is not one of them.

NEW PALTZ, N.Y., Sept. 13 (UPI)--Police had their first lead today in the theft of the $35,000 jeweled crown of the former heavyweight boxing champion, Floyd Patterson, when they recovered the car used by the burglars.

TOKYO, Sept. 13--Unobserved by the milling throngs nearby in the busy Japanese version of Wall Street, Shinto priests chanting prayers and hearty construction workers drinking sake (rice wine) staged a traditional ceremony today in marking the completion of the steel framework for Emperor Hirohito's new $30million palace.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP)--President Johnson told Peace Corps volunteers today he hoped to see a time when "some form of voluntary service to the community and the nation and the world is as common in America as going to school, when no man has truly lived who only serves himself."
The calves and cubs of Wall Street, who hope to be tomorrow's bulls and bears, devoted part of their lunch times yesterday to witnessing an exhibition of table tennis in 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza.
Assemblyman Percy E. Sutton was elected Manhattan Borough President yesterday by the unanimous vote of the eight members of the City Council from the borough.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- The Senate Education subcommittee approved a bill today calling for the expenditure of $4.4-billion over a three-year period for higher education, an increase of more than a billion over the amount requested by President Johnson.
While a number of death knells have been sounded for small independent retailers, many of these merchants are remaining very much alive by participating in cooperative buying organizations.

BOSTON, Wednesday, Sept. 14--Edward J. McCormack, former State Attorney General, held off a challenge by Kenneth P. O'Donnell, to win the Democratic nomination for Governor yesterday in the Massachusetts primary.
Refined senses and plenty of patience were necessary to get anything out of the long program of avant-garde music by James Tenney, Max Neuhaus and Jackson MacLow last night at Town Hall.
The Federal Aviation Agency has acquired a Lear Jet Model 24 to be used by agency pilots on familiarization flights. The aircraft will be based at the agency's Oklahoma City aeronautical center.
SAIGON, Sept. 13 (Reuters) --An American infantryman was shot to death in central Saigon today by another United States soldier he had seriously wounded, an American spokesman said.

ATLANTA, Sept. 13 (UPI)-- A 42-year-old tree-trimmer who has a seven-page police record was charged today with the slaying of a 16-year-old Negro boy that touched off three nights of racial violence here.

Members of the City Council yesterday picked up the checks for $1,000 in additional expense alloments, voted last month, and Councilman Woodward Kingham, Republican of Manhattan, promptly turned his over to the New York Public Library.
Special Committee on Peacekeeping Operations--Approved report to General Assembly.

The adoption of a liberalized code of motion-picture ethics, which would provide for a limited type of film classification, seemed virtually assured here yesterday following a meeting of the board of directors of the Motion Picture Association of America.
WHILE the bears have clawed the averages back to market lows of January, 1964, leading stocks have been even harder hit.
EVEN the most avid hunter or fisherwoman must stay at home sometimes.

NEW CANAAN, Sept. 13-- Artists, from Fairfield County will take to the sidewalks on Saturday and Sunday for the annual New Canaan Outdoor Art Show, Oils, pastels, ceramics and other works will be made on the spot during the exhibition, which is being sponsored by the New Canaan Chamber of Commerce. On view will be 575 entries, largest number since the show began 11 years ago.

MAINBOCHER, a couturier who has become a legend in his own time, is a specialist in fashions that simmer but never boil. Mr. Bocher knows enough about cooking to appreciate that flavor improves with time.
HARTFORD, Sept. 13--Gov. John N. Dempsey ordered an investigation today into the reported dumping of 10,000 gallons of crude oil into Long Island Sound near Old Saybrook.
Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., who was a Deputy Mayor in the administration of Robert F. Wagner, announced yesterday that he would work for the re-election of Governor Rockefeller.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13-- Amendments to lessen businessmen's opposition to the Administration's anti-inflation measure were suggested today by Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.
